51080001.about: the energy challenge. natural fuels. introduction to renewable energy. solar , wind and geothermal energy, river currents, seas andoceans. photo voltaic use of solar energy. energy conversion: thermodynamics of energy conversion, heat engines, work cycles, thermal efficiency, problems in planning the energy sector. fuel cells: what is a battery. thermodynamics and kinetic principles, the difference between primary and secondary batteries, definition and mode of operation of fuel cells. electric vehicles battery vs. stationary batteries applications, cost vs. benefit. pv: principles of photovoltaic cells: light harvesting, charge transfer, thermodynami c limit, electronic 1st, 2nd and 3rd configuratons of device, manostructures and generation of pvs. bio-fuels: harvesting energy from biochemical reactions, biofuels feedstock, ethanol production, biodiesel, oil sources.
51080001.name: Technologies for Clean Energy

51080002.about: The seminar will consider several clean energy technologies and discuss barriers for their realization. The participants will experience in gathering relevant information and its critical analysis, discuss the problems' scale, and options for sustainable energy future. Active participation in mandatory.
51080002.name: Seminar in Global and National Energy Challenges

51080003.about: profitability analysis vs. cost-benefit. competitive and uncompetitive markets. dynamic efficiency and sustaianble development. transition to renewable energy sources. benefits and costs at different times, present and future values,the value rate of return to use. local and global air pollution, methods to determine the optimal level of air pollution, goverment orders, taxes, subsidies, trade in air pollution quotas. assigning financial value to air pollution, cvm, the use of questionnaires and surveys for assigning financial value. hedonistic prices - hpm. health production function, the value of human life, the value of a disease. benefits of future  generations. benefits and costs of different groups. benefit transfer. costs of energy shortages. forecasting energy prices. expected income forecasts, feasibility of investment in various facilities. electricity rates, uncertainty.
51080003.name: Economy and Management of Energy Systems

51080005.about:
THE COURSE IS INTRODUCTORY TO THE SOLAR ENERGY FIELD AND GIVES A BROAD OVERVIEW OF THE PHYSICS AND THERMODYNAMICS FOR SOLAR ENERGY UTILIZATION AND HARVESTING MECHANISMS. TOPICS: SOLAR RADIATION, THERMODYNAMICS OF SOLAR ENERGY, PHOTOVOLTAICS, SOLAR THERMAL, ENERGYSTORAGE, RESEARCH AND NEW CONCEPTS.
  LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL KNOW::
 1. ABILITY TO APPLY MATHEMATICS, SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING PRINCIPLES FOR SOLAR ENERGY APPLICATIONS.
 2. ABILITY TO DESIGN AND CONDUCT EXPERIMENTS, ANALYZE AND INTERPRET DATA RELATED TO SOLAR ENERGY RADIATION. 3. UNDERSTAND AND ANALYZE SOLAR ENERGY HARVESTING SYSTEMS (PVS, CSP AND MORE).
 4 . UNDERSTAND THE ADVANTAGES AND LIMITATIONS OF EXISTING SOLAR ENERGY CONVERSION MECHANISMS.
 5. UNDERSTAND PRCTICAL CONSIDERATIONS OF SOLAR SYSTEMS. 
 6. ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE OF EXISTING RESEARCH ON SOLAR ENERGY.
51080005.name: Solar and Photovoltaic Energy

51080009.about: the topics of the course are according to the research area and expertise of the lecturer. sylabus will be determined by the lecturer,with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the beginning of the semester when the course is taught.
51080009.name: Selected Topics in Energy 1

52080001.about: Review of applications in ocean engineering indicating basic engineering aspects, theoretical background, assumptions, design practice: marine vehicles, floating structures, seabed mounted structures, breakwaters, subsea pipelines, flexible structures for aquaculture.  characteristics of the marine environment hydrostatic pressure, waves, currents and sand transport.  design practice guides and standards. learning outcomes: the student will be familiar with: a variety of applications of ocean engineering, characteristics of the marine environment in aspects of design, design principles in ocean engineering, structural philosophy of thin shell structure s for marine vessels and floating platforms.  the student will be familiar with the theories and practical engineering methods for design in marine environment and their underlying assumptions.
52080001.name: Introduction to Ocean Engineering

61070006.about: This course explores the behavioral foundations of communication technology and the information sciences, and the ways in which theories and methods from the behavioral sciences play a role in understanding people's use of, access to and interactions with information and communication technologies. Multiple levels of analysis-individual, small group and larger collectives - will be included, along with multiple disciplinary perspectives. Course topics will include: human perception and cognition, cognitive perspectives ondesign, attention and memory, psychological theories of language use and self-presentation in computer-mediated communication, socia l psychological perspectives on coordination and group work, social science theories of social ties and relationships, user motivation, ppersuasion and more. The course will also provide a high-level view of methodologies used in the behaviroal and social sciences.
61070006.name: Physchological and Social Aspects of Technology

61070009.about: Human-Computer Interaction (HCI) and design theory and techniques. Methods for designing, prototyping and evaluating user interfaces to computing applications. Human capabilities, interface technology, interface design methods, prototyping tools, and interface valuation tools and techniques. All methods and techniques are learned while completing while completing a significat team project. Learning Outcomes: at the completionn of the course, students will be able to design, prototype and evaluate user interfaces for computer applications. Prerequisites.corequisites prerequisite: Students are expected to have previously taken a course in programming, de sign, or psychology, or should have equivalent professional experience in one of these area.
61070009.name: Human-Computer Interface and Design

61070016.about: This course covers basic design principles: Secrecy, privacy, Intgrity, authenticity. Basic cryptology. Protocols for access. Control: One-time paswords, challenge-response protocols. EKE. Operating system security: Linux security and access control models, secure coding, trusted computing, disk encryption. Protection in communication networkds: Viruses and wworms, firewalls, IPSc.SSL.TLS, intrusion detection, wireless LAN security. Privacy on the Internet. Assignments and projects will be tailored to the context of the student's degree objective. Learning Outomes: At the completion of this course, students will be able to understand principles of comp uter system security and incorporate approaches for risk managment and best practices.
61070016.name: Security and Privacy Concepts

61070023.about: THIS COURSE INTRODUCES THE TECHNICAL COMPONENTS OF MOBILE HEALTH SYSTEMS (INCLUDING SENSING, DATA ANALYIS, USER INTERFACE DESIGN, EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN, DATA INTEROPERABILITY AND PRIVACY AND SECURITY MECHANISMS) AND DEVELOPS AND UNDERSTANDING FOR THE SOFTWARE STRUCTURES AND TECHNIQUES USED TO CREATE NOVEL AND EFFECTIVE MOBILE HEALTH APPLICATIONS.UPON SUCCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS COURSE, STUDENTS WILL HAVE A BROAD AS WELL AS IN-DEPTH PICTURE OF THE STATE-OF-ART OF HEALTH AND HEALTHCARE TECHNOLOGIES.
61070023.name: Health Technology, Data and Systems

61070027.about: This course aims to bridge the gap between academic studies of computer science and production software engineering. The course provides a fast-paced introduction to key tools and techniques that can facilitate the bilding of prototypes and actual working systems. It introduces technologies for building Web applications and mobile applications, systems for effective storage of data, and toolsthat support and ease code writing, such as distributed version-control systems, editors and debuggers. Learning Outcomes: Upon successful completion of this course, students will have an understanding of the principles and practice of the software tools and syste ms available and needed to create health technology solutions and enterprises.
61070027.name: Startup Systems Design and Engineering

61070028.about: Learn and apply key concedpts of modeling, analysis and validation from machine learning, data mining and signal processing to analyze and extract meaning from data. Implement algorithms and perform experiments on images, text, audio and mobile sensor measurements. Learning Outcomes: Upon successful completion of this course, student will have gained working knowledge of supervised and unsupervised learning techniques inclding classfication, regression, clustering, feature selection and dimenstionality reducation.
61070028.name: Applied Machine Learning

61070029.about: the goal of computer vision is to compute properties of the three - dimensional world from digital images. problems in this field include reconstructing the 3d shape of an environment, determining how things are moving and recognizing people and objects and theiractivities, all through analysis of images and videos. an introduction to computer vision, with topics including image formation, feature detection, motion estimation, image mosaics, 3d shape reconstruction and object and face detection and recognition. applications of these techniques include building 3 maps, creating virtual characters, organizing photo and video databases, human computer in teraction, video surveillance, automatic vehicle navigation and mobile computer vision. this is a project-based course, in which students will implement several computer vision algorithms throughout the semester. assignments and projects will be tailored to the context of the student's degree objective. learning outcomes: upon successful completion of this course, student's will have understood the principles and amassed practical experience in implementing computer vision algorithms.
61070029.name: Introduction to Computer Vision

61070044.about: the course covers the tools needed to handle data-science tasks, focusing on problem formulation, data preparation and cleaning, data modeling, implementation of analysis tasks and presentation. the following methods and topics are taught: data preparation: sampling methods, similarity join, record linkage, locality sensitve hashing (lsh). data modeling: binning, non-linear transformation, domain-knowledge feature extraction, handling a noisy environment. model selection and evaluation: ranking evaluation (auc, aclc), classification (lift, accuracy, recall, precision, f-score), density estimation (mean absolute error, mean squared error, cross entropy. log likelihood). causality vs. correlation. supervised and unsupervised learning methods: naive bayes, linear regression, logistic regression, decision tree, k-nearest neighbors, linear hyperplane,random forests, svm, non-linear svm, processing data streams: stochastic gradient descent (sgd), sampling and filtering data streams, bloom filter, flajolet-martin algorithm, moments and the ams method, dgim method. pagerang for links analysis. community detection in social networks: girvan-newsman algorithm, spectral clustering, counting t
61070044.name: Data Science in the Wild

61070046.about: the reduction in the cost of storing and manipulating information has led organizations to capture increasing amounts of information about individual behavior. new trade-offs have emerged for parties involved with privacy-enhancing or intrusive technologies: individuals want to avoid the misuse of the information they pass along to others, but they also want to share enough information to achieve satisfactory interactions. organizations want to know more about the parties with which they interact, but they do not want to alienate them with policies deemed as intrusive. we are interested in finding that point where we can satisfy most of these needs. pr ivacy is a complex and multi-faceted concept. this course combines technical, economic, legal and policy perspectives to present a holistic view of its role and value in the digital age. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, students will: 1. understand the technological aspects of privacy in a pro-business environment. 2. grasp the privacy concerns involved in the internet, wireless communications and computer matching, tracking techniques and data mining, privacy enhancing technologies and anonymous protocols. 3.understand t
61070046.name: Privacy in the Digital Age

61070049.about:
this studio practicum helps students learn about and develop product management skills by putting those skills immediately to use in the context of their startup products. these skills include planning for production and life cycle management, documentation and planning changes and upgrades.
  learning outcomes:
 at the end of this course, students will have developed working knowledge of product management they can put to use after graduation. they will be able to: 1. plan a product to facilitate its life cycle. 2. plan product upgrades 3. document product changes and upgrades. 4. assess the impact of changes and upgrades.
61070049.name: Product Management

61070050.about:
in the specialization project, students work singly or in small groups to engage in research and development activity, building deep expertise in one technical area, and providing a deep understanding of innovation in that area. student teams work with faculty and industry advisors to understand the scope of a problem, then address it via new technological innovation. projects can use different analysis, user research, hci and more. in general, the first semester students take the course could be spent doing more formative, explorative work that exposes and explores needs or pursues some lower-level techniques for an already-understood need. in second semester, students would typically either move towards a more concrete implementation or explore other alternatives, though it may still involve formative work. the second semester must involve implementation.building of some technology. each project is accompanied by two advisors, primary and secondary faculty advisors, and a potential industry advisor. 
learning outcomes: 1. developing technical innovation via engagement in research activities. 2. working and solving open-ended problems. 3. team coordination and work.
61070050.name: Independent Research - a

61070051.about:
In the specialization project, students work singly or in small groups to engage in research and development activity, building deep expertise in one technical area, and providing a deep understanding of innovation in that area. student teams work with faculty and industry advisors to understand the scope of a problem, then address it via new technological innovation. projects can use different methodologies: building.engineering machine learning, algorithms, data analysis, user research, hci and more. in general, the first semester students take the course could be spent doing more formative, explorative work that exposes and explores needs, or pursue  some lower-level techniques for an already-understood need. in the second semester, students would typically either move towards amore concrete implementation or explore other alternatives, though it may still involve formative work. the second semester must involve implementation.building of some technology. each project is accompanied by two advisors, a primary and a secondary advisor, and a potential industry advisor. 
learning outcomes: 1.developing technical innovation via engagement in research activities. 2. worknig and solv
61070051.name: Independent Research - B

61070052.about:
in the specialization course, students work singly or in small groups to engage in research and development activity, building deepexpertise in one technological area, and providing a deep understanding of innovation in that area. student teams work with facultyand industry advisors to understand the scope of a problem, then address it via new technological innovation. projects can use different methodologies: building.engineering, machine learning, algorithms, data analysis, user research, hci and more. in general, accompanied by two advisors, a primary and a secondary faculty advisor, and a potential industry advisor. 
learning outcomes: 1. develop ing technical innovation via engage in research activities. 2. working and solving open-ended problems. 3. team coordination and work.
61070052.name: Independent Research - C

61070053.about:
company challenges are the first part of the project-driven curriculum at jacobs, and are an integral part of the education of learning by building. in the company challenges, students respond to challenges posed by leading startups, companies, and organizations in nyc, and engage in a group to deliver technology solutions and work together in cross-campus teams that include students from multiple programs and specialization. the teams build real prototypes and technology, develop business plans to tackle the challenge and demonstrate their work to the organization at the end of the semester. company challenges go beyond a problem to solve or work to b e done--they require a thought provoking idea or challenge posed by the company that gives students the freedom to explore different paths toward breakthrough ideas and prototypes. 
learning outcomes:
 in this project, students learn how to address a real-world problem. after the project, they will be able to:
 1. communicate and work in a cross- disciplinary team.
 2. generate and assess solution ideas. 3. develop prototype technology.
 4. define a business plan
61070053.name: Project - Company Challenges

61070054.about:
in this project-based course, teams of students build a startup from the ground up, developing a fully-functional prototype that can be shared with others, tested with users and is at the level where it can be leveraged as a launching pad for future endeavors. the course allows students to develop an idea, product and pitch, and learn how to create and tell a compelling startup story and testtheir technology with users. during this class, students work closely with practitioners and users throughout the tech world. students participate in studio sprints and weekly studio and studio sessions, with assistance from studio leads. studio leads are active t echnical managers, entrepreneurs and product managers in nyc that act as scrum masters for a cohort of startup studio teams. these advisors provide practical feedback and instruction, encourage weekly progress and help address any blockers or risks that students are facing. teams found true startups, with operating procedures, deliverables, milestones. 
learning goals: 1. learning how to address a real-world problem
 2. working in a cross-disciplinary team
 3. developing and prototyping technology.
61070054.name: Project - Startup Studio

61070055.about:
this is independent work supervised by either a faculty member at jacobs, cornell tech, technion or cornell, or supervised by a technical expert. academic supervision is provided by the program director or another faculty member. tasks could range from studying theoretical material, doing a small-scale project, learning skills by taking part in a larger project or performing an experiment, etc.
 learning outcomes vary depending on the type of task, but they include: 
at the end of the course, the student will
 - be able to learn material and.or skills on his.her own 
- be able to communicate that material to the supervisor 
- have attained new knowledg e and.or skills.
61070055.name: Independent Research 1

61070056.about:
this is independent work supervised by either a faculty member at jacobs, cornell tech, technion or cornell, or supervised by a technical expert. academic supervision is provided by the program director or another faculty member. tasks could range from studying theoretical material, doing a small-scale project, learning skills by taking part in a larger project or performing an experiment, etc.
 learning outcomes vary depending on the type of task, but they include:
 at the end of the course, the student will
 - be able to learn material and.or skills on his.her own
 - be able to communicate that material to the supervisor
 - have attained new knowledg e and.or skills.
61070056.name: Independent Research 2

61070062.about:
this course looks at several ways of studying connective media, from different perspectives such as computer-mediated communication, theories from sociology and ethnographic methods. through studying these theories, students learn how to approach their own research projects and how to study particular characteristics of online social media. research projects will be done in pairs or groups ofthree and address targeted aspects of behavior around connective media, design the study of on the theories and methods taught. from the course, students should be able to independently conduct an empirical study of social media characteristics in relation to mobi le, desktop and mixed media. the course will consist of essays, smaller assignments and a large research project. lectures will be based on a set of relevant academic readings with discussion.
 learning outcomes:
 at end of the course, the student will
 - be ableto apply existing theories from social science to the design of experiments
 - be able to plan experiments that validate or refute a hypothesis
 - have mastery of the regulations and other considerations in experiments with humans
61070062.name: Usability and User Experience Research

61070065.about:
this is an introductory course in cryptography. a key aspect of the course will be implementing cryptographic schemes, as well as showing how to break poorly designed or implemented schemes. will be on fundamental notions and contruction with proofs of security based on precise definitions and assumptions. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will: have acquired a basic understanding of the central elements of cryptography. 2. know and understand how cryptographic techniques are used to establish security. 3. be able to identify different approaches to quantifying security
 4. be able to implement suitable cryptographic algothims wit hin broader projects.
61070065.name: Cryptography

61070068.about:
this course is a comprehensive introduction to the key aspects of new product development and product management that will provide a helpful perspective for technologists working in cross-functional teams with business leaders in the marketing, product, finance, legal and business development disciplines. the course focuses both on concepts frameworks utilizing "solutions architecture" while working on cross-functional teams in both agile and waterfall development environments.
 the course will also discuss the development process of an "intellectual property suite" and its importance in the new product development process and relevance to the competit ive landscape.
 topics covered will include definition of the market, sales and distribution, competition, business development, product management and milestone-based performance tracking.
learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course, the student will
 - have anunderstanding of key business disciplines, enabling him.her to work in a cross-functional team environment leading to the successful launch of new products
 - have acquired an overview of new product development and frameworks that will all technologists to successfully
61070068.name: Business for Tech

61070069.about:
this course covers algorithms and computational tools for solving optimization problems with the goal of providing decision-supportfor business intelligence. the course will cover the fundamentals of linear, integer and nonlinear optimization. 
 it emphasizes optimization as a large-scale comuptational tool, and shows how to link programming languages with optimization software to develop industrial-strength decision-support systems. 
students will be shown how to incorporate uncertainty into optimization problems. 
the course covers a variety of modern applications, including pricing and marketing for e-commerce, ad auctions on the web, and online ri de-sharing. 
learning outcomes:  at the end of the course the student will: 1. understand the various optimization methods currently used. 2. be able to apply the methods learned in class to practical cases
61070069.name: Optimization Methods

61070070.about: this hands-on course will prepare you to be future innovators by teaching you the human-centered design methodology known as "design thinking" that was made famous by david kelley, founder of ideo, and the standord d.school. you will be part of a cross-disciplinary team where you will be immersed in the entire design thiking cycle: empathize, define, ideate,prototype and test. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will: 1. have a firm grounding in the history and philosopy of the design thinking movement. 2. have experience working on a team designing an innovative product. 3. be able to prototype and test a product, bringing the idea  of a product into reality
61070070.name: Design Thinking

61070610.about:
this course constitutes an introduction to natural language processing (nlp), the goal of which is to enable computers to use humanlanguages as input, output or both. nlp is at the heart of many of today's most exciting technological achievements, including machine translation, automatic conversational assistants and internet search. possible topics include summarization, machine translation, sentiment analysis and information extraction as well as methods for handling the underlying phenomena (e.g., syntatic analysis, word sense disambiguation, and discourse analysis).
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course, the student will be able to
 - use models of language in computer programs
 - analyze potential algorithms in terms of their effectiveness
 - use standard approaches in building computer programs.
61070610.name: Natural Language Processing

61080005.about:
the goal of this course is to help students deepen their theoretical and historical perspective on social change, and to creativelyenvision various alternatives for the relationship between social change and technology. we will read a range of revolutionary thinkers - including, but not limited to: karl marx, friedrich engels, antonio gramsci, stuart hall, frantz fanon, mohandas k. gandhi and paulo freire. we will study their theories of revolution, the underlying tension within the division of labor in society, and discuss the role that technology can play in forming and reforming social relations. we will use this as a lens to reflect both upon exis ting technology and the underlying relations that create and sustain it, as well as to envision new technological possibilities supported by (and supporting) alternative forms of social organization. coursework will consist of significant reading, reading reflections, speculative design exercises and final course project.
 learning outcomes:
 the goal of this course is to help students deepentheir theoretical and historical perspective on social change, and to creatively envision various alternatives for the relationshipbetween soci
61080005.name: Revolutionary Technologies

61080006.about:
rerequisites:
 intermediate programming ability in java or c: experience programming a user interface you must be in the final yearof your program description augmented and virtual reality technologies and applications are becoming increasingly popular. this course presents an introduction to this exciting area, with an emphasis on designing and developing virtual and augmented reality applications. the course will cover the history of the area, hardware technologies involved, interaction techniques, design guidelines, evaluation methods, and specific application areas.
 learning outcomes:
 1. understanding aand prespective on the vr.ar landscape, pas t, present and future. 
 2. undeerstanding of fundamental computer vision, computer graphics and human-computer interaction techniques related to r.ar.
 3. insights to key application areas for vr.ar.
 4. the ability to design and implement vr.ar experiences.
61080006.name: Virtual and Augmented Reality

61080007.about:
this workshop-based service learning course will engage students in participatory design projects that seek to use technology to improve education and community services in new york city. students will be paired with individuals and organizations working on roosevelt island and elsewhere in the city and will work together to learn and apply user-centered and participatory design methodologiesto address important challenges facing the city and its inhabitants. potential collaborators include school teachers, civic educators, student teams, librarians, healthcare providers, and government agencies. based in part on their selected projects, students will  be exposed to relevant theories and perspectives impacting the modern city - such as migration, race, gender, sex and disability. the project will result in a set of design prototypes and speculative visions that collectively re-assess and re-imagine the role oftechnology in everyday urban lives. this course may require evening meetings to accommodate community partners and collaborators. 
learning outcomes:
 students will learn to creatively identify and envision new technological possibilities serving their partner organizations
61080007.name: Remaking Tyhe City

61080010.about: product studio is the foundational studio course for product development at cornell tech. students form semester-long teams and select a "how might we" question posed by a company. during the semester students learn the basics of product development so they can apply the knowledge and skills from their degree program: identifying impactful problems to solve, product ideation and design, development process, and constructing a meaningful product narrative and complete product loop. in this course, second year students in the jacobs programs will join their one-year classmates to evaluate and refine their ideas and form teams for the spring studio during  the second half of the fall semester. learning how to build (late fall and early spring): in late fall, you will learn the key managerial skills required to build a product and manage a product team -- issues around your product architecture, product roadmaps, keeping your team aligned, managing its progress, etc. together these skills are often called product management (though we prefer the word product science).
61080010.name: Preparing for Studio

61080011.about:
this course will help students gain the necessary skills of building a data product. many industries today are faced with high datavolumes and there is an understanding that "data is the new gold". but value is not created by data, rather, it is created by the application of data for a b2b or b2c need.  to link the possibilities of data to business needs is a skill that is highly in demand in today's business world. this course aims to fill the current skill gap by educating students with the basic data skills that are needed in order to guide an organization to become data-centric and potentially create data products. these classes will be a combinat ion of lectures, discussions, and hands on training with data. the students will build their own predictive model, without the needto directly write code.
 learning outcomes: learn basic data skills to guide organizations.
61080011.name: Designing Data Products

61080012.about:
Urban strategies and case studies grounds students in the basics of urban and spatial design practices, as well as the surrounding environmental, sociological, political, and economic dimensions. This course will use primary and secondary source material and theoretical and empirical works to understand cities as complex interrelated environments. Students will learn about the multidimensional drivers that shape the urban systems and built environment that form our cities. the course will teach students how to analyze andtransform urban environments to create livable and sustainable cities for future generations.
 The course will also contribute a des ign perspective for the program: project based, empirical, iterative, situated, and integrative. the course uses new york city as areal-world laboratory and augments foundational and theoretical examples with case studies of successful and unsuccessful initiatives.  (site visits are planned to various nyc locations, but maybe explored through digital means during the semester).  Students will develop projects that address urgent urban challenges such as sustainability, infrastructure, resiliency, mobility, affordability,access, and e
61080012.name: Urban Strategies and Case Studies

61080015.about:
This course examines the design, deployment, and adoption of computing technologies that aim to engage with issues of social justice. through discussions of case studies from the us and across the world, we will study technology and social justice in specific domains such as agriculture, finance, health, education, data collection, privacy, and more, examining the design, deployment, and adoption of different computing technologies in these domains. we will also explore many of the big debates in the field through readingand discussing seminal papers, including how to define social justice and.or design justice, what it means for technologies to engag e with social justice, how technology design can better serve marginalized communities, how to approach and measure success, how toconsider failure, what constitutes 'good' work, how to broach the 'digital divide' and more.
 1. demonstrate a broader understanding of the complexities surrounding existing and emerging social-technical systems.
 2. start developing a critical toolkit for anticipating the ethical implications and consequences of your own technical projects (e.g., studio).
 3. engage with leading scholars andpractitione
61080015.name: Special Topics: Technology and Social Justice

61080016.about:
this is a collaborative course where participants (nyc community and graduate students from cornell tech and weill cornell ctsc) work on a prototype for a real-world problem that is worth investigating around digital fabrication. this workshop will introduce students to the concepts and methodology of design and making with digital fabrication tools. students will be able to draw from their unique backgrounds and areas of study.research (e.g., computer science, biomedical science, clinical research, business, engineering,etc) to problem-solve while working in intergenertional and intercultural teams. 
the ability to digitally fabricate parts and whole  pieces directly from our computers or design files used to be an exotic and expensive option, but 3d printing has fast become the preferred medium to allow easily adaptable ideas to develop from concept to creation quickly, at a relatively low cost. not limited to 3d printing, this course will focus on the area of materials and making, simulation, computation design, and skills to co-create in diverse cross-disciplinary teams.
 learning outcomes:
 1. collaborate in a diverse team-based environment to think creatively andintegrate
61080016.name: Digital Craft at Large

61080017.about:
This course examines the design, deployment, and adoption of computing technologies that aim to engage with issues of social justice. through discussions of case studies from the us and across the world, we will study technology and social justice in specific domains such as agriculture, finance, health, education, data collection, privacy, and more, examining the design, deployment, and adoption of different computing technologies in these domains. We will also explore many of the big debates in the field through readingand discussing seminal papers, including how to define social justice and.or design justice, what it means for technologies to engag e with social justice, how technology design can better serve marginalized communities, how to approach and measure success, how toconsider failure, what constitutes 'good' work, how to broach the 'digital divide' and more.
 learning ouctomes:
 1. critically discuss common methods in designing technology for social justice.
 2. demonstrate an understanding of the key debates framing this research area.
 3. demonstrate an understanding of how to design quality research studies on these topics.
 4. critically discuss positive and n
61080017.name: Digital Life Research Seminar

61080018.about:
Firms in creative industries influence many physical and psychological aspects of our lives, from what we eat and wear to how we entertain ourselves, but markets for cultural goods are complex and difficult to navigate. entrepreneurs must, therefore, understand the structure and functioning of the cultural market and ecosystem in order to sustainably capture economic value through technological advances. students will analyze business cases of firms in a wide range of creative industries such as art, fashion.online retail, games, publishing.media, and theater to explore and understand the economic, organizational, and strategic underpinnings of entrepr eneurship and markets in the digital world. the learning from these cases will be supplemented by practical insights provided by several guest speakers. Learning Outcomes:
 1. Articulate opinions or arguments about case.specific issue on the spot.
 2. Demonstratethe ability to change ones conclusion through evidence-based discussion.
 3. Be able to think on ones feet and speaking up in public about one s thoughts on an issue.
61080018.name: Entrepreneurship in Creative Industries

61080020.about:
this courses examines fundamental concepts in digital marketing and prepares you for roles as a marketer, product manager or entrepreneur. students will be exposed to an overview of the major players in the digital industries, as well as a variety of tools commonly found in start-ups and technology firms. we will cover this using a mixture of case studies and lectures. the hope for this course is that this will leave the student with the skills and a plan that they could refer to when they work for established firms or start their own ventures.
 lerning outcomes:
 1. demonstrate knowledge of basic concepts of digital marketing.
 2. ability to apply con cepts and skills within an established firm or new venture.
61080020.name: Digital Marketing

61080021.about:
This course provides fundamental concepts and tools to value assets, including firms and projects, using an economic framework. It begins with an overview of two approaches to valuation: 1) discounted cash flow (dcf) and 2) valuation by multiples using comparableassets. we will first discuss the fact that valuation by multiples and the dcf approach are one and the same. then, we will discussthe dcf approaches in detail, including projections and costs of capital. We will wrap up the course with a case discussion of valuing hyper-growth technology firms and issues specific to valuing high-tech.start-up firms. This course is especially useful to anyone  preparing for a career role in project management, including marketing and operations, and valuing entrepreneurial opportunities (E.G., startups). Both conceptual understanding and practical implementations through case studies will be emphasized.
 Learning Ouctomes:
 1. demonstrate knowledge of basic concepts and tools in valuing assets 2. display understanding of valuation to apply in project management.
61080021.name: Valuations

61080023.about:
this course teaches the fundamentals of digital signal processing (dsp) and digital communication using a balanced mix of theory and hands-on implementations. the course will start by teaching basic concepts in linear algebra, probability, and signals and systems. course topics include time and frequency analysis, sampling, filters, and de-noising. experimental projects that involve real-timesignal processing and communications systems will be used to demonstrate the individual concepts covered in lectures. 
 learning ouctcomes:
 1. collaborate in a diverse team-based environment to think creatively and integrate constructive feedback into your work.
  2. identify new fields or real-world problems and contexts that are worth investigating around digital fabrication. 
.
61080023.name: Applied Digital Signal Processing and Communications

61080025.about:
one goal of this course is to develop your proficiency in quantitative modeling within the environment of a spreadsheet, such as good design and effective presentation of information. another goal is to extend your skills and understanding of advanced quantitative tools using advanced spreadsheets features such as solver optimization algorithms, monte carlo simulation, and decision analysis.
the course is hands-on, and largely conducted in lab.
 learning ouctomes:
 1. become proficient in quantitative modeling within microsoft excel. 2. upgrade individual skills and understanding of advanced quantitative tools.
61080025.name: Decision Models

61080028.about: although there have been tremendous innovations in design, material sciences, bio- and information technologies, direct interactions and collaborations between scientists, architects, and engineers are rare. one approach is to couple architectural designers with engineers and scientists within a research-based laboratory-studio in order to develop new ways of thinking, seeing and working in each of our fields. this combined studio+course is an introduction to fundamental concepts and methods in design and emerging technologies across architecture, engineering, and science to prepare students with the necessary tools and knowledge for iterative, hybrid,  and synthetic thinking in design and making across disciplines. course work includes exposure to different theories, research, andpractices of design and emerging technologies, making and digital fabrication (3d printing), computational and generative design, new materials, and bio-inspired design. emphasis will be upon problem generation over immediate problem solving with specific focus in areas of materials and making, generative design, simulation, computational design, physical modeling, and digital fabrication within a hybrid
61080028.name: Design and Making Across Disciplines

61080029.about: this course provides a broad overview of the opportunities and challenges related to urban data and helps familiarize students withkey datasets and the tools and methodologies to visualize and analyze them. the course will introduce a framework to reason about urban data by focusing on (i) what the data is about (city infrastructure, city assets, people, people s assets, flora and fauna, etc.), (ii) what type of data it is (imagery, audio, radio, sensory, surveys, time series, etc.), (iii) how the data is collected (contributed, individually collected, mass collected, crowdsourced, iot, etc.), and (iv) how data can be utilized and protected from uneth ical use, with special attention given to privacy concerns. the course will present various tools and methodologies to process the data, including data mining, machine learning, gis, network analysis, simulation, agent-based modeling, data visualization. traditional big data challenges (volume, velocity, variety, veracity, and validity) will be reviewed and the associated challenges specific to urban data such as quality, privacy, bias, and data governance will be highlighted. instructors will help students achieve familiarity with ke
61080029.name: Urban Data

61080087.about:
many technology companies face the challenge of managing physical resources. for example, online retailers such as amazon need to decide how much inventory to stock for each item and where to open fulfillment centers. on-demand transportation companies such as uber need to decide which driver to assign to each customer request and how to incentivize drivers to reposition in expectation of future demand shifts. online grocers such as freshdirect need to decide how to schedule deliveries and in which order to visit the customers. depending on the setting, the physical resources take the form of inventories, fulfillment centers, trucks and drivers. when m anaging such physical resources, we often have to make decisions in the face of uncertainty, as customer demands, procurement lead times and travel times are not known with certainty.
 in this course we will study mathematical models, algorithms and computationaltools for managing physical resources as they relate to technology companies. we will understand how we can build optimization models to solve logistics problems, make real-time decisions and incorporate uncertainty into our decision-making process. we will see how we can de
61080087.name: E-Logistics

61080088.about:
the goal of this course is to educate students about the complexity and nuances of healthcare delivery.  the course will be especially useful for non-clinicians who intend to go into fields that will require a detailed understanding of healthcare.  class sessionswill not summarize healthcare, rather, they will analyze healthcare, through themes such as people, time, money, communication, uncertainty, and others.  students will come away from the course with a deeper appreciation of why it is difficult to change healthcare. they will then be able to anticipate the intended and unintended consequences of interventions and policies that they and others m ight implement.
learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will: 
1. understand the importance of the patient-doctor relationship and concepts of professionalism, as well as current threats to these essential components of healthcare. 
 2. understandthe people, places and things that comprise healthcare organization and delivery. 
 3. appreciate the compllexity of medical decision making, including the role of unceratainty. 
 4. analyze the role of time and money in healthcare and the tensions that they create. 
 5.
61080088.name: Healthcare Organization and Delivery

61080089.about: this course is part of a city-wide effort to create new tech that supports and defends journalism and media - the most critical elements of our democracy - as they are increasingly threatened by political and market forces. this course will bring together journalism, design, media studies, and technical disciplines to understand the various threats to journalism and media, and attempt to address these challenges using technical and computational methods and techniques. the free press, journalism and the media are some of the most critical elements of our democracy, but have been increasingly under attack by political and market forces. these challenges  include: dwindling resources and support for deep investigative journalism, smear, law and technical and even physical assaults ofmedia organizations and journalists, challenges to credibility and reliability including fake news and discrediting campaigns, and shifting business models and income sources that threaten both local and national news organizations and coverage. the main content of this course will be provided in a weekly meeting in a semi-rotating location. in addition, there will be two hackathon events which will jumps
61080089.name: Technology, Media and Democracy

61080090.about:
students will learn how to model randomness, analyze its impact, and make optimal decisions when it is present. the class will cover stochastic modeling techniques, statistical principles, simulation, and decision-making under uncertainty. using applications, theclass will demonstrate how one can use statistical principles to gain insight from data generated by systems with randomness. students will use simulation models to assess the performance of such systems and gauge how it changes in response to our decisions. students will be introduced to and use stochastic modeling techniques, such as markov chains and brownian motion, to build models of rand om phenomena and use these to gain understanding and guide decisions. as well as covering theoretical concepts, the course will putsubstantial emphasis in computational implementation of both simulation and decision-making problems.
 learning ouctomes: 
 1. learn how to model randomness, analyze and make optimal decision.
 2. demonstrate knowledge of various modeling techniques.
61080090.name: Modeling Under Uncertainty

61080091.about:
in this class, students will learn how to successfully navigate the opportunities and challenges of a bigco (big company) and buildproducts in a complex environment at scale. students will also learn about how business development, m and a, and other corporate activities complement, and sometimes compete with product teams to drive larger strategic initiatives forward in bigcos. students will work in teams matched with a real-world opportunity and advisor from a bigco. teams will then build and pitch a working product inthree sprints culminating in a final presentation and demo. the class will include lectures and prominent guest speakers from the in dustry.
 learning ouctomes: at the end of the course the student will:
 1. demonstrate understanding of organizational structures and cultures to implement change.
 2. develop digital innovation in response to organizational challenges.
61080091.name: Bigco Studio

61080092.about:
an introduction to some fundamental algorithms and data structures used in current applications. cryptocurrencies (hashing, merkle trees, proofs of work), ai (nearest neighbor methods, k-d trees, autoencoders), and vr.ar (gradient descent, least squares, line-drawing algorithms). lectures will be supplemented with occasional applied laboratory taught in the evening. 
 progamming assignments in python.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will:
 1. understand important cs algorithms (such as hashing and dynamic programming), including the ability to write correct code and pseudocode.
 2. solve standard dynamic programming problems, by writing the recurrence and programming a solution.
 3. apply hashing techniques where appropriate, including situations where their applicability is not immediately obvious (such as  nearest neighbor search).
 4. understand streaming algorithms and their tradeoffs and apply such methods where they are useful.
 5. understand image processing methods such as convolution and image segmentation.
61080092.name: Algorithms and Structures for Applications.

61080093.about:
viewed variously as a niche currency for online criminals and a technological threat to the financial industry, bitcoin has fueled mythmaking, financial speculation, and real technological innovation. the class will study both bitcoin and the technological landscape it has inspired and catalyzed. topics will include: the mechanics of consensus algorithms, such as proof of work and byzantine consensus, and their role in blockchains and cryptocurrencies, cryptographic tools employed in cryptocurrencies, including digital signatures algorithm and zero-knowledge proofs, the evolution and mechanics of bitcoin and its ecosystem, smart contracts, and special topics, such as trusted hardware in blockchain-based systems, smart contracts and real-world contract law, and cryptocurrencies andcrime. 
 learning outcomes: :
 understanding of the bitcoin landscape.
61080093.name: Blockchains, Crptocurrencies and Smart Contracts

61080095.about:
head worn mixed reality devices require real-time computer vision for multiple purposes, such as motion tracking, scene understanding, and interaction input. this course presents a hands-on overview of these computer vision techniques for mixed reality, from monocular pose estimation, to stereo-view hand tracking, and scene reconstruction with depth sensors and multiple cameras. fundamental approaches as well as current challenges, from geometric vision to learning-based approaches, are presented in the context of mixed reality, with readings from textbooks and relevant papers. 
 students will complete three individual assignments and one group project , in the form of mixed reality research prototypes and conference-style report.
 learning ouctomes: the student will:
 1. understanding of computer vision techniques. 
 2. develop a research prototype using concepts learned in the classroom.
61080095.name: Mixed Reality

61080096.about:
deep learning is an area of machine learning that has enabled enormous progress on long-standing problems in machine perception andreinforcement learning. this course will give students an understanding of neural networks, their limitations, and their current applications. beyond reviewing state-of-the-art systems, students will be responsible for completing a project in deep learning. the course is designed to prepare students to evaluate and produce new state-of-the-art deep learning algorithms. students are expected to understand the basics of machine learning, but no background in neural networks is expected. students should have experience with p ython and should be comfortable with probability, linear algebra, and calculus.
 learning outcomes: 
the student will:
 1. understanding of neural networks. 
 2. evaluate and produce new deep learning algorithms.
61080096.name: Deep Learning

61080100.about:
what makes a city. this course will explore how a city is composed of a complex interaction of urban systems, ranging from infrastructure and transportation networks to social and political systems. students will be introduced to the concept of the city as a  system of systems  and the needs of users operating and interacting within such systems. the course will also offer a broad perspectiveon pressing urban challenges such as sustainability, resiliency, and equity. a special focus will be on emerging technologies such as iot and big data and their practical applications to tackle such challenges. students will gain practical knowledge of how to mode l systems to support useful simulations and build solutions. in addition, students will develop strategies that can transform cities and improve urban life. the course will consist of a combination of classic texts and contemporary readings, case studies, site visits, hands-on assignments, a team-oriented project, and visiting lectures by leading urban practitioners.learning ouctomes:
 1. students will be able to recognize, analyze and represent urban systems, understand the relationship between systems and associated complexities.
61080100.name: Urban Systems

61080101.about:
machine learning systems are increasingly being deployed in production environments, from cloud servers to mobile devices. this course will focus on challenges inherent to engineering machine learning systems to be correct, robust, and fast. assignments will be project focused, with students building and deploying systems for applications such as text analysis and recommendation systems. in addition to machine learning models, practical topics will include: tensor languages and auto-differentiation, model debugging, testing, and visualization, compression and low-power inference. guest lectures will cover current topics from local ml engineers.
 learni ng outcomes: 
 1. mastery of the key algorithms for training and executing core machine learning methods. 
 2. understanding of thecomputational requirements of running these systems.
 3. practical ability to debug, optimize, and tune existing models in production environments.
 4. skills to develop frontends to easily interact with and explain predictive systems.
 5. understanding how bias can be propagated and magnified by ml systems.
 6. facility to compare.
61080101.name: Machine Learning Engineeing

61080103.about:
this course will introduce students to the field of ubiquitous computing -- a multidisciplinary research area that draws from machine learning, machine perception, signal processing, human computer interaction, as well as psychology and sociology. class discussions and hands on exercises will be the focus of this class with a few formal lectures. discussions will highlight the various challenges in data collection, representation and tractability of models, and evaluation. we will brain-storm ideas on how future research can go about tackling some of these challenges. students will be required to lead and critique papers. everyone will take turns prese nting papers and in leading discussions. participation in discussions will be evaluated as well as mini projects assignments duringthe term and an end of term final project.
 learning outcomes:
 students will learn about fundamental principles in the field of ubiquitous computing, which draws from machine learning, signal processing, device building, and human computer interaction.
61080103.name: Ubiquitous Computing

61080104.about:
the course will help students develop their strategic thinking, strategy formulation and execution skills.  it will use a series ofcases involving companies in different strategic situations such as in an emerging  industry, mature industry, transforming industry, etc. and engage students in developing and . or  evaluating appropriate strategies in these varied situations. it will build directly upon your prior core class  in strategy but delve deeper and help build a skill in formulating strategy, refining strategy and very importantly evaluating strategy.
 learning ouctomes:
 develop student skills in 
 1. structured thinking and complexity manageme nt 2. strategic analysis 3. strategy identification, formulation, evaluation, and refinement 4. develop a rigorous approach for addressing complex business problems.
61080104.name: Advanced Strategic Anlaysis

61080106.about:
to complement students' entrepreneurial journeys at cornell tech, students enrolled in this course will learn a set of methodologies that support the identifying and onboarding of early adopters as customers. students will complete the course with a set of tools and examples of real contracts, frameworks, and system and process designs that can be used to help them in acquiring their very first customer. in addition to the tools to support customer acquisition, students will make an attempt at acquiring their first customer for a real or hypothetical startup that is being budilt in startup studio at cornell tech. 
 learning ouctomes:
 students will hav e gained a set of tools and examples of real contracts, frameworks, and system and process designs.
61080106.name: Early Adopters

61080108.about:
this class introduces the principal legal issues involved in starting, managing and operating a technology-oriented business by entrepreneurs. it is intended to provide nonlaw students with an understanding of many of the laws and regulations to which developing businesses in the united states tech sector are typically subject from the time an entrepreneur conceives and begins to build a business, implements a business plan, and obtains financing, to when she begins operations in anticipation of managing a mature company and considering possible exit strategies. from time to time in class, i will adopt the role of a general counsel to a start-up compan y advising clients.students about how laws and regulations affect their businesses at various stages of development, as well as about typical key contractual terms and negotiating strategies. practicing lawyers specializing in certain areas of the law-- such as tax, intellectual property, employment law and others particularly relevant to start-up technology companies-will serve as guest lecturers.
 the course is designed to impart an understanding not only about substantive areas of the law that intersect with tech businesses but a
61080108.name: Law for Non-Lawyers

61080109.about:
how can intelligent machines perceive, make decisions, and execute their plans in an uncertain, dynamic world: this course will cover algorithms for robotic perception, planning, and control with a focus on real-time adaptation and learning. students should have prior experience with data processing and machine learning methods.
 topics covered include probabilistic methods for scene segmentation, multimodal sensory intergration, latent variable models for dynamical systems, path planning for navigation and reinforcement learning for motor control. 
learning outcomes:
students will learn fundamental principles underlying algorithms for intelligent syst ems as well as how to implement these algorithms for real-time processing.
61080109.name: Intelligent Autonomous Systems

61080110.about: the goal of this course to prepare students to lead companies that have embedded social missions and to engage various stakeholdersthat are at the nexus of business and social value. internally, leaders will need to be prepared to manage the organization's culture, establish a mission, and find synergies in pursuit of a triple bottom line. externally, leaders must manage not only supply chain and customer relationships, but also seek to fundamentally change the social, environmental and legal environments in which business operates. a major focus of the course will be on the challenges associated with connecting social initiatives and missions with bo ttom-line benefits. how can the goals of a company be articulated in and driven by the corporate mission. how can leaders establisha mission that is big enough to attract employees, customers and partners but specific enough to be achievable. also, what does success look like for a social entrepreneur and, which goals are established by the market and which by the mission. students will alsowrestle with questions on the implementation and execution of social entrepreneurship. central to this theme is corporate growth. how can companie
61080110.name: Social Entrepreneurship

61080111.about:
we are in the midst of a digital tsunami. digital technologies have progressed exponentially over the last decades and a tipping point has been reached. further the pace of progress in digital technologies shows no signs of slowing down. all industries are susceptible to the forces of digital transformation and most executives are or will soon be confronted by the dynamics of digital disruption. there will be significant new opportunities as the underlying forces of digital disruption and value creation are understood andleveraged. succeeding in this rapidly changing world will require both a solid understanding of digital products, services and busin ess models and an inspirational leadership style to be bold, take risks and lead complex change.
 learning outcomes:
 1. be better prepared to help organizations to compete and win in the digital world.
 2. provide an effective combination of theory and practice in digital transformation and innovation for executives.
61080111.name: Leading Digital Transformation and Innovation

61080112.about:
this studio-based course covers the first steps of entrepreneurship: how to come up with new product and startup ideas, find teammates with complementary and diverse backgrounds, and rally around something that matters. you will invent and explore thousands of ideas, helping each other evaluate and improve those ideas, and you will meet as many of your classmates as possible, working in different teams each week and for each homework.
 this course prepares you for the entrepreneurial journey ahead in spring studio and beyond.
 learning outcomes: students will learn the basic fundamentals in forming teams and product ideas to prepare for spring studio.
61080112.name: Entrepreneurship Zero (Studio)

61080113.about: this course has one overarching objective, to make its participants better decision makers through the provision of a framework fora good decision process. more specific objectives are: (1) to understand the critical role of framing, so that participants are able to structure their decisions in the most useful way(s) and to see how coworkers, competitors, and other stakeholders view the samedecision situation, (2) to identify typical shortcomings in intuitive judgment and provide methods for overcoming these shortcomings.(3) to develop the skill of using multiple scenarios to make decisions in the face of great uncertainty and complexity, and (4) to provide tools for managing group decisions.
61080113.name: Managerial Decision Making

61080114.about:
sales and business development provides an overview of the principles and practices of direct sales and business development leveraging research, practical and experiential resources.  classes include instructor-driven content, expert practitioner guests, and experiential exercises. it is designed to have lectures, class discussions and exercises, guest lectures and reading assignments. 
 participants will develop a go-to-market sales strategy for their startup projects as a final deliverable for the class.
61080114.name: Sales and Business Development

61080115.about:
this course provides an introduction to the human-centered and technical workings behind interactive devices ranging from cell phones and video controllers to household appliances and smart cars. this is a hands-on, lab-based course. for the final project, students will build a functional interactive device of their own design, using javascript, single-board linux computer, embedded microcontrollers, and other electronics components.
 learning ouctomes:
 by the end of this course, students will build a functional interactive device of their own design.
61080115.name: Developing and Designing Interactive Dev

61080116.about:
this course is designed to introduce students to the challenges and pitfalls of financing new enterprises. the class sessions will combine lectures and cases. the course covers three broad topics: 
 1. identifying and valuing opportunities: this section focuses on identifying good ideas and valuing the asset side of the balance sheet. 
 2. contract design and financing alternatives: this section will discuss contracts from a conceptual perspective and a valuation perspective. we will study how various financial contracts affect the incentives of financiers and entrepreneurs. 
 3. exit.harvesting strategies: this section will focus on exits by acquisiti on and through initial public offerings (ipos).
 learning outcomes:
 students will learn about fundamental principles of finance inan entrepreneurial setting.
61080116.name: Entrepreneurial Finance

61080117.about: what does it take to make an idea or concept into a successful commercial undertaking. well, a whole lot - a great product in a compelling market, a strong team with determination, and most certainly a sound business model. a business model defines how a company creates value with key resources and processes, how that value is delivered to customers, and ultimately how the company makes profits for shareholders. legacy business models can be the downfall of even the most successful companies, whereas innovative business models can comletely disrupt established markets, creating massive value for customers and shareholders. this course explores and demo nstrates the concepts underlying coherent business models, as well as the history of business models across technological cycles. it covers business model design and analysis across various markets, including both traditional and digital. since multiple business models can co-exist in different markets, the course will examine the the implications of different approaches and how business models are often used as a distinctive competitive advantage. this course is designed to have practical applications, using relevant real-world exam
61080117.name: Business Models

61080118.about:
digital technologies have raised important ethical questions. although often the focus is how ethical issues arise from ways peoplehave used these technologies, there is growing interest in ethical values associated with the design and development of digital systems and devices. the study of values in, or values embodied in technology, has grown in importance as engineers and computer and data scientists have acknowledged that sound ethical practice is a responsibility alongside technical. this course introduces studentsto the latter. after providing a background to this way of thinking -- about ethics as a dimension of technology design and developm ent - it introduces students to values at play, one particular approach to putting these ideas into practice. 
 students are encouraged to apply this learning to their own projects. learning outcomes:
students who successfully complete this course 1. recognize how and to what extent values are implicated in technical artifacts, incidentally or by design. 2. engage critically with everyday technical systems._
 3. recognize instances of design that seem to elevate or obstruct certain values._
 4. engage actively with valuesembodied i
61080118.name: Values at Play in Digital Technologies

61080119.about: this course introduces students to the concepts, methods, techniques, and theory of visual design in the context of creating digital products. students will analyze examples, past and present, of form in relationship to content on web and mobile. from there, theywill learn and practice basic principles for typography, color, and composition through prototyping, visual iteration, and critique. brand elements, ux principles, accessibility, user research, and pattern libraries will be discussed. you will not be a full-fledged, full-stack digital product designer at the conclusion of this five-week course. you will, however, understand better how and why we should care about how people experience our products, and how seemingly arbitrary design decisions are in fact not arbitrary, and have consequences. we will be both working at the micro-scale (typography, color, form) and at the macro-scale (design patterns, accessibility, ethics) towards this understanding. you will understand better what makes a good designer, so that you are not just relying on job titles to figure out who knows what. we will also work towards habits of seeing and of critique that will make you a better collabora
61080119.name: Visual and Interaction Design for Digital Products

61080120.about:
negotiation is the art and science of securing an agreement between people who have some conflicting interests.
 seen this way, younegotiate every day with partners about travel plans, with roommates about dishwashing, with teammates about who writes the first draft of the paper.  and you can begin to see how you can turn situations into profitable negotiations getting a hotel room upgrade, managing a dispute on a client team, finagling a deadline extension. the goal of this class is to help you do better in these and other important negotiations.   as is true in life, there is no formula you can simply apply to achieve success in negotiation.  nor is  there a single right answer to the question of what is the best tactic to use.  i will provide you with frameworks and empirical findings that shed light on which tactics are likely to be effective, given particular situational constraints (relationships, few outside options, etc.).
 learning outcomes: 
 1. hone ability to decide when tactic is likely to work.
 2. practice appropriate skillsto gain experience and confidence.
 3. learn fundamental principles in negotiations to apply learnings in the both the workforce and in pers
61080120.name: Negotiations

97030021.name: English Pre Preacademic Prep. for MAIMAD

97030029.name: Scien. tech. writing Pre Preacad. Heseg.

00140003.about: Data processing, introduction to sets and probability. Sample space, events, counting sample points, combinatorical conditional andtotal probability, independence, Bayes' theorem, one and higher dimensional random variables, probability distributions, expectation and higher moments, Chebyshev's inequality, known discrete and continuous distributions, regression, sampling, estimation of parameters, testing hypotheses, decision under uncertainty, basic concepts in simulation.
00140003.name: Statistics

00140004.about: Optimization problems in Civil Engineering and their formulation. Classical optimization techniques, linear programming, search techniques, network programming, dynamic programming.
00140004.name: System Analysis

00140005.about: Basic experiments in mechanics and strength of materials and fluid mechanics.
00140005.name: Engineering Laboratory

00140006.about: The final examination comprises examination on the theoretical aspects as well as on the practical applications. The least squares approximation, Divided differences, Polynomial interpolation, Nimerical integration, Solution of ordinary equations. Equations characteristic to civil engineering. Linear and non-linear equations. Finite difference approximations to derivative. Solution of eliptic, parabolic and hyperbolic partial differential equations. Types of boundary conditions. The explicit, the implicit and the Crank-Nicolsson method for parabolic equations. The ADI method. Stability conditions. Treatment of inhomogeneous media. Methods of solution o f linear algebraic equation system, Gauss-Jordan, Jacobi. Convergence of the iterative methods. Sparce matrices. Ill-conditioned systems. Scaling of matrix coefficients. Solving equations characteristic to the different areas of Civil Engineering.
00140006.name: Introduction to Numerical Methods

00140008.about: Representation and communication of engineering information in construction using graphics (drawings). Visualization of engineeringobjects in three- dimensional space (reading plans, sections and details): communication of building concepts using sketches, basicdrafting, basic 3d modeling, use of appropriate software.
00140008.name: Graphical and Engineering Information

00140011.about: The course focuses on appropriate and sustainable technology for small-scale development communities. It will introduce students toopen ended problems at the community level. Allow them to develop: cultural and social awareness, skills to solve those problems and provide integrated engineering solutions, and gain a better understanding of the importance of engineering in society.
00140011.name: Engineering for Developing Communities

00140101.about: Solution in principle of an advanced problem in structural design. Conceptual design solutions and selection of a preferred solution. General detailing of several elements from the selected solution.
00140101.name: Project in Structures

00140102.about: INTRODUCTION, ELEMENTS OF VECTOR ALGEBRA AND PRINCIPLES OF STATICS. FORCE SYSTEMS IN PLANE AND SPACE AND EQUIVALENT FORCE SYSTEMS. FREE BODY DIAGRAM, EQUILIBRIUM AND ADEQUACY OF CONSTRAINTS. PLANE AND SPACE TRUSSES, BEAMS AND FRAMES. DISTRIBUTED FORCES. INTERNAL FORCE AND MOMENT DIAGRAMS. DIFFERENTIAL RELATIONSHIPS OF EQUILIBRIUM. SUPERPOSITION METHOD FOR INTERNAL FORCE DIAGRAMS. CABLES AND ARCHES. SECTION PROPERTIES (CENTROID! FIRST AND SECOND MOMENTS). CENTER OF GRAVITY AND CENTER OF MASS.
00140102.name: INT. TO ENGINEERING MECHANICS

00140103.about: Elements of vector algebra. Principles of statics. Force systems in plane and space. Equivalent force systems. Free body diagram. Equilibrium. Adequacy of constraints. Plane and space trusses, beams and frames.  Internal force and moment diagrams. Differential relationships of equilibrium.  Section properties (centroid, first and second moments). Center of gravity and center of mass. Cables.
00140103.name: Intro.to Engineering Mechanics

00140104.about: Introduction. Tension and compression:  stress and strain, transformation of stresses in the case of simple tension or compression.Torsion of different sections. Pure bending, shear in bending, shear center. General transformation of stress and strain. Mohr's circle:  trajectories. Deflection of beams, the differential equation of the elastic line, the  conjugative beam method, superposition. The three-moment equation and statically indeterminate beams. Basic concepts of elastic buckling: Euler's equation.
00140104.name: Strength of Materials 1

00140107.about: Stress field, differential equilibrium, stress function, stress transformation, strain field, strain transformation, compatibility equation. Linear theory of elasticity. Two dimensional problems. Elastic energy. Energy methods in elasticity.
00140107.name: Introduction to the Theory of Elasticity

00140108.about: Internal forces and influence lines in statically determinate structures. Betti's theorem and calculations of elastic deflection. Force (flexibility) method. Displacement (stiffness) method. Influence lines in statically indeterminate structures.
00140108.name: Structural Analysis

00140113.about: Classification of buildings, soils and foundations. Modulus of subgrade reaction and foundation settlements of shallow foundation. Design and construction of reinforced concrete foundation. Foundation analysis and design of shallow rigid foundation system, failure criteria. Differential settlements and redistribution of internal dorces and moments, soil-structure iteration. Flexible foundation: strap footings and mat foundation. Classical solution of beam and plate on elastic foundation.
00140113.name: Foundations

00140131.about: A general design of a project in structures, based on guided and supervized study of affiliated literature.  Assessment of alternative solutions.  Presentation of a seminar to conclude the study of the problem and introduce the selected solution.approach.
00140131.name: Extended Project - Part a

00140132.about: A detailed design based on advanced computational analytical methods for the topic presented and solved in principle in 14131.
00140132.name: Extended Project Part B

00140143.about: COMPUTER ORIENTED FORMULATION OF THE STIFFNESS AND FLEXIBILITY METHODS. STIFFNESS AND FLEXIBILITY MATRICES OF PRISMATIC MEMBERS. ASSEMBLY OF STIFFNESS MATRIX. COMPUTER PROGRAMS FOR CONTINUOUS BEAMS' TRUSSES AND FRAMES. STIFFNESS AND FLEXIBILITY MATRICES OF NON-PRISMATIC MEMBERS. INTRODUCTION TO THE FINITE ELEMENT METHOD.
00140143.name: Computer Methods in Structural Analysis

00140145.about: Buckling: Buckling of columns and frames. Symmetry in buckling of frames. Computerized solution of buckling problems. Beam-columns.Energy in structures, elastic energy, quasi-static loading, energy  conservation. Minimun principles. Castigliano theorem. Transformation of moments of inertia. Non-homogeneous section. Yield criteria, plastic hinge, plastic analysis of beam.frames. The cross section's core.
00140145.name: Strength of Materials 2

00140146.about: Vibration of damped and un-damped single degrees of freedom systems. Free and forced vibration. Earthquake excitation: characterization and measurements, linear response spectrum. Vibratory of un-damped multiple degrees of freedom systems, free vibrations, modal analysis, modal spectral analysis. Continuous systems and characterization of modal parameters. Equivalent representation of continuous and lumped-mass systems.
00140146.name: Intro to Struc Dynamics and Earthquake Engineering
