00160834.about: scripting language fundamentals, utilization of statistical and geographical libraries, cursors and object geometry access, objectsoriented programming in scripting language, creation and execution of gis tools serially, web service formation in scripting language, introduction to topological editing and automation.
00160834.name: Workshop in Geographic Information System Development

00160835.about: image orientation with geometric constraints, integration of stochastic constraints into image orientation, orientation accuracy and quality analysis, controlled convergence, aerial triangulation of strips and blocks, incorporation of gps data into the orientation processes, incorporation of inertial navigation systems (ins) data into the orientation processes, outlier detection, control freeaerial trinagulation. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know how to: 1. incorporation of geometric constraints into image orientation. 2. incorporation of stochastic constraints into image orientation. 3. outlier detection and data snoop ing in photogrammetric blocks. 4. photogrammetric orientation of large images blocks. 5. performance of direct orientation. 6. performance of photogrammetric orientation without control.
00160835.name: Numerical Aspects in Image Triangulation

00160837.about:
the wealth of geospatial information collected by aircraft and spacecraft in the past decades allows us to investigate geophysical and environmental processes in unprecedented accuracy. in recent years, advances in the field of machine and deep learning have begun to gradually supplement and, in some cases,  replace traditional manual and computational methods. when combined with scientific reasoning and statistical analysis, this collection of approaches, sometimes termed "data science", is a primary modern tool in the analysis of geoinformatic data. the course will review statistics- and machine-learning based techniques for quantitative analysis  of visual, aircraft and spacecraft data: statistical significance tests, data preprocessing and filtering, exploratory data analysis, fundemental machine and deep learning tools (regression, svm, yolo, mask r-cnn) and unsupervised data analysis (pca, autoencoder, vae). learning outcomes: upon concluding the class, students will be able to:
 1. formulate a scientific hypothesis for a data-driven investigation. 2. preprocess and filter raw data and train a convolutional neural network to create a derived dataset.
 3. use unsupervised au
00160837.name: MACHINE LEARNING FOR GEO-ENVIRONMENTS

00170001.about: Topics: Sampling methods and statistical analysis of ecological parameters. Species.area relations. Island biogeography and its application in ecological conservation. diversity indices. Mathematical models in ecology. Selecting and prioritizing land for conservation. Ecosystem management.
00170001.name: Ecological Systems

00170010.about: Introduction, kinematics and dynamics of systems of rigid bodies, Newton - Euler equations, Lagrange equations, D'Alembert's principle, dynamics of pneumatic tire, track, suspension system and off-road vehicles, mechanics of soil reaction, human body response, formulation of vehicle system models, methods for numerical solutions, ride simulation, optimization of suspension systems, methods for experimental testing.
00170010.name: Selected Subjects in Vehicle Dynamics

00170012.about: Topics studies in Introduction to Transport and Pollution in Soil: transport of water, air and solutes in unsaturated porous media,the development of the Richards equation, models for retention curces and unsaturated hydraulic conductivity, the theoretical derivation of Darcy Law, the Brinkman equation and the Forchheimer equation, an analysis of infiltration phenomena by analytical end numerical solutions, evaluation of front dynamics using the Boltzmann transformation, formulation of the solute mass balance equation, the theory of evaporation from soils, gases and vapor .
00170012.name: Physics of Porous Medium

00170022.about: Energetic and microbial growth, Biological reactions applied to pollutant removal technologies, nitrification, denetrification, Premoval anaerobic processes, treatment ponds, Wetlands.
00170022.name: Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering

00170031.about: Spatial analysis of ecological and environmental systems using GIS and remote sensing technologies, and their actual implementations (i.e., computerized mapping of land use from satellite images, dynamic spatial model of an ecosystem, global climate change models), as well as urban environment. The use of these models for decision making and for assessing consequences of alternative scenarioswill be emphasized.
00170031.name: Remote Sensing in Ecology and Environment

00170033.about: concepts of most mommon spectroscopic technioues- near-and mid-infrared (transmittance, diffuse reflectance, attenuated total reflectance)absorbance in the uv-visible range. excitation-emission matrix fluorescence. introduction to matlab programming language. chemometrics methods- principal component analysis (pca). partial least squares (pls) - parallel factor analysis (parafac) - multiway pls (n-pls) - wavelet decomposition, neural metworks. implementation of chemomentrics methods in matlab for a number of examples related to food, environment, soil and agriculture.
00170033.name: Introduction to Chemometrics

00170034.about: classification of vehicles, vehicles system engineering, vehicle components: chassis, engine, transmission, engine and transmissionmatching, mechanics of pneumatic tires, braking and steering characteristics,hitching systems, safety systems,engineering matching between vehicles systems, prediction of vehicle performances on and off-road terrain, steering systems for various platforms, hybridpower train means, considerations in vehicle design, evaluation of vehicle performances by experiments, during the course the topics will be demonstrate in the lab. by simulations and theoretically
00170034.name: Vehicle Engineering-Systems and Performances

00170036.about: topics: precision agriculture principles and their implementation. global positioning system (gps) receivers, differential correction and real time kinematic gps. geo-referenced data. geographic information systems (gis) software for primary spatial data management (with matlab). yield monitoring, soil sampling, acquisition equipment for mapping field variability. remote sensing principles for mapping agricultural parameters. automated on-the-go measurement systems. principles of variable rate application of seeds, water,fertilizers and pesticides. integrate yield and soil nutrient maps with other geo-referenced data to develop an effective site-speci fic crop management program. identification of potential advantages (economic and environmental) and current limitations of precision agriculture.
00170036.name: Introduction to Precision Agriculture

00180002.about: this course is designed to introduce students to concepts, theory and practice of engineering ethics. it will allow students to explore the relationship between ethics and engineering and apply classical moral theory and decision making. course parts: engineeringethics fundamentals, ethical aspects in complementary fields and ethics in advanced topics. learning ouctomes: the student will be able to: 1. understand his or her roles and duties as a professional, with a value perspective of stakeholders and society. 2. define and analyze ethical dilemmas to make decisions integrated into the engineering world. 3. integrate human values, such : safety and human respect and well-being, within the engineering thinking and into the engineering processes.
00180002.name: Ethics in Engineering

00180104.about:
THE COURSE PROVIDES AN INTRODUCTION TO TOPOLOGY OPTIMIZATION, A POWERFUL COMPUTERIZED DESIGN TOOL WITH DIVERSE ENGINEERING APPLICATIONS. THE METHOD IS USED FOR INNOVATIVE APPLICATIONS IN AUTOMOTIVE AND AVIATION INDUSTRIES, STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING, ARCHITECTURE ANDBIO-MEDICAL ENGINEERING. DETAILED CONTENT - METHODS: FINITE ELEMENTS FOR ELASTIC CONTINUUM, OPTIMIZATION OF A VARIABLE THICKNESS SHEET FOR MINIMUM COMPLIANCE, TOPOLOGY OPTIMIZATION FOR MINIMUM COMPLIANCE USING OPTIMALITY CRITERIA, GENERAL OPTIMIZATION MINIMIZATION OF MAXIMUM STRESS, EXTENSION TO 3D: PDE FILTER, PARALLEL COMPUTING. DETAILED CONTENT - APPLICATIONS: STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS IN CAD SOF TWARE, DEFINITION OF DESIGN SPACES, FORCES, SUPPORTS, LOADING SCENARIOS, OBJECTIVE FUNCTIONS AND DESIGN CONSTRAINTS, TOPOLOGY OPTIMIZATION FOR STIFFNESS, NATURAL FREQUENCY AND STRENGTH OF A 3D STRUCTURE IN CAD SYSTEMS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 AFTER SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETING THE COURSE, THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO 1. FORMULATE STRUCTURAL DESIGN PROBLEMS AS OPTIMIZATION PROBLEMS._
 2. IMPLEMENT THEIR OWN COMPUTER PROGRAM EXECUTING TOPOLOGY OPTIMIZATION PROCEDURES OF TWO-DIMENSIONAL CONTIUA FOR PRINCIPAL RESPONSE REQUIREMENTS, SUCH AS CO
00180104.name: TOPICS IN STR. ENG.: TOPOLGY OPTIMIZATIO

00180116.about: Indeterminate prestressd structures. Prestress effets, pressure line, secondary moments, concordant cable. Precast effect of topping on long term displacements, debonding, differential shrinkage and continuous structures using precasts. Ultimate bending-moment capacity - cracking and non-linear constitutive laws. Unbonded prestressed structures, design principles. ULS capacity, punching capacity and construction detalis. Prestress of water tanks, design principles and structural block design, wall design and construction details. Strut and Tie method.
00180116.name: Prestressed Concrete Structures

00180121.about: Introduction:  buckling phenomenon and its physical explanation, non-linear behaviour, definition of critical load by different approaches, small perturbations. The principle of conservation of energy, etc., conservative and non-conservative systems. The differential equation and its linearization, boundary condition and eigenvalues. Approximate methods of analysis, approximate deflection curve, calculus of variations, Rayleigh-Ritz method. Galerkin's method. Vianello-s method. Finite differences method. Stiffness-matrix method. Various structural elements. "Beam-columns", frames, lateral buckling of beams, buckling of plates.
00180121.name: Principles of Structural Stability

00180130.about: Engineering investigation in a selected subject in structural engineering. The investigation includes: Definition of the problem, critical literature survey, data collection and investigation tactics. Investigation of the problem by using theoretical models and.or laboratory experiments. Summary of the investigation and its findings with conclusions and recommendations for further research. The investigation should be presented in a detailed report and in a lecture to students and members of staff.
00180130.name: Advanced Seminar in Structural Engineering

00180138.about: Survey of bridge configurations and schemes. General design considerations. Bridge loading. Circular and rectangular culverts. Slabbridges and girder bridges - design and analysis. Gerber-type bridges.  Arch bridges (fixed ends, two or three hinges). Typical bridge details, piers, bearings, wing walls, etc. Prestressing in bridges.
00180138.name: Concrete Bridges

00180139.about:
A methodology for technological and project optimization that allows engineers to meet performance, budget and schedule requirements, with a minimum of rounds of changes and updates. Optimization as the goal, defining optimization, simplicity, robustness and standardization. Development as an iterative process. Defining customer and value chain requirements. Balanced allocation of weights to requirements. Formulating the optimal concept. The simplified mathematical model (linear) and the complete mathematical model (non-linear) for the formulation of the optimal concept. Common sense considerations and avoiding "excessive demands". A model for robust concept formulation. The potential to simplify, improve efficiency and reduce costs of products. Optimal development processes and organizational culture. The issue of uncertainty. The course will include case studies from various fields: high-tech, civil engineering, automotive, aviation and consumer products.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: THE ACADEMY TEACHES ENGINEERING STUDENTS SUBJECTS INENGINEERING SCIENCES (PHYSICS, MATHEMATICS, COMPUTER AS SPECIFIC SUBJECTS CONNECTED TO THEIR PROFESSIONAL LEARNING TENDENCY (MECHANICS, AERONAUTI COMPUTER S
00180139.name: TECHNOLOGY AND PROJECT OPTIMIZATION

00180140.about: Discussion of recent research in steel structures. Selected topics from:  Stability of regular and thin walled members, bracing, P-delta, initial imperfections, plastic hinges, interaction equations. Joints, including circular and rectangular tubes. Residual stresses. Secondary stresses in trusses.
00180140.name: Selected Topics in Steel Structures

00180141.about: topics: response, damage indices and analysis methods for yielding structures under dynamic loading. classification of control types. active and semi-active control design approaches. dynamic behavior rules for energy dissipation devices. design methodologies forstructures with energy dissipation devices. analysis and design of structures with tuned mass dampers. analysis and design of base isolated structures.
00180141.name: Structural Control Under Dynamic Loading

00180222.about: Basic topics revision (basic equations and linear theory). Non-linear operties of water waves. Statistics and spectral analysis of wind-waves. Expertimental measurements of water waves in the open sea, measurements using wave gauges array and pressure gauges array. Experiments will be accompanied by qualitative observations of surface drift and orbital motions. boussinesq and KDV equations. Wave-current interactions. Advanced measurment techniques, differences between laboratory and open sea measurements, remote sensing, directional spread of waves, energy, processing of the experimental data, methods for obtaining the directional spectrum of waves ene rgy (frequency.wave number spectrum), conclusions. : Learning Ouctomes: At the end of the course the student will: 1. Acquire knowlede on theories and numerical solution methods in the field of nonlinear water waves. 2. Acquire knolwlede on proceses governing excitation and evolutionof water waves b the above blowing wind. 3. Acquire experience in designing and operating experimental setups,accompained by data processing for obtaining important parameters governing the nonlinear wave fields evolution both in the lab and in the open s
00180222.name: Advanced Topics in Water Waves: from Theory to Experiment

00180310.about: An engineering investigation of a selected topic in the field of environmental and water resources engineering.  It will include problem definition, literature review and.or data collection, investigation of the problem through mathematical modelling and.or experimental work, conclusions.  Results will be summarized in a professional report and an oral presentation.
00180310.name: Advanced Seminar in Evnvironmental and Water Engineering

00180417.about: Confined and unconfined flow under isotropic and anisotropic conditions.  Phreatic surface.  Piping.  Filter design.  Seepage forces.  General principles of slope stability.  Failure of slopes under various conditions of seepage.  Methods of stability analysis including computer applications.  Residual strength and progressive failure.  Models and similitude.  Choice of soil parameters.  Use of A and B coefficients.
00180417.name: Seepage and Slope Stability

00180418.about: Methods of design of sheet pile walls.  Anchors.  Slurry walls.  Types of wall supports and their influence on stress distribution on the wall.  Soil structure interaction.  Movements near excavations and retaining walls.  Overall stability.  Underground structures.  Choice of soil parameters.
00180418.name: Retaining Structures

00180420.about: Principle of effective stress in saturated and unsaturated soil.  Pore water pressure coefficients.  Stress space and stress paths. Rendulic and Henkel representations.  Soil strength criteria.  Hvorslev strength theory.  Rowe's stress dilatancy, and the Critical State approaches to soil behaviour.  The coefficient of earth pressure at rest.  Behaviour of soil under cyclic loading.  Behaviour of swelling and collapsing soils. One-week laboratory at end of semester.
00180420.name: Advanced Soil Mechanics

00180423.about: An engineering investigation on a selected topic in the field of geotechnical engineering.  The investigation will include:  1.  Definition of the problem , 2.  Critical literature survey and data collection,  3.  Analysis of existing data,  4. Investigation of the problem using theoretical models and.or laboratory and field experiments, 5.  Summary of the investigation with conclusions and recommendations for further research.  The investigation will be presented in a detailed report, and in a lecture to students and staff.
00180423.name: Advanced Seminar in Geotechnical Engineering

00180500.about: fundamentals of radiation physics, natural and artificial ionizing radiation, sources of ionizing radiation in buildings external and internal radiation, dosimetry, materials with different radionuclide contents. problem of radon gas in buildings. mechanisms of radon exhalation and transport. soil as the main source of radon. testing methods and demonstration of the spectrometry for measurements of radionuclide activity concentrations in building materials and soils. testing indoor radon concentrations and resistance of materials to radon penetration. radon mitigation in existing and new buildings. national, european and international standardization i n the field of radiation protection in construction. learning outcomes: upon completion of this course the students will have an understanding of the natural sources of ionizing radiation, will learn about the main factors influencing the radiation doses the building occupants are exposed to. and about the methods of measurement of gamma radiation and radon and their mitigation. in addition, the students will learn about controversial aspects related to public discussions about a need to make stricter the norms of radiological protec
00180500.name: Radiation Safety in Buildings

00180501.about:
systems analysis tools e.g: life cycle assessment, material flow analysis, sustainability indicators, economic valuation for evaluating the environmental and cost tradeoffs of engineering design and decision making case studies in green building design will be emphasized.
learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will: 1. have an understanding of the complexity of environmentaland sustainability issues related to engineering activities in the built environment. 
 2. have an awareness of theanalytical toolsand resources for evaluating the implications for the environment employing a systems perspective. 
 3. have applied methods and too ls related to process and economic input output lca.
00180501.name: Life Cycle Assessment in Civil and Environmental Engineering Systems

00180503.about: sample preparation and hydration stopping. testing physical properties particle size distribution and helium pycnometry. microstructure testing: mercury intrusion porosimetry and optical microscopy. thermal analysis: isothermal calorimetry, tga and dsc. mineral composition analysis by means of xrd. testing transport properties: chlorides penetration and water absorption. non-destructive testing methods. learning outcomes: upon completion of this course it is intended that the student will be able to: apply the studied experimental methods to achieve their research goals with understanding the principle, advantages, disadvantages and limitations of each  method
00180503.name: Advanced Experimental Methods for Construction Materials

00180504.about: Types of plants and methods of production. Casting of elements including: forms reinforcement, batching, conveying. Principles of mechanical compaction. Architectural finishing. Accelerated hardening at room temperature. Hot concrete. Different methods of accelerated curing at high temperatures, their effect on properties of products. Calculation of time and energy requirements. Tolerances, joints. Quality control and assurance during production and erection. Tolerances. Performance specifications including: thermal insulation, waterproofing, durability.
00180504.name: Technology of Precast Concrete Buildings

00180506.about: Effects of technology on construction schedule, economy efficiency and quality.  Construction design of: lightweight, heavyweight, mass, high strength, water proof concrete.  Special processes: pumping, shotcrete, under water concreting, slip-forming. Quality control and assurance, specifications, durability, repair.
00180506.name: Concrete Construction and Technology

00180507.about:
Engineering ivestigation  or a critical literature survey in the area of building sciences.building materials. The work will include definition of the problem, literature or engineering survey, followed by discussion and conclusions. The conclusions will be basedon the present state of knowledge, and if necessary, recommendations will be presented regarding future work. 
 Designated for the M.Eng route only.
00180507.name: Advanced Seminar in Building Sciences

00180600.about: Economic parameters of a construction venture, development stages, models for estimating of investment cost, life cycle costs, the cost of land, assessment of benefits from building activity, estimating of demand for building ventures, financing of construction ventures, investment decisions under risk, feasibility analysis of public projects.
00180600.name: Development and Feasibility Analysis of Construction Ventures

00180601.about: Construction inputs and outputs in the Israeli economy, types of construction firms, managerial functions in construction company, organization principles of construction companies, information system in construction company, strategic planning in construction, performance measurement in construction.
00180601.name: Management of a Construction Company

00180603.about: Financial Management in Construction Companies with emphasis on the following subjects: principles of accounting, preparation and analysis of financial statements, types of businesses, cost control, budgeting and budget control, taxation and financing in construction companies.
00180603.name: Financial Management in a Construction Company

00180616.about: Professional and legal responsibility of the engineer, principles of contract law with emphasis on contracts of professional service and construction:  issuance and acceptance of tenders.  Formation of construction contracts and problems flowing from their implementation, e.g. incomplete subsurface information, changed conditions and changes in the work, architectural and engineering supervision, professional insurance and indemnity, construction and third party liability and insurance thereof, delays in construction, quality of the work, performance bonds, damages and other legal remedies for breach of contract:  legal and administrative process of to wn planning, building permits, liability in tort for injury on the site and third parties, judicial and arbitral dispute resolution.
00180616.name: Legal Problems and Issues in Construction

00180617.about: Introduction to underground construction. Types of rocks and soil planning under geological uncertainties. Contractual aspects, mobilization and site organization, scheduling excavation and tunneling methods, muck removal, support methods, auxilliary tasks, pipe jacking, micro-tunneling, trench support, piles and sheet piles, anchoring and soil stabilization, case studies.
00180617.name: Planning and Methods of Underground Construction Projects

00180623.about: A five credit extended seminar with a theoretical, analytical, or experimental orientation, related to construction management. Thework will include definition of the problem, determination of methodology, problem solution, It may include critical literature survey,  development of a model,  field data gathering, etc., presentation and analysis of findings, conclusions and recommendations.  Results will be presented in a detailed written report, as well as in a lecture to students and faculty.
00180623.name: Advanced Seminar in Construction Management

00180703.about: Engineering investigation in a selected subject in transportation and highway engineering. The investigation will include: problem definition, preparation of the investigation program, critical literature survey, collection of the existing data. Data:  Data analysis using adapted models and findings with conclusions, recommendations and suggestions for future research.
00180703.name: Advanced Seminar in Transportation and Highway Engineering

00180704.about: Advanced systems in public transportation: rail, bus, ferry. Interrelationships of different systems. Advanced data collection systems.  Methods for optimal timetableing. Algorithms for vehicle scheduling for different vehicle types.  Route design at the network level and for short-term trips. Optimal synchronization in timetableling.  Intermodality within and between different modes. Priority systems. Efficient design of operations and control.
00180704.name: Advanced Systems in Public Transportation

00180706.about: travel demand analysis using activity based approaches and its implication for transportation planning. travel demand as derived from daily activities demand. estimation of system of discrete choice models and their applications using micro simulation
00180706.name: Activity Based Transportation Planning

00180708.about: statistical models in transportation planning: factor analysis, cluster analysis and structural equation models. advanced discrete choice models including probit and logit kernel. estimation based simulation, numerical maximization and the method of simulated maximum likelihood.
00180708.name: Advanced Models in Transportation Planning

00180709.about: simulation as a technique for solution of complex dynamic problems, classification of simulation techniques, classification and characteristics of traffic simulation models: macroscopic, mesoscopic, microscopic. steps in developing a simulation model: selecting amodel, experimental design, calibration and validation, conducting experiments and analysis of the results, example applications
00180709.name: Traffic Simulation Modeling

00180710.about: Syllabus: The world of infrastructures engineering and smart cities poses special challenges to engineers who will design the systems and build the technological and managerial infrastructure in the information era. The course will provide the knowledge required in complex and large systems engineering, in a multidisciplinary and multi-systemic perspective. Advanced methodologies and practical tools will be learned using the latest technologies to provide the right service to stakeholders with emphasis on users. The course will give the required knowledge in future transportation platforms for ervices and engineering, such as complex infrastructure projects, autonomous vehicles, use of AI, BD technologies, database management and solving dilemmas arising from conflicts between technology, business, innovation, and entrepreneurship for the society need. Learning Outcomes: At the end of the course the students will be able to: 1.	Understand the needs of stakeholders and society. 2.	Define the large scope of engineering and social requirements for the design and planning process, with a system and multidisciplinary perspective. 3.	Know how to prioritize projects and allocate resources
00180710.name: civil systems engineering and smart citi

00180814.about: classical and satellitic control networks. advanced reference systems. quality criteria: accuracy, reliability and sensitivity. optimization of control networks
00180814.name: Geodetic Networks Analysis

00180816.about: lidar measurements, dsm-data sources, accuracy analysis, quality control, vector data analysis, terrain representation and tin, grid analysis-interpolation, visibility, filers (smoothing, edges, median) shading, merging overlapping dsms, spatial analysis-spectralanalysis shape analysis, automatic feature extraction from dsm (tin - triangulated irregular network).
00180816.name: Topographic Analysis

00180817.about: advanced data entry techniques, data conversion, raster to vector, data projection, topology: principles and application via advanced spatial analysis, advanced database structure: geodatabase, geo- relational data model vs. object-component data model, advanced 3d applications, raster data model application, network analysis, linear referencing, conflation, spatial statistics, geocoding, gis-cad integration, web-based gis innovations.
00180817.name: Geo-Spatial Data Processing

00180819.about: advanced image processing, object extraction using morphological and multi-spectral methods, hyper-spectral remote sensing: principle components analysis and clustering, image interpretation using artificial neural networks, expert systems and fuzzy logic, data mining.
00180819.name: Multi Dimensional Remote Sensing

00180821.about: gis application development: introduction, data collection and integration from various sources, projections and non-linear conversions, integration of spatial data models and algorithms, creation and maintenance of topological structures,building and maintaininga geodatabase, application development using a scripting language, applications via development language
00180821.name: Applied Gis Workshop

00180823.about: models and methods in gps data processing. the solution of the integer ambiguity. single epoch solution. geodetic control networks based on permanent gps stations, vrs and rtk
00180823.name: Satellite Geodesy

00180825.about: correlation analysis. unsolvable problems and tikhonov regularization
00180825.name: Spectral Analysis in Geodesy

00180826.about: the analysis of general problems in real-esate appraising. preparation of a full real-estate appraising report (including: gathering zoning.planning, legal and market information, structuring the appropriate principles, factors and considerations, value calculations and conclusion, writing and presenting the full appraising report). the seminar topics include both the theoretical aspects of real-estateappraising and the more empirical.practical aspects of fieldwork.
00180826.name: Advanced Seminar in Real Estate Studies

00190001.about: Review of linear algebra. Positive definite matrices. Equilibrium equations: discrete and continuous systems. Laplace equation. Analytical methods: Fourier series, convolutions, Fourier transform, complex variables and conformal mapping.
00190001.name: Fundamental Mathematics for Engineers

00190003.about: NUMERICAL METHODS FOR SOLVING ENGINEERING PROBLEMS: SOLVING SYSTEMS OF LINEAR EQUATIONS WITH AN EMPHASIS ON SPARSE MATRICES, ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS - IVP AND BVP, SOLVING ELLIPTICAL AND PARABOLIC PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS USING FDM-, FINDING A MINIMUM AND A MAXIMUM OF FUNCTIONS USING DETERMINISTIC AND STOCHASTIC METHODS, INTERPOLATION AND NUMERICAL INTEGRATION. THE COURSE WILL BE ACCOMPANIED BY A NUMBER OF LARGE HOME EXERCISES THAT WILL GIVE THE STUDENT BETTER UNDERSTANDING BY SOLVING REAL-WORLD PROBLEMS.
00190003.name: Numerical Methods in Engineering

00190004.about: Tensors, tensor functions, tensor fields. Material and spatial description of continuum. Deformation gradient and strains. Velocity, velocity gradient and spin. Conservation of mass. Momentum balance and stress. Energy and entropy. Classical material models. General
00190004.name: Introduction to Continuum Mechanics

00190006.about: Advanced linear programming. Network theory. Concepts and definitions. The maximum-flow problem: augmentation algorithm - application and extension. The minimum spanning tree problem. The multi-terminal minimal cuts problem. Synthesis of a network. The shortest path algorithm - Dijkstra, Pert, Bellman-Ford, Yen, Floyd. The minimum cost-flow problem: flow planning between origins and destinations. Optimum centers in a network with applications. Optimum circuits in a network (Eulerian circuit, the chinese postman problem, Hamiltonian circuits). In addition - selected topics in dynamic programming, and scheduling problems.
00190006.name: Quantitation Methods in Engineering and Management Systems

00190007.about:
Approximations to probability distributions (the central limit theorem, further studies in known distributions).  Estimation (some properties of estimators, confidence intervals, selecting the sample size). Methods of estimation and properties of joint estimators(the methods of moments and maximum liklihood, efficiency, consistency).
 Hypothesis testing (common large-sample tests, calculating type II error and sample size, testing hypothesis concerning means and variances).  Linear regression (the least squares method, approximations to non-linear models), and the basis of non-linear regression. Introduction to stochastic processes (random arrival, in ter-arrival time distribution).
00190007.name: Selected Topics in Statistics

00190054.name: Seminar in Advanced Problem in Agriculture

00190057.about: The course will introduce the sstudents t6o a variety of advanced topics in environemntal and water engineering and sciences topics. The students will be exposure to these topics through participation in seminars given on these topics.
00190057.name: Seminar in Environment and Water Engineering

00190058.about: In depth study of recent developments in water, soil, and environmental science and engineering. A detailed outline will be provided by the lecturer and the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is given. Spring semester: Recycling Biorefineries. Winter semester 2018q.019: Modeling flow and transport phenomena in porous media.
00190058.name: Advanced Study in Agricultural Engineering

00190062.about: Systems:  State variables, boundary conditions.  Reality, model, simulation, optimization. Multi-compartment systems. Continuous deterministic models. Stochastic events. Reduction and simplification. Verification. Population dynamics. Environmental systems.
00190062.name: Models and Simulations of Natural System

00190136.about: Basic concepts, variable types, constraints, objective function. various formulations of optimal design problems. Structural optimization methods. applications in various structural elements and complex systems. Optimization of large scale structures.
00190136.name: Optimal Structural Design

00190141.about: Displacements, velocities and accelerations - relative and absolute. Lagrange's equations for discrete systems. Continuous systems,free and forces: beams and plates. Effect of damping. Wave equations in one dimensional problems. Numerical solutions. Variational methods applied to vibrations of beams, with and without shear forces. Hamilton's principle, Rayleigh-Ritz method. Use of computers for solution of practical problems.
00190141.name: Dynamics of Structures 1

00190145.about: Concepts of Serviceability and Safety. Constitutive Relationships of Concrete and Steel. Stages of Flexural Behavior of Reinforced Concrete Beams. Theoretical Predictions of Moment-Curvature Relationship. Biaxial Bending. Ductility and Deformations at Ultimate Limit State, Load-Moment Interaction Curves for Columns, Bond, shear.
00190145.name: Selected Topics in Reinforced Concrete

00190148.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the Committee for Graduate Studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00190148.name: Advanced Topics in Structures

00190149.about: basic continuum mechanics: tensors, kinematics, stresses, equilibrium. constitutive equations: hyperelasticity, material inhomogeneity and anisotropy, models of soft materials. electro-active materials: electro-mechanical coupling, coupled boundary-value problems. chemo- active materials: chemo-mechanical coupling, coupled boundary-value problems.
00190149.name: Mechanics of Soft Materials

00190206.about: Analysis and use of stochastic data.  Multiobjective decision making. Detailed formulation and solution of water resources problems: capacity expansion, development and operation of surface water systems, development and management of aquifers, treatment and re-use of sewage effluents, combined regional systems, reservoir operation, design and operation of distribution systems.  Each student will carry out a project in the course of the semester.  (No final examination).
00190206.name: Water Resources Systems Engineering 2

00190309.about: HYSICO-CHEMICAL WATER TREATMENT PROCESSES. IN THE FIRST HALF OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS  WILL COMPREHENSIVELY COVER ACID-BASE AND REDOX REACTIONS, COMPLEXATION OF METALS WITH HYDROXYL AND OTHER COMMON LIGANDS, AND CHEMICAL COMPLEX-BASED CHEMICAL PRECIPITATION IN SALINE SOLUTIONS. THE THEORETICAL PART WILL END WITH LEARNING TO SIMULATE WATER TREATMENT REACTIONS WITH THE SOFTWARE PHREEQC. THE SECOND PART OF THE COURSE WILL ADDRESS GENERAL DESIGN OF SEVERAL WATER TREATMENT PROCESSES: CHEMICAL AND PHYSICAL PRECIPITATION AND SETTLING, REGULAR AND ADVANCED (FREE RADICALS) OXIDATION, ION EXCHANGE, ACTIVATED CARBON ADSORPTION AND DISINFECTION (INCLUDING BY PRO DUCTS).
00190309.name: Advanced Water Treatment

00190310.about: Wastewater characterization, interrelationship between quality parameters. Disposal methods and effluent quality requirements. General overview of treatment processes.  Pre- and primary treatment. Principles of biological treatment - thermodynamic and kinetic considerations.  Suspended growth processes, activated sludge, aerated lagoons, oxidation ponds.  Biological nitrogen removal. Fixed film processes:  Trickling filters and biodisc.  Sludge handling:  Dewatering, drying and ultimate disposal. Physical.chemical treatment, wastewater renovation.
00190310.name: Advanced Wastewater Treatment

00190315.about: Study and search for relevant information on an environment-related topic, a comprehensive scientific.engineering summary of the subject, and its presentation in the classroom. Also, participation in 30 departmental seminars within a maxmum of three consecutive semesters from the date of registering for the course, and writing of an one-page summary of six of these seminars, as discussed in class.
00190315.name: Environmental Engineering Seminar

00190318.about: Topics: Chemical equilibrium, mathematical methods for systems in chemical equilibrium, the carbonate system, Kinetics, solubility and complexation, redox chemistry, introduction to environmental organic chemistry, photochemistry, the physical and chemical structure of the atomosphere, tropospheric chemistry, the ozone hole, principals and applications of analytical instrumentation for environmental chemistry.
00190318.name: Environmental Chemistry

00190324.about: Environmental Quality and public health aspects of water and wastewater systems.  Water in nature.  Parameters that define the composition and nature of water and wastewater.  Processes for treatment of water and wastewater and their integration into systems for quality control.  (This course is intended for students without engineering background).
00190324.name: Principles of Water and Wastewater Sanitation

00190326.about: Physical properties and chemical composition of municipal solid wastes.  Storage and transport systems.  Disposal methods includinglandfill, incineration, composing pyrolysis and disposal to sea. Recycling and resource recovering of solid wastes.  Disposal management, economics, analysis of performance and costs.
00190326.name: Treatment and Disposal of Solid Wastes

00190335.about: Aerosols: their occurence, sources and effects.  Physical properties of atmospheric particles:  size distribution,  sedimentation and coagulation.  Particles and water vapor.  Optical and electrical properties.  Chemical characterization of atmospheric particles.Distribution of particles in the troposphere and stratosphere. Particle sampling and analysis.  Recent aerosol studies.
00190335.name: Atmospheric Aerosols

00190340.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the Committee for Graduate Studies prior to the beginning of the term. Winter semester 2018.2019: Phreeqc Basics.
00190340.name: Advanced Topics in Environmental Engineering

00190341.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the Committee for Graduate Studies prior to the beginning of the term. Spring Semester 2017.2018: Advanced modeling of flow and transport in unsaturated media.
00190341.name: Advanced Topics in Environmental Quality

00190424.about: Background, seismology, measurements characteristics of earthquakes. Behaviour of soil under cyclic loading. Vertical shear wave propagation. Site response. Behaviour of shallow and deep foundations and retaining walls during earth quakes. Slope stability.
00190424.name: Geotechnical Earthquake Engineering

00190427.about: STRESSES AND STRAINS, YIELDING AND PLASTIC FLOW, FORMULATION OF ELASTIC-PERFECTLY PLASTIC CONSTITUTIVE MODEL, INCLUSION OF ISOTROPIC STRAIN HARDENING, NUMERICAL INTEGRATION, MODIFIED CAM-CLAY AND CRITICAL STATE SOIL MECHANICS, KINEMATIC HARDENING AND BOUNDING SURFACE PLASTICITY, POSTULATES OF UPPER AND LOWER BOUNDS, VELOCITY HODOGRAPH, STRESS FIELDS AND STRESS DISCONTINUITIES, THE SLIP-LINE METHOD, NUMERICAL TECHNIQUES FOR LOWER AND UPPER BOUND SOLUTIONS, THE MOBILIZED STRENGTH DESIGN (MSD) METHOD.
00190427.name: Constitutive Laws in Geomechanics

00190430.about: Bearing capacity equations. Correction factors related to soil compressibility. Shallow foundations on layered soil. Soil structureinteraction effect of structure rigidity on soil stress distribution, example of raft foundation. Elastic approach to pile analysisbased on mindlin. Wave equation analysis of driven piles, pile integrity testing, analysis of loading tests, foundation in swellingclays.
00190430.name: Foundations

00190431.about: tunneling methods, tunnel stability analysis, elastic and elasto -plastic solution for tunneling induced ground displacement, empirical methods, consideration of 2d and 3d aspects in modeling, tunneling effects on existing nearby pipelines and tunnels, tunneling effects on nearby building and determination of performance criteria, design of monitoring systems. course objectives: this course various geotechnical and structural aspects of tunneling in soft ground and the effect of tunneling induced ground displacements on nearby structures such as buried pipelines and buildings. the course is an advanced course requiring proficiency in geotechnical engin eering as well as good understanding of structural engineering. students who complete the course will be capable of evaluating various engineering risks associated with tunneling in soft grounds (sands and clays) and to select and design supporting systems, as well as evaluate the stressing (and damage) of nearby structures. learning outcomes: a student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to: 1. evaluate the tunneling induces ground settlement troughs using various methods. 2. calculate the tunnel stability and the
00190431.name: TUNNELING IN SOFT GROUND

00190432.about: arching and basic principles of buried structures design, stresses in elastic media with a cavity (elliptic, squared, rectangular, spherical , horseshoe), lined tunnels with circular and non-circular cross sections, thick prefabricated and monolithic linings, thin-wall linings (rectangular, elliptic, arches), spherical lined cavity, seismic and dynamic behavior of buried lined and non-lined structures learning outcomes: students who will complete the course requirements will be familiar with various types of buried structures and analysis methods for evaluating the developed stresses in buried structural elements, as well as to perform structural desig n of the relevant components
00190432.name: MECHANICS OF BURIED STRUCTURES

00190512.about: Chemical and mineral composition of Portland Cement, methods of its determination and their practical implications.  The cement water system.  Hydration, factors affecting rate of hydration, hydration products.  Mechanical properties of the cement-stone and the factors affecting these properties.  Structure of the cement-stone, sorption isotherms, Power's model, Feldman-Sereda's model.  Critical evaluation of models.  The system cement-paste aggregate, bond between paste and aggregate.  Concrete properties.  Corrosion of the cement and durability of concrete.
00190512.name: Advanced Chapters in Cementitious Materials

00190619.about: current construction management practice - common tools and points of failure:difficulties, inefficiencies, waste. measures of success. methods for managing design, information and production in various branches of engineering. value generation, production flow, pull- scheduling and computerized information management. application of lean management principles in design and construction of built facility projects.
00190619.name: Lean Construction-Production Management in Design and Construction

00190621.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the Committee for Graduate Studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00190621.name: Advanced Topics in Construction Management

00190624.about: management of construction projects at the initiation stage: project scope definition, decision methods, planning under uncertainty, project context and main stake holders, organizational structures and procurement methods, brief preparation, project design, statutory limits, land expropriation processes.
00190624.name: Construction Projects at the Initiation Stage

00190625.about: changes in the fundamental assumptions regarding project management, planning and control under uncertainty, creating result oriented focus challenging the status quo,teamwork based on interdependence and trust intensive communication, adapting the principles of project management to the unique context of the project, the roles of the project manager during the various stages of the project, managing an organizational change.
00190625.name: Project Management in Dynamic Environmen

00190627.about: principles of building information capturing parametrics, object- oriented modeling, capturing design intent, visualization, engineering analyses, fabrication detailing and automation, interoperability and model servers, integrated project delivery. students willparticipate in a multi-disciplinary team project covering the building lifecycle from concept to fabrication using cnc.
00190627.name: Advanced Building Information Modeling

00190702.about: AASHO Road Test:  pavement performance and roughness measurements. Design of flexible pavements based on AASHO Road Test results.  Stress distribution in layered system.  Material characterization:  resilient and permanent behaviour, fatigue.  Design methods based on theory of elasticity.  Pavement evaluation and rehabilitation.
00190702.name: Advanced Design of Flexible Pavements

00190704.about: Laboratory engineering investigation on a selected topic related to the evaluation of properties of unstabilized pavement materials(subgrade, subbase, and base courses).  The investigation will include:  a preliminary literature survey, preparation of testing program, execution of laboratory work and preparation of a summarized engineering report.
00190704.name: Road Building Materials - Laboratory 1

00190705.about: Laboratory engineering investigation on a selected topic related to the evaluation of properties of stabilized pavement materials and bituminous mixtures.  The investigation will include:  a preliminary literature survey, preparation of testing program, executionof laboratory work and preparation of a summarized engineering report.
00190705.name: Road Building Materials - Laboratory 2

00190707.about: Vibration compaction of pavement layers.  Recycling of pavement materials.  Cold asphalt mixtures.  Advances in geotextile layers. New technologies in concrete:  prestressed pavements, continuous reinforcement pavements, fibre-concrete pavements.  Stabilization of pavement material.  Methods for pavement evaluation.  Energy considerations in paving technologies.  Pavement management systems.
00190707.name: Advanced Technology in Pavement Construction

00190709.about: The systems approach and its application to transportation engineering and planning. Transportation network analysis and equilibrium assignment. Volume-delay functions. Formulations of the deterministic user equilibrium problem. Stochastic user equilibrium problem. Route Choice models. Algorithms to solve the deterministic and stochastic traffic assignment.
00190709.name: Transportation Network Analysis

00190710.about: The theory of travel demand modeling and forecasting for transportation system. The theory of discrete choice model and random utility theory. The logit and nested logit models. Estimation, statistical test and evaluation of discrete choice models and their application for travel demand analysis.
00190710.name: Demand Modelling

00190714.about: Transportation and town planning. Traffic flow characteristics in urban area. Freeways and tollways. Traffic characteristics of unsignalized intersections. Gap acceptance. Special intersections (staggered and rotary intersections). Weaving sections. Trucks impacton urban traffic. Pedestrian flow and level of service. Traffic system management.
00190714.name: Advanced Traffic Engineering

00190717.about: Accident distributions on a road network, accident rates, evaluation of road safety improvements, the effects of geometric and traffic characteristrics on road safety at sections.  Safety aspects of intersection design:  traffic conflicts, exposure and accident rates. Pedestrian safety and economic considerations in safety improvements.
00190717.name: Safety in Traffic Engineering

00190718.about: Non signalised intersection:  delays, capacity, signing.  Isolated signalised intersection:  Delays, capacity, detours, different design tactics for fixed signals, traffic actuated signals (basic, volume density and traffic adaptive control).  Green wave, off line and on line optimization, computer programs.
00190718.name: Traffic Control

00190719.about: The driving task:  models, influencing factors.  Driver information systems:  signing, road markings, road delineation.  Driving behavior in traffic and traffic control methods.  Research methods:  accident analysis, counts and observations, laboratory and field experiments. Design for driver, pedestrian and passenger protection.
00190719.name: Human Factors in Transportation 1

00190721.about: Basic concepts in economics, utility theory, indifference curves, consumer surplus, production function, urban congestion, road pricing, public transport, economic evaluation, vehicle operating costs, value of time.
00190721.name: Transport Economics

00190725.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the Committee for Graduate Studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00190725.name: Advanced Topics in Transportation Engineering

00190813.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the Committee for Graduate Studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00190813.name: Advanced Topics - Mapping and Geo-Information Engineering

00190814.about: Geometry and orientation of continuous cameras and dynamic imagery. The use of stereoscopic satellite images for calculating planimetric and altimetric data.  Orientating blocks of close range, analog or digital, sets of images, taken from arbitrary  positions and in arbitrary attitudes.
00190814.name: Advanced Applications in Analytical Photogrammetry

00340010.about: Kinematics of particle, motion in different coordinates systems, angular velocity, rotating coordinate system, relative velocity and acclerations, rigid body kinematics. Particular solutions of the equations of motion, energy methods, impulse and momentum. Equations of motion, center of mass, balances of linear and angular momentum, resultant force and moment, kinetic and potential energies, balance of energy, conservative systems, impact. Rigid body dynamics: interia tensor, angular momentum, kinetic energy, equations ofmotion, impulse, pure planar motion, three-dimensional motion, dynamic balancing, Euler equations, gyroscopic effects.
00340010.name: Dynamics

00340013.about: Continuum, properties of fluids, stress, shear and pressure. Hydrostaties. Kinematics, description of motion, streamlines. Integralcontinuity and momentum equations. Newtonian fluids, Navier-Stokes equations and boundary conditions. Flow far from a body: Eular equation. Bernoulli's equation, lift. Flow near a surface: boundary layer eqns, shear, drag, similarity laws. Turbulent flow: pipe flow, turbulent boundary layer, correlations, forces on bodies. One-dimensional compressible flow: nozzles, shock wave. Fanno and Rayleigh lines.
00340013.name: Fluid Mechanics 1

00340015.about: Introduction: stages of the design process and requirements from machine elements. Review of components. Fundamental criteria of failure in static and fatique loads. Joints: screws, seals, riveting, pins etc. Welded joints.
00340015.name: Mechanical Engineering Design 1

00340016.about: Continuation of 034015 with attention to more complex elements which require an iterative design process and optimization. Solutionof open problems and analysis of component failure e.g.spur, bevel and helical gears, ball and roller bearings. Hydrodynamic bearings. Clutches and brakes.
00340016.name: Mechanical Engineering Design 2

00340022.about: Introduction of electronic circuit analysis and design principles, with emphasis, and examples from mechatronics. Basic components and semi-conductor components. Principles of circuit analysis. Circuit response to analog and digital inputs. Analog systems and circuits based on operational amplifiers. Digital electronics, gates, and logic circuits. Flip flops and circuits based on flip flops.
00340022.name: Introduction to Mechatronics

00340028.about: Vectors, resultant forces and moments, equilibrium of systems and structures (free body diagram), trusses, franes and machines, principle of virtual work, distributed loads, center of mass, force and moment diagrams in beams, uniaxial stress and uniaxial strain, Hooke's laws, failure, statically indeterminate problems, uniaxial thermal strains, displacements and strains of truss members, the stiffness matrix, torsion, shear stress.
00340028.name: Solid Mechanics 1

00340029.about: Stress tensor, strain tensor, sress-strain relation (Hooke's law), failure criteria, normal stress and shear streaaes in bending ofbeams, defledtions os eastic beams, energy-methods for calculating deformations, statically indeterminate beams and frames, buckling of columns.
00340029.name: Solid Mechanics 2

00340030.about: basic concepts in material processes and the design of simple process planning of an industrial product. acquaintance with basic processes: machining (lathing, milling, etc.), forming processes (extrusion, forging, deep drawing), and assembly. machines and tools for these processes, thermal, mechanic and dynamic characteristics of machine.process. basic concepts in quality control and manufacturing cost consideration. matching manufacturing with product design and manufacturing systems. in an accompanying laboratory the use of machine tools in their various operations will be exercised. use of measuring machines. introduction to computer aided manufact uring and design.
00340030.name: Manufacturing Processes

00340032.about: Introduction, signal and systems (continuous, discrete), linear algebra (review, vector spaces), state space - continuous.discrete systems, canonical realizations, linearization, matrix functions, solutions of state equations in the time domain, modes, impulse response, reconstruction of initial conditions, solving state equations by transforms. Laplace transform, Z transform, convolution integral and summation, matrix transfer function. Norms of signals and systems, connecting systems, stability of systems, frequency response, graphical representations, modal analysis of vibrating mechanical systems,
00340032.name: Linear Systems M

00340033.about: Systems of linear algebraic equations. Interpolation. Numerical integration. Numerical differentiation. Ordinary differential equations: initial value problems. Boundary value problems.
00340033.name: Numerical Analysis M

00340034.about: Magnetic circuits. Transformers. Electromagnetic devices. DC motors: principal of operation, circuit model, dynamic behavior, electronics of driver circuits. Stepper motors: principle of operation, dynamic behavior, electronics of driver circuits. Brushless dc motors. Selection of small motors. AC motors: generation of a rotating field, synchronous motors, 3-phase induction motors, circuit model, mechanical characteristics. Position and velocity control of DC and AC motors.
00340034.name: Electric Actuators

00340035.about: Basic concepts, system, properties, states, process, Zeroth and First laws. Energy, enthalpy. Applications of the first law to closed and open systems. Pure substance: liquid-vapor and single phase systems. Ideal gas. The Second law: Carnot principle, thermodynamic temperature, entropy. The second law for control volume. Work cycles-vapor and gas. Refrigeration cycles. Gas mixtures.
00340035.name: Thermodynamics 1

00340039.about: Temperature measurement, strain and stress measurements, measurement of force and torque, pressure measurement, velocity and flow rate measurement, displacement, size, force and power measurement.
00340039.name: Experimental Methods Laboratory

00340040.about: Introduction. Simplification of block diagrams. Modeling and DC motor. Open loop control. Feedback and closed loop control scheme. Internal stability. Steady-state performance. Dynamic performance. Root-Locus method. Signal and systems in the frequency domain. Nyquist stability criteria. Stability margins. Systems with dead-times. Design of lead-lag controllers. Realization and tuning of PID controllers.
00340040.name: Introduction to Control

00340043.about: Basic concepts in parametric and associative cad. Introduction to designt intent. Principles of 3-D part modeling in cad. Topics incomputer based part drawing. Basic principles of 3-D assembly drawing in cad. Computer based measure and tolerance assignment.
00340043.name: Computer Based Engineering Drawing

00340044.about: Basic concepts: accuracy, repeatability, sensitivity, measurement error, hysteresis. Review of first and second order systems, response function. Static and dynamic measurments. Data acquisition and processing. Experimental system design. Statistical measurement theory. Techniques for temperature measurement, strain and stress measurements. Measurement of force and torque, pressure measurement, velocity and flow rate measurement, displacement, size, force, power measurement. Technical writing.
00340044.name: Int. to Experimental Methods and Meas.

00340045.about: The economic analysis of engineering decisions uses concepts of discounting, interest, time, inflation, price, value, depreciation,taxes, etc. We study intuitions and quantifications of these concepts. We examine economic decisions in engineering, with special emphasis on uncertainty. We study info-gap robustness analysis and probabilistic tools for risk evaluation.
00340045.name: Introduction to Economic Decision Making for Engineers

00340047.about: fluid mechanics measurement techniques: integral load measurements, pressure measurements: manometry, pressure transducers, calibration, unsteady measurements, pressure sensitive paint, flow visualization techniques, volumetric measurements, velocity measurements: pitot tube, prandtl tube, hot-wire anemometry, laser doppler anemometry, particle image velocimetry, turbulence measurements with different techniques, wall shear-stress measurements.
00340047.name: Advanced Laboratory in Fluid Mechanics

00340048.about: Principles of descriptive engineering:  projection methods, lines and planes, axonometry, prismatic bodies, rotational bodies, developments, metal sheet bending. Mechanical drawings principles: wiews, cuts, assembly drawings, standards. Dimensioning and Tolerancing: standards, dimensioning methods, tolerances, geometrical tolerances, tolerance calculations.
00340048.name: Introduction to Engineering Drawing

00340051.about: EQUATION OF MOTION FOR AN OSCILLATOR, NATURAL FREQUENCY AND INERTIA, EQUIVALENT STIFFNESS, ENERGY AND POWER BALANCE, NONLINEAR OSCILLATOR, PHASE PLANE, STABILITY, RESPONSE TO IMPULSE, BASE EXCITATION, ECCENTRIC MASS, VIBRATION ISOLATION, MULTI DEGREES OF FREEDOM SYSTEMS. MODES OF VIBRATION, VIRTUAL WORK, INTRODUCTION TO LAGRANGE EQUATIONS. EQUATIONS DECOUPLING, VIBRATION IN COMPLEX FORM. APPROXIMATION METHODS SWEPT SINE EXCITATION. LABORATORY EXERCISE AND PROJECT.
00340051.name: Dynamics and Mechanics of Vibration

00340052.about: development and production of a complete small formula racecar, which includes the entire process of design, construction, integration, manufacturing, assembly, marketing, economic analysis, experimental testing and final use. an experimental and.or theoretical study is performed within a specific problem area that the student wishes to deepen a knowledge within.
00340052.name: Flagship Project - Formula Racecar

00340053.about: stress tensor, strain tensor, stress-strain relations (hooke s law), yield and failure criteria, introduction to linear elasticity (equations of equilibrium, solution of classical problems), area moment of inertia, normal and shear stresses in bending of beams, deflections of elastic beams, energy-methods for calculating deformations, buckling of columns.
00340053.name: Solid Mechanics 2M

00340054.about: study of mechanical components and mechanical elements design. learn failure criteria under static and fatigue loading and safety factors. ability to analyze and calculate mechanical joints: screws, seals, rivets, pins, welds. design of mechanical elements: springs, power screws, shafts, bearings, spur gears, worm gears, clutches, brakes and elementary mechanisms.
00340054.name: Mechanical Design 1M

00340055.about: introduction: continuum, stress, fluid, viscosity. control volume and integral description: mass conservation, momentum, angular momentum and energy equations. bernoulli s equation. dimensional analysis and similarity laws. kinematics: streamlines, streaklines, and pathlines. stream-function and material derivative. differential description: continuity and momentum equations. hydrostatics. newtonian fluids, naiver-stokes equations and boundary conditions. normalization of equations, nondimensional numbers and order-of-magnitude analysis. exact solutions. surface tension: contact angle, young-laplace equation and capillary rise. stokes equations. euler equations and potential flow. boundary layers: differential and integral boundary layer equations, approximate solutions, viscous forces and drag. laminar and turbulent flow in pipes: reynolds  experiment, turbulence, moody diagram, losses and engineering bernoulli s equation. experimenting with fluid mechanics as part of a personal or group project.
00340055.name: Fluid Mechanics 1M

00340056.about: 1. introduction to scientific computing 2. solving linear equations: a. gaussian elimination. b. lu decomposition. c. matrices  norms and condition number. d. iterative methods 3. solving nonlinear equations 4. introduction to optimization 5. qr factorization, applications, eigenvalues, singular values. 6. interpolation theory. 7. numerical integration and differentiation. 8. ordinary differential equations: initial value problems and boundary value problems.
00340056.name: Int. to Scientific and Eng. Computing

00340057.about: acquaintance with all parts of experimental systems (sensors, signal processing, sampling). understanding sources of experimental errors and ways of identifying them. acquaintance with the dynamic response of sensors and its implications. acquaintance with experimental methods common in mechanical engineering. training in the design of experimental systems. training in the analysis of experimental systems and experimental results.
00340057.name: Advanced Lab in Mechanical Engineering

00340058.about: the first part of the course introduces basic concepts of probability theory: basic rules of probability, combinatorics, conditional probability, discrete and continuous random variables, and the central limit theorem. the second part focuses on statistical inference and includes descriptive statistics, sampling distribution, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit tests, tests of independence and simple linear regression.
00340058.name: Probability and Statistics for Mech.Eng.

00340059.about: STUDENTS WILL BE EXPOSED TO SPECIFIC LECTURES AND TOURS IN THE PARTICIPATING FACULTIES. TOPICS TO BE REVIEWED: STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING! GEOINFORMATION! WATER ENGINEERING! TRANSPORTATION! ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING. ROBOTICS! ENERGY! SUSTAINABILITY! SOLID MECHANICS!CONTROL! OPTICS! BIOMECHANICS. CHEMISTRY BIOCHEMISTRY ENGINEERING! BIOMATERIALS! MEDICAL MATERIALS! MATERIALS FOR MICROELECTRONICS AND QUANTUM! MATERIALS FOR PRODUCTION AND STORAGE OF ENERGY.
00340059.name: INT. TO ENGINEERING

00340205.about: Power units: low pressure tanks (industrial and airborne), pumps, motors and hydrostatic transmissions. Accumulators and high pressure vessels. Piping systems: production technologies and applications of pipes. Tubes & hoses. Pressure thermal stress analysis. Dynamic pressure propagation and losses. Seals: static and dynamic seal design. Leakage analysis for liquids & gases. Hydraulic locks &its prevention.
00340205.name: Pneumatic and Hydraulic Components 1

00340210.about: Classification and operation ranges of turbo-pumps. Structure and principles of operation of turbo-pumps. Losses and efficiencies. Characteristic curves. Design of pumping systems. Similarity rules. Sample calculations. Computerized design of turbo-machines. (Thecourse includes only the fluid engineering aspects and not the mechanical design of turbo-machinery).
00340210.name: Turbomachinery and Jet Engines 1

00340353.about: A design project of a complex system will be performed, from definition of a need and specification, through conceptual and productdesign, including the construction of a prototype and its testing. Several teams of students will be working for two semesters each, altogether 4-5 semesters. Each team will prepare a full report that will be part of the general report. A full cycle of design andconstruction will be emphasized, by using up-to-date design methods and engineering science.
00340353.name: Design of a New Project 1

00340355.about: The final research project. (supervised by faculty members only) comprises self-learning of the research topic, literature review, definition of the research goal and overview of the different methodologies to tackle the defined research goal. Description of the experimental, theoretical and numerical solutions or combinations of them, oral presentation and written report of results and conclusions.
00340355.name: Research Project in Mechanical Eng. 1

00340371.about: design of an engineering project, based on elements that are being taught in "engineering design 1". tutoring will be enlarged on: tolerancing, materials, processes and fixtures. the project will include: concept selection, embodiment design including analysis and structure optimization and detailed design in computerized drawings. the design will include all the required data for manufacturing.
00340371.name: Design for Manufacturing Project

00340379.about: the engineering project is a final "cap-stone" project at the faculty of mechanical engineering in different fields such as energy,robotics, computer aided design (cad), micro-electro mechanical systems (mems), (bio-)mechanics, naval design, optical systems, mechatronics, control and combinations of them. the final project is a synthesis of all relevant topics that the students acquired during their first three years of studies. besides the general prerequisites, in addition there are specific prerequisites according to the different project groups as published in moodle.
00340379.name: Engineerng Project 1

00340380.about: the engineering project is a final "cap-stone" project at the faculty of mechanical engineering in different fields such as energy,robotics, computer aided design (cad), micro-electro mechanical systems (mems), (bio-)mechanics, naval design, optical systems, mechatronics, control and combinations of them. the final project is a synthesis of all relevant topics that the students acquired during their first three years of studies. besides the general prerequisites, in addition there are specific prerequisites according to the different project groups as published in moodle.
00340380.name: Engineering Project 2

00340381.about: The final research project. (supervised by faculty members only) comprises self-learning of the research topic, literature review, definition of the research goal and overview of the different methodologies to tackle the defined research goal. Description of the experimental, theoretical and numerical solutions or combinations of them, oral presentation and written report of results and conclusions.
00340381.name: Research Project in Mechanical Eng. 2

00340382.about: the participants will learn mechanical product development methodology that will be applied during the process of project development. they will learn the main project milestones, from requirements through needed design reviews to the implementation of the designin detailed development reports accompanied by a built model (simulation) or a prototype.
00340382.name: Engineering Development Methodology 2

00340401.about: Experiences on kinematics, control, programming, and simulation of robots.  Equipment:  educational robots, industrial robot (Puma)vision system.
00340401.name: Advanced Robotics Laboratory

00340404.about: Different topics will be selected each year.  Typical topics are: solid modeling, design simulation of robots, manufacturing and numerically controlled systems, dynamics, etc.
00340404.name: Advanced Laboratory in Cad.Can

00340406.about: Demonstration of principles studied in the courses "Control Theory" and "Industrial Automation."
00340406.name: Advanced Control and Automation Laboratory

00340410.about: DEVELOPMENT AND DESIGN OF A PROJECT IN THE ENERGY FIELD BASED ON A TASK DEFINITION AND A BACKGROUND LITERATURE (THERE ARE NO TUTORIALS). THE PROJECT EXECUTION DEPENDS ON THE DESIGN PROGRESS. AT THE END OF THE SEMESTER, A FINAL REPORT SUMMARIZING THE PROJECT DEVELOPMENT, DESIGN AND EXECUTION (IF RELEVANT) ACHIEVEMENTS WILL BE SUBMITTED.
00340410.name: Advanced Energy Laboratory

00340411.about: PERFORMANCE OF DIESEL AND SPARK IGNITION ENGINES, ENGINE ENERGY BALANCE, VOLUMETRIC EFFICIENCY, MECHANICAL LOSSES AND METHODS OF THEIR ASSESSMENT, POLLUTANT EMISSIONS BY DIESEL AND SPARK IGNITION ENGINES, EMISSIONS CONTROL. OPERATING PRINCIPLE AND PERFORMANCE OF STIRLING ENGINE. DESIGN AND PERFORMANCE OF PISTON COMPRESSORS. TECHNICAL VISIT.
00340411.name: Ad.Lab.Internal Combustion Engines

00340413.about: Design of a mechanical product with electrical motors. Use of shafts, bearings, transmissions and motors and their analysis in otder to meet the requirements. Tolerance, material selection, coatings and heat treatments. Preparation of production drawings, product's, production, assembly and testing in the lab.
00340413.name: Design and Manufacturing Laboratory

00340422.about: Topics: the speed of light. holography. optical levitation. light as an electromagnetic wave. black body radiation and quantum optics. optimal design and imaging. optical alignment. resonators. waveguides. acousto optics. vision systems. polarization and spatial filters. design, fabrication and characterization of optical fibers.
00340422.name: Optics Laboratory

00350001.about: Rigid body transformations. Direct and inverse kinematics for robotic arms. The Jacobian. Workspace geometry and manipulability indices. Robot dynamics. Trajectory planning. Robot sensors.
00350001.name: Introduction to Robotics

00350003.about: Principles of Interactive Computer Aided Geometric Desin (CAGD). Raster-scan Display System. 3D geometrical transformations. Homogeneous coordinate. 3D viewing: perspective and parallel projections. Mapping into a viewport. Color models: RGB, CMY, YIQ, HSV. Lightmodel. Texture mapping. Visible determination: backface elimination, depth sorting, Z-buffer. Rendering techniques of shaded images. Ray tracing. Introduction to geometric modelers.
00350003.name: Cad Systems 1

00350008.about: Simplification of switching functions and their implementation. Electric and pneumatic sensors and industrial switching elements. Ladder diagrams:  relay cascade method, Huffman method. Sequential systems with random inputs. Programmable  controllers. Pneumatic circuits:  cylinders, cascade circuits, utilization of valves as logic elements, cylinder STOP modes, Cole-Pessen method. Programmable  sequence counters. Timers, counters, shift registers, schmitt triggers, codes, encoders, principles of numerical control (NC).  Iterative systems. Robots. Parts handling.
00350008.name: Industrial Automation

00350010.about: Basic definitions. Degrees of freedom in complex mechanisms. Transmission of motion and equivalent mechanisms. Analytical graphicaland calculational methods for determining velocities and accelerations in mechanisms. Spatial mechanisms. Kinematic analysis and synthesis using computers. Kinematics of gears. Gear trains. Kinematics and dynamics of cams. Inertial forces in mechanisms.
00350010.name: Kinematics of Mechanisms

00350013.about: Summation of finite differences (explicit and implicit) for solving parabolic and elliptic equations: consistency, stability and convergence. Problem solving in complex regions by analytical and numerical mapping. Solution of hyperbolic equations using method of characteristics and finite difference methods (explicit and implicit). Applications for problem solving in fields of mechanical engineering: fluid dynamics, heat and mass transfer, theory of elasticity.
00350013.name: Computational Methods in Mechanical Eng.

00350016.about: Introduction. Dynamic properties of tires and mechanics of forces generation. Vehicle - aerodynamics. The drive system: engine, transmission, power train, acceleration performance. Component adaptation and optimization.
00350016.name: The Automotive System 1

00350022.about: Principles of finite elements methods (including a brief review of other popular numerical methods) for the solution of one- dimensional boundary value problems. Critical evaluation of the choice of the physical model and its mathematical formulation (dimension of the problem, material behavior, and boundary conditions). Reliability of the numerical solution. Knowlegeable use of professional codes for the design of mechanical projects in solid  mechanics and heat transfer.
00350022.name: Finite Elements for Engineering Analysis

00350023.about: Integrated circuits and packaging trends. Thermally induced failures, thermal packaging, heat transfer from bodies with heat sources, review of principles, conduction in printed circuits, free convection in pcb arrays, forced convection in pcb arrays, optimization of fins and pins, optimization in adhesive layers, boiling, cooling with micro channels, numerical methods, commercial computer codes.
00350023.name: Cooling and Thermal Mana.of Elec.Compon.

00350024.about: Defects in working surfaces, surface roughness, surface hardness, friction forms, lubrication forms, wear measurement and identification, wear forms, quality control of friction pairs, improving working surfaces, coatings.
00350024.name: Applied Tribology

00350026.about: General introduction of the various disciplines included in Mechanical Engineering and general introduction of physical models and mathematical tools relevant to these disciplines. Thought techniques for problem solving. Writing technical reports. Study of mechanical systems by disassembly and analysis.
00350026.name: Creative Overview of Mechanical Engin.

00350028.about: Definitions: radial and axial turbomachines, water, wind, steam and gas turbines. Control volume analysis. Compressible flows, quasi one - dimensional flow, choked flow. Second law and the euler turbomachine equation. Dimensional analysis. Axial flow compressors and ducted fans, mean - line calculations. Wind turbines: actuator disc approach ( betz limit ), blade element theory, blade elementmomentum method.
00350028.name: Turbomachinery Fluid Mech.and Thermodyna

00350032.about: REVIEW AND EXAMPLES OF MICROCONTROLLER EMBEDDED MECHANICAL SYSTEMS. DATA AND NUMBERS REPRESENTATION IN MEMORY. DIGITAL AND ANALOGUEHARDWARE INTERFACES. PROGRAMMING MICROCONTROLLERS IN C AND IN MATLAB.SIMULINK. REAL TIME SUB-SYSTEM INTERFACING. POLLING VS INTERRUPT BASED I.O. SENSORS AND ACTUATORS SOFTWARE CONTROL OF STEPPING AND DC MOTORS. INTERFACING ACCELEROMETERS AND DIGITAL ROTATION SENSORS. DIGITAL FILTERS AND CONTROLLERS FOR TUNING THE DYNAMICS OF ELECTROMECHANICAL SYSTEMS. LABORATORY MINI-PROJECTS ON SOFTWARE.HARDWRE SUB-SYSTEMS.
00350032.name: Microprocessor Based Product Design M'

00350033.about: Specifications of measurement systems, errors and accuracies. Sensing mechanisms: electromagnetic, piezoelectric, thermoelectric, variable resistance, capacitance, inductance. Sensors kv measurement of force, acceleration, pressure etc. Microsensors. interlacing analog and digital sensors. Sampling and data ecquisition. Processing of measurements, filtering. Noise and interference suppression. Spatial measurements.
00350033.name: Introduction to Integrated Sensing Syst.

00350034.about: Definition of failure, overload failure, lefm, fracture toughness, loading modes, fracture, leak before break criterion (example), fatigue (HCF.LCF). Paris law, ductile to brittle transition, environmental effects, microstructure and toughness, fractographic analysis, fracture micromechanisms, case histories. laboratory: 1. Fracture toughness determination. 2. Fractography.
00350034.name: Failure of Materials

00350035.about: Order of magnitude analysis of the Navier-Stokes equations and dimensionless numbers in fluid mechanics. Thin wing theory. Hydrodynamic lubrication and Reynolds equation for creepinf flows. Gas-liquid surface tension. Stability of boundary layers and integral methods for boundary layers. Reynolds stresses in turbolent flows. Turbolent flow in a pipe and turbolent boundary layers. One-dimensional compressible flow. Mach cone and normal shock waves.
00350035.name: Fluid Mechanics 2

00350036.about: Design specifications and consideration, modeling, selection of sensors and actuators: controller design methods, controller realization. Simulations, interative design, economical considerations.
00350036.name: Control System Design
