00350039.about: Classification of signals. Time domain analysis. Fourier methods, filters. Special analysis. Identification of linear systems. Modebased signal processing. Diagnostics of systems. Spectral analysis is of vibration. Source identification. Measurements and filtering. Mechanical parameter identification.
00350039.name: Signal Processing for Vibrations and Diagnostics

00350041.about: Introduction to micro-electro-mechanical systems (mems). elastostatics theory:  field equations. Dielectrics. elastostatic energy. Mems statics: electromechanical beams and plates. Residual stresses. Piezoelectrics. Thermoelectric elasticity theory: boundary-value problems. Exact and numerical solutions. Thermal effects in microsystems: thermal mismatch in layered structures. Solutions of coupled electro-thermomechanical problems. Dynamics and vibration of electromechanical systems. Electric driving forces. Damping mechanisms and measures in microsystems. Nonlinearity, stability and linearization.
00350041.name: Mechanics of Microsystems

00350043.about: Displacement vector. Displacement gradient tensor. Transformation of tensors. Strain and stress tensors. Differential equations of equilibrium. external load boundary conditions. Strain energy and work of external forces. Constitutive equations. Compatibility conditions. Analytical and numerical solutions of selected problems in the theory of elasticity.
00350043.name: Introduction to the Theory of Elasticity

00350044.about: A first course of the Ship Engineering option, usually taken in the fourth or fifth semester.  Syllabus:  first acquaintance with naval architecture terminology and hull definition by means of drawings, the fundamentals of initial stability, methods of numerical integration, hydrostatic calculations, the influence of free liquid surfaces, stability at large angles of heel, stability regulations, damage stability and bending moment.
00350044.name: Hydrostatics of Ships

00350045.about: the discipline of cryogenics (chronology, branches), liquefaction of gases (isenthalpic and isentropic expansions, staging, optimization), miniature joule-thomson cryocoolers (staging, fast cooldown, autonomous systems, infrared sensors, cryosurgery, open.closed-cycle, mixed coolants), the variety of cryocoolers and their unified perspective, choked mass flux of real gases (elevated pressures, low temperatures), special topics: solid cryogens, superfluid helium, magnetic cryocooling, superconductivity, space applications,the third law.
00350045.name: Cryogenics:Cryocoolers and Liquefiers

00350046.about: Study of methods and tools for engineering project management. Introduction to project management, scheduling of activities and resources allocation. Study of the unique characteristics of engineering projects and their management. Understanding of nature of project life cycle and investment strategies. Use of project management software for performing an extensive final project and presentation.
00350046.name: Management of Engineering Project

00350048.about: Design principles integrated with analysis from areas of: dynamics, strength of materials, kinematics and vibration. The focus on the physics of mechanical design. Included are topics such as: machine elements, mechanisms, centrifugal governors, vibration isolation of machines, impact loading, shocks.
00350048.name: Integrated Design and Analysis

00350049.about: principles of marine power systems: steam turbines, gas turbines and diesel, power cycles, operating characteristics and limitations. engine-propeller matching and propulsion power transmission, including combined systems. selection of propulsion systems. principles of electric.hybrid power generation. electric drive operating principles and characteristics. maintenance principles. principlesof fluid system design and pumps.
00350049.name: Principles of Marine Engineering

00350050.about: Introduction to optical design, geometric optics, numerical methods for paraxial ray, single lens properties, imaging, monochromatic aberrations, chromatic aberrations, properties of optical systems, optical materials, light sources, detectors, characterization of optical systems, examples of generic optical systems.
00350050.name: Optical Systems Design

00350051.about: Short review on optical materials, first order optics, radiometry, optical systems, and metrics for performance of optical systems (spot diagram, ray fan, OPD, MTF) and their relation to image quality. Tolerancing of optical systems. Impact of mechanical motion on first order optical properties. Specification of optical components. Fabrication issues and limitations. Mounting of optical components. Thermal considerations. System considerations. Self-weight deflection. Finite elements modeling of opto-mechanical assemblies.
00350051.name: Optical-Mechanical Design

00350052.about: Physical optics analysis of coherent and incoherent optical systems, space invariant and space variant optics and their limitations, analog optical information processing, phase-contras microscope, nondiffracting beams, diffractive optics, computer generated holograms, physical limitation of diffuse light concentration, imaging and nonimaging concentrators, anamorphic concentration, optical metrology, three dimensional measurements, triangulation, confocal-microscopy, near-field microscopy.
00350052.name: Linear Optics and Applications 1

00350053.about: Renewable energy sources, availability and methodes of utilization. Direct heat utilization and conversion to electricity. Conversion of wind power to mechanical energy and electricity. Heat utilization in thermodynamic cycles. Energy storage, considering the non-compatibility between availability of energy sources and electrical energy demands. Energy sources in Israel, suitable technologies, policy and tariffs.
00350053.name: Renewable and Sustainable Energy

00350061.about: Models of ship resistance.  The components of ship resistance, their analysis and model tests.  Elements of wave theory.  Ship motions and waves.  Elements of propeller theory.  Calculations based on propeller series.  Elements of maneuvering theory and course stability.  Introduction to planing hulls.
00350061.name: Ship Hydrodynamics

00350062.about: Theory of elastic and inelastic buckling of columns and plates. Methods of structural analysis including virtual work, potential energy, complementary energy, Castigliano's theorems, matrix methods. Membrane theory of shells.
00350062.name: Analysis of Structures

00350063.about: Terminology of ship structures, ship structures according to ship type, scantling in accordance with the regulations of classification societies. Longitudinal framing, transverse framing, decks, bulkheads, double bottom, superstructures, stem and stern, hatch coamings.
00350063.name: Naval Architecture 1

00350091.about:
Maximum work, availability and irreversibility.  Free energy functions. Maxwell relations, Clapeyron equation. Equations of state, law of corresponding states, generalized diagrams. Equilibrium, phases and components.  Partial properties, chemical potential, fugacity.
 Ideal and real mixtures and solutions.  Chemical reactions, chemical equilibrium.
00350091.name: Thermodynamics 2

00350123.about: An overview of computer integrated manufacturing systems.
00350123.name: Introduction to Manufacturing Systems 1

00350124.about: Metal behavior in the plastic zone,  yield models,  therom-physical properties, friction and wear,  analysis of systems in plastic deformation.  The method of ideal work,  the method of lower bound, the method of upper bound,  the method of slip lines.  Analyzingcharacteristic processes:  forging, rolling, drawing, extrusion, spinning, etc.  Emphasis on energetic optimization.
00350124.name: Analysis of Manufacturing Processes

00350141.about: Energy demand and plant rating. Steam power: thermodynamic cycles and plant components, heat balances, power and heat in industry, station arrangements. Gas turbines: thermodynamics, open and closed cycles, recuperators, jet-type gas turbines, combined cycles. Common problems of thermal power plants. Introduction to engineering economy and optimization.
00350141.name: Heat and Power Installations

00350146.about: Ideal and real thermodynamic cycles. SI and CI engines. Efficiencies, criteria for design of air flow, supercharging, fuel supply, ignition, combustion timing, heat transfer in engine, lubrication and cooling, rotating engines (Wankel).
00350146.name: Internal Combustion Engines

00350188.about: System theory: modeling , matrix polynomial description, controllability, observability, minimal realization, stability. Feedback (SISO): block diagram algebra, closed loop stability and causality, steady state performance, sensitivity and robustness. Design: design criteria, lead-lag, design algorithms. Industrial controllers: PID, dead-time compensators, cascade and feedforward, non-minimumphase systems, internal model control. Feedback (MIMO): state feedback, observers, pole placement. Non-linear systems: NL elements,system representation, describing function, popov and circle criteria, phase plane, Lyapunov methods.
00350188.name: Control Theory

00360001.about: Anaytic functions of complex variable. Conformal mappings and solution of Laplace equation. Residual theorem, principle of argument, Rouche's theorem, evaluation of definite integrals. Solution of PDEs through separation of variables. Sturm - Liouville problem. Solution of ODEs with series expansion. Legendre polynomials. Bessel functions. Learning Outocmes: At the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. Investigate the main properties of analytic functions and construct series expansions. 2. find solution of laplace equation in 2D with the help of analytic functions and conformal mappings. 3. Construct computation of intergrals with the help  of residuals of analytic functions. 4. Analyze ordinary linear non-autonomous differential equations. 5. Use bessel functions and Legendre polynomials for various physical problems.
00360001.name: Analytical Methods in Mechanical Engineering 1

00360003.about: Kinematics of a continuum.  Notion of stress.  Conservation of mass. Balance laws of linear momentum, angular momentum, and energy.Invariance under superposed rigid body motions.  Constitutive equations for elastic solids, viscous fluids, and elastic-plastic solids.  Linearization.
00360003.name: Introduction to Continuum Mechanics

00360004.about: Governing equations of elasticity and plasticity (review). Elasto-plastic stress distribution near cracks (planar).  Mechanics of brittle and ductile fracture.  Stress intensity factor as a practical fracture criterion.  The effect of plastic zone on crack propagation. Mixed mode fracture. Fatigue. Stress corrosion. The "path independent integral" - J.  Special topics to be chosen by the students.
00360004.name: Fracture Mechanics

00360005.about: Basic  principles, virtual work, D'Alembert's principle, Lagrange's equations, conservation laws, Routh's method.  Hamilton's principle, Hamilton's equations, non-conservative and non-holonomic systems. Rigid body dynamics.
00360005.name: Analytical Dynamics 1

00360006.about: Stress waves in infinite medium. Reflection and refraction in plane boundaries. Waves in finite media: rods, beams and plates. Approximate solutions and Pochhammer-Chree equations.  Waves in viscoelastic media. Experimental methods for measuring dynamic properties of solids.
00360006.name: Stress Waves in Solids

00360007.about: Multi-degree of freedom dynamical systems (Newtonian and Hamiltonian, formulation, Lagrange's equations). Continuous dynamical systems (beams, plates, shells) and the reduction of their order (assumed modes, Galerkin, and Rayleigh-Ritz). Periodic oscillations andquasiperiodic beats (exact, approximate and numerical solutions). Stability of oscillations and parametric analysis (stiffness, damping and dynamical constraints). Spectral analysis and an introduction to random vibrations.
00360007.name: Vibrations of Structures

00360008.about: Conservation equations.  One dimensional flow: isentropic flow, nozzles, effects of friction and heat transfer, normal shock. Wave propagation and reflection. Two dimensional flow: oblique shock waves, Mach lines, interference.  Compression and expansion.  Linearized inviscid theory.  Thin airfoil in subsonic and supersonic flow. Solution of supersonic flows by method of characteristics.
00360008.name: Compressible Flow

00360009.about: Heat conduction equation. Initial and boundary conditions. Steady and unsteady heat conduction. Analytical solutions. Mass diffusion in binary mixtures. Boundary conditions. Diffustion in quiescent media. Energy transfer in single and binary systems. Viscous dissipation. Coupled convective heat and mass transfer. Thermal and mass boundary layers. Evaporation and condensation on drops and films.
00360009.name: Heat & Mass Transfer

00360010.about: The general form of the Reynolds Equation.  Load carrying capacity, flow rate and friction losses.  One-dimensional solutions of the Reynolds Equation.  Journal bearings and thrust bearings.  Gas bearings, hydrostatic bearings.  Mechanical seals.  Numerical solutions of the complete Reynolds Equation.  Special bearing configurations.
00360010.name: Theory of Hydrodynamic Lubrication

00360012.about: Part 1: system theory (MIMO). System representation: polynomial, transfer matrix. State space.  Poles and zeroes. Controllability. Observability. Hidden modes. Minimality. Realization. Part 2: feedback systems (mimo): closed loop stability. Generalized Nyquist theorem. Robustness: modeling of uncertainties, sensitivity matrices, SV and SSV. Performance vs. robustness. Design methods: diagonaldominance, observer.controller, IMC.
00360012.name: Linear Control Systems

00360013.about: Static optimization. Least squares problems. Discrete time optimal control dynamic programming. Calculus of variations: Euler-Lagrange and Bolza problems. Continuous time optimal control-general formulation, the Hamiltonian, the maximum principle. Minimum time problem. Optimal linear regulator (LQ). Riccati equation and its properties. The LQg problem. Fixed order optimal control.
00360013.name: Process Optimization

00360014.about: Basic equations in plasticity:  Solution of typical processes like forging, extrusion, etc. by the slab method (equilibrium, yielding). Exact solutions (slip-lines),  energy methods and approximate solutions.  Limit analysis:  upper and lower bounds for studying spinning, deep drawing, rolling, piercing and extrusion. Dynamic effects in metal-forming processes. Forming of porous materials. The lectures will emphasize the engineering approximations for reaching solutions using optimization procedures.
00360014.name: Metal Forming Processes

00360015.about: Variational formulations, method of weighted residuals, variational principles and approximate solutions (for boundary-value problems).  One-dimensional elements (Co,C1). Solution of linear algebraic equations. Multi-dimensional isoparametric elements. Program structure, preprocessing and postprocessing. Error estimate. Boundary elements, finite strip and spectral element methods.
00360015.name: Finite Element Methods in Mechanical Engineering 1

00360020.about: Explicit, implicit and parametric equations of lines, curves and surfaces. Envelopes, intrinsic equations and offset curves. Analysis, representation and design of conic sections. Interpolation and design with cross-sections. Frenet-Serret equations. First and second matrices. Design and analysis of 3-D composite parametric curves and surfaces (patches), using Ferguson, Bezier splines and Coon formulations. Rational Bezier representation of conic sections.
00360020.name: Computational Geometry 1

00360026.about: Forward and inverse kinematic  equations, Jacobian, singularity, Lagrange equations, symbolic simulation, motion and state equations. Perfect global linearization, robustness, linear control, min-max and adaptive control, tracking.
00360026.name: Kinematics Dynamics and Control of Robots

00360027.about: Introduction to water waves.  Forces on stationary, moored and floating marine structures in calm water and waves. Motions of shipsand moored bodies in waves.  Deterministic and statistical analysis of ship motions and sea loads. Advanced topics in fluid-structure interaction systems revealed in recent research.
00360027.name: Dynamics of Marine Structures

00360031.about: Topics: contact, adhesion and friction modeling of real surfaces. The course is based on reading of classical and up to date papersfrom the Tribology literature.
00360031.name: Theoretical Tribology

00360032.about: FUNDAMENTAL PRINCIPLES OF FLUID MECHANICS, 1D FLOWS, ORDER OF MAGNITUDE ANALYSIS AND ASYMPTOTIC EXPANSIONS, LUBRICATION APPROXIMATION, FREE-SURFACE PROBLEMS, CREEPING FLOWS, LOW REYNOLDS HEAT CONVECTION, BOUNDARY LAYERS, HIGH REYNOLDS HEAT TRANSFER, STABILITY ANALYSIS IN FLUID MECHANICS.
00360032.name: Analytical Fluid Mechanics

00360035.about: Basic concepts and governing equations.  Nonstationary theory of thermal explosion.  Ignition and extinction. Stationary theory of thermal explosion.  Ignition by a hot surface.  Theory of hot laminar flame propagation in open regions. Flame propagation in enclosures. Diffusional thermal stability of laminar flames. Hydrodynamic instability of flames.  Diffusional combustion of gases.  Aerodynamics of gas torch.  Theory of liquid atomization.  Burning of droplets.  Detachment of flame from burning liquid by air flow.
00360035.name: Introduction to Combustion Engineering

00360038.about: Introduction. Surface tension. Laplace-Young equation. Interfacial boundary conditions. Capillary flows: meniscus problem, coating problems, surface waves. Thermocapillary flow. Introduction to the theory of hydrodynamic stability. Linear stability analysis. Stability of interfaces. Marangoni instability. Flow and stability of thin liquid films.
00360038.name: Interfacial Transport Processes

00360041.about: Systematic conceptual design techniques of a new product, including analysis of new needs. Customer value management, house of quality, abstractization and functional analysis. Intuitive and discursive techniques for concept generation, synthesis to full solutions by concurrent engineering techniques, design for manufacturing, value engineering and quality engineering.
00360041.name: Advanced Engineering Design 1

00360044.about: The concept of configuration space as the basic medium for robot planning algorithms. Major path-planning methodologies.  Sensory based planning in the context of navigating in 2-d environments. Trends of navigating general articulated robots based on distance data collected on-line. Application of concepts for mobile robots.
00360044.name: Robot Path-Planning and Sensor Based Navigation

00360045.about: Design for manufacturing of curves and surfaces based on polynomial and parametric representation: B-splines, NURBS.  Interpolationmethods for curves and surfaces. Fitting of composite surfaces. Methods for elevating and reducing the degree of a surface. Creating surfaces with sweeping and blending operations. Intersection between surfaces.  Trimmed surfaces.  Boolean operations on parametric surfaces.
00360045.name: Computational Geometry and Cad Models 2

00360048.about: Analysis of nonlinear vibrations in mechanical systems: asymptotic techniques (multiple scales).   Numerical methods (poincare maps).   Periodic solutions (ultrasubharmonics). Quasiperiodic solutions.  Nonlinear stability.  Bifurcations. multi-degree-of-freedom engineering systems  (modal interaction). Self excited systems  (flow induced vibration).   Continuous systems (dynamic buckling).
00360048.name: Analysis of Nonlinear Vibrations.

00360049.about: Structure of neural networks, feedforward.feedback. Learning methods as parameter estimation.  Relation to adaptive methods in control, signal processing and classification.  Special characteristics of neural networks. Supervised, reinforced and unsupervised learning.  Neuro-controllers distant teacher problem.  Classifiers for diagnostics representation issues.
00360049.name: Neural Networks for Control and Diagnostic

00360050.about: Generalized dynamical systems.  Linearization and the first method of Lyapunov.  The second method of Lyapunov.  Popov criterion inthe frequency domain.  Min-max controllers, uncertain systems and variable structure systems.  Bilinear systems. Adaptive control.
00360050.name: Nonlinear Control Systems

00360053.about: Reliability analysis of technological systems.  Integration of analytical methods with engineering models. Design and interpretation of tests.  Probabilistic and information-gap models of uncertainty.  Strategic design and decision under severe uncertainty. Statistical hypothesis tests for acceptance and performance.  Environmental and lifetime testing.  Fault diagnosis. Taguchi method.  Availability and maintainability.  Standards and specifications.
00360053.name: Reliability and Testing

00360055.about: Micro-optics, multilevel binary optics, optical coordinate transformations, wavefront shaping, on the limits of optical interconnects, sub-wavelength structured optical elements, space-invariant and space-variant sub-wavelength polarization elements, optical storage and optical recording concepts, laser resonators with intracavity non-conventional optical elements, laser mode discrimination, thermal imaging, color science.
00360055.name: Linear Optics and Applications 2.

00360057.about: Strategic decisions under uncertainty in analysis, design and certification of complex systems. Reliability, risk assessment and control. Reliability and risks in projects. Desision paradigms for information-gap uncertainty. Realizability with limited information. balancing robustness against opportunity. Evolution of preferences through analysis of uncertainty. Trade-offs with qualitative value judgments and multiple criteria. Learning and value of information. Decisions with hybrid uncertainties.
00360057.name: Info-Gap Analysis of Risk and Reliability

00360058.about: Micro-Macro relations. Probability, morphology, effective properties. Heterogeneous microbeams: average deflection, dispersion. Micro length-scale, two-point correlation, bounds. Variations, nonlinearity, approximations, probabilistic reactions. Cross-sectional microstructure,  composites, multiple-point correlation, antisotropic effects, properties and scales, morphological effects on deflections and reactions. Micromechanics and strength.
00360058.name: Micromechanics of Solids 1

00360059.about: THE GOAL OF THIS CLASS IS TO ACQUAINT FUTURE ENGINEERS AND SCIENTISTS WITH THE MAIN CONCEPTS OF POLYMER PHYSICS (INCLUDING POLYMER STATISTICAL PHYSICS AND THERMODYNAMICS, POLYMER MECHANICS AND RHEOLOGY, AND TRANSPORT PROPERTIES). WE WILL DISCUSS THEORETICAL AND COMPUTATIONAL APPROACHES USED TO DESIGN POLYMER-BASED MATERIALS AND PREDICT THEIR PROPERTIES. AT THE END OF THE SIX-WEEK CLASS, THE STUDENTS WILL BE OFFERED A PROBLEM SIMILAR TO ONE ENCOUNTERED IN REAL-LIFE CHEMICAL INDUSTRY AND WILL WORK TOGETHER TO FIND A SOLUTION USING MODELINGAND THEORY. THIS CLASS WILL BE OF INTEREST TO STUDENTS CONSIDERING CAREERS IN ADVANCED MANUFACTURING, CHEMICAL, PLAST ICS, ELECTRONICS, PHARMACEUTICAL, AUTOMOTIVE, PACKAGING, COATINGS, BUILDING AND CONSTRUCTION, AND OTHER INDUSTRY R AND D. TODAY, POLYMERS ARE INDISPENSABLE MATERIALS IN ALL THOSE INDUSTRIES, AND UNDERSTANDING THEIR FUNDAMENTALS IS OFTEN NECESSARY TO DESIGN PROCESSES (3D-PRINTING, EXTRUSION, FOAMING, SOLUTION PROCESSING) AND MATERIALS (COMPOSITES, NANOCOMPOSITES, FOAMS, FILMS) TO SOLVE OUR PRESENT-DAY CHALLENGES (WATER DESALINATION, ENERGY EFFICIENCY, RECYCLING). LEARNING OUTCOMES: BY THE END OF THE COURSE, THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE T
00360059.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN POLYMER PHYSICS

00360061.about: low reynolds number flows. particle translation and rotation. drag resistance. micro-hydrodynamics. diffusion. inertial relaxation and drift. added mass. piv applications. particles in shear flows. particle-laden jets. collisions. impactors. particle interactionsin flow. fluidized and packed beds. particle separation  principles.  sedimentation. cyclones. fractal agglomerates. particles in turbulent flows.
00360061.name: Fluid-Particle Systems

00360062.about: basic equation in elasticity. concentrated force on plane boundary of an elastic semi-infinite body. hertz solution of contacting elastic bodies.  non-hertzian contact. normal and tangential loading of the contact zone.  perfectly slip and perfectly stick contact.  elastic-plastic contact for different poisson ratios.  loading and unloading of elastic-plastic contact. contact of rough surfaces. practical examples.
00360062.name: Contact Mechanics

00360063.about: FITTING CONTINUOUS AND DISCRETE MODELS TO MEASURED DATA AND PHYSICAL PHENOMENA. LEAST-SQUARES MODEL FITTING, LINEAR AND NONLINEAR, MEASURES FOR FIT QUALITY, STATISTICAL DISTRIBUTION OF FITTED PARAMETERS, UNCERTAINTY RANGE. MONTE-CALO CARLO SIMULATION OF FITTED MODELS. STATIC MODEL FIT (MECHANICS), NONLINEAR FIT IN MECHANICS, HEAT TRANSFER AND VIBRATION. COVARIANCE MATRIX, CROSS- AND AUTO-CORRELATION, APPLICATION FOR RECOVERING MOTIONS FOR VIDEOS. FOURIER TRANSFORM, FITTING IN THE FREQUENCY DOMAIN OF MULTI-INPUT.OUTPUT MODELS. POWER SPECTRAL DENSITY. ESTIMATING FREQUENCY RESPONSE UNDER INPUT AND OUTPUT NOISE. FITTING DISCRETE MODELS FROM SAMPLED DATA, P REDICTION ERROR FIT, STATE-SPACE MODEL FIT AND EXTRACTING PHYSICAL PARAMETERS FROM FITTED MODELS, EIGENVECTORS AND EIGENVALUES. APPLICATION TO DYNAMIC AND ACOUSTIC PROBLEMS, LABORATORY EXAMPLES.
00360063.name: Experimental Modeling of Systems

00360064.about: advanced engineering science research topics in the area of expertise of the lecturer. the syllabus will be prepared by the lecturer and approved by the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is given.
00360064.name: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Engineering 4

00360065.about: classification of electromechanical and magnetomechanical phenomena according to characteristic properties of actuators and sensors, electrostatics and magnetostatics in vacuum and in media, piezoelectricity, electromechanic response of ferroelectric materials, magnetostriction, ferromagnetic shape memory alloys, ferroelectirc relaxors, typical experimental methods. emphasis is given to applications and dynamics of actuators and sensors.
00360065.name: Electro/Magneto Mech' for Actu/Sensing

00360067.about: research topics in advanced engineering science as determined  by the lecturer according to his area of expertise.  the syllabus will be decided by the lecturer and approved by the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is taught.
00360067.name: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Engineering 6

00360070.about: image formation in near-field optics, resolution limit and evanescent waves, subwavelength structures, metamaterial based on nanostructures, surface waves, plasmon-polaritons, phonon-polaritons, periodic and quasiperiodic structures, near-field thermal emission, vectorial optics (stokes polarization parameters, mueller matrix, poincare sphere), polarization-dependent nanostructures, optics ofthin metals, geometric phase in nanostructures, applications for nanophotonics.
00360070.name: Nanooptics and Periodic Structures

00360071.about: topics: modeling of biomechanical systems at the micro.nano scale using tools from engineering and statistical mechanics: dna mechanics and packing in viruses, biological motors, mechanics of vesicles and cell membranes, muscle mechanics.
00360071.name: Biomechanics of Cells and Molecules

00360072.about: fundamental kinematics tools based on screw theory and line geometry. insight and physical undertstanding of terms (i.e. screw theory, transformation, singularity, rigidity, force closure) with applications in biomechanics of the large joints and robotics.
00360072.name: Kinematics in Biomechanics and Robotics

00360073.about: research topics in advanced engineering science as determined by the lecturer according to her.his area of expertise.  the syllabuswill be decided by the lecturer and approved by the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is taught.
00360073.name: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Engineering 8

00360074.about: topics:  aerodynamics concepts, thin airfoil theory, boundary layer equations, laminar and turbulent flows, transition. passive andactive flow control: steady methods, flow instability, perturbed flows, forced flows, shear flows and jets, controlling dimensionless parameters, actuators, industrial and wind turbine applications, theoretical and numerical approaches.
00360074.name: Active and Passive Flow Control

00360075.about: research topics in advanced engineering science as determined by the lecturer and approved by the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is taught.
00360075.name: Advanced Topics in Mechanical Eng.  9

00360077.about:
CAUCHY S EQUATION, FLUIDIC AND ELASTIC CONSTITUTIVE RELATIONS, SCALING AND DIMENSIONLESS NUMBERS, FLOWS IN ELASTIC TUBES, ACOUSTICSAND ELASTICITY, THIN VISCOUS FILMS INTERACTING WITH ELASTIC MEMBRANES, MODELS OF FLUIDIC SOFT-ACTUATORS AND -ROBOTS, FLUIDS INTERACTING WITH BI- AND MULTI-STABLE STRUCTURES, ELECTROCAPILLARITY PHENOMENA._
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 BY THE END OF THIS COURSE, THE STUDENT WILL HAVE GAINED AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE PHYSICAL MECHANISMS THAT GOVERN SYSTEMS INVOLVING FLOW AND ELASTICITY, AT DIFFERENT LIMITS, AND WILL BE ABLE TO DERIVE THE GOVERNING EQUATIONS AND SOLVE THESE EQUATIONS IN SIMPLE CASES.
00360077.name: TOPICS IN FLUIDS AND ELASTICITY

00360079.about: formation of harmful pollutants in an internal combustion engine, introduction to health effects of pollutants, thermo-chemistry and analysis of factors affecting pollutant formation, relationships between engine performance and pollutant formation,  greenhouse gas emissions, methods of emission control in spark ignition engines, methods of emission control in compression ignition engines, chemistry, analysis and design principles of various after treatment technologies, advanced simulation tools for after treatment systems.
00360079.name: Control of Vehicle Emissions

00360080.about: introduction to advanced vehicle propulsion schemes, vehicle energy consumption, gear-box, electric and hybrid propulsion systems, energy and power balances, braking energy recuperation, energy storage batteries, supercapacitors, flywheels, hydraulic accumulators, propulsion  system based on internal combustion engines and on fuel cells, fuels for advanced propulsion systems, renewable fuels,energetic and environmental impacts, well-to-wheel analysis, advanced tools for propulsion system design simulation and performanceanalysis
00360080.name: Advanced Automotive Propulsion Systems

00360081.about: definition, description and actual status of mems today. miniaturization and its influence on the mechanical behavior of devices.  micromachining methods and their implementation for fabrication.  introduction to micro mechanics design. integration of sensing andactuation, combining optics, electronics and reacting materials.  using cad packages for micro electromechanical systems (mems) design. simulation and analysis of microsystems and packaging principles.
00360081.name: Principles of Micro Electromecanical Systems (Mems) Design and Production

00360082.about: engine performance analysis and development trends, thermodynamic analysis of engine cycles, gas exchange processes, analysis of fuel injection processes in si (spark ignition) and ci (compression ignition) engines, combustion in si and ci engines, the knocking phenomenon, emission formation and control in si and ci engines, heat transfer in engines, automotive fuels, advanced engine combustion concepts, simulation methods.
00360082.name: Internal Combustion Engine Fundamentals

00360083.about: engineers make decisions,  focusing on functionality, efficiency and reliability. this course focuses on philosophical aspects and limitations of decisions under uncertainty.  anomalies of decision.  satisficing and optimizing as bases for decision. no-failure design and disaster recovery.  theory selection for decision support.  the need for multiple uncertainty theories. rationality.
00360083.name: Decisions: Challenges and Implications

00360087.about: analysis of mechanical and robotic systems with multiple unilateral frictional contacts.  contact kinematics and contact forces, coulomb's friction model, statics-graphical methods, formulating dynamics with constraints under different contact modes. painleve's paradox and dynamic jamming, impact models, zeno phenomenon dynamically walking robot models, stability of orbits in hybrid systems, poincare  maps. learning outcome: at the end of the course the student will be capable of: 1. analysis of planar problems in staticswith multiple unilateral frictional contacts by methods and by solving alinear programming. 2. formulating  equations of motion for a mechanical system with contact constraints. 3. formulating conditions for occurrence of painleve's paradox in a system with a single frictional contact.4. formulating impact laws for a single contact with and without friction in a system of rigid bodies.5.formulating equations of motion of a mecanical systems with intermittent contacts as a hybrid system. 6.conducting numerical sinulations of mecanical systems with intermittent contact. 7. finding periodic solutions of a hybrid dynamical system and their stability usingpoincare map.
00360087.name: Hybrid Dynamics in Mechanical Systems

00360088.about: Introduction to statistical mechanics and thermodynamics at nanoscale dimensions, molecular dynamics simulations, interatomic potentials, molecular statics simulations, mechanical and thermal properties of solids, Monte-Carlo simulations, lattice defects, calculating mechanical properties of solids with lattice defects, multiscale materials modeling, advanced simulation techniques in particledynamics. Learning Outcomes: at the end of the course the student will 1. Be aquainted with advanced computational techniques in nanomechanics, 2. Be familiar with computational techniques to find equilibrium states in a multi-body system, 3. Have experience in ex ecuting dynamic calculations for multi-body systems (atomistic 4. Understand mechanical properties from the atomic level and defectstructures in materials 5. Be experienced in solving problems in nanomechanics.
00360088.name: Computational Nanomechanics of Solids

00360090.about: introduction to cellular biomechanics focusing on the physical basis of cell mechanosensing: the ability of biological cells to sense and respond to elasticity and mechanical cues. experimental techniques and theoretical modeling (using statistical mechanics and stochastic processes) of mechanics at the nanoscale. stress-induced phase transition in lipid membranes and cytoskeleton networks, mechano-chemical coupling: coupling between force and conformational changes in single molecules and bond rupture experimental methods for measuring mechanical forces and deformations at the nanoscale including: single molecule force spectroscopy, traction force mic roscopy (tfm) and fluorescence resonance energy transfer (fret) sensors. learning outcomes: upon completion of this course it is intended that the student will: 1. understand the difference between mechanical behavior of classical systems and mechanics of self-assembly systems (e.g. biological membranes and acting cytoskeleton). 2. understand the role of stochasticity on the single molecule level (for cell mechanosensors and molecular motors). 3. know how to derive macroscopic properties from single molecule behavior. 4. know how to
00360090.name: Cell Mechanics and Cell Mechanosensing

00360093.about: types of composites, applications, anisotropy and hooke's law: from the most general material to isotropic material, engineering moduli and stiffness tensor. micromechanics of composite materials, effective properties and energy of heterogeneous media, representative volume element, voigt-reuss bounds and examples for calculating the effective moduli of a fiber-reinforced composite transformations of the stiffness tensor, plane conditions, invariants and properties of an unidirectional iamina local (principal) and global directions. mechanical properties of composite laminates, stiffness tensor of composite plates, kinematic considerations, constitutiv e equations. boundary conditions, examples of exact solutions, elastic energy and approximation methods, solution accuracy. hydrothermal stresses and material constants. strength, failure modes and criteria of composite laminate. learning outcomes: by the end of the course the student will: 1. demonstrate a basic understanding of what a composite material consists of, how it behaves, suitableapplications and limitations. 2. demonstrate an understanding of how the structure and mechanical properties of the constituent materials affect
00360093.name: Mechanics of Composite Materials 1

00360096.about: introduction to electrochemical flow systems for energy storage and water desalination, and their relevance to future energy and water technological solutions. development of relevant fluid mechanics principles: channel flow, particlulate flows, creeping flow. development of relevant thermodynamics principles: phase and chemcial equilibrium, work from a spontaneous process, equations of state. analysis of phenomena at charged interfaces: electric double layer formation and electrochemical reactions. transport phenomena and macroscopic porous electrode theory. selected advanced topics such as: percolation theory applied to flowable electrodes, flow batt ery theory with homogenous reactions, ion selectivity in capacitive deionization. learning outcomes: 1. articulate where emerging technologies such as flow batteries and capacitive deionization fit into the technological landscape of grid-scale energy storage andenergy efficient water desalination devices. 2. develop deep intuition, analytical problem solving skills, and numerical solutions towards relevant interfacial phenomena, including the nernst equation, butler-volmer equation, the poisson-boltzmann equation, and phase equilibr
00360096.name: Electrochemical Flow Systems

00360097.about: continuum kinematics, elastodynamic conservation equations. plane waves, green's function, waves in periodic medium, bloch-floquet theorem, elastic band structure. energy relations, causality and passiity.  quasi-static and dynamic effective properties.  asymptotic homoenization for wavelengths and low frequencies.  willis homogenization. applicability limit of dynamic homoenization, metamaterial properties. learning outcomes: upon completion of the course, the students will know: 1. be able to formulate the equations governing wave propagation in periodic elastic media. 2. understand the concept of effective dynamic properties, and the physical restri ctions they must satisfy. 3. be familiar with the two most common approaches for dynamic homogenization, i.e., asymptotic homogenization and willis homogenization. 4. understand how dynamic metamaterial properties emerge. 5. understand the limit of applicability of dynamic homogenization
00360097.name: Dynamics of Composites

00360099.about: RESEARCH TOPICS IN ADVANCED ENGINEERING SCIENCE AS DETERMINED BY THE LECTURER. DETAILED BY SYLLABUS AND LEARNING OUTCOMES WILL BE PUBLISHED BEFORE THE BEGINNING OF EACH SEMESTER IN WHICH THE COURSE WILL BE GIVEN.
00360099.name: ADVANCED TOPIS IN MECHANICAL ENG. 11

00360100.about:
IN THE COURSE A NUMBER OF PAPERS RELATING TO ROBOT LOCOMOTION WILL BE DISCUSSED. THESE PAPERS INCORPORATE IDEAS FROM MECHANICS, DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY, NON-LINEAR CONTROL, AND GEOMETRIC MECHANICS. THIS WILL SERVE AS AN INTRODUCTION TO THE MATHEMATICS OF WHAT IT MEANS TO MOVE THROUGH THE WORLD, AND SOME OF THE MATHEMATICAL TOOLS NEEDED TO EXPRESS AND PLAN MOVEMENT. OUR DISCUSSION WILL FOCUS PRIMARILY ON GEOMETRIC MECHANICS AND THEIR POTENTIAL TO UNIFY DIFFERENT MODES OF LOCOMOTION.
 INTRODUCTION: SHORT MATH BACKGROUND: GROUPS AND QUOTIENTS, AND THE LIE GROUPS SE(2) AND SE(3), MANIFOLDS AND DIFFEOMORPHISMS, INTRODUCTION TO GEOMETRIC MECHANICS: SYMMETRY, C ONSERVATION, AND SYMMETRY REDUCTION.
 MAIN READINGS: THE GEOMETRIC MECHANICS OF SWIMMING AND SLITHERING, MODELS OF LEGGED LOCOMOTION, ADDITIONAL ADVANCED TOPICS FROM THE CURRENT PRIMARY LITERATURE FOLLOWING THE INTERESTS OF THE PARTICIPANTS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. EXPLAIN THE GEOMETRIC CONCEPT IN DESCRIBING MOTION, FOR SYSTEMS WITH AND WITHOUT SYMMETRIES.
 2. ANALYZE THE DISADVANTAGES AND ADVANTAGES OF USING THIS CONCEPT IN DESCRIBING THE MOVEMENT OF ROBOTS AND THEIR CONT
00360100.name: GEMETRIC CONCEPTS IN ROBOT LOCOMOTION

00360101.about:
This course concerns topics related to the biomechanics of the human body in terms of the kinematics and kinetics of the skeleton and its joints and the mechanics of different hard and soft tissues. The topics covered: anatomical planes, joint angles, walking and running gait cycles, ground reaction force, center of mass, potential and kinetic energy, mechanical models for walking and running, static problems, muscle forces and joint moments, 3d skeletal model! types of joints, pathological gait, measurement devices and methods (e.g. motion capture, inertial measurement units, force plates) inverse kinematics, bone and joint pose estimation, inverse  dynamics, muscle composition and structure! muscle models, force-length-speed-activation relationships, electromyography, muscle force optimization, linear isotropic and anisotropic elasticity, bone composition and structure, bone mechanics, bone implants, typesof soft tissues, nonlinear elasticity, characterization of the soft tissue mechanical properties, mechanics of tendons and ligaments, viscoelasticity. 
 learning outcomes: by the end of this course, the students will be able to:
 1. understand the terminology used in biomechanic
00360101.name: BIOMECHANICS OF HUMAN MOVEMENT

00360103.about:
TS WILL BE CAPABLE OF:
 1. ANALYZING THE THE ACOUSTICAL BEHAVIOUR OF COMMON PHENOMENA - DIFFRACTION! DOPPLER E.G. 
 2. CALCULATING THE SCATTERING FOR LAYERED MEDIA AND DURING PENETRATION TO SOLIDS.
 3. EXPLAINING THE MECHANISM OF SIMPLE ACOUSTICAL DEVICES.
 4. PERFORMING SIMPLE SIGNAL PROCESSING FOR SOUND WAVES.
 5. UNDERSTANDING THE BASIC PARAMETERS GOVERNING ACOUSTIC MEASUREMENTS DEVICES. 
6. UNDERSTANDING THE BASICS FOR ACOUSTICS EXPERIMENTATION.
00360103.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN PHYSICAL ACOUSTICS

00360104.about:
REVIEW OF NEWTONIAN FLUID MECHANICS, KEY NON-NEWTONIAN PHENOMENA: VISCOELASTICITY, VISCOPLASTICITY, SHEAR THINNING, SHEAR THICKENING, YIELD STRESS, NORMAL STRESS DIFFERENCES, RELAXATION TIME, EXTENSIONAL THICKENING, MATERIAL FUNCTIONS FOR NON-NEWTONIAN FLUIDS: STEADY AND START-UP SIMPLE SHEAR AND EXTENSIONAL FLOWS, FUNDAMENTAL CONSERVATION LAWS THAT GOVERN NON-NEWTONIAN FLOWS AND NON-DIMENSIONAL NUMBERS, LINEAR VISCOELASTICITY,  FLUID MECHANICS OF RHEOMETRY, ELEMENTARY CONSTITUTIVE EQUATIONS AND THEIR USE IN NON-NEWTONIANFLUID MECHANICS: GENERALIZED NEWTONIAN MODELS, NONLINEAR VISCOELASTIC MODELS, VISCOPLASTIC MODELS, CHANNEL FLOWS OF COMPLEX FLUIDS, FREE-SURFACE FLOWS OF NON-NEWTONIAN FLUIDS, MICROSTRUCTURE, CONFORMATION AND ELASTIC DUMBBELL MODEL FOR DILUTE POLYMERS, EXPERIMENTAL DEMONSTRATIONS: ROD-CLIMBING WEISSENBERG EFFECT, SHEAR THINNING, SHEAR THICKENING, EXTENSIONAL THICKENING (OPEN-SIPHON EFFECT).
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW: 1. GAINED AN UNDERSTANDING OF THE KEY NON-NEWTONIAN PHENOMENA, SUCH AS VISCOELASTICITY, VISCOPLASTICITY, SHEAR THINNING, SHEAR THICKENING, YIELD STRESS, AND THEIR EFFECT ON THE BASIC FLOWS USED INTHE RHEOLOGIC
00360104.name: TOPIC IN NON-NEWTONIAN-FLUID MECHANICS

00360105.about:
introduction to composite materials! application of composite materials! manufacturing techniques! and micromechanics. fiber/matrixinteraction and their interface. micromechanical damage models! the evolution of damage in a single ply. mathematical models for stress analysis in composite materials! the influence of ply sequence on the structural and material behavior. laminate plate theory! effective elastic properties. influence of temperature and moisture. damage mechanisms and damage propagation in composite materialscomposed of several plies. fracture mechanics in composite materials! failure theories. advanced experimental and characterization m ethods! practical examples from experiments using advanced diagnostic tools. numerical methods for damage prediction in composite materials! practical examples of numerical and experimental data. 
 learning outcomes: upon completion ofthis course its is intended that a student will be able to:
 1. understand what is a composite material! its advantages and limitations in aerospace use._
 2. choose the type of material and fit its structural architecture to the relevant engineering application. 
 3. understand the different failure
00360105.name: STRENGTH OF COMPOSITE MATERIALS

00360106.about:
THIS COURSE INTENDS TO FACILITATE THE HIGHER-LEVEL MATHEMATICAL BACKGROUND NEEDED IN MANY ADVANCED COURSES! SPECIFICALLY! BUT NOT EXCLUSIVELY! IN THE AREAS OF SYSTEMS AND CONTROL THE FIRST PART OF THE COURSE TOUCHES ON FUNDAMENTAL RESULTS OF REAL AND COMPLEX ANALYSIS SUCH AS ANALYTIC AND HOLOMORPHIC FUNCTIONS! PROJECTION THEOREM! CAUCHY S INTEGRAL FORMULA! PARSEVAL S THEOREM! ETC. THE SECOND PART OF THE COURSE DEALS WITH LINEAR ALGEBRA AND ITS INFINITE-DIMENSIONAL EXTENSION AKA. FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS. THIS INCLUDES THE GENERAL TREATMENT OF VECTOR AND HILBERT SPACES! NORMS! INNER PRODUCTS! LINEAR OPERATORS! SEMI-DEFINITENESS! MATRIX (IN-)EQUALITIES! SINGU LAR VALUE DECOMPOSITION! ETC. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1.  ACQUIRE THE MATHEMATICAL BACKGROUND REQUIRED TO STUDY MIMO LINEAR AND NONLINEAR SYSTEMS.
 2. LEARN OPTIMIZATION METHODS! AND INTERRELATIONS BETWEEN TIME! FREQUENCY! AND LAPLACE DOMAINS! WHICH ARE REQUIRED IN MANY INTERDISCIPLINARY FIELDS! SUCH AS DYNAMICS! CONTROL! ROBOTICS! SIGNAL PROCESSING! MACHINE LEARNING! ETC.
00360106.name: ADVANCED LINEAR ALGEBRA AND ANALYSIS

00360107.about:
THEORY OF INERTIAL SENSING! NAVIGATION! AND ORIENTATION DETERMINATION. DEEP-LEARNING THEORY. DATA-DRIVEN APPLICATIONS IN INERTIAL SENSING AND NAVIGATION FOR AUTONOMOUS PLATFORMS! ROBOTICS! AND PEDESTRIAN NAVIGATION. AS PART OF THEIR FINAL PROJECT! STUDENTS WILL APPLY THE THEORY AND APPLICATIONS LEARNED DURING THE COURSE BY SOLVING REAL-WORLD INERTIAL SENSING PROBLEMS WITH DEEP-LEARNING ALGORITHMS. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO: 1. GAIN EXPERIENCE AND CAPABILITIES IN INERTIAL SENSING AND DEEP LEARNING.
 2. GAIN THE ABILITY TO DESIGN! TRAIN! AND VALIDATE A DEEP NE URAL NETWORK.
 3. HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN REAL-WORLD INERTIAL SENSING RELATED PROBLEMS AND SOLUTIONS.
00360107.name: LEARNING BASED INERTIAL SENSING

00360710.about:
PYTHON INTRODUCTION, COMPLEX NUMBERS FOR PLANAR MOTIONS, THE SCIENTIFIC METHOD, HOLONOMIC VS NON-HOLONOMIC MOTION, A* ALGORITHM ANDPATH PLANNING, KALMAN FILTERS, PARTICLE FILTERS, KINEMATIC CHAINS, FORWARD KINEMATICS USING POX, IK AND DIFFERENTIAL IK, VISUAL SERVOING, GRAVITY COMPENSATION, REGRESSION LEAST SQUARES AND TLS, PID CONTROL AND REAL PID, LINEAR AND NON-LINEAR MODEL FITTING.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. ACQUIRE USEFUL THEORETICAL TOOLS IN ROBOTICS AND WILL BE ABLE TO EXPLAIN AND ANALYZE FEATURES REQUIRED OF A ROBOT IN ORDER TO CARRY OUT A GIVEN TASK.
 2. REALIZE, BY BUILDING AND PROGRAMMING , A ROBOT ACCORDING TO A CHANGING TASK DEFINITION.
 3. EXPLAIN THE KINEMATICS AND CONTROL CONSIDERATIONS OF THE ROBOT THAT IS IMPLEMENTED TO PERFORM A GIVEN TASK.
00360710.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN MODULAR ROBOTICS

00360711.about: THIS COURSE WILL COVER MICROFABRICATION TECHNOLOGIES, ORIGINALLY DEVELOPED FOR INTEGRATED CIRCUIT FABRICATION, AND THEIR MORE RECENT APPLICATIONS IN HEALTHCARE AND BIOLOGY. THE OPENING LECTURE WILL PROVIDE AN INTRODUCTION TO MICROFABRICATION AND MICROSYSTEMS: PHOTOLITHOGRAPHY, ETCHING, EVAPORATION, SPUTTER COATING, OXIDATION, ETC. TWO CLASSIC EXAMPLES OF SILICON MICROSYSTEMS WILL FOLLOW: PRESSURE SENSORS AND ACCELEROMETERS. WE WILL THEN MOVE ON TO MICROFABRICATION FOR HEALTHCARE AND BIOLOGY AND ""SOFT LITHOGRAPHY"" TECHNIQUES. TOPICS WILL INCLUDE (1) MICROELECTRODE ARRAYS (2) MICROFLUIDICS AND ITS APPLICATIONS TO CELL BIOLOGY, IN PARTICULAR FOR REVOL UTIONARY TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS CELL SORTING AND SINGLE CELL RNA SEQUENCING, (3) PROTEIN AND CELL MICROPATTERNING. DIFFERENT METHODOLOGIES, UTILITY, AND THE INFLUENCE OF MICROPATTERNING ON CELL MECHANICS AND ULTRASTRUCTURE, (4) MEASURING CELL FORCES USING TRACTION FORCE MICROSCOPY (TFM IS BASICALLY PIV). TWO DIFFERENT TFM METHODS: DEFORMABLE MICROPILLARS AND HYDROGELS WITH FIDUCIAL MARKERS. (5)BIOHYBRID MATERIALS FOR BUILDING ACTUATORS AND POWERING DEVICES. (6) ORGAN-ON-A-CHIP. THE COURSE WILL INCLUDE SEVERAL HANDS-ON EXPERIMENTS AND DEM
00360711.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN MICROFABRICATION

00380715.about: A rigorous and formal development of classical thermodynamics:  basic concepts, work, heat, energy, equilibrium:  the laws of thermodynamics and their generalization:  application to closed and open systems. Reversibility, availability, maximum work, entropy. Application to single and multi-component, homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, solutions and chemical reactions.
00380715.name: Advanced Thermodynamics 1

00380781.name: Robust Guidance and Control Via Min-Max

00380800.name: Analysis and Modeling Methods in Micro-Systems

00380811.name: Nonlinear Waves in Descrete Mechanical Models

00440268.name: Int. to Data Structur and Algorithms

00450002.about: The course is intended for students in their first semesters. It's purpose is to describe the many fields of electrical engineering and computer engineering and to present key aspects of the high-tech engineer's skills. Topics:Electrical and Computer Engineering. The electric and electromagnetic phenomena. Electricity grid and electric energy sources. Communication systems. Information storage. Information processing Micro-Nano-Technology devices. Photonics and electro-optic devices. Other selected topics.
00450002.name: An Overview of Electrical and Comp.Eng.

00450100.about: PRACTICE DESIGN, USE OF CST ELECTROMAGNETIC SIMULATION SOFTWARE, MEASUREMENT OF BASIC ANTENNAS (WIRE, PRINTED-CIRCUIT (MICROSTRIP)), LINEAR, PLANAR PHASED-ARRAYS. RADIATION-PATTERN, IMPEDANCE-MATCHING, POLARIZATION, DIRECTIVITY, GAIN. EFFECTS OF FEEDING. EFFECTS OF BEAM-SCANNING ON DIRECTIVITY AND GAIN. USE NETWORK-ANALYZER FOR EVALUATION OF ANTENNAS. VISUALIZATION OF RADIATION-PATTERNS AND POLARIZATION OF SCANNED BEAMS IN 3D-SPACE.
00450100.name: APPLIED ELECTROMAGNETICS LAB

00450101.about: ERROR CORRECTION CODES-TECHNIQUES AND APPLICATIONS. NOISY CHANNELS, REPETITION CODE, GAUSSIAN CHANNEL CODING, NOISE IN IMAGES, TYPOGRAPHICAL CORRECTION, CODING FOR ERASURES, BURST ERRORS AND INTERLEAVING, GRAPH CODES, CONSTRAINED CODING. SYSTEMATIC ERRORS IN COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS,  RECORDED STANDARD WI-FI SIGNAL: IN TIME AND FREQUENCY DOMAIN, SIGNAL SYNCHRONIZATION AT THE INPUT AND OUTPUT OFTHE SYSTEM, WRITING  A MATLAB FUNCTION FOR CORRECTING SYSTEMATIC ERRORS (CORRECTION OF NONLINEARITY IN THE RANSMITTER), PRACTICAL TRANSMISSION OF WI-FI PACKETS WITHOUT PRE-DISTORTION, MEASUREMENT OF THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THE DISTORTED SIGNAL AND ACTIVATION OF THE  PRE-DISTORTION ALGORITHM.
00450101.name: DIGITAL COMMUNICATION LAB.

00450102.about: THE LAB IS INTENDED TO DEMONSTRATE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF BASIC CONTROL METHODS ON ACTUAL SYSTEMS. THE CONTENTS OF THE LABORATORY WILL INCLUDE SYSTEM MODELING, PARAMETER ESTIMATION, AND DESIGN OF LINEAR CONTROLLERS USING CLASSICAL METHODS. IN THE FOUR LABORATORY SESSIONS, THE STUDENTS WILL REVISIT BASIC DESIGN METHODS OF LINEAR CONTROL, AND CARRY OUR PARAMETER IDENTIFICATION AND CONTROL OF A SERVO MOTOR, CONTROL OF A HOVERING SYSTEM, AND CONTROL OF A CIRCULAR INVERTED PENDULUM.
00450102.name: LINEAR CONTROL LAB

00450103.about: GEOMETRICAL OPTICS, PROPERTIES OF THE BASIC OPTICAL COMPONENTS, IMAGING, WAVE OPTICS, DIFFRACTION PHENOMENA (NEAR AND FAR FIELD), INTERFERENCE PHENOMENA AND COHERENCE, FOURIER TRANSFORM AND SPATIAL FILTERING, OPTICAL DETECTORS AND ANALYZERS, SPECTRUM OF LIGHT, FIBER OPTICS, LASING, OPTICAL SIGNAL AMPLIFICATION. EACH STUDENT HAS TO COMPLETE 2 OUT OF 3 PROPOSED EXPERIMENTS. EACH EXPERIMENT CONSISTS OF 2 MEETINGS, 4 HOURS EACH. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO PERFORM PREPARATORY AND SUMMARY TASKS FOR EACH EXPERIMENT.
00450103.name: PHOTONICS LAB

00450104.about: INTRODUCTION TO HIGH FREQUENCY EFFECTS ON PCB : THE STRUCTURE OF PCB, SIMULATION OF HIGH FREQUENCY EFFECTS, OBSERVATION AND MEASUREMENT WITH OSCILLOSCOPE. INTRODUCTION WITH JITTER PHENOMENON ON PCB: THE MATHEMATICAL MODEL, STATISTICAL ANALYSIS, MEASUREMENT AND ANALYSIS USING ADVANCED TEST TOOLS.
00450104.name: HIGH SPEED DIGITAL SYSTEMS LAB

00450105.about: INTRODUCTION TO TCP/IP PROTOCOL SUITE, WITH FOCUS ON THE MAIN PROTOCOLS THAT ENABLE COMPUTERS TO USE THE INTERNET. DEEP DIVE INTO TCP PROTOCOL AND ITS ALGORITHMS. INTRODUCTION TO SWITCHING AND ROUTING. SOCKET PROGRAMMING IN LINUX.
00450105.name: COMPUTER NETWORKING LAB

00450106.about: THE LABORATORY OFFERS EXPERIMENTS IN THE FOLLOWING AREAS: POWER ELECTRONICS: BUILDING, MEASURING AND ANALYZING SWITCHED POWER CONVERTERS RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEMS AND ELECTRIC VEHICLES SIMULATION OF LARGE-SCALE GRIDS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON ENERGY STORAGE AND POWER SYSTEM DYNAMICS.
00450106.name: ENERGY AND POWER SYSTEMS LAB

00450107.about: INTRODUCTION TO PYTORCH, USING DNNS FOR IMAGE AND TEXT CLASSIFICATION, REGULARIZATION AND OPTIMIZATION, HYPER-PARAMETER TUNING, CORRECT WORKING PRACTICE, USING CNNS FOR IMAGE CLASSIFICATION, , USING DIFFERENT ARCHITECTURES, TRANSFER LEARNING, RESIDUAL NETWORKS, GENERATIVE MODELS FOR IMAGE SYNTHESIS, INTRODUCTION TO TRANSFORMERS, CONTROLLABLE GENERATION, INTRODUCTION TO SELF-SUPERVISED LEARNING FOR CLASSIFICATION.
00450107.name: DEEP LEARNING LAB

00450108.about: INTRODUCTION TO BASIC TOOLS FOR IMAGE PROCESSING IN THE VISIBLE AND THERMAL SPECTRUM, COLOR SPACES, IMAGE QUALITY METRICS, USING WAVELETS FOR IMAGE PROCESSING TASKS, PREDICTIVE AND TRANSFORM CODING, IMAGE REPRESENTATIONS (E.G., SPARSE REPRESENTATION) FOR VARIOUS APPLICATIONS (E.G., INPAINTING), VARIATIONAL IMAGE PROCESSING, IMAGE REGISTRATION, FEATURE EXTRACTION, HOUGH TRANSFORM, CONCLUDING TASK.
00450108.name: IMAGE PROCESSING LAB

00450109.about: INTRODUCTION TO SIGNALS MEASURED FROM THE HUMAN BODY:  TWO SESSIONS WILL DEAL WITH SPEECH SIGNALS, AND  TWO WITH ECG AND PPG. STUDENTS WILL LEARN HOW TO ANALYZE THESE SIGNALS USING CLASSICAL SIGNAL PROCESSING METHODS. STUDENTS WILL ALSO LEARN TO DEAL WITH VARIOUSNOISES AND WORK WITH DATASETS.
00450109.name: SIGNAL PROCESSING LAB

00450110.about: LEARNING OF CADENCE TOOLS FOR SCHEMATIC/LAYOUT DESIGN AND FOR ANALOG SIMULATIONS. SMALL SIGNAL AND NOISE ANALYSIS OF A COMMON SOURCE AMPLIFIER. CORRECTION OF AMPLIFIER PARAMETERS TO IMPROVE PERFORMANCE. DRAWING OF LAYOUT OF THE AMPLIFIER. EXECUTION OF DRC AND LVSCHECKS. USE OF SEMI-AUTOMATIC LAYOUT TOOLS TO SPEED-UP CUSTOM LAYOUT DESIGN.
00450110.name: ANALOG VLSI LAB

00450111.about: EVALUATION OF ARCHITECTURES AND TRADE-OFFS FOR OPTIMAL DESIGN OF A HARDWARE ACCELERATOR (ASIC). SYSTEMVERILOG IMPLEMENTATION, FUNCTIONAL SIMULATIONS. USE OF UVM BASED VERIFICATION INCLUDING RANDOM INPUT GENERATION AND COVERAGE MEASUREMENTS. SYNTHESIS AND IMPLEMENTATION OF LAYOUT, INCLUDING SYNTHESIS, DFT, LEC, FLOORPLANNING, POWER GRID DESIGN, STANDARD CELL PLACEMENT, CLOCK TREE SYNTHESIS, FINAL ROUTE.
00450111.name: DIGITAL VLSI LAB

00450112.about: HANDS-ON LAB ON SIDE-CHANNEL ATTACKS ON MODERN PROCESSORS. THE STUDENTS WILL STUDY AND IMPLEMENT PRACTICAL ATTACKS THAT EXPLOIT HARDWARE SIDE CHANNELS, SPECIFICALLY, CACHE TIMING ATTACKS TO LEAK INFORMATION ACROSS OS ISOLATION BOUNDARIES, TRANSIENT EXECUTION ATTACKS SUCH AS SPECTRE V1, AND POWER SIDE CHANNEL ATTACKS.
00450112.name: HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE SECURITY LAB

00450113.about: INTRODUCTION TO OBJECT ORIENTED PROGRAMMING, PRIMITIVE DATA TYPES, COLLECTIONS AND STREAMS, CLASSES, INHERITANCE INTRODUCTION TO UI/UX AND APPLICATION PROGRAMMING, SERVER COMMUNICATION, SENSORS, UI/UX IN MOBILE APPLICATIONS
00450113.name: BASIC SOFTWARE LAB

00450114.about: UI/UX AND APPLICATION PROGRAMMING, SERVER COMMUNICATION, ADVANCED SENSORS, UI/UX IN MOBILE APPLICATIONS. ADVANCE SOFTWARE PRACTICES, SMART CONTRACTS ON A BLOCK CHAIN, PARALLEL PROGRAMMING
00450114.name: ADVANCED SOFTWARE LAB

00450115.about: STUDENTS WILL LEARN AND PRACTICE COMPUTER VISION TECHNIQUES. AMONG THE ISSUES OF THE COURSE THERE WILL BE: OBJECT RECOGNITION AND CHARACTERIZATION, FIND FEATURE POINTS, SEMANTIC SEGMENTATION, OBJECT TRACKING IN VIDEO, EXTRACTION OF 3D VISUAL INFORMATION, 3D-RECONSTRUCTION, CONCLUDING MISSION.
00450115.name: COMPUTER VISION LAB

00450116.about: IMPLEMENTATION OF A SYSTEM CONSISTING OF A PROCESSOR, PERIPHERAL DEVICES AND ADDITIONAL LOGIC ON A SINGLE CHIP. HARDWARE/SOFTWARE INTEGRATION AND COMMUNICATION BETWEEN THE VARIOUS DEVICES. DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS OF A MULTI-CORE MICROPROCESSOR ARCHITECTURE. EFFECT OF THE VARIOUS PARAMETERS ON THE SYSTEM'S PERFORMANCE. PARALLEL ALGORITHM IMPLEMENTATION, PERFORMANCE ANALYSIS, BOTTLENECK DETECTION, AND LOAD BALANCING. HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE.
00450116.name: A LAB IN COMPUTER ARCHITECTURES

00450117.about: COMPUTER SYSTEM UNDERSTANDING REQUIRES KNOWLEDGE IN SEVERAL AREAS. THE LABORATORY WILL CONCENTRATE ON ANALYZING THE VARIOUS BARRIERS OF A COMPUTER SYSTEM! WAYS TO OVERCOME THEM! PERFORMING MEASUREMENTS! AND ANALYZING THE EFFICIENCY OF THE VARIOUS COMPONENTS. THE LABORATORY PROVIDES PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE IMPLEMENTING A RISC-V-BASED HARDWARE SYSTEM IN AN FPGA COMPONENT.
00450117.name: LABORATORY ON COMPUTER PROCESSOR

00450118.about: THE LAB INCLUDES A BASIC THEORETICAL INTRODUCTION TO THE ATOMIC STRUCTURE AND BAND STRUCTURE OF LOW-DIMENSIONAL MATERIALS AND AN INTRODUCTION TO TRANSISTORS BASED ON CARBON-NANOTUBES AND TWO-DIMENSIONAL MATERIALS! THEIR SCATTERING PHENOMENA AND REGIMES. THE EXPERIMENTS WILL INCLUDE ELECTRICAL DEVICE CHARACTERIZATION: OUTPUT (ID-VDS) AND TRANSFER (ID-VGS) MEASUREMENTS FOR TRANSISTORS WITH DIFFERENT PROPERTIES SUCH AS CHANNEL LENGTH. STUDENTS WILL EXTRACT DEVICE PARAMETERS FROM THE MEASUREMENTS AND COMPARE THEM TO SIMULATIONS.
00450118.name: NANO-ELECTRONIC DEVICE LAB

00450119.about: COORDINATE TRANSFORMATIONS! ROTATION MATRICES! BASIC CONCEPTS IN ROBOTICS: STATE SPACE! TASK SPACE! KINEMATICS! INVERSE KINEMATICS!DYNAMICS! THE JACOBIAN MATRIX! SIMPLE PATH PLANNING. CONTROLLERS FOR ROBOT MOTION: PID! PURE PURSUIT! ILQR. BASIC DEEP LEARNING TOOLS: INFERENCE FROM TRAINED NETWORKS! OBJECT DETECTION WITH NNS! FINE-TUNING TRAINED CNNS TO NOVEL DATA. CALIBRATION OF A CAMERA TO ROBOT TASK SPACE. DETECTION AND GRASPING OF OBJECTS USING IMAGE INPUTS. TUDENTS WHO ACCOMPLISHED THE PROJECT IN MOBILE ROBOTS COURSE (046214) CAN'T TAKE THE LAB BECAUSE OF A PARTLY OVERLAP IN THE TOPICS.
00450119.name: ROBOTIC LEARNING LAB

00460010.about:
the statistical inference problem. background in probability. statistical models and sufficient statistics. point estimation, the method-of-moments, maximum likelihood and error bounds. confidence intervals and the bootstrap. hypothesis testing with a pair and multiple hypotheses. nonparametric hypothesis testing, goodness-of-fit and testing for independence. linear regression and lasso.
 learning outcomes: 
 the students will be familiar with the fundamental problems of statistical inference, and their theoretical analysis.the students will be able to rigorusly plan a statistical inference method for engineering problems and understand their limitatio ns. the student will obtain necessary background to advanced courses and research in statistics, data-science and machine learning.
00460010.name: STATISTICAL INFERENCE

00460042.name: Introduction to Electric Power Systems and Smart Grids

00460044.about:
the course focuses on energy conversion systems which are based on renewable sources. renewable sources:  photovoltaic panels and arrays! partial shading! maximum power tracking controllers and techniques. energy storage systems: optimal control of  storage devices! algorithms for electric vehicle battery management. management and trading in modern power systems: computational methods for power networks and smart grid applications.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course! the studetns will:
 1. acquire a board knowledge regarding the challenges in modern energy systems.
 2. understand standard  renewable energy sources models with focus on photov oltaic technology._
 3. be able to analyze the behavior of energy storage systems in a power grid and in an electric vehicle. 
 4. solve problems in modern power systems which are based on renewable sources and storage devices! using basic principles of energy conversion and signal processing tools.
00460044.name: RENEWABLE ENERGY SYSTEMS

00460045.about:
the course focuses on advanced design of voltage converters and power electronics circuits. several key topics are: current controlin switched power converters! filters for electromagnetic compatibility! magnetic component design! llc converter and their controlcircuits! hc-dcm-sr converter! soft switching! transformerless inverters! and principles of printed circuit design._
 learning outcomes: upon successful completion of the course! the student will be able to:
 1. design power electronics circuits and switched voltage converters! which are based either on pwm switching! or resonant operation.
 2. design and analyze control circuits used that are  used in switched voltage converters.
 3. to test and evaluate the performance of these circuits! in terms of electromagnetic compatibility.
 4. to plan and analyze the operation of printed circuits! which are used in circuits of this type.
00460045.name: DESIGN OF POWER ELECTRONICS CIRCUITS

00460053.about:
the course discuss phenomena that emerge from the quantization of light fields! namely of photons. as an engineering course! in addition to the basic physics of the photon characteristics! applications where the quantum nature of light is essential e.g. quantum sensors! quantum radars! and light based quantum computing will be examined. starting from the transition of classical light fields to photons! and then discussing variety of photonic states (number! coherent! entangled etc.) and their special features. emphasize will be given to the photonic quantum vacuum and its impact on many measureable phenomena. without matter photons are essentially mean ingless - thus photon matter interaction will be detailed which will enable the study of photons propagation in linear and nonlinear media as well as photon sources and detectors. several applications will be analyzed.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the coursethe students will be able to:
 1. understand in detail what is a photon.
 2. recognize and know to apply the distinct characteristics of quantum light.
 3. familiar with the basics of photon-matter interaction.
 4. basically design photon sources detectors and devices.
00460053.name: QUANTUM OPTICS

00460054.about:
the course will present topics in quantum information processing and quantum computing that are of relevance to the various approaches for modern day quantum computers. discrete- and continuous-variable quantum computing: qubits! gates! universality! different quantum states with emphasis on gaussian states! gaussian operators! phase space representation and the wigner function. physical implementations: superconducting qubits! photonic implementations and measurements. quantum error correction codes: error types! quantumquantum codes characterization! concatenated codes! degenerate codes! stabilizer codes! surface codes and bosonic codes! such as the  binomial! cat and gkp codes. the measurement-based quantum computation paradigm! graph states and cluster states.
 to:
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. describe and explain the basic concepts behind the various implementations of modern day quantum computers. 
 2. understand the challeges in constructing quantum computers.
 3. apply a wide varetyof different tools developed to overcome the challenges of designing quantum computers. 
 4. analyze quantum error correction codesof diffe
00460054.name: MODERN QUANTUM COMPUTING

00460205.name: Introduction to Coding Theory in Communication

00460213.about:
the course introduces basic tools in control, planning, and perception essential to the deployment of modern mobile robots in the real world (e.g., self-driving cars and autonomous drones). control: motion equations of mobile robots, open and closed loop methods.motion planning: geometric, differential, and optimal methods. perception: sensors, localization and estimation. learning outcomes:the end of the coure the students will know: 1. to derive the motion equations of a given mobile robot and design fundamental closed-loop control laws.
 2. to develop motion planning methods for a given robotic system._
 3. to develop estimation and localization m ethods for the robot. 
 4. to run those algorithms via ros and the simulator.
00460213.name: MOBILE ROBOTS

00460214.about:
this is an supplementary project to the course mobile robots. the project provides the students with hardware experience where the full control-planning-estimation stack is deployed on an autonomous race car (otherwise the students run experiments in simulation only). 
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the students will be be:_
 1. developing ros code to work on the car's computer.
 2. familiarity with the harware experience from working with the car! and dealing with issues.
 3. deploying a full autonomy stack that includes control algorithms (e.g.! pid! pure pursuit! and lqr)! motion planners (e.g.! prm and rrt)! and localization approach es (e.g.! ekf! and particle filters) on a real robot.
00460214.name: PROJECT IN MOBILE ROBOTS

00460215.about:
the students will learn basic tools in algebra and how to use them in order to design and analyze neural networks that can be applied to complex objects such as sets! graphs! point clouds and more. the course will begin with an introduction to groups! the main algebraic structure used in the field. in the second part of the course! we will use the knowledge we have gained to review central methods for designing architectures and to analyze a variety of architectures that have been presented in recent years. list of topics: groups - definitions and basic results. group actions. basic concepts in the representations of finite groups and the theory of cha racters. basic concepts in the invariant theory. deep learning on complex objects: canonization! symmetrization and intrinsic methods! characterization of linear layers! convolution on groups. examples: images! groups! graphs and three-dimensional objects. expressive power and universality.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course! students will be able to:_
 1. explain and use basic concepts in group theory._
 2. explain and use basic concepts in the field of representations of finite groups.
 3. design! analyze and implemen
00460215.name: DEEP LEARNING AND GROUPS

00460225.name: Physical Principles of Semi Conductor Devices

00460248.about:
Dispersion effect! and its impact on pulse propagation in optical fibers! interaction between light and matter: absorption! stimulated emission! spontaneous emission and the connection between these effects! continuous wave (cw) lasers! dynamics in lasers and itsapplication to study q-switch pulsed lasers! light propagation in anisotropic materials: snell equation and the index ellipsoid! the electro-optic effect and its application to modulate intensity! phase! and polarization of light.
 learning ouctomes: at the end of the course! the students will be able to:
 1. gain a deep understanding and be able to model the following effects: dispersion and its impact on optical pulse propagation in fibers! interaction between light and matter for obtaining optical amplifiers and laserswith an emphasis on optical communication systems!  propagation of light in anisotropic media! and the electro-optic effect and itsimplementation to modulate light. 2. know how to calculate fundamental limitations of optical amplifiers and lasers! and on pulse propagation in dispersive optical fibers. 3. know from the practical perspective!  to formulate the equations needed for a numerical analysis and t
00460248.name: PHOTONICS AND LASERS

00460250.name: Nonlinearity and Periodic Structures in Photonics

00460251.about:
material platforms for photonic integrated circuits. advantages and drawbacks of photonic integration. dielectric waveguides of one-dimensioanl and two-dimensional cross-sections. multiple modes of propagation and the single-mode condition. propagation effects inphotonic circuits: linear scattering! dispersion! nonlinear inded! raman and brillouin scattering! two-photons absorption! free carrier effects! temperature effects! and photoelasticity. building blocks of passive photonic integrated circuits: couplers! ring resonators! gratings! interferometers. realization of photonic filters from basic building blocks. active components: modulators! detecto rs! and the integration of light sources. coupling of light to/from the integrated circuit. co-integration of electronics and photonics. state-of-the art of industry in the field.
learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. design waveguides in photonic integrated circuits.
 2. calculate the modes of propagation in photonic integrated waveguides both analytically and numerically.
 3. design photonic-integrated filters from basic building blocks.
 4. select a suitable material platform forthe real
00460251.name: SILICON PHOTONICS

00460265.name: Advanced Circuits and Architectures with Memristors

00460280.name: Prinples and Tools for Computer Security

00460326.name: Introduction to Biological Signals and Systems

00460734.about:
introduction to quantum information theory and communication via a quantum channel: classical capacity of a quantum channel, quantum capacity, and communication with entanglement assistance. background on classical information theory and quantum information theory. postulates of quantum mechanics. isolated/noisy quantum systems. physical description of a quantum channel and mathematical definition. basic communication protocols and resource inequalities. classical and quantum entropy and information measures. the meaning of conditional entropy and why can it be negative. quantum method of types and schumacher compression. capacity of a quantum channel for the transmission of classical information (bits). capacity theorem for a classical-quantum channel. the regularization problem and super-additivity of the holevo information. communication with entanglement assistance.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able :
 1. understand the principles at the basis of quantum shannon theory, the information-theoretic description of communication problems, and basic protocols for the conversion of quantum resources. 
 the students will apreciate the significant
00460734.name: QUANTUM INFORMATION THEORY

00460746.name: Algorithms and Application in Computer Vision

00460747.about:
the speech signal and its acoustics characteristics, pitch and formants, representations of the speech signal: lpc, spectrum, mel, cepstrum, mfcc, isolated word recognition, dtw and keyword spotting, automatic speech recognition: acoustic model, pronunciation model, language model, acoustic modeling: hidden markov models (hmms), deep learning models, loss functions and ctc, transformers, speech synthesis and vocoders.
 learning outcomes: with the completion of the course, the students will know:
 1. understand and be familiar with how speech is generated and the acoustic components of the speech signal, how speech is represented in deep neural network systems.
 2. be familiar with probabilistic modeling and deep learning algorithms for estimating, recognizing, and detecting a sequence of random variables and how they can be used with speech signals.
 3. be familiar with the most recent models for automatic speech recognition and how to train them.
 4. will be familiar with the most recent models for generative algorithms for sequence generation, conditional and unconditional, and how to apply them to synthesize human-like speech.
00460747.name: DEEP LEARNING FOR SPEECH SIGNALS

00460853.name: Advanced Architecture of Micro- Processors' Systems

00460880.name: Logic Design Automation of Vlsi Systems

00460881.about:
the course deals with formal hardware verification, combining theory and advanced real-life use, emphasizing principles and methodologies to overcome t   theoretical limitations of formal methods. the course material includes an introduction to chip design and hardware verification, exploration of formal verification algorithms and search engines, use of temporal logic and sva, reduction methods, formal applications for ip and soc designs, logic equivalence and coverage, security specifications and verifications, machine learning in formal verification.
 learning outcomes:
 with the completion of the course, students will be able to use the learned ide as and concepts of verification, especially in formal verification. the students will deeply understand different applications and modern tools used in industry and with advanced verification methods. the knowledge acquired in the course will serve as an excellent basis for research and development of verification tools and methods.
00460881.name: HARDWARE FORMAL VERIFICATION

00460887.about:
The class objective is to introduce the breadth of research areas at the department, and to help students who consider a m.sc. degree to choose their own future research field. every week, two faculty members will give short lectures overviewing the topics of their current research. the lectures will be followed by a discussion with the lecturers. the course is intended for students in the first year of their m.sc., before submitting a research proposal, as well as undergraduate students with average grade above 84 and over 100 accumulated credit points. 
 Learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will:
 1. Become familiar with faculty m embers.
 2. Be aware of research areas and research methods.
 3. Be abe to futher develop skills for digesting research presentations and reading professional publications. 
 4. Be abe to further develop skills for critical reviewing of research talks and papers.
 5. Be able to choose personal research direction for graduate studies.
00460887.name: INTRODUCTION TO DEPARTMENTAL RESEARCH

00460918.name: Physical Design Automation of Vlsi Systems

00460954.about:
ANALOG DESIGN METHODOLOGY BASED ON FEEDBACK CONTROL OF EVERY IMPORTANT PARAMETER IN THE SYSTEM.STABILITY OF THE RESULTING MULTILOOPSYSTEM. CURRENT MIRRORS WITH UNMEASURABLE HIGH OUTPUT IMPEDANCE, TRANSCONDUCTORS WITH WIDE INPUT RANGE, ANY LOAD-STABLE LDOS WITH INSTANT LOAD REGULATION. STRUCTURAL DESIGN METHODOLOGY, PRACTICAL FREQUENCY COMPENSATION, BANDGAP VOLTAGE REFERENCES, OPERATIONAL AMPLIFIER SPEED, ACCURACY AND CONSUMPTION IMPROVEMENT.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW THE FUNDAMENTAL ISSUES IN ANALOG CIRCUIT DESIGN AND WILL HAVE THE ABILITY TO PERFORM CIRCUIT DESIGN, INCLUDING ANALYSIS OF CIRCUITS SUCH AS BANDG AP VOLTAGE REFERENCES AND OPERATIONAL AMPLIFIERS.
00460954.name: TOPICS IN ANALOG CIRCUIT DESIGN

00460955.about:
ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE! AND SPECIFICALLY DEEP NEURAL NETWORKS BECOME THE SINGLE MOST INTERESTING APPLICATION. IT IS EXPECTED THAT A GROWING PERCENTAGE OF THE WORLD'S COMPUTE POWER WILL BE DEDICATED TO TRAINING AND INFERENCING OF NEURAL NETWORKS FOR MANY TASKS. TRAINING LARGE NEURAL NETWORK MODELS SUCH AS LARGE LANGUAGE MODELS (LLM) REQUIRE SPECIALIZED SYSTEMS AND STANDARD DATACENTERS CANNOT TRAIN SUCH MODELS IN AN EFFICIENT WAY. THIS COURSE AIM TO COVER MULTIPLE ASPECTS OF DESIGNING AND BUILDING HIGH-PERFORMANCE LARGE-SCALE DATACENTERS (SUPERCOMPUTERS) FOR MODERN AND FUTURE NEURAL NETWORK TRAINING. IN THIS COURSE! WE WILL COVER ACCELERATED COMPUTING A ND THE ROLE OF GPUS AND SPECIALIZED CPUS IN FUTURE AI SYSTEMS AS WELL AS THE IMPORTANCE OF HIGH-PERFORMANCE INTERCONNECT. THE COURSE CONSISTS OF A SERIES OF LECTURES. SEVERAL LECTURES ARE BASED ON PUBLISHED PAPERS AND OTHER COVER RECENT RESEARCH PERFORMED IN NVIDIA. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. EXPLAIN TECHNOLOGICAL TRENDS AND CONSIDERATIONS IN THE DESIGN OF DATA CENTERS FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE APPLICATIONS.
 2. DESCRIBE TRAINING PROCESSES OF LARGE MODELS FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELL
00460955.name: TOPICS IN AL DATA-CENTER HW ARCHITECTURE

00470100.about:
OVERVIEW OF ULTRAFAST OPTICAL PULSES: AN INTRODUCTORY STUDY ON THE ULTRAFAST OPTICAL PULSES. TRANSMISSION OF OPTICAL PULSES IN FIBER OPTICS, CONSIDERING BOTH LINEAR AND NON-LINEAR PHENOMENA. GENERATION OF ULTRAFAST PULSES USING VARIOUS LASER TECHNOLOGIES, SUCH ASSOLITON, DISPERSION-MANAGED SOLITON, DISSIPATIVE SOLITON, PASSIVE AND AMPLIFIED PARABOLIC PULSES, AND "MAMYSHEV" LASERS. GENERATIONOF ULTRAFAST PULSES BEYOND THE CONFINES OF A LASER CAVITY.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:_AT THE END OF COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO: 1. UNDERSTAND AND ANALYZE THE PROPAGATION OF ULTRAFAST OPTICAL PULSES AND EVALUATE THE RESULTS OF LINEAR AND NON-LINEAR EFFECTS IN  OPTICAL FIBERS.
 2. UNDERSTAND THE ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES OF DIFFERENT PULSE LASERS AND PULSE COMPRESSION METHODS.
 3. DESIGN A LASER WITH A SPECIFIC OUTPUT.
 4. WRITE A SIMULATION AND OPTIMIZATION PROGRAM FOR A PULSE LASER, OPTICAL PULSE COMPRESSOR ETC.
00470100.name: TOPICS IN FIBER BASED ULTRAFAST SOURCES

00480000.about: computational photography is an emerging new field created by the convergence of computer graphics, computer vision and optics. itsrole is to overcome the limitations of traditional cameras and imaging systems by using computational techniques to capture better and richer information about our world. applications spread from everyday photography to all fields of science, from astronomy to microscopy, and in medical imaging. topics include: basic imaging and optics, depth of field, defocus and motion deblurring, computational cameras, compressive imaging, light fields, burst imaging and high dynamic range, computational illumination, light transport, t ime of flight cameras.
00480000.name: Computational Photography

00480001.about:
GEOMETRIC DATA PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS IS A FAST-GROWING RESEARCH DIRECTION WITH APPLICATIONS IN A BROAD RANGE OF FIELDS. IT IS BASED ON CLASSICAL AREAS SUCH AS DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY AND HARMONIC ANALYSIS, WHILE CURRENT APPLICATIONS INVOLVE CONTEMPORARY TOPICS SUCH AS GEOMETRIC DEEP LEARNING, DIMENSIONALITY REDUCTION, AND SIGNAL PROCESSING ON GRAPHS.
