THE MAIN PURPOSE OF THIS COURSE IS TO INTRODUCE THE FUNDAMENTAL THEORY OF GEOMETRIC DATA ANALYSIS, WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS PUT ON A UNIFIED PERSPECTIVE ON BOTH CONTINUOUS AND DISCRETE ANALYSIS, AS WELL AS EMERGING RELATED APPLICATIONS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDETNS WILL BE ABLE T O:
 52 1. DEFINE FUNDAMENTAL TERMS IN SPECTRAL GRAPH THEORY AND DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY._
 2. APPLY GEOMETRIC ANALYSIS TECHNIQUES TO HIGH-DIMENSIONAL DATA.
 3. IMPLEMENT (IN MATLAB/PYTHON) ALGORITHMS FOR DATA EMBEDDING AND DIMENSIONALITY REDUCTION.
00480001.name: PROCESSING AND GEOMETRIC ANALYSIS INFORM

00480004.about:
geometric data processing and analysis is a fast-growing research direction with applications in a broad range of fields. it is based on classical areas such as differential geometry and harmonic analysis, while current applications involve contemporary topics such as geometric deep learning, dimensionality reduction, and signal processing on graphs. the main purpose of this course is to introduce the fundamental theory of geometric data analysis, with special emphasis put on a unified perspective on both continuous and discrete analysis, as well as the emerging relatd applications. 
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the studetns will be abl e to:
 1. define fundamental terms in spectral graph theory and differential geometry.
 2. apply geometric analysis techniques to high-dimensional data.
 3. implement (in matlab/python) algorithms for data embedding and dimensionality reduction.
00480004.name: GEOMETRIC DATA PROCESSING AND ANALYSIS

00480006.about:
THE GOAL OF THIS CLASS IS TO EXPOSE THE STUDENTS TO A VARIETY OF MODERN METHODS FOR VISUAL DATA COMPRESSION! WITH EMPHASIS ON VIDEO. THE COURSE WILL PRESENT THE PRINCIPLES UNDERLYING MODERN SYSTEMS AND STANDARDS FOR IMAGE AND VIDEO COMPRESSION! AND FUNDAMENTAL TRADEOFFS! SUCH AS THE RATE-DISTORTION AND RATE-PERCEPTION-DISTORTION TRADEOFFS. TOPICS COVERED IN THE COURSE WILL INCLUDE PREDICTIVE AND TRANSFORM CODING! HYBRID VIDEO CODING! MOTION ESTIMATION! ALGORITHMS FOR RATE CONTROL! AND METHODS FOR VIDEO QUALITY ASSESSMENT.IN ADDITION! THE COURSE WILL COVER RECENT ADVANCEMENTS IN LEARNED IMAGE AND VIDEO COMPRESSION! AND THE DESIGN! TRAINING AND ANALYSIS  OF DEEP NEURAL NETWORK MODELS FOR COMPRESSION! SUCH AS GENERATIVE ADVERSARIAL NETWORKS (GANS) AND VIDEO COMPRESSION TRANSFORMERS.
LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. UNDERSTAND AND DESCRIBE THE METHODS UNDERLYING MODERNIMAGE AND VIDEO COMPRESSION SYSTEMS.
 2. DEVELOP AND ANALYZE EFFICIENT VIDEO COMPRESSORS.
 3. UNDERSTAND! DESIGN! AND ANALYZE STATE-OF-THE-ART METHODS THAT USE DATA TO TRAIN DEEP NEURAL NETWORK MODELS THAT CAN SERVE AS HIGHLY EFFICIENT IMAGE AND VIDEO COMPRESSORS.
00480006.name: TOPICS IN IMAGE AND VIDEO COMPRESSION

00480010.about:
O PRESENT PAPERS THAT HAVE BEEN SELECTED FROM THE FIELD._
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:_
 1. TO BE ABLE TO EXPLAIN THE TRANSFORMER ARCHITECTURE IN DETAIL.
 2. TO BE ABLE TO ANALYZE DIFFERENT TRANSFORMER ARCHITECTURES AND TRAINING METHODS AND COMPARE THEM.
 3. TO BE ABLE TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT TRANSFORMERS IN A VARIETY OF FIELDS.
00480010.name: TOPICS IN DEEP LEARNING: TRANSFORMERS

00480080.about:
THE COURSE SURVEYS MAIN RESEARCH TOPICS ON MODERN COMPUTER SYSTEMS, WITH THE FOCUS ON THE INTERACTION BETWEEN HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE, SUCH AS SECURE EXECUTION (SPECIFICALLY, TRUSTED EXECUTION ENVIRONMENTS), ADVANCED OPERATING SYSTEM DESIGN, HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE SUPPORT FOR COMPUTATIONAL AND I/O ACCELERATORS, AND MORE. IT COVERS BOTH CLASSIC PAPERS AND RECENT DEVELOPMENTS._
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW:
 1. WILL BE EXPOSED TO THE METHODS AND IMPORTANT TOPICS IN SYSTEMS RESEARCH.
 2. WILL BE EXPOSED TO PRINCIPLES OF SECURE HARDWARE AND ADVANCED OPERATING SYSTEMS.
00480080.name: S.T. IN COMPUTER SYSTEMS-A. SOFTWARE

00480100.about:
in this course, we will study methodologies to guarantee the reliability, robustness, equity, and reproducibility of advanced machine learning systems, such as deep neural nets. we will discuss recent concerns about modern machine learning algorithms and will tackle these by introducing flexible tools that are supported by theoretical guarantees. we will focus on prediction uncertainty estimation as well as mitigation of discrimination against minorities. we will also explore frameworks for multiple hypothesis testing as powerful tools for making new scientific discoveries and for interpreting complex learning systems. this advanced course covers influ ential papers in the field of dta science. learning outcomes: by the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. quantify the uncertainty in predictions obtained by any machine learning algorithm. 2. analyze whether predictions obtained by a machine learning algorithm are biased against sub-populations. 3. implement data-driven statistical tests for a single hypothesis. 4. implement data-driven statistical tests for multiple hypotheses.
00480100.name: RELIABILITY IN MODERN MECHINE LEARNING

00480102.about:
THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON DEEP GRAPH ARCHITECTURES. FIRST FEW LECTURES WILL PROVIDE AN OVERVIEW OF THE FIELD. WE WILL THEN SWITCH TOA SEMINAR FORMAT WHERE A PAIR OF STUDENTS WILL PRESENT 2-3 ARTICLES PER WEEK ON TOPICS SUCH AS THEORY! APPLICATIONS! GRAPH GENERATION.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE TO: 1. UUNDERSTANDING OF THE LATEST LITERATURE IN THE FIELD OFGRAPH LEARNING.
 2. EXPERIENCE IN SUMMARIZING AND WRITING REVIEWS OF ARTICLES._
 3. EXPERIENCE IN DELIVERING A PRESENTATION ON A RESEARCH PAPER.
00480102.name: TOPICS IN DEEP LEARNING ON GRAPHS

00480150.about:
numerous scientific fields have recently expanded their capabilities thanks to extensive data collection. the high-dimensional probability methodology enables an understanding of the fundamental limits of extracting information from such data. the course will present its elements, and demonstrate its applicability in statistical inference and learning problems. 
 1. introduction to probability in high dimension and non-asymptotic statistics. 2.  subgaussian random variables and hoeffding's inequality. subexponential random variables and bernstein's inequality. bernstein's conditions. orlicz spaces. applications in estimation and classification problems .
 3. maximal inequalities. nets, covering and packing numbers. applications in unconstrained linear regression and under sparsity assumptions._
 4. concentration of matrix norms. concentration of sums of independent matrices, and matrix bernstein s inequality. davis-kahan inequality. applications in matrix estimation, matrix denoising, community detection, and principal component analysis (pca)._
 5. minimax lower bounds.  basic and tensorization properties of information divergences. le-cam s two point method and multiple-hypot
00480150.name: PROBABILITY IN HIGH DIMENSIONS FOR DATA

00480200.about:
THIS COURSE WILL BE GIVEN IN A SEMINAR FORMAT. STUDENTS WILL GET EXPOSED TO RECENT WORK ON MULTI-ROBOT SYSTEMS, WITH AN EMPHASIZE ON ALGORITHMIC ASPECTS IN COORDINATION, PLANNING, AND CONTROL. THEORETICAL TOPICS WOULD BE CONSIDERED AS WELL AS PRACTICAL CONSIDERATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF AUTONOMOUS DRIVING, SMART MOBILITY, DRONE NETWORKS, AND WAREHOUSE ROBOTICS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE:
 1. FAMILIARITY WITH RESEARCH AREAS, METHODS, AND TOOLS IN MULTI-ROBOT SYSTEMS, WITH EMPHASIS ON ALGORITHMIC FOUNDATIONS OF CONTROL AND MOTION PLANNING._
 2. DEVELOP SKILLS IN EVALUATING AND CRITIQUING RESEARCH PAPERS IN ROBOTICS AND SMART MOBILITY._
 3. DEVELOP PRESENTATION SKILLS AND APPLY THE ASSERTION-EVIDENCE METHOD FOR PRESENTATION DEVELOPMENT.
00480200.name: TOPICS IN ROBOTICS: MULTI-ROBOT SYSTEMS

00480214.about:
THIS COURSE WILL BE GIVEN IN A SEMINAR FORMAT. STUDENTS WILL BE EXPOSED TO RECENT WORK ON AUTONOMOUS ROBOTIC SYSTEMS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON ALGORITHMIC ASPECTS IN CONTROL, PLANNING, AND ESTIMATION. THEORETICAL TOPICS WOULD BE CONSIDERED AS WELL AS PRACTICAL CONSIDERATIONS. ON THE SIDE OF THEORY, WE SHALL REVIEW, FOR INSTANCE, LEARNING-BASED APPROACHES FOR PLANNING AND CONTROL, DISTRIBUTED COMPUTATION AMONG ROBOTS, MARKOVIAN REASONING, AND ROBOTIC NETWORKS. ON THE PRACTICAL SIDE, WE WILL CONSIDER, E.G., COORDINATION BETWEEN MULTIPLE ROBOTS, AUTONOMOUS DRIVING, SEARCH AND RESCUE, ROBOTS IN SPACE AND UNDERGROUND, AND SMART MOBILITY. THE STUDENT PRESENTATION S WOULD BE BASED ON SURVEY PAPERS FROM THE ANNUAL REVIEW OF CONTROL, ROBOTICS, AND AUTONOMOUS SYSTEMS AND CENTRAL PAPERS IN THE STUDIED AREAS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO: 1. FAMILIARITY WITH RESEARCH AREAS, METHODS,AND TOOLS IN AUTONOMOUS SYSTEMS, WITH EMPHASIS ON ALGORITHMIC FOUNDATIONS OF CONTROL, PLANNING, AND ESTIMATION.
 2. DEVELOP SKILLS IN EVALUATING AND CRITIQUING RESEARCH PAPERS IN ROBOTICS AND CONTROL.
 3. DEVELOP PRESENTATION SKILLS AND APPLY THE ASSERTION-EVIDENCE METHOD
00480214.name: TOPICS IN ROBOTICS: MODERN METHODS AND A

00480250.about:
the course deals with the fundamentals of network coding theory. the course will review  the main models, algorithms, and codes of network coding in detail, particularly for distributed data systems and communications. we will consider several practical solutionsand applications of network coding in various areas of networking, security, storage, and distributed computing.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. familiar with advanced network coding techniques for distributed data systems and heterogeneous communications, the practical solutions and applications of network coding in various areas of networking, a nd the main challenges in using them.
 2. gain an understanding of the settings in which using network coding is advantageous, as well as in the caveats that must be avoided to make effective and efficient use of network coding in distributed data systems and heterogeneous communications._
 3. to characterize the main challenges of using coding in distributed systems and the advantages of using network coding.
00480250.name: NETWORK CODING FOR ADVANCED INFORMATION

00480300.about:
THE COURSE WILL COVER TWO RECENT IMPORTANT DEVELOPMENTS RELATING PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS (PDE) OF FREE BOUNDARY TYPE AND PROBABILITY. ONE IS INTERACTING PARTICLE SYSTEMS WHOSE HYDRODYNAMIC LIMIT IS GIVEN BY A FREE BOUNDARY PROBLEM. IN THESE MODELS! BROWNIAN PARTICLES ON THE REAL LINE ARE SUBJECT TO BRANCHING AND SELECTION. SELECTION REFERS TO REMOVAL OF A BOUNDARY PARTICLE. THE COURSE WILL PRESENT PROOFS OF THE RELATIONS BETWEEN THE PROBABILISTIC MODELS AND PDE. THE SECOND DEVELOPMENT IS THE PROBABILISTIC REPRESENTATION OF OF SOLUTIONS TO THE SUPERCOOLED STEFAN PROBLEM! WHICH DESCRIBES THE INTERACTION BETWEEN TWO PHASES OF A MATERIAL: LIQUID AND  SOLID. IT HAS LONG BEEN KNOWN THAT CLASSICAL SOLUTIONS TO THIS PROBLEM DO NOT EXIST GLOBALLY. THE NEW APPROACH TO BE TAUGHT IN THECOURSE IS A PROBABILISTIC REPRESENTATION OF SOLUTIONS TO THE PDE! ALONG WITH THE PROOF OF THE CENTRAL RESULT IN THE AREA! NAMELY THE EXISTENCE AND UNIQUENESS OF GLOBAL SOLUTIONS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. READ AND COMPREHEND ARTICLES FROM CURRENT LITERATURE ON THE SUBJECT. MORE BROADLY.
 2. MATHEMATICAL TOOLS COVERED ARE RELEVANT AND IMPORTANT FOR RE
00480300.name: PROBABILITY AND STOCHASTIC PROCESSES

00480710.about: the course will describe advanced topics in integrated optoelectronics and analyze modern devices and systems for light modulation and detection on-chip.  the course will discuss the integration of novel nanomaterials in optoelectronics to enhance light-matter interaction and will review recent publications from the lecturer field of expertise.
00480710.name: Advanced Topics

00480711.about: Design and construction of components connected with linear and nonlinear optics and their applications.  Construction of equipmentto measure intensity, wave length, etc.  Building of laser devices. Measurements on various lasers with the aim of understanding their operation and finding their characteristic parameters.  Optical data processing, fiber optics, sensors and interferometry.  Measurements by lasers, optics of thin films, photography by lasers and holography. Electro-optic materials and their use in linear and nonlinear optics.
00480711.name: Electrooptics Laboratory 1

00480712.about: Design and construction of linear and nonlinear optics components and their applications.  Construction of equipment to measure intensity, wave length, etc. Building of laser devices. Measurements on various lasers with the aim of understanding their operation and finding their characteristic parameters.  Optical data processing fiber optics, sensors and interferometry.  Measurements with lasers, optics of thin films, photography by lasers and holography. Electro-optic materials and their use in linear and nonlinear optics.
00480712.name: Electrooptics Laboratory 2

00480715.about: This is an advanced course in systems, learning and control. It will be concerned with advanced topics of current interest which lie within the research interests of the teacher. A detailed outline will be provided by the lecturer and the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is given.
00480715.name: Advanced Topics in Systems, Learning and Control 1

00480716.about: This is an advanced course in systems, learning and control. It will be concerned with advanced topics of current interest which lie within the rsearch interests of the teacher. A detailed outline will be provided by the lecturer and graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is given.
00480716.name: Advanced Topics in Systems, Learning Control 2

00480717.about: advanced topics in systems learning and control to be determined according to the research interests of the teacher. a detailed outline will be provided by the teacher and the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is taught.
00480717.name: Advanced Topics in Systems Learning and Control 3

00480718.about: the course will cover advanced topics in systems, learning and control. the course will survey recent literature connected to the lecturer's research interest.
00480718.name: Advanced Topics in Systems Learning and Control 4

00480719.about: the course will cover advanced topics in systems, learning and control. the course will survey recent literature connected to the lecturer's research interest.
00480719.name: Adv.Topics in Systems Learning Control

00480720.about: an advanced course dealing with a variety of topics in machine learning, from the lecturer's field of expertise.  detailed syllabusand learning outcomes will be beginning of each semester in which the course will be given. the course will also serve as a basis for students interested in carrying out research thesis in the field.
00480720.name: AN ADVANCED COURSE IN MACHINE LEARNING 1

00480722.about:
OTIMIZATION IS A CENTRAL TOOL TO FORMALIZING AND SOLVING MACHINE LEARNING AND BIG DATA  PROBLEMS. WE WILL STUDY RECENT ADVANCED TOOLS IN OPTIMIZATION AND AND DEMONSTRATE HOW TO EMPLOY THESE TOOLS IN ORDER TO SOLVE PROBLEMS IN STATISTICAL LEARNING, OPTIMIZATION AND GAME THEORY.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSES THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW:
 1. THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW ADVANCED TECHNIQUESAND ALGORITHMS IN OPTIMIZATION, AND WILL BE ABLE TO READ AND UNDERSTAND RELATED PAPERS.
 2. THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO DESIGN ANDANALYSE OPTIMIZATION METHODS USING THE TOOLS THAT WE WILL STUDY._
00480722.name: TOPICS IN LEARNING: OPTIMIZATION METHODS

00480732.about: This is a seminar-like course dealing with advanced topics, theretical and applied, which are pertinent to the generation, reception propagation and scattering of waves. Research topics of the instructor will be emphasized.
00480732.name: Advanced Topics in Wave Theory 1

00480747.about: Analysis of physiological systems.  Development and application of signal pattern recognition methods for diagnostic purposes. Development of instrumentation for physiological research and clinical investigation.  Parametric analysis of biological systems. Development and simulation of models for biological systems and processes.
00480747.name: Biolgical Signals and Systems Laboratory

00480812.about: the course presents current applications of oxides in microelectronics, focusing on high-k dielectrics in cmos technology. the course then address the physics and applications of functional oxides. the course interweaves aspects of the physics underlying the unique elecronic properties of the oxides with practical aspects of oxide growth and examples of integration in electronic devices. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will have a broad perspective on oxides as electronic materials and their applications in current and future electronic devices. the student will be able to identify the relations between the material properties (atomic structure, composition) with the electronic structure in several case studies, and explain their underlying physics. the student will be able to explain the prospects and usefulness of functional oxides in future electronic devices.
00480812.name: Oxide Physics and Devices

00480816.about: The projects offered are the development and implementation of digital signal processing algorithms for communication applications such as speech and image coding and enhancement.  Both software development and real-time hardware implementations can be carried out in the lab.
00480816.name: Signal Processing Laboratory

00480823.about: Model representations.  Guided waves and the transmission line analogy in open and closed structures.  The dispersion relation.  Green's functions and their classification.  Guidance and radiation properties of stratified structures.  Alternative representations and characteristic Green's functions.  Integration in the complex plane: asymptotic techniques, singular contributions and their geometrical interpretation.  The geometrical theory of diffraction (GTD):  edge and vertex diffraction, creeping waves.
00480823.name: Analytical Methods in Wave Theory 1

00480828.about: array signal processing in the time and frequency domains, subspace methods, beamforming, performance measures, spatial aliasing, delay-and-sum, superdirective, null steering, minimum variance distortionless response (mvdr), linearly constrained minimum variance (lcmv), generalized sidelobe cancellers (gsc), direction-of-arrival estimation, adaptive beamforming, differential beamforming, beampattern design. learning outcomes: students who will successfully complete the course will be able to: 1.implement algorithms for array signal enhancement in the time and frequency domains. 2.design and apply optimum beamformers for spatial filtering in sensor arra ys.
00480828.name: Array Signal Processing and Analysis

00480836.about: the hfic lab is focused on research in integrated circuits for various applications, as communication imaging and sensing. hfic provides a research environment for graduate students for future wireless and wireline communication systems on highly-integrated cmos implementations including areas of interest as: rf.mm-wave circuits, algorithmic and high speed mixed signal, radio system architectures. the lab is equipped with a modern probe station to enable on wafer measurements and a full characterization up to 110 ghz. learning outcomes:  by the end of the hfic lab the student will be familiar with the research  environment of integrated circuits for va rious applications, as communication imaging and sensing. the student will learn various areas of interest such as: rf.mm-wave circuits, algorithmic and high speed mixed signal, radio system architectures
00480836.name: The Hfic Lab

00480843.about: articial and natural agents operating complex environments are often required to function under highly challenging conditions of uncerainty resulting from partiial and delayed observations, model ignorance system-malfunctions and communication bottlenecks a possible approach dealing with such difficulties is the adoption of a strategy which balances exploitation and exploration roughly speaking exploitation aims at utilizing previously gained knowledge in order to promote a goal, while exploration focuses on discovering novel strategies which may be beneficial in the future. the ee balance has assumed center stage in biology since the time of darein an d has played a foundational role in the theories of optomal control and reinforcement learning since the early 1960s however exceptin very limited setups, there is little understanding of provably effective ways to balance exploration and exploitation in this course we will study the ee tradeoff from multiple perspectives and within different systems, bothe natural and artificial, in an attempt to distill general principles of operation such a perspective may lead to a better understanding of biological systems and in turn, contribut
00480843.name: Exploration and Exploitation in Artificial and Natural Agents

00480846.about: Advanced course in which current topics in computer communication networks will be discussed. The course will also serve as a basisfor student interested in carrying out thesis research in the field. Winter Semester 2017.2018: System Aspects of Communication Networks.
00480846.name: Topics in Computer Communication Networks 1

00480848.about: Advanced course in Elecrtro-Optics. The topics will be chosen according to the interest of the instructor.
00480848.name: Advanced Topics in Electro Optics 1

00480852.about: Investigation of modern energy sources.  Magnetic fields and mechanical forces caused by permanent magnets.  Microprocessor measurements in power systems.  Controllers and process control. Simulation of electro-mechanical systems.  Power electronic devices. DC & AC motor control.
00480852.name: Advanced Energy Conversion Laboratory

00480860.about:
Introduction:  The human vision system, image sensors, image displays.  Image Transforms:  2D-FT, Hadamard, Walsh, SVD and KarhunenLoeve transforms.
 Image Enhancement:  Histogram modification, smoothing and sharpening by filtering techniques. Image Restoration: Correction of de-focusing and movement effects, Wiener filtering. Image Compression:  Information preserving techniques,  predictive and transform methods. Introduction to image analysis and computer vision.
00480860.name: Image Processing

00480864.about: Course addressing advanced topics in architecture, design and analysis of computer systems. The course will also serve as a basis for student interested in carrying out thesis research in the field.
00480864.name: Advanced Topics in Computer Architecture 2

00480865.about: An advanced course in signal processing which deals  with research topics in the over of interest of the instructor.
00480865.name: Selective Topics in Signal Processing 2

00480866.about: Advanced course in which current topics in computer communication networks willl be discussed. The course will also serve as a basis for student interested in carrying out thesis research in the field.
00480866.name: Computer Communication Networks 2

00480867.about: Advanced course in Electro-Optics. The topics will be chosen according to the interest of the instructor.
00480867.name: Advanced Subjects in Electrooptics 1+2

00480870.about: In this course, advanced topics in novel areas in the the department will be developed under the individual supervision of a staff member.  The course is intended for students who are in the initial phases of  searching for a research subject and do not yet have a research thesis supervisor.  The course can be taken for one semester only in each of the M.Sc. and D.Sc study programs.
00480870.name: Developing Topics in Electrical Engineering 1

00480871.about: In this course, advanced topics in novel areas in the department will be developed under the individual supervision of a staff member. The course is intended for students who are in the intial phase of searching for a research subject and do not yet have a research thesis supervisor. The course can be taken for one semester only in each of the M.Sc. and D.Sc study programs.
00480871.name: Developing Topics in Electrical Engineering 2

00480877.about: The laboratory offers software hardware and projects.  The student will be individually supervised by one of the teachers. Prerequisites will be determined by the instructor according to the project chosen.
00480877.name: Hardware and Software Laboratory

00480879.about: Advanced topics in design methodologies and architectures of VLSI systems.  Specific topics will be selected in coordination with the students from the following:  Architectures of processor arrays, simple and complex processors, special-purpose processors, reconfigurable topologies of processing arrays, wafer-scale integration, CAD tools:  simulations, verification and silicon compilers.
00480879.name: Seminar in Vlsi Architecture

00480885.about: the course will survey the main technological developments in computer engineering.
00480885.name: Advance Topics in Computer Engineering

00480887.about:
the class objective is to introduce the departmental researchelds fields to students who consider a msc degree in the electricalering engineering department, and help them choose their own futureeld. research field. every week, two departmental faculty members willures give short lectures overviewing the topics at the forefront of theire research fields. the lectures will be followed by a q-asession with the lecturers. the course is intended for students in the first year of their msc, before submitting a research proposal, as well as excellent students in the last year of their bsc.
 learning outcomes: the class will introduce students to the variety  of research topics in the electrical engineering department.
00480887.name: Introduction to Departmental Research

00480888.about: cryptocurrencies are typically implemented on p2p networks with blockchain protocols. the properties and guarantees of these protocols achieve unprecedented security by using techniques from grame theory, distributed systems, and cryptography. their architecture raises a variety of questions and exposes challenges in security, privacy, and performance. the course will  teach tools for design and analysis of blockchain protocols, and review classical and contemporary results: hash functions, encryption schemes, synchronous.asynchronous consensus, markov chains, system design, event-driven simulation, blockchain basics, transactions, smart contracts, pro of of work (pow), proof of stake (pos), classical cryptocurrencies, high-performance blockchains, blockchain attacks and defenses, privacy. learning outcomes: familiarity with tools for design and analysis of blockchain protocols and cryptocurrencies, as well as the cutting edge solutions. after the course, the student will be able to 1. analyze the security and privacy of a blockchain protocol, 2. analyze and simulate blockchain and consensus protocols. 3. design all layers of a blockchain system.
00480888.name: Blockchin and Cryptocurrency Protocols

00480889.about:
advanced course dealing with current research topics in machine learning for computer networks. the course will cover recent papersin networking and machine-learning conferences. the topics include machine learning and optimization for a wide range of networkingapplications, such as routing, congestion control, packet scheduling, hashing, and bloom filters. learning ouctomes:
 at the end ofthe course the student will be:
 a. familiarity with the research approach in machine learning and optimization for computer networks.
b. familiarity with the current literature.
c. acquisition of scientific presentation skills.
00480889.name: Machine Learning for Computer Networks

00480890.about:
neural networks have shown tremendous success in many domains. at the same time, recent years have shown the simplicity of fooling networks by adversarial example attacks. these attacks undermine the reliability of deep learning-based systems. in this seminar, wewill learn about these attacks and how to deal with them. in particular, we will learn:_
 - methods for proving robustness of neural networks to adversarial attacks. 
 - training methods that leverage formal methods with the goal of improving the neural network'srobustness. 
 - methods for understanding the robustness behavior of neural networks.
we will focus on practical methods, study tool s that im implement them, and learn the limitations required to make these methods capable of analyzing deep networks. we will alsodiscuss open research questions. the seminar will cover papers from leading conferences. 
learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. explain practical methodologies to guarantee correctness of deep networks.
 2. familiar with current  research chalenges in guaranteeing correctness of deep networks.
00480890.name: Seminar in Correctness Guarantees for Deep Learning

00480891.about:
the course focuses on hardware methods for building secure systems and methods of attacking them.
 a special emphasis is given to side-channel attack methods and advanced machine learning techniques for reverse engineering. we will learn the theory of using such attacks and experience how they work using dedicated education kits. the course will also cover recent research results of protecting advanced systems as well as attacking them.
 learning outcomes: the main goal of the course is to teach the students and to allow them hands-on experience of: 1. what is hardware security, and why it is needed.
 2. the use of side-channel attacks and how to prote ct against them.
 3. the best-known methods of implementing hardware security techniques. 
 4. the  use of existing means e.g. sgx (intel), trustzone (arm).
00480891.name: Hardware - Security - from Theory to Practice

00480892.about:
design and analysis of algorithms for blockchain networks. topics: fundamentals of blockchain networks. fairness, sharding and off-chain channels. focus on graph theory tools: flow, routing, coloring, clustering and topology design. data structures and coding methods. clustering and topology design. data structures and coding methods. learning outcomes:
 following the seminar, a student will be familiar with various major challenges in the area of blockchain networks and will have tools for dealing with such challenges. the student will be able to analyze and understand the pros and cons of a particular approach. the student will be exposed to tools th at can help in the future with new challenges in the field.
00480892.name: BLOCKCHAIN ALGORITHMS

00480907.about: foundations of light propagation in tissue and review of current optical imaging techniques which enable tissue visualization at several scales of depth. special attention will be given to tomographic approaches for imaging depths in which light is completely diffusive. current applications of diffuse light mostly in the fields of biology and medicine. light scattering by small particles. light propagation in biological tissue:  models and simulation tools. ballistic techniques in optical imaging. diffusive techniques in optical imaging. hybrid techniques in optical imaging. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be: 1. familiar w ith the physical underpinnings of light propagation in biological tissue. 2. familiar with the analytical and numerical techniques used in the field. 3. capable of analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of various imaging techniques and will know how to explain the origin of the differences.
00480907.name: Optical Propagation in Scattering Media and Its Application to Biomdical Imaging

00480921.about: An advanced course in image and vision sciences which deals with topics in the area of interest of the instructor.
00480921.name: Visual Systems and Image Structure

00480922.about: The students will carry out projects concerned with the visual system, image structure, pattern recognition and various aspects of computer vision.  The projects will require the implementation and testing of algorithms for interpretation of images and 2-D signals in general.
00480922.name: Vision Image Structure and Computer Vision Laboratory

00480929.about: Topics covered in this course: adaptive algorithms for FIR filters, the RLS and the Lattice filter,  adaptive filtering in the frequency domain. The LMS will be extensively studied, its performance and convergence results will be the most recent in the literature. Applications of adaptive filters in communications and signal processing will be extensively discussed.
00480929.name: Adaptive Signal Processing

00480930.about: Advanced course in Electro-Optics. The topics will be chosen according to the interest of the instructor.
00480930.name: Selected Topics in Electrooptics

00480931.about:
THE COURSE INTRODUCES CLASSICAL AND GENERALIZED INFORMATION MEASURES, AND IT STUDIES SOME OF THEIR APPLICATIONS IN DATA SCIENCE, STATISTICS, PROBABILITY AND COMBINATORICS. THE FIRST HALF OF THE COURSE REFERS TO THE CLASSICAL INFORMATION MEASURES BY SHANNON AND TOTHEIR APPLICATIONS, THE SECOND PART OF THIS COURSE REFERS TO FISHER INFORMATION, TO GENERALIZZED INFORMATION MEASURES AND THEIR APPLICATIONS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: 
 1. THE STUDENT WILL BE EXPOSED TO VARIOUS CLASSICAL AND GENERALIZED INFORMATION MEASURES, AND TO SOME OF THEIR APPLICATIONS IN DATA SCIENCE, STATISTICS, PROBABILITY AND COMBINATORICS.
 2. THE STUDENT WILL BE CAPABLE OF THINKING ABOU T THE INCORPORATION OF INFORMATION MEASURES FOR SOLVING PROBLEMS IN DATA SCIENCE, AND ABOUT UTILIZING INFORMATION MEASURES WHICH PROVE HELPFUL IN SOLVING MATHEMATICAL PROBLEMS. THE ACQUAINTANCE WITH INFORMATION MEASURES AND THEIR APPLICATIONS IS OF RELEVANCE TO MULTI DISCIPLINES IN THE FIELDS OF ELECTRICAL ENGINEERING, COMPUTER SCIENCE, MATHEMATICS AND PHYSICS.
00480931.name: Information Measures and Applications

00480933.about: Prerequisites: At least 3 courses in the communications chains of undergratuate studies.  Specific requirements will depend on the subject. The projects will be in the realization of advanced algorithms for demodulation and decoding as well as for design of codes.
00480933.name: Communications Laboratory

00480934.about: Fundamental concepts and parameters of digital communication systems. Important channel models.  Block and convolutional codes and their ensemble performance.  Trellis codes.
00480934.name: Coded Communications

00480940.about: An Advanced course in signal processing which deals with research topics in the over of interest of the instructor.
00480940.name: Topics in Signal Processing 4

00480942.about: Advanced topics in Communication Theory will be discussed.
00480942.name: Advanced Topics in Communication and Information 3

00480951.about:
PHOTONIC INTEGRATED CIRCUITS FOR MODULATION, PRE-DETECTION OF LIGHT PHASE, AMPLITUDE, POLARIZATION, FREQUENCY. ADVANCED PHOTON STATISTICS: PHOTODETECTION, OPTICAL AMPLIFICATION. COHERENT OPTICAL DETECTION: PRINCIPLES, PERFORMANCE LIMITS, SUB-SYSTEMS (INTEGRATED PHOTONICS, DSP). APPLICATIONS: ULTRA-HIGH-SPEED PHOTONIC INTERCONNECTS WITH DIRECT.COHERENT DETECTION. COHERENT REMOTE SENSING: LIDAR, DISTRIBUTED-FIBER-SENSING.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL KNOW:
 1. APPRECIATE THE WIDE APPLICABILITY OF THE COHERENT DETECTION IN USE CASES RANGINE FROM NEXT-GEN DATA INTERCONNECTS TO REMOTE OPTICAL SENSING OVER BOTH FIBER-OPTICS A ND FREE-SPACE OPTICAL PROPAGATION MEDIA. 2. COMPREHEND DIRECT-DETECTION.COHERENT PHOTONIC COMMUNICATION AND SENSING SYSTEMS UNDER AUNIFIED FRAMEWORK, COMBINING PHYSICAL OPTICS, MATHEMATICAL SIGNAL AND NOISE ANALYSIS, AND MODERN OPTICAL ENGINEERING PRINCIPLES. (SUCH AS THE USE OF SILICON INTEGRATED PHOTONICS). 3. ABILITY TO ANALYZE, DESIGN, MEASURE, VALIDATE THE OPTO-ELECTRONIC LINK BUDGET OFOPTICAL SYSTEMS SUBJECT TO COMMON PRINCIPLES: DATA TRANSMISSION SYSTEMS, LIDAR AND 3D VISION SYSTEMS, FIBER OPTIC METROLOGY SYSTEMS.
00480951.name: Photonic Cmmunication and Sensing

00480954.about: the goal of this class is to expose the students to a variety of statistical methods for solving image processing problems the course will cover an introduction to nonparametric estimation nonparametric dimensionality reduction methods statistical properties of natural images. markov random fields applications to denoising deblurring super resolution, clur kernel estimation. learning outcomes: 1. the student will be familiarity with basic statistical methods and their use in image processing in particular. 2. the sudent will be able to fit the statistical models learned in class to a variety of signal processing problems as well as to implement estimat ion algorithms for solving these problems.
00480954.name: Statistical Methods in Image Processing0

00480964.about: Results from Fourier analysis and the theory of linear spaces. Non-stationarity and time-varying systems. Time-Frequency (T-F) methods: A classification. Continous and discrete Short-Time Fourier Transforms (STFT). Tiling of T-F plane. The continuous wavelet- transform and the scalogram. Discrete wavelet-transform and frame theory. Wavelet and Gabor frames. The Haar basis. Orthonormal waveletbases and multiresolution. Relaxing the orthogonality constraint. Regularity of orthonormal wavelet bases. Wavelets, subband filtering and Malat's algorithm. Orthonormal bases with compact support. Symmetry and bi-orthogonal wavelet bases. Adaptive, waveform analy sis: Base libraries search procedures for an optimal basis. Adaptive, shift-invariant decompositions. Two-dimensional wavelet expansions.
00480964.name: Mixed Time-Frequency Representation and Applications

00480966.about: The laboratory is offered to grduate students interested in the field of microelectronics.  Prerequisits:  at least 3 courses in the microelectronics and solid state physics chain of undergraduate studies.  The projects will be either in the design.characterization of ICS or in the characterization of electtrical and electro optical devices as well as in the processing of microelectronics devices.
00480966.name: Microelectronics Laboratory

00480967.about: The lab is intended for students interested in carrying out projects in the area of computer networks and telecommunications.  The projects will include the development of both hardware and software for computer networks.  The laboratory may serve as an initial phase in determining a research thesis in this area.
00480967.name: Computer Networks Laboratory

00480972.about: An advanced course in image and vision sciences which deals with topics in the area of interest of the instructor.
00480972.name: Advanced Topics in Image Structure 2

00480976.about: The laboratory is intened for students who are interested in carrying out a project in the area of computer systems and subsystems in general, and parallel ones in particular. Additional prerequisite and concurrent courses (undergraduate and graduate) will be determined for each topic.  Project topics will include design of systems, construction of development tools for advanced systems, as well as performance evaluation through measurement and simulation. Projects will entail development of systems software and.or hardware as necessary,  with particular emphasis on system performance and the contributors to it. This labortory may constitute a first st ep in formulating a research topic in the field.
00480976.name: Laboratory in Parallel Systems

00480978.about: Electrons dynamics (generation and propagation).  Interaction of electrons with waves in the low gain  compton regime, fast and slow wave interaction.  Space charge waves. High gain  compton regime. Beam modulation  by cavities: the klystron. Slow wave structures: dielectric and periodic, floquet theorem.  Traveling wave amplifier and backward wave oscillator.  Free electron laser.  Gyrotron.Magnicon.
00480978.name: Radiation Sources Based on Electron Beams

00480979.about: topics will be selected from modern developments in probability theory and stochastic processes.
00480979.name: Selected Topics in Probability and Stoch

00480980.about: Cooperation and competition in large-scale and broadband networks: motivation and examples.  Game theory fundamentals.  Flow control games, routing games, competition on bandwidth.  Design of noncooperative networks: the Braess paradox, topology design, capacity allocation, gateway design.  Management of noncooperative networks:  Stackelberg strategies, levying tools.
00480980.name: Design Management Noncooperative Communication Networks

00480985.about: introduction to algebric topology. modern topological tools for big data analysis and various engineering problems. applications oftopological methods in various areas such as network analysis, signal processing, biological systems, etc. probabilistic and statistical analysis of topological systems. learning outcomes: 1. the student will get familiar with the fundamentals of applied topologytheir advantages and applications in engineering 2. the student will be able to implement these topological metods.
00480985.name: Topological Methods in Engineering, Networks and Data Analysis

00480989.about:
the course presents tools for analyzing the dynamics of new energy sources and modern power systems. the course has three main parts: the quasi-static approximation and its limitations, the  dq0 transformation, and uses of distributed control in power systems. students will also learn how to analyze dynamic phenomena using matlab - simulink. 
 learning outcomes: 1. students will understand standard power system dynamic models. 2. students will understand the quasi-static approximation and its limitations. 3. students willbe able to analyze the dynamics of complex power systems in simulation.
00480989.name: Power System Dynamics

00480990.about: Within the framework of this course, the students can undertake a project which comprises either a literature search and.or suitable simulations and.or appropriate computer programming, and.or laboratory project implementation. The project can serve as a partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master if Electrical Engineering (i.e. the non-thesis Master program).
00480990.name: Seminar 1

00480991.about: Within the framework of this course, the students can undertake a project which comprises either a literature search and.or suitable simulations and.or appropriate computer programming and.or laboratory project implementation. The project can serve as a partial fulfilment of the requirements for the degree of Master in Electrical Engineering (i.e. the non-thesis Master program).
00480991.name: Seminar 2

00480996.about: Periodic structures in microwave, optical and quantum systems. Open and closed periodic structures.  Scattering and propagation problems.  Green's function. Transients.  Two and three dimensional structures.  Systems of finite number of identical cells. radiation from electrons moving in periodic structures.
00480996.name: Waves in Periodic Stuctures

00490005.about: The laboratory is intended for students who wish to carry out projects in the area of control, and who complied with the prerequisites and with other courses (in undergaduate.graduate curricula) which will be determined according to the chosen subjects. The projects will primarily be in realization and simulation of algorithems in advanced control topics, using the laboratory equipment.  The laboratory may serve as a first step in defining a research subject leading to a thesis in the control area. Enrolling to the courseis conditioned on approval by the faculty member in charge.
00490005.name: Control Topics Laboratory

00490006.about: The laboratory is intended for students who wish to carry out projects related to electromagnetic fields or waves. The student is expected to design, implement and test various devices related to these projects. Measurements may be performed either in the time orin the frequency domains. It is possible to carry out numerical projects with available software. The laboratory might be a convenient first stage in the process of determining a research topic for a future advanced degree thesis.
00490006.name: Electromagnetic Waves Laboratory

00490014.about: Review of updated developments in probability theory and random processes.
00490014.name: Selected Topics in Probability Theory and Stochastic Processes 2

00490018.about: advanced topics in architecture, design and analysis of computer systems.
00490018.name: Advanced Topics in Computer Systems 3

00490026.about: Theory of knowledge in distributed systems and its application to the design of distributed protocols and the modelling of multi-party games. Possible-world sematics, modeling distributed systems. Modal logics of knowledge and time, knowledge of individuals, common knowledge and related state of knowledge of groups, knowledge in games, application to the design and analysis of distributed protocols and games.
00490026.name: Knowledge and Games in Distributed Systems

00490027.about: Basic results on single-user channel coding. The Gaussian channel. Vector Gaussian channel and water pouring. Band limited Gaussianchannel. Single-user channels that depend on random states. Capacity with side information. The basic multi-user channel models. Coding theorem and the capacity region of the multiple access channel (Mac). The Gaussian Mac. The general broadcast channel. The degraded broadcast channel (DBC). The Gaussian broadcast channel. Overview of basic results on single-user source coding. Lossless coding for correlated sources (slepian-Wolf). Lossy source coding with side information. The Wyner-Ziv problem. Optional: duality between channel coding and source coding with side information.
00490027.name: Multi-User Information Theory

00490032.about: updated developments in the communication field from the aspects of information theory and statistical communication theory.
00490032.name: Advanced Topics in Communication and Information 4

00490036.about: advanced topics in design and analysis of vlsi systems. the course will also serve as a basis for students interested in carrying out thesis research in the field.
00490036.name: Advanced Topics in Vlsi 1

00490037.about: advanced topics in design and analysis of vlsi systems. the course will also serve as a basis for students interested in carrying out thesis research in the field.
00490037.name: Advanced Topics in Vlsi 2

00490040.about: topics: coded communications ldpc and ra codes. asymptotic anlysis of ldpc ensembles on the binary erasure channel. performance vs.complexity of ldpc and ra codes on the binary erasure channel. iterative message-passing decoding algorithms and the sum-product algorithm. asymptotic analysis of ldpc ensembles on binary-input output - symmetric memoryless channels and the derivation of density evolution equations. the bcjr algorithm and log-map iterative decoding of turbo codes. exit charts for the examination of the convergence behavior of iterative decoding algorithms. facotr graphs and their general appllications in digital communications.
00490040.name: Codes on Graphs and Iterative Decoding Algorithms

00490042.about: the physical foundation and the mathematical tools for the comprehension and design of photonics circuits on an optical chip. topics:  overview of optical chips and application - the physical foundation of optical surface waves. the modes of optical structures based on complex media and especially nano-sized. basic photonic circuit elements (including optical couplers, switcher, periodic structures, filtering and routing elements). plasmonics - light guiding in nano - metalic structures.
00490042.name: Advanced Photonic Circuitry

00490050.about: topics in nano-electronics, to be determined according to the research interests of the teacher. a detailed outline will be provided by the teacher and the graduate studies committee prior to the semester in which the course is taught.
00490050.name: Advanced Topics in Nano-Electronics 1

00490053.about: the lab is intended for students who wish to research the area of machine learning and its applications, such as natural language processing, recognition in audio and images. the project will be supervised by a senior faculty member and could be considered as a first step toward a thesis in this area.
00490053.name: Machine Learning Laboratory

00490056.about: state-of-the-art research in shape analysis in three dimensions on similarity, segmentation, saliency detection, understanding collections of shapes, shape completion, feature curves on surfaces.
00490056.name: Topis in Computer Vision: Shape Analysis

00490061.about: channel polarization, successive cancellation decoding, error exponents, code construction algorithms, generalizations of the original polarizing matrix,compression via polarization, and related subjects. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to design, encode and decode a polar code.
00490061.name: Polar Codes

00490062.about: physical approaches for three dimensional mapping of objects and scenes, mainly by light. the approaches are based on triangulation, depth of field, structured light, coherence, scattering , diffraction analysis, shading, shadows, polarization, aperture engineering, fluorescence, time of flight and tomography. the scenes span scales: microscopic, through macroscopic, to astronomic. approachesfor three dimensional display. learning outcomes: following the course the students will 1. be familiar with principles and approches for passive and active measurments of object range. 2. be familiar with principles and approches for passive and active measurment s of object slopes (gradients) and three dimensional shapes. 3. be familiar with principles and approches for sensing volumetric objects (e.g. tomography). 4. be familiar with principles and approches for creating visual effects exploited for three dimensional display. 5. understand the limitations and advantages of the different approaches.
00490062.name: Three Dimensional Imaging and Consnstruction

00490063.about: combinatorial and algorithmic problems related to data access: command queues and rotational position optimization, constrained data placement. analytical treatment of indirection systems: combinatorial modeling of indirection systems, optimal wear leveling, dataplacement via graph algorithms. data representation- coding data for optimized access: write once memories, re-write codes. date reliability: errors,faults and their models, basic elements in combinatorial and algebraic error correcting coding theory, , asymmetric and unidirectional errors, array codes for storage systems, reliability analysis of codes storage systems. open problems: combinato rial theory problems, algorithmic problems. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be 1. familiar with the algorithnic and analytical techniques that enable the design of modern storage devices, including non volatile memories and large scale storage system. familiar with a comprehansive set of tools laying the foundation for deep and effective research contribution in the area of data storage.
00490063.name: Information in Storage Devices

00490064.about: basic principles in energy minimization methods (convex and non convex nonlinear diffusion (perona malik) and anisotropic diffusion(weickert). contour evolutions using level sets, active contour segmentation. numerical implementation of nonlinear pde's. total variation denoising, denoising with higher order functionals. evolution of manifolds. nonlocal operators and energies. applications denoising,deconvolution, image enhancement, segmentation, optical flow, image registration. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will: 1. be able to use mathematical knowledge and will be familiar with convex optimization tools. 2. be able to imple ment code for numerical solution of nonlinear partial differential equations. 3. know advanced image processing algorithms which are based on these methods.
00490064.name: Variational Methods in Image Processing

00540132.about: student will learn open-ended problem-solving and team-work skills. experience with the course-project will expose them to the tools needed to solve industrial-size design problems - tools that will be acquired during the remainder of the degree. the course also serves as a route map for their degree program. this course is part of the technion wide "good start" initiative.
00540132.name: Mini-Project in Chemical Engineering

00540133.about: Brief introduction of the technion and the faculty of chemical eng. Definition of the chemical engineering and the Biochemical Engineering disciplines. Role of the chemical and biochemical engineer in the industry. research in chemical engineering. The course is intended for chemical engineering or biochemical engineering students during their first semester.
00540133.name: Overview of Chem Biochem Eng

00540135.about: The aim of this course is to introducethe field of chemical and biochemical engineering, and to provide basic tools to those who study this field. The coverd topics include: the chemical industry in Israel, an introduction to biotechnology and to the production of bio-chemicals. Accuracy anf units. Non-dimensional numbers, ideal.nonideal gases, Liquid.gas phase equilibrium, the phase rule, and steam tables. Material balances: steady state material balances, without and with chemical reactions, material balances with recycle and bypass. Energy balances: the general energy balance equation, heat and work, steady state energy balances. Energy balances wit h chemical reactions, simultaneous material and energy balances. Non-steady state material and energy balances.
00540135.name: Intro. to Chemical and Biochemical Eng.

00540136.about: Filtration of biochemicals, cell disruption, introduction to membrane separation.
00540136.name: Separation Processes 1 Chem-Bioche Eng

00540203.about: The class deals with the principles of momentum transfer in fluid dynamics and their aoolication to engineering. The dollowing topics will be covered. Fundamental concepts: continuum, stresses, viscosity, scalar and vector fields. Fluid statics. Kinematics: equations in integral form, Euler and Lagrange equation, strean lines, vorticity, rate of deformation. Mass balances, continuum equation.Fluid dynamics: stresses, Newton's law, microscopic momentum balances, equation of motion, Energy balances, mechanical energy balance, Bernoulli's equation, turbulent flow, flow in closed tubes and pipes, fluid machinery. Boundary layer.
00540203.name: Principles of Chemical Engineering 1M

00540251.about: Summer work in the chemical industry on a project that will provide the student with first-hand industrial experience. Duration of work - minimum 6 weeks.  The student is required to present a written report describing the nature of his work in the plant. Note: The course is open to students that have accumulated at least 80 credit points.
00540251.name: Summer Work in Industry 1

00540305.about: Industrial separation operations based on principles of mass transfer. Interphase mass transfer.  Stagewise and differential contact separation in gas-liquid systems ( absorption, distillation, humidification ), liquid-liquid systems ( extraction ) and solid-fluid systems ( drying, crystallization ). Introduction to multicomponent separations.
00540305.name: Separation Operations 2

00540309.about: THE COURSE DEALS WITH CHEMICAL ENGINEERING UNIT OPERATIONS AND KINETICS- AND EQUILIBRIUM-DRIVEN SEPARATIONS. THE SUBJECTS INCLUDE FLOW IN PIPES, FLOW ACCESSORIES, PUMPS, FLOW THROUGH STATIONARY AND FLUIDIZED BEDS, SOLID FILTRATION, PARTICLE SIZE ANALYSIS, SEDIMENTATION, PRECIPITATION, CRYSTALLIZATION, MEMBRANE AND ELECTRO-SEPARATIONS, DISTILLATION, EXTRACTION, ADSORPTION, CHROMATOGRAPHY, HUMIDIFICATION AND DRYING OF SOLIDS.
00540309.name: Separation Processes Chem-Biochem Eng

00540310.about: The purpose of this laboratory is to train the students in: 1.  Operating typical equipment units and instrumentation.  2.  Data acquisition and analysis.  3.  Technical report writing.  4.  Team work.  The experiments are designed to illustrate the principles ofmomentum and heat transport processes and their application to the appropriate unit operations.
00540310.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory 1

00540314.about: Development of a dynamic process model. Linearization. Analysis of dynamic systems in the time and Laplace domain. Time domain response of linear systems. Stability. Design and tuning of feedback control systems. Analysis and synthesis of feedback control systemsusing the Root Locus method. Familiarization and use of computer programs for the solution of mathematical models, and for analysisand graphical display.
00540314.name: Int. to Process Dynamics and Control M

00540315.about: Equilibrium between phases, estimation of composition in ideal and non-ideal solution, activity coefficients, chemical equilibrium,estimation of compositions in equilibrium, flow
00540315.name: Thermodynamics B

00540316.about: basic concepts, intensive and extensive parameters, internal energy and the first law, energy, work and heat calculations, equations of state, heat calculations in chemical processes, entropy and the second law, carnot cycle, kinetic theory and temprature, open systems, joule-thomson effect, thermodynamic properties, free energy, gibbs' phase rule, heat machines and pumps, two laboratory exercises, a practical project.
00540316.name: Advanced Thermodynamics a

00540317.about: phase equilibrium in multi-component systems. composition calculation for ideal and non-ideal solutions, activity coefficient, electrolyte solutions, chemical equilibrium, and equilibrium compositions. laboratory experiments for determining values of enthalpy, entropy and gibbs energy, solid surface tension, classification of solutions according to excess properties, stability and separation prediction into two phases.
00540317.name: Advanced Thermodynamics B

00540318.about: in this lab experiments are carried out to illustrate the principles and processes behind the basic opertaions of processes based on momentum and heat transfer. goals: a) understand and operate typical instrumentation. b) learn how to perform experiments on laboratory scale industrial equipment and analysis of results. c) learn how to write a technical report d) learn how to work in team. thelaboratory is conducted in the form of a series of 5 hour experiments preformed by groups of students every two weeks. after each experiment a full technical report is provided.
00540318.name: Chemical Engineering Lab. Bio-Chem

00540319.about: Phase equilibrium in multi-component systems. Composition calculation for ideal and non-ideal solutions, activity coefficient, electrolyte solutions, chemical equilibrium, and equilibrium compositions. Laboratory experiments for determining values of enthalpy, entropy and gibbs energy, solid surface tension, classification of solutions according to excess properties, stability and separation prediction into two phases.
00540319.name: Advanced Thermodynamics B

00540320.about: introduction to heat and mass transfer in chemical engineering. heat transfer mechanisms. energy balances and the differential equation for heat transfer. steady and unsteady state conductive heat transfer. convective heat transfer: dimensional analysis, the thermal boundary layer, correlations for forced and natural convective heat transfer coefficients. heat transfer with phase change. heatexchangers. radiative heat transfer. mass transfer mechanisms, the differential equation for mass transfer, steady and unsteady state diffusive mass transfer. convective mass transfer. the solutal boundary layer. applying computational methods for the solution of heat and mass transfer problems.
00540320.name: Principles of Chemical Engineering 2M

00540321.about: REACTION RATES, ELEMENTARY REACTIONS, REVERSIBILITY AND EQUILIBRIUM, TEMPERATURE EFFECTS, COMPLEX REACTIONS, CHAIN REACTIONS, EXPLOSIONS, POLYMERIZATION.  HOMOGENEOUS CATALYSIS.  ENZYMATIC KINETICS, ADSORPTION AND HETEROGENEOUS CATALYSIS. THE KINETIC THEORY OF GASES, COLLISION THEORY, POTENTIAL SURFACES, ACTIVATED COMPLEX THEORY.
00540321.name: Introduction to Chemical Reactors'Design

00540322.about: THE PROPERTIES OF VARIOUS IDEAL REACTORS: BATCH, PFR, CSTR, SEMI BATCH.  ANALYSIS OF SIZE EFFECTS AND PRODUCTS' DISTRIBUTION UNDER ISOTHERMAL CONDITIONS.  ANALYSIS OF THERMAL EFFECTS IN BATCH, SEMI BATCH, PFR, AND CSTR REACTORS:  AUTOTHERMAL OPERATION, OPTIMAL TEMPERATURE ROUTE, STABILITY CONSIDERATIONS. MODELS DESCRIBING REAL REACTORS, RESIDENCE TIME DISTRIBUTION. HETEROGENEOUS SYSTEMS: THE GLOBAL RATE EQUATION, MASS AND HEAT TRANSPORT IN SOLID FLUID CATALYTIC REACTIONS, EFFECTIVENESS. DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS.
00540322.name: Reactor Design Principles

00540324.about: THE COURSE DEALS WITH CHEMICAL ENGINEERING UNIT OPERATIONS AND KINETICS- AND EQUILIBRIUM-DRIVEN SEPARATIONS. THE SUBJECTS INCLUDE FLOW IN PIPES, FLOW ACCESSORIES, PUMPS, FLOW THROUGH STATIONARY AND FLUIDIZED BEDS, SOLID FILTRATION, PARTICLE SIZE ANALYSIS, SEDIMENTATION, PRECIPITATION, CRYSTALLIZATION, MEMBRANE AND ELECTRO-SEPARATIONS, DISTILLATION, EXTRACTION, ADSORPTION, CHROMATOGRAPHY, HUMIDIFICATION AND DRYING OF SOLIDS.
00540324.name: Separation Processes Chem-Biochem Eng

00540330.about: the objective of this course is to provide experience and knowledge in chemical process simulation. the material covered integratesthe use of simulation in the following subjects: material and energy balances, heat and mass transfer, thermodynamics, multicomponent vapor-liquid equilibrium, and others. the course makes use of self-paced teaching materials in multimedia to allow progress at a rate suiting each participant.
00540330.name: Chemical Process Simulation Laboratory

00540350.about: Introduction and definitions.  Mechanisms of polymerization.  Kinetics of chain polymerization.  Kinetics of copolymerization.  Kinetics of stagewise polymerization.  Industrial polymerization processes in bulk, suspension, emulsion and solution.  Chemical structure of useful polymers.
00540350.name: Polymers 1

00540351.about: Thermodynamics of polymer solutions. Methods of molecular weight determination. Rheology of polymeric solutions and melts. Physicalproperties of polymers in the solid state. Amorphous and crystalline structures. Rubber elasticity. Fabrication methods of thermoplastics.
00540351.name: Polymers 2

00540364.about: Summer work in the chemical industry on a project that will provide the student with first-hand industrial experience. Duration of work: minimum 6 weeks. The student is required to present a written report describing the nature of his work in the plant. Note: thecourse is open to students that have accumulated at least 120 credit points.
00540364.name: Summer Work in Industry 2

00540367.about: Experimental or theoretical research project on topics of particular interest in various disciplines of chemical engineering under the supervision of a senior faculty member. Note: the course is open to students with academic distinction only.
00540367.name: Research Project 1

00540368.about: Experimental or theoretical research project on topics of particular interest in various disciplines of chemical engineering under the supervision of a senior faculty member. Note: the course is open to students with academic distinction only.
00540368.name: Research Project 2

00540369.about: Bulk polymerization and molecular weight characterization. Unsaturated polyesters and related products. Thermodynamics of polymer solutions. Morphology and transitions. Rheology of molten polymers. Compounding and analysis of fabrication processes of thermoplastic materials. Mechanical, thermal and physical properties of polymers.
00540369.name: Polymer Engineering Laboratory

00540373.about: Crystal structures. Bonding in solids. Crystallography and diffraction techniques. Microscopy, spectroscopy, thermal analysis. Crystal defects and non-stoichiometry, application: selective membranes, solid solutions, interpretation of phase diagrams, electrical properties, magnetic and optical properties, synthesis methods.
00540373.name: Int. Solid State Chemistry for Engineers

00540375.about: Introduction, background: crystalline structures, energy bands, density of states, the Fermi level, mobility and conductivity, doping, basic microelectronic devices. The fabrication plant, silicon growing, oxidation, diffusion processes, ion implantation, photolithography, wet and dry etching, chemical vapor deposition, epitaxial growth, metallization processes, integrative elements of production.
00540375.name: Semiconductor Device Fabrication for Chemical Engineers

00540376.about: utilization of engineering knowledge in daily life, with focus on the principles of ecological devices encountered in the home environment. introduction of ecological devices encountered in daily lives, and their engineering principles. among the introduced devices: desert coolers, solar cookers, geothermal cooling, photovoltaic panels, natural construction materials.
00540376.name: Ecological Engineering in Daily Lives

00540377.about: many chemical products are produces, transferred and sold as powders. expertise in powder technology is essential to produce powders with suitable properties, handling these powders and further processing them. the course will focus on industrial (focusing on pharmaceutical industry) aspects of making and using powders: crystallization, separation, size reduction, processing and characterization methods.
00540377.name: Introduction to Powder Technology

00540378.about: SELECTED TOPICS FOCUSING ON PROPERTIES OF POLYMERS AND POLYMERIC SYSTEMS, THEIR STRUCTURE, AND STRUCTURE PROPERTY RELATIONSHIP. MECHANICAL AND PHYSICAL PROPERTIES. CRYSTALLINE AND AMORPHOUS STRUCTURE, TRANSITION TEMPERATURES, INTRODUCTION TO VISCOELASTICITY: RELAXATION AND CREEP. ELASTICITY, THERMOPLASTIC ELASTOMERS. DESCRIPTION OF THE BEHAVIOR OF SELECTED POLYMERS.
00540378.name: Structure and Properties of Polymers

00540400.about: The experiments performed in this laboratory are designed to illustrate the principles of mass transfer processes and chemical reaction engineering and their applications.  The aim of the laboratory and its mode of operation are similar to those of Chemical Engineering Laboratory 1.
00540400.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory 2

00540406.about: Experimental or theoretical research on problems of particular interest in various disciplines of chemical engineering.  The research projects are supervised by senior faculty members and usually extend over 2 consecutive semesters. Students are required to submit two interim reports.
00540406.name: Senior Thesis 1

00540407.about: The student will generally complete the research project started in Senior Thesis 1 and is required to submit a final report and participate in a Poster session.
00540407.name: Senior Thesis 2

00540408.about: collision theory, potential surfaces, reaction coordinates, theory of activated complexes, reaction order. first and second order reactions, complex reactions, chain reactions. temperature effects. homogeneous catalysis. adsorption and heterogeneous catalysis. enzymatic kinetics and cell growth. the properties of various ideal reactors: batch, pfr, cstr. analysis of size effect and products' distribution under isothermal conditions.
00540408.name: Introduction to Chemical and Biochemical Reactors' Design

00540409.about: analysis of thermal effects in batch, semi batch, pfr, and cstr reactors: autothermal operation, optimal temperature route, stability considerations. models describing real reactors, residence time distribution. heterogeneous systems: the global rate equation, mass and heat transport in solid -fluid catalytic reactions, effectiveness. design consideration.
00540409.name: Reactor Design Principles

00540410.about: process and mechanical considerations in process design. process and mechanical flowsheets. materials of construction. safety and environmental protection. design of piping, pressure vessels, heat exchangers, pumps and compressors, distillation columns, solid.liquid systems and plant services. group final project including: process and mechanical flowsheets, material and energy balances, and specification sheets for the main equipment items.
00540410.name: Plant Design M

00540411.about: Applying and integrating chemical engineering concept to solve practical problems related to the energy field. Students will take part in a design and development project simulating tasks faced by a chemical engineer.
00540411.name: Project in Chemical Engineering: Energy

00540412.about: enzyme-catalyzed reactions kinetics, inhibition and cooperativity, immobilized enzymes, introduction to metabolic control analysis.flux balance in metabolic networks. systems-level aspects of metabolism and genetic regulation. restriction enzymes and their use in genetic engineering. expression vectors and cloning. dna libraries. dna sequencing, amplification, mutagenesis. applications of genetic engineering to medicine. growth stochiometry. microorganisms and their cultivation. population growth kinetics. biological reactors. heat and mass transfer in bio-reactors. genetic stability in population and in reactors.
00540412.name: Biochemical Engineering

00540413.about: This course deals with applications of polymers, in biotechnology, in particular synthetic polymers. Applications in the field of medicine, such as drug controlled release and tissue engineering, in the field of bioseparations such as two-phase extraction, membrane separation and sorbents for chromatography, and advanced technologies such as utilizing "smart polymers" for switches.
00540413.name: Polymers and Applications in Biotechnol.

00540415.about: THE OBJECTIVE OF THE COURSE IS TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE OF THE KEY PROCESSES IN THE PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRY AND THE ENGINEERING CONSIDERATIONS IN THEIR DESIGN, THROUGH LECTURES BY SENIOR ENGINEERS IN THE INDUSTRY LED BY A FACULTY MEMBER. THE COURSE INCLUDES AN OVERVIEW OF THE OIL AND GAS INDUSTRIES. THE FOLLOWING SUBJECTS WILL BE PRESENTED: CRUDE OIL REFINING PROCESSES, THERMAL AND CATALYTIC PROCESSES FOR PROCESSING AND CRACKING OF CRUDE OIL DISTILLATES, EXTRACTION AND UPGRADING PROCESSES FOR AROMATIC MATERIALS, ETHYLENE AND POLYOLEFIN PRODUCTION PROCESSES, CRUDE OIL AND DISTILLATES  ECONOMY, TRADE AND LOGISTICS, PROCESS PROBLEMS ANALYSIS, EQUIPMENT IN THE PET ROLEUM INDUSTRY, ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND UTILIZATION ASPECTS AND SPECIAL ASPECTS OF THE PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRY REGARDING SAFETY AND THE ENVIRONMENT.
00540415.name: Process Engineering in the Petrochemical Industry

00540416.about: this course teaches students how to carry out integrated design of chemical processes to meet market demands with increased profits, reduced environmental footprint and ensuring safe and stable process operation. this course is taught in flipped format.
00540416.name: Integrated Chemical Process Design

00540417.about: topics taught are: introduction to process design, engineering ethics, plant cost estimation and profitability analysis, separationsequence synthesis, heat exchanger network synthesis, integration of process control and design, plantwide control system synthesis, hazop and hazan. the extended course project involves the design and economic analysis of a complete chemical process.
00540417.name: Integrated Chemical Process Design

00540419.about: PART 1: KINETICS OF ELEMENTARY REACTIONS, CHEMICAL EQUILIBRIUM, KINETICS OF MULTI-STEPS REACTIONS: COMPLEX REACTIONS, CHAIN REACTIONS, EXPLOSION REACTIONS, POLYMERIZATION. ADSORPTION AND DESORPTION, CATALYSIS. KINETICS OF HOMOGENEOUS, HETEROGENEOUS AND ENZYMATIC CATALYSIS. PART 2: THE KINETIC THEORY OF GASES, TRANSPORT COEFFICIENTS, COLLISION THEORY, TRANSITION STATE THEORY, POTENTIAL ENERGY SURFACES. PART 3: THE PROPERTIES AND DESIGN OF IDEAL REACTORS (BATCH, PFR, CSTR, SEMI-BATCH). RELATION BETWEEN CHEMICAL KINETICS, SIZE AND TYPE OF REACTOR UNDER ISOTHERMAL OPERATION. EFFECT OF CONNECTING REACTORS, SELECTIVITY ISSUES.
00540419.name: Int.to Chemical and Biochemcal Reactors' Design

00540420.about: in this laboratoty, experiments are carried out to demonstrate: a. principles of unit operations in mass transfer, b. principles ofchemical reactor engineering.
00540420.name: Chemical Engineering Laboratory 2 Bc

00540452.about: Overview of environmental pollution problems and their abatement methods. Fundamental aspects of air pollution:  types of pollutants, their properties and the incurred potential damage. Air quality standards. Distribution ofpollutants in the atmosphere. Pollutantdispersion and propagation. Pollutant control techniques. Generation of pollutants by combustion processes. Processes for the removal of pollutants.
00540452.name: Environmental Engineering-Air Pollution

00540477.about: THIS IS AN INTERDISCIPLINARY COURSE INCLUDING: A. INTERDISCIPLINARY TECHNOLOGIES EXPOSURE (ITE). IN WHICH LEADING SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS FROM A BROAD RANGE OF INDUSTRY AND RESEARCH BRANCHES WILL TEACH THE COURSE POPULATION ABOUT FUNDAMENTAL ENGINEERING PRINCIPLES. B.  MEET THE SCIENTISTS AND ENGINEERS - LABS  FIELD TOURS.
00540477.name: INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH EXPOSURE

00540478.about: INTRODUCING CHEMICAL AND BIOCHEMICAL ENGINEERING AND PROVIDING BASIC TOOLS TO THOSE WHO STUDY THIS FIELD. THE COVERED TOPICS: UNITSAND ACCURACY, IDEAL/NONIDEAL GASES. PHASE EQUILIBRIUM, STEAM TABLES, HEAT, WORK. MATERIAL AND ENERGY BALANCES IN STEADY STATE, WITHAND WITHOUT REACTIONS. RECYCLE AND BYPASS. SIMULTANEOUS MATERIAL AND ENERGY BALANCES. NON-STEADY STATE MATERIAL AND ENERGY BALANCES.
00540478.name: INT. TO CHEMICAL AND BIOCHEMICAL ENG.

00540483.about: EXPERIMENTS VERIFYING VARIOUS THEORETICAL AND PRACTICAL PARAMETERS RELATED TO THE PROCESSES IN THE MICROELECTRONIC INDUSTRY SUCH AS: OXIDATION, SPIN-COATING, PHOTOLITHOGRAPHY, ISOTROPIC AND UNISOTROPIC ETCHING (SILICON, SILICA, METALS), THIN FILM DEPOSITION BY ALD, METALLIZATION, ELECTRICAL AND STRUCTURAL CHARACTERIZATION, REALIZATION OF MICROELECTRONIC DEVICES.
00540483.name: MICRO-PROCESSING LAB

00560120.about:
THE COURSE FOCUSES ON TRANSMISSION ELECTRON MICROCOPY (TEM) AND SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY (SEM) OF SOFT MATTER, INCLUDING: THE COMPONENTS OF SEM AND TEM, THE PRINCIPLES OF IMAGE FORMATION IN EM, THE PHYSICS OF ELECTRON BEAM-SPECIMEN INTERACTION, SPECIMEN PREPARATION AND CRYO-EM, ELECTRON TOMOGRAPHY FOR 3D CHARACTERIZATION, ELEMENTAL ANALYSIS, AND APPLICATIONS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL:
 1. BE ABLE TO DESCRIBE THE MAIN COMPONENTS OF SEM AND TEM AND UNDERSTAND HOW THEY CONTRIBUTE TO IMAGE FORMATION USING VARIOUS IMAGING MODES AND WITH DIFFERENT DETECTORS.
 2. UNDERSTAND THE PRINCIPLES THAT DETERMINE CONTRAST AND R ESOLUTION IN EM.
 3. KNOW HOW VARIOUS SPECIMEN PREPARATION TECHNIQUES CAN BE USED IN ORDER TO IMAGE.PROBE SOFT MATTER WITH EMPHASISON CRYO-EM, INCLUDING INCLUDING LIMITATIONS, ARTIFACT, AND ELECTRON-BEAM RADIATION-DAMAGE.
 4.  UNDERSTAND THE PRINCIPLES USED IN TEM THREE-DIMENSIONAL CHARACTERIZATION.
00560120.name: Electron Microscopy of Soft Matter

00560146.about: An advanced course designed for in-depth studies of chemical engineering subjects by various lecturers, mainly visitors, e.g., on sabbatical leave.  A detailed syllabus will be determined each year the course is offered and distributed in advance to the interested committees. Winter semester 2018.2019: Powder technology.
00560146.name: Selected Engineering Subjects

00560149.about: Half of the course focuses on optimization methods for linear and non- linear problems with or without constraints. The rest of the course focuses on iterative solution of matrix equations as a basis for solving complex numerical problems, as well as solving ordinary and partial differential equations . At the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. solve various optimization problems. 2. Solve ODEs and PDEs including boundary value problems and initial value problems and parabolic and elliptic equations . 3. Use advanced background in iterative solution of numerical problems .
00560149.name: Optimization and Numerical Analysis

00560166.about: Surface tension and interfacial tension. Van Der Waals interactions. Curved surfaces - the Young-Laplace and Kelvin equations. Surface tension of solutions. Wetting on surfaces-equilibrium, hysteresis, dynamics. Wetting in porous media.
00560166.name: Interfacial Phenomena

00560178.about:
Asymptotic methods: regular perturbations. Singular perturbation techniques: strained parameters, inner,outer and composite expansions, multiple scales.  Numerical methods: techniques for solving sets of algebraic equations. Finite element analysis of linear and non-linear elliptic and parabolic partial differential equations. Applications chemical engineering problems. Learning Outcomes: Upon completion of the course students will know how to:
 1. Solve systems of linear algebraic equations using direct and iterative methods. 
2. Solve systems of nonlinear algebraic equations using the Newton Raphson technique.
 3. Apply the Gauss Legendre methiod for  numerical integration. 
4. Approach the solution of liner and nonlinear, elliptic and parabolic partial differential equations using the Galerkin FRinite Element Method.
 . 5. Constuct regular (straightforward) asymptotic expansions of the solution of nonlinear algebraic and differential equations. 
 6. Identify the source of nonuniformity in the asymptotic expansions. 
7. Solve nonliner differential equations using the Method of Strained Coordinates.
 8. Solve nonlinear differential equations using the Method of Multiple Sc
00560178.name: Approximate Methods in Chemical Engineering

00560379.about: the purpose of this laboratory is to train the students in membranes separation processes, including reverse osmosis, ultrafiltration, nanofiltration, microfiltration, gas separation and pervaporation.
00560379.name: Membrane Processes Laboratory

00560386.about: an advanced course on chemical engineering issues, mostly given by visiting lecturers. a detailed outline will be issued the semester the course is offered. Winter semester 2018.2019: Surface and Interface Analysis of Functional Materials.
00560386.name: Selected Engineering Issues 2

00560391.about: topics:   sensor  requirements vs. application.  advantages of nanomaterials  for  sensing applications.  metallic and semiconducting nanoparticles.  organic and inorganic nanowires and nanotubes. optical, mechanical  and chemical  sensors based on nanomaterials.sensors based on hybrid nanomaterials.  signal processing for individual sensors and array of sensors (electronic nose devices).
00560391.name: Sensors Based on Nano (Bio) Materials

00560394.about:
Chemistry of odor molecules, formation mechanisms of smell molecules - volatile and semi volatile organic compounds, metabolic processes and clinical use - breath sampling, technologies and detection methods- analytical systems and sensors, using the technology in other areas-environmental, food, forensics.
