 Learning Outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. Describe and interpret processes chemical molecules related to odor 2. Understand thermodynamic processes and mechanisms in the formation of volatile molecules.  3. Predict processes that can create volatile molecules or markers in clinical practice in the industry. and in the environment. 4. Compare and demonstrate the odor-sensing mechanisms and their use in organisms in nature, particularly humans. 5. evaluate and predict metabolic pathways that can be used as markers for clinical disease diagnostics. 6. Recognize and understand the methodology of breath analysis and its applications. 7. Select and adapt analytical technologies and sensing technologies for testing odorprints.   8. Understand and analyze statistical results of literature in the field.  9. Analyze and summarize scientificresults and p
00560394.name: Odor Fingerprints: Introduction and Applications

00560396.about: OPICS: SURFACE FORCES (DLVO THEORY) BETWEEN COLLOIDAL PARTICLES (NANO- AND MICRO-PARTICLES) AND APPLICATIONS TO THE ADHESION ENERGYAND SURFACE TENSION OF SOLIDS AND LIQUIDS, ENERGY DIAGRAMS FOR THE STABILITY OF SUSPENSIONS AND EMULSIONS, KINETIC EQUATIONS FOR COAGULATION IN SUSPENSIONS AND EMULSIONS AS FUNCTION OF SURFACE FORCES, TEMPERATURE, PARTICLE SIZE, AND THE VISCOSITY OF THE CARRIER LIQUID. LEARNING RESULTS: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL BE CAPABLE TO: A. CALCULATE SURFACE FORCES DUE TO MOLECULAR EFFECTS, B. ESTIMATE QUALITATIVELY (USING ENERGY DIAGRAMS) AND QUANTITATIVELY (USING KINETIC MODELS) THE PROCESSES THAT TAKE PLACE DURING THE COLLISION OF COLLOIDAL PARTICLES AND THE STABILITY TIME OF SUSPENSIONS AND EMULSIONS (SHELF LIFE). IN ADDITION, THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO ANALYZE THE EFFICIENCY OF PARTICLE SEPARATION PROCESSES.
00560396.name: Colloids

00560397.about: overview of membrane processes and their physical principles. processes: water, energy production, electrochemisrty and others. biological and synthetic membranes. polymers and advanced materials for membranes. thermodynamics, trasport and selectivity mechanisms for molecules and ions in different membranes. surface phenomena in membranes: fouling, its types and their mitigation. modificationand characterization of membranes. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. understand and analyze separation mechnism in various membrane processes, including electromembrane systems, energy generation, water purification, gas s eparation etc. 2. understand advantages and limitations of existing membrane processes at the level of physical mechanisms (thermodynamics and kinetics). 3. see how advanced materials and biomimetics can improve membrane performance. 4. understand phenomena of polarization and fouling, their effect on membranes preformance and their mitigation.
00560397.name: Membranes Principles and Materials

00560398.about: role of the catalytic surface, reactivity of surfaces, absorption. desorption on surfaces, catalyst porous structure, electronic metal support interactions, lewis- bronsted acid- base heterogeneous catalysts, synthesis and charechterization of heterogeneous catalysts, heterogeneously catalyzed reactions pertaining to the synthesis of alternative fuels. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. understand the role of the catalytic surface. 2. understand the functionality and how to computeparameters relevant to the catalyst physical and chemical parameters. 3. know the effect of the catalyst electronic and surface prop erties on catalytic perfomance. 4. explore catlyst synthesis and charechterization methods. 5. correlate catalytic properties and reactions relavant to alternative fuels.
00560398.name: Catalysis on Surfaces

00560399.about: the course will focus on current and future energy systems, covering resources, extraction, conversion, storage and end-use technologies. examine various renewable and conventional energy production technologies, energy end-use practices and alternatives, and wold wide consumption practices. quantitative evaluation and analysis of energy technology system proposals in the context of engineering, political, social, economic and environmental. learning out comes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. listand explain the main sources of energy and their primary applications. 2. describe the challenges and problems associated with the u se of various energy sources. 3. discuss potential solutions to the supply and environmental issues associated with fossil fuels and other energy resources. 4. list and describe the primary renewable energy resources and technologies. 5. convert units of energy, to quantify energy demands and make comparisons among energy uses, resources, and technologies.
00560399.name: Engineering for Energy and Environment

00560400.about: introduction to modern concepts of process saftey, hazard analysis and design for safety. analyze causality in accidents by studying past accidents in a variety of industries and identifying the engineering and organizational flaws that led to these losses.identification of potential hazards and hazardous conditions associated with the processes and equipment involved in the chemical process industries. methods of predicting the possible severity of theses hazards and presenting, controlling or mitigating them. quantitative engineering analysis based on application of mass and energy balances, fluid mechanics of liquid, gas, and two-phase flows, heat t ransfer and the conservation of energy, mass transfer, diffusion and dispersion under highly variable conditions, reaction kinetics, process control, and statistics. concepts of management and individual responsibility, teamwork and the appreciation for orders ofmagnitude estimation and relative significance. learning outcomes: at the end of th course the student will be able to: 1. understand the concepts of safety barriers, process and personal safety, and also understand the role of engineering in developing and implementing risk
00560400.name: Process Safety in Chemical Engineering

00560402.about: the course focuses on computational methods for determination of molecular level properties and calculation of thermodynamic properties at the macroscopic level using statistical mechanics, as well as reaction rate coefficients using conventional transition statetheory (tst) and microcanonical tst (rrkm). a relevant background in statistical thermodynamics will be given. construction of elementary kinetic models is explained, demonstrated, and practiced. the course integrates programming (mainly using python) and emphasizes molecular visualization and automation. the course will make use of open-source software (e.g., rdkit and psi4) to allow the part icipants to practice these methods in any future framework independent of proprietary software. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. represent molecules using software tools 2. manipulate the 3d conformation of molecules 3. conduct electronic structure calculations 4. calculate thermodynamic properties such as standard enthalpy and entropy change of formation based on electronic structure calculations using the partition function 5. calculate reaction rate coefficients as well as pressure-depende
00560402.name: Molecular and Chemical Kinetic Modeling

00560403.about:
Ionic materials and solutions. ideal and non-ideal solutions, weak and strong electrolytes, debye-hockel and bjerrum theories, ion-solvent interactions, salting-in/out, hoffmeister series. ion diffusion and conductance.  Ions at interfaces: double layer, electrokinetics. charged particles, dlvo theory. polyelectrolytes, gels, ionomers, and complexes. Electrode processes and ion-selective membranes. Ions in living systems, nanomaterials and nanochannels. Applications of ionic systems. 
 learning outcomes:
 tudents who successfully complete the course will be able to: 1.  aquire conceptual knoweldge of different phenomena involving ions 2. understand the  physics and behavior of ions in solutions, interfaces and polymers. 3. undertsand how to model phenomena and processes that involve ions 4. become familiar with technologies based on ionic systems and materials.
00560403.name: IONIC SYSTEMS

00560404.about:
objective: to gain therotical and hands-on knowledge on polymer synthesis, fabrication and characterization methods.
 lab topics:_
mfi (melt flow index)- rheology of polymers and their indexing. crystallization - monitoring of polymer formation using optical microscopy and determining crystallization using dsc. concentrated solutions - polymer viscosity measurements as a function of concentration and the influence of shear forces on these solutions. extrusion - effect of temperature, polymer density and extrusion speed on the extrusion process. mechanical properties - testing tensile properties of different polymers using a mechanical testing instrume nt. rheometer - polymer rheology. synthesis lab - synthesis of polyurethane, nylon 6,10 and laminated polyester. saxs - small anglex-ray scattering of polymers.
 learning outcomes: by the end of this course, the students will 1. understand the principles in polymer synthesis, polymer processing, and polymer characterization.
 2. the students will know how to perforem and analyze methods for poly synthesis, polymer processing and polymer characterization.
00560404.name: POLYMER ENGINEERING LABORATORY

00560405.about:
THE COURSE CONSISTS IN FRONTAL LECTURES. ACTIVE PARTICIPATION IS EXPECTED FROM THE STUDENTS ATTENDING THE COURSE, TO MAXIMIZE ALL THE DISCUSSIONS. IN GENERAL, THE MAIN TOPICS THAT WILL BE DISCUSSED DURING THE SEMESTER WILL INCLUDE (NOT NECESSARILY IN THIS ORDER) THE FOLLOWING TOPICS: 1.  FOUNDATIONS OF FLUID MECHANICS - EQUATIONS AND THEIR APPLICATIONS AT ALL SCALES IN THE UNIVERSE.
 2.  TURBULENCE AND STATISTICAL FLUID MECHANICS. WHAT CAN BE PREDICTED AND WHAT CANNOT.
 3.  KOLMOGOROV FOUR FIFTHS LAW, SCALING 4.  TURBULENT MIXING.
 5.  PREDICTING TRANSPORT BY UNPREDICTABLE FLOW: UNIVERSALITY 6.  RAIN FORMATION AND TURBULENCE.
 ARTICIPANTS WILL APPRECIA TE HOW OFTEN TURBULENCE IS PRESENT IN REAL WORLD SITUATIONS AND WHAT IMPACT ON PHYSICAL PROCESSES IT CAN HAVE. THEY WILL BE EQUIPEDWITH TOOLS FOR QUANTITIVE APPROACH. THEY WILL LEARN FUNDAMENTAL ASPECTS FOR QUALITATIVE UNDERSTANDING, WHICH INCLUDES SCALING, INTERMITTENCY AND MULTIFRACTALITY.
00560405.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN TURBULENCE

00560406.about:
INTRODUCTION TO CONTROLLED DRUG DELIVERY: HISTORY, BASIC PRINCIPLES, ADVANTAGES/DISADVANTAGES, LIMITATIONS, SMART DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS MOTIVATION AND CURRENT STATE-OF-THE-ART. SMART DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS: NANO-BASED SYSTEMS, STIMULI-RESPONSIVE SYSTEMS, TARGETE3D-SYSTEMS, CARRIER-FREE SYSTEMS. CELLULAR-BASED SYSTEMS AND THERAGNOSTIC SYSTEMS. SMART DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS ENGINEERING: SMART COMPONENTS/CHEMISTRIES (PHASE TRANSITION), STIMULI/SUITABLE SMART DDSS (PH, REDOX, MOLECULE-RESPONSIVENESS  SYSTEMS, BIO-RESPONSIVE, , LIGHT, TEMPERATURE, MAGNETIC, ULTRASOUND, OTHERS). SMART DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS CHARACTERIZATION: CHEMICAL (COMPOSITION AND FUNCTIONALI TY), PHYSICAL (SIZE, MORPHOLOGY AND DISTRIBUTION) AND THERMAL ANALYSIS. IMPLANTS AS SMART DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS: ADVANCES AND ACTIVELY MOVING POLYMERS. SYSTEMS VALIDATION AND MONITORING MODELS: IMAGING, IN VITRO AND IN VIVO (INCLUDING PK/PD MODELING (PHARMACOKINETIC/PHARMACODYNAMIC MODELING). SMART DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS PROJECTS DISCUSSION. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. DETERMINE THE KEY DIFFERENCES BETWEEN REGULAR DRUG DELIVERY SYSTEMS (DDSS) AND SMART ONES. 
 2. EVALUATETHE IMPAC
00560406.name: TOPICS IN SMART DRG DELIVERY SYSTEMS

00560407.about:
his course covers the fundamentals and applications of process intensification (pi). pi in the spatial domain: shape-selective catalysts and microstructured reactors. pi in the functional domain: membrane reactors! static mixer reactors and reactive distillation.pi in the temporal domain: oscillatory flow reactors! reverse flow reactors and simulated moving bed reactors. pi in the thermodynamic domain: utilizing solar power! ultrasound and microwave energy in reacting systems.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the coursethe students will be able to:
 1. understand the 4 different domains of pi! their implementation! and their integration.
 2. to lear n to conduct a literature survey on topic of their choice in the field of pi.
 3. learn to perform a critical analysis of publishedscientific work in the field of pi.
 4. learn to present their analysis coherently and practice giving al seminar._
 5. the students will learn to derive a mathematical model for a reverse-flow-reactor (or a different system)! solve it numerically and analyze theresults.
00560407.name: CHEMICAL PROCESS INTENSIFICATION

00560408.about:
NEERING PROBLEM AND ASK THEM TO DEVELOP THEIR OWN SOLUTIONS WHILE WORKING IN TEAMS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. UNDERSTAND THE STATE-OF-THE-ART IN BIOINSPIRED NANO-ENGINEERING TECHNOLOGIES. 
 2. CRITICALLY READ!ANALYZE! AND INTERPRET THE SCIENTIFIC LITERATURE IN BIOINSPIRED NANO-ENGINEERING. 
 3. APPLY THE KNOWLEDGE OF BIOINSPIRED NANO-ENGINEERING TO THINK CRITICALLY ABOUT POSSIBLE BNP SOLUTIONS FOR UNMET NEEDS IN MEDICINE._
 4. CLEARLY REPRESENT IDEAS IN WRITTEN REPORTS AND ORAL PRESENTATION.
00560408.name: TOPICS IN BIOINSPIRED NANO ENGINEERING

00560410.about:
this interdisciplinary course will cover a wide range of topics! such as the synthesis of bio-inspired particles (i.e.! nature-mimicking particles) and their characterization! the use of contrast agents and composites in particles! and the exploitation of their advantages as vehicles for delivering various medical substances! including small molecules! proteins! and rna molecules. the course will be taught in the form of problem-based learning (pbl)! where the students will be exposed to different clinical needs in which these particles are used for therapy or specific pain relief. this course will equip the students with tools to characterize the engi neering problem and ask them to develop their own solutions while working in teams. 
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the studetns will be able to:
 1. understand the state-of-the-art in bioinspired nano-engineering technologies.
 2. critically read! analyze! and interpret the scientific literature in bioinspired nano-engineering.
 3. apply the knowledge of bioinspired nano-engineering to think critically about possible bnp solutions for unmet needs.
 4. clearly represent ideas in written reports and oral presentatio
00560410.name: BIOINSPIRED NANO-PARTICLES ENGINEERING

00580002.about:
basic concepts of multiphase flows and their governing equations, kinetic equations, population balance equations, general introduction about sedimentation, fluidization, emulsification, atomization processes and their industrial applications. modeling approach, volume of fluids, discrete elements, two-fluid model. measurement techniques, shadows imaging, mie scattering. PIV.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the student will understand:
 1. understanding subjects of multi-phase flow_.
 2. model calculations of sedimentation and fluidization
 3. model development for types of flow.
 4. understanding measurement techniques of multi-phase flo w.
00580002.name: INTRODUCTION TO MULTIPHASE FLOW - C

00580003.about:
introduction of climate change, green house gas emissions from transport sector and industry, carbon capture, utilisation and storage and industrial decarbonization, co2 capture technologies, co2 utilization, and storage,  low carbon or renewable energies. methane emmitions.
 learning outcomes: 
 at the end of the course the student will be abke to: _
 1.understand the climate issues associated with released gases.
 2. learn the solutions those environmental issues.
 3. compplete processes analysis and preparation towardsfuture research in this field.
00580003.name: DECARBONIZATION AND EMIISION CONTROL - C

00580126.about: the course will be given in english, intending to present all the relevant aspects of the fuel cell technology. the main topics that will be discussed will include: introduction, basic principles, advantages.disadvantages, comparison with batteries, applications,limitations, current state-of-the-art, type of fuel cells, fuels, oxidants, electrochemical reactions, fuel cell operation characterization, fuel cell materials, membrane electrode assembly and fuel cell stacks. at the end of the course the students will be able to: 1. understand the basics of fuel cell technology 2. understand the technology, its applications, advantages and disadvantages ove r other electrochemical devices. 3. analyze the current challenges of the technology, state-of-the-art performance, and to understand the components and requirements to develop a successful fuel cell device.
00580126.name: Fuel Cells

00580127.about: Cartesian tensors.  Deformation.  Stress.  Constitutive equations. Equations of continuity, motion and energy.  Navier-Stokes equations. Exact solutions.  Stream functions.  Non-Newtonian flow.  Creeping flow.  Boundary layers.  Turbulent flow.
00580127.name: Transport Phenomena - Fluid Flow

00580143.about: Phenomenology of diffusion, transport coefficients, one-and multi- dimensional heat and mass transport, diffusion in concentrated solutions, anisotropic media, generalized equations for heat transport and mass transport in binary systems. Analytical and numericalsolutions of problems involving heat and mass transport via forced and natural convection. Multi-component diffusion, coupled heat and mass transport,moving-boundary problems.
00580143.name: Transport Phenomena Heat and Mass Transfer

00580145.about: Stoichiometry of a reaction system.  Conservation equations and their reduction to various reactor models.  Residence time distribution. Heterogeneous reaction rates.  Heat and mass transfer in gas-solid catalytic reactions.  Design methods.  Selected topics.
00580145.name: Advanced Reactor Design

00580172.about: Application of classical and statistical thermodynamics and scaling theories to the following topics: conformation of a single polymer chain. Polymers in dilute solution : osmotic pressure,viscosity and scattering of radiation. Thermodynamics of polymer solution:phase separation and stability,liquid crystals, gels and rubber elasticity. Polymer melt: entanglement and viscosity. Thermodynamics and kinetics of phase separation.
00580172.name: Polymer Thermodynamics

00580174.about: This course is designated for the Masters of Engineering program. In its  framework a final project will be performed, which may beeither experimental research, engineering design project or a critical literature review.
00580174.name: Advanced Seminar in Chemical Engineering

00580177.about: Functions of complex variables. Integration in complex plane. Linear spaces. Fourier series. Fourier and other integral transforms.Sturm-Liouville problems. Classification of partial differential equations (PDES). First  order PDES. Elliptic and parabolic PDES. Separation of variables. Green's functions. Applications in chemical engineering.
00580177.name: Mathematical Methods in Chemical Engineering

00580183.about: advanced topics in  polymer science  with  special emphasis on applications in biotechnology: controlled drug release,  tissue engineering,  hydrogels, membrane separation, bioadhesion and advanced technologies  such as utilizing "smart polymers" for switches.
00580183.name: Polymers in Biotechnology

00580184.about: topics: characterization methods for the laboratory work: dilute solution  viscosity and molecular weight, shear viscosity of concentrated solutions, melt viscosity, polymer crystallization followed by light microscopy and calorimetry, x-ray diffraction, mechanical properties,  crosslinking during shear blending, extrusion.
00580184.name: Polymer Characterization Laboratory

00580185.about: crystal structures.  crystallography and x-ray diffraction.  bonding in solids.  crystal defects and non-stoichiometry.  solid solutions. phase diagrams.  electrical properties.  examples of simple solid state devices.  synthesis methods.
00580185.name: Solid State in Chemical Engineering Grad

00580186.about: Introduction to classical and quantum mechanics. Ensembles. Boltzmann statistics. Fermi-dirac and bose-einstein statistics.  Classical partition function.  ideal and real gases.  Liquids.  Correlation functions.  Selected advanced topics such as:  Emulsions, liquid crystals,  Polymers.  Chemical reactions.
00580186.name: Statistical Termodynamics in Chem. Eng.

00640001.about: The student devotes one day a week to a small research project.  He is required to make a critical literature survey, plan experiments, carry them out, discuss the results and draw conclusions.  A written report must be submitted at the end of the year.  Instead of the research project, the student may choose a design project.  The student will be asked to design a food plant or a division ofone. The project will include flow diagrams, engineering diagrams, general layout, detailed specification for all equipment, piping, electricity, steam, etc., and a feasibility study.
00640001.name: Undergraduate Research 1

00640002.about: The student devotes one day a week to a small research project.  He is required to make a critical literature survey, to plan experiments, to carry them out, to discuss the results and to draw conclusions.  A written report must be submitted at the end of the year.  Instead of the research project, the student may choose a design project.  The student will be asked to design a food plant or adivision of one. The project will include flow diagrams, engineering diagrams, general layout, detailed specification for all equipment, piping, electricity, steam, etc., and a feasibility study.
00640002.name: Undergraduate Research 2

00640003.about: Eight weeks of summer work in the food industry.  Firsthand experience of current problems, technologies and knowledge of this industry.
00640003.name: Practice in Food Industry

00640005.about: Students taking this course will write an independent paper on a specific subject in one of the areas of food engineering, technology, or science.  Such a project will only be approved in case the student concerned needs one (or less) credit points to complete his curriculum.
00640005.name: Special Project

00640106.about: The laws of thermodynamics.  Thermodynamic properties of pure substances.  Gases.  Compression and compressors.  Gas mixtures. Thermodynamic properties of moist air.  Drying, humidification, air conditioning.  Refrigeration.  Phase equilibria.  Evaporation and freezing with emphasis on the evaluation of changes in phase composition of foods.
00640106.name: Thermodynamics in Biotechnology and Food Engineering

00640115.about: Flow properties of food materials. Flow in pipes and through equipment. Pumps and flow equipment in the food industry. Settling, flow through porous media, filtration. Principles of steady state and transient heat and mass transfer. Heat transfer by radiation. Heat transfer with a phase change (evaporation, freezing and thawing). Principles of membrane processes. Reaction kinetics in foods.
00640115.name: Food and Biotechnology Engineering Principles 1

00640117.about: Transformation and separation processes: size reduction, mixing, homogenization, filtration, centrifugation, membrane processes, extraction, adsorption, and distillation.
00640117.name: Heat Transfer Phenomena

00640118.about: thermal processing, refrigeration, freezing, evaporation, dehydration, lyophilization. elements of process control.
00640118.name: Mass Transport Phenomena

00640119.about: Decision-making process towards plant erection. Pre-project and Process design:  Process and engineering flow-diagram. Development of equipment specifications. (Obtaining and analyzing of bids). Plant layout. Design of utility and process pipelines.
00640119.name: Plant Design

00640120.about: introductory course aim to provide basic tools relevant for engineers. the course will include topics such as: exact and iterative methods for linear systems, finding roots of non-linear equations, curve fitting, interpolation, derivatives and integrals based on finite differences and differential equations. as part of the requirements students will have to implement algorithms in matlab.
00640120.name: Numerical Methods in Biotech and Food En

00640209.about: Advanced aspects of engineering and technology in biological systems: microbial and enzyme inactivation, advanced measurement characterization techniques, advanced preservation technologies (ohmic heating, high hydrostatic pressure, PEF, shock-waves), supercritical fluid extraction, membranes, control, process development. Lab exercises include microwave heating, water- product relations, ohmic heating, shock waves, and membrans. Students perform a product development and process-planning project.
00640209.name: Advanced Technologies in Food Engi.

00640210.about: Selected topics in food science and technology, such as: food rheology, food irradiation, extrusion, microwaves, bioluminescence, toxicology of food additives, modern aspects of wine technology. Principles of secondary packaging, technology of fish products, dietary fibers. Some of the topics are covered in Food Technol. 3 and the others in Food Technol. 4.
00640210.name: Selected Topics in Food Technology a

00640211.name: Selected Topics in Food Technology B

00640212.about: Course objective: knowing food production processes and equipment. introduction, raw material reception, size-reduction, quantity measurement, dosing, mixing, fluid conveyance, storage of fluids, powders and solids, heat treatment, extrusion, separation, evaporation, distillation, concentration, cooling: freezing, freeze-drying, freeze-concentration, solid conveyance, packaging, cleaning and sanitizing, product development, process automation and control, quality assurance.
00640212.name: Food Technology

00640238.about: Raw materials in the food and biotechnology industries. Structure and properties of foods and biological systems, coloids. Phase separation: filtration, dearation, gelation, crystallization. Properties: mechanical, rheological, swelling and shrinkage. Models and measuring methods.
00640238.name: Structure and Properties of Food and Biological Materials

00640239.about: Technological and engineering aspects in food anf biological products processing. Lab exercises in heat and mass transfer, sterilization and pasteurization, heat exchangers, diffusion, drying, concentration, microwave heating. Separation and concentration by membranes, filtration and centrifugation. Analytical methods for monitoring of processes, rheology of liquids and semi-solids, enzymaticmethod and sensors.
00640239.name: Bioprocess and Food Process Eng. Lab.

00640249.about: the purpose of the course is to provide the student with knowledge of the processing of fruit and vegetables, with an understandingof the various biochemical processes occurring after harvest and after production of common fruits and vegetable based products, while familiarizing with the processing technologies and processing units.
00640249.name: Agricultural Produce Processing

00640250.about: Raw materials in the food and biotechnology industries. Structure and properties of foods and biological systems, coloids. Phase separation: filtration, dearation, gelation, crystallization. Properties: mechanical, rheological, swelling and shrinkage. Models and measuring methods.
00640250.name: Biomaterial Science and Technology

00640251.about: this course will cover the scientific challenges and processes used to create convincing and marketable plant-based and clean meats, including the biological and chemical processes used to produce plant-based meat and clean meat, the environmental and economic drivers behind the market for meat replacements, and the dietary roles of plant- and animal-based proteins.
00640251.name: The Science Behind Meat Alternative

00640322.about: Lipids in food: structure, properties and uses in food, reactions,_nutritional aspects, structured lipids. Lipids oxidation, antioxidats and carotenoids. Carbohydrates: properties, derivatives. Polysaccharides and dietary fibers: structure, properties and uses infood. Maillard browning and its nutritional aspects, enzymatic browning. Amino acids, peptides and Proteins in food systems. Uses enzymes in the food industry. Water activity and its influence on the kinetics of reactions in foods.
00640322.name: Food Chemistry

00640324.about: The importance of performing analysis of food products. Standards in food production and the agencies enforcing them in Israel and abroad. Terms: GMP, HACCP, ISO. Food labeling. Spectroscopy and polarimetry - background and uses in food analysis. Gas chromatography, mass spectrometry, liquid chromatography - theoretical background of each method and uses in food analysis. Food additives and food supplements. Food allergens.
00640324.name: Analytical Methods in Biotechn. and Food

00640325.about: Qualitative and quantitative assays of sugars, ionic properties of amino acids, separation and analysis of proteins, properties of milk proteins, fractionation and characterization of lipids, enzyme kinetics, enzyme inhibition, enzymatic and non-enzymatic browning, trypsim inhibitors, effect of technological treatments of the stability of vitamin C in foods, properties of meat pigments.
00640325.name: Biochemistry Lab.

00640326.about: Different methods for determining moisture in food. Analysis of quantity and quality of lipids food: peroxide value, iodine value, volatile aldehydes, fatty acid composition using gas chromatography and mass spectrometry. Analysis of preservatives using HPLC. Examining adulteration in meatand dairy oroducts using immunological methods. Analysis of protein content in food using Kjehldal and spectroscopy. Analysis of caffeine and antioxidant content in beverages.
00640326.name: Food, Biological Material Analyses Lab

00640331.about: standardization serves as a threshold and necessary condition for world trade and a means of cost savings. the course teaches the standardization process, advantages, practice and the development systems. quality, standards - essence, structure, preparation processes, groups and types, objectives of standardization and its benefits, regulatory bodies, total quality management, statistical process control, metrology, non-destructive testing, the human factor in quality.
00640331.name: Standardization Conspectus

00640413.about: Basic techniqes in microbiology, staining, preparing media, effect of chemo-physical factors on bacteria, bacterial enumaration. The cycles of elements in nature, bacterial growth, bacterial systematic, bacteriophage bacterial spores.
00640413.name: Microbiology Lab.

00640419.about: Structure and function of the procaryota. Effect of chemophysical factors on the growth and existence of microorganisms. Halophilic, thermophilic and psychrophilic microprganisms, geochemical activities of microorganisms, growth, reproduction and nutrition of bacteria. Antimicrobial compounds. Bacterial taxonomy. Bacterial spores. Bacteriophages and viruses.
00640419.name: General Microbiology

00640420.about: Microorganisms in food, mycology, yeasts, food spoilage, preservation by thermal processes, preservatives, ethanolic, lactic acid and other fermentation products, alcoholic drinks. Pathogenic bacteria in foods.
00640420.name: Food Microbiology

00640507.about: Basic principles in bacterial genetics, DNA modification enzymes, Plasmids, Phage display, DNA libraries, Blotting technoques, DNA sequencing , Chromosome walk, PCR, site directed evolurion and echnological aspects of molecular biology. directed evolurion, prokaryotic expression system, eukaryotic expression system, DNA microarrays, non-coding RNA, transgenic animals, animal cloning, introduction to gene therapy, introduction to synthetic biology, introduction to structural biology, regulating biotechnology.
00640507.name: Molecular Biotechnology

00640508.about: Growth of E. Coli on two sugars, regulation of aspartokinase in E. Coli, macromolecular composition as a function of growth media. Mutagenesis and screening for auxotrophs via transposons. Transformation of plasmid DNA in bacilli. Operation of fermentors.
00640508.name: Biological Reactors Laboratory

00640509.about: Composition of microorganisms growth media, theory and practice of continuous culture. Agitatio, mass transfer and scale-up in fermentation systems. Methods of large scale fermentations: organic feedstoks, organic acids, amino acids and antibiotics. Enzymatic reactors, cell culture biotechnology.
00640509.name: Process Biotechnology

00640522.about: What is biotechnology and what is food engineering, integration between basic and applied science, properties and evaluation of food, the cell as a factory of bio-molecules, key elements in production and research in biotechnology and food engineering, the link between food and health, the microbial genome and its uses in vaccine production and diagnostics, microbial cells as a biotechnological platforms, examples of production processes.
00640522.name: Introduction to Biotechnology and Food Engineering

00640523.about: The organization of cellular genomes, replication, maintenance and rearrangements of genomic dna, RNA synthesis and processing, protein synthesis and processing, biotechnological applications.
00640523.name: Introduction to Molecular Biotechnology

00640615.about: Appetite and satiety, control of food consumption. Body composition, estimation methods and their physiological-nutritional importance. Digestion and absorption.  Proteins, metabolism, essential amino acids.  Nutritional value of proteins.  Evaluation methods.  Carbohydrates in nutrition: hormonal control of blood glucose.  Lipid metabolism.  Cholesterol and lipoproteins.  Essential fatty acids.  Energetics, physiology and the interrelationships between the energy, protein, lipid and carbohydrates requirements.  Direct and indirect calorimetry. Minerals and vitamins in nutrition.
00640615.name: Nutrition

00660010.about:
active learning/experiencing planning a food/biotechnology plant (applying knowledge from previous-courses): choosing a topic! preparing: executive-summary! flow-chart! equipment diagram and table! equipment-unit diagram! accessories table! calculations (quantities! flow-rates! capacities and efficiencies! energy balances)! recycling and critical points. expanding knowledge about factory planning and food-technologies and biotechnology - lectures by experts from industry. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the studetns will be able to:
 1.actively learn by experiencing the process of planning a food/biotechnology plant.
 2. independently plan (at a basic level) a new production-line in a factory in these fields.
 3. prepare an executive summary! a process flow chart! an equipment diagram! an equipment table! a table of accessories and controllers for an equipment unit! perform calculations of quantities! capacities! efficiency! and energy balances._
 4. plan recycling processes in the factory! prepare a list of critical points! and detail their calculations and assumptions.
00660010.name: DESIGN OF FOOD  BIOTECHNOLOGY FACTORIES

00660011.about: the igem project is a unique opportunity for studentsto propose and carry out a multidisciplinary project in synthetic and quantitative biology. the first phase will involve a group-think effort to come-up and design in  detail the project idea. the second phase will involve carrying out the project in the lab. the work on project will be a year long effort and will culminate in the international igem competition. in addition, the students will carry out additional sub projects in public outreach, and fundraising to partially support their project. conditional approval for participation in the course are special registration and an interview with the l ecturer. at the end of the course the student will know: 1. clone in gibson and golden gate assemblies. 2. design of complex biological experiments. 3. work with genetic databases. 4. analyze sanger sequencing results. 5. work with gene ciruit design software packages. 6. be able to carry out simple bioinformtic analysis on second generation. 7. to simulate simple genetic circuits. 8. to programe and operate  advanced experimental systems. 9. measure bacterial growth curves.
00660011.name: Igem Project

00660012.about: the goal of the group project is to develop a new product in the field of biotechnology or food from the initial stages of generation of the ideas to the practical implementation, based on knowledge from basic courses. the teams will develope integrative projectsincluding: designing the product details, literature survey, raw material specification, economical evaluation, market analysis, a basic business plan. at the end of the semester the teams will present the product and portfolio to faculty members. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student is expected to be able to: 1. get a solid understanding of food or biotech product developm ent challenges 2. get familiar with experimenting and learn to design and conduct experiments. 3. learn to formulate user-based solutions to different problems using design-thinking tools. 4. develop multidisciplinary group working skills and access new networks.5. learn to give a pitch talk and a professional seminar in english to experts in the field.
00660012.name: Advanced Project in Biotechnology and Food Engineering 1

00660013.about: a follow up course 066012 aimed at projects with an applicative potential. the goal is to develop a new product in the field of biotechnology or food from the initial stages of generation of the ideas to the practical implementation, based on knowledge from basiccourses. the teams will develop integrative projects including: designing the product details, literature survey, economical evaluation, market analysis, a basic business plan. at the end of the semester the teams will present the product to experts in the field from industry and academy. learning outcomes: in the end of the course the student is expected to be able to: 1. get a solid understa nding of food or biotech product development challenges. 2. get familiar with experimenting and learn to design and conduct experiments. 3. learn to formulate user-based solutions to different problems using design-thinking tools. 4. develope multidiscipllinary group working skills and access new networks. 5. learn to give a pitch talk and a professional seminar in english to experts in the field.
00660013.name: Advanced Project in Biotechnology and Food Engineering 2

00660015.about: this course aims at enriching the students to an advanced field that is not covered in the compulsory courses. the course instructor may be a guest expert. the course content, structure and availability will be dependent on the instructor availability, and will be approved by the undergraduate and graduate faculty committees.
00660015.name: Selected Topics in Biotechnology and Food Engineering

00660121.about:
an advanced course which aims to provide students with the understanding of the various technologies that are used in medical diagnostics. the course will treat medical diagnostics as a nested application focusing initially on the principles of molecular detection with particular focus on selex and elisa. next, fundamentals of device and readout of molecular interactions via biosensors for diagnostic tests in medicine, concepts of transducers, recognition themes and performance factors will be explored. finally, integration of multiple data channels to generate a data matrix for detection and treatment of a medical condition. the course will cover basi c topics of data analysis including analysis of high dimensional data, dimensional reduction, clustering analysis and multiple hypothesis testing. 
 learning outcomes: upon successful completion of the course, the students will have:
 1. an understanding of the physical principles underlying elisa and selex. 2. an understanding of the introductory to utilization of the boltzmann distribution.
 3. an understanding of the ligand binding problem, mass action kinetics, and elements of diffusion theory. 
 4. an ability to identify dif
00660121.name: Medical Diagnostics

00660215.about: Milk composition. Physico-chemical structure of milk. The fat globule. Protein organization. Casein micelles. Enzymatic and acid coagulation of milk. Raw milk Mastitis. Cold storage of milk. Unit operations in processing dairy products. Standartization, homogenization, pasteurization, sterilization, aseptic filling. Mesophilic and thermophilic starter cultures. Processing of yogurt, soft cheeses, casein. Whey utilization.
00660215.name: Technology of Fluid Milk Products

00660217.about:
THE COURSE OBJECTIVE IS TO PROVIDE AN OVERVIEW OF THE BASIC SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL CONCEPTS OF PACKAGING AND SHELF-LIFE. COURSE CONTENT INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING TOPICS: FUNCTIONS AND REQUIREMENTS OF PACKAGING, MATERIALS USED FOR PACKAGING WITH A FOCUS ON POLYMERSAND PLASTICS (CHEMISTRY, STRUCTURE, PROPERTIES), MASS TRANSFER AND THEIR INTERRELATION TO KINETICS OF SPOILAGE. ADDITIONAL TOPICS INCLUDE INCLUDE FACTORS AFFECTING SHELF-LIFE, STRATEGIES FOR EVALUATION AND EXTENSION OF SHELF-LIFE, AS WELL AS ENVIRONMENTAL AND LEGAL CONSIDERAATIONS. 
LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW: 
 1. DESCRIBE THE MAIN FUNCTIONS OF FOOD.BIO LOGICAL MATERIAL PACKAGE.
 2. FAMILIARIZE WITH THE MAIN MECHANISMS OF POLYMERIZATION._
 3. DISTINGUISH BETWEEN THERMOPLASTIC AND THERMOSET POLYMERS._
& 4. UNDERSTAND THE STRUCTURE OF POLYMERS IN THE SOLID STATE, THE TYPES OF THERMAL TRANSITIONS OCCURRING IN GLASSY AND SEMICRYSTALLINE POLYMERS. 
 5. UNDERSTAND BASIC CONCEPTS OF VISCOELASTIC PROPERTIES OF POLYMERS, EMPHASIZING POLYMER MELT PROPERTIES, AND THE RELEVANCY OF MODELS.
 6. DESCRIBE THE MECHANICAL BEHAVIOR I.E., STRESS-STRAIN CURVES OF POLYMERS AND UNDERSTAND THE INFLUE
00660217.name: Packaging and Shelf Life: Food and Biological Products

00660226.about: Grape ripening, pre-harvest operations, desteming.crushing, sulfur-dioxide, skin contact, must corrections, wine yeast, fermentation (alcoholic fermentation, stuck fermentation, by-products, malo-lactic fermentation), residual sugar, basic cellar operations (racking, stabilization, filtration, blending, fining, storage, sanitation), aging, oak barrels, bottling, quality control, wine spoilage, special wines.
00660226.name: Technology of Winemaking

00660230.about: The course focuses on principals and methods used for sensory evaluation of food. Basic understanding of anatomy and physiology of the chemical senses and factors affecting their activity. Sensory tests will be studied and the capabilities and limitations of eachwill be discussed. In addition, statistical analysis of test results will be practiced as well as withdrawing meaningful conclusions. Learning to select judges and training them as panel members. Students will experience performance of sensory tests, analyzing the data and withdrawing conclusions as well as taking part in designing a sensory test.
00660230.name: Sensory Evaluation of Food

00660241.about: Aseptic filling and packaging, modified atmosphere packaging (MAP), active packaging, smart (intelligent) packages, packages for microwave oven. Corrosion of metal cans, graphical design and printing on packages, packages and the environment, principles of secondary packaging.
00660241.name: Advanced Chapters in Packaging

00660247.about: the latest materials related developments in the field of biotechnology and food engineering. the main groups of materials used in industry, their characterization and our ability to modify their properties. focus on composite and surface-active materials, smart,antibacterial and bio-inspired materials. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the students will be 1. familiar with the main polymeric families in the industry, and their characteristics. 2. understand how similar materials can have different uses. 3.  be familiar with advanced processes for preparing edible materials for the food and the pharmaceutical industries. 4.  understand the scientific importance and technological potential of developing advanced materials in the food and pharmaceutical industries.
00660247.name: Advanced Materials for Biotechnolgy and Food

00660248.about: the course covers principles and applications of rheology and texture analysis used for the characterization of varied material systems. topics: introduction to rheology analysis, elastic solid, viscous liquid, linear viscoelasticity and non-linear behavior, practical rheological measurements, instrumentation and measuring systems, applications in varied material systems, food texture and sensory analysis. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will: 1. understand the principles and fundamentals of rheology anlysis. 2. apply rheology tools to study different material systems. 3. understand principles and fundamentals of texture measure ments. 4. understand the different parameters of food texture and their relation to sensory analysis. 5. understand the limitation of rheology and texture analysis.
00660248.name: Rheology- Principles and Applications

00660252.about:
food production pollutes the environment, and pollution harms our health through food. adherence to sustainability principles ensures provision of healthy nutrition and food-security. we will examine the supply chain: agricultural cultivation, food production andconsumption, analyze the effects of these processes on the environment, and how to improve their sustainability.
 learning outcomes: by the end of the course, the student will be able to:
 1. explain all environmental aspects of the israeli food supply chain. 2. be familiar with the major environmental aspects of the global food supply chain.
 3. analyze the various aspects of the influences o f the food system on the environment.
 4. explain in detail the environmental impact on the food we eat (in israel and globally).
 5. suggest appropriate practical tools for decreasing the negative environmental impact of the israeli and global food system.
00660252.name: Food and Sustainability

00660329.about:
THIS COURSE PROVIDES STUDENTS WITH FUNDAMENTAL AND PRACTICAL KNOWLEDGE IN THE FABRICATION AND CHARACTERIZATION OF EMULSIONS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON THE UNIQUE CHEMICAL REACTIONS AND INTERACTIONS OCCURRING IN SUCH COLLOIDAL SYSTEMS. LECTURES WILL ADDRESS CHEMICAL REACTIONS IN EMULSIONS, DROPLET LIPID OXIDATION, INTERFACIAL PHENOMENA AS WELL AS EMULSION DIGESTIVE FATE AND CONTROLLED RELEASE OF BIOACTIVES. THIS COURSE WILL ALSO EXPOSE STUDENTS TO NOVEL DEVELOPMENTS AND FORMULATIONS IN THE FIELD. ATTENDEES WILL ALSO LEARN OF SPECIALTY EMULSIONS, STRUCTURED EMULSIONS, COLLOID-STABILIZED EMULSIONS (PICKERING EMULSIONS), MICROEMULSIONS AND NANOEMULSIONS USED IN THE FOOD AND PHARMACEUTICAL APPLICATIONS.  PRACTICAL SESSIONS WILL ENABLE GAINING EXPERIENCE IN PRODUCTION OF EMULSIONS, ANALYSIS OF THEIR CHARACTERISTICS AND STABILITY.
 STUDENTS SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETING THE COURSE WILL BE ABLE TO: 1. DETAIL KEY ASPECTS OF EMULSION CHARACTERISTICS, EMULSIFICATION METHODS AND EMULSION STABILITY MECHANISMS.
 2. DESCRIBE AND IMPLEMENT EMULSION PRODUCTION SCHEMES (E.G. HIGH-PRESSURE HOMOGENIZERS) AS WELL AS CHARACTERIZATION TECHNIQUES (SUCH AS ANALYTICAL CENTRIFUGATION, LASER SCATTERING AND OTHER METHOD
00660329.name: Emulsions in Food and Biotechnology

00660332.about: the interface between nanotechnology and biological materials will be in the focus of the class, and methods to achieve synergetic activation. the planned program will deal with the theory, the synthetic methods and the properties of the nps. that includes, metallic nps semiconductors-based synthesis and photoanode or photocathode fabrication. construction of optical and electrical biosensorswill be discussed and implemented in additional labs. specifically, on these topics: 1. biocatalysis. 2. bioelectronics and biosensors. 3.properties of nano-materials. 4.nanomaterials in biological research and medicine. 5. photocatalysis and photoelectrocatalysis . 6. biological materials (with emphasis on dna) as nanotechnological tools. 7. nanobio hybrid systems. 8. nano particles synthesis. 9. first and second generation of amperometric glucose biosensors. learning outcomes: a student will be able to use nanotechnologytools. the student will have a knowledge to construct optical or amperometric biosensoes. in the complementay lab, the student willimplement the theoretical knowledge and to test basic tools. the student will present related articles and critic the above with the studied tools
00660332.name: Bio-Nano Hybrids and Biosensors

00660333.about:
this course focuses on the effect of active substance on living creatures, including on the basic understanding of fharmacology anddrug delivery concepts. the course begins with a series of introductory lectures that describe the basic principles of pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics and on the various drug receptors in our body. the following discussions include toxicity, choosing the correct drug for both the patient and the disease, interactions between drugs and food, anti-cancer and psychiatric treatments and concepts for designing delivery systems. practice classes will cover deeper knowledge of basic terminology as well as treating strategie s of very common diseases (e.g. high blood pressure, hyperlipidemia, allergies etc.).
 learning outcomes: 1. students will be familiar with basic principles and terminology of pharmacology. 2. students will understand how drugs work and what are the clinical considerations for choosing the proper drug. 3. students will be familiar with main delivery systems and their advantages.disadvantages.4. the students will be familiar with some of the most common diseasesf from diagnosis to treatment and monitoring.
00660333.name: Biopharmaceutics- Pharmacology and Drug Delivery

00660418.about: Physiology of food and water-born pathogens: bacteria, molds and viruses. Characterization of pathogenicity and virulence factors: attachment, invasion, growth and survival within host cells. Reasons for emergence of new pathogens and re-emergence of known microoranisms as humman pathogens. Detection and identification of pathogens and their toxins: conventional vs. new molecular methods. Antimicrobial agents: mode of action and resistance. Risk assessment and predictive modeling.
00660418.name: Microbiology of Pathogens

00660505.about: Separation process principles.  Specific problems in biotechnology.  Preparation, cell disintegration, stabilization. Filtration, centrifugation, precipitation.  Solvent extraction. Adsorption, chromatography, ion exchange.  Membrane processes. Electrophoresis, electrodialysis, isoelectric focusing. Distillation, molecular distillation.  Evaporation, drying, lyophilization.  Economics of downstream processing.
00660505.name: Downstream Processing in Biotechnology

00660513.about: Biology of cells in tissue cultures, growth conditions and media, RNA and protein processing in mammalian cells, plasmid vectors and protein expression systems in mammalian and insect cells, mass cell culture and the production of biochemicals (growth factors, cytokines, monoclonal antibodies).
00660513.name: Biotechnology of Animal Cells

00660516.about: Purification of plasmid DNA, restriction enzyme analysis, transforming e. coli by calcium or electroporation techniques, cloning, analysis of clones, purification of mammalian DNA and RNA, southern and northern analysis, overexpression of recombinant proteins in e. coli, western analysis, PCR analysis.
00660516.name: Molecular Biotechnology Laboratory

00660517.about: genetic markers and physical mapping, genomic maps and sequences, genetic of quantitative traits, statistical tools in gene mapping, breeding by classic selection and by marder-assisted selection, genetic manipulation in plants and animals, applying genomic technology in modern food engineering.
00660517.name: Gene Technology in Food Engineering

00660518.about: Enzyme properties, methods for production and purification of enzymes including immobilization techniques and uses in bioreactors. Utilization of enzymes in organic media. Uses of biocatalysts in the food and pharmaceutical industry. Topics include quantitative aspects and emphasis will be given to practical aspects of enzymology.
00660518.name: Applied Biocatalysis

00660521.about: Polymers for tisssue engineering, synthetic and natural polymers, synthesis, characterization, properties,2d and 3d scaffolds, applications of cells in tissue engineering,seeding methods, dynamic seeding, characterization. Bioreactors for mammalian cell culturing, cell-matrix interactions the ECM-cell interactions, engineering cells and organs, bio-artificial organs, tissue engineered organ, gene therapy in tissue engineering.
00660521.name: Tissue Engineering

00660524.about: Peptide biochemistry: physical and chemical properties, biotechnological and chemical methods for peptide production and characterization.  Current antimicrobial peptides research and their role in fighting antibiotic resistance. Mechanisms of drug resistance, and antimicrobial action, toxicological and physiological effects, structure-activity relationships, applications.
00660524.name: Biotechnology of Antimicrobial Peptides

00660525.about: research commercialization in pharma industry and biotech start-up companies. generic drugs, regulations (ind, nda, anda and dmf preparation for fda), quality system (gmp, cgmp, glp, gcp), patents and intellectural property, technology transfer, the company, market, marketing and manufacturing.
00660525.name: Entrepreneurship in Biotechnology and Food Engineering

00660526.about: THE SYNTHETIC BIOLOGY COURSE WIL INVOLVE BOTH THEORETIAL AND LABWORK WHOSE GOAL WILL BE TO DESIGN, MODEL AND ASSEMBLE A SYNTHETIC BIOLOGICAL CIRCUIT. THE FIRST PART OF THE COURSE WILL BE DEDICATED TO LEARN THE NECESSARY TOOLS IN ORDER TO DESIGN, BUILD, SIMULATE AND ANALYZE GENETIC CIRCUITS. THE SECOND PART OF THE COURSE WILL BE DEDICATED TO LEARNING HOW TO BUILD AND TEST A GENETIC CIRCUIT IN THE LAB. THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN ADVANCED CLONING TECHNIQUES, SUCH AS GIBSON ASSEMBLY, GOLDEN GATE ASSEMBLY AND PLATE READER ANALYSIS. FINALLY, THE STUDENTS WILL SUBMIT A FINAL PROJECT WHICH WILL ADDRESS CURRENT CHALLENGES WITH SYNTHETIC BIOLOGY GENE CIRCUITS. LEAR NING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURE THE STUDENT WILL KNOW: 1. WHAT ARE BIOLOGICAL CIRCUITS. 2. WHAT IS BOOLEAN ALGEBRA. 3. HOW TO WRITE COUPLED RATE EQUATIONS. 4. HOW TO MODEL INDUCTION. 5. HOW TO SOLVE RATE EQUATIONS WITH MATLAB. 5. HOW TO PLAN PRIMERS FOR CLASSICAL CLONING VIA RESTRICTION ENZMES. 6. HOW TO CLONE TWO BIOLOGICAL PARTS WITH MCS. 7. TO CARRY OUT THE FOLLOWING PROCESSES: PCR,RESTRICTION, LIGATION, DNA TRANSFORMATION. 8. HOW TO PLAN PRIMERS FOR GIBSON ASSEMBLY CLONING AND GOLDEN GATE . 9. HOW TO ASSEMBLE THREE-PART DN
00660526.name: Synthetic Biology

00660527.about: the course provides comprehensive knowledge and systematic understanding of different biotechnological products development processand the phases involved, assisting students to successfully become integrated in the biotech industry. the course focuses on drug development process, from academic research based-idea to an industrial product. the course will introduce the students to different development stages to assess safty, tolerability and efficacy in several therapeutic indications as well as the importance of regulatory requirements throughout the entire process. learning outcomes: course completion will provide applicable knowledge, tools and th orough understanding of biotechnological product development process, helping students to successfully integrate in the biotech industry. the course will enable: 1. being familiar with important concepts in the development world. 2. knowing the different development phases in the transition from academic research based idea to an industrial product 3. understanding the rational in systematic development of a biotechnological product. 4. understanding the importance and implementation of regulation in the development process: reduce ri
00660527.name: From Bench to Market - Biotech Industry

00660528.about: the aim of the course is to give the student basic knowledge in neuroscience research. the course will include comprehensive characterization of the nerves system components and their role based on the cellular approach. the course will discuss research methodologies to study main topics in neuroscience such as: developmental neuroscience, neuroimmunology, and memory and learning. in addition, state of the art technologies such as optogenetics, dredd, single-cell rnaseq and tissue clearing will be reviewed. learning outcomes: upon successful completion of the course, students will be familiar with the structure of the nerves system, with special emphas is on the cellular function of the various components of the nervous system. students will be familiar with the main topics in neuroscience research and the experimental approaches used.
00660528.name: Methodologies in Neuroscience Research

00660529.about:
the revolution in dna sequencing technologies during the last decade has enabled the sequencing of tens of thousands of cancer tumors, both their dna and rna. large scale sequencing initiatives, such as the cancer genome atlas (tcga), revolutionized both our understanding of cancer biology and the way treatment is provided to patients. in this, course, students will receive a brief introduction to cancer development and an overview of the dna.rna next generation sequencing (ngs) technologies. the course will emphasize howthese tools can be applied to various datasets, and how this analysis can lead to better diagnosis and determine treatment decisions .
learning outcomes: at the end of the course the stuents will:
 1. understand the bioinformatics tools needed for analzing the output data of the sequencing devices.
 2. how to apply them for various datasets.
00660529.name: Cancer Bioinformatics

00660532.about:
in recent years there is a significant increase in the amount of biological data available in digital formats. thus, often, the bottleneck in many projects is the ability to analyze the data rather than data acquisition. in this course the students will learn thebasic skills for analysis of large datesets. the use of available databases and how to import data from them. the course will emphasize the  hands-on  approach and students will practice the studied methods. the course will cover: basic statistics, data import, data visualization, linear regression, dimensional reduction, clustering analysis, classifiers, multiple testing correction and basic image analysis.
 learning outcomes:
 the student will know the background of the main computational methods and tools that are usedto analyze large biological datasets. the student will be familiar with the large databases thatare available on the network, and will experience analyzing biological data with these tools.
00660532.name: Introduction to Analysis of Big Data in Biology

00660533.about:
can we build a cell. can we use non-living building blocks like dna molecules, phospholipids, macromolecules  to assemble an autonomous self-replicating system with life properties. have we reached a sufficient understanding of the cell to create artificial versions of it  and can we engineer synthetic systems conserving the features of life in radically different architectures. these are questions at the center of the rapidly evolving field of bottom-up artificial cell assemblycan. assemblycan we build a cell, can we usenon-living building blocks the aim of the course is to introduce this effervescent field. we will present the essential modules that  were reconstituted on synthetic platforms, such as cell-free gene expression, dna replication, membrane encapsulation, energy production  we will also explore imaginative cell designs, challenging the traditional conception of what can be considered as a  cell .communication between artificial cells and collective behaviors on synthetic tissue models will be discussed as well._
learning outcomes: by the end of the course the student will:
 1. be familiar with the field of bottom-up artificial cell assembly, understanding the curren
00660533.name: TOWARDS ARTIFICIAL CELLS

00660534.about:
IN RECENT YEARS THERE IS SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN THE AMOUNT OF BIOLOGICAL DATA AVAILABLE IN DIGITAL FORMATS. THUS, OFTEN, THE BOTTLENECK IN MANY PROJECTS IS THE ABILITY TO ANALYZE THE DATA RATHER THAN DATA ACQUISITION. IN THIS COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN BASICSKILLS TO ALLOW ANALYSIS OF LARGE DATASETS. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS WILL LEARN TO USE AVAILABLE DATABASES AND HOW TO IMPORT DATA FROMTHEM. THE COURSE WILL EMPHASIZE THE  HANDS-ON  APPROACH AND STUDENTS WILL REQUIRE TO PRACTICE THE METHODS IN CLASS AND HOMEWORK. THE THE COURSE WILL COVER: BASIC STATISTICS, DATA IMPORT, DATA VISUALIZATION, LINEAR REGRESSION, DIMENSIONAL REDUCTION, CLUSTERING ANAL YSIS, CLASSIFIERS, MULTIPLE TESTING CORRECTION.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN THE BACKGROUND OF THE MAIM COMPUTATIONAL METHODS AND TOOLS THAT ARE USED TO ANALYZE LARGE BIOLOGICAL DATASETS. HE WILL BECOME FAMILIAR WITH THE LARGE DATABASES THAT ARE AVAILABLE ON THE NETWORK, AND WILL EXPERIENCE ANALYZING BIOLOGICAL DATA WITH THESE TOOLS
00660534.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN BIG DATA FOR BIOTECHN

00660605.about: Topics: Preventive nutrition: prevention of coronary heart disease, cancer, osteoporosis, metabolic syndrome and ways to prologn life through caloric restrictions.
00660605.name: Preventive Nutrition, Health Aspects

00660614.about: the course will provide students with comprehensive knowledge of the nutritional requirements of humans along the healthy lifespan and different target populations with the prospect of fabricating tailored and personalized foods. students will learn of the specific nutritional requirements (athletes, celiac patients, people with food allergies), populations with specific nutritional preferences (kosher, vegetarian, vegan) and the possibility of personalized nutrition. learning outcomes: upon succsessful completion of thiscourse, students will be able to describe and detail the unique nutritional needs and preferences: 1. along the healthy human lifesp an. 2. amongst populations with specific needs and the challenges in the manufacturing of tailored foods. 3. for populations with specific preferences.
00660614.name: Personalized Nutrition

00680006.about: Students taking this course should write an independent paper on a specific subject in one of the areas of food engineering, technology or science.  Such a project will only be approved in case that the student concerned needs one (or less) credit points to complete his curriculum.
00680006.name: Special Project

00680009.about: The course is intended for students pursuing non-thesis Master of Engineering degree. A project will be performed in a subject related  to experimental research, or engineering design or critical literature review.
00680009.name: Advanced Seminar in Food Engineering

00680238.about: introduction: structure and properties of food and biological materials and their significance in the relevant technological fields. structure and properties of liquid water and ice solutions, ion specific effects, saccharides and their effects, surface tension, capillarity and wetting, nucleation and crystallization freezing, glass transition polymers: types of polymers in biotechnology and food bond types, conformations, configurations, basic polymer physics, polymer solution thermodynamics, rheology and structure, polymerization and gelation, gel swelling and shrinkage, self assembling systems, colloidal systems stability.
00680238.name: Biomateiral Science and Technology

00680505.about:
the course focuses on experimental design and analysis of data relevant to life sciences in general and biotechnology and food engineering in particular. it presents statistical methods for decision-making in those fields. specifically, the course will cover the following topics : review on probability distributions, descriptive statistics, point estimation, hypothesis testing and inferences,analysis of variance (anova), simple linear, nonlinear and multiple regression, distribution-free procedures, design of experiments, quality control methods. 
 learning outocmes: by the end of the course, the student will be able to: - perform exploratory analysis  of data by graphical and other means, summarize data visually and numerically.
 - use appropriate statistical methodologies and concepts, formulate a problem in statistical terms, and carry out a variety of formal inference procedures.
 - plan experiments while considering statistical modules, sufficient sample size, and avoiding potential statistical "pitfalls". - create quantitative modelsto solve real experimental problems across different domains and in particular in biological research.
 - use of statistical software for com
00680505.name: EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND ANALYSIS

00680509.about: Composition of growth media, theory and practice of continuous cultures. Agitation, mass transfer and scale - up in fermentation systems. Methods of large scale fermentations: organic feedstocks, organic acids, amino acids and antibiotics.
00680509.name: Process Biotechnology

00680512.about: The course will provide students with information and tools to select and implement advanced analytical methods, emphasizing understanding of their modes of operation and their key advantages and limitations in analysis of foods or biologicals. Students successfully finishing this course will be able to describe the underlying principles of common analytical methods (sampling, separation methods and physical characterization) and innovative methods for physicohemical characterization of biologicals (Advancedf MS, 2D NMR, DLS, Advanced microsopies). Students will also acquire tools to evaluate and screen the suitability of advanced analkytiucs for speci fic applications as well as tackle comprehensive data analyses (omics anlyses). Finally, students will be able to describe a verityof applications of advanced analytics in Medicine, Research and the Food and Biotechnology industries. Learning Outcomes: Students successfully completing this course should be able to: 1. Describe, classify and characterize basic physicochemcial anlaysis methods. 2. Describe, classify and characterize advanced physicochemical analysis methods. 3. List key advantages and limitations of advanced analytical
00680512.name: Modern Analytical Methods in Biotechnology

00840135.about: Algebraic equations, systems of linear equations, interpolation, differentiation, integration, ordinary differential equations (andsystems of ODE'S).
00840135.name: Numerical Analysis for Aerospace Engi.

00840143.about: Basic definitions, requirements analysis, architecture, processes, conceptual design and trade-off studies, decisions under uncertainty. Utility function, risk management, quality and reliability principles, integration, verification and validation of systems.
00840143.name: Aerospace Systems Engineering

00840154.about: By providing knowledge of common measurement techniques and their basic operational principles, this course is intended to introduce undergraduate students to experimental methods, sensors, and computer-aided data acquisition, as relevant to aerospace engineeringapplication. The fundamentals emphasized in the  curriculu, stretch upon variety of dusciplines.
00840154.name: Experimental Methods in Aerospace Eng.

00840213.about: Introduction, the thermodynamic system and properties, equilibrium, processes. Temperature scales. Equations of state, P-V-T surfaces, two - phase regions. Work, heat, energy and the first law of thermodynamics. Conservation of energy in open systems, enthalpy. Quasistatic adiabatic processes. Thermodynamic efficiency. The Carnot cycle. Reversible and irreversible processes, the second law ofthermodynamics. The Clausius inequality, entropy. Availability. The Helmholtz and Gibbs functions. The Maxwell equations. Equilibrium among phases, the Clausius-Chapayron equation. Properties of a pure substance. Thermodynamic cycles and heat engines. One-dimensio nal steady and non steady heat conduction.
00840213.name: Thermodynamics

00840220.about: Equations of motion for an aircraft as a point of mass. Standard atmosphere and pitot-static system. Aerodynamic forces. Thrust andfuel consumption of turbo-jet and propeller-driving engines. Analysis of aircraft performance: straight and level flight, range andendurance, climb and descent, turning flight, Take-off and landing. Flight envelope. Specific energy as a state variable.
00840220.name: Flight Mechanics 1

00840221.about: Aerodynamic couples, longitudinal static stability, pitch control, hinge moments, control forces, maneuver stability and control, phugoid and short period oscillations, control in asymmetric flight, lateral static stability, roll control, dihedral effect, lateraloscillations.
00840221.name: Flight Mechanics 2

00840225.about: Particle kinematic: inertial and accelerated frames of reference. Work, energy, impulse and momentum. Planetary motion. Particle systems. Rigid-body kinematics. Tensor of inertia, Euler's equations, gyroscopic motion, stability. Discrete systems: resonance and damping, Lagrange equations, linear theory, orthogonality.
00840225.name: Dynamics

00840311.about: Fundamentals. Integral and differential forms of the conservation equations for mass, momentum and energy. Theorems of Kelvin, Helmholtz, Bernoulli and Crocco. Irrotational incompressible flow. Velocity potential. The Laplace and boundary conditions. Two-dimensional source and vortex. Doublet. flow around a rotating cylinder. The Kutta-Zukowskii theorem. Theory of wing sections. Vortex filaments. Biot-Savart law. Lifting-line theory. Induced drag. Elliptic wing. The horse-shoe model. Ground effect and wind-tunnel corrections.
00840311.name: Incompressible Aerodynamics

00840312.about: Coservation laws for one-dimensional compressible flow. Isentropic flow. Normal shock waves. Flowin a nozzle. Flow in inlet. The Rayleigh and Fanno flows. Moving shock waves and shock tubes. Oblique shocks. Prandtl-Weyer flow. Weak shocks: first and second order approximations. Theory of a wing section in supersonic flow. Equation for velocity potential in compressible flow. Similarity laws for subsonic and supersonic flows. Critical Mach number. and supersonic flows. Wave drag. Sears-Hack and Von Karman bodies.
00840312.name: Compressible Flow, Inlets and Nozzles

00840314.about: Continuity and navier - Stokes equations, exact solutions of the navier - Stokes equations, laminar boundary layers in two - dimensional flow, similar solutions approximate integral methods of solutions, separation, introduction to turbulent boundary layers, friction and form drag, jets and wakes, steady one and two-dimentional heat condution, fins, transient conduction, convective heat transfer, energy equationn, thermal boundary layers, Reynolds analogy, introduction to radiation, laboratory experments.
00840314.name: Viscous Flow and Heat Transfer

00840506.about: Introduction. Force systems, force.moment resultants. Static equilibrium. Free-body diagram. Trusses: joints and sections methods. Beams: axial force, shear force, and bending moment diagrams. Stress and strain: concept, relation, in axial loading (stress-strain diagram) and shear, Hook's law. Axial deformation of bars, indeterminate systems. Torsion of circular bars. Bending stresses in beams. Moment and product of inertia. Shear stresses in beams. Combined loading in beams. Deflection of beams under bending. Euler bucking.
00840506.name: Solid Mechanics

00840515.about: introduction to theory of elasticity. introdaction to tensors. displacement field, stress and strain tensors. strain measures. principal stress and transformations of stress. failure criteria. thermal stresses. constitutive laws. generalized hook's law. boundrey value problems. saint-venant's principle. plane stress.strain problems. airy function. axisymmetric problems. stress concentration.
00840515.name: Introduction to Theory of Elasticity

00840630.about: Importance of transferring engineering information in a standard manner. Building 3D geometry in the computer (the digital model) and producing drawings from it. Definition of projections- ansi and iso standards. Review of manufacturing processes and their influence on the drawing. Standard methods of dimensioning and providing product manufacturing information. Use of the digital model for other applications - analyses. Excersises using commercial CAD systems.
00840630.name: Computerized Engineering Drafting

00840641.about: Integration of design and manufacturing, selection of materials and design optimization, fatigue and shaft design, journal and anti-friction bearings, design of welded joints, brazing, sheet technology and riveting, adhesive bonding, design of bolted joints, design for reliability and maintainability, plastic forming of sheet metals structures, design of composite structures, airborne forging, extrusion and casting, special processes, quality assurance and NDT.
00840641.name: Aerospace Engineering Design and Manufac

00840653.about: In the last academic year of his studies, the student selects a two-semester design project.  Four or five projects, in a variety of subjects, such as flight vehicles, aviation power plants, etc., which require synthesis of the broad aeronautical field, are offered each year.  The list of projects offered is published separately every year.  The student is guided in organizing and approachingthe problems involved (timetable, consideration and alternatives, CAE, final report, use of auxiliary material, catalogs and consultation).
00840653.name: Design Project 53

00840737.about: Characterization of dynamic systems, applications of Laplace transform, impulse response, step response, frequency response transfer function representation, Bode diagrams, non-minimum phase systems, state-space representation, linearization, state-transition matrix, matrix exponential, canonical transformations, Lyapunov stability, Routh-Hurwitz stability criterion, controllability and observability. Laboratory experiments.
00840737.name: Dynamic Systems

00840738.about: Closed-loop and open-loop system; steady-state performance; system type; root locus; PID control design; actuator saturation and integrator windup; Nyquist stability; robustness margins Lead/Lag compensation; loop shaping; digital control; discretization of continuous controllers; casualty of discrete time controllers; dicrete time PID control; lab experiments.
00840738.name: Control Theory

00840913.about: Space environment,spacecraft missions, aplications for communications and remote sensing. Luaunch vehicles, spacecraft main subsystems, orbital dynamics,classical central-force problem, orbital position as a function of time, orbits in three dimensions and reference frames, J2 perturbation, spacecraft propulsion, orbital maneuvers, satellite attitude dynamics, gravity gradients stabilization,gyroscopic attitude control, electric power, thermal control.
00840913.name: Fundamentals of Space Engineering

00850101.about: Construction and flight of model airplane by use of engineering principles (general subject).
00850101.name: Model Airplane Construction 1

00850201.about: Summarized history of the development of the aerospace sciences. Types and components of flight vehicles.  Basic aerodynamics (concepts, dimensions, standard atmosphere, etc.), subsonic and supersonic flows. Astronautics, propulsion, flight control, aerospace structures, stability and flight mechanics.  The airplane as a system.
00850201.name: Introduction to Aerospace Engineering

00850220.about: The course will include a number of theoretical and experimental projects. theoretical projects will be concerned with estimating stability derivatives and acrodynamic coefficients of a light airplane (as cessna 172) and consequently, with estimating its performance and flying qualities. Experimental projects will be devoted to in-flight verification of the theoretical estimates.
00850220.name: Experimental Flight Mechanics

00850305.about:
Subsonic, transonic and supersonic wind-tunnels, shock tube and shock tunnel, balances, wind tunnel corrections, dynamic testing, hot wire anemometer, Laser Doppler anemometer, flow visualization methods. Laboratory study,:  stability, wing-body interference, boundary layer, heat transfer.
 ,Select three out of four.
00850305.name: Experimental Methods in Aerodynamics

00850322.about: The fundamental equations and methods of solution in the various speed ranges.  Subsonic profiles, supercritical profiles, stall and high lift devices.  Finite wing theory.  Lifting line, vortex lattice and panel methods, low aspect-ratio wings. Area-rule.  Supersonic wings.  Applications to aircraft design.
00850322.name: Applied Aerodynamics

00850326.about: In this workshop, the students shall learn how to utilize commercial computational fluid dynamics packages for the solution of CFD problems based on the following stages: grid generation packages, flow solvers, and flow visualization packages. Comparison between results obtained by using various algorithms and comparisons against solutions obtained by using solvers that the students develop in "computational aerodynamics".
00850326.name: Workshop in Computational Aerodynamics

00850405.about: Advanced experiments in flight vehicle propulsion and combustion.
00850405.name: Rocket and Jet Propulsion Lab

00850407.about: Joule-Brayton Cycle Thermodynamics, Varios engine architectures, Thrust Generation, Component Efficiencies, Euler Turbomachinery Equation, Velocity Triangles, Axial and Radial Compressors, Turbine, Combustion Chambers, Materials in Gas Turbines, Engine Failure Mechanisms, Manufacturing processes, Bearings and gears, Fuel and lubricants, Jet engine dynamics and vibrations, Life limits and riskanalysis, turbine engine control.
00850407.name: Introduction to Jet Engines

00850455.about: introduction to jet engines and turbines: various engine architectures (turbojet and gas generators), online health monitoring, fundamentals of turbomachinery, turbine engine control, turbine, axial, and radial compressors, bearings and gears, fuels and lubricants, blade vibrations, measurments of temprature and pressure in hot gas environments, measurments of shaft speed and fuel rate, measurements of vibrations and thrust, pressure and temperature loss determination. the course is based on preparing and preforming 6 experiments in the field of gas turbines subsystems, focusing on experimental methodology, measurement analysis, and student participati on in experiment preparation.
00850455.name: Laboratory in Jet Eng. and Turbines
