00850505.about: 5-6 tests dealing with stress and stability of thin aerospace type structures - with special emphasis on measurements, data reduction and interpretation of test results, experimental analysis, stress and stability, loads, clamping fixtures and boundary conditions, test control: testing techniques, static and dynamic, special instrumentation and measurement techniques, final project, for instance upgrading of an existing test setup.
00850505.name: Experimental Methods in Aero. Structures

00850605.about: BASIC AVIONICS IN FLYING PLATFORMS, ACTUATORS, FLIGHT CONTROLLERS, RADIO COMMUNICATION, POWER SOURCES, ELECTRIC INTEGRATION. COMMUNICATION PROTOCOLS IN FLIGHT CONTROLLERS, NAVIGATION SOLUTION, AUTOPILOT IMPLEMENTATION ON PIXHAWK HARDWARE, AUTOMATIC CONTROL GAINS DESIGN. ALGORITHM S DEPLOYMENT ON HARDWARE AND AUTOMATIC CODE GENERATION.
00850605.name: AVIONICS LAB. AND FLIGHT SOFTWARE

00850634.about: Design of components and subassemblies for aerospace. Preparation of specification. Discussion of several solutions. Choise of preferred solution. Detailed design of subassemclies.
00850634.name: Projects in Mechanical Design

00850640.about: Familiarization with ILS/Maintenance Engineering in industrial projects. Influence on systems design to achieve Availability and LCC goals, choosing an optimal maintenance concept and designing the support system. Industry ILS practices. Exercises improving the skills of analysis and written and oral expression. Use of English in preparation for work as engineers.
00850640.name: Integrated Logistics Support

00850679.about: disciplinary or multidisciplinary project in aerospace engineering.
00850679.name: Advanced Design Project

00850695.about: The design process: conceptual. Preliminary (PD) and detail design. Customer.market definition of requirements. Civil and military regulations (far.jar. milspects). Preliminary aircraft sizing: weight, performance and cost tradeoffs and parametric analysis. aircraft layout and inboard profile. Special topics and advanced thechnologies that influence preliminary design.
00850695.name: Preliminary Design of Aircraft

00850705.about: THE GOAL OF THE LAB IS THE DESIGN OF A COMPLETE CONTROL SYSTEM FOR THE AUTONOMOUS FLIGHT OF A QUADCOPTER. MODELING OF A QUADCOPTER IS PERFORMED FROM BASIC PRINCIPLES. COMPLIMENTARY FILTERS AND MULTI-LOOP CONTROLLERS ARE DESIGNED TO STABILIZE THE SYSTEM.  THE COURSE CONCLUDES WITH THE AUTONOMOUS FLIGHT OF THE QUADCOPTER.
00850705.name: Required Elective Control Laboratory

00850801.about: Seminar in Aerodynamics. Technical presentation and writing, indluding: proposals of research projects, thesis presentations and documents, technical reports and lectures, conference presentations and proceedings, and journal articles. In this seminar course, thetechnical content is focused on aerospace applications. The class is intended for students who have more than 120 credits.
00850801.name: Seminar in Aerodynamics

00850802.about: Seminar in Structures. Technical presentation and writing, indluding: proposals of research projects, thesis presentationswho and documents, technical reports and lectures, conference presentations and proceedings, and journal articles. In this seminar course, the technical content is focused on aerospace applications. The class is intended for students who have more than 120 credits.
00850802.name: Seminar in Structures

00850803.about: Seminar in Propulsion. Technical presentation and writing, indluding: proposals of research projects, thesis presentationswho and documents, technical reports and lectures, conference presentations and proceedings, and journal articles. In this seminar course, the technical content is focused on aerospace applications. The class is intended for students who have more than 120 credits.
00850803.name: Seminar in Propulsion

00850804.about: Seminar in Control. Technical presentation and writing, indluding: proposals of research projects, thesis presentationswho and documents, technical reports and lectures, conference presentations and proceedings, and journal articles. In this seminar course, the technical content is focused on aerospace applications. The class is intended for students who have more than 120 credits.
00850804.name: Seminar in Control

00850805.about: Seminar in Space. Technical presentation and writing, indluding: proposals of research projects, thesis presentations and documents, technical reports and lectures, conference presentations and proceedings, and journal articles. In this seminar course, the technical content is focused on aerospace applications. The class is intended for students who have more than 120 credits.
00850805.name: Seminar in Space

00850851.about: Elective:  This course is designed to train outstanding students in carrying out independent work of a research character.  Normally, this project should be taken during the last year of his undergraduate studies.  The student works under the close supervision ofa faculty member who provides him with a subject for an experimental or theoretical research project. The student carries out the research and his results are summarized in a report.  This subject can be taken with the expressed confirmation by the faculty memberresponsible for this elective.
00850851.name: Research Project 1

00850905.about: introduction to satellite subsystems: structure, power, computer and software, radio-frequency communication, attitude control, andpropulsion. operation of a satellite's coputer software and radio. electrical measurements of a power system. measurements and vacuum effects. measurements and control of angular momentum. experiment in rocket propultion. the course is based on preforming 5-6 experiments in the field of spacecraft subsystems, focusing on experimental methodology, measurement analysis, and student participation in experiment preparation.
00850905.name: Lab.in Spacecraft and Satellite Systems

00850915.about: Motion in a central force field. Time equation for eliptic, hyperbolic and parabolic orbits. initial value problem and boundary value problem. Interplanetary trajectories. Change of orbital element. Orbit determination from observation. Relativr motion and formation flying. General perturbations and Gauss Variational Equation. effect of atmospheric drag. Effect of solar radiation pressure. Mission planning: Sun-synchronous orbits, stable perigee orbits. Satellite ground-track. Solar-luni effect. The three body problem.
00850915.name: Space Mechanics

00850920.about: Review of rocket propulsion. Mission requirements for space propulsion. Physics of electric propulsion devices: single particle motions in electric and magnetic fields, plasma as fluid, collisional processes, transport and diffusion across magnetic field and sheat. Ion thruster and Hall thruster operation and design.
00850920.name: Space Electric Propulsion

00860150.about: communication models, source coding, channel coding. compression with and w.o distortion. entropy. analog and digital channels. coding techniques. error correcting codes. channel capacity. multiplexing techniques. network: wide, cellular, local , wireless. protocols. encryption. e-mail applications.
00860150.name: Data and Computer Communication for Systems Engineers

00860172.about: Introduction.  Methods for solving parabolic, elliptic and hyperbolic partial differential equations, characteristics, aeronauticalexamples.
00860172.name: Numerical Methods in Aeronautical Engineering

00860201.about: Projectile trajectories within the atmosphere.  Wind effect and ballistic coefficient.  Motion analysis of unguided rockets during the powered phase.  Analysis of causes of dispersion for powered unguided rockets.  Concepts of dynamic stability of projectiles.  Spin stabilization.
00860201.name: Exterior Ballistics and Dynamics of Rockets

00860219.about: Introduction:  the parameters which influence the behavior of the rotor in hovering and vertical climb.  The motion of a single blade: flapping, lead-lag, and pitch motions.   The forces and moments that act on a  single blade and the whole rotor during horizontal flight.  The helicopter performance in hovering, vertical flight and horizontal flight.
00860219.name: Helicopter Dynamics and Aerodynamics

00860222.about: Requirements analysis and specification methods for software intensive systems. Model based analysis of embedded computer systems. Introduction to object based analysis and specification, using the ESCAM (embedded computer systems analysis and modeling) method. Analysis of the static view, the activities and data flow. Dynamic processes. Model validation and verification: static and dynamic tests and simulation. Requirements management and specification generation for embedded systems.
00860222.name: Embedded Computer Systems Analysis

00860241.about: Static aeroelasticity: strip theory, divergence, control surface effectiveness and reversal, wing sweep effects. Structural modal approach. Unsteady aeroelasticity: Unsteady aerodynamics, wing and control surface flutter, gust response. Learning Outomes: On completions of the course the student will be able to: 1. Familiarization with the scope of aeroelasticity and with basic terms and topics of static aeroelasticity. 2. Ability to develop and use computational tools for static aeroelastic analysis. 3. Deepen the knowledfge of static aeroelastic phenomena. 4. Understand control surface effectiveness. 5. Ability to develop and use computational tools f or modal analysis. 6. Familiarization with unsteady aerodynamics and analytical tools for unsteady aerodynamics. 7. Understand flutter. 8. Ability to develop and use computational tools for flutter analysis. 9. Deepen the knowledge of various flutter analysis tools and mechanisms. 10. Familiarization with advanced non- linear unsteady aeroelasticity problems. 11. Familiarization with gust response. 11. Ability to develop and use compputational tools for gust response. 12. Familiarization with advanced non-linear gust response problem
00860241.name: Aeroelasticity 1

00860290.about: topics: fundamentals of orbit dynamics. orbital elements. perturbations. basic orbit maneuvers. linear and nonlinear control theories. formulation of the orbit control problem. gauss equations. optimal orbit control: impulsive and continuous, controlling the local time of sun-synchronous satellites, controlling the ground-track of satellites orbit, control of circular and elliptical constellations. autonomous formation control: reconfiguring, formation keeping, intercept and rendezvous, lambert guidance.
00860290.name: Satellite Orbit Control

00860312.about:
NONLINEAR ELEMENTS: PROPERTIES AND CHALLENGES, FIRST AND SECOND ORDER SYSTEMS: GEOMETRIC ANALYSIS, PHASE PLANE, EQUILIBRIUM POINTS AND THEIR STABILITY, BIFURCATION, CHAOS, LYAPUNOV STABILITY ANALYSIS: DIRECT AND INDIRECT, LOCAL AND GLOBAL STABILITY, REGION OF ATTRACTION, BOUNDED RESPONSE, INPUT-TO-STATE AND INPUT-OUTPUT STABILITY, STABILITY OF FEEDBACK SYSTEMS: CRITERIONS, CANONICAL REPRESENTATIONS: RELATIVE DEGREE, NORMAL FORM, ZERO DYNAMICS, DESIGN METHODS: LOCAL LINEARIZATION AND GAIN SCHEDULING, FULL AND PARTIAL FEEDBACK LINEARIZATION BACKSTEPPING SLIDING MODE CONTROL. LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 ON COMPLETION OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO: 1.  ANALYZE THE STABILITY OF FIRST AND SECOND ORDER SYSTEM USING GRAPHICAL METHODS OF VECTOR FIELDS, PHASE PORTRAITS AND BIFURCATION DIAGRAMS. 2. ANALYZE STABILITY OF NONLINEAR SYSTEMS USING THE VARIOUS LYAPUNOV METHODS: LOCAL AND GLOBAL STABILITY, REGION OF ATTRACTION, BOUNDED RESPONSE, FINITE TIME STABILITY. 3. DESIGN NONLINEAR CONTROLLER USING THE FOLLOWING DESIGN METHODS: FULL AND PARTIAL FEEDBACK LINEARIZATION, BACKSTEPPING, SLIDING MODE OONTROL.
00860312.name: Nonlinear Control

00860320.about: topics: heat transfer equations. fourier's law and advanced heat conduction problems. principles of forced convection. external andinternal forced convection. equations of heat transfer in compressible boundary layers. convection in high speed mach numbers. aerodynamic heating. principles of radiation. heat transfer in space. thermal protection systems for ballistic missiles, including ablation.
00860320.name: Heat Transfer in Aerospace Engineering

00860321.about: the syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the committee for graduate studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00860321.name: Selected Topics in Fluid Dynamics 1

00860325.about:
surface energy and surface tension, marangoni stresses, plateau-rayleigh instability, stability of fluid jets and sheets, formationof drops and bubbles, dynamics of superposed fluids, kelvin-helmholtz instability, thermo-cappilary and chemical effects, dispersed-phase flows, the stability of particle-laden flows.
 learning outcomes: 
 upon completion of this course it is inteded that a student will be able to:_
 1. understand the concept of surface energy, surface tension and curvature pressure.
 2. formulate flow equations for surface-dominated flows._
 3. conduct scaling analysis and understand the dimensionless numbers characterizing a multiphase f low.__
 4. analyze the stability of fluid jets, sheets and superposed fluids.
 5. understand the driving mechanisms in droplet formation and atomization processes and analyze the dynamics of particles and droplets in flows.
00860325.name: STABILITY OF MULTIPHASE FLOWS

00860366.about:
reynolds- averaged equations and the problem of closure. vorticity dynamics. statistical and spectral description of turbulence. homogeneous isotropic turbulence and structure of fine scales. kolmogorov theory and the energy cascade. turbulent shear flows. wall-bounded flows. turbulent boundary layers. turbulent mixing. physical and spectral models. subgridscale modeling. transition to turbulence. 
 coherent structures.
 learning outcomes:
 the end of the course the student will: 1. understand the key equations governing turbulent flows (momentum, energy). 2. utilize the classical statistical and spectral mathematical tools for analyzing turbulence and  other problems involving fluctuating vector fields.
 3. understand the turbulent energy cascade and its relationship coherent structures in turbulence. 4. understand the modern literature on coherent motions and the basic ideas underlying townsend's attached eddy hypothesis. 5. understand the closure problem and different modeling approaches currently utilized in industry and academia to address it.
00860366.name: Introduction to Turbulent Flow

00860376.about: Governing equations, conservation law form, model equations. Computational grids: transformations, grid generation, curvilinear coordinates. Finite difference methods: delta form, solution methods to the model equations, stability and convergence. Finite volume methods. Systems of equations: Jacobians, characteristics. Boundary conditions. Numerical methods for the solution of Euler equations. Flux-splitting methods. Reynolds averaged Navier-Stokes equations: introduction, evaluation of viscous terms.
00860376.name: Computational Aerodynamcis

00860385.about: the continuum hypothesis and the knudsen number. kinetic description of a flow field. the boltzmann equation. microscopic boundary conditions. numerical and approximate solutions to the boltzmann equation. moment equations. rarefied gas flows in the continuum andballistic limits. acoustic wave propagation in a rarefied medium. learning outcomes: upon completion of this course it is intended that a student will be able to: 1. identify and characterize gas flow problems where the continuum hypothesis is violated, 2. formulate problems of fundamental and engineering significance in rarefied gas flows, 3. analyze basic model problems in the continuum and ballistic flow limits.
00860385.name: Introduction to Rarefeid Gas Flows

00860389.about: Theory of subsonic and supersonic flow over slender bodies, solutions using source and doublet distributions, Munk's approximation,supersonic wave drag of slender configurations, bodies with minimum wave drag, area rule, slender wing theory, lift calculation forslender wings and wing-body configurations using conformal mapping, leading-edge suction force and induced drag, flow separation and vortex lift.
00860389.name: Aerodynamics of Wings and Bodies

00860395.about:
introduction to basic concepts in acoustics, aeroacoustic analogies, theory of edge scattering, airfoil leading and trailing edge noise, open rotor noise, rotational effects (broadband and tonal noise), sound propagation in waveguides (plane waves and acoustic modes), ducted fan noise (aero engine noise), sound propagation effects in non-uniform flow.
learning outcomes:
 upon completion of this course a student should be able to: understand the physical principles of aeroacoustic phenomena 
 utilize the classical aeroacoustic analogies
00860395.name: Aircraft Aeroacoustics

00860401.about:
fundamentals of internal combustion engines (reciprocating and rotary piston, 4 and 2 strokes), different methods of energy storage(fuel classification, accumulators, pneumatic system, twisted elastomers, flywheels, springs, phase change materials). analysis of ideal and real cycles, gas exchange process and super-charging. fuel injection, ignition and combustion process, engine. performancemap and propeller characteristics, engine performance at high altitude. learning outcomes: the end of the course the student will know: 1. designing a propulsion system for aircraft propeller
 2. matching a propulsion system for desired aircraft performances
 3. m easuring propulsion system performance map
 4. selecting turbocharging systems
 5. evaluation of aircraft performance at high altitudes
 6. evaluation of fuel injection systems
 7. selecting components to reduce pollutants
00860401.name: Propulsion Systems for Propeller-Driven Aircraft

00860403.about: introduction and principles of propellant grain, motor case, linear, nozzle, thrust control, ignition, initiation and mission ending. formulation, homogeneous and heterogeneous propellants, properties and manufacture. design of grains, structural analysis and internal ballistics. motor design: material selection, applications and manufacture. propellant handling and storage. erosive burning. thrust vector control. space applications. learning outcomes: the student will gain knowledge and understanding of all the issues relative to solid propellant rockets: 1. various kinds of solid propellants. 2. propellant grain geometries, structure and internal bal listics. 3. manufacture processes, storage, handling and testing. 4. motor parts, case, nozzle, igniters, etc. 5. methods of thrustvector control.
00860403.name: Solid Rocket Propulsion

00860413.about: Instability of flow and formation of liquid sprays. Interaction of air streams and sprays. Single droplet evaporation and combustion. Species and energy equations. Size distribution of droplets, time and distance variations as a result of evaporation and combustion. Mathematical methods: discrete, statistical, continuous and sectional.
00860413.name: DYNAMICS AND COMBUSTION OF SPRAYS

00860414.about: The ramjet engine, concept and performance.  Different kinds of ramjets:  the ram-rocket, the scramjet.  The compact design.  The main components of the engine (inlet, combustion chamber, nozzle, fuel control system) and their influence on the performance of the engine. The compatibility of the engine components. Principles of automatic control ramjets for unmanned vehicles.  Preliminary design and performance estimation of ramjet engines.  Operational research for the definition of an optimal solution for representativemissions.
00860414.name: The Ramjet Engine

00860461.about: The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the committee for Graduate studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00860461.name: Selected Topics in Aerospace Propulsion1

00860470.about:
thermodynamic cycles of propulsion systems for hypersonic flight, chemical kinetics, ignition and extinction, conservation equations of reaction flow, laminar premixed and non-premixed flames, turbulent flames  observations and models, flame stabilization in subsonic and supersonic flows, deflagration to detonation, detonation in gas mixtures, analysis of detonation engines. learning outcomes:by the end of the course the students: will be able to perform cycle analysis of different supersonic propulsion systems and evaluate efficiencies
will be familiar with the important chemical mechanisms of hydrocarbon fuels 
 will be able to calculate the ignition  delay time of reactive gas mixtures
 will be able to use simplified models for laminar and diffusion flames 
 will be able to calculate the structure of laminar flames 
 will be familiar with different combustion models for turbulent flames and the condition at which each model is valid 
 will be able to explain methods and underlying physics for flame holding in subsonic and supersonic flows and evaluate the stabilization limits. 
 will understand the physical and chemical processes of transition from deflagration to detonat
00860470.name: Introduction to Supersonic Combustion

00860478.about: Definition and classification of combustion processes. The chemistry and thermochemistry of fuels. Flame temperature. Ignition and explosion. Laminar and turbulent flames. Turbulent mixing in jets. Flame stabilization by bluff bodies. Forced ignition. Detolation.Explosives and blast waves combustion of solids. Fire extinguishing processes. Air pollution from combustion.
00860478.name: Combustion Processes

00860480.about: introduction to turbomachinery, review of compressible flow, flow with work exchange, euler turbomachinery equation, velocity diagrams, energy transfer, dimensional analysis, concepts of flow guidance, understanding efficiency and loss mechanisms in turbomachinery, centrifugal comfressors, axial flow compressors, heat transfer in gas turbines, thermal management techniques, design of hot gas path components. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will understand 1. hot gas path components. 2. the physics associated with turbomachinery components typically encountered in small jet engines. 3. how to blend the scientific knowledge acquir ed in the primary courses (e.g. aerodynamics, heat transfer and structures) in a single application. 4. how to form a strong basis towards multi-disciplinary turbomachinery design and analysis. 5.  the fluid dynamicsof turbo machines to analyze and evaluate design decisions. design decisions.6. how to apply the knowledge acquired in fundamentals of compressor design towards small jet engines.7. how to apply the knowledge acquired in fundamentals of turbine design towards small jet engines. 8. how to evaluate the turbine gas-path heat
00860480.name: Turbomachinery Aero-Thermal Fundamentals

00860484.about: Geometrical optics, interference and diffraction.  Light scattering and its application to measurements of particle size, gas concentration and temperature. Laser Doppler velocimetry.  Lab. demonstration.
00860484.name: Advanced Measurement Techniques

00860520.about:
introduction to tensor notation. basics of continuum (solid) mechanics kinematics of finite deformations.  constitutive laws for nonlinear active materials. basics of nonlinear magnetoelasticity. basics of nonlinear electro-elasticity. maxwell stress. nonlinear coupling in active materials. stability and bifurcations in active nonlinear composites
 learning outcomes: upon completion of this course the student will be able to: 1. be familiar with tensor analysis
 2. correctly apply nonlinear elasticity theories in  modeling of active materials
 3. read and understand advanced scientific publications on nonlinear active material models
 4. apply and eval uate various stress, strain and deformation measures
 5. model and predict the behavior of active materials
 6. be familiar with nonlinear multiphysics modeling approaches
 7. improve their scientific presentation skills
 8. estimate the magneto- or electro- physical meaning of instabilities in materials with coupled materials and understand the mechanical response of the active materials
 9.understand the physical meaning of instabilities in materials with coupled materials
 10. be familiar with the mathematical formulatio
00860520.name: Coupled Problems in Functional Materials

00860521.about: the syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the committee for graduate studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00860521.name: Selected Topics in Aerospace Structures1

00860530.about:
linear theories of static behavior of elastic thin-walled beams, plates and shells will be studied, emphasizing their importance toaerospace structures. the general approach will be starting from the 3d elasticity equations and reducing them to the equations of the structure. special emphasis will be given to solution algorithms.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student willbe able:_
 1. o solve problems in thin-walled structures with an analytic approach (e.g., problems in torsion of rods, problems in bending of rectangular plates and problems of membrane shells of revolution).
 2. .to write computer programs for the solution of pro blems in thin-walled structures according to the studied algorithms.
 3.to recognize the equations that commercial codes for structural analysis (e.g., finite element software) solve, in order to be a smart user  and to be able to modify and extend these codes.
00860530.name: ANALYSIS OF THIN-WALLED STRUCTURES

00860534.about:
monitoring in engineering, structural damage, maintenance strategies and non-destructive evaluation, measurement principles and error sources, design of measuring system for shm, sensors for shm, dynamic beam theory and damage, frequency and modal analysis, static and dynamic end effects, wave propagation in waveguides, failure modes and criticality analysis, strategies of shm system, infrastructure design with shm under deficiency in knowledge.
 learning outcomes:
 upon completion of this course it is intended that a student will be able to:
1.identify potential failure modes of a given structure
 2.identify structural markers for hazardous damages an d produce "marker-damage" map
3.compare between various sensors and critically evaluate manufacturer specifications
4.fit the best monitoring approach to a given structure
5.apply knowledge acquired in various faculty courses in design of shm systems
6.design shmsystem and evaluate its contribution to performance and reliability of the monitored system and to its maintenance cost
7.perform aresearch of shm methods and develop advanced monitoring  methods
00860534.name: Structural Health Monitoring

00860535.about: analyze the structural durability and failure analysis of aeronautical structures by the fracture mechanics methods.linear elastic fracture mechanics. the stresses field around the crack tip for tensile or or shear loadings. multi axial loadings around the crack tip. stress intensity factor (sif) and of the fracture toughness. energy methods and j-integral for sif calculations. dynamic fracture. elasto-plastic fracture mechanics. crack propagation under cyclic loading. structural fatigue. comparison of the fracture mechanics approach with the conservative fatigue approach. non destructive tests (ndt) methods. fracture mechanics in non-metallic material . nasa and esa (european space agency) standards for fracture mechanics.learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able: 1. to recognize the fracture mechanics methods for analysis of the structural durability and structural failure analysis of aeronautical structures. 2. to recognize the stresses field around the crack tip, to calculate the stress intensity factor (sif) for different load cases. 3. to understand the meaning of crack in an aircraft structure and using the fracture mechanics as a basictool for str
00860535.name: Fracture Mechanics in Aero Structures

00860574.about: The finite element method for linear static problems of structures and heat conduction. Variational formulation and virtual work, global and element level, matrix operation, families of finite elements, numerical integration, convergence, programming aspects, eigenvalue problems-vibrations and buckling of structures.
00860574.name: Finite Elements in Aeronautical Engineering

00860576.about: Equilibrium, kinematics, anisotropic elasticity, boundary conditions, planar problems in cartesian and polar coordinates, Concentrated forces, Eigenfunctions, contact problems, thermoelasticity, 3D elasticity, Superposition, Reciprocal and uniqueness theorems, general solutions, energy laws and application in thermoelasticity. Thermal stresses in beams and plates, elastodynamics and wave propagation.
00860576.name: Theory of Elasticity

00860577.about: Introduction and basic assumptions. Multi-degrees of freedom systems, continuous structures (beam, membrane and plate). General principles - Newton, D'alembert, virtual work, Lagrange, Hamilton. Boundary conditions. Damping. Generalized coordinates. Coupling and coupled generalized coordinates. Formulation using vibratory modes and finite- element. Sub-structures. Introduction to nonlinear oscillations. Aerospace applications.
00860577.name: Dynamics of Structures

00860650.about:
introduction to avionics and servo systems. description of electrical servo system, development of motion equation for a permanent magnet direct current motor, brushed and brushless (bldc). selection of additional servo element: gears, amplifiers and sensors. description of hydraulic servo system, development of motion equation for a hydraulic piston with servo valve for motion control. description of pneumatic servo system. comparison between the different servo systems including examples. principles and examples of closed-loops for various servo systems.
learning outcomes:
in the end of the course the student will know how to:
 1.solve problems by us ing the equation of motion for permanent magnet direct current motor
 2.choose the electrical servo components: motor, gear, amplifier and sensors
 3.solve problems by using the equation of motion for hydraulic piston with and without servo valves
 4.fit the proper servo system that meets the technical needs
 5.close various control loops for the various servo systems
00860650.name: Servo Systems Design

00860651.about:
introduction to avionics and radar systems, radar working principles. development of the radar equation without losses and with losses and noise. types of radar systems their equations,characterizations and parameters. the use of pulse-compression for better radar resolution and the matched filter for it. development of the target detection and false alarm probabilities in thepresence of noise for various rcs. development of measurement methods of range,velocity and angles. description of the radar hardware elements (transmitter, antenna, receiver andprocessor), their technologies and costs.
learning outcomes:
in the end of the course the student will know how to:
 1. solve the radar equation for different radar types and scenarios
 2. calculate and choose different waveforms
 3. choose the proper pulse compression method and its matched filer
 4. calculate detection and false-alarm probabilities for various targets
 5. choose the elements of the radar system according to the technical and economic requirements.
00860651.name: Radar Systemd Design

00860730.about: graph theory, algebraic and spectral graph theory, the consensus protocol, relative sensing networks, analysis of networked, systems (stability, rate of convergence, performance, controllability) nonlinear networkes models, connectivity maintenance and maximization, rigid formation for control and localization, graph design for networked systems, applications: formation control of quadrotors,attitude consensus for multiple satellites, autonomous vehicle swarms.
00860730.name: Networked Dynamic Systems: Analysis and Design

00860733.about: characteristic function. gaussian vector. discrete-time processes (iid, bernoulli, binomial counting process) and continuous-time random processes (poisson, wiener). autocorrelation and covariance functions. sum processes,. gaussian and markov processes. stationary. mathematical manipulation of random processes: differentiation, integration. input-output relations of linear systems in time and frequency domains and in state space. ergodicity. introduction to processing of random signals.
00860733.name: Random Processes in Aerospace Systems

00860755.about: Equation of motion in six degrees of freedom.  Linearizations and approximations. Longitudinal and lateral models and transfer functions. Overview of aerospace sensors, Design of longitudinal autopilots, lateral and directional autopilots, coupling, control of flight paths, automatic landing. Learning Outcomes: on completion of the course thestudent will be able to: 1. Derive non-linear equations of motion offlight vehicles. 2. Derive linearized model of aircraft dynamics and analyze their dyamic characteristics. 3. Design basic stability
00860755.name: B Dynamics and Control of Flight Vehicles

00860759.about: Orientation parametrization, Major coordiante frames in Navigation Systems, 3D Rigid Transformation between Different coordinate frames, Dynamics, Inertial sensors, Inertial Navigation Equations, Earth model, Sensor error characteristics, Inertial error prograation, GNSS, overview of INS-GPS EKF. Learning Ouctcomes: At the end of the course the student will: 1. Learn the Operating Principles and the Underlying Equations of Inertial Navigation Systems. 2. Learn to perform analysis to inertial navigation errors. 3. Get Familiar with Principle of Operation of GNSS Systems.
00860759.name: Navigation Systems

00860760.about: Classification of guidance systems.  Guidance methods:  command guidance, homing.  Basic guidance laws:  line of sight, proportional navigation.  Guidance implementation:  tracking and steering loops, guidance transfer function. Seeker heads. Random refraction. Aerodynamic steering, thrust vector control. Effects of the aerodynamic configuration on the steering loop. Planar proportional navigation with first-order time constant. Miss distance calculations.
00860760.name: Principles of Guidance and Homing

00860761.about:
Inertial and dead reckoning navigation, probabilistic information fusion, vision aided navigation, simultaneous localization and mapping, IMU pre-integration, visual-inertial bundle adjustment, cooperative navigation and slam (centralized and distributed), activestate estimation and belief-space planning. Learning Outcomes: After completion of the course the student will know how to:
 1. Develop and implement vision-aided navigation and slam algorithms. 2. Derive and implement probabilistic formulations for cooperative information fusion, van and slam. 3. Implement and solve standard bundle adjustment optimization using real imagery. 4. Develop algori thms for belief space planning.
00860761.name: Vision-Aided Navigation

00860762.about:
probabilistic inference, belief space planning, information theoretic costs, belief space planning approaches for autonomous navigation and active slam, gaussian processes, relation between belief space planning and reinforcement learning. 
 learning outcomes thestudent will acquire fundamental understanding of the mathematical models and solution methods for planning under uncertainty (belief space planning) in the context of mobile robotics and in particular, autonomous navigation and perception.
00860762.name: Autonomous Navigation and Perception

00860777.about: Fundamental concepts. Stochastic processes (review). Least squares estimators. The orthogonality principle. Statistical characteristics and convergence of estimators. Cramer-Rao bounds for deterministic and stochastic parameters. Parameter estimators: blue, maximum likelihood, maximum a posteriori, minimum mean squared error. Kalman filter. extended Kalman filter. Stationary and time-varying parameter estimation using the extended Kalman filter. Examples for estimation and identification in aerospace systems.
00860777.name: Fundamentals in Estimation Theory

00860788.about:
system structure and applications, reference frames and coordinates, satellite trajectories, signals and the navigation message, receiver structure and functionality, pseudorange, doppler and phase observables, the position solution, ranging and positioning errors, the velocity solution, differential measurements, system performance, aerospace applications.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course participants will acquire understanding of gps structure and functionality, signals and transmitted data, the basics of gps signal processing, and the essential algorithm components. students will obtain the knowledge required to perform gps positioning a nd velocity computations. upon completion of this course the student will have fully developed tools for gps positioning. misra + enge.
00860788.name: GPS BASED NAVIGATION DESIGN

00860800.about: Introduction. Inviscid hypersonic flow. Shock waves and expansion wave relations, approximate calculations of aerodynamic forces, similarity relations. Viscous hypersonic flow: boundary layer equations, hypersonic transition, aerodynamic heating, viscous interactions. Introduction to hot flows: equilibrium, frozen and nonequilibrium flows.
00860800.name: Fundamentals of Hypersonic Gasdynamics

00860802.about:
the concept of dimensions, dimensional independence, dimension functions, dimentional homogeneity, the pi-theorem, geometric similarity, general similarity theory, self-similarity, limmiting cases of self-similarity, incomplete self-similarity (self-similarity ofthe second kind), turbulence and incomplete similarity, compressible flows and similarity, geophysical and astrophysical flows and similarity, fermi problems, spring models. learning outcomes: upon completion of this course it is inteded that the student will be able to: define the relevant non-dimensional quantities in a physical problem
 determine when complete or incomplete similarity solut ions are anticipated
 perform both complete and incomplete similarity analyses to obtain physical insights into the solution of physical problems
 perform 'fermi'-type approximation analysis of complex problems
 use spring models to represent a wide range of physically complex systems
 independently identify and apply approximation techniques to a physical problem of current research interest
00860802.name: Similarity and Approximation Methods

00860821.about: the course will be offerd by visitors to the faculty in their field expertise. specific course topics and dates will be published according to availability of the appropriate teachers.
00860821.name: Selected Topics in Aerospace Engineering 1

00860822.about: the syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the curriculum committee prior to the beginning of the term.
00860822.name: Selected Topics in Aerospace Engineering 2

00860923.about: coordinate systems. date and time. keplerian mechanics. lagrange and gauss equations. lagrange and poisson brackets. the fundamental averaging theorem. accessibility and feedback control of continuous orbital transfer. high-order zonals. halo orbits. transfer to halo orbits. space analytical mechanics. euler-lagrange and hamilton equations. applications to astrodynamics and rigid satellite dynamics.
00860923.name: Astrodynamics

00860926.about:
attitude representation, attitude kinematics and dynamics, sensors actuators and disturbing moments, passive stabilization (spinners and gravity-gradient), reaction wheels and control moment gyros, linear attitude control, nonlinear attitude control, static attitude determination methods, examples and applications of attitude determination and control.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able able to:
 1. represent the attitude in different representations.
 2. pose and analyze the attitude equations of motion with various actuators
 3. design and analyze basic attitude control laws using linear and nonlinear methods.
 4. perform static attitude determination using a few basic methods.
00860926.name: SPACECRAFT ATTITUDE CONTROL

00870542.about: the syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the committee for graduate studies prior to the beginning of the term.
00870542.name: Selected Topics in Aerospace Eng. 2

00880103.about: Initial and boundary value problems in ordinary differential equations - Greens functions, characterization of second order partialdifferential equations, separation of variables, Strum-Liouville problem, heat equation, Laplaces equation, wave equation, integraltransforms, Greens functions in PDES, introduction to asymptotic methods.
00880103.name: Applied Mathematics for Aeronautical Engineers 1

00880104.about: Perturbation methods: regular perturbation methods, asymptotic series, nonuniformity, singular perturbation methods, boundary layers, matched asymptotic expansions, rapid oscillations and the WKB method, examples from various fields of application. Variational methods: the first and second variations, the Euler-Lagrange equations, constraints, variational principles in mechanics, approximate methods, eigenvalue problems and the minmax principle.
00880104.name: Applied Mathematics for Aeronautical Engineers 2

00880209.about: Systems integration. Interfaces and environmental conditions. hardware.software integration. Man machine interfaces and simulators.design and execution of system tests. Evalulation and verification of systems.
00880209.name: Systems Integration

00880221.about:
participation in the weekly seminars where lectures are given by researchers and engineers in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering. learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the student will know:
 1. widen their horizons owing to the exposure to various subjects in aerospace engineering presented by experts from industry and academia from israel and abroad.
 2. recognize current research topics in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 3.  gain knowledge of open problems facing researchers and engineers in aerospace engineering today.
 4.recognize the importance of the correct presentation of research results, and will get a n idea on the way an effective lecture should be given.
 5. acquire new ideas that will help them in their research toward an advanced degree.
 6. know how to benefit and find interest in a lecture on a subject remote from their area of research.
00880221.name: Seminar in Aerospace Engineering1

00880222.about:
participation in the weekly seminars where lectures are given by researchers and engineers in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 learning outcomes:
 the end of the course the student will know: 1. widen their horizons owing to the exposure to various subjects in aerospace engineering presented by experts from industry and academia from israel and abroad.
 2. recognize current research topics in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 3. gain knowledge of open problems facing researchers and engineers in aerospace engineering today.
 4.recognize the importance of the correct presentation of research results, and will get an id ea on the way an effective lecture should be given.
 5. acquire new ideas that will help them in their research toward an advanced degree.
 6. know how to benefit and find interest in a lecture on a subject remote from their area of research.
00880222.name: 2 Seminar in Aerospace Engineering

00880223.about:
participation in the weekly seminars where lectures are given by researchers and engineers in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the student will:
 1. widen their horizons owing to the exposure to various subjects in aerospace engineering presented by experts from industry and academia from israel and abroad.
 2. recognize current research topics in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 3. gain knowledge of open problems facing researchers and engineers in aerospace engineering today.
 4.recognize the importance of the correct presentation of research results, and will get an ide a on the way an effective lecture should be given.
 5. acquire new ideas that will help them in their research toward an advanced degree.
 6. know how to benefit and find interest in a lecture on a subject remote from their area of research.
00880223.name: Seminar in Aerospace Engineering 3

00880224.about:
participation in the weekly seminars where lectures are given by researchers and engineers in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know: 1. widen their horizons owing to the exposure to various subjects in aerospace engineering presented by experts from industry and academia from israel and abroad.
 2. recognize current research topics in the various disciplines of aerospace engineering.
 3. gain knowledge of open problems facing researchers and engineers in aerospace engineering today.
 4.recognize the importance of the correct presentation of research results, and will get an idea on the way an effective lecture should be given.
 5. acquire new ideas that will help them in their research toward an advanced degree.
 6. know how to benefit and find interest in a lecture on a subject remote from their area of research.
00880224.name: 4 Seminar in Aerospace Engineering 4

00880316.about: Euler's equations, potential equation, small disturbance equation, and low frequency approximation.  Boundary conditions for transonic flow around an airfoil.  The special problems associated with numerical solution of transonic flows. Selected topics from:  finite difference methods, the finite volume method, finite element methods. Shock-wave-boundary layer interaction and its numerical treatment.
00880316.name: Numerical Methods for Transonic Flows

00880318.about: Fundamental theorems. Wing sections: Zukowskii's airfoils, leading edge suction. Sohngen's inversion, Wing in non-uniform motion, idicial functions, drag and thrust, cavity flow, permeable wings, Ground effect, Finite wings, boundary intergral quation, Asymptoticwing theories, induced drag, Munk's theorems, Puckett's equation, Delta wings. Learning Outcomes: At the end of the course the student will know: 1. the foundations of classical aerodynamics. 2. Asymptotic approaches in aerodynamics.
00880318.name: Wing Theory

00880320.about: caudal fin propulsion: speed limit, propulsion. efficiency. body propulsion. longitudinal stability under neutral buoyancy. pectoral fins propulsion. rowing. sail aerodynamics. sailing: optimal course, portuguese man-of-war. flapping flight. flight envelope for abird.
00880320.name: Aero and Hidro-Dynamics of Propulsion in Nature

00880413.about: Instability of flow and formation of liquid sprays. Interaction of air streams and sprays. Single droplet evaporation and combustion. Species and energy equations. Size distribution of droplets, time and distance variations as a result of evaporation and combustion. Mathematical methods: discrete, statistical, continuous and sectional.
00880413.name: Dynamics and Combustion of Sprays of Liquid Fuels

00880504.about: Finite element methods in the solution of parabolic and hyperbolic partial differential equations.  Models in the analysis of heat conduction and elastodynamics. Semi- discretization and time-space finite elements. Finite elements for non-linear problems in continuum mechanics, fluid flow and heat transfer. Computational errors.  Accuracy and stability. Mixed, hybrid and penalty methods.
00880504.name: Initial and Boundary Problems in Finite Elements Method

00880751.about: Dynamical systems.  Definition of the control problem.  Functional variational approach. Conditions of optimality, boundary conditions.  Maximum principle.  Dynamic programming. Methods for trajectory optimization.
00880751.name: Optimal Control in Flight Systems 1

00880759.about: Review of proportional navigation, miss distance computation using the adjoint method, optimal evasive strategies from homing missiles, optimization of guidance laws for homing missiles, derivation of advanced guidance laws for homing missiles, deerivation of advanced guidance laws using differential games theory. learning Outcomes: On successful competition of this course, students should beable to: 1. Apply missile guidance laws in 2D and 3D engagements. 2. Analyze the miss distance performance of linear guidance laws using the adjoint methods. 3. Derive optimal control based linear guidance laws. 4. Derive linear quadratic and bounded control diffe rential games based linear guidance laws. 5. Synthesize optimal evasion strategies from homing missiles, using optimal control and the adjoint method. 6. Reduce the order of a linear guidance problem using the terminal projection transformation.
00880759.name: Advanced Topics in Missile Guidance Theory

00880780.about: Linear stability of free shear layers, boundary layers and buoyancy - induced boundary layers,  introduction to nonlinear analysis,multiple scales techniques, wave-wave interaction, secondary instability, critical layers, convective and absolute instability, local and global instability.
00880780.name: Hydrodynamic and Thermal Stability of Boundary Layers

00880785.about: (without a thesis). The student is expected to perform an independent research work of about 250 hours under the supervision of a faculty member. The project may also be based on a critical literature survey or synthesis between various areas.
00880785.name: Final Project

00880792.about: Linear operator theory, System norms, Generalized plant descriptions, Linear fractional transformations, KYP lemma, Controller syntheis (H2 and H00 synthesis), Semi-definite programming and linear matrix inequalities, parametric and dynamic uncertainty modelling,small gain theorem, robust stability and robust performance, structured singular value, U-syntheis, D - K interation. Learning Outcom,es: At the end of the course the student will beable to: 1. Explain the motivation for robust conrol. 2. Compute numerically and analytically system norms for dynamical systems. 3. Build generalized plant descriptions for systems with exogenous inputs and contro lled variables. 4. determine the stability margins of feedback systems. 5. Apply the small gain theorem for robustness analysis. 6.Model uncertain dynamical systems. 7. design H2 and Hinf optimal controllers using LMIs and SDPs. 8. Numerically and analytically determine the robust performance and robust stability of a feedback system. 9. Synthesize robust feedback controllers.
00880792.name: Robust Control

00880794.about: Introduction to systems engineering. Basic tools in systems engineering. Modeling and Monte-Carlo simulations of systems. Systems engineering in product life cycle. Support engineerings: reliability and maintainability.
00880794.name: Foundations of Systems Engineering

00880795.about: Principles of classical control theory, designs in time and frequency domains. Introduction to digital control. Designs in state space, Lunberger observer and separation theorem. Random processes, response of linear systems to random signals. Kalman filter.
00880795.name: Control for Systems Engineers

00880796.about: Final project in the ME. Program in systems engineering. Includes team work for system engineering of a product and the teaching ofthe necessary material entailed.
00880796.name: Final Project in Systems Engineering

00880797.about: test and evaluation as the orderly measurement of a system and the objective assessment of the results to help make engineering decisions. the principles and the application of test and evaluation as part of risk mitigation process, to prove, demonstrate and assess the ability of existing, proposed, new or upgraded, capability systems and modifications to satisfy specified technical and operational requirements objectives.
00880797.name: Systems Test and Evaluation

00880900.about: keplerian orbital mechanics. perturbations. the general relative motion problem. impulsive station keeping. linear formation flyingdynamics and control. high-order relative motion. formulation of relative motion using orbital elements. canonical control. centralized.de-centralized formation keeping.low-thrust propulsion for formation flying. applications: sparse-aperture imaging, remote sensing.
00880900.name: Distributed Spacecraft Systems

00940101.about: The course provides an overview of aspects of industrial engineering and management, emphasizing system integration in the design of products and services, layout planning, the design of information systems, management of supply chains and service systems, etc. The course includes an overview of decision making and is accompanied by a project.
00940101.name: Intro.to Industrial Eng. and Management

00940139.about: Modeling of inventory systems for various products, for finite and infinite horizon, under deterministic or stochastic conditions, and with special constraints. Planning multi-echelon inventory systems and supply chains. Models for managing and controlling supplychains.
00940139.name: Manage. Logist. System.

00940142.about: Classification of production systems, graphical and mathematical models for system representation. scheduling in flow shop and job shop environments. Mass production systems and assembly systems. Dynamics of production systems: critical wip, bottleneck productionrate, relation between wip, throughput and lead time. Push versus pull control systems: MRP, MRP 2, Kanban, Conwip, DBR.
00940142.name: Operation of Production Service Systems

00940170.about: the course discusses a variety of industrial engineering methods. the course will teach: systematic analysis of process and their presentation, work measurement, lean, six sigma, agile software development, ergonomics and product design principles. focus will be given to applying various advanced methods including automatic data collection using sensors and data analysis using machine learning algorithms.
00940170.name: Industrial Engineering Methods

00940179.about: class includes visits in various industries and introduction to the different challenges each industry has: e.g. food, plastic, electronics, public sector, non-profit, hospitals, production, call centers, software. in every industry the students will learn the unique challenges for the industrial engineer and will learn to apply the correct tools.
00940179.name: Industrial Engineering in the Field

00940189.about: Groups of students will prepare a design project proposal whose aim is to apply the knowledge and tools studied in previous course work. The project proposal will include a literature review, description of the existing situation and problem, methodology, alternative problem solutions and the potential benefits of the proposed solutions.
00940189.name: Design Project Proposal Development in Ind. Eng.

00940195.about: Students will apply IE and M knowledge and skills in order to implement the preliminary project proposal developed in course (094189) and solve a real-world problem. Student teams will implement an untegrative project relating to IE and M topics, designing a new system (or change an existing system) and including a cost-benefit analysis. The grade will be based on the quality of the solution and the level of knowledge and skill application.
00940195.name: Design Project 1, Industrial Eng.

00940196.about: Students will further develop the project implemented in the Design Projrct 1 course (094195). The course will enable exceptional project teams to extend the project completed in the pre-requisite course. Hence, participation is contingent upon the written approval concurrently. of the project coordinator. The grades in the course will reflect the quality of the solution proposed by the team and the level of implementation of knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course.
00940196.name: Design Project 2, Industrial Eng.

00940197.about: Students will conduct a research project under the supervision of a faculty advisor.  The project may involve any of the following:review of relevent literature, methodological development, data collection and data analysis. Registration requires the approval ofthe faculty advisor.
00940197.name: Semester Research Project

00940198.about: The study of cases in industrial engineering, through the application of relevant techniques.  The cases will be dealt with in two stages: a) presentation and analysis of the problem, and b) survey of possible approaches for a solution. For each case, students will be required to submit  a detailed report, including problem analysis techniques and recommendations.
00940198.name: Case Studies in Industrial Engineering

00940202.about: The course will provide students with basic knowledge and tools for performing data analysis using python. The course will include the following topics: data collection and cleaning, efficient data representations, exploratory data analysis, data visualization, clustering and basic classification methods.
00940202.name: Introduction to Data Analysis in Python

00940204.about: Gathering and processing data in a distributed system must take into consideration the cooperative aspects of the different components in the systems. The goal of this course is to lay the foundations to the theory of distributed systems in which the components in the systems have different goals than the designer of the system.
00940204.name: Distributed Data and Rational Agents

00940210.about: The course gives an introduction to computer technologies and networks, as well as some basic computer science terminology. Topics include: the structure of the computer from the programmer's point of view. Memory organization. OP-code, addressing. Selected topics in modern operating systems, including processes and threads, scheduling problems, semaphores, the critical-section problem and memory-management. Introduction to networks: the seven-layer model of computer networks, basic protocols such as stop-and-wait and go-back-n, TCP.IP and the internet. Computations and computational complexity.
00940210.name: Computer Architecture and Operating Sys.

00940219.about: SOFTWARE DEVELOPMENT METHODS IN LARGE SYSTEMS WITH INTRODUCTION TO DESIGN AND PROGRAMMING IN OBJECT-ORIENTED METHODOLOGY. THE COURSE WILL BE TAUGHT USING THE JAVA PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE.
00940219.name: Software Engineering

00940222.about: THE COURSE INTRODUCES PRINCIPLES AND APPLICATIONS OF MODEL-BASED SYSTEMS ENGINEERING, THE MODERN APPROACH TO ARCHITECTING COMPLEX SYSTEMS INVOLVING HUMANS, HARDWARE AND SOFTWARE USING OPM ISO-19450 STANDARD FOR MODELING AND DESIGNING SYSTEMS. TOPICS: OBJECT, PROCESS, STATE, SYSTEM STRUCTURE, BEHAVIOR AND FUNCTION, BENEFICIARY, ENVIRONMENT, COMPLEXITY MANAGEMENT, TEXTUAL-GRAPHICAL REPRESENTATIONS, STRUCTURAL AND PROCEDURAL RELATIONS.
00940222.name: Specification and Analysis of Information Systems

00940224.about: THE COURSE DEALS WITH FUNDAMENTAL CONCEPTS IN DESIGNING AND ANALYZING DATA STRUCTURES AND ALGORITHMS. TOPICS: SORTING ALGORITHMS, FUNDAMENTAL DATA STRUCTURES: STACK, QUEUE, BINARY TREE DATA STRUCTURES INCLUDING UNIVERSAL HASHING, BASIC GRAPH ALGORITHMS: SEARCHING, SHORTEST PATHS, MINIMUM SPANNING TREE, DYNAMIC PROGRAMING.
00940224.name: Data Structures and Algorithms

00940226.about: the course deals with fundamental concepts in designing and analyzing combinatorial algorithms. topics: sorting algorithms, basic graph algorithms: searching, shortest paths, minimum spanning tree, network flow.
00940226.name: Introduction to Algorithms

00940241.about: The course covers basic topics in relational database management, including design using erd and normalization, querying in sql, and introduction to transaction management. The student will be involved in the design and development of a database.
00940241.name: Database Management

00940288.about: we examine issues in the intersection of law, ethics, and technology that arise from the use of data systems. case studies on subjects such as liability, discrimination, privacy, and content management are used to understand the need for dialog among these disciplines. these case studies will be used to form the foundation of a dialog.
00940288.name: Ethical Issues in Data Responsibility

00940290.about: The grade will be determined based on continuous work during the semester and bi-weekly reports. The lab covers the following topics: data gathering from sensors, load shedding, reading from an input file and partitioning into data strams, data cleaning, cloud computing, nosql databases, map-reduce, and hadoop.
00940290.name: Data Gathering and Management Lab

00940295.about: Methodology and practice of building data analysis systems for large- scale data using statistical tools (e.g., regression) and learning tools (clustering and classification). The map reduce methodology will be used for data analysis, and tools such as search engines and databases will be integrated. Paradigms for visualization of analysis results will be employed.
00940295.name: Data Analysis and Visualization

00940312.about: Methodology of operations research. Distribution problems and the transportation method. Linear programming. Formulating various problems as linear and integer programming models. C.P.M. Maximal flow and other network models. Integer programming and branch and bound method. Dynamic programming.
00940312.name: Deterministic Mod.in Operations Research

00940313.about: Methodology of operations research. Distribution problems and the transportation method. Linear programming. Formulating various problems as linear and integer programming models. C.P.M. Maximal flow and other network models. Integer programming and branch and bound method. Dynamic programming.
00940313.name: Deterministic Models in Oper.Research

00940314.about: This course is concerned with the construction of mathematical models of stochastic systems and includes the basic concepts of the theory of stochastic processes.  The course concentrates on the following topics:  Counting processes (Bernoulli, Poisson Processes), Markov jump Processes.  Markovian queueing processes, etc: Markov chains.  In addition, the course contains an introduction to queueing theory, dealing mainly with single server queues (M.M.1 and M.G.1 models).
00940314.name: Stochastic Models in Oper.Research

00940333.about: Difference and differential equations with constant coefficients, systems of difference and differential equations with constant coefficients, introduction to dynamic programming, introduction to integer programming, totally unimodular systems and their applications, Gomory cut method, Branch and bound method and its applications.
00940333.name: Dynamic Models in Operations Research

00940345.about: BASIC CONCEPTS IN LOGIC, MATHEMATICAL PROVING METHODS. SET THEORY: BASIC DEFINITIONS, RELATIONS, EQUIVALENCE RELATIONS, ORDER RELATIONS, FUNCTIONS, CARDINALS, CANTOR'S DIAGONALIZATION. COMBINATORICS: BASIC COUNTING PRINCIPLES, NEWTON'S BINOMIAL, INCLUSION - EXCLUSION PRINCIPLE, RECURRENCE RELATIONS.
00940345.name: Discrete Mathematics (for I.E)

00940347.about: BASIC CONCEPTS IN LOGIC, MATHEMATICAL PROVING METHODS. SET THEORY: BASIC DEFINITIONS, RELATIONS, EQUIVALENCE RELATIONS, ORDER RELATIONS, FUNCTIONS, CARDINALS, CANTOR'S DIAGONALIZATION. COMBINATORICS: BASIC COUNTING PRINCIPLES, NEWTON'S BINOMIAL, INCLUSION - EXCLUSION PRINCIPLE.
00940347.name: Discrete Mathematics

00940395.about: groups of students will prepare a design project proposal whose aim is to apply the knowledge, techniques, and other tools acquiredin previous course work (including the ability for self-study, cooperation). the proposal will include a literature survey, description of the existing situation and problem, methodology, difficulties, comparison to alternative solutions, and the potential benefits of the proposed solutions.
00940395.name: Design Project Proposal, Info. Systems

00940396.about: teams of students will apply skills from their degree in order to implement the project proposal developed in the preceding course to solve a real-world problem in information systems (in the broad sense). the grade will be based on the quality of the solution (including originality, efficiency,  ease of use), the quality of the presentation, and the level of knowledge and skill demonstrated.
00940396.name: Design Project 1, Information Systems

00940412.about: Probability spaces. Conditional probability. Random variables. Transformation of random variables. Expectations and moments. Discrete and continuous distributions. Vector of random variablrs and their joint distributions. Characteristic functions and limit theorems. Conditional distributions and expectations.
00940412.name: Probability (Advanced)

00940423.about: Descriptive statistics and grafical methods. Point estimation, interval estimation and hypothesis tests. Non-parametric tests. basics of sampling. Linear regression and correlation.
00940423.name: Introduction to Statistics

00940424.about: descriptive statistics and graphical methods. point estimation, confidence intervals and hypothesis tests. chi-square tests for goodness of fit and independence. simple linear regression. statistical analysis using r or python.
00940424.name: Statistics 1

00940481.about: The first part of the course introduces basic concepts of probability theory: basic rules of probability, combinatory, conditional probability, discrete and continuous random variables and the central limit theorem. The second part focuses on statistical inference and includes descriptive statistics, sampling distribution, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, goodness of fit tests, tests of independence, and simple linear regression.
00940481.name: Int.to Probability and Statistics

00940503.about: Theory of consumer behavior and demand. Theory of production and cost. Firm behavior under perfect competition.
00940503.name: Microeconomics 1

00940504.about: Firm behavior under imperfect competition. The theory of distribution under different market structures. General equilibrium and welfare economics.
00940504.name: Microeconomics 2

00940513.about: Input output analysis. Market equilibrium and the dynamics of economic processes. The goods market. The money market and international trade.
00940513.name: Macroeconomics

00940520.about: the course equips the students with relevant tools for effective consultancy to small and midium enterprises , including tools in management, decision making, and financial analysis. the students present case studies, involving them in the process of learning. final project will include a case study withe active involvement in an organization.
00940520.name: Workshop in Smes 1

00940564.about: Present value and future value. Effective vs. stated interest rates. Project evaluation and net present value. Loans and savings. Financial management in inflationary environments. Introduction to risk. The Capital Asset Pricing Model. The financial structure of the firm. Modeigliani-Miller result. An introduction to options and futures.
00940564.name: Introduction to Financial Management

00940569.about: The course introduces financial markets, valuation models, and methods for portfolio selection and risk management. The course starts with equity markets, mean-variance portfolioselection selection, CAPM and APT. Then it reviews derivatives and bond markets with an emphasis on risk management.
00940569.name: Capital Markets and Investments

00940591.about: Supply, demand and market equilibrium, government policy and its effect on the equilibrium. Production, cost function and derivation of the supply curve. Behavior under various market structures: perfect and imperfect competition. The national economy: the national accounts. Determination of national income in a Keynsian model. The interest rate and its effect on investment. Equilibrium in the money market. Money demand and supply. General equilibrium in the commodities and money market. Fiscal and monetary policies.
00940591.name: Introductory Economics

00940594.about: The course covers selected topics in micro and macro economics. the micro topics include consumer and production theory, equilibrium in competitive markets and monopolies, government intervention and international trade. The macro topics are national accounting, the keynesian model, money markets and the IS-LM model.
00940594.name: Principles of Economics for Engineers

00940600.about: SEMINAR IN COGNITIVE SCIENCE. FACULTY MEMBERS WILL DELIVER INTRODUCTORY LECTURES TO COGNITIVE RESEARCH AT THE TECHNION. AMONG THE TOPICS TO BE COVERED: LANGUAGE, VISION, PERCEPTION, ATTENTION, MEMORY, DECISION MAKING, COGNITION AND THE BRAIN AND HUMAN COMPUTER INTERACTION. NOTE: REGISTRATION IS OPEN ONLY TO STUDENTS WHO ARE REGISTERED IN THE COGNITIVE SCIENCE SPECIALIZATION.
00940600.name: SEMINAR IN COGNITIVE SCIENCE

00940700.about: programming in python with emphasis on data processing, analysis and visualization. basic concepts in statistics (mean, median, variance, standard deviation, correlation), clustering algorithms (k-means, hierarchical agglomerative clustering), search (ad hoc retrieval) and ranking (the vector space model, search evaluation), classification (knn and rocchio) collaborative filtering and content-based recommendation.
00940700.name: Introduction to Data Science and Engin.

00940701.about: the student will undertake a research project, supervised by a faculty member. the supervisor, together with the student and the course instructor, will define the project's topic, expected goals and grade metrics. registration is open only for members of the excellence program and subject to approval of the instructor. at the end of the course the student will present his work.
00940701.name: Research Project 1

00940702.about: the student will undertake a research project, supervised by a faculty member. the supervisor, together with the student and the course instructor, will define the project's topic, expected goals and grade metrics. registration is open only for members of the excellence program and subject to approval of the instructor. at the end of the course the student will present his work.
00940702.name: Research Project 2

00940703.about: the student will undertake a research project, supervised by a faculty member. the supervisor, together with the student and the course instructor, will define the project's topic, expected goals and grade metrics. registration is open only for members of the excellence program and subject to approval of the instructor. at the end of the course the student will present his work.
00940703.name: Research Project 3

00940704.about: c programming for those who have learned to program in python. variables and types. control structures. functions. arrays. pointers. dynamic memory management. input and output. structures. system calls
00940704.name: C Programming Workshop

00940815.about: Students will develop and present a business plan for their technology based business idea through weekly instruction and feedback sessions in class, through lectures by experienced entrepreneurs and through mentoring by industry experts. Students will be provided support by the bronica entrepreneurship and innovation center ( beic ).
00940815.name: Business Plan for Commercializing

00940820.about: The cours will emphasize understanding of processes of financial reporting and contents of financial reports, and principles of managerial accounting (pricing) and their main instruments. It will also provide tools for analyzing corporate activity, using integrative company-related information, primarily financial reports.
00940820.name: Introduction to Accounting

00940842.about: Income tax regulations. Tax assessment. Court appeals against assessments. Capital funds and income from capital. Evasion and avoidance. Criminal income tax offenses. Capital gains tax. Withdrawal of capital funds and income from capital. Property tax. Tax on capital appreciation. Inheritance taxes. Stamp tax.
00940842.name: Taxation and Real Estate Rules

00950111.about: The course will provide undrestanding of the principles, technology, design, implementation and control of manufacturing systems. This understanding will help in implementing advanced manufacturing technologies to improve the throughput, profitability and competitivness of manufacturing systems. The technologies discussed will include: numerical control systems, industrial robots, material handling systems (AS.RS and agv's), programmable controllers, computer vision, computer aided design (CAD), computer aided process planning (CAPP), group technology (GT), and flexible manufacturing systems (FMS). problems of integration of these technologies into a c im system will be highlighted.
00950111.name: Manufacturing Systems Design

00950113.about: Total quality management: historical and update methods, defining operational function, quality evaluation methods, demong's 14 principles, customer focused strategy and team structure, operation and training. Self-managed work teams, the learning organization, TQM in logistics, quality cost, benchmarking, ISO-9000, the Malcolm baldridge award, planning and operating maintenance systems (breakdown and preventive).
00950113.name: Quality, Productivity and Maintenance

00950139.about: WE WILL STUDY QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITIVE MODELS FOR PLANNING! MANAGING AND CONTROLLING PROJECTS! INCLUDING THE PROJECT S INITIATIVEPHASE (DECISION TREES! UTILITY THEORY AND PARALLEL CONCEPT DEVELOPMENT)! SCOPE (WBS CONSTRUCTION! PROJECT NETWORK MODELS)! SCHEDULING AND RESOURCE LEVELING. WE WILL ALSO COVER THE PROJECT S BUDGET! RISK MANAGEMENT! CONTROLLING METHODS AND AGILE.
00950139.name: PROJECT MANAGEMANT

00950140.about: THE COURSE TEACHES MODELS FOR PROJECTS  INITIATION, PLANNING, MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL UNDER DETERMINISTIC AND STOCHASTIC CONDITIONS AND VARIOUS CONSTRAINTS. DURING THE COURSE, THE STUDENTS  LEARN TO FORMULATE AND SOLVE PROBLEMS VIA VARIOUS APPROACHES AND TOOLS SUCH AS: LINEAR AND INTEGER MATHEMATICAL PROGRAMMING, DYNAMIC PROGRAMMING, PROBABILISTIC DECISION TREES AND SIMULATION.
00950140.name: Project Planning and Management

00950219.about: IN THIS COURSE YOU WILL LEARN ADVANCED FEATURES OF PYTHON AND JAVA! WRITING TESTS AND DEBUGGING METHODOLOGIES. TOOLS FOR PARALLEL PROGRAMMING AND SOLVING THE RESULTING HURDLES. THE USE OF BASIC LINUX TOOLS AND SUPPORTING SYSTEMS (SUCH AS CONTAINERS) AND CONTINUOUS INTEGRATION SYSTEMS AS NEEDED FOR PRODUCTION GRADE ML SYSTEM.
00950219.name: WRITING SOFTWARE FOR MACHINE LEARNING

00950280.about: review of research in selected topics in machine learning with an emphasis on topics that are relevant for structured data (structured prediction, probabilistic graphical models, deep neural networks with an emphasis on convolutional and recurrent networks). identifying a research problem that can lead to a short research paper. development and implementation of relevant algorithms. real-world data experiments. research will be summarized in a final report.
00950280.name: Project in Machine Learning

00950295.about: complementary topics in linear algebra (inner product spaces, norms, orthonormal bases, eigen-values), matrix decomposition (spectral decomposition theorem, svd), linear systems (gauss elimination process), lest squares, iterative methods (power method), linear programming (simplex method, duality, applications to classification and sparse solutions to linear systems), perturbation theorems for matrix decomposition, introduction to tensors.
00950295.name: Algebraic Methods for Data Science

00950296.about: COMPLEMENTARY TOPICS IN LINEAR ALGEBRA (INNER PRODUCT SPACES, NORMS, ORTHONORMAL BASES, EIGENVALUES AND EIGENVECTORS), MATRIX DECOMPOSITION (SPECTRAL DECOMPOSITION THEOREM, SVD), LINEAR SYSTEMS, LEAST SQUARES, ITERATIVE METHODS FOR SINGULAR VALUE DECOMPOSITION, ITERATIVE METHODS FOR LARGE-SCALE AND SPARSE LEAST SQUARES PROBLEMS, PERTURBATION THEOREMS FOR MATRIX DECOMPOSITION, INTRODUCTION TO TENSORS.
00950296.name: ALGEBRIC METHODS FOR DATA SCIENCE

00950334.about: WE WILL STUDY THEORETICAL AND APPLIED ASPECTS OF SIMULATION IN PARTICULAR MONTE CARLO SIMULATION AND DISCRETE EVENT SIMULATION. THE COURSE WILL INCLUDE THREE MAIN PARTS. THE FIRST PART WILL FOCUS ON GENERATING RANDOM VARIABLES USING THE INVERSION ACCEPTANCE-REJECTION AND COMPOSITION METHODS. WE WILL LEARN HOW TO GENERATE NON-CORRELATED AND CORRELATED NORMAL VARIABLES AS WELL AS HOMOGENOUS AND NON-HOMOGENEOUS POISSON PROCESSES. THE SECOND PART WILL BE DEVOTED TO DISCRETE EVENT SIMULATION AND WILL INCLUDE SIMULATION OF QUEUEING FOR A VARIETY OF SYSTEMS SUCH AS SERVICE, HEALTHCARE! TRANSPORTATION, SYSTEMS! MARKOVIAN CHAINS AND INVENTORY SYSTEMS. WE WIL L LEARN HOW TO CONSTRUCT AND ANALYZE A DISCRETE EVENT SIMULATION MODEL IN PYTHONSIM LOGISTIC, DISTRIBUTION AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT. THE THIRD PART OF THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON VARIANCE REDUCTION TECHNIQUES AND IMPORTANCE SAMPLING.
00950334.name: SIMULATION - MODELING AND ANALYSIS

00950605.about: This course examine if there could be an engineering model that allows the prediction of human behavior in work and training environments. For this purpose, we review the basic experimental methods, the classical experimental findings and the accepted theoreticalapproaches in the social and behavioral science. Reviewed models include those that predict behavior at the group and individual level. We also discuss the possibility of externally modifying human behavior by the use of practice and incentives. The grade will bebased on a test and a final project.
00950605.name: Introduction to Psychology

00950622.about: A CORNERSTONE OF COGNITIVE SCIENCE IS APPLYING NEUROSCIENTIFIC APPROACHES TO INVESTIGATE HOW NEURAL MECHANISMS REALIZE COGNITIVE FUNCTIONS. THIS COURSE WILL INTRODUCE COGNITIVE NEUROSCIENCE NON-INVASIVE TECHNIQUES SUCH AS MRI, EEG, AND BRAIN STIMULATION. IT WILL EXAMINE HOW THESE TECHNIQUES ARE USED TO STUDY COGNITIVE PHENOMENA, E.G., PERCEPTION, LANGUAGE, MEMORY, AND CREATIVITY.
00950622.name: INT. TO COGNITIVE NEUROSCIENCE

00960120.about: Quality assurance (QA) support systems: handbooks, manuals, standards, information systems. Vendor rating. Reliability and maintainability issues. Quality function deployment (QFD). QA in design and configuration control. Waivers. Common human errors and their treatment. Metrology. Environmental stress screening (ESS), and acceptance test procedures (ATP). Economics of quality. Case studies.
00960120.name: Quality Engineering

00960122.about:
