 - raise theoretical and applied research questions that ar e relevant to organizational context.
 - identify conflicts, dilemmas and challenges that employees and organizations are facing and to analyze them from diverse perspectives._
 - apply theoretical conclusions and integrate them in organizational practices.
 - develop practical interventions for dealing with organizational challenges and dilemmas.
00980602.name: BEHAVIOR IN ORGANIZATIONS

00980603.about: Analytical techniques in the behavioral sciences. Topics covered include: causal analysis, the development of propositional frameworks, the measurement of organizational properties, the logic of survey analysis including the use of the elaboration scheme, complexscaling, the use of clustering techniques, techniques for evaluation of social programs.
00980603.name: Data Collection and Research in the Behavioral Sciences

00980610.about: Major topics in human factors and resource management related to the role of human operators in engineering systems. The course reviews basic issues which serve systems engineers in designing products or systems and, in particular, the human ability to absorb process and information. The course presents various approaches to the understanding of psychological processes and their impact on thedesign of engineering systems. The course also deals with organizational structures and their fittness level to different systems.
00980610.name: Human Factors in Techological Systems

00980663.about: in spite of the heterogeneity between consumers some psychological process are shared by most consumers such as impulsive buying and risk avoidance. the class will focus on aspects of consumer behavior such as goal pursuit and automaticity, and will expose the students to research domains and methods in consumer psychology. learning outcomes:at the end of the course the student will be able to 1. use a broad foundation of knowledge across various content areas of consumer psychology. 2. critically evaluate theoretical andempirical aspects of consumer behavior research. 3. summarize and review a research article. 4. lead a discussion related to consume r psychology issues 5. identify research ideas in consumer behavior. 6. develop and plan a consumer behavior research. 7._develop an experimental design, theory development and testing. 8. present research ideas orally and in writing.
00980663.name: Consumer Psychology Seminar

00980666.about:
this course will review advanced topics in cognitive science, broadly defined. topics that will be covered throughout the course: cognitive representations, language and thought, cognition and ai, and cognition and decision making. students will critically reviewand discuss advanced current research in cognitive science, and submit a final seminar paper._
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course students will be able to:
 - describe and discuss the current state of cognitive science research, and how it spans acrosstheories, findings, and models. - skeptically critic cognitive science articles._
 - present academic papers that lead to in-depth s cientific discussion.
00980666.name: ADVANCED COGNITIVE SCIENCES

00980712.about: A systematic approach to project management in organizations, under highly qualified human resources constraints. Awareness and analysis of the connections between knowledge leaders and different missions. Exposure of risks resulting from human resource allocations volume to the same missions, during the preliminary planning stages. The high flexibility of the tools allows for their matching to different content factors and the organization desired culture.
00980712.name: Managing New Product Development Project

00980722.about: This course focuses on advanced and innovative topics in the management of information systems that are not covered in the regular management of information system courses. Each semester, this course will focus on a different set of topics. Winter Semester- Introduction to Machine Learning in Python.
00980722.name: Selected Topics in Management of Information Systems

00980740.about: Types of studies (retrospective, prospective, experimental), types of variables, graphical representations, parametric vs. nonoparametric methods, hypothesis test, two-sample tests (independent and matched samples, continuous variables), confidence intervals, contingency tables, correlations and simple regression.
00980740.name: Statistics for Managers

00980748.about: behavioral economics is the effort to ground theoretic economic assumptions in experimentation of actual human behavior. the first part of the course will introduce participants to research in behavioral economics and the second part will be devoted to the natureand nature of (un)ethical behaviors using the behavioral economics approach. at the end of the course students should be able to:a.identify common judgment and decision making biases. b. understand under which conditions decision making biases and unethical behaviors are most likely to occur. c. get familiar with effective interventions to overcomes biases and to minimize unethical behaviors.
00980748.name: Behavioral Economics and Ethics

00980754.about: WITH AN EMPHASIS ON VENTURE-BACKED START-UPS, THIS COURSE INTRODUCES VARIOUS ASPECTS OF REGULATION AND THE LAW RELATED TO ENTREPRENEURSHIP. ALTHOUGH WE OFTEN CONSIDER REGULATION TO BE A BARRIER TO ENTREPRENEURSHIP, IT CAN ALSO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR BUSINESSES. A SOPHISTICATED ENTREPRENEUR CAN CRAFT A BUSINESS MODEL THAT TAKES ADVANTAGE OF REGULATORY CHANGES. IN THIS COURSE, WE WILL EXAMINE TEST CASES FROM ISRAELI AND US COMPANIES THAT HAVE SUCCESSFULLY CHALLENGED REGULATIONS AND CASES OF COMPANIES THAT IGNORED REGULATIONS AND FACED REPERCUSSIONS AS A RESULT. THE COURSE COVERS REGULATORY FRAMEWORKS THAT EVERY ENTREPRENEUR SHOULD BE FAMILIAR WITH - I NCLUDING LIMITATIONS ON PRIVATE OFFERINGS AND SALES OF SECURITIES TO NON-ACCREDITED INVESTORS, AND THE TAX FRAMEWORK FOR EMPLOYEE EQUITY-BASED COMPENSATION. ADDITIONALLY, THE COURSE EXAMINES THE SYSTEM OF LAWS THAT ENTREPRENEURS AND INVESTORS CREATE FOR THEMSELVES THROUGH PRIVATE ORDERING (FOUNDERS' AGREEMENTS, INVESTMENT CONTRACTS, AND ARTICLES OF INCORPORATION), AS WELL AS HOW CORPORATE GOVERNANCE DEVELOPS OVER THE COURSE OF THE COMPANY'S GROWTH STAGES. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL GET: * KNOWLEDGE
00980754.name: SELECTED TOPICS ON ENTREPRENEURSHIP

00980759.about:
THIS COURSE S OVERARCHING OBJECTIVE IS TO FAMILIARIZE STUDENTS WITH THE GLOBAL DISCOURSE AND MINDSET-SHIFT TOWARDS SUSTAINABILITY ALONG, AND AROUND, THE CHAIN OF INVESTMENT (FROM CORPORATE LEVEL THROUGH INVESTORS TO POLICY MAKERS).
 THE COURSE WILL EXAMINE ISSUESWITH CLASSIC ECONOMIC THEORY, WILL GO THROUGH BASIC CONCEPTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS WHICH ADDRESS THESE ISSUES AND WILL COVER PRACTICAL, REAL-LIFE CHANGES AND EMERGING TRENDS HAPPENING RAPIDLY IN MARKETS TODAY AND RESHAPING THE BUSINESS LANDSCAPE.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 AT THE END OF THE COURSE, THE STUDENT WILL HAVE AN OVERARCHING UNDERSTANDING OF GLOBAL AND LOCAL TRENDS IN THE FIELDS OF SU STAINABILITY AND ESG AND THEIR IMPACT ON THEIR VENTURES.
 * THE STUDENT WILL HAVE PRACTICAL KNOWLEDGE ON HOW TO IMPLEMENT ESG CONSIDERATIONS AND MEASUREMENTS INTO THEIR LINE OF BUSINESS.
 * THE STUDENT WILL BE LITERATE IN SUSTAINABILITY CONCEPTS AND DEFINITIONS, AND ABLE TO FOLLOW TRENDS AND DEVELOPMENTS INDEPENDENTLY._
 * THE STUDENT WILL DEVISE A STRATEGY FOR THEIR LINE OF BUSINESS OR UNCOVER A RELEVANT CASE STUDY.
00980759.name: SELECTED TOPICS ON ESG. SUSTAINABILITY

00980760.about: Data collection from human subjects, human perception models, thinking and decision making, human learning and cognition, job satisfaction, work motivation, stress and burnout at work, teamwork, leadership and group processes, interpersonal communication, group decision-making, cooperation vs. conflict, power relationships, organizational culture and climate.
00980760.name: Organizational Behavior

00980761.about: The course provides students with the theoretical basis and design principles of business organizations. This is a macro-level analysis course and will focus on the issues: Organizational structure, processes and organizational environment (this course complements the micro-level analysis course).
00980761.name: Organizational Structures and Processes

00980763.about: Aspects of management in the global, multi-cultural environment, including: cross-cultural differences and their implication on motivational approaches, communication in organizations, negotiation, implementation of change and international mergers and acquisitions. The course includes case studies and experimental learning.
00980763.name: Cross-Cultural Management

00980771.about: The course reviews financial securities markets and their traded securities.  The course focuses on mean-variance analysis application of portfolio management, the capital asset pricing model, markets efficiency and performance evaluation.
00980771.name: Capital Market and Investments

00980772.about: The financial policy of the firm including: financing of investment projects, paying investors, securities issues and compensation of managers.
00980772.name: Corporate Finance

00980782.about: The course focuses on the main strategic issues faced by general managers and senior management teams. Strategic capabilites and the competitive space, the global enviroment and competitors, managing the firm scope and synergism among the business units, dynamic management of strategy and strategic changes, strategic implementation and the role of the board of directors.
00980782.name: Competitive Strategy

00980783.about: Review of major marketing issues from the manager's viewpoint, including:  consumer behavior, market research, segmentation and positioning, issues related to constructing the firm's marketing mix.
00980783.name: Marketing Management

00980788.about: The procedure of identifying and developing a business idea and consolidating it into a working paper. The course  examines information and data, defines the tools constructing all into a pre-feasibility report. Theory and technical systems will be applied to a practical project corresponding to the required standards of a board of directors.
00980788.name: Entrepreneurship and Businessentrep Development

00980803.about:
errors are a recurring fact in the life of organizations and may yield negative or positive consequences. in this course! the causes of errors will be identified and reviewed. new frameworks! strategies and methodologies to deal with errors that prevent the negative consequences of errors while promoting their positive results and learning benefits will be discussed. organizational activitiesrelated to errors will be discussed through a synthesis of the relevant approaches offered by the disciplines of operations management and organizational behavior! focusing on the organizational level of analysis! dynamism and prioritization. 
_learning outcomes: at the end of the course! the students will be able to: 1. explain processes that cause or may cause errors. 2. to plan practical management frameworks for prevention! real-time coping and learning from errors. 3. explain how errors enable learning and processes improvement. 4. explain a variety of organizational performance using what we learn about errors.
00980803.name: WORKSHOP IN LEARNING FROM ERRORS

00980804.about:
students in this course will acquire knowledge and understanding and skills for implementing the learn startup metodology. the goalof this metodology is to identify a relevant business model! without wasting resources. it is the leading methodology worldwiede for managing startup offers a qick and orderly processes for understanding customers.! and defining the startup's business strategy! identifying the business model riskiest assumptions the assumptions! vis-a-vis the cusomer and other validatinghen systematically anditeratively relevant stakeholders! including suppliers and investors. 
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course! studetns will b e able to: 1. identify and implement the first steps needed to advance the startup! in accordance with the  lean startup methodology.
 2.  identify and analyze unmet needs that require a solution as the basis of the startup. 
 3. develop a business model for the startup that will synthesize the needs in search of solutions! potential customers! including first movers! the solutions and business proposition! and the income model of the startup. 
 4.  validate a specific solution with potential customers and users! by conducting inte
00980804.name: THE LEAN STARTUP

00980815.about:
TECHNOLOGY AROUND US IS EVER-CHANGING AND OUR FUTURE IS DEPENDENT ON IT. WE WILL IDENTIFY THE EVOLUTION OF TECHNOLOGY ACROSS THE MAIN AREAS THAT IMPACT THE SOCIAL AND BUSINESS ENVIRONMENT. DURING THE COURSE! EACH GROUP OF STUDENTS WILL THEN FURTHER EVOLVE ONE OF THE AREAS AS PART OF A COLLABORATIVE WORK (IN A GROUP OF  FOUR STUDENTS). THE PURPOSE OF THE COURSE IS FOR EACH GROUP TO PREPARE A RECOMMENDATION BASED ON THE POTENTIAL EVOLUTION IN THIS AREA ON WHICH SHE WORKED.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OFTHE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. ANALYZE THE POTENTIAL EVOLUTION OF THE TECHNOLOGY WORLD IN WHICH THEY ARE EMPLOYED! AND DIVE DEEPER INTO O NE OF THE AREAS AT A LEVEL THAT ENABLES TO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ACTION.
 2. DEVELOP A BUSINESS MINDSET USING TOOLS TO ANALYZE CHANGES AND EVOLUTION IN THE TECHNOLOGICAL WORLD.
 3. PRESENT AN IDEA BASED ON MARKET RESEARCH.
00980815.name: TOPICS ON THE FUTURE OF TECHNOLOGY

00980920.about:
THE COURSE WILL COVER ADVANCED TOPICS RELATED TO THE INTERACTION BETWEEN PEOPLE AND ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (AI) SYSTEMS. IT WILL COVER PROBLEMS THAT ARISE IN SUCH HUMAN-AI INTERACTION, SUCH AS EXPLAINING THE DECISIONS OF AI MODELS, TRUST, COLLABORATION, PERSONALIZATION AND ADAPTATION. THE COURSE WILL INCLUDE DISCUSSION OFPAPERS ADDRESSING THESE RESEARCH QUESTIONS. BOTH COMPUTATIONAL AND ALGORITHMIC ASPECTS OF THE PROBLEMS WILL BE LEARNED, AS WELL AS METHODS RELATED TO THE INTERACTION DESIGN AND COGNITIVE ASPECTS. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 - DESCRIBE A VARIETY OF PROBLEMS STEMMING FROM THE INTERACTION OF AI SYSTEMS WITH PEOPLE.
 - CRITICALLY READ RESEARCH PAPERS IN THE AREA OF HUMAN-AI INTERACTION. - FORMULATE RESEARCH QUESTIONS RELATEDTO HUMAN-AI INTERACTION AND SUGGEST A RESEARCH PLAN.
00980920.name: TOPICS IN HUMAN-AL INTERACTION

00980960.about:
ADVANCED MODELS IN THE MANAGEMENT OF WELL-BEING AND PERFORMANCE OF EMPLOYEES IN ORGANIZATIONS. ISSUES WILL COVER TEMPORAL/STABLE, INDIVIDUAL-LEVEL/MULTI-LEVEL, PREDICTIVE/DESCRIPTIVE, BEHAVIORAL/ATTITUDINAL, AND THEORETICAL/EMPIRICAL RESEARCH REGARDING THE WELL-BEING AND TASK-PERFORMANCE OF EMPLOYEES IN ORGANIZATIONS. THE COURSE RELIES ON QUANTITATIVE TOOLS, RESEARCH PAPERS, AND CLASS DISCUSSION. STUDENTS WILL WRITE A RESEARCH PROJECT/ARTICLE BASED ON THEIR LEARNINGS IN THE COURSE.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO: 1. IDENTIFY AND DEVELOP RESEARCH QUESTIONS AND THEORETICAL FRAMEWORKS TO RESOLVE RESEARCH QUESTION S RELATED TO WELL-BEING AND PERFORMANCE IN ORGANIZATIONS. 
 2. DEVELOP APPROPRIATE EMPIRICAL METHODS TO ADDRESS AND RESOLVE.
 RESEARCH QUESTIONS IN THE AREAS OF PERFORMANCE AND WELL-BEING. 3. GIVE FEEDBACK TO THEIR COLLEAGUES REGARDING THEORIES AND RESEARCH METHODS EXAMINING QUESTIONS OF PERFORMANCE AND WELL-BEING IN ORGANIZATIONS.
00980960.name: JOB PERFORMANCE AND WELL-BEING IN ORGAN.

00990601.about: Topics covered include: allocation of functions between man and machine, the arousal model, creativity in industry, programmed training, the acquisition of skills, new approaches to motivation, environmental factors affecting work, attitudes of managers, the criterion problem, and interviewing as decision process.
00990601.name: Advance Seminar in Psychological Research

00990621.about: The nature of small groups.  Approaches to the study of groups. Individuals and groups.  Group formation and development.  The physical environment of groups.  The personal environment of groups. The social environment. Group composition. Group structure. The task environment - issues, applications and prospects.
00990621.name: Seminar in Group Dynamics

00990624.about: The student will carry out an individual research project on a topic of his.ther choice, with the approval and guidance of the instructor. The topic may relate to secondary analysis of existing data, to a bibliographical paper, to the development of a new methodology, etc.
00990624.name: Research Seminar - Individual

00990635.about: Behavioural-sciences graduate students and guest speakers present their research work. Up-to-date research and crosstalk between the sub-domains represented in the research group: Cognitive psychology and human-factors engineering. Organizational psychology, marketing, quality assurance and organizational strategy. At the end of the course the student will extend his generalknowledge and the research methods, developing critical thinking and getting to know relevant researchers.
00990635.name: Seminar in the Behavioral Sciences

00990745.about: The course addresses selected topics on the entrepreneurship field and from time to time will concentrate on a special chain of subjects to be decided by the assigned teacher.
00990745.name: Selected Topics in Entrepreneurship

00990760.about: Efficient interaction between individuals and organizations requires frequent negotiations.  The course reviews the research literature on negotiations, addressing its practical implications for business negotiation and conflict resolution.
00990760.name: Negotiation Management

00990766.about: leadership models (full range model, contingency and normative models), levels of analysis (organization, group, diadic, leadershipdevelopment, fundamental group processes, symlog theory of group processes, group characteristics and team effectiveness, inter-relationships between leadership and group processes.
00990766.name: Leadership and Group Processes

00990772.about: The course focuses on advanced topics in accounting which are not studied in the other courses.  Each semester focuses on a different topic.
00990772.name: Selected Topics in Accounting

00990777.about: hands on experience and coaching in developing and presenting a business plan for a technion patent in collaboration with the inventor. classes will be conducted by industry experts. students will present their business plan to vc managers.
00990777.name: Project in Entrepreneurship

00990787.about: The course addresses theoretical and practical marketing issues, as determined by the lecturer.  It enables focusing on state-of-the-art questions of interest such as: consumer behaviour, international marketing, new product marketing, service marketing and marketing quantitative models.
00990787.name: Selected Topics in Marketing 1

00990792.about: characterizing the corporate innovation process, venture capital funds, public sector enterprises and academia. methods for encouraging innovation, assessment, evaluation and selection of innovative ideas. preparing technical proposals and organizing innovation activities.
00990792.name: Managing the Innovation Process

00990793.about: the course addresses one of the most profound decisions for new ventures:which market(s) to focus on. students will learn how to identify,evaluate and prioritize market opportunities for an innovative technology, and apply it on real startups,to set a promising strategic focus. the three-step methodology is based on hundreds of cases. learning outcomes:at the end of the course the student will know to identifying different applications and customers for innovative technoligies. evaluating the value creation potential of amarket opportunity. evaluating the challenges in capturing value for each market opportunity. setting a promising strategic focus. u nderstanding how to balance between focus and flexibility in new ventures. understanding the complementing nature and the added value of the tools learned in this course to other well-known business tools that are taught in other courses.
00990793.name: Market Opportunity for Innovative Tech

00990794.about: marketing is a crucial component of every organization's operations. during our course, we are going to examine changes and trends in the field and deepen our knowledge in digital marketing. we will analyze how big brands are utilizing digital marketing tools while facing challenges and exploiting opportunities. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know to play digitalmarketing activities. to measure effectiveness of digital campaigns. depict challenges in digital marketing. identify marketing opportunities in paid and organic search results. understand how to effectively operate in social networks. find the resources for conti nuous update and learning of future trends.
00990794.name: Issues in Current Marketing

00990860.about: Topics: global, managing export management. Out-sourcing and licensing, international joint ventures, knowledge management, global coordination and control, configuring and implementing global strategy.
00990860.name: Managing in the Global Economy

01040000.about: a rapid introduction to integration in one and several variables. solving ode with constant coefficients. the chain rule in severalvariables. line and surface integrals of the first and second types. theorems of green, gauss and stokes. conservative vector fields. (the course is designed exclusively for the students of the math.-physics study track in order to provide them with the mathematical background needed for the first year courses in physics.
01040000.name: MATHEMATICAL PREPAREDNESS FOR PHYSICS

01040001.about: A quick overview of integration in one, two or three variables. line and surface integrals of type one and two. Green gauss and stokes theorems. conservative vector fields. (Designed for the mathematics-physics program to enable the early study of physics courses).
01040001.name: Methods in Integration

01040002.about: truth tables, tautologies. sets, set operations, logic operations and their connections. the power set, relations. functions and their properties, their composition and inverse. permutations, even and odd. equivalence relations, finite and infinite order relations. denumerable sets, cantor's theorem, rational and irrational numbers. the infinite decimal representation as an example of a limit. induction. hall's theorem and the pigeonhole principle.
01040002.name: Basic Concepts in Mathematics

01040003.about: The real numbers as a complete ordered field, infinite sequences of real numbers, real valued functions of a single real variable: limits and continuity, continuity on a closed interval, monotonic functions, inverse functions, differentiability and the fundamental theorem of differential calculus, Taylor's theorem, L'Hopital's rule, curve tracing, elementary, functions, methods of integration, definite integrals, integrable functions, fundamental theorems of integral calculus, improper integrals. Sequences and numerical infinite series, power series.
01040003.name: Differential and Integral Calculus 1

01040004.about: The n-dimensional Euclidean space RN, real valued functions on RN: limits, continuity and differentiability, the chain rule and thedirectional derivative, the gradient and its properties, implicit functions and inverse mappings, extremal problems and Lagrange multipliers, multiple integration:  definition, applications and techniques, the Jacobian and change of variables. Vector analysis:  line integrals and surface integrals, GREEN's, stokes' and Gauss' formulas.
01040004.name: Differential and Integral Calculus 2

01040012.about: The real numbers. Infinite sequences of real numbers. Real functions of one variable: limits, continuity, continuity on a closed interval, monotonic functions and inverse functions. Differentiability and the main theorem of the differential calculus. The taylor theorem, the l'hopital rule and study of the behavior of a function. the antiderivative and methods of integration. The definite integral and its properties. Integrable functions. The principle theorems of the integral calculus. Improper integrals. Series of numbers, sequences of functions, series of functions and power series. Remark: 104012 differs from 104010 in emphasis on theoretical aspect s.
01040012.name: Differential and Integral Calculus 1T

01040013.about: General term series, functions series, power series. Functions of several variables, basic differential calculus of such functions.Sequences and series of functions, power series. Taylor's formula, local and global extrema, implicit functions, transformations inrn. Multiple integrals, line integrals, surface integrals, vector valculus.
01040013.name: Differential and Integral Calculus 2T

01040016.about: Fields. Complex numbers. Matrices. Linear equations - solution by elimination. Invertible matrices. Determinants. Linear spaces: basis and dimensions. Linear transformations: representation by matrices, similarity, characteristic values, diagonalization. Cayley-Hamilton theorem. Minimal polynomial. Jordan Normal Form. Inner product spaces. Gram-Schmidt process. Unitary and Hermitian transformations. Quadratic forms. Symmetric matrices.
01040016.name: Algebra 1/Extended

01040018.about: The final grade will be determined by weekly quizzez, one midterm exam and a final exam. The real numbers. Infinite sequences of real numbers. Real functions of one variable: limits, continuity, continuity on a closed interval, monotonic functions and inverse functions. Differentiability and the main theorem of the differential calculus. The Taylor theorem, the l'Hopital rule and study of thebehavior of a function. The antiderivative and methods of integration. The definite integral and its properties. Integrable functions. The principle theorems of the integral calculus. Improper integrals. Series of numbers, sequences of functions, series of functio ns and power series. In the course there is a greater emphasis on theory and applications than in 104003.
01040018.name: Differential and Integral Calculus 1M

01040019.about: Fields, complex numbers, Polynomials. Systems of linear equations and matrices. Gauss elimination. Determinats. Vector spaces, spanning sets, linear independence. Basis and dimension. The rank of a matrix. Invertible matrices. linear transformation, the kernel and the image of a linear transformation. Marix representation of a linear operator and change of basis. Similar matrices. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors. Diagonizable matrices.
01040019.name: Linear Algebra M

01040022.about: Function of several variables, basic differential calculus of such functions. Multiple integrals, line integrals, surface integrals, vector calculus. Vectors in r2 and r3. Scalar product, vector product and mixed product. Additional topics in differential calculus: Taylor's formula, local and global extrema, implicit functions, transformations in rn.
01040022.name: Differential and Integral Calculus 2M

01040030.about: Fourier series: orthonormal series of piecewise continuous functions. Gram-Schmidt orthonormalization. Bessel's inequality. Completeness and closure. The Weierstrass approximation theorems. Convergence of Fourier series. Partial Differential equations:  introduction, the Cauchy problem, characteristic lines and canonical forms, the wave equation, the Sturm-Liouville problem, the heat equation, the Laplace equation, maximum and minimum principles for harmonic functions, the Poisson integral.
01040030.name: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations

01040031.about: the real numbers, limits of sequences and of single variable functions, continuity and uniform continuity, the derivative and its basic properties, taylor series and its applications, investigation of functions.
01040031.name: Calculus 1M

01040032.about: the indefinite integral, methods of integrations, riemann's integral, generalized integrals, infinite series of numbers and of functions, uniform convergence, multivariate functions, continuity, partial derivatives, differentibility, commutativity of integration and differentiation, double integrals, claculating area.
01040032.name: Calculus 2M

01040033.about: vectors, planes, straight lines, surfaces and curves in space, triple integrals, line integrals, green's theorem, 2-d conserving fields, including the singular case. surface integrals, gauss' theorm. extrema of multivariate functions, with and without constraints.
01040033.name: Vector Analysis

01040035.about: indefinite and definite integrals, ordinary differential equations of first order, the existence and uniqueness theorem, linear differential equations of order n, stability, systems of linear equations. generalized integrals, series of numbers, series of functions and uniform convergence, solving ode's using power series.
01040035.name: Ordinary Dif.Equations and Calculus 2H

01040036.about: the real numbers. infinite sequences, subsequences (including bolzano-weierstrass theorem). real function of one variable: limits and continuity, continuous functions on a closed interval (weierstrass theorems, intermediate value theorem), monotone functions and invertible functions. differentiability and the main theorems of differential calculus: the theorems of fermat, rolle, lagrange and cauchy. l'hopital s rule, taylor s theorem, analyzing functions. primitive and methods of integration, definite integral and its properties, integrable functions, the fundamental theorem of calculus, improper integral. numerical series. remark: in this course there  is a greater emphasis on theory and applications than in 104018.
01040036.name: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS 1T

01040038.about: methods for solving systems of linear equations: norms of vectors and matrices, iterative methods. inner product spaces: cauchy-schwarz inequality, orthogonal complement and gram-schmidt process, orthogonal projections, orthonormal bases, bessel inequality, qr decomposition. operators in inner product spaces: linear functionals, riesz theorem and the adjoint operator, normal operators, self-adjoint operators, unitary operators, positive operators. spectral decomposition theorem, orthogonal diagonalization, jordan normal form, polar decomposition theorem, svd decomposition, cholesky decomposition. min-max theorem and rayleigh quotient. bilinear and quad ratic forms, polarization identity, classification of quadratic forms over the reals: matrix congruence, sylvester's law of inertia. tensor calculus.
01040038.name: ALGEBRA 2M

01040041.about: The final grade will be determined by weekly quizzez, one midterm exam and a final exam. The real numbers. Infinite sequences of real numbers. Real functions of one variable: limits, continuity, continuity on a closed interval, monotonic functions and inverse functions. Differentiability and the main theorem of the differential calculus. The Taylor theorem, the l'Hopital rule and study of thebehavior of a function. The antiderivative and methods of integration. The definite integral and its properties. Integrable functions. The principle theorems of the integral calculus. Improper integrals. Series of numbers, sequences of functions, series of functio ns and power series. In the course there is a greater emphasis on theory and applications than in 104003.
01040041.name: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS 1M1

01040042.about: The final grade will be determined by weekly quizzez, one midterm exam and a final exam. The real numbers. Infinite sequences of real numbers. Real functions of one variable: limits, continuity, continuity on a closed interval, monotonic functions and inverse functions. Differentiability and the main theorem of the differential calculus. The Taylor theorem, the l'Hopital rule and study of thebehavior of a function. The antiderivative and methods of integration. The definite integral and its properties. Integrable functions. The principle theorems of the integral calculus. Improper integrals. Series of numbers, sequences of functions, series of functio ns and power series. In the course there is a greater emphasis on theory and applications than in 104003.
01040042.name: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS 1M2

01040043.about: Function of several variables, basic differential calculus of such functions. Multiple integrals, line integrals, surface integrals, vector calculus. Vectors in r2 and r3. Scalar product, vector product and mixed product. Additional topics in differential calculus: Taylor's formula, local and global extrema, implicit functions, transformations in rn.
01040043.name: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS 2M1

01040044.about: Function of several variables, basic differential calculus of such functions. Multiple integrals, line integrals, surface integrals, vector calculus. Vectors in r2 and r3. Scalar product, vector product and mixed product. Additional topics in differential calculus: Taylor's formula, local and global extrema, implicit functions, transformations in rn.
01040044.name: DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS 2M2

01040066.about: fields: definition and examples, finite fields (modulo p), complex numbers and polynomials in complex numbers, matrices and elementary arithmetic operations with matrices, elementary line operations and elementary matrices, row reduction. systems of linear equations, linear spaces and subspaces, the subspace spanned by a set of vectors and linear independence, basis and dimension of a vector space, invertible matrices, change of basis and transformation matrix between two bases, linear transformations, representative matrix of a linear transformation and matrix similarity, determinants, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, diagonalization of operators and mat rices
01040066.name: Algebra a

01040112.about: reflections and rotations in the plane and in euclidean space, the group of rigid motions in the plane and in space. the structure of the orthogonal group o(3) and the unitary group u(2). infinitesimal generators of rotations, lie algebra. laplacian isometry groups, introduction to spherical geometry, hyperbolic geometry and lorentzian geometry.
01040112.name: Geometry and Symmetry

01040119.about: The project is intended for research-oriented students.  The student will have to study a subject and.or participate in the research of a faculty member.  A summary of the work will be submitted after completion of the project.
01040119.name: Project in Applied Mathematics

01040122.about: Complex numbers, analytic functions, conformal mappings, complex integration, Cauchy's theorem, Cauchy's formula, the maximum principles, the argument principle, the calculus of residues, harmonic functions, Taylor and Laurent series.
01040122.name: Complex Function Theory 1

01040131.about: Introduction. Applications of ordinary differential equations (ODE). First order ODE: separation of variables, linear, ad hoc methods. Existence and uniqueness theorem for initial value problems. Second order linear ODE: basis of solutions, Wronskian, equations with constant coefficients, inhomogeneous equations, comparison of coefficients, variation of parameters. Systems of equations, inhomogeneous systems. Basic qualitative theory: the concept of stability, phase plane, power series methods. Laplace transforms, existence and applications.
01040131.name: Ordinary Differential Equations/H

01040134.about: Properties of integers, equivalence relations, groups, sub-groups, cyclic groups, normal sub-groups, Lagrange's theorem, quotient groups, the homomorphisms theorems, rings and fields:  definition and examples, polynomial rings, the Euclidean algorithm and the g.c.m., zero divisors, integral domains, ideals, quotient rings, and the homomorphism theorem, unique factorization in rings of polynomials over a field.
01040134.name: Modern Algebra H

01040135.about: Introduction, examples and applications of ordinary differential equations (ODES). First-order odes: linear and separable equations, some elementary solution methods, existence and uniqueness for initial problems. Second and higher order linear odes: base, wronskian, constant coefficients, nonhomogeneous odes, method of undetermined coefficients, variation of parameters, systems of odes, nonhomogeneous systems. Introduction to the qualitative theory: stability, phase plane. Power series solutions. in this course theory isemphasised more than in 104131.
01040135.name: Ordinary Differential Equations/T

01040136.about: sequences and series of functions, pointwise convergence and uniform convergence, term-by-term integration and differentiation, domain of convergence of a power series, development in power series of a function. ode: introduction, examples and applications of ode. first order equations: linear equations, separable equations, ad-hoc methods, direction field, existence and uniqueness theorem for an initial value problem, stability. linear equations of order two or more: basis, wronskian, equations with constant coefficients, stability, inhomogeneous equations: comparison of coefficients, variation of parameters. systems of differential equations with ini tial conditions, systems with constant coefficients. foundations of the qualitative theory: stability, phase plane. solution via power series. sturm-liouville theory:  properties of the eigenvalues and the eigenfunctions.
01040136.name: ORDINARY DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS M

01040142.about: Definition and examples. Continuity. The completion theorem, the Baire catedory theorem, the Banach fixed point rheorem, Compactness. Compactness in metric spaces. sequential compactness. Lebesgue number and total boudedness. Local compactness, the Aazela-Ascoli Theorem, the one-point compuctification. Connectedness. Path Connectedness, connected components. Tychonoff's Theorem. Basis, Uryssohn's Lemma and Teitze's Theorem. Compact Hausdorff spaces. Additional topics may include. The Stene-Weierstrass Theorem, Lindeloff'sTheorem, compactifiations.
01040142.name: Int. to Metric and Topological Space

01040144.about: Basic constructions (quotient spaces and gluing, manifolds, traiangulations, etc.) the fundamental group and its uses (e.g. the Brower fixed point theorem). The van-kampen theorem and its uses (e.g. the fundamental groups of surfaces and graphs.) Covering spaces.The classification of surfaces, Euler characteristic. The geometry of surfaces (spherical, euclidean, hyperbolic).
01040144.name: Topology

01040157.about: Review of division of integers, dividion of polynomials. Congruences, the chinese remainder theorem and Gaussian integers. Primitive roots, quadratic reciprocity and other subjects such as: Gauss sums, Jacobi sums. Quadratic fields, cyclotomic fields and Diophantine equations.
01040157.name: Introduction to Number Theory

01040158.about: 1. GROUPS, SUBGROUPS, CYCLIC GROUPS, PERMUTATION GROUPS. 2. NORMAL SUBGROUPS, HOMOMORPHISMS, DIRECT AND SEMIDIRECT PRODUCTS, QUOTIENT GROUPS, ISOMORPHISM THEOREMS. 3. THE STRUCTURE THEOREM FOR FINITELY GENERATED ABELIAN GROUPS. 4. THE ACTION OF A GROUP ON A SET: ORBITS AND STABILIZERS, BURNSIDE'S LEMMA, CLASS EQUATION. P-GROUP AND SYLOW'S THEOREMS. 5. FREE GROUPS, THE SYMMETRIC GROUP, SIMPLE GROUPS AND AUTOMORPHISMS GROUPS.
01040158.name: Introduction to Group Theory

01040165.about: Lebesgue measure, measurable functions, integrable functions and convergence theorems, the relation between the Riemann and Lebesgue integrals, monotone functions and functions of bounded variation, differentiation of monotone functions, absolutely continuous functions, the Riemann-Stieltjes integral, the theorems of Fubini and Tonelli.
01040165.name: Real Functions

01040168.about: THE DETERMINANT'S PROPERTIES AND CALCULATION. THE ADJOINT MATRIX. DIRECT SUMS AND PROJECTIONS. INVARIANT SUBSPACES, QUOTIENT SPACES. THE POLYNOMIAL RING: ROOTS AND FACTORIZATION, EUCLIDEAN ALGORITHM. THE MINIMAL AND CHARACTERISTIC POLYNOMIALS AND THE CAYLEY HAMILTON THEOREM. EXISTENCE AND UNIQUENESS OF THE JORDAN FORM. INNER PRODUCT AND THE CAUCHY SHWARTZ INEQUALITY. ORTHOGONAL BASES AND THE GRAMM-SCHMIDT ALGORITHM. DUALITY, RIESZ THEOREM, THE ADJOINT OPERATOR. SELFADJOINT, UNITARY AND NORMAL OPERATORS. DIAGONALIZATION AND THE SPECTRAL DECOMPOSITION. THE POLAR DECOMPOSITION. BILINEAR AND QUADRATIC FORMS.
01040168.name: Algebra B

01040174.about: Direct sums and matrix representation - revision. The (classical) adjoint matrix. Invariant subspaces and restriction of a linear operator. The minimal polynomial and cayley - hamilton theorem. Primary decomposition theorem. Nilpotent operator and the index of nilpotency. Jordan canonical form and matrix similarity over the field of complex numbers. inner product spaces. Orthogonal complementand gram - Schmidt process. The adjoint of an operator and self adjoint - operator. Orthogonal projections. Unitary operators and isometries. Normal operators. Spectral decomposition and orthogonal diagonalization. Positive definite operators and polar decompositi on. Linear functionals and the dual space. Bilinear forms and quadratic forms. Congruence of matrices. The determinant as a volume form. Additional topics as time permits.
01040174.name: Algebra Bm

01040177.about: Curves in E3 , curvature, radius of  curvature, torsion, Frenet-Serret formulas, surfaces in E3 , the space E3 , curves on surfaces, the first linear element, the second fundamental  form for a surface, geodesics and geodesic curvature, Gaussian curvature, the equations of Gauss and of Codazzi, surfaces of revolution, developable surfaces, W-surfaces.
01040177.name: Differential Geometry

01040185.about: Solving problems from various fields of mathematics.
01040185.name: Seminar for Undergraduates 1

01040186.about: Advanced puzzles in Mathematics will be presented and solved in a variety of topics of mathematics, such as Inequalities, Combinatorics, Number Theory and Game Theory.
01040186.name: Puzzles and Mathematics 1

01040187.about: Advanced puzzles in Mathematics will be presented and solved in a variety of fields of mathematics, such as Polynomials, Combinatorics, Probability and Geometry.
01040187.name: Puzzles Amd Mathematics 2

01040192.about: Model construction. Dimensional analysis. Similarity method. Introduction to perturbation theory. Introduction to the qualitative theory of ordinary differential equations. Stability of linear systems. Second order nonlinear systems. Phase plane. Stability of equilibrium points. Periodical solutions. Bifurcations. Introduction to Fourier series. Discrete Fourier series. Fast Fourier transform. Introduction to spectral methods in sign processing.
01040192.name: Introduction to Applied Mathematics

01040193.about: Examples of optimization problems from the fields of physics, engineering and economics, linear programming, duality,simplex method, one variable minimization, curve fitting:  many variable minimization: the method of steepest descent, Newton's method, restrictedgradient, penalty methods, feasible directions, duality methods.
01040193.name: Optimization Theory

01040195.about: The real number system, functions, limits of sequences and of functions, continuity and uniform continuity, the derivative, Taylor's formula, investigation of functions in Cartesian coordinates, polar coordinates and in parametric representation.
01040195.name: Infinitesimal Calculus 1

01040214.about: Inner product spaces, orthonormal systems, the Gram-Schmidt method, Fourier series, convergence in norm and pointwise convergence of Fourier series, the Fourier transform and its properties, convolutions, applications to partial differential equations, the Laplace transform and its properties, applications to ordinary differential equations and integral equations, Hilbert spaces, L2 spaces and Fourier series, introduction to operators on Hilbert space.
01040214.name: Fourier Series and Integral Transforms

01040215.about: Complex numbers, analytic functions, the Cauchy-Riemann equations, harmonic functions, elementary functions of a complex variable, the integral:  Cauchy's integral theorem, Cauchy's integral formulas and applications, Taylor and Laurent series, singularities, theresidue theorem and its applications, mappings by elementary functions, conformal mappings and applications.
01040215.name: Complex Functions a

01040220.about: Basic concepts for partial equations (PDES) and associated conditions. Solving pdes of first order, the cauchy problem, and characteristic curves. Classification of second-order pdes, and canonical forms. Well-posedness. The one-dimensional wave equation, d'alambert's method. the method of separation of variables and sturm-liouville problem. The heat and wave equations on finite interval. thelaplace and poisson equations. The maximun principle and properties of harmonic functions. Introduction to numerical methods for solving pdes.
01040220.name: Partial Differential Equations/T

01040221.about: Complex numbers, complex functions. Derivatives, analyticity and the cauchy-riemann equations. Harmonic functions, the extended complex plane, conformal mappings. Line integrals, the cauchy and liouville theorems. The cauchy formula for a function and its derivatives. Power series, radius of convergence, laurent series. Zeroes, singular points and their classification. The residuum theorem and calculation of residua. Application to real integrals. The argument theorem and rouche's theorem. The fourier transform and its properties. the inverse transform, the plancharel equality, convolutions and the delta function. applications to pdes. The laplace tran sform, its properties and inversion. applications to signal analysis. the z-transform.
01040221.name: Complex Functions and Integral Transform

01040222.about: Probability spaces, events, axioms of probability. Combinatorics, dependent and independent events, conditional probability, Bayes'theorem. Random variables - continuous and discrete. Distribution functions and density functions. Expectation, variance and highermoments. Classical probability distributions. Chebyshev's inequality. Sums of independent random variables, the weak law of large numbers and an application to Weierstrass' approximation theorem. Random vectors, conditional expectation and the curve of regression. Generating functions. The central limit theorem. Random walks.
01040222.name: Probability Theory

01040223.about: Prerequisites: (104013 or 104014 or 104020 or 104022 or 104281 ) and (104016 or 104171) and (104131 or 104135 or 104285). Introduction to partial differential equations (pdes). Solution of first order equations. Cauchy problem and characteristic curves. classification of pdes and canonical forms. Well posed problems. One-Dimensional wave equation, D'Alembert method. Sturm-Liouville problem, inner product spaces and orthonormal systems, parseval (in)equality. Convergence of classical fourier series, dirichlet theorem, derivation and integration theorems. The method of separation of variables, the heat and wave equations in a finite interval. Laplace and  poisson equations. The maximum principle and properties of harmonic functions. The Green function.
01040223.name: Partial Differen.Equa.and Fourier Series

01040228.about: Basic concepts for partial equations (PDEs) and associated conditions. Solving PDEs of first-order, the Cauchy problem, and the method of characteristic. Classification of second-order PDEs, and canonical forms. Well-posedness. The one-dimensional wave equation, D'alambert's method. Trigonometric Fourier series, Fourier transform applications to ODEs and PDEs, the method of separation of variables and Sturm-Liouville problem. The heat and wave equations on a finite interval. The Laplace and poisson equation. The maximum principle and properties of harmonic functions.
01040228.name: Partial Differential Equations/M

01040250.about: Problems from abstract algebra, linear algebra and combinatorics, where computer aided solutions can be obtained, will be presented. The theoretical background of the problems will be discussed and computers will be used to solve them.
01040250.name: Computer Aided Problem Solving 1

01040252.about: REMARKS: THE COURSE IS INTENDED FOR OUTSTANDING STUDENTS FROM THE THIRD SEMESTER AND ABOVE, STUDYING IN A STUDY TRACK THAT INCLUDESMATHEMATICS. AT MOST THREE OUT OF THE FOUR COURSES 104252,104253,104254,104255, COULD BE  CONSIDERED FOR THE DEGREE. THE COURSE WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH WAYS OF THINKING AND STRATEGIES FOR SOLVING PROBLEMS AND PUZZLES IN A VARIETY OF MATHEMATICAL SUBJECTS: COMBINATORICS, NUMBER THEORY, GEOMETRY, ALGEBRA, COMPLEX NUMBERS, REAL FUNCTIONS, INEQUALITIES, MATHEMATICAL GAMES. THIS IS IN ADDITION TO CONCRETE TOPICS SUCH AS CONTINUED FRACTIONS, PHYSICAL SOLUTIONS, PROBLEMS INVOLVING THE LATTICE OF INTEGERS, CHEBYSHEV POLYNOMIALS , FUNCTIONAL EQUATIONS AND MORE.
01040252.name: PUZZLES AND MATHEMATICS 1

01040255.about: REMARKS: THE COURSE IS INTENDED FOR OUTSTANDING STUDENTS FROM THE THIRD SEMESTER AND ABOVE, STUDYING IN A STUDY TRACK THAT INCLUDESMATHEMATICS. AT MOST THREE OUT OF THE FOUR COURSES 104252,104253,104254,104255, COULD BE  CONSIDERED FOR THE DEGREE. THE COURSE WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH WAYS OF THINKING AND STRATEGIES FOR SOLVING PROBLEMS AND PUZZLES IN A VARIETY OF MATHEMATICAL SUBJECTS: COMBINATORICS, NUMBER THEORY, GEOMETRY, ALGEBRA, COMPLEX NUMBERS, REAL FUNCTIONS, INEQUALITIES, MATHEMATICAL GAMES. THIS IS IN ADDITION TO CONCRETE TOPICS SUCH AS CONTINUED FRACTIONS, PHYSICAL SOLUTIONS, PROBLEMS INVOLVING THE LATTICE OF INTEGERS, CHEBYSHEV POLYNOMIALS , FUNCTIONAL EQUATIONS AND MORE.
01040255.name: PUZZLES AMD MATHEMATICS 4

01040273.about: the stone-weierstrass theorem. hilbert spaces, convex sets and projections, orthonormal systems, the riesz representation theorem and its applications. fourier series: convergence in norm, uniform convergence, convergence theorems of fejer and dirichlet. normed spaces, banach spaces, the algebra of bounded operators, the dual space, compact operators, fredholm s alternative. the spectral theorem for compact selfadjoint operators on a hilbert space and its applications. the maximum-minimum theorem, the functional calculus for compact normal operators. fourier tranforms: the fourier tranform on l1 and on l2, applications of the fourier transform. the lap lace transform, applications of the laplace transform.
01040273.name: INT.TO FUNCTIONAL AND FOURIER ANALYSIS

01040274.about: Introduction: solution of equations of third and fourth degrees by radicals. Composite extensions, algebraic extensions, algebraically closed fields, splitting field of a polynomial. Extensions of embeddings, uniqueness of the root field and of the splitting field of a polynomial. Uniqueness of finite field. Normal extensions, Separable extensions, counting embeddings. Galois extensions and Galois groups. The theorem of the primitive element. The funfamenral theorem of Galois theory. Solvable groups and solvability by radicals. Cyclotomic extensions, realization of abelian groups as Galois groups over the rational number field. Existence of the algebra ic closure of a field, and additional topics: "constructions with straightedge and compass", the Fundamental Theorem on symmetric polynomials, norm, and trace in finite extensions, separability and trace form Kummer theory.
01040274.name: Field Theory

01040276.about: Hilbert spaces, convex sets and projections, orthonormal systems, examples, normal spaces. Bounded operators, adjoint space, Hahn-Banach theorem in Hilbert space, Riesz theorem. Fourier series, Fourier and Laplace transforms, integral operators, min-max, Hilbert-Schmidt-Mercer theorems. Functions of compact operators, Dirichlet problems. Applications.
01040276.name: Introduction to Functional Analysis

01040277.about: Selected topics for the following fields: graph theory (planar graphs, Euler formula, connectivity), topology of surfaces (triangulation, genus), geometry of surfaces (geodesics, minimal surfaces, spherical triangles), group theory (abstract groups, Lagrange theorem, generators).
01040277.name: Topics in Math.for Architecture Students

01040279.about: Construction with straightedge and compasses is moved to "Field Theory" (104278). Additional topics: Division rings and quateruious.
01040279.name: Introduction to Rings and Fields

01040293.about: REVIEW OF SET OPERATIONS. SUPREMUM OF A FAMILY OF SETS, CARDINALS AND THEIR ORDERING. THE CANTOR-BERNSTEIN THEOREM, CANTOR S THEOREM ON THE
01040293.name: Set Theory

01040294.about: 1. numerical linear algebra: direct and iterative methods for solving linear systems, lu and qr decompositions, eigenvalue problems, error analysis and induced matrix norm. 2. dft/fft: discrete fourier transform, fast fourier transform, spectral methods 3. root finding methods 4. finite difference approximations and quadrature methods 5. least squares approximation
01040294.name: INT. TO NUMERICAL ANALYSIS

01040295.about: N-DIMENSIONAL EUCLIDEAN SPACE. CONCEPTS FROM POINT-SET TOPOLOGY, COMPACTNESS, CONNECTEDNESS AND PATH-WISE CONNECTEDNESS. MAPS BETWEEN EUCLIDEAN SPACES, CONTINUITY AND DIFFERENTIABILITY. TAYLOR S FORMULA AND LOCAL EXTREMA. THE INVERSE AND IMPLICIT FUNCTION THEOREMS. CONSTRAINED EXTREMA AND LAGRANGE MULTIPLIERS. EMBEDDED DIFFERENTIABLE MANIFOLDS. CURVES, LENGTH, LINE INTEGRALS. MULTIPLE RIEMANNINTEGRATION, CHANGE OF VARIABLES FORMULA, IMPROPER INTEGRALS. SURFACE AREA AND SURFACE INTEGRAL. FLUX. DIVERGENCE AND ROTOR OPERATORS. GREEN, STOKES AND GAUSS THEOREMS. CONSERVATIVE FIELDS.
01040295.name: Infinitesimal Calculus 3

01040814.about: this course is for computer science students. computer architecture. algorithmic approach to problem solving. basic concepts in thec language. top-down design. structured programming. bottom-up design. debugging. partial and complete correctness proof of programs. measures of algorithm efficiency: time and space complexity. polynomial and exponential complexity. probabilistic analysis of algorithms. randomized algorithms. intractable problems. stack. queue. representations of arithmetic expressions, and implementation oftheir evaluation by stack. recursion and its implementation. branch and bound search. efficient sorting.
01040814.name: Introduction to Computer Science

01040818.about: advanced systems programming: from assembly level to an advanced programming environment. computer architecture: heap, stack. introduction to assembly. compilation and building of multi-file projects. linking and loading. advanced memory management: smart pointers, memory allocation systems. object layout in memory. allocation and deallocation order. resource management. synchronous and asynchronous operations. rendering a page in the browser.
01040818.name: Computer Organization and Programming

01040823.about: the course presents the central issues of modern operating systems, including: processes and threads, scheduling and context switching, cooperation, critical section, semaphores and condition variables, interrupts, memory management, paging, virtual memory, file systems. in the tutorial the students obtain deep knowledge of an advanced operating system.
01040823.name: Operating Systems

01040824.about: advanced c: pointers, structures, dynamic memory management, linked lists, trees. version management. compilation, linking, and using libraries. basic shell commands. python as glue language for system programming. debugging, software testing, automatic testing. introduction to c++: object-oriented programming, abstract data types, types, static and dynamic polymorphism.
01040824.name: Introduction to Systems Programming

01040918.about: emphasis on abstract data structures, selection and designing data structures for efficient solution of given problems. various data structures, their properties, implementations and applications: arrays, stacks, queues, dequeues, various types of lists, search trees, heaps and priority queues, hash-tables. other topics: basic concepts of complexity, garbage collection, memory allocation, internal and external sorting and searching.
01040918.name: Data Structures 1

01040952.about: boolean algebra, the digital model, switching functions, logic gates and functional completeness. the transistor as a switch. combinational and sequential circuits, the synchronous methodology. state machines. floating point. error correction codes. hardware description language. the von neumann machine, instruction set, addressing modes, branches. the stack. routines. traps. pipelined processor, latency vs. throughput. control and data hazards.
01040952.name: Digital Systems and Computer Structure

01060009.about:
THE COURSE DEALS WITH PROPERTIES OF SOBOLEV SPACES OF MAPPINGS TAKING VALUES IN S1! WHICH ARE QUITE DISTINCT FROM THOSE OF STANDARDSOBOLEV SPACES OF SCALAR FUNCTIONS. WE WILL STUDY THE IMPACT OF THE TOPOLOGY OF THE TARGET ON THE RELEVANT SOBOLEV SPACE. AMONG THETOPICS THAT WILL BE STUDIED WE MENTION: THE LIFTING PROBLEM IN THE SPACES W1!P( !S1)! VMO SPACES! DEFINITION OF THE TOPOLOGIC DEGREE FOR SELF MAPS OF S1 IN VMO AND IN FRACTIONAL SOBOLEV SPACES! DENSITY OF SMOOTH MAPS IN SOBOLEV SPACES OF S1-VALUED MAPS! THE STRUCTURE OF THE SPACE W1!1( !S1) AND DISTANCES BETWEEN HOMOTOPY CLASSES IN THIS SPACE! ADDITIONAL TOPICS (AS TIME PERMITS).
_LEARNING OUT COMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDETNS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. KNOW THE ESSENTIAL DIFFERENCES BETWEEN STANDARD SOBOLEV SPACES AND THOSE OF S1-VALUED MAPS. 
 2. BE AWARE THAT NOTIONS LIKE THE DEGREE WHICH ARE CLASSICALLY DEFINED FOR CONTINUOUS MAPS! CAN BE GENERALIZED TO CERTAIN SPACES THAT INCLUDE DISCONTINUOUS MAPS._
 3. COMPREHEND THE ROLE OF THE TOPOLOGY OF BOTH THE DOMAIN AND THE TARGET IN THE THEORY OF SOBOLEV SPACES OF MAPS  FROM A DOMAIN TO A TO A MANIFOLD.
01060009.name: SOBOLEV SPACES OF CIRCLE-VALUED MAPS

01060010.about:
the aim of the course is to expose students from their fifth semester of studies (and are not on academic probation) and beginning graduates, before submission of research proposal,to the variety of contemporary research areas in the faculty.
 the course will consist of weekly lectures by faculty members. registration for the course is conditional on the coordinator's approval. attendance anda weekly assignment are mandatory. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, students will become familiar with current researchareas of faculty members.
01060010.name: Exposure to Research in Mathematics

01060011.about: the project supervisor will define, together with the student, the topic of the project and the goals based on which the grade willbe determined. during the semester there will be supervision and several group meetings. at the end of the semester, the student will submit and present his work. the course is intended for students from their fifth semester with an average of 80 and above and for beginning graduates, before submision of research proposal. learning outcomes: students will experience mathematical research, scientific writing, and presentation. also, in the search and selection of a supervisor and field of research.
01060011.name: Projects in Mathematics 1

01060012.about: research experience under the guidance of a faculty member intended for students interested in an extended research project. registration for the course is conditional on the approval of the supervisor and the course lecturer coordinator. during the semester there will be several group meetings. at the end of the semester, the students will submit and present their work. the course is intended for students from their fifth semester with an average of 80 and above and for beginning graduates, before submission of research proposal. learning outcomes: students will experience mathematical research, scientific writing, and presentation. also, in the searc h and selection of a supervisor and field of research.
01060012.name: Projects in Mathematics 2

01060061.about:
online learning: definition, basic examples, perceptron, littlestone dimension. pac learning: definition, loss functions, erm principle, vc dimension, boosting. metric properties of vc classes. uniform convergence. sample compression schemes, examples, and pac learnability. universal learning.__
 learning outcomes
 at the end of the course the students will know: 1. learn the basic ideas in statistical learning theory. 2. understand the importance of definitions and be able to change the according to applications.____
 3.know guiding algorithmic principles, like compression and boosting 4. be familiar with bridges between learning theory and other are as of math, like metric spaces and probability theory._
01060061.name: Learning Theory

01060062.about:
IN THIS COURSE WE WILL DISCUSS THE QUESTION OF WHETHER IT IS POSSIBLE TO DESIGN RESPONSIBLE ALGORITHMS THAT PROCESS SENSITIVE DATA WHILE AVOIDING THE RISK OF EXPOSING PERSONAL AND SENSITIVE INFORMATION. WE WILL ADDRESS THIS QUESTION FROM A THEORETICAL PERSPECTIVE! FOCUSING ON THE CONCEPT OF DIFFERENTIAL PRIVACY! WHICH OFFERS A FORMAL MATHEMATICAL DEFINITION OF ALGORITHMIC PRIVACY. COURSE CONTENT OVERVIEW: A SYSTEMATIC DEVELOPMENT OF THE DEFINITION OF DIFFERENTIAL PRIVACY AND ITS BASIC PROPERTIES.
 DESIGN AND ANALYSIS OF DIFFERENTIALLY-PRIVATE ALGORITHMS.
 CAN ANY ALGORITHMIC TASK BE SOLVED PRIVATELY. ANALYSIS OF THE COST OF DIFFERENTIAL-PRIVACY IN TERM S OF COMPUTATIONAL AND DATA EFFICIENCY.
 ADDITIONAL SELECTED TOPICS AS DETERMINED BY THE INSTRUCTOR'S DISCRETION.
 THIS IS A THEORETICAL COURSE THAT DEMANDS MATHEMATICAL MATURITY.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. DESIGN AND ANALYSE DIFFERENTIALLY-PRIVATE ALGORITHMS.
 2. COMPUTE BOUNDS ON THE AMOUNT OF DATA NEEDED IN ORDER TO PRESERVE PRIVACY.
 3. PROVE IMPOSSIBILITY RESULTS.
01060062.name: TOPICS IN DATA PRIVACY AND ALGORITHMS

01060100.about: Free groups, subgroups of free groups: Nielsen-Schreier theory, Presentation of groups by generators and relators, Magnus representations, Fox calculus, free products with amalgamations, Reidemeister-Schreier rewriting process, HNN extensions, one relator groups.
01060100.name: Combinatorial Group Theory

01060156.about: Mathematical logic as a formal description of mathematical reasoning and proof. The propositional calculus: The logical connectives, truth tables and propositions. Proof system and the Completeness of this system. The predicate calucles: Formulas, structures, assignments and models. A proof system. Godel's completeness theorem. Categoricity and completeness of theories. Formal number theory: Axiom system for number theory. Nonstandard models of number theory. Godel's incompleteness theorem. Recursivity, decidability, Church's thesis.
01060156.name: Mathematical Logic

01060170.about: Homology of complexes. Cohomology groups. Ext and Tor for rings and algebras. Homological dimension for rings and algebras.
01060170.name: Homological Algebra

01060173.about: Chess-like games, Zermelo's theorem. Two player zero-sum games, the minimax theorem. Normal form games, Nash's theorem. Characteristic function games, the core concept, the Shapley- Bondareva theorem, the Shapley value, bargaining problems, the Nash solution.
01060173.name: Game Theory

01060306.about: definitions and examples. ideals and homomorphisms. solvable and nilpotent lie algebras.engel's theorem. the theorms of lie and cartan. the killing form, semisimple lie algebras.  decomposition into root spaces. root systems.  classification of simple lie algebras over c.
01060306.name: Lie Algebras

01060308.about: basic definitions. classical groups. actions of algebraic groups on varieties. homogeneous spaces and quotients. assigning a lie algebra to an algebraic group. semi simple elements, unipotent elements and the jordan decomposition. commutative groups and diagonalizable groups. nilpotent, unipotent and solvable groups. borel subgroups and parabolic subgroups. flag varieties.
01060308.name: Linear Algebraic Groups

01060309.about: differentiable manifolds and vector fields. definition and examples of lie groups.  flow on manifolds, invariant vector fields, oneparameter subgroups.  the lie algebra of a lie group.  the exponential map and the adjoint respesentation.  homogeneous spaces, liegroups as symmetr y groups.  the fundamental group of a lie group, the simply connected covering group.  haar measure.
01060309.name: Lie Groups

01060349.about:
1. Convergence concepts - convergence in probability, almost sure convergence, weak convergence for probability measures and sub-probability measures.
 2. Kolmogorov's three series theorem, the law of large numbers, applications.
 3. Markov chains.
 4. Ergodic theory.
01060349.name: Advanced Probability

01060350.about: Tensor fields, differential forms, Riemannian manifolds, connections, parallel translation, curvature and torsion, Geodesics: the Hopf-Rinow theorem, Jacobi fields, the Hadamard-Cartan  theorem, submanifolds.
01060350.name: Riemannian Geometry

01060374.about: simplicial complexes,connectivity, fixed point theorems and their use in matching theory, borsuk's theorem and it's use for lower bounds on the chromatic number of graphs, evasiveness of graph properties, topological helly and caratheodory theorems.
01060374.name: Topological Methods in Combinatorics

01060378.about: Abstract measure and integration, regular Borel measures, Lebesgue spaces and function spaces, the Riesz representation theorems, absolute continuity and the Radon-Nikodym theorem, product measures, Fubini's theorem.
01060378.name: Measure Theory

01060380.about: Commutative rigns: ideals, milradical and Jacobson radical. Modles, exact sequences, tensor products, algebras. Quotient rings and quotient modules. Primary decomposition. Intergral extensions of rings, valuations. Chain conditions. Noetherian rings, artinian rings. Discrete valuation rings and Dedekind domains. Completions of rings. Dimension theory.
01060380.name: Modern Algebra 1

01060381.about: Categories and functors, products and coproducts. Universal objects. Fiber products and coproducts. Free groups. Coproducts in the category of groups and in the category of abelian groups. Tensor products. Linear algebra over rings. Simple and primitive rings: Schur's Lemma, Jacobson density theorem, Wedderbruan-Artin theorem. Jacobson radical, semisimple artinian rings. Algebras over fields:finite dimensional central simple algebras and division algebras. Tensor products of algebras. Theorems of Frobenius, Skolem-Noether, Wedderbrun. Double centralizer theorem. Splitting fields. Crosssed products and cyclic algebras. The Brauer group of a field.
01060381.name: Modern Algebra 2

01060383.about: Simplexes and simplicial complexes, simplicial approximation, homotopy groups, simplicial homology and cohomology groups. Applications:  theorems of Hopf, Lefschetz and Brouwer, Cech homology and cohomology groups, singular homology and cohomology.
01060383.name: Algebraic Topology

01060385.about: Study of selected topics in topology.  The aim of the seminar is to introduce the student to reading, understanding and lecturing about mathematical results.
01060385.name: Topics in Topology 2

01060393.about: Linear spaces and operators, matrices, determinants and permanents, expansion theorems, the compound and induced matrices, the Kronecker product, unitary spaces, the characteristic polynomial, pencils of quadratic forms and the characterization of eigenvalues by extremal problems, field of values, inclusion domains for eigenvalues, Gershgorin's theorem, matrix and vector norms, nonnegative matrices, The Perron-Frobenius theorem, doubly stochastic matrices, the Konig-Frobenius theorem and Birkhoff's theorem, the proof of the van der Waerden conjecture for permanents.
01060393.name: Matrix Theory

01060394.about: Extrema of integrals, the Euler-Lagrange equations, applications in geometry and mechanics, second variation, Hamilton-Jacobi theory, problems in optimal control.
01060394.name: Calculus of Variations

01060395.about: Representation of functions by infinite series and products, entire functions, analytic continuation, normal families, the Riemann mapping theorem, the Schwarz-Christoffel transformation, harmonic functions, the Dirichlet problem, harmonic measure, elliptic functions, the monodromy theorem, Picard's theorems.
01060395.name: Function Theory 2

01060396.about: Connectivity, Euler paths and Hamiltonian circuits, trees, bipartite graphs, matchings and covers, Hall's theorem, theorems of Konig, Menger, Dilworth, Ramsey, directed and planar graphs, Kuratowski's theorem, chromatic numbers, groups and graphs,  flows in networks and the maximum flow - minimum cut theorem.
01060396.name: Graph Theory

01060413.about:
Elliptic equations: second order equations, the maximum principle, existence and uniqueness theorems, higher order equations, weak solutions and regularity theorems.
 Hyperbolic equations:  Well-posed problems, the energy integral, existence and uniqueness theorems.
01060413.name: Partial Differential Equations

01060423.about: A selection of topics from combinatorial geometry, including classical results about polygons in the plane and other results obtained by probabilistic methods.
01060423.name: Combinatorical Geometry

01060429.about: 1. Discrete and continuous time martingales. 2. Brownian motion and its properties - continuity, nondifferentiability, distributionof zeros, law of the iterated logarithm, reflection principle. 3. Markov processes and semigroups. Application to stochastic representations of solutions of partial differential equations. 4. Stochastic integrals. 5. Stochastic differential equations.
01060429.name: Stochastic Processes

01060431.about: Riemann surfaces, covering surfaces, functions and differentials on Riemann surfaces. Uniformization theory, groups of Mobius transformations.
01060431.name: Riemann Surfaces

01060433.about: Selected topics in functional analysis and its applications. Spring semester 2017.2018: High Dimensional Convex Geometric Analysis.
01060433.name: Topics in Functional Analysis

01060702.about: 1. Affine algebraic groups, the associated Lie-algebras. Homogeneous spaces, solvable subgroups, Borel subgroups, centralizer of tori, the structure of reductive groups. 2. The irreducible reproduction of semisimple groups over a field with characteristics and bilinear forms. 3. Introduction to the modular reproductive theory.
01060702.name: Selected Topics in Algebra

01060717.about:
SHANNON INFORMATION MEASURES, AND THEIR PROPERTIES. THE INTERPLAY BETWEEN INFORMATION THEORY AND EXTREMAL COMBINATORICS, WITH APPLICATIONS. THE ASYMPTOTIC EQUIPARTITION PROPERTY, AND LOSSLESS COMPRESSION OF DISCRETE STATIONARY SOURCES. SHANNON CAPACITY OF GRAPHS,PROPERTIES, AND BOUNDS. THE METHOD OF TYPES IN COMBINATORICS, WITH APPLICATIONS IN INFORMATION THEORY. THE GENERALIZED INFORMATION MEASURES BY RENYI, AND THE GUESSING PROBLEM. GENERALIZED DIVERGENCE MEASURES WITH APPLICATIONS. 
_LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. FAMILIARITY WITH CLASSICAL AND GENERALIZED INFORMATION MEASURES, TOGETHER WITH THEIR DIVE RSE APPLICATIONS (ESPECIALLY IN COMBINATORICS AND GRAPH THEORY).
 2. FORMULATE NEW PROBLEMS AND TO APPLY THESE MATHEMATICAL TOOLS IN SOLVING THEM.
01060717.name: TOPICS IN INF. THEORY AND COMBINATORICS

01060723.about: Differentiable manifolds, differentiable function and mappings, rank emersions submanifolds, vector field on manifolds, tangent covectors, tensor fields, extention algebras, partitions of unity applications. Exterior differentiation.
01060723.name: Differentiable Manifolds

01060800.about: Selected topics in ergodic theory and its applications.
01060800.name: Topics in Ergodic Theory

01060802.about: Selected topics in representation theory and its applications.
01060802.name: Topics in Representation Theory

01060803.about: Selected topics in geometry and its applications. Spring semester 2017.2018: Hyperbolic Groups
01060803.name: Topics in Geometry

01060860.about: theoretical background and practical techniques involved in writing a compiler, grammars and languages, programming a scanner, top-down parsers with and without backup, simple precedence grammars and their parsers, and other bottom-up recognizers, run-time storage organization, symbol tables, internal forms of the sourse program, semantic routines for block-structured languages storage allocation, error recovery, code of organization, hints to the compiler writer. learning outcomes: 1. the student will be familiar with basic general concepts relating to high-level languages and grammars: top-down.bottom-up parsing, precedence grammars, block-structured  languages, semantics, etc. 2. the student will be familiar with the main technique methods involved in the compilation process: symbol tables, internal forms, storage allocation, optimizations, etc. 3. the student will be prepared to implement all these conceptsin a possible continuation course or high-tech companies by constructing a compiler for a given or new programming language.
01060860.name: Theory of Compilation C

01060926.about: Advanced topics in number theory which will be determined whenever the course is given.
01060926.name: Selected Topics in Number Theory 1

01060927.about: Advanced topics in number theory which will be determined whenever the courss is given.
01060927.name: Selected Topics in Number Theory 2

01060928.about: Advanced topics in combinatorics which will be determined whenever the course is given.
01060928.name: Selected Topics in Combinatorics

01060929.about: Advanced topics in analysis wich will be determined whenever the course is given.
01060929.name: Selected Topics in Analysis

01060933.about: Advanced topics in topology which will be  determined whenever the course is given.
01060933.name: Selected Topics in Topology 2

01060934.about: Advanced topics in algebraic geometry which will be  determined whenever the course is given.
01060934.name: Selected Topics in Algebraic Geometry

01060935.about: Advanced topics in probalility which will be determined whenever the course is given.
01060935.name: Selected Topics in Probability

01060936.about: Selected topics in mathematical analysis, which will be determined whenever the course is given.
01060936.name: Selected Topics in Mathematical Analysis 3.

01060937.about: Selected topics in mathematical analysis. To be determined whenever the course is given.
01060937.name: Selected Topics in Mathematical Analysis 4

01060941.about: Topics in analysis which will be determind whenever the course is given.
01060941.name: Seminar of Analysis

01060942.about: Banach spaces, conjugate spaces, Baire and open mapping theorems, Auerbach theorem, Riesz lemma, Hahn-Banach theorem, reflexivity, weak convergence closed graph theorem, the dual spaces and c(k),, Alaoglu and Krein-Milman theorems, metrizability of weak topologies, Banach algebras, spectrum ideal, holomorphic caculus c(x) algebra, Abelian- Banach algebras, Gelfand mapping.
01060942.name: Functional Analysis

01060944.about: this course is an exploration of the mathematical structures that form the backbone of quantum theory and its application to quantum information. with a curriculum designed to bridge abstract mathematical concepts with the tangible framework of quantum computing and information! students will gain a holistic understanding of the computational and theoretical aspects underpinning this cutting-edge field. the course covers a range of topics that lay the mathematical foundation for understanding quantum states and transformations. it begins with an exploration of hilbert space! qubits! and state vectors to establish the groundwork of quantum mechanics. st udents will gain insights into quantum channels and operations! along with the choi-jamiolkowski isomorphism! which are crucial forunderstanding quantum mathematical representation. the comprehensive study of quantum measurement postulates will pave the way for discussions on the mathematical theory underlying quantum measurements. additionally! students will delve into the mathematical grounding of key quantum communication protocols! such as quantum teleportation and super-dense coding. the curriculum also includes an examination o
01060944.name: QUANTUM FOUNDATIONS

01060960.about: Equations of classical mechanics, Lagrangian and Hamiltonian, symplectic geometry, canonical transformations and generating functions method of Hamilton-Jacobi, integrable systems. Stochastigation and elements of KAM theory.
01060960.name: Dynamical Systems 1 - Hamiltonian Dynamics

01080324.about: Concepts from set theory. Compact sets, perfect and connected sets. Metric spaces. Sequences and series in matric spaces. Closure of a metric space. Continuity, compactness and connectedness. The Riemann-Stieltes integral. Lebesque measure and integral, and onvergence theorems. The Arzela-Ascoli and the Stone-Weierstrass theorems.
01080324.name: Elements of Modern Analysis for Electrical Engineering

01080327.about: Normed spaces and Hilbert spaces. Linear and adjoint operators. Elements of spectral theory in Hilbert spaces and applications.
01080327.name: Functional Analysis for Electrical Engineering

01140014.about: Optics and waves: electromagnetic radiation spectrum, colors, interference, diffraction, standing waves, beats, resonance, geometrical optics, acoustics. Modern physics: particle-duality, photons, atomic structure. Photo-electric effect. Nuclear structure, nuclear radiation, elementary particles. Forces in nature, solid state structure. Temperature, specific heat, change of states of matter, latent heat, ideal gas, vapor pressure, expansion of solids, liquids and gases.
01140014.name: Mechanics and Waves

01140020.about: Experiments in classical mechanics - linear motion, rotation and periodic motion, conservation laws.
01140020.name: Physics Lab. 1M

01140021.about: Experiments on ballistic motion of electrons in electric and magnetic fields, a.c. circuits (damped oscillations, resonance, modulation, non-linear elements),  propagation of sound waves, standing waves.
01140021.name: Physics Lab. 2M

01140030.about: Experiments on ballistic motion of electrons in electric and magnetic fields. a.c. circuits (damped oscillations, resonance, modulation, non-linear elements), propagation of sound waves, standing waves.
01140030.name: Advanced Phys. Lab. 2 Mc

01140032.about: Measurement accuracy and error estimates.  Experiments in classical mechanics:  linear motion, collisions, force and potential energy. Experiments in electricity: motion of electrons in electric and magnetic fields.
01140032.name: Physics Lab. 1H

01140034.about: Experiments with cathode ray tube: free electron motion in electric and magnetic fields, working principle of cathode ray oscilloscope. Simple circuits experiments: DC and AC, floating voltage, transformer, low pass, high pass, band pass filters, Lissajous figures, impedance, resonance RCL circuits, Q factor. Project.
01140034.name: Physics Lab 2Mp

01140035.about: experiments in waves (sound, light, micro) utilizing wave interference, diffraction, polarization for physical quantities measurements. interferometers michelson and mach-zander, 2 slit experiment, waveguide, atomic spectroscopy, bragg scattering.
01140035.name: Physics Lab 3

01140036.about: The principles of statistical mechanics. Random variables. Ensembles (microcanonical, canonical and grand canonical). The laws of thermodynamics.
