Classical statistical mechanics (ideal gas). quantum statistical mechanics (ideal gases of fermions and bosons, blackbody radiation, Bose-Einstein condensation). Mean fiels theory and phase transitions. Thermodynamics potentials and their application (including Maxwell relations and response functions). equations of state, phase transitions, phases. Diagrams and equilibrium between phase. Thermodynamic cycles (Carnot cycle, efficiency).
01140036.name: Statistical and Thermal Physics

01140037.about: Nobel prize experiments in Modern Physics (Photoelectronic effect, Frank-Hertz effect, nuclear magnetic resonance, electron spin resonance), in solid state physics (conductivity, Hall effect, photovoltaic) and nuclear physics.
01140037.name: Physics Lab 4Mh

01140038.about: wave physics expiriments (sound, light and microwave), iterference, diffraction and wave polarization phenomena utilization in different physical quatities measurments. michelson, fizeau and sharing interferometry, two slits experiment, microwave waveguide, atomic optic spectroscopy, acousto-optic effect. project.
01140038.name: Physics Lab. 3Mp

01140051.about: Newtonian mechanics: internal and external forces, conservation of energy, linear momentum, angular momentum, equations of motion, Galilean transformation, accelerated systems. Special theory of relativity: velocity of light and its measurement, relativity principle, Lorentz transformation, proper time, relativistic Doppler effect, relativistic energy and momentum, collisions, creation and decay of particles.
01140051.name: Physics 1

01140052.about: Electricity and magnetism: electrostatics, electric field, Gauss law, electric potential, capacitors and dielectrics, Ohm's Law, RCcircuits, magnetic field, Ampere's Law, Faraday's Law, inductance, magnetic properties of matter, Maxwell's equations. Waves:  mechanical waves, linear chain of oscillators, transverse waves in a string, acoustics in gas or liquid, boundary conditions, standing waves, frequency spectrum, phase and group velocity, interference and diffraction, Bragg scattering, electromagnetic waves in vacuum and in matter, polarization, energy of waves.
01140052.name: Physics 2

01140054.about: Foundations of quantum mechanics: particle properties of waves, wave properties of matter, quantization of radiation and energy, wave functions and the Schrodinger equation, probabilistic approach, solutions of Schrodinger equation for free particle and in the presence of various potentials. Quantum theory of hydrogen atom, many-electron atoms and the periodic table. Solid state: structure ofsolids, free electron model, band structure, conductors, insulators, semiconductors. Nucleus: structure of the nucleus, nuclear forces and binding energy, radiactivity, nuclear reactions, fission and fusion. Fundamental particles: particle and anti-particles, cons ervation laws, classification of particles, fundamental forces in nature.
01140054.name: Physics 3

01140071.about: Classical mechanics:  Newton's laws, dynamics of a particle, Galilean transformation,  non-inertial systems, conservation of energy, linear momentum and angular momentum, many-particle systems, dynamics of rigid bodies, harmonic oscillator, gravitation. Relativistic mechanics: Lorentz transformation of space time and of momentum-energy, velocity transformation, relativistic dynamics, zero-mass particles.
01140071.name: Physics 1M

01140073.about: Particle properties of waves: Black body radiation, photoelectric effect, x-rays radiation, Bragg scattering, Compton effect. Wave properties of particles: De Broglie waves, wave packets, Heisenberg uncertainty principle, Atomic structure, atomic spectra, Bohr model for the atom. Basics of quantum mechanics: The Schrodinger equation, one- dimensional potential well, Harmonic oscillator, tunneling through a potential barrier, particle in a box, degeneracy. Operators and measurements, matrix representation of Quantum Mechanics, Perturbation thepry, the density matrix. The hydrogen atom by Schrodinger, Spin and the Stern Gerlach experiment, Pauli exclusio n principle, atoms with many electrons, the periodic table. Solid state structure, Fermi model for metals, band structure of metalsinsulators and semiconductors, Superconductivity.
01140073.name: Quantum physics for engineering

01140074.about: Newton's laws, Galilean transformation, non-inertial systems, conservation of energy, linear momentum and angular momentum, many-particle systems, dynamics of rigid bodies, forced and damped harmonic oscillator, gravitation and Kepler laws, precession. Relativistic mechanics: lorentz transformation of space-time and momentum-energy. Velocity transformation, relativistic dynamics, photons.

01140075.about: Electrostatics, electric field and electric potential, electric current, fields of a moving charges, magnetic field, electromagnetic induction, Maxwell equation, fields in matter. Introduction to waves, dispersion, reflection and refraction, phase and group velocities, momentum and energy of electromagnetic waves, polarization, interference and diffraction.

01140076.about: Electrostatics - charge and fields, the electric potential, electrical fields around conductors, electric currents, the fields of moving charge, the magnetic field, electromagnetic induction, alternating current circuits, Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic waves, electric fields in matter, magnetic fields in matter.
01140076.name: Physics 2P

01140077.about: Newtonian mechanics: internal and external forces, conservation of energy, linear momentum, angular momentum, equations of motion, galilean transformation, accelerated systems. Special theory of relativity: velocity of light and its measurement, relativity principle, lorentz transformation, proper time, relativistic doppler effect, relativistic energy and momentum, collisions, creation and decay of particles.
01140077.name: Physics 1L

01140078.about: Electrostatics, electric field, Gauss law, electric potential, capacitors and dielectrics, Ohm's law, Kirchoff laws, rc circuits, magnetic field, Ampere's law, Faraday's law, inductance, magnetic properties of matter, Maxwell's equations. optics. Transverse wavesin a string, acoustics in gas or liquid, standing waves. Waves: phase and group velocity, interference and diffraction, bragg scattering, electromagnetic waves in vacuum and in matter, polarization, energy of waves.
01140078.name: Physics 2L

01140081.about: Measurement accuracy and error estimates. Experiments in classical mechanics: linear motion, collisions, force and potential energy, harmonic motion, angular momentum and moment of interia. Experiments in electricity: motion of electrons in electric and magnetic fields, helical motion.
01140081.name: Physics Lab. 1

01140082.about: Experiments in alternating current: charge and discharge of capacitors, growth and decay of current in inductors, measurement of impedance, resonance in RLC circuits. Experiments in wave motion: sound waves, light waves, Bragg scattering with microwaves. Experiments in modern physics: photoelectric effect, spectroscopy, Franck-Hertz effect.
01140082.name: Physics Lab. 2

01140086.about: Harmonic motion, coupled oscillators, normal modes, continuous systems, superposition, traveling and standing waves, dispersion relations, wave packets, phase and group velocity, reflection and transmission, beats and modulation, 2 and 3 Dimensional waves. electromagnetic waves, polarization, interference, Huygen's principle, diffraction gratings, radiation, refractive index, Snell's law. Introduction to quantum mechanics.

01140101.about: Survey of Newtonian mechanics.  Variational principles and Lagrange equations.  Conservation laws.  Central force and the two body problem.  Scattering.  Motion of rigid bodies:  Euler angles, inertia tensor, the gyroscope.  Small oscillations:  vibrational mode as an eigenvalue problem.  Canonical formalism:  Hamiltonian, canonical transformations, Poisson brackets, Lioville theorem. Hamilton-Jacobi equation.
01140101.name: Analytical Mechanics

01140102.about: Principle of relativity. minkowski metric. Four-vector. Special relativitic dynamics. Gravity as geometry: the equivalence principle. Newtonian gravity in spacetime terms. Curved spacetime: local inertial frames. Vectors in curved spacetime. The geodesic equation. Symmetries and conservation laws. Schwarzschild geometry. Gravitational redshift. Gravitational lensing. Collapse and black holes.Cosmology: the big bang.
01140102.name: Space Times and Black Holes

01140208.about: 1. Interferometric measurement and computer-based analysis of wave- fronts. 2. High resolution spectroscopy (fabry-perot). 3. Infra-red fourier spectroscopy. 4. Study of spatial resolution in imaging systems (optical transfer function). 5. Polarized light microscopy. 6. Thermal and magnetic measurements using fibre interferometry. 7. Sagnac effect: optical gyroscope.

01140210.about: Geometrical optics, Fourier theory, diffraction, Fresnel diffraction, Fraunhofer diffraction, interferometry, coherence, lasers, holography.
01140210.name: Optics

01140226.about: Report of faculty staff members on current research in the department.
01140226.name: Report on Research Activity 1

01140227.about: Report of faculty staff members on current research in the department.
01140227.name: Report on Research Activity 2

01140246.about: boundary value solution with green's functions, and with orthogonal basis functions. expansion in multipoles. electrostatics in matter, magnetostatics, magnetic moment, magnetostatics in matter, inductance maxwell's equations, scalar and vectorial potentials, tensorial analysis, relativistics nutation of maxwell's equations, energy and momentum tensor and conservation laws, green's function of the wave equation, em radiation, leinerd-weichert potential, dipole approximation, the action of the em field.
01140246.name: Electromagnetism and Electrodynamics

01140248.about: Intended for medical students only. Prerequisites: Part A of the physics classification exam - mechanics, or an exemption from it. Vectors, Newton's laws of motion, work and energy, circular motion, torque, simple harmonic motion, hydrostatics and hydrodynamics.

01140249.about: Intended for medical students only. Prerequisites: Part B of the physics classification exam - electricity, or an exemption from it. Waves: oscillations, mechanical waves, sound waves. Electricity and magnetism: electrostatics, direct current circuits, magnetism,electromagnetic induction, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves. Modern physics: the principles of quantum mechanics, nuclearphysics, radioactivity, ionizing radiation.
01140249.name: Physics 2R

01140250.about: Two experiments from the following list:  detectors of nuclear radiation, optical coherence, Fabry-Perot interferometer, elastic waves, plasmons, order-disorder transition, Holography 1. etc.

01140251.about: Two experiments from the following list: neutron activation, angular correlations, accelerator, x-ray diffraction, holography 2, CO2 laser, Fourier spectrometer, Fizeau's experiment, critical point of mixtures, P-V-T He-4, superconductivity. ek.

01150203.about: The experimental background of quantum mechanics (photoelectric effect, Bragg scattering , compton scattering, Davisson-Germer experiment, spectral lines, the two slits experiment, Rutherford experiment), uncertainty for waves. Schroedinger's equation in (x,p) space  (related terms: wave packet, probability current, uncertainty principle, group velocity). One dimensional examples (potential well, harmonic oscillator, potential barrier and tunneling, two barriers and two wells, periodic potential). three dimensional problems (central potential, spherical well, three dimensional oscillator, hydrogen atom). Dirac's formalism, evolution of states in the sc hroedinger picture, spin, Stern-Gerlach experiment, identical particles. time-independent theory.
01150203.name: Quantum Physics 1

01150204.about: Schroedinger's and heisenberg's representations. Correspondence with classical dynamics. Angular momentum (spin orbit coupling, fine and hyperfine structure, the Zeeman effect). The periodic table (hund's rules, level occupation), chemical bond and the hydrogen molecule, the helium atom. Dynamics in a magnetic field (Landau levels, the Aharonov-Bohm effect). Scattering theory (including partial waves and the Born approximation). Time-dependent perturbation theory (including the fermi golden rule, absorption and quantum transitions). The semiclassical approximation and the Bohr-Sommerfeld rules. Foundations of quantum mechanics (measurment theory, EPR, Bell).
01150204.name: Quantum Physics 2

01160004.about: short review of accelerators and detectors. nuclear propertis. radioactivity. nuclear reactions. nuclear models. basic properties of quarks and leptons. space-time and internal symmetries and conservation laws. lepton and quark scattering. quarks in hadrons. quantum chromodynamics. weak interactions. electroweak interactions and the standard model. particle physics and cosmology.
01160004.name: Physics of Nuclear and Elementary Particles

01160027.about: Introduction to the Physics of fluid dynamics. The fundamental description of the fluid state and transport in fluids. The dynamicsof fluids and their equations of motion, conservation laws and scale invariants. Instabilities and the emergence of turbulence.
01160027.name: Physics of Fluids

01160028.about: Seminar talks given by the students on most recent discoveries and breakthroughs based on scientific and semi-popular publications.
01160028.name: Seminar on Selected Topics in Physicsw

01160029.about: The basic physics underlying biological cells, Intermolecular forces and the biophysics of the basic building blocks: proteins and membranes. Transport in biological systems, enzymes kinetics and pattern formation. Electrical processes, from ion channels to neurons and neural networks.
01160029.name: Introduction to Biophysics

01160030.about: Seminar talks given by the students on  recent discoveries and breakthroughs based on scientific and semi-popular publications.
01160030.name: Seminar on Selected Topics in Physics (Spring)

01160031.about: Qubits, quantum gates, Deutsch algorithm, Schmidt decomposition, mixed states, quantum operations, entangled states, Grover algorithm, Shor algorithm, quantum key, information and entropy, quantum channel, error correction.
01160031.name: Quantum Information Theory

01160033.about:
basic properties: nuclear properties, the force between nucleons, nuclear models, nuclear decay and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, neutron physics and fission. nuclear astrophysics: cross section, reaction rate, hydrogen burning, helium burning, advanced burning stages, the slow process, the rapid process, nuclear processes during supernova explosion, primordial nucleosynthesis. learning outcomes
 upon completion of this course it is intended that a student will be able to: 1. understand the core concepts of nuclear processes, in particular energy production in stars. 2. write the basic equations of nuclear processes and the relevant constants. 3. w rite and justify the assumptions leading to the equations. 4. solve problems similar to those given in class and homework. 5. present qualitative description of phenomena related to the equations and theories.
01160033.name: Nuclear Astrophysics

01160034.about: historical introduction. discovery of superfluidity and superconductivity, gases in the classical and quantum limits. the de-broglie thermal wavelength,bose-einstein condensation. experimental confirmation of its existence,experimental properties od superfluid 4he,the two fluid model,elementary excitations and the landau criterion for superfluidity,superfluid 4he in rotation. properties of 4he as a macroscopic quantum system,basic electromagnetic and thermodynamic properties of a superconductor, microscopic bcs theory of superconductivity, electrodynamics of superconductors according to london. magnetic flux quantization,pippard s model and the coheren ce length, type i and type ii superconductors,critical currents and magnetic flux dynamics in superconductors,the josephson effect,the josephson junction as a macroscopic quantum device, high temperature superconductivity, the london picture and the ginzur - landua theory of phase transitions. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically read updatedliterature. 2. to design simple experiments. 3. to calculate basic physical properties of microscopic quantum materials.
01160034.name: Introdution to Systems with Macro Quantum Properties

01160035.about: transport properties of quantum solids.  topics: review of tight binding. wannier functions. semiclassical electron dynamics. quantum oscillations. boltzmann equation. linear response theory and kubo formula. onsager relations. landauer formula. anderson localizaton. integer quantum hall effect. topology of the band structure. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically read updated literature. 2. to calculate basic transport properties of condensed quantum materials.
01160035.name: Quantum Theory of Matter 1

01160036.about: introduction and rational for the course nanostructured semiconductors characterization methods of semiconductor nanostructures andquantum structures electronic structures of semiconductor nano and quantum structures doping and carrier statistics in quantum structures transport of charge carriers in semiconductor quantum structures optical properties of quantum structures coherent control ofconfined charge carriers in semiconductor quantum structures learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able:1. to critically read updated literature. 2. to design simple experiments in nanostructures. 3. to calculate optical and electronic properties of nanostructures.
01160036.name: Semiconductor Based Quantum Structures

01160037.about: background and rehash of fundamentals of quantum computing, sources and types of noise in realistic quantum computers, simulation and characterization of noise, approximate quantum computing, approximate quantum algorithms, approaches and algorithms for quantum error correction, fault-tolerant quantum computing, vision for industrialization of the quantum computer learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to program the quantum computers of ibm. 2. to evaluate the effects of noise on quantum computers.
01160037.name: Noisy Quantum Computing

01160040.about: quantum channel, duality between channels and states, completely positive maps quantum error corrections, stabilizer coats, enthropy, cluster states, adiabatic computations, open systems, lindbland equations, toric code, security proofs, tensor networks, topological states, quantum complexity classes. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically readupdated literature. 2. to create simple algorithms of fixing errors in quantum systems. 3. to use the standard tool box of the quantum information theory.
01160040.name: Advanced Quantum Information Theory

01160041.about:
coherence, amplification of radiation in maxwell's equations, gaussiam light beams, orbital angular momentum of light beams, fabry-perot resonator, optical resonators, quantum description of light-matter interaction, rate equations of atomic medium, gain saturation, the laser, multi-mode lasing, ultrashort laser pules and mode-licking.
learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically read updated literature.
 2. to design simple experiments with laser systems.
 3. to calculate physical properties of lasers and their emitted radiation.
01160041.name: Laser Physics and Quantum Optics

01160042.about:
EXOTIC ATOMS ARE BOUND SYSTEMS IN WHICH ONE OR MORE OF THE PARTICLES IS EXOTIC. PRECISION MEASUREMENTS IN THESE SYSTEM ALLOW TO REMOVE OR AMPLIFY CERTAIN EFFECT (E.G. NUCLEAR, WEAK OR ELECTROMAGNETIC PHYSICS) IN COMPARISON WITH ORDINARY SYSTEMS SUCH AS THE HYDROGEN ATOM. IN THIS COURSE WE WILL PRESENT THE STANDARD MODEL, AND SOME OF ITS OPEN PROBLEMS AND QUESTIONS. WE WILL FOCUS ON THE PRECISION FRONTIER, WHICH IS ONE OF THE THREE FRONTIERS IN WHICH THESE QUESTIONS ARE TACKLED (THE OTHERS ARE HIGH ENERGY, AND COSMOLOGY). WE WE WILL FOCUS ON SIMPLE ATOMIC SYSTEMS, ENERGY LEVELS IN HYDROGENIC ATOMS, THE SCHR-DINGER AND DIRAC EQUATIONS, THE FINE AND HYPER FINE STRUCTURE. WE WILL ALSO COVER QUANTUM AND NUCLEAR EFFECTS. SUBSEQUENTLY, EACH STUDENT WILL GIVE A SHORT PRESENTATION ON ONGOING RESEACH IN EXOTIC SYSTEMS SUCH AS: POSITRONIUM, MUONIUM, ANTI-HYDROGEN, ETC.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. CALCULATE THE ENERGY LEVELS OF VARIOUS BOUND SYSTEMS UNDER DIFFERENT APPROXIMATIONS, AND COMPARE WITH EXPERIMENT.
 2. EXPLAIN THE MOTIVATION BEHIND PRECISION MEASUREMENTS IN SIMPLE ORDINARY AND EXOTIC ATOMS._
 3. GET TO KNOW THE ONGOING RESEARCH
01160042.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN EXOTIC ATOMS

01160083.about: introduction to quantum information and light-matter interaction. applications of quantum mechanics in computation, simulations, communication, encryption, and metrology. survey of leading physical implementations, including superconducting qubits, cold ions and atoms, color centers, quantum dots and wells, photons, and mechanical oscillators. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically read updated literature. 2. to design simple optical quantum qubit experiments, of superconductors, of ions and atoms. 3. to calculate basic properties of different physical qubits.
01160083.name: Quantum Technologies

01160095.about:
the course deals with solving complex problems that include a combination of the basic physics topics studied in the first degree in physics! including: mechanics! electricity! and quantum theory. solving the problems is done by analyzing the main processes in the problem! derivation of the scaling relations of the main processes on the variables in the problem! derivation of an approximate analytical solution up to an order of magnitude for the problem! and comparison with observations. the course is a supplement to the first degree studies in physics which focus on the basic topics separatly! and helps to develop the physical understanding required t o solve complex problems encountered in research in physics.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be ableto:
 1 . analyze a complex problem in physics which includes a variety of processes! using the material taught in the basic undergraduate courses in physic.
 2. identify the main processes! to simplify the problem! to derive an approximate analytical solution.
 3. derive a quantitative order of magnitude solution.
01160095.name: ORDER OF MAGNITUDE PHYSICS

01160096.about:
introduction to the standard model of particle physics and the motivation for physics beyond standard model. understanding the general principles in searches for new physics with focus on low energy systems. the relation between fundamental constants and new physics. searching for new interactions (spin independent and spin dependent). very light dark matter searches! from theory to experiment. dipole moments as probes of new physics. atomic parity violation systems as a probe of new physics.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to:
 1. understand the main problems of the standard model of particle physics and the need for new physics beyond it._
 2. know the principles beyond different experimental system which are used to new physics searches in a qualitative and quantitively ways. 
 3. understand the differences between the systems and to connect between a specific setup anda specific extension of the standard model.
 4. know different experimental probes of very light dark matter.
01160096.name: LOW ENERGY PROBES OF NEW PHYSICS

01160105.about: Basic probability theory: combinatorics,conditional probability, Bayes theorem, law of large numbers, density of probability.  Study of typical distributions: binomial, Possion, normal, Chi2 and Briet Wigner and their application in physics.Errors: statistical and systemtic errors,the central limit theorem. Sampling:estimation,method of least squares,maximum likelihood,separation of signal and back- ground in a physics expertment. Interval of confidence,hypothesis testing. Advanced simulation methods. Artificial neural networks. calculation methods using computers: random numbers distributions.
01160105.name: Statistic and Numerical Methods in Physics

01160110.about: Radiative equilibrium of the atmosphere. Thermodynamic properties, vertical motion and convection. Cloud formation. The dynamic equations of motion. The  geostrophic approximation. The thermal wind equation. Atmospheric waves-gravity and mountain waves, Rossby waves. The origin and spectrum of atmospheric turbulence. Aspects of general circulation-fronts, transport of energy and of angular momentum.
01160110.name: Physics of the Atmosphere

01160161.about: the syllabus will be announced at the beginning of the semeter.
01160161.name: Topics in Theoretical Physics 1

01160217.about: topics: lattices and crystals, reciprocal lattice, x-ray diffraction, phonons, bloch's law, nearly-free electron model and bound electron model, electron dynamics, specific heat, metals, semiconductors, magnetism.
01160217.name: Solid State Physics

01160321.about: overview of the cell: components, architecture and dynamics. biomolecular forces and interactions. experimental methods in biophysics: light and electron microscopy, force measurements. force generation and biomechanics. the cytoskeleton: structure, mechanical properties, force generation by polymerization. molecular motors: models,collective behavior of motors, muscle contraction. cell mobility: polymerization-based cell mobility.
01160321.name: Biophysics of the Cell

01160354.about: the solar system and extrasolar planets. basic equation of stellar structure. stellar formation and evolution. white dwarfs, neutron stars and black holes. galaxies: active galactic nuclei: massive black holes. clusters, dark matter and the large scale structure of the universe. the big bang theory:dark energy.

01170001.about: an introduction to the basic principles of string theory. electromagnetism and gravity with compact extra dimensions. relativistic particles. relativistic strings:nambu-goto action,equations of motion, symmetries and conservation laws,light cone variables. quantization of strings:open string and closed string. dirichlet-branes and charges,strings and black holes, duality.

01170004.about: magnetic measurement techniques: magnetization, nuclear or electronic spin resonance and neutron scattering. the relationship between measurable quantities and theoretically calculable correlation functions. the connection between electric measurements and the relevant correlation functions.
01170004.name: Experimental Techniques in Correlated Electron

01170006.about: quantum diffusion - cooperon-diffuson. quantum transport:kubo-landauer-thouless-kohn approach. basic phenomena:sharvin-sharvin aharonov-bohm coherent backscattering, weak localization-universal, conductance fluctuations, negative. magnetoresistance.  anderson localization. interactions and disorder. quasi-particle lifetime-tunnel conductance-density of states anomaly. thermodynamics: persistent currents in normal metals.
01170006.name: Quantum Mesoscopic Physics

01170015.about: Two and many-electron atoms, molecules, atoms in an electromagnetic field, scattering, atomic clocks, laser cooling, magneto-optical trapping, evaporative cooling, Feshbach resonances, Bose-Einstein condensates, the Gross-Pitaevskii and Bogoliubov-de Gennes Equations, the Bogoliubov excitation spectrum, solitons, quantized vortices.
01170015.name: Physics of Atoms and Molecules

01170016.about: Main definitions of plasma parameters and plasma processes. Plasma magneto-hydrodynamics, introduction to kinetic theory of plasmas, introduction to plasma thermodynamics, drift motions of charged particles in plasma, waves in plasma, plasma sources, plasma diagnostics.
01170016.name: Physics of Plasmas

01170018.about: Survey of band theory and phonons.  Electron statistics in semiconductors.  Galvonomagnetic effects.  Cyclotron resonance. Photoconductivity.  Non-homogeneous devices.  P-n junction, metal-semiconductor junction.  High field effects in semiconductors. The Gunn effect and other instabilities.  Applications.
01170018.name: Semiconductor Physics

01170090.about: celestial coordinates: ground, balloon and space-borne experiments. telescopes, instrumentation, detectors, photometry, spectroscopy, polarimetry: x-ray astrophysics, global fitting, statistical methods, high-resolution atomic plasma spectroscopy: radio and millimeterwave astrophysics,bolometers, radio receivers, millimeter-wave polarimetry, noise and signal-to-noise ratio: cosmic microwave background experiments: advanced optics, interferometry, atmospheric turbulence, adaptive optics, image processing in astronomy.
01170090.name: Observational Astrophysics

01170140.about: Groups and subgroups, quotient sets, isomorphism, homomorphism, representations, classification of representations, direct productsand physical examples. Continuous groups, crystal groups, SU(n), Young tableau, tensor operators, Wigner-Eckart theorem and physical applications. Simple Lie algebras, Cartan subalgebra, roots and weights, Dynkin diagrams, examples of physical applications.

01180018.about: Phenomena common to strongly correlatged, bonsons and spins, in condensed matter and cold atom gases. Analysis of models of strong interactions using exact theorems, asymptotic expansions and variational approaches. Macroscopic quantum phenomena such as seen in superfluids, low dimenstional antiferromagnets and strongy correlated metals at low temperatures.
01180018.name: Many-Body Theory

01180052.about: Chiral symmetry and its breaking.  Current algebras.  Quantum chromodynamics and renormalization group.  Unification theories of interactions.  Models in particle physics. Supersymnetry and superstrings.
01180052.name: Elementary Particle Physics 2

01180076.about: This laboratory overlaps Physics Laboratory 7. Two experiments, with further extension and development, to be performed from the following list, provided the experiment was not done in Physics Laboratory 6:  Mossbauer effect.  Half life of an excited nuclear level.  Angular correlations in nuclei.  Hall effect.  NMR and EPR. Measurement of parameters of CO  or He-Ne lasers.  Experiments in holography and advanced optics.
01180076.name: Advanced Laboratory

01180081.about: Field equations and equations of motion in general relativity. Variational principle.  Energy and momentum of the gravitational field.  Classification of Einstein spaces.  Solutions of the field equations.  Gravitational radiation.  Cosmology.  Gravitational collapse and black holes.  Other theories of gravitation.
01180081.name: Theory of Gravitation

01180085.about: Large scale structure and stellar content of galaxies. Dynamics of stellar systems. Disk dynamics and spiral structure. Star clusters. Interstellar matter. Chemical evolution of galaxies. Galaxy formation. Active Galaxies.
01180085.name: Galactic Physics 1

01180090.about: Radiation processes: Bremsstrahlung, Synchrotron, Compton. Interaction of high energy particles with matter. Particle acceleration.Jets. Cosmic rays. Galactic and extragalactic X-ray sources. Gamma-ray sources and Neutrino sources.
01180090.name: High Energy Astrophysics

01180092.about: Differential geometry.  Calculus of forms.  Elements of homology and cohomology.  Bundles.  Holonomy.  Curvature.  Parallel transport. Homotopy groups.  Exact sequences and characteristic classes. Applications:  supersymmetry, anomalies, monopoles, quantum Hall effect.
01180092.name: Geometric Methods in Physics

01180093.about: Theoretical and mathematical concepts in various fields in Physics. Statistical ensembles.  Many body systems and phase transitions.
01180093.name: Topic in Theoretical Physics

01180095.about: I. Geometrical cosmology. 1.The expansion of the universe.  2. Relativistic models. 3.The geometry of the universe - observational implications. II. Physical processes in the early universe. 1.Phase transition.  2.Nucleosynthesis. 3.Cosmic background radiation. III. Large scale structure. 1.Gravitational instability.  2.Galaxy formation.
01180095.name: Cosmology

01180101.about: Bosonic string theory. Conformal field theory, quantization of the Bosonic string, perturbation theory, scattering amplitudes, compactification, T-duality, Dirichlet-branes.
01180101.name: Introduction to String Theory 1

01180102.about: Superstring theories, quantization and spectrum of superstrings, supersymmetry, Calabi-Yau spaces, supergravity theories, string theory beyond perturbation theory, M theory.
01180102.name: Introduction to String Theory 2

01180106.about: The syllabus will be given at the beginning of the semester.
01180106.name: Selected Topics in Mathematical Metods in Elementary Particle Physics

01180107.about: The syllabus will be given at the beginning of the semester.
01180107.name: Selected Topics in Quantum Field Theory

01180111.about: The syllabus will be given at the beginning of the semester
01180111.name: Selected Topics in Astrophysics

01180114.about: the purpose of this course is to show how the same notions appear in different areas of physics.
01180114.name: Selected Topics in Theoretical Physics

01180115.about: Topics in stellar evolution, stellar pulsation, stellar rotation, the physics of accretion, close binary stars.
01180115.name: Advanced Topics in Stellar Physics

01180116.about: Structure of the interstellar medium. Ionization processes. Heating and cooling processes. Emission line and continuum diagnostics.Absorption lines. Interstellar dust. Gas dynamics. Molecular clouds and star formation.
01180116.name: Physical Processes in the Interstellar Medium

01180117.about: Electric susceptibility, atomic and ionic polarizability,the Kramers- Kronig relations, electromagnetic waves in anisotropic crystals, the index ellipsoid, introduction to nonlinear optics, second-order nonlinearities, wave propagation in nonlinear media, second harmonic generation, phase matching, parametric amplification and oscillation, frequency up-conversion, electro-optic effect, third order nonlinearities, optical Kerr effect, four wave mixing, stimulated processes,phase conjugation, spatial and temporal solitons, vector and composite solitons,photorefractive nonlinear optics,holographic data storage.
01180117.name: Nonlinear Optics and Materials

01180121.about: The fundamental physical quantities describing a star.  Basic equations of stellar structure. Stellar types: from main sequence to white dwarts and neutron stars, mass loss, stellar and planet formation. Stellar pulsation and rotation. Tidal force. Mass transfer.Accretion disks and jets.
01180121.name: Stellar Physics

01180122.about: Dirac and Klein-Gordon equations, interactions of a particle in electro-magnetic fields, spin, scattering, perturbation theory and Feynman graphs, second quantization, quantization of the electromagnetic field, Dirac and Klein-Gordon fields.
01180122.name: Quantum Mechanics 3

01180123.about: Fundamental interactions and experimental methods in particle physics, T, P, C and CP symmetry, SU ( N ) symmetry, quark model, hadron spectroscopy, decay rates, the electroweak Standard Model, strong interactions - QCD, grand unitication problems.
01180123.name: Introduction to Paticle Physics

01180126.about: Physical conditions of astrophysical systems. Thermodynamic processes: equations of state, degeneracy, ionization and recombination. Radiative processes: emission and absorption of continuum,scattering,equation of radiative transfer,synchrotron emission,spectral lines (in absorption and emission), fluids and plasma dynamics: ideal fluids, viscosity, sound waves and supersonic flows, shock waves and explosions, hydrodynamical Instabilities, hot and cold plasma, magneto-hydrodynamics.Alfen waves.
01180126.name: Astrophysical Processes

01180129.about: (1) Review of principles and background (2) Equilibrium Statistical Mechanics of interacting particles: van der Waals fluid, Virialexpansion. Lattice models and magnetism. Mean field theory. Statistical field theory. (3) Non-Equilibrium statistical Mechanics: Dissipative dynamics and the approach equilibrium. Linear response theory.
01180129.name: Statistical Mechanics 2

01180130.about: Review of the special theory of relativity.  Postulates of the general theory of relativity:  principle of covariance and principleof equivalence.  Tensors. Riemannian geometry.  Parallel displacement and covariant differentiation.  Geodesics.  Riemann tensor.Curved space and flat space.  Field equations.  Equations of motion. Schwartzchild solution.  Comparison with observation.  Concepts of relativistic cosmology.
01180130.name: Introduction to General Relativity

01180132.about: Renormalization, renormalization-group equation and its applications. Path integrals.  Gauge theories and applications.
01180132.name: Quantum Field Theory 1

01180133.about: This course continues Quantum Field Theory 1:  Renormalization, gauge fields and Yang-Mills theories.  Introduction to QCD.  Field theories on a lattice.  Symmetry breaking and introduction to supersymmetry.
01180133.name: Quantum Field Theory 2

01180137.about: Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) - Properties of the quantum vacuum: Spontaneous emission, Casimir and Unruh effect - particle creation. Quantum optics - two-level systems coupled to classical light (Bloch, Rabi- Ramsey). Three-level systems (optical pumping, Doppler cooling, slow light). Cavity QED, Cooperative effects (Superradiance, superfluidity, Bose-Einstein condensation).
01180137.name: Quantum Matter Interactions

01180139.about: the sylabus will be given at the beginning of the semester.
01180139.name: Selected Topics in Mathemtical Physics

01180141.about: THE SYLLABUS WILL BE GIVEN AT THE BEGINNING OF THE SEMESTER.
01180141.name: Sel. Top. in Biophysics and Soft Matter

01180143.about: quantum properties of solids arising from electronic interactions. topics: second quantization.  hartree-fock approximation.  jellium model and wigner crystals.  linear response theory.  screening. rkky. random phase approximation.  fermi liquid theory, landau parameters, zeroth sound.  stoner instability.  ferromagnetism. hubbard model and antiferromagnetism.  ginzburg-landau theory of superconductivity.  electron-phonon interaction.  bcs theory of superconductivity learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically read updated literature. 2. to use the standard tool box of the condensed material theory.
01180143.name: Quantum Theory of Matter 2

01180144.about: course focuses on strong interaction effects and on advanced theoretical techniques used in the study of quantum solid state systems. topics: path integral techniques. quantum magnetism. the renormalization group. quantum critical points.  gross-pitaevskii equation, super fluidity,  luttinger liquids. fractional quantum hall effect. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able: 1. to critically read updated literature. 2. to use the standard tool box of many-body systems.
01180144.name: Quantum Theory of Matter 3

01180145.about:
primordial fluctuations and gravity waves, perturbed spacetime and gauge choice, energy-momentum conservation, photons: propagation, boltzmann equation and collision term, temperature anisotropies: baryon-photon fluid, tight coupling limit, acoustic oscillations,silk damping, polarization anisotropies: spin-weighted spherical harmonics, e and b mode polarization, integral solutions, angular power spectra and cosmological constraints, secondary anisotropies and spectral distortions.
 learning outcomes: 
 at the end of this course, the student will have a much deeper understanding of the origin and growth of fluctuations in the early universe. this is e ssential for the formation of galaxies and cosmic structures in the present-day universe. 
 the student will also know what currentcmb experiments measure and how this can be used to constrain cosmological models. the student will also understand the basic ingredients of publicly available boltzmann codes and be able to run them himself in order to produce theoretical predictions for observed cmb power spectra. finally, the student will have the required technical background to understand research papers on this rapidly evolving to
01180145.name: Physics of the Cosmic Microwave Background

01180147.about:
exact diagonalization - construction of the hamiltonian, using symmetries and conserved quantities, lanczos algorithm. classical monte carlo - markov chains and metropolis algorithm, critical slowing down, cluster updates. quantum monte carlo - quantum to classical mapping and the sign problem, world line representation, stochastic series expansion ( sse ), loop algorithms. 
 matrix product state (mps) techniques - entanglement entropy and area law, density matrix renormalization group (dmrg), real and imaginary time-evolution methods. 
 learning outcomes:
 upon successful completion of this course students will become acquainted with a variety of comp utational techniques for classical and quantum many-body problems relevant to present-day research. students will be able to analyze a given problem and understand which method would result in the most efficient simulation and analysis, implement the appropriate numerical algorithm, and analyze the outcome of the numerical simulations interpreting the physical properties of the system under study.
01180147.name: COMPUTATIONAL MANY-BODY PHYSICS

01180148.about:
maxwell equations and optical properties of materials, plasmons at planar interfaces and nanoparticles, applications of surface plasmons, near-field microscope, theoretical and numerical methods of nano-optics, green s functions in electrodynamics, quantum systems in nano-optical fields, interaction of electron beams and plasmonic particles, introduction to microscopic and macroscopic quantumelectrodynamics, lamb shifts and casimir forces, nonlocality in nano-optics, nonlinear nano-opitics and strong-field interactions. 
 learning outcomes: 
 at the end of the course the student will be able to:_
 - understand in depth the principles of nano-optics fr om classical and quantum perspectives.
 - know the experimental and theoretical methods of nano-optics.
 - get acquainted with modern applications of nano-optics in quantum physics. 
 - understand articles on this rapidly evolving topic.
01180148.name: QUANTUM NANOPHOTONICS

01240107.about: many electron atoms and the hartree fock approximation. the periodic table of the elements. metals and non-metals, ionic and molecular materials. avogadro's number, empiric and structural formulas. the chemical equation and stoichiometry, the hamiltonian of a molecule and the born oppenheimer approximation. linear variation molecules. effective linear combinations of the atomic orbitals, the valence bond approuch, polyatomic molecules, resonance structures, hybridizations and spatial structure of molecules. the carbon compounds: alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, cells, nernst equation, concentration cells. amines, carbocyclic aci ds. solutions, concentrations, reaction velocity, arrhenius dependence, reaction energy profile, chemical equilibrium, equilibrium in water, weak acids and bases, ph, electric cells.
01240107.name: Chemistry for Physicists M

01240108.about: many electron atoms and the hartree fock approximation. the periodic table of the elements. metals and non-metals, ionic and molecular materials. avogadro's number, empiric and structural formulas. the chemical equation and stoichiometry, the hamiltonian of a molecule and the born oppenheimer approximation. linear variation molecules. effective linear combinations of the atomic orbitals, the valence bond approach, polyatomic molecules, resonance structures, hybridizations and spatial structure of molecules. the carbon compounds: alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, cells, nernst equation, concentration cells. amines, carbocyclic aci ds. solutions, concentrations, reaction velocity, arrhenius dependence, reaction energy profile, chemical equilibrium, equilibrium in water, weak acids and bases, ph, electric cells.
01240108.name: Chemistry for Physicists

01240117.about: Introduction: elements, compounds and mixtures. Ionic and molecular compounds. Chemical equations and stoichiometry chemistry. Concentrations of compounds in fast response solutions. The definition of reaction kinetics. Chemical equilibrium and the equilibrium constant. Acids and bases. Atomic structure: historical backgrounds: the classical view. Rutherford's experiments, electromagnetic radiation and the emission spectra of hydrogen. Plank's formula, Bohr's model. The quantum model. Atomic orbitals. atomic structure andthe periodic table. The chemical bond: ionic and covalent  bonds, Lewis structures, polyatomic molecules, hybridization and molecula r geometry. Molecular orbitals in diatomic molecules.
01240117.name: Principles of Chemistry a

01240118.about: States of matter: ideal gases. The state equation, Maxwell-Boltzman distribution and the definition of temperature. Real gases, phase transitions, intermolecular forces, the crystalline state. Thermodynamics: the first law of thermodynamics, exothermic and endothermic reactions. The second law: entropy and free energy. Chemical equilibrium: thermodynamics equilibrium, factors affecting equilibrium. Le-Chatelier's principles, saturated solutions and the solubility product constant. Oxidation-reduction: oxidation states of the elements and organic compounds. Oxidation- reduction processes. The electrochemical series, galvanic cells, the nernst equation f or cell voltages, concentrations cells.
01240118.name: Principles of Chemistry B

01240120.about: Atoms, molecules and ions. Quantum theory and the electronic structure of atoms. The periodic table. Chemical bonding. molecular geometry and molecular orbitals. Thermochemistry. the gaseous state. Intermolecular forces, liquids and solids. physical properties ofsolutions. Chemical kinetics. Chemical equilibrium. Acids and bases. Electrochemistry. Properties of representative elements.
01240120.name: Principles of Chemistry

01240122.about: Experiments in different areas of general chemistry. The course includes lectures on subjects concerning the experiments and also on the subject of estimation of the accuracy of measurements and determination of experimental errors.
01240122.name: Laboratory in Principles of Chemistry

01240210.about: The course will deal with the main models used for describing bonding in transition metal complexes, with focus on those that describe.predict best the magnetic and photophysical properties thereof. Particular emphasis will be given to the involvement of transition metals in vital biological systems such as oxygen, transport.utilization, the electron transfer chain and in anzymes. In the end of the course the students will know how to use the modern theories of chemical bonding in inorganic complexes and will understand how they come into effect in advanced biological systems.
01240210.name: Chemistry of Transition Metals

01240212.about: Experiments related to subjects studied in the course "Analytical Chemistry 1 for Chemists: (124211).
01240212.name: Analytical Chemistry 1 Lab./ Extanded

01240213.about: Spectrophotometry: molecular absorption, Beer's law, photometric titrations, determination of the formula of a complex, flame photometry, fluorimetry. Analytical separation methods: extraction, gas-liquid and liquid-liquid chromatography, ion exchange. Electroanalysis: electrogravimetry, coulometry in controlled current and potential, polarography in straight current and pulses, cyclic voltametry, amperometry.
01240213.name: Analytical Chemistry 2 / Extended

01240214.about: Experiments related to subjects studied in the course "Analytical Chemistry 2 for Chemists" (124213).
01240214.name: Analytical Chemistry 2 Lab./ Extanded

01240220.about: Introduction to analytical chemistry. Estimation of experimental errors. Error propagation. Standard deviation. Confidence limits. Linear regression. Lod. Activity and Deby-Huchel equation. Chemical equilibrium. Gravimetry and analytical precipitayion processes. Calculation of titration curves. Titrations: precipitation, acid-base, redox, complexometry, calculation of relative precision. Kjeldahl analysis. Buffer solutions: bronsted equation and chemical approximations. Fundamentals of electrochemistry. Kinetic analysis.
01240220.name: Analytical Chemistry 1 / Extanded

01240305.about: Main group chemistry, emphasizing differences in structure, stability and reactivity between compounds involving first-row elementsand the others. Survey of various bonding theories required for understanding the phenomena unique to transition metal complexes.
01240305.name: Inorganic Chemistry

01240355.about: Research work in one of the research groups at the chemistry faculty at the technion. The course is open for undergraduates with anaverage grade above 80 and a minimum of 75 academic credit points. Before starting off the project, the student must hand out to the teaching committee a research proposal, approved by the intended supervising faculty member. At the end of the project the studentwill prepare a poster for presentation in a faculty forum, and a final report, approved by the supervisor, will be submitted to theteaching committee. The work should extend over 240 hours.
01240355.name: Special Research Project in Chemistry

01240356.about: A series of lectures by the chemistry faculty members on timely research topics. Each lecture will introduce a scientific problem, and the principles of the research methodology that led to its solution. Registration requires a fulfilment of the demands of the recommended program for the first three semesters in one of the chemistry programs. Class attendance is mandatory. The grade will be set according to an exam on the lectures material.
01240356.name: Introduction to Research in Chemistry

01240400.about: Principles of  quantum theory and of the theory of the chemical bond. Basic quantum mechanics: The Schroedinger equation and its solutions for a rotator in the plane. The harmonic oscillator. The hydrogen atom. Quantum mechanical operators. The variation principle. Perturbation theory. Spin. The helium atom. The Pauli principle. Many electron atoms. The Hartree- Fock method. The structure of the periodic table. Simple diatomic molecules: the valence-bond method, the method of molecular orbitals, hetero-atomic molecules. Polyatomic molecules: localized molecular orbitals, hybridization, conjugated and aromatic molecules. Time-dependent perturbation theo ry: transition probabilities, the Franck-Condon principle.
01240400.name: Quantum Chemistry 1

01240408.about: Experiments that lead to the birth of quantum mechanics. The time dependent schroedinger equation,the stationary schroedinger equation, the uncertainty principle, the schroedinger equation in one- dimensional cases. pay-electrons in conjugated polyenes, potentialbarrier tunneling and classically forbidden reactions, particle in a box, quantum wells, rotor in a plane and the electronic spectrum of benzene, harmonic oscillator and molecular vibrations, rotation spectrum of di-atomic molecules, the hydrogen atom and the definition of orbital, perturbation theory, fermi golden rule variational methods, electronic spin, singlet and triplet states, potentia l surfaces and molecular structure via the born- oppenheimer approximation, franck-condon transition, molecular orbitals.
01240408.name: Intr.to Quantum Chemi.and Applications

01240413.about: Introduction: basic concepts, naxwell velocity distribution. general formalism: ensembles, density of states, gibbs distribution, partition function, calculation of thermodynamic functions, thermodynamic equivalence of ensenbles. Ideal gas of identical particles,the classical limit (boltzmann statistics), thermodynamic functions of molecular gas, chemical equilibrium. Quantum statistics: Fermi-Dirac and Bose-Einstein distributions, electrons in metals, black-body radiation. Mean-field theory of phase transitions. Statistical models in adsorption and elasticity of polymers. Theory of fluctuations. The fundamentals of physical kinetics.
01240413.name: Statistical Thermodynamics

01240414.about: Rate equation, reaction order, first and second order reactions, complex reactions, steady state, chain reactions, temperature effect. Molecular dynamics: collision theory, potential energy surfaces, reaction coordinate, activated complex theory. Unimolecular reactions, lindemann, rrk, rrkm, homogeneous catalysis. Surface chemistry: adsorption, heterogeneous catalysis, surface tenison, colloids.
01240414.name: Physical Chemistry-Chemical Kinetics

01240415.about: Definitions, work, heat, internal energy, state properties, the first law of thermodynamics, entropy and the second law. Carnot cycle and heat engines, free energy and chemical potential. single component phase diagram. Clausius-clapeyron equation. The phase rule. Binary systems. Multi-component phase diagrams. Chemical equilibrium in gases and solultions. Deviations from ideality. Debye-Huckle model for electrolyte solutions. Electrochemical cells and Nernst law. Surface tension. Wetting. capillarity. Polymers and macro-structure.
01240415.name: Physical Chem.-Chemical Thermodynamics

01240416.about: Electrical multipoles, dipole-dipole interaction, Van Der Waals-London interactions, electrical polarizability, electrical polarization in insulators, dielectric liquids-clausius-mossotti relation, dielectric solids-ferroelectricity  piezoelectricity. magnetic moment, magnetic dipolar interaction, precession in a magnetic field, paramagnetism, cyclotron motion, diamagnetism. electromagnetic waves in matter, fresnel equations, radiative transitions-fermi golden rule.
01240416.name: Electromagnetism and Matter

01240417.about: Spectroscopy: stimulated absorption and emission. Selection rules. Einstein coefficients and spontaneous emission. Rotational, vibrational and vib-rotational spectrum of di-and polyatomic molecules (ir and raman). Electronic spectrum: vibronic structure, franck-condon principle, NMR and ESR spectroscopy. Symmetry and group theory: symmetry elements and symmetry operations. The symmetry point groups and the classification of molecules, complexes and orbitals. Basic concepts of group theory. Representation of symmetry operations by means of matrices: reducibility, characters, character tables, orthogonality of irreducible representations. Applications: r otational, vibrational and electronic spectroscopy.
01240417.name: Physical Chemist.-Molecular Spectroscopy

01240503.about: The kinetic theory of gases. Thermodynamics: the first law and thermochemistry, the second law and entropy, free energy and chemical equilibria, multicomponent systems, the chemical potential, solutions and colligative properties. Electrochemistry:  properties ofions and aqueous solutions, electromotive forces and electrochemical cells, colloidal systems, electrokinetic phenomena. Biologicalapplications.
01240503.name: Physical Chemistry 1B

01240507.about: ESSENTIAL INTRODUCTORY MATERIAL WILL BE SENT TO THE STUDENTS BEFORE THE BEGINNING OF THE COURSE! BY THE FACULTY OF MEDICINE. GASSES! ATOMIC STRUCTURE! THERMOCHEMISTRY! KINETICS! CHEMICAL BOND AND MOLECULAR STRUCTURE! INTERMOLECULAR INTERACTIONS! CHEMICAL EQUILIBRIUM! COLLIGATIVE PROPERTIES! LOW-SOLUBILITY SALTS! ACIDS AND BASES! BUFFERS! TITRATIONS! ELECTROCHEMISTRY.
01240507.name: GENERAL AND PHYSICAL CHEMISTRY FOR MED.

01240510.about: Gas laws: first and second laws of thermodynamics, thermochemistry, free energy, chemical equilibrium, ideal solutions, coligative properties, osmotic pressure. Electrochemistry: conductivity, ion separation, ion diffusion, ionic strength, electrochemical cells, electro- motive force, electrodes, concentration cells, contact potential, chemical kinetics, homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis, spectroscopy, photochemistry.
01240510.name: Physical Chemistry

01240601.about: Teaching of measuring and experimental methods in physical chemistry, study and analysis of basic physical phenomena, the procedureof writing a scientific report and proper data processing. The subjects of the experiments are the kinetic theory of gases, thermochemistry, chemical equilibrium, kinetics, electrochemistry spectrophotometry and surface chemistry.
01240601.name: Physical Chemistry Lab. 1

01240605.about: Experimental physical chemistry in the following topics: the kinetic theory of gases, electrochemistry, surface chemistry, determinatin of molecular structure, infra-red, visibe and ultra-violet spectroscopy.
01240605.name: Physical Chemistry Lab. 2 for Chemists

01240608.about: Study of measurements methods and advanced laboratory techniques for an experimental investigation of laws and  phenomena in the field of physical chemistry. Conducting experiments in thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, electrochemistry, the kinetic theory of gases, surface chemistry, infra-red, visible and uv spectroscopy. Introduction to advanced methods, emphasizing independent work, using advanced vacuum techniques.
01240608.name: Phys Chem Lab for Materials Engineering

01240609.about: Experimental physical xhemistry in the following topics: the kinetic theory of gases, electrochemistry, surface chemistry, determination of molecular structure, infra-red, visibe and ultra- violet spectroscopy.
01240609.name: Physical Chemistry for Biomol.Chem.Lab

01240610.about: Teaching of measuring and experimental methods in physical chemistry, study and analysis of basic physical phenomena, the procedureof writing a scientific report and proper data processing. The subjects of the experiments are the kinetic theory of gases, thermochemistry, chemical equilibrium, kinetics, electrochemistry spectrophotometry and surface chemistry.
01240610.name: Physical Chemistry Lab 1

01240611.about: two body mechanical oscillators (harmonic.disharmonic), identification of normal modes in 3-body system, measuring time dependent signals, computerized signal processing, assembling simple electronic circuits, currents and voltage measurements. response of forcedresonance circuits, resonance spectral width of q-factor, computerized simulation of multi-body oscillator, measuring vibrational spectrum of tiatonic molecule.
01240611.name: Introduction Lab. in Chemical Physics

01240613.about: advanced experimental methods in physical chemistry, analysis of experimental data and validation of theoretical models on the topics including kinetic theory of gases, thermo-chemistry, chemical equilibrium, chemical kinetics, electrochemistry, surface chemistry, electromagnetism of matter. methods used include thermal and acoustic measurements, infrared, visible and ultra-violet spectroscopy, electron spin spectroscopy.
01240613.name: PHYSICAL CHEMISTRY LAB. 2 FOR CHEMIST

01240618.about: Study of measurements methods and advanced laboratory techniques for an experimental investigation of laws and  phenomena in the field of physical chemistry. Conducting experiments in thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, electrochemistry, the kinetic theory of gases, surface chemistry, infra-red, visible and uv spectroscopy. Introduction to advanced methods, emphasizing independent work, using advanced vacuum techniques.
01240618.name: Phys Chem Lab for Materials Engineering

01240703.about: Principles of mechanistic and physical organic chemistry. Potential energy surfaces, kinetics and mechanisms, the Hammett equation,reactive intermediates (carbenium ions, carbanions, radicals, carbenes, etc.) their properties and reactions.
01240703.name: Structure and Activity in Organic Chem.

01240708.about: Introduction-bonding, structure, bond energies. Organic reactions: thermodynamics, kinetics, acidity and bacisity. Alkanes. Rotational barriers, cycloalkanes, strain. Chain reactions, halogenations. stereochemistry. Enantiomers, diastereomers. Alkyl halides, Sn1,Sn2, E1, E2. Alcohols and ethers. Alkenes. NMR. Alkynes and nitriles. Aldehydes and ketones. Carboxylic acides and derivatives. Conjugation, aromaticity.
01240708.name: Organic Chemistry 1/ Extanded

01240711.about: Electrophilic aromatic substitutions, aromatic halides, amines, nucleophilic aromatic substitutions, quinones, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, bifunctional compounds. amino acids and proteins. IR spectroscopy, carbohydrates, heterocyclic compounds, mass spectrometry.
01240711.name: Organic Chemistry 2 / Extanded

01240801.about: Saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons: alcohols, phenols and ethers: alkyl halides: acids, esters, fats and lipids.
01240801.name: Organic Chemistry 1B

01240911.about: Simple organic syntheses based on the lectures of Organic Chemistry 1 and 2, stress being applied to laboratory techniques and spectroscopic identification.
01240911.name: Organic Chemistry Lab 1

01240912.about: Multiple step higher level sytheses of organic compounds, use of advanced laboratory apparatus, application of spectroscopic methods (IR, UV, NMR).
01240912.name: Organic Chemistry Lab. 2M

01250000.about: waves and particles. wavefunctions. operators. schroedinger s equation. quantum size effect. tunneling. vibrations. kinetic isotopic effect. rotations. the hydrogen atom. measurements. the uncertainty principle. completeness relations. dirac notations. absorptionand emission spectra. the variation principle. spin. hartree fock. pauli s exclusion. the periodic table. chemical bond. (the course includes 4 lab classes).
01250000.name: Int. to Quantum Chemistry for Engineers

01250001.about: introduction, atomic and molecular weight, concentration units, stoichiometry. atomic spectra. the bohr model for the hydrogen atom. particles and waves, the schrodinger equation, particle in a one-dimensional box. atomic orbitals, the periodic table of the elements. ionic and covalent bonds, lewis structures, dipole moment, structures of molecules. gases: ideal gases, the kinetic theory of gases. liquids, vapor equilibrium, phase diagrams. thermochemistry, internal energy, enthalpy, hess law. chemical equilibrium, equilibrium in heterogeneous systems, le chatelier's principle. electronic solutions, insoluble salts and solubility product. acids and bas es. oxidation, reduction, electrochemical cells, batteries.
01250001.name: General Chemistry

01250013.about: Safety instructions, measurements and accuracy, combustion reactions, concentration determination by titration, determination of hydration water in copper sulfate. Chemical equilibrium and Le-Chatelier principle. Determination of zinc equivalent (ideal gas laws).Atomic absorption and emission spectrum, elements in flame, absorption law, phase diagrams, measuring the enthalpy of vaporization,ion exchangers, acid and bases, elution curves. Note: the lab is given once in 2 weeks.
01250013.name: General Chemistry Laboratory

01250101.about: ionic equilibrium: a. systems involving insoluble salts - solubility product, preparation, titrimetric and gravimetric determinations, electolytic  solubility and conductivity, conductometric titrations. b. acid-base systems - acid ans base stength, ph, buffer systems, titrations and indicators, illustrative determinations. c. oxidation-reduction systems - oxidation state, half reactions, electrochemical cells, the nernst equation, potentiometry, redox titration, ph measurements.
01250101.name: Analytical Chemistry 1 for Engineers

01250102.about: general experiments in various areas in analytical chemistry. preliminary lecture will be given in the beginning of each lab.
01250102.name: Analytical Chemistry Lab.1 for Engineers

01250105.about: general experiments in various areas in analytical chemistry.
01250105.name: Analytical Chem. Lab 1 for Biochem.Eng.

01250800.about: the course is offered in the form of massive open online course (mooc) the course provides general knowledge in organic chemistry and deals with the structure, properties, preparation and investigation of organic compounds of importance in industry and in daily life. the course includes the following: alkanes and cycloalkanes. stereochemistry. chiral centers. enantiomers, diastereomers, meso compounds. radical halogenations, alkyl halides, grignard reactions. nucleophilic substitution reactions and elimination reactions. alcohols addition reactions to alkenes. aromatics and chemistry of aromatic compounds. aldehydes, ketones and their derivatives. carb oxylic acids and derivatives of carboxylic acids. amides and peptide bonds. amino acids. biological molecules.
01250800.name: Organic Chemistry M

01250801.about: saturated and unsaturated hydrocarbons, alcohols and ethers, alkyl halides, acids, esters, fats and lipids. stereochemistry, amines, amino acids, proteins, aldyhydes and ketons: chemistry of carbohydrates, aromaticity and reactions of benzene, condensation reactions for the building of molecules.
01250801.name: Organic Chemistry

01250802.about: Hybridization, chemical bond, electron affinity, ionization energy, dipol moment. Alkanes and cycloalkanes radical chain halogenation. Stereochemistry, chiral centers, enantiomers, diasteriomers, meso compounds. Alkyl halides, grignard reactions. Nucleophilic reactions. Alcohols and ethers: preparation and reactivity. elimination and addition reactions. Alkenes and alkynes. Aldehydes and ketones and their derivatives: preparation, addition and condensation. Amines: preparation and reactivity. carboxylic acids: preparationand reactivity. Protective groups, synthesis and degradation of peptides. Carbohydrates. Aromaticity and the chemistry of aromatic c ompounds.
01250802.name: Organic Chemistry Rbm

01250803.about: ALKANES! ALKENES! ALCOHOLS! ETHERS! STEREOCHEMISTRY! REACTION MECHANISMS - CONSIDERATIONS AND DEMONSTRATION THROUGH NUCLEOPHILLIC SUBSTITUTIONS AND ELIMINATION MECHANISMS! SYNTHESIS OF AMINO ACIDS AND PEPTIDES.

Methods in surface research.

two of the following subjects: 1. atoms, molecules and nano structures in a laser field: harmonic generation, ionization, optical lattices.

two of the following subjects: 1. spectrscopy and microscopy of nano crystals.

01260604.about:
The lab includes 2 out of 4 experiments with quantum systems. each experiment is 3 weeks. list of experiments: ,Nitrogen vacancies in diamond as quantum sensor - ODMR measurements. ,Interference from single photons, experiments in quantum optics with single photons.
 ,quantum computing with NMR - single qubit experiments.
 ,Nitrogen vacancy in diamond as a single qubit- ODMR with single photon detectors.
 Learning outcome:
The course is intended for students with basic background in quantum information and quantum technology that want to get experience with basic experiments in this field. At the end of the course, the student will be able to:
1. know in practice at least two experiments which are basic for modern quantum technology.
2. Understand the practical problems that limitthe capabilities of quantum systems in the real world exper and experience minimizxation of these limitations.

01260605.about:
2 of 4 experiments with quantum systems. experiment will be carried out for 6 weeks. list of experiments: , Nitrogen vacancies as quantum sensor, ODMR measurements and dynamic decoupling. 
, Interference from single photons, quantum optics with single photons, quantum key distribution. 
 ,Quantum computing with NMR. 
 , Single two qubit.
 Single nitrogen vacancy qubit, ODMR with single photondetectors and quantum sensing. 
 Learning Outcomes:
 The course is intended for students with relatively advnaced background in quantum information and quantum technology that want to get experience with both basic and advanced experiments in this field. At the en d of the course, the student will be able to:
1. Know in practice at least two experiments which are basic for modern quantum technology.
2. Understand the practical problems that limit the capabilities of quantum systems in the real world and experience minimization of these limitations.

01260700.about: Molecular orbitals of organic molecules, symmetry, correlation diagrams. The Woodward-Hoffman rules and their application to electrocyclic, cycloaddition and sigmatropic reactions (both thermal and photochemical). Organic synthesis with catalytic antibodies. Organic synthesis with transition metal complexes.

01260901.about: Major updated developments in organic chemistry: organometallic chemistry, enantioselective synthesis, computational chemistry, catalytic antibodies, polysacharide synthesis. Requirements: project to be presented to the class.

01260902.about: Study of Laboratory techniques. Emphasizing independent work. Design and performance of experiments in field that are relevant to modern Organic Chmistry. Projects will be presented to the class.

01270002.about:
introduction lecture. industrial catalysis and part kinetics. general theory of catalysis, heterogeneous industrial catalysis and kinetics. theory of and research on heterogeneous catalysis. theory of and research on homogeneous catalysis. group assignment. 
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the students will be able to answer and formulate questions concerning catalysis in molecular terms.
 - answer and formulate questions concerning catalysis in molecular trms. 
 -   select the proper type of atalysis, biocatalysis, homogen eous catalysis or heterogeneous catalysis to catalyze a transformation. 
 - describe the mechanistic, energetic and kinetic aspects of importa (i.e widely applied) catalytic transformations. 
 - describe and understand current methods for acquiring insight into catalytic transformations. - gain an understanding of energy, environment and innovation problems and their relation to catalysis. - work essential information into poster presentation (subgroups) and use it to convince others of the knowledge they acuired on catalysis.
01270002.name: HETEROGENEUS CATALYSIS

01270004.about: THE PURPOSE OF THESE LECTURES IS TO GIVE AN ACCESSIBLE AND SELF-CONTAINED INTRODUCTION TO QUANTUM SCATTERING THEORY IN ONE DIMENSION. PART A DEFINES THE THEORETICAL PLAYGROUND AND DEVELOPS BASIC CONCEPTS OF SCATTERING THEORY IN THE TIME DOMAIN (ASYMPTOTIC CONDITION, IN- AND OUT- STATES, SCATTERING OPERATOR(. THE AIM OF PART B IS THEN TO BUILD UP, IN A STEP-BY-STEP FASHION, THE TIME INDEPENDENT SCATTERING THEORY IN ENERGY DOMAIN. THIS AMOUNTS TO INTRODUCE THE LIPPMANN-SCHWINGER EQUATION FOR THE STATIONARY SCATTERING STATES, TO DISCUSS FUNDAMENTAL PROPERTIES OF THE SCATTERING STATES AND SUBSEQUENTLY TO CONSTRUCT THE SCATTERING AND TRANSMISSION OPERATORS IN TERMS OF THE SCATTERING STATES. PHYSICAL CONTENTS OF THESE OPERATORS IS THEN ILLUMINATED BY DERIVING EXPLICIT FORMULAS FOR THE PROBABILITY OF TRANSMISSION/REFLECTION OF QUANTUM PARTICLES THROUGH/FROM THE INTERACTION REGION OF THE POTENTIAL. AN ILLUSTRATIVE NUMERICAL EXAMPLE IS GIVEN, WHICH ALSO HIGHLIGHTS AN EXISTENCE OF SCATTERING RESONANCES. FINALLY, PART C ELABORATES THE NON HERMITIAN SCATTERING THEORY (SIEGERT PSEUDO STATE FORMALISM), WHICH OFFERS AN EXTREMELY POWERFUL TOOL SUITABLE FOR CLEAR CUT UNDERSTANDING OF THE RESONANCE
01270004.name: QUANTUM SCATTERING THEORY

01270005.about:
THE COURSE WILL COVER SELECTED TOPICS IN CHEMICAL BIOLOGY, AIMING TO PROVIDE AN ENTRY-LEVEL INTRODUCTION TO THE PROMINENT RESEARCH SUBJECTS IN THIS AREA: CHEMICAL BIOLOGY OF GENOME EDITING! DIRECTED EVOLUTION OF PROTEINS, BIOORTHOGONAL CHEMISTRY, GENETIC CODE EXPANSION, CHEMICAL TOOLS TO STUDY EPIGENETICS! CHEMICAL GLYCOBIOLOGY, PROXIMITY LABELING AND QUANTITATIVE PROTEOMICS, ACTIVITY-BASED PROTEIN PROFILING. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDETNS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. FAMILIAR WITH THE PROMINENT RESEARCH TOPICS IN MODERN CHEMICAL BIOLOGY.
 2. UNDERSTAND AND DESCRIBE HOW CHEMICAL METHODS HELP IN SOLVING BIOLOGICAL QUESTIONS.
 3. PROCESS AN ARTICLE ON ONE OF THE TOPICS STUDIED INTO A PRESENTATION THAT THEY WILL PRESENT TO THE CLASS.
01270005.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN CHEMICAL BIOLOGY

01270010.about:
MOTIVATION: WHEN ARE OPEN QUANTUM SYSTEMS NEEDED.
 BASIC LANGUAGE: DENSITY MATRIX, TENSOR STATES, REDUCED STATES. MODEL OF THE ENVIRONMENT. ENVIRONMENT STATES.
 REDUCED DYNAMICS: LINDBLAD EQUATION DERIVATION. WHAT ARE THE APPROXIMATIONS USED. WHEN IS THIS CORRECT.
 PROPERTIES OF THE LINDBLAD EQUATION: STRUCTURE OF THE EQUATION, MATHEMATICAL PROPERTIES, DECOUPLING BETWEEN COHERENCES AND DIAGONAL ELEMENTS.
 HOW TO SOLVE THE LINDBLAD EQUATION AND PROPERTIES OF THE STEADY-STATE. EXAMPLE 1 OF APPLICATIONS OF OPEN QUANTUM SYSTEMS. DECOHERENCE IS THE ENVIRONMENT THE ENEMY.
 DECOHERENCE IN QUANTUM INFORMATION AND QUANTUM TO CLASSICAL TRANSITION LEARNING OUTCOM ES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW:
 - HOW TO MODEL  A NON-ISOLATED QUANTUM SYSTEM AND TO OBTAIN BAS INTUITIONS REGARDING ITS BEHAVIOR.
 -_BE FAMILIAR WITH BASIC MODELING OF NOISE.
 - HOW TO WRITE AND SOLVE THE DYNAMICAL EQUATIONS OF A SYSTEM UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF ITS SURROUNDINGS, STARTING FROM A MICROSCOPIC MODEL.
 - BE FAMILIAR WITH BASIC MODELING OF DECOHERENCE.

01270011.name: AN INTR. TO RENORMALIZATION IN ATOMIC

01270107.about: Synthesis and biosynthesis of porphyrins and their metal complexes. Electronic structure and spectroscopy of neutral, radical cationic and radical anionic derivatives. Coordination in metalloporphyrins from an inorganic point of view and its biochemical effect. Survey of the biochemical processes involving metallo- porphyrin containing proteins and enzymes and their mechanisms.

01270109.about: Introduction, Environmental regulations, Reliability of environmental analysis, Environmental sampling and monitoring, TR-LIF, LIDAR, DIAL, LPS, MPI methods. LOD of heavy metals, Matrix effects, Electroanalytic methods. Israel water resources, Criteria and regulations for water quality. Industrial effluents. Contamination removal and water treatments. Mass spectrometric methods. Selective detection of P and S compounds, Organic adsorbates analysis. Surface characterization and chemical, physical and morphological properties. Aerosols: definitions, classification, chemical and aerodynamic properties. Exchange of natural compounds by polymers, Polymers r ecycling. Molecular recognition processes and application to sensor development. Pollution sources of SO2, CO2, CO, CFC, NOx, aerosols, and their environmental effects, Aerosol surface reactions, The ozone hole and the greenhouse effect, Environmental regulationsfor atmospheric pollution control, Minimization of atmospheric pollution.

01270403.about: General properties of surfaces. Thermodynamics of surfaces and interfaces. Structure of solid surfaces. Electronic properties of surfaces and interfaces. Interaction of gas molecules with solid surfaces. Chemical adsorption. Physical adsorption. Adsorption isotherms. Properties of the adsorbed layer. Experimental methods in surface studies. Particular studies in surface research will be discussed.

01270415.about:
The variational method for ground and excited states, self consistent field method for electronic spectrum (Hartree-Fock) and for vibrational-rotational spectrum (Hartree): numerical integration of one-dimensional Schrodinger equation, the Raleigh-Schrodinger perturbation theory within the framework of finite matrix approximation and methods to calculate the radius of convergence of the perturbation series.
 The students will exercise the theoretical aspects of the topics studied by writing computer programs.

01270427.about: Crystal lattices, difraction from a lattice, reciprocal lattice. Drude model of conduction in metals - electrical end thermal Conductivity, Sommerfeld correction - ideal Fermi gas, electronic heat capacity. Quantum theory of conduction - Bloch's theorem, energy bands, electrons and holes, effective mass, Fermi surface, electron dynamics in a magnetic field, band structures of semiconductors -the intrinsic state, statistics of charge carriers, impurity levels, optical properties - excitons, lattice dynamics-phonons, heat capacity, optical properties of ionic crystals.

01270433.about: Topics: Experimental methods in surface sciences, vacuum technology, electron and ion specroscopies (AEX, XPS, UPS, EELS, HREELS and ISS). Low energy electron diffraction (LEED). Electron, photon and ion stimulated chemical and physical processes on surface (ESP,PSP, ISP). Scanning proble microscopy (SEM, AFM, STM). Mass spectrometry methods for the study of surface processes (TDP). Studies on surface processes.

01270435.about: topics:  quantum description of decaying meta-stable states with applications in physics, chemistry, and engineering: a survey of resonanace phenomena in physics, chemistry and engineering. feshback type resonances and shape type resonance, methods for observing rersonance in hamiltonian quantum mechanics, non-hermitian quantum mechanics, analytic continuation of the hamiltonian and compex scaling methods, the advantages of studying resonances by non-hermitian quantum mechanics. computational methods and algorithms for evaluating resonance energies and lifetime. applications of nonhamiltonian quantum mechanics to the study of resonances in atomic, mole cular and laser driven systems. applications to the transmission light through otical waveguides. applications of the theory to different fields of natural sciences.

01270436.about: review: statistical mechanics, erogodic assumption, ensembles,entropy, detailed balance, fluctuations. nonequilibrium systems: langevin and fokker-planck equations, jump processes and the master equation. stochastic pumps, thermal ratchets, network theory for steady states. entropy production. fluctuation theorems. jarzynski and crooks relations. simple models of molecular machines. small systems thermo- dynamics, stall force, efficiency at maximum output.

01270437.about: global challenges and renewable energy. background review of photochemistry,homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis and solid statephotoelectrochemical cells, particle photocatalysis, material challenges. photophysics and nanoparticles, exciton dymanics, semi- conductor . metal interace, semiconductor . liquid junction, photo- induced electron-transfer dynamics, classical marcus theory. relevant experimental techniques, guided discussion on literature (focus on applications).

01270438.about: symmetry elements, multiplication of symmetry operations and point groups, basic properties of groups, group representations,reducibility and irreducibility, character tables, symmetry proprerties and quantum mechanics, normal modes, selection rules and spectroscopy, symmetry in chemical bonding, symmetry breaking by substitution or by external fields, symmetry in reaction mechanisms, jahn-teller distortion, conical intersections.
