01270441.about: the interaction between light and biomolecules. the evolution of biological photochemical systems. photophysical and photochemical processes. the electronic structure of biological chromophores and the influence of their environment. light absorption, energy and electron transport. photosynthesis at atomic resolution. vision and signaling processes. utilizing biological solar energy conversion and artificial photosynthesis.

01270442.about: materials and semiconductor nanocrystals (e.g. quantum dots and wires) heterostrucures and self-assmebly of complex structures. preparation methods of nanocrystals (colloidal synthesis, spray and evaporation). structural and chemical characterization methods (sem, tem, afm, xrd). characterization methods of optical and optoelectronic properties of nanocrystals. physical properties: density ofstates, excitons, exciton-phonon interation, plasmons, relaxation processes (radiative and non-radiative, auger). theoretical models for electronic band structure and optical properties. devices: lasers, diodes, detectors, single electron transistors, spin - based  switching.

01270443.about: second quantization of many fermions systems. fock space operators and tensor products. the density operator and liouville space.introduction to quantum thermodynamics. the fermi-dirac distribution function. second quantization of the interaction operators. discrete models of solids. quantum dynamics. open quantum systems. the markovian approximation and kinetic models of transport. quantum master equations. rge transport. tunnel junctions out of equilibrium and current-voltage curves. effects of molecular vibrations on transport through molecules. the quantum scattering approach. the transmission function and self energies. the landauer transport form ula. tunneling and interference effects in charge transport througth molecular junctions.
01270443.name: Molecular Electronics

01270444.about:
biological building blocks, biological self-assembly processes, biological polymers and fibrils, bioinspired materials, optical andopto-electronic properties, charge transfer properties, dielectric and capacitance properties, bioelectronic devices,  applicationsof biological materials in industry and research, future applications of biological materials.
 learning outcomes: exposure of the student to multidisciplinary research and to judgmental reading and understanding of the subject.
01270444.name: Biological Materials and Bioelectronics

01270446.about:
superposition principle and wave functions, density matrix, quantum interference and duality principle, entanglement and non-locality including bell states, the classic-quantum boundary, principles of quantum communication and quantum teleportation, quantum computing (basic level) and quantum sensing, limited aspects of magnetic resonance mainly related to two level system and bloch sphere, quantum optics and jaynes cummings equations, lindblad master equation, collective excitations of spins in resonator, principles and approaches to quantum materials and molecules to be used in quantum devices maintaining long coherence times, minimization of photon. phonon noise.and approaches to quantum materials and molecules to be used in quantum devices maintaining long coherence times, minimization of photon.phonon noise. learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the student will be able to:
1 .realize how quantum phenomena can be revealed in daily life and in modern experiments, including some existing and future applications of quantum effects.
 2. understand and describe the measurement process and its effects on the measured object.
3. understand and describe in mathematical terms
01270446.name: Introduction to Molecular Quantum Tech

01270447.about:
various physical and topological implementations of quantum computers based on superconductors (superconductor devices, transmon, quantization of elements in circuit), topologies of molecular quantum computers, molecular magnets, quantum sensors based on magneticresonance, nv centers in diamond and their application to quantum computing, quantum sensing and single photon sources, artificial two-level systems (dots, wires and nanpometric planes of semiconductors), cold atom and ions magnetometer atomic clocks based on ions and atoms, applications of quantum computing in theoretical chemistry. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will  be able to:
 1.know and describe in mathematical terms the principles of operation and the performances of real quantum devices.
2. know methods and processes of preparation of various materials used for quantum devices.
3. describe various applications of quantum computers for the solution of real problems, mainly in quantum chemistry.
01270447.name: Applications of Molecular Quantum Thchnology

01270451.about:
quantum dots.rods, lamellar and perovskite semiconductors. electronic band structure, spin-orbit, angular momentum, spinors. single-, charged and multiple excitons, polarons, plasmons, phonons, electron-hole spin exchange coupling, hyperfine and overhauser effect, relaxation (radiative, auger, trapping), spin coherence. colloidal chemistry, vapor transport and spray deposition. optical, magneto-optics, optically detected magnetic resonance, second-order photon correlation methods.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course, the student should understand the fundamental principal which endow materials with special physical properties (e.g., discrete electronic state, long coherence time) that are suitable for quantum information or memory devices. furthermore, the student will be acquainted with fabrication procedures that control the physical properties of materials with potential application for quantum technology.  the students will also learn about various physical methodologies most suitable for characterization of optical and magneto-optical properties, and will be aware of the challenges and obstacles for implementation of artificial materials in quantum technologies.
01270451.name: Physical Chemistry of Quantum Materials

01270452.about:
coherent quantum control using short laser pulses and radio frequency pulses: 1. characterization, shaping, and generation of femtosecond laser pulses, quantum coherent control using shaped femtosecond pulses 2. nmr principles: polarization, interactions, hamiltonians (chemical shift, spin-spin coupling). the fid and how it is measured. cw and pulsed nmr. the density matrix and the equation of motion for coupled two-level systems, their spectral transitions, coherence transfer between coupled spins, inept (h-c), decoupling techniques
 learning outcomes the student will master the experimental tools and their use for quantum control and measurement usin g optical and electromagnetic techniques.
01270452.name: Quantum Control and Measurement in Physical Chemistry

01270453.about: ntroduction to electrochemistry: the electrode-solution interface, cell types, voltage losses. electrochemical thermodynamics and kinetics: nernst, arrhenius and tafel equations, butler-volmer model, single and multi-step mechanisms, the marcus theory. mass transfer: fick and cottrell experiments, the diffusion layer. a central focus: voltammetry. coupled electrochemical-chemical reactions, mechanism elucidation. hydrodynamic methods (rotating electrodes). impedance-based methods. applied electrochemistry: electrolysis, electrolysis, electro-synthesis, energy storage and conversion. learning outcomes: by the end of the course, the students willl have m astered the basics of modern electrochemistry, both as an analytical tool towards material characterization and reaction mechanism elucidation, and as a broadly applicable synthetic tool. students will be able to plan electrochemical experiments and analyze results from a variety of techniques. students will acquire a critical approach to analyzing the electrochemical literature.
01270453.name: ELECTROCHEMISTRY

01270454.about:
students will learn how to program numerical simulations for various topics in chemical physics and quantum physics/chemistry. students will learn to sanity check, convergence test and effectively debug multiple topics, including solving the laplace equation, simulating particle motion, simulating thermodynamics, reactions progress, quantum evolution of hamiltonians and molecular potential diagonalization.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the students will be:
 1. confident and independent in simulating multiple chemical physics and quantum physics/chemistry problems._
 
 2. verify the correctness of the simulation.
 
 3. be able to improv e the efficiency of their program to make it practical to use.
01270454.name: PRACTICAL SIMULATION IN CHEMICAL PHYSICS

01270455.about:
the offered course is a bridge between the quantum world and realm of organic chemistry. in the course, students will learn how quantum-chemical concepts relate to the properties and reactivity of organic molecules. students will learn how molecular orbitals dictate the functionality of molecules and the selectivity of organic reactions, and how this selectivity affects synthetic outcomes. wewill discuss classic concepts such as the anomeric effect, hyperconjugation, and the woodward-hoffmann selection rules, which are acornerstone of physical-organic chemistry and play an important role in modern chemistry, to this day. the course material enables t he students to develop an intuition and a toolset for analyzing organic reactions.
 learning outcomes:
 students will encouter the term ~molecular orbital~ and learn how orbitals dicatet reactivity and properties. the course material gives students intuition and a toolset with which to analyse organic reactions. during the course, students will use various model systems, from which conclusions can be generalized. these reactions enable prediction of reaction selectivity. they will see several classic and important chemical reactions
01270455.name: MOLECULAR ORBITALS IN ORGANIC CHEMISTRY

01270456.about:
biological building blocks, biological self-assembly process, biological polymers and fibrils, bioinspired materials, design principles of materials from the nanometer scale to designing biological polymers, current industrial and research applications of biological materials, future applications of biological materials. project of seminar and written task.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will know:
 1. the students will know the unique properties of biological building blocks from the single molecule level up to large polymers._
 2. the students will acquire new tools for designing biological materials and will be able to cho ose the biological building blocks for a specific biological material with a desired property, and match between the material s properties and its application._
 3. the students will be able to critically read multidisciplinary research papers in subjects relevant to the design and use of biological materials._
 4. following the project that will be done in class, the students will be able towrite research proposals that integrate several disciplines in areas related to the design and use of biological materials.
01270456.name: BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS

01270458.about:
uring the course students will learn: (1) the classification of sensors according to chemical and physical principles, advantages and disadvantages of different sensing methods, (2) how to define the important characteristic parameters of a sensor, how they are measured and calculated, (3) how to design a development path for a new chemical sensor suitable for application requirements, (4) how to construct of a calibration curve and methods for calculating the result.
learning outcomes: after the course, the student should have knowlege of or be able to:
 1. explain current and new sensory methods with relevance to industrial applications.
 2. give a d etailed explanation of scientific mechanisms of the chemical sensors and identify factors that might affect the sensor performance 3. compare the performance of various sensors.
 4. identify r and d directions for the introduction of a new types of chemical sensors.
01270458.name: INTRODUCTION TO CHEMOSENSORS

01270459.about: harmonic oscillator (equations of motion for driven and damped harmonic oscillator, line width, power absorption, impulsive excitation), linear response theory (response functions, susceptibility, and their application to harmonic oscillator, kramers-kronig relations), light-matter interaction (euler-lagrange equations of motion, lorentz force, derivation of classical and quantum hamiltonian of light-matter interaction, dipole approximation), time-dependent schrodinger equation (formulation of the tdse, two-level system, transition probabilities, fermi golden rule), absorption of energy from electro-magnetic radiation (schrodinger and heisenberg pictur es of quantum mechanics, absorption line shape as dipole correlation function), molecular relaxation (vibrational normal modes, absorption line shape as correlation function of normal coordinates, recurrences, fermi-pasta-ulam paradox), energy relaxation: isolated binary collisions, landau-teller formula, langevin equation, quantum-mechanical description: system-bath interaction, anharmonic oscillator), phase relaxation, measurements of vibrational life time, intra- and inter-molecular transport, rotational diffusion, frequency fluct
01270459.name: SPECTROSCOPY DYNAMICS IN CONDENSED PHASE

01270460.about:
programming using qiskit, solving mathematical problems with qc, quantum communication problems: superdense coding, quantum teleportation, quantum games, quantum phase estimation, algorithm for solving linear equations, simulation of hamiltonian eigenstates, introduction into noisy intermediate-scale quantum and hybrid quantum-classical algorithms: variational quantum eigensolver for quantum chemistry, quantum noise and noise mitigation techniques. learning outcomes: 
 at the end of the course the students will know to provide students familiar with quantum theory with the tools and expertise needed to perform potential computations on quantum computer s in any field with an emphasis on physics and quantum chemistry problems. the labs are based on the ibm quantum information software kit (qiskit), hence, familiarity with python programming is required. the course will be divided into two major sections: 1) introduction into quantum programming using qiskit with mostly mathematical examples and 2) quantum programming of quantum physical and chemical simulations: simulating dynamics, computing energy levels of quantum systems.
01270460.name: COMPUTATIONAL QUANTUM LAB IN CH!  PHYS.

01270461.about:
when are open quantum systems needed and basic language. reduced dynamics: lindblad equation derivation. what are the approximations used. properties of the lindblad equation: decoupling between coherences and diagonal elements how to solve the lindblad equation and properties of the steady-state depending on time and students interests the following examples will be studied: decoherence a undesired effect of the environment. decoherence in quantum information and quantum to classical transition. sometimes the environmentis useful (enaqt, quantum transport, quantum biology) quantum thermodynamics: multiple environments are even better.
 quantum heat m achines and thermalization. determining if quantum provides any advantage quantum noise: effects in quantum technologies: noise andopen quantum systems. measurements and open quantum systems.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will know:
 1. how to model a non-isolated quantum system and to obtain basic intuitions regarding its behavior.
 2. be familiar with basic modeling of noise.
 3. how to write and solve the dynamical equations of a system under the influence of its surroundings, starting from a micro
01270461.name: INTRODUCTION TO OPEN QUANTUM SYSTEMS

01270727.about: Selected recent achievements in main group organometallic chemistry (such as Li, B, Ng, Ap, Cu, Zn) in  synthetic organic transformations. Special emphasis on the configurational stability of SP3 organo-metallic and on the synthesis and reactivity of functionalized organometallic reagents.
01270727.name: Organometallic Chemistry in Organic Synthesis

01270730.about: Sturcture determination of organic compounds using modern spectroscopic methods. Emphasis will be given to NMR methods, MS, UV, IR and chiroptical methods.
01270730.name: Structure Determination by Physical Methods

01270735.about: Metal-catalyzed industrial processes wacker process: monsanto acetic and synthesis, dupont adiponitrile synthesis, hydro- formulation. Synthetic applications of homogeneous catalysis: a. Suzuki, stille, heck couplings. b. Carbenoids in synthesis: cyclopropanation, C-H insertion, metathesis. Catalytic functionalization of hydrocarbons. c. Asymmetric catalysis privileged ligands, non -linear effects, kinetic resolution.
01270735.name: Selected Topics in Homogeneous Catalysis

01270738.about: conjugate addition,organometallic species, controlling stereochemistry of double bonds, eliminataion reactions, stereochemistry of enolates, chemoselectivity, alkylation reactions, stereoselective reactions of cyclic compounds, pericyclic reactons, synthesis and reactivity of carbenes, heterocyclic chemistry, main group elements and aromatic compounds.
01270738.name: Organic Chemistry 3 Expanded

01270740.about:
controlled polymerization, telechelic polymers. copolymers: random, block, gradient, sequence controlled.
post polymerization modifications, mechanochemistry. architectures: linear, crosslinked, hyperbranched, brush, star, cyclic, single chain polymer nano- particles, dendrimers, foldamers. emulsion polimerization: spheres and particles. assemblies, capsules and polymersomes. this course introduces to the student advanced polymer synthesis. the goal is to connect between polymer synthesis and architecture. new concepts inpolymer chemistry will be taught, showing a  different size of organic chemistry. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the st udent will know: 1. how to design the synthesis of 3d polymeric assemblies. 2. identify different macromolecular assemblies. 3. explain breaking of symmetry during assembly.
01270740.name: Polymers: from Synthesis to Architecture

01270741.about:
Peptide synthesis:historical perspective of peptide synthesis early development, principles of peptide synthesis, solution phase synthesis solid phase synthesis, new development in amide bond formation. chemical protein synthesis and modification: overview of protein structure, the concept of chemoselective ligation, native chemical ligation (ncl), application of protein synthesis, protein semi- synthesis, non-ncl based ligation.
 Learning Outcomes: The end of the course the student will know: 1. The general chemistry behind peptide and protein synthesis.
 2. Solid phase peptide synthesis (for example: solid spports, linkers, protecting groups) and sol ution phase peptide synthesis. 
 3. Peptide ligatio methods (for example Native Chemical Ligation).
 4. Protein semi-synthesis.
01270741.name: The Chemistry of Peptides and Proteins

01270742.about: studies on chemical mechanisms of antibiotics action, including the major classes of antibiotics in human clinical use, the molecular bases of antibiotic resistance and the chemical logic and enzymatic machinery by which microbes make the major classes of naturalantibiotics. learning outcoming: 1. acquaiting with the major classes of existing antibiotics and their mechanisms of action. 2. ability to understand and critically examin the app0roaches towards the discovert of calsses of antibiotics.
01270742.name: Medicinal Chemistry of Antibiotics

01280001.about: Lectures in advanced topics in chemistry given by guest professors from well-known universities.
01280001.name: Advanced Topics in Chemistry 1

01280002.about: Lectures in advanced topics in chemistry given by guest professors from well-known universities.
01280002.name: Advanced Topics in Chemistry 2

01280004.about: lectures in advanced topics in chemistry given by guest professors. the syllabus will be presented for approval of the committee for graduate studies, prior to the beginning of the term.
01280004.name: Advanced Topics in Chemistry 4

01280006.about: Advanced course in experimental chemical physics dealing with research subjects from the field of the lecturer expertise. The syllabus will be submitted by the teacher for approval of the committee for graduate studies prior to the beginning of the term.
01280006.name: Advanced Topics in Exper. Physical 1

01280007.about:
studies on advanced research methods in one of the specific fields: analytical chemistry, theoretical chemistry, organic chemicstry, inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, chemical physics, environmental chemistry.
 the project involves the study of advanced laboratory methods, planning of experiments and preparation of a scientific report.
01280007.name: Advanced Research Methods 1

01280008.about:
studies on advanced research methods in one of the specific fields: analytical chemistry, theoretical chemistry, organic chemistry,inoraganic chemistry, physical chemistry, chemical physics, environmental chemistry.
 the project involves study of advanced laboratory methods, planning of fexperiments and preparation of a scientific report.
01280008.name: Advanced Research Methods 2

01280413.about: The seminars cover topics from physical and nalytical chemistry literature, topics that have no direct relationship with the student's research. The object of the seminars is to develop the ability of reading, understanding and criticizing.
01280413.name: Seminar in Physical and Analytical Chemistry

01280713.about: The seminars cover topics from organic and inorganic chemistry literature, topics that have no direct relationship with the student's research. The object of the seminars is to develop the ability of reading, understanding and criticizing.
01280713.name: Seminar in Organic and Inorganic Chemistry

01280718.about: Rational analysis of complex synthetic problems, basic concepts of retrosynthetic analysis and the general strategies for generation of possible synthetic pathways by systematic reduction of molecular complexity. Applications will be provided through synthesis ofnatural products.
01280718.name: Advanced Retrosyntetic Analysis

01280719.about: basic principles in drug discovery, the wide range of molecules such as peptides, peptidomimetics.small molecules and proteins as potential therapeutics against various diseases. various examples of well-known drugs as insulin, hiv protease inhibitors, epo will discuss. the course will cover the discovery processes that lead to a particular drug and how chemistry plays a vital role in this process, chemical synthesis( synthesis, structure based design, etc.). at the end of the course the student will know: 1. the discovery process that lead to new drugs. 2. the contribution of chemistry to these processes. 3. the complexity of the drug discovery proces s. 4. the different research areas that are involved in this process such as targets identification and sturcture activity relationship.
01280719.name: Chemistry in Drug Discovery

01340019.about: Structure and function of amino acids, peptides and proteins, primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary structure of protein, protein folding and chaperones, fibrous, structural and membranal proteins, isolation and analysis of proteins, hemoglobin and allosteric interactions, cooperatively, enzyme catalysis, kinetics, regulation and inhibitors, coenzymes and cofactors, biochemistry of lipids and carbohydrates.
01340019.name: Introduction to Biochemistry and Enzymology

01340020.about: Variability, principles of Darwinism, Mendelian inheritance, chromosomes, life cycles, recombination, chromosomal aberrations and genome structure.  Gene-enzyme theory, chemical basis of inheritance. Replication of mutations and mutagenesis, the genetic code. Chromosome structure, genes and differentiation.  Specific problems in human genetics.  Polymorphism, genetic engineering.
01340020.name: General Genetics

01340039.about: Bacteriophages: structure, lytic cycle, identification and counting. A detailed discussion of the properties of the phages: T2, T4,T6, P1 and Lambda. Animal viruses: structure, lytic cycle, identification and counting. Defense mechanisms against virus infections. A detailed discussion of properties of viruses of the families: picornavituses, papovaviruses and retroviruses (including HIV). Infection cycle of prions.
01340039.name: Molecular Virology

01340040.about: Plant cell, Plant-water relations, Plant growth and development, hormonal regulation, plant hormones, auxins, gibberellins, abscisic acid, ethylene, metabolism, photosynthesis, light reactions, Calvin cycle, photobiological processes, photoperidism, flowering, fruit ripening and plant senescence.
01340040.name: Molecular Plant Physiology

01340058.about: Biology and the research approach, water and the environment, macromolecules, chemical evolution. The central dogma-nucleic acids, replication, transcription, the genetic code and translation, DNA technology and genomics, the prokaryotic cell, membtanes- structure and function, metabolism and energy, the eukaryotic cell-organells, mitosis and meiosis, from cell to tissue, differentiation, thebasis of evolution, taxonomy phylogenetics and systematics.
01340058.name: Biology 1

01340069.about: a. morphogenesis. pattern formation. gardients and morphogenetic fields. morphogenes, master genes, and homeotic genes. establishment of the body axis from the nematode to the mouse. cell-cell interaction and apoptosis in development. b. differentiation and organogenesis. regulation of gene expression during development. regeneration. cell fate and lineage. determination and differentiation. organogenesis of sex organs, eyes, limbs and fingers. c. evolution and development. from similar gene pools to different organisms. evolutionary changes in developmental genes and the regulation of gene expression.
01340069.name: Developmental Biology

01340082.about: Nucleic acids: building blocks, DNA structure, chromatin structure in eukaryotic cells and DNA packaging. DNA replication, repair and recombination - mechanism and enzymes involved in the process. mRNA transcription. - basic mechanism and elements involved. RNA processing and spilicing. Translation - the genetic code, tRNA, ribosome structure. Translation initiation, elongation and termination.
01340082.name: Molecular Biology

01340111.about: Introduction to the animal kingdom. Invertebrates-protozoa, flat and segmented worms, arthropods, echinoderms. Chordates and vertebrates - origin and basic features, development of body plans, filtration and food processing systems, urogenital system, and circulatory system. The amphioxus as a template. Basic histology (cell types and tissue organization). Evolution and structure- function relationships of the digestive, urogenital, respiratory, and central nervous systems, sense organs. Principles of embryonic development. Evolution of the integument and its derivates (scales, hair and feathers).
01340111.name: Zoology

01340113.about: Catabolism and anabolism, the metabolic pathway. Regulaton mechanisms in metabolic pathway. Major pathway: glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, oxidative phosphorylation and photosynthesis, the pentose phosphate pathway, gluconeogenesis. Metabolic energy stores: glycogen, fatty acids and hormonal regulation of their synthesis and breakdown. Metabolism under stress conditions: hunger and diabetes. Metabolism of phospholipids, cholesterol, amino acids and nucleotides. Integration of cellular metabolism.
01340113.name: Metabolic Pathways

01340117.about: Cellular physiology: structure and function of pumps, carriers and channels. System physiology: the kidney-filtration and reabsorption, regulation of blood volume and blood pressure. Blood-composition and roles, erythropoiesis, platelets and coagulation. The nervous system - the central and peripheral systems, excitatory and inhibitory neurons, supporting cells and myelination, action potential and synaptic transmission. Muscels - smooth and striated muscle, mechanism of striated muscle contraction, the neuro-muscular synapse, regulation of contraction of smooth muscle and heart muscle.
01340117.name: Physiology

01340119.about: Regulation of gene expression in prokaryotes and eukaryotes: control of transcription-regulatory cis elements, transcription factors, chromatin  modification. Alternative splicing. Translation regulation. Regulatory non-coding RNA. Genome structure. Coordinared expression og gene families. Role of repetitive sequences and mobile elements in gene expression and phenotypic diversity. Genome-wide regulation. Integrative view on different regulation systems and its phenotype implication.
01340119.name: Regulation of Gene Expression

01340121.about: The course describes basic principles in general microbiology. Major topics discussed are: the historical roots of microbiology, innovations and new techniques in modern microbiology, structure and function of prokaryotic cells, the influence of chemophysical conditions on microorganism growth and survival, drug resistance, metabolic diversity, microbial ecology, structure, function and infectivity of viruses and bacteriophages, genetic material transfer in bacteria, bacterial spores, microorganism evolution and systematics, immunology and pathogenicity.
01340121.name: Microbiology and Virology

01340123.about: The purpose of the seminar is to develop reading comprehension and critical analysis of scientific texts. Discussions will be held in small groups. At the end of the semester the students will have to summarize their work in writing and present it to their fellowstudents and teachers. The topics of the seminar will be published at the beginning of each semester.
01340123.name: Seminar in Biology 1

01340124.about: The purpose of the seminar is to develop reading comprehension and critical analysis of scientific texts. Discussions will be held in small groups. At the end of the semester the students will have to summarize their work in writing and present it to their fellowstudents and teachers. The topics of the seminar will be published at the beginning of each semester.
01340124.name: Seminar in Biology 2

01340125.about: The purpose of the seminar is to develop reading comprehension and critical analysis of scientific texts. Discussions will be held in small groups. At the end of the semester the students will have to summarize their work in writing and present it to their fellowstudents and teachers. The topics of the seminar will be published at the beginning of each semester.
01340125.name: Seminar in Biology 3

01340127.about: The course teaches the basic principles and selected topics in modern biology. The definition of life. The cell as the basic unit of the living organism. The materials of the living cell, basic metabolic process. Examples of physiological systems. The genetic code and gene expression. The human genome. Genetic engineering. animal cloning. Stem cells. Genetic therapy.
01340127.name: Topics in Biology

01340128.about: Structure and function of membranes (rehearsal). The cytoskeleton-cytoskeleton proteins and their cellular role, polar cells. Cellular organelles: the endoplasmic reticulum- contranslational translocation, quality control and degradation of defective proteins by the ubiquitin system. The Golgi and endosome systems, mechanisms of vesicular transport. Post- translational transport of proteins to the nucleus andmitochondria. From cell to tissues: cell - cell and cell-matrix (ECM) adhesion. ECM role in intercellular communication. Cell to cell communication- introduction, cell surface receptors and signaling pathways of GPCR.RTKS. Cell cycle control-molecu lar mechanisms.
01340128.name: Cell Biology

01340133.about: The evidence for evolution of life through its pattern of process. diversification of bacteria, archaea, and eukaryotes with a focus on animals and human evolution. Natural selection, genetic drift, and population structure. measuring selection on variation and its interaction with other forces. Evolution of multicellularity, development, genetic systems and novelty.
01340133.name: Evolution

01340134.about: The course includes labs in the following subjects: microscopy, protozoa, flat and segmented worms, arthropods, echinoderms, chordates (amphioxus and sea lamprey), vertebrate anatomy (shark, amphibians, birds and mammals) and the structure-function relationships of body systems, embryonic development, cartilage and bone histology, evolutionary adaptations to movement in various animal groups.The lab will be accompanied by histological preparations of various systems in various groups.
01340134.name: Laborratory of the Animal Kingdom

01340137.about: the course covers: a. the differences between embryonic stem cells and adult stem cells, their characterization, and conditions fortheir growth. b. stem cell manipulation and differentiation and their use in tissue engineering and cell therapy. c. reprogramming of somatic cells into multipotent cells. d. cancer stem cells.
01340137.name: Stem Cells

01340140.about: Regulation of cellular pathways by the ubiquitin-proteasome system for protein degradation. How modifications by ubiquitin or ubiquitin-like modifiers alter protein recognition, interactions, fate. System components, their structure and mode of action. Proteasomemechanism, an energy-dependent proteolysis machine. Involvement in transcription regulation, genome integrity, cell cycle control, cancer, neurodegeneration, immune response.
01340140.name: Ubiquitin and Protein Turnover

01340141.about: THIS COURSE SHOWS HOW A LARGE RANGE OF BIOLOGICAL PROBLEMS CAN BE APPROACHED AND SOLVED USING FUNDAMENTAL IDEAS AND CONCEPTS FROM COMPUTER SCIENCE: BIOLOGICAL NETWORKS ALGORITHMS, BIOLOGICAL SEQUENCE ANALYSIS, BIOLOGICAL IMAGE PROCESSING, ANALYZING DATA LISTS, DYNAMIC SYSTEMS SIMULATION, AND MORE. THIS IS NOT A PROGRAMMING COURSE, YET THE POPULAR PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE PYTHON WILL BE TAUGHT ANDUSED.
01340141.name: Computational Biology

01340142.about: Use of light microscope, Drosophila and Mendelian analysis, inheritance of sex-linked genes, visualization of meiosis, mitosis and human chromosomes, a 3-point cross, isolation of lethal mutations and translocations, lac operon phenotype, analysis of trp operon mutants, complemention in yeast, Luria-Delbruck experiment, making phade hybrids, physical mapping of DNA, isolation suppressors, isolation of C. elegans developmental mutants.
01340142.name: Molecular Genetics Laboratory

01340143.about: Amino acids separation and characterization, protein isolation and separation, expression of a recombinant protein, factors influencing enzymatic reactions, denaturation and refolding of enzymes, glycolysis and respiration, bioenergetics, analysis and separation of lipids.
01340143.name: Biochemistry and Metabolism Lab.

01340144.about: Amylase production in germination, water potential, control of growth by auxin, identification of auxin and ethylene mutants and genotyping, degradation of a transcription factor in response to auxin, regulation of stomatal opening, light reactions of photosynthesis.
01340144.name: Plant Physiology Lab

01340145.about: Acquiring basic principles in pharmacology by defining drugs, and studying molecular mechanisms. Regulation stages of drug development. Toxicity-characterization and quantification. Principles in pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics and pharmacogenetics. Nervous system-neuropharmacological processes, receptors and neurotransmitters, agonistic and antagonistic drugs. Pharmacological thinking using fundamental groups of drugs. Drug abuse and recovery.
01340145.name: The Science of Drugs

01340147.about: this course explores the metabolic relationships between muscle, liver and fat, in human health and disease, the pathways that contribute to pathogenesis and the key factors that can be targeted therapeutically. in addition, muscle wasting by the ubiquitin-proteasome system and autophagy, and metabolism of carbohydrates, lipids and proteins will be discussed in the context of satiety  and human disorders including, diabetes, obesity, hyperlipidemia and starvation.
01340147.name: Metabolism and Human Disease

01340150.about: Students plan and carry out a research project mentored by a faculty member. Scope: 195 hours. The student will submit a 15 page scientific report, including the relevant background, to the mentor and faculty teaching committee. The course is for students accepted to the excellence track.
01340150.name: Research Project for the Excellence Prog

01340151.about: Three aspects of RNA function will be covered: 1. Enzyme (ribozyme) with diverse catalytic roles and step in establishment of life on earth. 2. A regulator of gene expression (with emphasis on non-coding RNAs such as piRNA, lncRNA, snoRNA and tmRNA). 3. An inherited molecule in eukaryotes, with transgenerational impact.
01340151.name: The Modern Rna World

01340153.about: Distribution and abundance of organisms.  Adaptation of organisms to their habitats.  Population growth and regulation.  Biologicalinteractions in the ecosystem.  Energy flow in the ecosystem. Species diversity.  Succession.  The ecology of human populations.
01340153.name: Ecology

01340154.about: IN THIS COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE EXPOSED TO BASIC STATISTICAL CONCEPTS AND METHODS FOR DATA ANALYSIS. SPSS STATISTICAL SOFTWARE WILL BE USED TO CARRY OUT THE VARIETY OF DATA ANALYSES. THE FOLLOWING TOPICS ARE COVERED IN THIS COURSE: GRAPHICAL DESCRIPTION OF DATA, MEASURES OF CENTER AND SPREAD, STATISTICAL TESTS OF HYPOTHESES, ESTIMATING PARAMETERS USING CONFIDENCE INTERVALS, EXAMINING RELATIONS AMONG CATEGORICAL AND QUANTITATIVE VARIABLES, FITTING LINEAR REGRESSION MODELS, ONE WAY ANOVA, RANDOM VARIABLES, BINOMIAL DISTRIBUTION, CONDITIONAL PROBABILITY.
01340154.name: Biostatistics for Biologists

01340155.about: Introduction: review of hormones and their biological activities, receptors and singaling mechanisms. Eicosanouds. Hormones and protein kinases in the regulation of transcription. Hypothalamus. Pituitary. Production and effects of hormones regulating metabolism, water and electrolytes, and reproduction.
01340155.name: Endocrinology

01340156.about: INTRODUCTION TO THE BASIC PHYSICAL PRINCIPLES GOVERNING CELLULAR DYNAMICS. RANDOM WALKS, DIFFUSION AND FRICTION. ROLE OF ENTROPIC, ELECTROSTATIC AND MECHANICAL FORCES IN BIOLOGY. PROCESSIVE ENZYMES AS "MOLECULAR MOTORS". METHODS OF SINGLE MOLECULE MANIPULATION AND ANALYSIS, AND APPLICATION TO THE STUDY OF BIOLOGICAL SYSTEMS.
01340156.name: Molecular Biophysics

01340157.about: THE COURSE WILL COVER BASIC TOPICS IN NEUROBIOLOGY: INTRODUCTION TO DIFFERENT BRAIN CELL POPULATIONS, NEURONAL FUNCTION AND ITS TRANSLATION TO HIGHER BRAIN FUNCTIONS (LEARNING AND MEMORY), MOLECULAR ASPECTS OF NEURODEGENERATIVE DISEASES, BRAIN DEVELOPMENT, AND IMMUNE-BRAIN INTERACTIONS. WE WILL DISCUSS STATE-OF-THE ART RESEARCH METHODS IN THE FIELD.
01340157.name: Introduction to Neurobiology

01340158.about: the course introduces basic techniques in bioinformatics, including ways to retrieve big data in biology and medicine. the course will focus on available tools to solve problems in modern biology. students will learn ways to represent and search for protein and nucleic-acid sequences, predict their structures and analyze biological networks.
01340158.name: Tools in Bioinformatics for Life Science

01340159.about: THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON MOLECULAR METHODS FOR MANIPULATING THE GENETIC MATERIAL (DNA) IN VARIOUS ORGANISMS. THE COURSE WILL COVER THREE MAIN TOPICS: 1. GENETIC ENGINEERING, 2. GENETIC EDITING, AND 3. SYNTHETIC BIOLOGY. IN THE COURSE, STUDENTS WILL USE MOLECULAR METHODS TO CREATE COMPLEX PLASMIDS. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS WILL USE CRISPR METHODS TO EDIT DNA IN HUMAN CELLS. STUDENTS WILL EXPERIENCE USING ADVANCED MOLECULAR METHODS AND WORK WITH MAMMALIAN AND BACTERIA CELLS.
01340159.name: LABORATORY IN GENETIC ENGINEERING

01340161.about: THE COURSE WILL EXPOSE THE STUDENTS TO THE MODERN WORLD OF BIOLOGICAL RESEARCH, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON RESEARCH CONDUCTED AT THE TECHNION S FACULTY OF BIOLOGY.
01340161.name: INT. TO CONTEMPORARY RESEARCH IN BIOLOGY

01340163.about: AS CLIMATE CHANGE AND ITS POTENTIAL RISKS  BECOMES VISIBLE   OVER OUR FUTURE! MANY TECHNOLOGIES INCLUDING BIOLOGICAL INNOVATIONS  OFFER POTENTIAL  SOLUTIONS TO MAKE ALL ASPECTS OF OUR LIVES MORE SUSTAINABLE.IN THIS COURSE VARIOUS ADVANCED  BIOLOGICAL TECHNOLOGIESAND THEIR POTENTIAL CONTRIBUTION WILL BE DECCRIBED IN  THE DISCIPLINS OF  FOOD SECURITY!AGRICULTURE-AGRITECH!MEDICINE!ENVIRONMENT! WATER AND ENERGY.
01340163.name: BIOLOGICAL TECHNOL. FOR GLOBAL SUSTAINAB

01360014.about: The course will address novel aspects of molecular biology and their application to modern biotechnology. Main issues are: recent advances in molecular genetics, protein engineering, combinatorial biology and chemistry, the molecular aspects of biological diversity and the method of mimicking biological processes in the test tube. The applications of combinatorial biology and other strategiesof molecular biotechnology for development of novel reagents. The development of new therapeutic and diagnostic agents and their clinical and medical applications.
01360014.name: Development of Novel Biological Drugs

01360022.about: the diversity of mechanisms of signal sensing and responses in microorganisms, using physiological genetic, molecular and genomic approaches. motility in prokaryotes and eukaryotes. chemotaxis and phototaxis in bacteria. bacterial and lower eukaryote photoreceptors, redox and light regulation. circadian clock and its regulation by light in neurospora. phototropism and gravitropism in phycomyces. quorum sensing. sensory histidine kinases.
01360022.name: Sensory Pathways of Microorganisms

01360032.about: topics:  gene network determination,network analysis by graph theory, structure and function of developmental gene networks including case studies from flies,nematodes, and sea urchin, modeling system properties (i.e.,  modularity and robustness), models for morphological evolution by changes to the genetic system.
01360032.name: Systems Biology

01360037.about:
through this course we will learn how to describe biological systems as information processing systems, and how to analyze them mathematically to understand their function. we will learn a framework for analysis of biological network dynamics, study network motifs and their functions, and analyze sensory systems and covalent modification systems. various biological processes will be discussed, including transcription regulation, signal transduction pathways, developmental patterning, neural information processing, and sensory adaptation, using examples in phages, bacteria, yeast, nematodes, fruit flies, and mammalian cells. 
 the course is open for stu dents with background in biology, physics, chemistry, computer science, or engineering. basic calculus knowledge is required. matlab programming will be used but previous experience is not required. students will be evaluated based on homework exercises (30) and final exam (70).
 learning outcomes: by the end of course,, students will:
 1. have basic knowledge of matlab programming, includinghow to numerically solve ode. 
 2. be familiar with various network motifs, such as positive/negative autoregulation, coherent/incoherent fe
01360037.name: SYSTEMS BIOLOGY

01360042.about: this course will review computational methods employed in modeling biological systems. the emphasis will be placed on case studies and classical biological modelling problems. incidentally, the students will be introduced to the process of formulating hypotheses in quantitative terms. the course will rely on hands-on, problem solving approach. all models will be implemented in matlab. lerningoutcomes: 1. familiairty with diffrent types of modelling approaches used to
01360042.name: Computational Modelling in Biology

01360088.about: Molecular aspects of human genetics through various genetic diseases. The following topics are addressed: diseases linked to X-chromosome, diseases associated with imprinted genes, tri-nucleotide expansion diseases, metabolic, mitochodrial and multifactorial traits and diseases and cancer genetics. Genetics of behaior, syndromes associated with disorders in embryonic development, sex determination, the human genome project and techniques for mapping and cloning genes and detecting mutations.
01360088.name: Molecular Genetics of Man

01360105.about: Introduction. Gametogenesis. Cleavage. Gastrulation. Neurolation. Ectodermis, mesodermis, endodermis. Cell rate determination by cytoplasm and nucleus. Interaction between cells and tissues. Developmental regulation on gene expression. Regulation at the transcriptional, processing and translational levels. Cell-cell interaction. Morphogenesis. Hormones and development. Drosophila embryogenesis. Sex determination. Evolution and development.
01360105.name: Molecular Cellular Biology of Development

01360158.about:
the course introduces basic techniques in bioinformatics, including ways to retrieve and analyze big-data in biology and medicine. the course will focus on available tools to solve problems in modern biology. students will learn ways to represent and search for protein and nucleic-acid sequences, predict structures and analyze biological networks.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the coursethe studetns will be able to:
 1. understand the basic principles applied in the main bioinformatics tools.
 2. apply the r programming language and other tools to answer biological and medical questions.
 3. evaluate the results of different bioinformatics tools using the correct statistical methods.
 4. acquire experimental biological dataset and prepare them for analysis. 
 5. design and perform a (small scale) research project in biology using bioinformatics tools and databases.
 6. summarize and present a research project for a professional audience.
01360158.name: TOOLS IN BIOINFORMATICS FOR LIFE SCIENCE

01360203.about: photosynthesis in a variety of marine organisms emphasing the light in the marine environment, unorganic carbon sources, characteristics of photosynthetic organisms, light and carbon exploitation, marine habitats and adaptations of marine vegetation to ambient conditions and tide schedule.
01360203.name: Marine Photosynthesis

01360204.about: aspects of the taxonomy, biology and ecologyof reef-building corals, including: evolution and taxonomy of stony corals, coral reef geology and paleoclimate in the gulf of eilat, processes affecting community structure, artificial reefs, status of coral reefs in eilat and anthropogenic impacts.
01360204.name: Biology of Corals

01360205.about: understanding the status of the micro world within the macro one. topics: sampling methods, isolation and enrichment, identification and quantification of microorganisms in open waters and salt ponds, molecular tools to characterize the population variability andits physiological conditions, oceanographic processes, primary and secondary productivity, control mechanisms and adaptations to stressful environments and theis relations to global changes and human influence on marine systems.
01360205.name: Marine Microbiology

01360206.about: the plankton structure, its adaptations to pelagic life and the taxonomy of the phytoplankton and zooplankton in the eilat bay. topics: aspects in the ecology of plankton distribution,(migration, feeding habits), the planktonic foodchain and the relations betweenthe plankton and the coral reef. plankton sampling methods and its preparation for analysis. advanced acoustic methods for the study of plankton.
01360206.name: Marine Plankton

01380000.about:
introduce concepts surrounding the translation of an idea from the lab to the development of a viable product in the pharmaceutical, medical device and biotech industries. demonstrating different approaches towards translational research. overview of the life sciences ecosystem, from start-ups to large companies, and the role of supporting organizations. 
leraning outcomes: the students will understand the stages required to bring an idea in the life sciences to an approved product, the different approaches towards development of a biomedical product and the roles of different organizations along the way. they will also learn to appreciate the uniquene ss of the israeli biotech ecosystem.
01380000.name: From Basic Science to the Biotech Ecosys

01380002.about: The course will examine the molecular changes that lead to cellular transformation. It will also focus on tumor progression and on genes that participate in the processes of metastasis and invasion. finally, the causes for drug resistance in cancer therapy, and new approaches to cancer  will be discussed.
01380002.name: Molecular Basis of Cancer

01380005.about: the course goal is to train students to investigate the biological role of proteins using structural bioinformatics tools. the aim is to understand the relationship between sequence, structure and function. the course includes methods description and practical examples. the students will learn to perform tasks like function prediction, modeling, etc.
01380005.name: Tools for Structural Bioinformatics

01380008.about: principles of flow-cytometry systems: liquid system, lasers, optical components, electronic components, signal identification and detection. fluorochromes: fluorescent proteins, antibodies for flow-cytometry, dna and rna dyes, cell cycle analysis, and compensation. safety. the principle of cell sorting. analysis: software for acquisitions and analysis, gates, statistics, results display. facsapplications in research, clinic and industry. learning results: 1. the student willl understand how flow cytometry systems operate. 2. the student will be able to plan and execute an experiment in flow cytometry, using instruments available at the lse core facili ty. 3. the student will understand the data collected by the flow cytometer and will be able to perform basic analysis
01380008.name: Cell Charaterization and Separation by Facs

01380009.about:
demonstrating the effectiveness and safety of new medical products is a critical part of the product development process. clinical trials and regulatory approval for new medical technologies are key components of successful product commercialization. this course discusses the basics of planning and performing clinical trials along with the global regulatory framework. 
learning outcomes: students are expected to understand the different types of study design, study protocol structure and content as well as the requirements for planning, conducting and completing a clinical trial. students will also gain basic knowledge of the principles and requirement s of worldwide regulations that govern the design, fabrication, and maintenance of medical products.
01380009.name: Clinical Studies and Regulation

01380012.about: gene editing by crispr-cas revolutionized molecular biology, agriculture, and medicine. in this course we will learn about different crispr methods, and how can we apply them to diverse biological systems. we will learn about the considerations when designing crispr-cas9 experiments, and strategies for successful gene editing experiment. learning outcoms: 1. design of crisprko-ki in differentmodel systems, while understanding the necessary considerations, controls, and alternative approaches. 2. knowledge of advanced crispr-cas9 based methods, including crispr large-scale, single-cell, and phenotypic screening. 3. knowledge of the crispr toolbox beyon d the  cut and paste (crispra.i, base editing, fluorescence, crispr-rna and more).
01380012.name: Genome Editing ) Crispr (

01380013.about:
this course will cover main aspects of drug development processes essential in pharmaceutics development. the topics include overview of drug development, intellectual property, clinical and planning trials in pharma. chemistry manufacturing and control, pre-clinical pharmacology, generic drug development,  ntes, personalized medicine and pharmacogenomics biostatistics, technology transfer and commercialization.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will:
 1. understand all stages of drug development 2.have knowledge of the pharmaceutical industry components 3. have nowledge of all the reforms and changes in the industry in the 21st  century such as personalize medicine
01380013.name: Fundamentals in Drug Development

01380018.about: Proteins and peptides characterization, chromatography, electrophoresis, identification, quantification of posttranslatioal modifications, mass spectrometry, interactions between proteins and their ligands, use of stable isotopes, protein chips and bioinformatics. The course will include one week of hands-on lab.
01380018.name: Proteomics

01380021.about: the role of multi-subunit complexes in energy dependent cellular processes. the mechanism of biological motors: methods to convert chemical energy from atp hydrolysis into physical motion. energy dependent conformational changes that control biological processes.overview of biological machines that participate for example in dna replication, muscle contraction, organelle transport, translocation, protein folding and protein degradation.
01380021.name: Biological Machines

01380023.about: Interaction of microorganisms with different environments, interaction of microorganisms with higher organisms. Roles of microorganisms in the biosphere. Microorganisms and current environmental problems, environmental microbial diversity. Microbial photosynthesis and the "new" phototrophs.
01380023.name: Microbial Ecology

01380029.about: a seminar on advanced topics in modern biology. taught by leading scientists and supervised by faculty from the department of biology. the detailed syllabus will be determined by the lecturers and approved by the graduate studies committee.
01380029.name: Advanced Topics in Biology

01380033.about: topics: methods of single-molecule force spectroscopy. the effect of force on thermodynamics and kinetics. mechanical unfolding of biomolecules. the mechano-chemistry of molecular motors.
01380033.name: Mechanical Processes in Biochemistry

01380034.about: Topics: various aspects of ddr such as: sensing and signaling of a DNA damage, cell cycle regulation, epigenetics modifications including changes in histone code and sub-code, double strand break repair (dsbr). Brca1.brca2 role in dsbr repair, cancer formation and treatment.
01380034.name: Cellular Response to Dna Damage

01380038.about: Experimental techniques and concepts that involve nucleic acids, and their implementation in research. The techniques used in the study of regulation, expression and function of individual genes, to high-throughput genomics techniques. Learning Outocomes: At the end of the course the student will be able to 1. Apply experimental techniques involving nucliec acids including: cloning, measurement of mrna levels, mapping methylated CPG. 2. Understand and know do genome-wide studies and analyze the results 3. Understand the chip-seq method.
01380038.name: Experimental Approaches in Nucleic Acids

01380039.about: Structure and function of proteins,methods for purification of natural and recombinant proteins, analysis of protein sequence, quantities and patterns of posttranslational modifications, protein-protein interactions and interactions with other ligands, 3d structure determination and prediction, enzyme mechanism, kinetics and inhibition. Learning Outcomes: At the end of the course the student will know 1. How to isolate specific proteins and enzymes using advanced biochemical approaches. 2. How to analyze the kinetic parameters of the enzyme activity. 3. How to define the structure of proteins using x- ray crystallography and to characterize and identit y the purity of the isolated proteins using electrophoresis chromatography and mass spectrometry. Purifications and analyses on their own in their future research.
01380039.name: Advanced Protein Structure and Function

01380045.about: the course will cover the history of poisons and scope of toxicology, exposure routes, the basis of toxic action at cellular and molecular levels covering the absorption, distribution, metabolism and elimination of toxicants, types and mechanisms of toxic action,carcinogenesis, environmental toxicology as well as human and ecological risk assessment. by the end of this course the student will be able to: by the end of this course the student will be able to:ical terms and 1. define toxicology and recognize the basic toxicological terms and conceptsify and discuss in detail the various mechanisms of toxicity 2. classify and discuss in detail the variou s mechanisms of toxicity 3. identify the toxic hazard of poisons on different organsexecution, 4. discuss basic concepts that are crucial for the design, execution, and interpretation of toxicology studies 5. describe the main u.s. and global regulatory agencies (e.g. osha, fda, cpsc, epa, etc.)
01380045.name: Principles of Toxicology

01380047.about:
THE COURSE WILL INTRODUCE THE STUDENTS TO MODERN BIOINFORMATICS PROGRAMMING, ACCESSING PUBLIC GENOMIC DATA AND PERFORMING STATE-OF-THE-ART GENOMIC COMPUTATIONAL ANALYSES. THROUGHOUT THE COURSE, THE STUDENTS WILL EXPERIENCE ANALYZING DIFFERENT TYPES OF GENOME-SCALE DATA, INCLUDING GENE EXPRESSION, EPIGENETICS AND SINGLE-CELL DATA, WHILE LEARNING TOPICS IN STATISTICS, MACHINE-LEARNING, VISUALIZATION AND REPRODUCIBILITY.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:  AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. CODE IN R AND USE DIFFERENT LIBRARIES TO PERFORM ADVANCED ANALYSES. 2. DOWNLOAD DIFFERENT TYPES OF GENOMIC DATA FROM PUBLIC RESOURCES, RUN A COMPLETE ANALYTIC PIPELINE AND EXTRACT INSIGHTS FROM THE DATA._
 3. USE STATISTICAL TOOLS TO EXTRACT INSIGHTS THAT ARE ROBUST AND SIGNIFICANT.
01380047.name: GENOMIC DATA SCIENCE

01380049.about:
advanced microscopy methods in life science research, including technology and applications. understanding basic concepts in optics, fluorescence, image analysis and processing. an array of florescent detection methods, in living cells, of dna, rna and protein will be presented, emphasizing specific examples from recent studies at the single-molecule resolution.
 at the end of the course, thestudents will be able to:
 1. explain how the microscope works and to self-operate an optical microscope for his research. 2. design and perform imaging in cell-biology with the understanding of the factors that affect the sample preparation and the imaging proces s.
 3.  compare between different methods of sample preparation for imaging, and define the best methods for his research.
 4. compare different methods of advanced microscopy techniques, and define the right method for the research. 5. analyze the obtained results with advanced image analysis software.
01380049.name: Advanced Imaging Techniques in Molecular Biology

01380060.about: Research project on a specific topic in biochemistry, molecular biology genetics, cell biology, botany, zoology or ecology.  The project will involve study of advanced laboratory methods, planning of experiments and preparation of a scientific report.
01380060.name: Research Project 1

01380061.about: Research project on a specific topic in biochemistry, molecular biology genetics, cell biology, botany, zoology or ecology.  The project will involve study of advanced laboratory methods, planning of experiments and preparation of a scientific report.
01380061.name: Research Project 2

01380069.about:
fundamentals of advanced microscopy methods! including super-resolution techniques! as well as their applications. the course will provide basic concepts in light microscopy! understanding of the optics! fluorescence and filters! parameters of digital imaging andimage analysis! and will present advanced applications of light microscopy. a wide array of methods for tagging different molecules(dna! rna! protein! metabolites a and ions) for fluorescent detection in living cells will be presented with emphasis on specific examples from recent research works at the single-molecule resolution. the students will learn image processing! segmentation and co-l ocalization analysis techniques as well as photo-manipulation and photoactivation in fluorescence microscopy! principles of live and fixed cells  sample preparation for imaging.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. understand and interpret how different microscopic systems work.
 2. plan imaging experiments in cell biology.
 3. compare different methods for staining cells and a variety of molecules.
 4. compare advanced methods of optical microscopy! including super-resolution methods.
 5
01380069.name: LIGHT IMAGING TECHNIQUES IN MOLECULAR

01380074.about:
understanding fundamental concepts of the physico-chemistry of protein 3d-structure and the manipulation of three-dimensional structures with chimerax. familiarity with research methods in structural biology and prediction of protein binding sites and activity! including a comprehensive and in-depth understanding of the algorithms. understand of the basics of ai technology and its applicationin protein and complex 3d-modeling. skillful application of these methods and their integration in research! including selected examples of interesting and up-to-date cases. 
 learning outcomes: upon completion of the course! the student will be able to:
 1. work with three-dimensional protein structures for the purpose of interpreting results of their research.

 2. plan and conduct computational experiments for predicting protein activity and modeling in structural biology! while understanding all the factors that impact the calculations! while providing a detailed understanding of the results.__
 3. compare different methods for predicting protein activity and assessing which method is more suitable for their research._
 4. to use advanced ai methods for protein 3d structure modeling a
01380074.name: STRUCTURAL BIOINFORMATICS

01380083.about: lectures on recent research in biochemistry, biophysics, molecular biology, immunology, cell biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, etc. each student will submit a written work at the end of the semester, which will summarize one of the studies discussed inthe course, by writing an opinion.perspective.commentary paper of 4-6 pages including an abstract, introduction, body, conclusion and a bibliography. attendance is mandatory. learning outcome: at the end of the course, the student should understand the fundamental principal which endow materials with special physical properties (e.g., discrete electronic state, long coherence time) that are su itable for quantum information or memory devices. furthermore, the student will be acquainted with fabrication procedures that control the physical properties of materials with potential application for quantum technology.  the students will also learn about various physical methodologies most suitable for characterization of optical and magneto-optical properties, and will be aware of the challenges and obstacles for implementation of artificial materials in quantum technologies.
01380083.name: Current Topics in Biology 1

01380084.about:
lectures on recent research in biochemistry, biophysics, molecular biology, immunology, cell biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, etc. each student will submit a written work at the end of the semester, which will summarize one of the studies discussed inthe course, by writing an opinion.perspective.commentary paper of 4-6 pages including an abstract, introduction, body, conclusion and a bibliography. attendance is mandatory. learning outcomes: 
 in the end of this course, the student will be able to: 1. follow ahigh-level scientific lecture given in english 2. summarize a scientific lecture as a scientific paper, written in english.
01380084.name: Current Topics in Biology 2

01380085.about:
lectures on recent research in biochemistry, biophysics, molecular biology, immunology, cell biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, etc. each student will submit a written work at the end of the semester, which will summarize one of the studies discussed inthe course, by writing an opinion.perspective.commentary paper of 4-6 pages including an abstract, introduction, body, conclusion and a bibliography. attendance is mandatory learning outcomes 
 in the end of this course, the student will be able to: 1. follow a high-level scientific lecture given in english 2. summarize a scientific lecture as a scientific paper, written in english.
01380085.name: Current Topics in Biology 3

01380087.about:
lectures on recent research in biochemistry, biophysics, molecular biology, immunology, cell biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, etc. each student will submit a written work at the end of the semester, which will summarize one of the studies discussed inthe course, by writing an opinion/perspective/commentary paper of 4-6 pages including an abstract, introduction, body, conclusion and a bibliography. attendance is mandatory learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will know: 1. follow a high level scientific lecture given in english.
 2. summarize a scientific lecture as a scientific presentation in english..
 3. learn about t he latest research developments, technologies and scientific systems in various fields in biology. 
 4. learn about different scientific, perspectives and ideas. 
 5. learn how to ask a scientific question, hypothesize and test the hypothesis.
01380087.name: CURRENT TOPICS IN BIOLOGY 5

01380088.about:
ectures on recent research in biochemistry, biophysics, molecular biology, immunology, cell biology, genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, etc. each student will submit a written work at the end of the semester, which will summarize one of the studies discussed in the course, by writing an opinion/perspective/commentary paper of 4-6 pages including an abstract, introduction, body, conclusion and a bibliography. attendance is mandator.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will know: 
 1. follow a high level scientific lecture given in english.
 2. summarize a scientific lecture as a scientific paper, written in english.
01380088.name: CURRENT TOPICS IN BIOLOGY 6

01960001.about: Selected topics in continuum mechanics, optimization, etc., emphasizing methods of applied mathematics.
01960001.name: Seminar in Applied Mathematics 2

01960012.about: generalized fourier series and sturm-liouville problems, self-adjoint and non self-adjoint problems, fredholm alternative theorem, green functions and their application. bessel and legendre equations. solutions of pde using transformation methods (laplace and fourier). 1. obtain solvability conditions for non-homogeneous odes with boundary conditions. 2. obtain and use green's functions for odes and pdes. 3. solve pdes using generalized fourier series usind special functions and familiarize with their properties. 4. solveodes and pdes using integral transforms, using special functions.
01960012.name: Analytical Methods for Differential Eqns

01960013.about: 1. numerical linear algebra: svd, least squares, qr decomposition, eigenvalue problems and the qr algorithm. 2. dft.fft: discrete fourier transform, fast fourier transform. 3. numerical methods for odes: initial value problems,one step methods ,consistency.stability.accuracy, multi-step, bdf, runge-kutta methods. learning outcomes: 1. use of algorithms to solve least squares problems and eigenvalue problems. 2. use of spectral methods to solve boundary value problems. 3. development or choice of a suitable numerical scheme for solving a given ode. 4. analysis of the accuracy and stability of a given numerical scheme for odes.
01960013.name: Numerical Analysis

01960014.about:
the first part of the course will be a short introduction to machine learning and the challenges the deep learning revolution of recent years has posed to the classical learning theory. the second and main part of the course will focus solely on the approximationaspect of deep learning.  possible topics include universality of fully connected networks, universality of convolutional networks and invariant networks, approximation rates for smooth functions, relationship between neural networks and more classical function bases (finite elements, splines, wavelets), and ~power of depth~ results which point to functions that can be approximated more effici ently by deep neural nets than by other models. learning outcome: students  who successfully complete this course will be able to:
a. know the basic concepts of machine learning and learning theory. b. be skilled to read a  state of the art research on approximation properties of deep neural networks and will be able to conduct independent research in this field.
01960014.name: DEEP LEARNING AND APPROXIMATION THEORY

01960015.about:
this seminar will expose the students to applications of advanced tools and methods in the research front of exact sciences, engineering, and life sciences. the seminar aims to assist students in the interdisciplinary program in applied math to find a mentor anda research topic. accordingly, each lecture will be given by a different lecturer affiliated with the interdisciplinary program inapplied math and which can serve as a mentor in the program. the lectures will emphasize relevant research projects for graduate students. the course project will focus on one of the research problems presented in the course.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the  course the stueents will be able to:
 1. various mathematical approaches and their application in solving problems in exact sciences, engineering, and life sciences.
 2. research projects conducted at the technion with emphasis on the connection between the experimental phenomena and the mathematical tools used to study them. 
 3. mathematics tools applied in different context. 
 4. interdisciplinary research projects at the technion with emphasis on projects with a substantial quantitative elements.
01960015.name: EXPOSITORY TO APPLIED MATH. RESEARCH

01970007.about:
THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON THE MATHEMATICAL TREATMENT OF A BROAD RANGE OF TOPICS IN QUANTUM INFORMATION FOCUSING ON QUANTUM RESOURCE THEORIES.  TOPICS INCLUDE (BUT NOT LIMITED TO) QUANTUM STATES! QUANTUM CHANNELS! QUANTUM MEASUREMENTS! QUANTUM TELEPORTATION! SUPER-DENSE CODING! COMPLETELY POSITIVE MAPS! NEUMARKIS THEOREM! STINESPRING DILATION THEOREM! CHOI-JAMIOLKOWSKI ISOMORPHISM! THE THEORY OF MAJORIZATION! THE PERES-HORODECKI CRITERION FOR SEPARABILITY! LIEB'S THEOREM AND THE STRONG SUBADDITIVITY OF THE VON NEUMANN ENTROPY. THE SECOND PART OF THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON SPECIFIC QUANTUM RESOURCE THEORIES INCLUDING QUANTUM ENTANGLEMENT! QUANTUM ASYMMETRY!  AND QUANTUM THERMODYNAMICS.  THE LATTER TOPICS WILL BE COVERED BOTH IN THE SINGLE-SHOT DOMAIN AND THE ASYMPTOTIC DOMAIN. THE COURSE IS INTENDED FOR BOTH GRADUATE STUDENTS AND SENIOR UNDERGRAD STUDENTS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDETNS WILL KNOW:
 1. QUANTUM FOUNDATIONS AND INFORMATION: STUDENTS WILL DEVELOP A DEEP UNDERSTANDING OF THE FOUNDATIONAL PRINCIPLES AND THE MATHEMATICAL FORMALISM OF QUANTUM MECHANICS! AND HOW THEY UNDERPIN QUANTUM INFORMATION THEORY. 2. ENTANGLEMENT THEORY: STUDENTS WILLMASTER THE
01970007.name: QUANTUM INF. AND RESOURCE THEORIES

01970009.about: Advanced topics in applied mathematics to be selected each time the course is offered.
01970009.name: Selected Topics in Applied Mathematics 2

01970010.about: Selected topics in applied mathematics. To be determined whenever the course is given.
01970010.name: Selected Topics in Applied Mathematics 3

01970011.about: Selected topics in applied mathematics. To be determined whenever the course is given.
01970011.name: Selected Topics in Applied Mathematics 4

01970014.about:
GENERAL INTRODUCTION TO DEEP LEARNING AND CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS. NEURAL COLLAPSE. FOURIER SIGNAL PROCESSING, WAVELET ANALYSIS, SEMI-DISCRETE WAVELET TRANSFORMS. WAVELET SCATTERING TRANSFORMS: TRANSLATION INVARIANCE, CONTRACTION, ENERGY CONSERVATION, DEFORMATION STABILITY, AND THE RELATION TO GENERAL CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS. WAVELET SCATTERING TRANSFORMS OF STOCHASTIC PROCESSES. GRAPH CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS: GRAPH FOURIER TRANSFORM, SPECTRAL GRAPH CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS, MESSAGE PASSING NETWORKS, AND ANALYSIS OF GRAPH NEURAL NETWORKS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. AANALYZE CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF SIGNAL PROCESSING.
 2. GENERALIZE CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS TO GRAPHS.
 3. READ RESEARCH PAPERS ON ADVANCED TOPICS OFMATHEMATICAL THEORY OF CONVOLUTIONAL NETWORKS._
01970014.name: MATH. THEORY OF CONVOLUTIONAL NEURAL

01980000.about: asymptotic expansions, stokes phenomenon, regular and singular perturbations of algebraic and transcendental equations, dominant balance, local solutions of ordinary differential equations, integrals : watson's lemma, laplace method, fourier-type integrals, stationary phase, steepest descant, nonlocal contributions,matched asymptotic expansions: boundary layers, weak advections, multiple scales: wkb, turning points, poincare-lindstedt, resonance. learning outcomes: the student will be able to obtain systematic approximations.
01980000.name: Asymptotic Methods

01980008.about: Topics to be selected each time the course is offered.
01980008.name: Selected Topics in Applied Mathematics

01980014.about:
the course will expose students to the use of advanced mathematical tools and methods in problems at the forefront of research in exact sciences, engineering and life sciences. each lecture will be given by researcher from a different discipline. at the end of the course, students will write a paper that analyzes the mathematical aspects of scientific articles on one of the research problems that was presented during the course.learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know:
 1. be familiar with a variety of mathematical approaches used in exact sciences, engineering and life sciences to enable the practical application of these appr oaches.
 2. be familiar with the research problems presented in the course, with an emphasis on aspects related to the integration of mathematical tools with empirical phenomena.
01980014.name: Selected Topics in Applied Mathematics 5

02040000.about: A discourse of landscape architectures main approaches and dilemmas in correspondence to other disciplines. First introduction to landscape architects in Israel and abroad. Studying landscape architects unique tools in designing new environments, preserving and restoring existing environments.
02040000.name: Introduction to Landscape Arch

02040004.about: The course is an introduction to all existing knowledge taught in the group of subjects "Garden detailing and construction", from the family of materials design professions and construction technology in landscape architecture. The course will impart basic skills in technical graphic expression, familiarity with scale, materials, technical concepts and basic details, experience in topography and an initial understanding of the process and details of garden planning.
02040004.name: Introduction to Landscape Construction

02040005.about: The course deals with topographic design in site developments. Lectures and class exercises will introduce landform, land structureand land weathering process and deal with the mapping, design and technical expression of topographic manipulations such as planes,walls, roads, terraces, grading and drainage, as well as cut-and fill plans and calculation.
02040005.name: Landscape Construction 1

02040006.about: Studying ornamental plants as a language and as a design tool for landscape architects. Studying plants' commune and representativeplants according to botanical, ecological, agro-technical and gardening groups.Including field trips that accomplishing the studying course.
02040006.name: Plants in Landscape 1

02040007.about: The students will learn about vegetation as part of a planning approach for the design and restoration of the open space. Emphasizing the aesthetic, experiential, functional, ecological and engineering roles of plants. The students will learn to Construct a master plan and defining planning principles for vegetation on a wide regional and national scale and in various functions. Construction of detailed vegetation plans, at varying kilometers, including plant registration and maintenance guidelines.
02040007.name: Plants in Landscape 3

02040060.about: Introduction with the basic concepts in landscape architecture. The project will underscore typical methods and work processes in the profession, including dealing with the problem of scale, and the use of land, vegetation and topography to create open spaces. The short projects will include field analysis, preparation of a program and proposal of a general physical solution for unbuilt areas. The project will be carried out as an individual work for each student.
02040060.name: Landscape Architecture Studio 10

02040061.about: The course will provide the tools and the ability to deal with the planning and design of a site in an existing urban space, with a broad view of the context and the urban environment. The studio will be built in stages, from a master plan to the construction of a design program for a selected space, and will include expending and intervening in existing buildings, organizing pedestrian and vehicle traffic, surface runoff, the urban heat island (UHI), materiality and more.
02040061.name: Landscape Architecture Studio 20

02040062.about: PLANNING AND DESIGN OF OPEN SPACES IN THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT. EMPHASIS WILL BE PUT ON THE SITE PLANNING FOR HOUSING AND NEIGHBORHOOD, AND THE COORDINATION AMONG DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF PLANNING AND BUILDING THROUGH THE PROCESS OF SITE DEVELOPMENT. THIS WILL BE AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT PROJECT.
02040062.name: Landscape Architecture Studio 30

02040063.about: Planning open spaces in an urban/rural space with an emphasis on knowing the various components of the system, their roles and their connections to the planning space and to the community. The project will include the preparation of plans tailored to the apparent needs, while taking into account the political, environmental, social, cultural and scenic context.
02040063.name: Landscape Architecture Studio 04

02040064.about: DETAILED PLANNING OF AN AREA UP TO 2500 DUNAMS WITH THE EMPHASIS ON THE NATURAL CONDITIONS AS A CRITERIA OF THE PHYSICAL SOLUTION. THE EXERCISE WILL GIVE SOLUTIONS FOR DIFFERENT ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING THE CIRCULATION SYSTEM AS PART OF THE PROCESS OF NATURAL SYSTEMS ANALYSIS AND SITE EVALUATION FOR DIFFERENT PURPOSES. THIS WILL BE AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT PROJECT.
02040064.name: Landscape Architecture Studio 50

02040065.about: PHYSICAL ANALYSIS OF A LANDSCAPE OF REGIONAL SCALE FOR USE IN A NATURAL MANNER, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE AREA AS A BASIS FOR USE AND CONSERVATION.
