THE EXERCISE WILL INCLUDE AN EXAMINATION OF THE NATURAL SYSTEMS OF THE REGION, AN ANALYSIS OF ITS RESOURCES FROM THE POINT OF VIEW OF SUITABILITY FOR THE DESIRED LAND USES, AND A PREPARATION OF PRELIMINARY LAND USE PLAN FOR THE REGION.
02040065.name: Landscape Architecture 60

02040066.about: THE OBJECTIVE OF THE FINAL PROJECT IS TO ENABLE THE STUDENT TO EXAMINE HIS DESIGN ABILITIES WHILE DEVELOPING AND APPLYING A CLEAR CONCEPT. EACH STUDENT WILL IDENTIFY A DESIGN PROBLEM, PREPARE A LITERATURE SURVEY, SELECT A SITE FOR THE PROJECT, ANALYZE NATURAL, ENVIRONMENTAL AND LANDSCAPE COMPONENTS, FORMULATE DESIGN OBJECTIVES, PREPARE A PROGRAM AND A PLANNING PROCESS. THIS WILL BE AN INDIVIDUAL STUDENT PROJECT.
02040066.name: Landscape Architecture Studio 70

02040090.about: Development of the landscape from earliest times to the beginning of the 11th century. The connections between cultures. The role and the function of open spaces in various cultures.
02040090.name: History of Landscape Architecture 1

02040091.about: Fundamentals of the study of  landscape development. Changes in landscape from the 11th until the 20th century. Development of the form and function of planned open spaces from the Middle Ages to the present century.
02040091.name: History of Landscape Architecture 2

02040150.about: An introduction to the science of ecology, evolution and ecology of nature conservation. In this course, we will review the different levels of complexity in ecology, starting from the level of species and environment to the levels of population, community and ecosystem. We will encounter and recognize the main ecological challenges in Israel and around the world. We will experience ecological research work and learn about nature conservation in Israel.
02040150.name: Introduction to Landscape Ecology

02040152.about: Recognizing and understanding the landscapes of the state of Israel and the processes of their formation. Analysis of the components of the landscape and their forms, and assessment of their sensitivity to changes caused by the forces of nature and human activity. Key factors that create the Israeli landscape: geology, climate, geomorphology, plant and animal systems and humans, past and present. An ample space will be allocated for to field excursions.
02040152.name: Landscape Interpretation

02040202.about: Plant design process as part of comprehensive landscape design. Emphasizing functional, experiential and compositional considerations in the design of small scale multiuse private or public sites, locations and climates. Various focused design exercises with further elaboration of plant communities.
02040202.name: Plants in Landscape 2:Basics of Design

02040204.about: Theoretical familiarity and practical experience with the GIS geographic information system - in the context of the field of training. The practice will take place in an ARCGIS environment. Main topics: methods of representation and questioning of spatial information, spatial analysis functions, computed cartography, reception and database building, use of GPS technology.
02040204.name: Introduction to Gis

02040401.about: The course provides an introduction to generic garden details, accessibility and safety standards and building materials. The course develops design skills on a detailed scale, manual and computerized sketching, an understanding of construction methods and technical concepts related to development work.
02040401.name: Landscape Construction 2

02040403.about: The course includes a semester long project, that includes preparing a complete set of working drawings. The project will include the followig: 1. Title sheet with location map. 2.  Layout and dimensioning plan. 3. Finished grading and drainage plan. 4. Rough grading plan with earthwork calculations. 5. Construction details. 6. Planting plan. 7. Irrigation plan. 8. Lighting plan. This projectwill be carried out by each student individually.
02040403.name: Landscape Construction 3 - Final Project

02040406.about: The course will include topics relevant to the construction of a small building by landscape architects (according to the particular operations), including the coordination of systems. The students will learn design, constructive principles such as forces, momentousness and basic properties of materials. The course will review the principles of mechanical systems and the shape of buildings. Emphasis will be placed on the connection between ground and structure by various solutions, such as retaining walls.
02040406.name: Theory of Structure for Landscape Arch.

02040407.about: THE COURSE TEACHES SKILL IN TOPOGRAPHIC DESIGN AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THREE-DIMENSIONAL PERCEPTION. THE COURSE DEALS WITH READING AND PLANNING TOPOGRAPHY LINES, GRADIENT ANALYSIS, LANDSCAPE DESIGN USING EARTHWORKS AND STRUCTURAL MEANS, ACQUAINTANCE WITH DRAINAGE ISSUES AND TRANSPORT OF RUNOFF WATER, USING DIVERSE ANALYSIS AND PLANNING PROGRAMMING.
02040407.name: DESIGN DEVELOPMENT AND DETAILING 1

02040409.about: THIS COURSE COMPLEMENETS AN INTRODUCTORY COURSE IN LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE. IT AIMS TO EXPAND THE "TOOLBOX" THROUGH EXERCISES TO DEVELOP LITERACY AND CRITICAL THINKING AND ANALYSIS OF SELECTED PROJECTS IN LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE.
02040409.name: LANDSCAPE READING

02040540.about: The relationship between planning, development and maintenance. Phases of implementation of a garden and its development.  Seasonal, annual and perenial care of open space maintenance. Economical considerations of mintenance of open space.
02040540.name: Maintenance of Green Open Spaces

02040626.about: The aim of the course is to enable the students to develop historical and theoretical tools and textual and research skills related to the final project. The student will identify one planning problem, prepare a theoretical overview of the chosen topic and analyze its components.
02040626.name: Research in Landscape Architecture

02040652.about: issues in representation of the landscape, in landscape architecture and other media. the representation of landscape as derived byideas and world views, and as informed by the character of the medium: painting, photography, litterature, etc. exposure to study of and exercises in the mediums of representation, with emphasis on both conceptual thinking and means of its communication.
02040652.name: Landscape Representation

02040655.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the leader, subject to the approval of the graduate committee, towards the beginning of the semester in which the course is schedules.
02040655.name: Selected Topics in Landscape Archi'__1

02040711.about: Specific design problem in landscape architecture. Details will be specified according to subject. Subject A.
02040711.name: Special Project/Topic in Lands.Arch.-33a

02040716.about: Specific design problem in landscape architecture. Details will be specified according to subject. Subject A.
02040716.name: Special Project/Topic in Lands.Arch.-44a

02040720.about: the syllabus will be determined by the teacher, and approved by the dean before the beginning of the semester.
02040720.name: Selected Topics.Special Project in Landscape Architecture 55B

02040721.about: the syllabus will be determined by the teacher, and approved by the dean before the beginning of the semester.
02040721.name: Selected Top/Special Pr.in La.Ar.33C

02040722.about: Field trip related to historic, cultural and environmental study of selected sites. Visits will include on-site meeting with planners, designers and managers. Participants will submit an exercise before the trip and a final submission.
02040722.name: Field Trip in Landscape Architecture 1

02040724.about: Field trip related to historic, cultural and environmental study of selected sites. Visits will include on-site meeting with planners, designers and managers. participants will submit an exercise before the trip and a final submission.
02040724.name: Field Trip in Landscape Architecture 3

02040725.about: Field trip related to historic, cultural and environmental study of selected sites. Visits will include on-site meeting with planners, designers and managers. Participants will submit an exercise before the trip and a final submission.
02040725.name: Field Trip in Landscape Architecture 4

02050000.about: This course aims to introduce students to the heritage and history of the conservation movement during the modern age. The course examines a broad range of issues, including tangible and intangible values, authenticity and reconstruction as fundamental values, tools for classification and evaluation, documentation, surveys, criteria, and current approaches in conservation, as well as approaches and mechanisms of conservation in Israel from the beginning of the 20th century up to this day.
02050000.name: Introduction to Conservation

02050012.about: The course examines a broad range of issues, ideas, and historical periods, thus serving as an introduction to the Humanities and Social Sciences program taught in our Faculty.
02050012.name: Int.to Arch.and Cultural His.of Mankind

02050017.about: The course introduces the origins and development of modern architecture and the development of modern built and open areas from the Renaissance through the industrial Revolution to the Second World War. The course examines historical and theoretical aspects via analysis of prominent movements, schools of thought, architects, buildings and open spaces.
02050017.name: History of Architecture in Modern Times

02050028.about: Presentation of theories, design methods and tools for evaluating the design process and the architecture. The course follows two trajectories: 1. examining concepts of analysis, program and synthesis of design and methods through an examination of historical methods and technological developments. 2. survey of architectural precedents and their examination, which will exemplify specific design strategies in order to evaluate their physical, material, virtual and environmental qualities.
02050028.name: Design Methods, Theory and Tools

02050096.about: This course examines art history in social, political and cultural context. Students will be introduced to the intellectual historyof architectural research and its evolvement as an independent discipline from art history.
02050096.name: Arch.as Related to the Hist. of Art

02050102.about: The course is intended to introduce students to architectural styles and concepts from Antiquity to the Modern Age, in their historical and cultural context. The course provides an analysis of exemplary buildings and renowned sites from the relevant eras, while trying to characterize typical building methods, architectural concepts, and urban design strategies. The review includes examples from the following periods: Mesopotamia, Egypt, the greek world, the Roman Empire, ancient Christianity, Islam, the Romanesque era, the Gothic era, the Renaissance, the Mannerism and the Baroque.
02050102.name: History of Architecture

02050105.about: The course examine the architecture and landscape architecture of the Jewish settlement during the pre-state Israel period in view of the global architectural discourse at the time. The course reviews three eras in light of changing world orders: the first duringthe interwar period, the second under the British colonial rule, and the third covers the current era of globalization and controversy over the meaning of space and architectural culture in Israel. The course includes reading assignments and projects' analysis.
02050105.name: Architecture in Israel:21 St. Century

02050111.about: The seminar will focus on specific issues of modern architecture as a continuation and extension of the discussions in the course "The Origins and Development of Modern Architecture". The particular theme of the seminar will vary each year. Examples of possible subjects: the works of one of the master of the modern movement, e.g. Mackintosh, F.L. Wright. Particular ideologies and architectural movements, e.g. Art Nouveau, Bauhaus. Cities of central importance in the development of the modern movement, e.g. London, Viena, Berlin.
02050111.name: Selected Topics in Modern Architecture

02050113.about: The course focuses on architecture after world war 2 and up to present time. It analyzes the main streams of architecture in the second half of the twentieth century, the disengagement with modernism expressed in postmodernism, the return to it as expressed in late modernism, and trends aiming to express regional distinctiveness, such as critical regionalism.
02050113.name: Selected Topics in Contemporary Archite.

02050152.about: The course reviews theories and methodologies of social thought on cities and urbanism. These throries are examined in view of challenges posed by the city in general and the Israeli city in particular, such as social inequality, gentrification, division of labor, neighborhood rehabilitation, urban motherhood and urban (non)citizenship. The course encourages students to develop abilities of policy making, policy implementation and policy intervention, by applying analyzes tools in order to examine social phenomena relevant to modern urban agenda.
02050152.name: Issues in Urban Sociology

02050154.about: The course examines relationship of individuals and communities with the built environment and open space, by exploring these relationship through fundamental concepts of cognitions, stances, behaviors, feelings, identity, communality, social practices and theories of everyday life. The course aims to help students to understand the way spatial policy and spatial intervention are shaped and developed in a given culture and system of meaning respectively.
02050154.name: Psychology for Architects

02050255.about: The course examines housing patterns built in Israel since 1948, with an emphasis on topics such as: "Court-yard", "Street", "Between the public and the private", "Human scale", "Neo- urbanism" etc. Architectural and urban theories, relevant to the understanding of the above patterns, will be discussed.
02050255.name: Urban Patterns in Israel

02050256.about: The course examines the urban aspects of public housing and public planning in Israel from the 1920s to the present. The acquaintance with the planning of new towns and neighborhoods is done chronologically. The changes in urban and neighborhood models over the years are clarified, as well as the reasons for these changes and the actual outcomes. Planning in Iarael is examined from two aspects - the ideological zionist and social aspect and the theoretical aspects based on precedents from abroad.
02050256.name: Development of Urban Design in Israel

02050257.about: THE ABILITY TO ANALYZE AND PROVIDE A PLANNING RESPONSE TO ALL THE RELEVANT CONTEXT COMPONENTS. UNDERSTANDING, RECOGNIZING,- DISTINGUISHING AND ANALYZING URBAN SPACES AND URBAN FABRICS UNDERSTANDING THE FULL RANGE OF CONSIDERATIONS IN AN URBAN, DEVELOPMENT, INCLUDING SOCIETY, ENVIRONMENT, ECONOMY, INFRASTRUCTURE, TRANSPORTATION, TEXTURE, HISTORY. RECOGNITION AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE THEORIES AND TOOLS OF URBAN DESIGN. ABILITY TO DEFINE NEEDS AND GOALS IN URBAN DEVELOPMENT. SUSTAINABLE PLANNING IN THE URBAN ENVIRONMENT. PRESENTING THE SCENIC SKELETON OF THE CITY.
02050257.name: Int. to Urban Design and Planning

02050304.about: Design and furnishing of spaces is a meaningful aspect of the architect's training, and significantly contributes to the integrity of the final architectural product. The course provides a hands-on experience in design on various scales, Workshop selection includes: interior design, furnishing in built spaces, open space design, and furnishing with an emphasis on compact design, material-conditioned design, experimental design, and more. The workshop will be accompanied by a series of lectures which will introduce exemplary works of local and international designers, as well as technological and technical fundamentals, design and manufacturing techniqu es.
02050304.name: Mini Design Studio a

02050426.about: THE SKELETON OF THE BUILDING, BUILDING ENVELOPES, PARTITIONS, ROOFS AND DRAINS, SEALING WALLS, FOUNDATIONS, INTERIOR AND EXTERIOR FINISHES. LIFE CYCLES AND FLEXIBILITY OF THE COMPONENTS OF THE STRUCTURE.nd exterior finishes, life cycles and flexibility APPLICATION OF CONSTRUCTION METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES. USE OF MATERIALS. PLANNING AND DESIGN OF BUILDING DETAILS SUCH AS: CONNECTIONS, ANCHORS,INSULATION, AND SEALS.
02050426.name: Building Tech.and Construction Details 1

02050427.about: The course examines relations and transitions principles between building spaces and their surroundings, and between spaces within buildings, and the way different elements such as vertical movement, horizontal grading and diagonal motion in the building and its surroundings affect these relations. The course emphasizes various openings, doors and entries, including the influence of transparency, shading, locking, security and accessibility. APPLICATION OF CONSTRUCTION METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES, USE OF MATERIALS, PLANNING AND DESIGN OF BUILDING DETAILS SUCH AS: CONNECTIONS, ANCHORS, INSULATION AND SEALING.
02050427.name: Building Tech.and Construction Details 2

02050430.about: The course involves working on a chosen semestrial project in a group format, with an emphasis on an integrative approach that combines architecture, engineering and industry.
02050430.name: Technology and Structures Workshop 1a

02050458.about: The course provides basic knowledge of building design and behavior of structural systems, while encouraging students to understandthe interconnection between architecture and engineering. The course emphasizes issues such ad stability and strength, the relationship between shape and structural features, rigidity, load distribution, and appropriate use of materials.
02050458.name: Structural Design 1

02050459.about: The course introduces students to basic principles of static behavior of building components and systems composed of straight and curved flat surfaces. Students will be equipped with tools for classification of complex architectural buildings according to their structural properties, as a basis for an architectural discourse and cooperation between architects and engineers.
02050459.name: Structural Design 2

02050460.about: The course equips students with basic principles of static behavior of structural components and systems composed from linear elements and their influence on architectural design. The course reviews basic concepts such as cross-section, components, design, and analytical design planning techniques.
02050460.name: Structural Design 3

02050492.about: CLIMATIC-ENERGY DESIGN PRINCIPLES FOR ACHIEVING THERMAL COMFORT CONDITIONS IN SUMMER AND WINTER IN BUILDINGS, THEIR SURROUNDINGS AND THE OPEN SPACE, WITH A MINIMAL INVESTMENT OF CONSUMABLE ENERGY. HEAT TRANSFER CALCULATIONS IN A BUILDING. ENERGY BALANCE IN THE BUILDING. CONDITIONS FOR ACHIEVING THERMAL-CLIMATIC COMFORT. CLIMATIC-ENERGETIC DESIGN. CLIMATE DATA FOR PLANNING BUILDINGS AND OPEN SPACES IN ISRAEL. EMPHASIS ON UNDERSTANDING THE PHYSICAL PRINCIPLES, WHILE PROVIDING QUALITY AND QUANTITATIVE PLANNING TOOLS: MANUAL AND COMPUTERIZED. ACQUAINTANCE AND APPLICATION OF THE PRINCIPLES OF GREEN BUILDING (SUSTAINABLE CONSTRUCTION) CLIMATE-ADAPTED AND SAV ING CONSUMABLE RESOURCES.
02050492.name: Building Systems-Climate and Energy

02050498.about: The course equips students with techniques of sites' observation, mapping, analysis and representation. students will learn to understand the way sites' physical properties - topography, rock and soil, microclimate, water (surface runoff and ground water), flora,fauna, visibility, accessibility, and others - influence on site development process, in the urban, economic, social, environmentaland cultural context
02050498.name: Site Planning

02050501.about: The course introduces students to the mechanism of visual perception, and the way the visual system interprets the surrounding environment. The course reviews issues such as dispersion of light and the array of colors in a lit-up space, natural light's propertiesand its use in lighting buildings, direct sun light vs. shading, properties and uses of light sources, light fixtures, measurements, calculations of natural and electric lighting, natural and artificial light combinations in buildings, outdoor illumination in streets, squares, buildings, and other sites. The course provides the students an opportunity to gain hands-on experience with advanced tools and computer programs for lighting calculation.
02050501.name: Building Systems - Light and Lighting

02050510.about: The architect as a safety generator. Accessibility and safety in the building and its surroundings. Risk definitions. Risk classifications. Building policy & legislation. Access and mobility. Fire safety measures and fire exit. Fire alarm systems. Emergency escape and rescue requirements. Emergency lighting and sign posting. Shelters and protected spaces. Safety in high-rise buildings. Protective and secure buildings. Varying demands of populations with special needs, and equal rights for people with disabilities. FAMILIARITY WITH AND IMPLEMENTATION OF ACCESSIBILITY REGULATIONS, SAFETY AND ESCAPE, USER SAFETY AND PROTECTION. ABILITY TO COLLABORATE WITH  CONSULTANTS.
02050510.name: Building Syst.-Safety and Accessibility

02050542.about: THE COURSE DEVELOPS STUDENTS  SKILLS IN ARCHITECTURAL LITERACY, PROVIDE THEM WITH PRELIMINARY ARCHITECTURAL LITERACY SKILLS, INCLUDING SPATIAL READING AND ANALYSIS (FACADE, CONSTRUCTION, STREET, SQUARE), AND ARCHITECTURAL REPRESENTATIONS (PLANS, CROSS SECTIONS, ELEVATIONS). SECONDARY ARCHITECTURAL LITERACY SKILLS INCLUDE READING SESSIONS OF SELECTED TEXTS, DEALING WITH ARCHITECTURAL SPACE, SUCH AS DESIGN DOCUMENTS, INTERPRETATIONAL TEXTS, ETC.
02050542.name: Erudition: Space and Text

02050543.about: acquire basic theoretical knowledge and develop basic understanding and familiarity with basic laws of descriptive geometry, basic systematic theoretical infrastructure in the field of spatial description, geometric operations in space, and finding solutions to spatial problems in architecture.
02050543.name: Descriptive Geometry

02050571.about: The course presents the basic principles of economic thinking (allocation of limited resources to satisfy infinite needs) and their application, mainly in microeconomics. The emphasis is on understanding and operating quantitative models that can be used to reach conclusions and offer solutions to economic problems, according to well-defined assumptions.
02050571.name: Spatial and Building Economics

02050574.about: THE COURSE IS AN INTRODUCTION TO THE PROFESSIONAL WORLD. ENGAGES IN PROVIDING AN INITIAL TOOLBOX FOR UNDERSTANDING THE CONCEPT OF SPACE, THROUGH CONCEPTUAL AND PRACTICAL EXERCISES ON ISSUES OF MATTER, FORM, FUNCTION AND EXPERIENCE. THE COURSE INCLUDES LECTURES, STUDY TOURS AND GUIDANCE DURING THE DEVELOPMENT OF PROJECTS.
02050574.name: Studio Project 1

02050575.about: THE COURSE FOCUSES ON TRANSITION FROM CONCEPT TO FORM, BY DOCUMENTING, EXPLORING AND ANALYZING EXISTING ARCHITECTURAL FORMATS, AND FINDING FEASIBLE WAYS OF INTERVENTION IN THESE FORMATS. IN ADDITION, STUDENTS WILL EXPLORE TOPICS SUCH AS INTERIOR AND EXTERIOR. PRIVATE AND PUBLIC, AND THE LIKE. THROUGHOUT THE COURSE STUDENTS WILL GET THE OPPORTUNITY TO DEFINE THEIR OWN VISION OF ARCHITECTURAL INTERVENTION.
02050575.name: Studio Project 2

02050576.about: PLANNING AND DESIGN IN AN ENVIRONMENTAL CONTEXT. THE COURSE AIMS TO METHODICALLY EXPOSE STUDENTS TO THE MAIN PHASES OF THE PLANNINGPROCESS. PROVIDING STUDENTS WITH TOOLS AND TECHNIQUES OF CRITICAL THINKING, WILL HOPE TO ENCOURAGE RESPONSIBLE AND ACCOUNTABLE PLANNING.
02050576.name: Studio Project 3

02050577.about: THE STUDY OF CONCEPTS AND TOOLS IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY URBAN RELATIONSHIPS, FORCES AND PROCESSES, WITH REFERENCE TO THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT, OPEN SPACES AND THE PUBLIC SPHERE. DEVELOPMENT OF DESIGN TOOLS TO SHAPE THE URBAN SPACE OVER TIME AND AFFECT USERS EXPERIENCE.EXPLORATION AND EXPERIMENTATION IN VARIOUS SCALES: PLANNING OF GENERAL PATTERNS AND URBAN SYSTEMS, DESIGN OF URBAN FABRIC, ARCHITECTURE OF SPECIFIC SITES, WITH A BROAD CONTEXTUAL UNDERSTANDING.
02050577.name: Studio Project 4

02050578.about: RESEARCH BY DESIGN: DEVELOPING A SUBJECT. IDEA THROUGH RESEARCH AND ARCHITECTONIC TOOLS, DESIGNING THE FUTURE OF A SITE BY UNDERSTANDING ITS PAST, AND USING CRITICAL RESEARCH METHODOLOGIES AS THE BASIS FOR A DESIGN APPROACH WHICH RELATES TO CONTEMPORARY ATTITUDESTO CONTINUITY AND CHANGE IN THE HISTORIC ENVIRONMENT. THE STUDIO IS ACCOMPANIED BY A THEORETICAL COURSE.
02050578.name: Thematic Studio: Built Heritage and Regeneration

02050579.about: RESEARCH BY DESIGN: DEVELOPING ARCHITECTURAL PROJECT WITH DIGITAL ARCHITECTURAL TOOLS, USING A RESEARCH METHODOLOGY LEADING TO A DESIGN POSITION, BUILDING A CRITICAL STANCE ON CONTEMPORARY ISSUES AND THE USE OF ADVANCED DESIGN TOOLS.
02050579.name: Thematic Studio: Computational Design and Fabrication

02050580.about: RESEARCH BY DESIGN: DEVELOPING A TOPIC . DISCUSSION . IDEA THROUGH ARCHITECTURAL TOOLS, USING RESEARCH METHODOLOGY LEADING TO A PLANNING POSITION, BUILDING A CRITICAL STANCE ON CONTEMPORARY ISSUES. MODERATE SELECTION OUT OF A VARIETY OF TOPICS OFFERED WITHIN THE HISTORY, THEORY AND CRITICISM SECTION.
02050580.name: Thematic Studio-Htc

02050581.about: RESEARCH BY DESIGN: DEVELOPMENT OF  TOPIC.DISCUSSION.IDEA THROUGH ARCHITECTONIC TOOLS, USING RESEARCH METHODOLOGY LEADING TO BUILDING A CRITICAL DESIGN POSITION ON CURRENT ISSUES. THE STUDIO WILL FOCUS ON ACTUAL ISSUES IN THE FIELD OF SUSTAINABLE ARCHITECTURE.
02050581.name: Thematic Studio:Sustainable Architecture

02050582.about: RESEARCH BY DESIGN: THE DEVELOPMENT OF A THEME . CONCEPT THROUGH ARCHITECTURAL MEANS, USING RESEARCH METHODS TO GENERATE A CRITICALRESPONSE TO CONTEMPORARY ISSUES THROUGH SITE-SPECIFIC DESIGN. THE STUDIO WILL BE ACCOMPANIED BY A SUPPORTING THEORETICAL COURSE.
02050582.name: Thematic Studio - General

02050584.about: during illness, daily routine is disrupted, and a person faces unexpected challenges related to both body and mind. the aim of the course is to introduce students to the discourse concerning architecture and health, focusing on the relationship between man and physical environment. the course will provide students with tools for reading and analyzing environments that focus on health in its broadest sense.
02050584.name: Architecture and Health

02050585.about: the aim of the course is to make the professional practice accessible during the studies. students will gain professional experience and feel the work atmosphere in the field. they will accompany the office staff, assist, and perform tasks designed to expose the student to the day-to-day professional activities of the organization. students will present learned outcomes at the end of the semester. in addition, they will participate in a workshop for cv writing, cover letter and self-presentation to an employer.
02050585.name: PRACTIKUM-PROFESSIONAL EXPERIE. IN ARCH

02050586.about: RESEARCH-BY-DESIGN: DEVELOPING AN ARCHITECTURAL IDEA/CONCEPT! USING RESEARCH METHODS TO GENERATE A CRITICAL RESPONSE TO CONTEMPORARY ISSUES AND A SITE-SPECIFIC ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN. A SUPPORTING THEORETICAL COURSE WILL ACCOMPANY THE STUDIO.
02050586.name: THEMATIC STUDIO GENERAL 2

02050587.about: THIS COURSE PRESENTS AN OVERVIEW OF THE COMPLEX RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN THE PHYSICAL AND THE DIGITAL! BETWEEN BIOLOGY AND TECHNOLOGY!BETWEEN NATURE AND CULTURE. IT EXPLORES THE WAYS IN WHICH THESE RELATIONSHIPS PRESENT THEMSELVES IN SPACE AND REDEFINE THE ESSENCE AND THE TOOLS OF DESIGN AND ARCHITECTURE.
02050587.name: TRANSIENT BOUNDARIES:PHYGITAL DESIGN

02050598.about: the course provides basic background and knowledge regarding transportation and road planning in the urban system. the course dealswith interrelationships between the transportation system and urban form, neighborhood design, and environmental impacts. planning and design standards, guidelines and regulations currently in operation in israel are reviewed. course topics include: urban road planning, parking, planning for pedestrians and bicyclists, mixed-use roads, alternative transportation modes, etc.
02050598.name: Transport and the City

02050599.about: The context and implications of building with repetitive elements in architectural design (asingle building and a building complex): the principles of building methods, and the development of buildin methods, standardization and interchangeable use of elements: economical and historical aspects in the development of industiralized building. Morphological repitition and its meaning for industiralized building.
02050599.name: Introduction to Industrialized Building

02050618.about: Selected problems in architectural design of stage "b" of special project 1.
02050618.name: Special Project 2a

02050627.about: Public interiors and furniture layouts in the renewal of existing buildings or within constraints prescribed by industrial modular systems, etc.  Conversion of undeveloped volumes into finished and equipped architectural spaces, or renewal and adaptation of spaces in existing buildings for new uses and changing situations. Alternatively:  development of programs, standard interior key - layouts and serial furniture for public buildings as part of their design process.
02050627.name: Interior Design & Furniture 2

02050668.about: The study of concepts and tools in order to identify urban relationships, forces and processes, with reference to the built environment, open spaces and the public sphere. Development of design tools to shape the urban space over time and affect users experience.Exploration and experimentation in various scales: planning of general patterns and urban systems, design of urban fabric, architecture of specific sites, with a broad contextual understanding.
02050668.name: Studio 4-Urban Design

02050688.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the leader, subject to the approval of the graduate committee, towards the beginning of the semester in which the course is schedules.
02050688.name: Special Topics in Architecture

02050720.about: The syllabi will be outlined by the lecturer and will be approved by the dean.
02050720.name: Special Topics in Architecture 3G

02050723.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the dean, towards of the semester in which the course is scheduled.
02050723.name: Special Topics in Architecture 3H

02050724.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduare committee, towards of the semester in which the course is scheduled.
02050724.name: Special Topics in Architecture 2I

02050725.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduare committee, towards of the semester in which the course is scheduled.
02050725.name: Special Topics in Architecture 3J

02050814.about: Basic techniques in architectural drawing, perspective in freehand drawing, light and shade, composition and relationship between structure of a three-dimensional object and its two- dimensional drawing. Drawing architectural objects of basic and intermediate complexity.
02050814.name: Architectural Drawing

02050818.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide variety of tools and skills. Workshop selection includes: illustration, architectural sketching, three-dimensional modeling, model construction, computer-based manufacturing, laser cutting, three-dimensional scanning, and basic graphic design.
02050818.name: Media Workshops 1B

02050819.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide variety of tools and skills. Workshop selection includes: illustration, architectural sketching, three-dimensional modeling, model construction, computer-based manufacturing, laser cutting, three-dimensional scanning, and basic graphic design.
02050819.name: Media Workshops 1C

02050822.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide variety of tools and skills. Workshop selection includes: illustration, architectural sketching, three-dimensional modeling, model construction, computer-based manufacturing, laser cutting, three-dimensional scanning, and basic graphic design.
02050822.name: Media Workshops 1F

02050824.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part, students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide range of tools and skills. Workshops selection includes: parametric design, CNC and 3-D printing, architectural simulation, animation, video presentation, and advanced computer graphics.
02050824.name: Media Workshops 2a

02050825.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part, students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide range of tools and skills. Workshops selection includes: parametric design, CNC and 3-D printing, architectural simulation, animation, video presentation, and advanced computer graphics.
02050825.name: Media Workshops 2B

02050826.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part, students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide range of tools and skills. Workshops selection includes: parametric design, CNC and 3-D printing, architectural simulation, animation, video presentation, and advanced computer graphics.
02050826.name: Media Workshops 2C

02050827.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part, students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide range of tools and skills. Workshop selection includes: parametric design, CNC and 3-D printing, architectural simulation,animation, video presentation, and advanced computer graphics.
02050827.name: Media Workshops 2D

02050828.about: The course is divided into three parts. In each part, students will be able to choose an intensive workshop that will equip them with a wide range of tools and skills. Workshop selection includes: parametric design, CNC and 3-D printing, architectural simulation,animation, video presentation, and advanced computer graphics.
02050828.name: Media Workshops 2E

02050873.about: Continuation of Basic Design 3 with a more complex problem, both from the practical and design aspects.
02050873.name: Basic Design 4

02050874.about: The object of the course is the development of new ways and means to convert art in all its expressions into an organic part of modern architecture.  Theoretical analysis and experiments.
02050874.name: Experimental Art 1

02050877.about: The course deals with investigating architectural problems through design processes. The topics of the course include: elaborating and examining of images, metaphors and symbols in the architectural design. Relationships between object and space in various scales, etc. Investigating the influence of design tools, design materials and.or design operations on the product of art.
02050877.name: Basic Design 5

02050878.about: The course aims to equip students with fundamental design concepts and tools of artistic expression. Course topics: 1. Introductionto forms and compositions in the two-dimensional and the three-dimensional space. 2. Visual expression of physical properties of existing and implanted bodies in space. 3. Means of expression from the realm of plastic art, including illustration, photography, andthree-dimensional means of expression, using a wide range of materials and techniques. Students are invited to reinforce the ideas raised in the course in workshops of their own choosing.
02050878.name: Basic Design 1a

02050886.about: The course provides students with farther design concepts in reference to the principles of perception and the senses, the human body, and the visual culture in a given environment. Topics of study include: 1. different components of visual perception and their interconnection in 2-D and 3-D (specific site, form, light vs. shadow, color). 2. Approaches of visual expression in built environments, including the mutual influence between man, object and environment as it is manifested in signs, symbols and images. 3. Expression of environmental contents and ideas via artistic means and installations which act upon the senses and the physical-visual experie nce. Students are invited to reinforce the ideas raised in the course in workshops of their own choosing.
02050886.name: Basic Design 2a

02050922.about: The course aims to introduce students to technologies, space representation techniques, and modeling of architectural forms, both virtual and physical ones. The course provides a review of the main technologies and techniques students will practice during the course of their studies, with an emphasis on illustration, sketching, and three-dimensional modeling. A profound examination of tools and selected methods will take place in media workshops.
02050922.name: Observing, Modeling and Representing 1

02050923.about: The course aims to expand students' knowledge of technologies and methods of space representation, virtual and physical modeling ofarchitectural forms and CNC techniques. The course reviews technological and technical developments, and outlines the principal tools and methods used in practice, with an emphsis on advanced techniques of two-dimensional graphic expression, 3-D and 4-D simulations. A farther examination of selected tools and methods will take place in media workshops.
02050923.name: Observing, Modeling and Representing 2

02050980.about: Study of a defined topic related to one of the courses in the study program.  The study will be guided by the lecturer responsible for the same course.  The student will work on the topic for about fifty hours during the semester.
02050980.name: Selected Topics in Architecture

02060003.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060003.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - Preservatiion 1

02060005.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060005.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - 2 Digital Architecture

02060006.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060006.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - 1 Digital Architecture

02060007.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given. Spring semester 2017.2018: Seminar on Bio-Climatic Solar Design.
02060007.name: Selected Topics in Green Architecture 1 Architecture

02060008.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060008.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - Green Architecture 2

02060009.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060009.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - History and Theory 2

02060010.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060010.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - 1 History and Theory

02060011.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060011.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - 2 Urban Design

02060012.about: the syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the graduate studies committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060012.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - 1 Urban Design

02060013.about: the course deals with two topics:desing and process of construction of architectural projects.  a series of lectures will be given,which will include main subjects of desing and construction of a built architectural project.  students will be able to assimilate the theoretical knowledge acquired in the studio project, and develop the ability to combine different building technologies at various design stages. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know: how to combine various components of an architectural project and understand how architect's knowledge and supervision over the different disciplines influences the final result.
02060013.name: Technological Workshop No.2

02060015.about: the course will deal with selected topics in history and theory.
02060015.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - History and Theory 4

02060016.about: the course will deal with selected topics in computational desing and fabrication.
02060016.name: Selected Topics in Architecture - Computational Desing and Fabrication

02060018.about:
the course will examine the relationship between architecture, digital interaction and games,  the way that architecture influencesparticipants in the virtual world and how experiences,  interaction and environments can be designed for the virtual world. the course will focus on virtual reality games and how these games are used today, the role of  architectural models and how these affect users.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course, students will be able to: 1. use interactive 3d application development enginessuch as unity.
 2. use 3d models from different sources and placing them into virtual environments._
 3. understand advanced concept s of developing architectural systems for virtual environments.__
 4. apply design principles to variable-scale 3d virtual environments.
 5. construct, implement and characterize design documents for the development of virtual environments with complex interactions and communication with a software developer for implementation. 6. develop a game in virtual reality environments from concept toimplementation.
02060018.name: ARCHITECTURE! GAMES AND VIRTUAL REALITY

02060044.about:
the world of materials is advancing continuously. the materials we deal with today are advanced, architectured, composite, smart, active, healing, living, and more. the course will review the material families in use today in advanced construction and design, together with contemporary research and development in the field. oriented towards an architectural perspective, the course will deploythe various aspects of architectural materiality, addressing technical considerations of mechanical performance, fabrication or cost, along with cultural and theoretical issues. 
 learning outcomes: the student will have:
 1. a wide acquaintance with the contempor ary world of materials and its terminology, both in practice and research. 
 2. a transversal applications for the different materials, through architectural perspective.
02060044.name: Building Materials Construction Methods

02060046.about: Conceptual design as the birth of a structure. The role of the architect in deciding the structural solution. The cooperation between the architect and the structural engineer. Decision making at the initial stages and its influence on the final structural and project design. Classification of data according to its importance. Analysis of factors influencing the solution quality -static scheme, materials, manufacturing and erection procedures, durability, economy, computer aided design at the initial stages. solution iteration.
02060046.name: Conceptual Design of Structures

02060062.about: educational workshop of 26 studio hours. a teaching framework for short term guest professors
02060062.name: Special Thematic Studio 2

02060063.about: educational workshop of 26 studio hours. a teaching framework for short term guest professors
02060063.name: Special Thematic Studio 3

02060071.about: educational workshop of 13 hours. a teaching framework for short term guest professors
02060071.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 5

02060072.about: educational workshop of 13 lecture hours. a teaching framework for short term guest professors
02060072.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 6

02060073.about: educational workshop of 13 lecture hours. a teching framework for term guest professors
02060073.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 7

02060074.about: educational workshop of 13 lecture hours. a teaching framework for short term guest professors
02060074.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 8

02060075.about: theory, approaches and trends in sustainable design. the complexity of environmental issues, with an emphasis on sustainability as an holistic view and interdisciplinary field.  implementation methods of sustainable concepts using recent precedents, from theory to practice and from urban scale to building scale. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student 1. will be familiar with the concept of sustainability and the theoretical knowledge. 2. will how to use planning tools with a comprehensive approach to susainability on various development levels, from urban planning to building design. 3. know how to prepare a seminar paper subject by st udying and analyzing literature and examining local and interantional precedents.
02060075.name: Comprehensive Approach to Sustainability

02060080.about: Development of alternative reading of the urban environment emphasizing the various ways this environment carries meaning for different users. The ways urban design tools and practices operate in the urban environment, challenged through updated theories from thecultural studies discipline.
02060080.name: Cultural Reading of the Urban Realm

02060095.about: the power of architecture in forming national identity as a natural, essential and indispensable phenomenon. the reciprocal relationship between professional knowledge and political power in the construction of israeli architecture. central themes in the architecture of the state-modernization, settlement, locality,history.memory.time, and their role in shaping the israeli landscape from 1948until today.
02060095.name: The Politics of Israeli Architecture: Modernism, National and Identity

02060096.about: main topics: a. commemoration methods - from traditional monumental structures of antiquity (i.e., obelisks and pyramids) to contemporary structures. b. levels of transparency in architecture from a historial perspective. c. space from the modern architecture perspective giedion, norberg schulz and others.
02060096.name: Architectural Issues: Memory and Commemoration

02060100.about: the relationship between architectural thought, state power and identity politics in post wwii world. the rise and consolidation ofthe modern movement in architecture. focus on the mobility of architectural knowledge in the contexts of europe, the u.s. and 3rd world countries in light of intercultural encounters, mega-projects and postcoolonial elites.
02060100.name: Critical Perspectives in Post Wwii Architecture

02060101.about: developing a conceptual and design statement that challenges and innovates contemporary architectural practice, applying research and design methodology and understanding the relationship between them, structuring a clear explanation of the project's manifest, building a thesis from detailed research to a description of the architectural design proposal.
02060101.name: Research in Architecture

02060170.about: The course examines the critical debate concerning public housing and public planning since the establishment of the state of Israel. the courses's subjects are the ideology behind settlement activity, the gap between the settling establishment and the settled population, the meaning of place - between east and west, the image of the house and the changing attitude to urbanity. These subjectsare examined through planning and architectural aspects, as well as social, cultural and political aspects. The course requirementsinclude presentation of articles in the classroom and writing a final paper.
02060170.name: A Critical Discussion of Public Housing

02060180.about: the nature of color, its appearance and function in nature and in society. the dimensions of color, color classification. color vision and perception. color harmonies in art and in nature.
02060180.name: Color Theory

02060284.about:
in this class we will learn the fundamentals of programming both in processing environment and in rhino grasshopper, using a visualand tangible approach that was developed especially for designers. we will produce our design in digital fabrication tooles such aslaser cutters and 3d printers.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the class students will be:
 1. familiar with the fundamentals of programing: variables, loops, functions.
 2. write a simple code, and hack an existing code.
 3. familiar with the field of computational fabrication and projects and works within this field.
02060284.name: Digital Design and Craft

02060403.about:
familiarity with much of the urban engineering infastructure - water, runoff, sewage, refuse and waste, electricity, infrastructuretunnels, communications, energy, public transport (metro, lrt), the urban street, public space infrastructure, and opening a view towards future logistics infrastructure. focusing on scale
 from the city street, borough.quarter facilities, to city and metropolitan facilities.
 at the end of the semester the student will be capable of: 1.combining urban and national infrastructure awareness into the urban desing and planning projects and processes. 2.uunderstanung the complexity of variety of infrastructures at both local a nd metropolitan levels. 3.innitiating consultation with infrastructure consultants and specialists.:
02060403.name: Urban and Metropolitan Infrastructure

02060404.about:
research seminar revolving the clos historial and theoretical connection between modern city planning and modern. the seminar includes reading academic literature, framing research questions in small groups, gropu field reserch of the class study case utilizing several research methods (archival research, interviews , architectural docmentation, questioners), and writing research papers in group.
 at the end of the course, the studend will be able to: 1. be familiar with the history and theory of city planning and housingas modern disciplinary issues and as a design continuum. 2. frame research questions and devise research design (in groups) revolvin g the course case study. 3. experience field research and employ appropriate research methods to their research question. 4. experience academic writing of a research paper (in groups).
02060404.name: Housing the City - Research Seminar

02060561.about: Visible radiation.  Human requirements for daylight and sunlight inside buildings.  Quantitative and qualitative criteria in lighting design.  Penetration of daylight, and its effect on depth and height of interiors.  Glare.  Directional properties of lighting.  Spectral composition.  Integration of natural and artificial lighting in the visual environment.  Daylight and sunlight in urban planning. Outdoor activity and artificial light during dark hours.  The lighting of pedestrian and vehicular passages.  Visual guidanceand attraction by lighting effects.  Street lighting.  Area lighting.  Lighting of monuments and building facades.
02060561.name: Lighting in Architecture

02060563.about: Approaches to the use of solar energy in buildings on various levels. Direct use for energy conservation in buildings.  Use by integral systems in a building.  Use by indirect solar systems. Lectures will be accompanied by demonstration and solution analysis madein the world in recent years, with planning exercises in order to understand the subjects from the planning and physical point of view and by a semestral project or a seminar paper.
02060563.name: Seminar in Planning Passive Solar Structure

02060564.about: New solutions in the climatalogical design of buildings.  Analysis of traditional solutions of building design for different climatic zones. Climatalogical aspects of town planning for different climatic zones.
02060564.name: Climatological Aspects of Building Design

02060566.about: Integrated effects of vegetation and urban texture on the urban heat island, air pollution and noise level. Design tools and directives for sustainable planning of an urban open space.
02060566.name: Vegetation and Urban Microclimate

02060567.about: KNOWLEDGE, UNDERSTANDING AND BASIC PLANNING OF THE BUILDING SYSTEMS, AND THEIR INTEGRATION IN THE OVERALL PLANNING OF THE BUILDING.WATER SYSTEMS, SEWAGE AND DRAINAGE, AIR CONDITIONING AND VENTILATION, ELECTRICITY AND LIGHTING, ACOUSTICS. COORDINATION AND INTEGRATION BETWEEN THE VARIOUS BUILDING SYSTEMS. FAMILIARITY WITH AND APPLICATION OF THE PRINCIPLES OF SUSTAINABLE CONSTRUCTION - CLIMATE-ADAPTED AND RESOURCE-SAVING. ASPECTS OF ENERGY CONSERVATION AND PERISHABLE RESOURCES IN VIEW OF LIFE CYCLES AND SUSTAINABILITY PRINCIPLES. ABILITY TO COLLABORATE WITH CONSULTANTS.
02060567.name: Building Sdystems - Environmental Control

02060570.about: review of leading israeli and global standards for design and evaluation of sustainable architectural projects. standards of energyuse in buildings, greenhouse gas emissions and resource depletion. re-evaluation of standards design and construction processes aimed at environmentally friendly practices.
02060570.name: Seminar in Evaluation of Sustainable Architectural Design.

02060571.about: review of different knowledge computational domains in sustainble design (i.e. energy, winds, shading and spread of buildings in the field). computational models: creation, evaluation and optimization. integration of simulation in performance based computer aideddesign. introduction to the application of advanced computational building simulation tools.
02060571.name: Computer Models for Sustainable Architec Tural Design

02060573.about: green architecture issues on different scales: urban, building, details of the buildind envelope and environmental control systems.topics: energy, thermal and lighting comfort, sustainable site and land, water and drainage, materials, resources and waste, internal air quality. applying si 5281 - buildings with reduced environmental impact (green buildings), and.or international green standards, (i.e.: leed - leading in energy -  environmental design).
02060573.name: Project in Green Architecture

02060574.about:
strategies and tactics initiated along the adaptive reuse design process will be summarized. various architecture analyses methods modified towards adaptive reused architecture will be mastered.
 visualization of precedent architecture spaces will be carried out in the immersive virtual reality visualization laboratory at the faculty, experiencing the perception of space in both states: the original and after intervention. interdisciplinary review of all relevant aspects (economy, society, urban planning and design, urbanregeneration, presrvation, sustainable architecture etc.)
learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the student will:
1. know how  to analyze adaptive reused buildgs.
2. will be familiar with the central aspects included the adaptive reuse area of expertise.
3.will be familiar with the strategies and tactics applied along the design process of adaptive reused buildings.
4. be able to initiate the above on any architecture design project involving intervention in existing buildings.
02060574.name: Adaptive Reuse of Existing Building

02060577.about:
the integration and interaction between the construction and architectural professions, with a focus on structural one as a three- dimensional totality, inseparable from the aesthetic, functional, ethical and architectural aspects of design. acquisition of skillsin solving structural issues, examining alternative structural systems, and analyzing them from the engineering and economic pointsof view.
 design of project from architectural concept to the determination of structural solution.
 learning outcomes:
 at the endof the course students will:
 1.experience in holistic design, where structure becomes a main factor in the architectural design, in  which building, materials and space work together, both from architectural and structural points of view.
 2.know how to switch between architectural to construction plans.
 3.experience the setting and design of structural systems which ensure stability on the one hand, while complementing architectural features on the other.
 4.gain experience understanding the mutual relation between architectural and structural design.
02060577.name: Comprehensive Structural Design

02060730.about: introduction to research material dealing with power relations in the urban space. development of critical tools to analyze the pract9ices of individuals and groups and comprehend the differences between formal, informal and other representations. the student will investigate a case study concerned with power relations in urban space in israel.
02060730.name: Contested Space: Architecture, Planning

02060808.about: topics: theory and practice of digital architecture since the beginning of the 90s. the impact of the current discourse on the identification and the development of distinct characteristics of digital architecture (i.e., tectonics, responsiveness and dynamics). key concepts in digital architecture. the scientific and technological theories which influence. the architectural discourse.
02060808.name: Theories of Digital Architecture

02060819.about:
this theoretical course deals with contemporary philosophical issues that links curatorial practice and architecture. it provides acritical perspective and depicts the historical and theoretical background and history of curatorship. it will discuss the development of the curatorial discipline, canonical exhibitions, changes in the museum's status and more.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know: to examine and analyse the intersection between curatorial practice and architecture. to identify the different expressions of this intersection in all of the exhibition components: from the encounter between the viewer and the spa ce, throgh the curatorial text and the design of the space.
02060819.name: Contemporary Curatorial Issuesadvanced

02060821.about: the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate studies committee, at the beginning of the semester in which the course will be given.
02060821.name: Selected Topics in Industrial Design 2

02060822.about: the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate studies committee, at the beginning of the semester in which the course will be given.
02060822.name: Selected Topics in Indutrial Design 3

02060823.about: the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate studies committee, at the beginning of the semester in which the course will be given.
02060823.name: Selected Topics in Industrial Design 4

02060824.about:
the course will cover aspects of human engineering and physical ergonomics in the context of industrial design. it will enhance thesensitivity to human factors aspects in design and the need to recognize human abilities and limitations. the course will provide principles and methods as well as practical tools to assess physiological, cognitive and emotional needs of the users population.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the students will be able to:
 1. understand ergonomic aspects that are relevant to physical design.
 2. get to know the bottom line of human engineering studies with relevance to the course._
 3.  apply principles and use  ergonomics / human engineering tools.
02060824.name: HUMAN ENGINEERING IN INDUSTRIAL DESIGN

02060825.about: the historical development of industrial design from the industrial revolution at the end of 18c until the eve of wwii (1939). cultural, geo-political, ecological and pedagogical aspects of design. technological advances and their impact (materials, working methods, etc). perceptual transformations of design and the designer and the cultual, technoligical and material evolution of products.
02060825.name: History and Theory in Industrial Design2

02060827.about: invited lectures of leading speakers from academia and industry in the fields of design, human factors, innovation, design management, research methods, breakthrough technology, sustainability and environment, art, information technology. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student: 1. will be familiar with innovative technologies. 2. will be familiar with original and innovative designeers and companies. 3. will be knowledableon general issues relevant to architecture and design. 4. will be familiar with leading industries in technology, innovation and desgin.
02060827.name: Design, Technology and Innovation 1

02060829.about:
students will implement algorithms in recently published computer graphics papers and build physical objects using digital fabrication tools. the algorithms will be embedded in rhino/grasshopper, which will define a parametric working interface that could become software add-ons in the future.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course students will be able to: 1. write advanced computational algorithms that produce complex geometries.
 2. generate a user interface and workflow in rhino/grasshopper environment.
 3. produce, design, and plan large-scale physical parametric structures.
02060829.name: MATTER OF PERSPECTIVE

02060830.about: the virtual space serves today as an extension and substitute for physical settings. topics:  theoretical and technological sources, conceptual basis and terminology, media studies and physical design, social involvment, digital technologies and internet tools. basic principles such as: presence, interaction and activation and social involvment.
02060830.name: Design of the Virtual Space

02060831.about: the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate studies committee, at the beginning of the semester in which the course will be given
02060831.name: Selected Topics in Industrial Design 5

02060835.about: using computer for form generation, simulation and manufacturing raises questions regarding the meaning and relevance of modernist-based concepts (such as performance, standard, mass-construction, module and grid).computer-based design is not limited to constrains of euclidian geometry. it offers new design methods that raise the level of information (geometric and performance information) which is used to create the architectural form. traditional architectural typologies and methods that have become conventions are nowreexamined in relation to the new ideas and design methods. nonetheless, computer- based design is not necessarily a paradigmatic ch ange that negates traditional design and representations methods.
02060835.name: Performalism - Performance in Digital Architecture

02060836.about:
Advanced class in Digital fabrication and computational design. The class goal is to give the students an intensive knowledge of the parametric tools available in the Rhino.Grasshopper environment, understand the logic when working with data structures and provide parametric comprehension that enables the design of data driven and customized products. The final project will be a product design exercise that will utilize the tools that will be taught in class.
 Learning Ouctomes: At the end of the course the student wil know how to:
 1. Use parametric design principles to design customized products.
 2. Understand in depth the relationship between digit al.
 3. Means of production and computational design.
02060836.name: Indutrial Design in the Era of Digital Indutrial Revolution.

02060837.about:
The user experience designer should translate complex requirements from various fields (Business, Marketing, Psychlogy) to a convenient, usable and delightful product while adapting to the needs of the user. The course introduces practical design methods and includes a broad ovedrview of the subjet, accompanied by a personal project. The course is for students in both industrial design masterdegree and architecture students. 
 Learning Outocmes: At the end of the course the student will know:
 To manage, lead and performthe design process for an app or a digital product according to the principles of user cventerd design.
02060837.name: Ux/Ui Design

02060838.about:
the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate committee, towards the beginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled.
 note: a detailed syllabus will be submitted for approval to the graduate school as a condition for opening the course in each semester.
02060838.name: Design in the Meeting Point of Human, Animal, Machine

02060839.about:
THE COURSE "INTRODUCTION TO COMPUTERIZED KNITTING" WILL INTRODUCE TUDENTS TO THE BASICS OF INDUSTRIAL KNITTING TECHNOLOGY. KNITTINGIS A KNOWN HANDICRAFT! BUT INDUSTRIAL KNITTING HAS GAINED MOMENTUM IN RECENT YEARS AS A MEANS OF PRODUCTION IN MANY FIELDS! FROM CLOTHING AND FOOTWEAR TO MEDICAL PRODUCTS! ARCHITECTURAL BUILDINGS AND EVEN SATELLITES. INDUSTRIAL KNITTING IS BASED ON MATHEMATICAL PRINCIPLES THAT ALLOW THE CREATION OF DETAILED TWO-DIMENSIONAL PATTERNS AND THREE-DIMENSIONAL INTRICATE STRUCTURES! ALL WHILE COMBINING DIFFERENT MATERIALS AND ALLOWING CONTROL OVER THE PROPERTIES OF DIFFERENT AREAS OF THE OBJECT. 
__LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE EN D OF THE COURSE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:_
 1. DESIGN AND FABRICATE KNITTED OBJECTS ON AN INDUSTRIAL KNITTING MACHINE._
 2. UNDERSTAND! PLAN! AND READ HOW BASIC STRUCTURES ARE KNITTED. 3. CREATE DIGITAL KNITTING INSTRUCTIONS AND PROCESS THEM USING M1PLUS! THE SOFTWARE BEING USED TO OPERATE STOLL KNITTING MACHINES._
 4. TO BE FAMILIAR WITH THE INDUSTRIAL KNITTING MACHINE! ITS KEY COMPONENTS AND OPERATION MECHANISM._
 5. FAMILIARIZE THEMSELVES WITH RECENT ACADEMIC RESEARCH DEALING WITH INDUSTRIAL KNITTING.
02060839.name: INTRODUCTION TO COMPUTERIZED KNITTING

02060840.about: contemporary computer based fabrication technlogies, methods and ideas in architecture. hands on design and fabrication assignmentsin which computer based fabrication machines (computer controlled milling machines, 3d printers and laser cutters) and software will be used.
02060840.name: Computer Based Fabrication Methods in Architecture

02060841.about:
Theories and methodologies of parametric design in Architecture: Parametric design as a way of thinking, classical architecture, parametric models of form finding, models and styles in digital Architecture. Developing parametric models using scripting environmentdefining elements, relationships and parameters
 Learning Outcomes: At the end of the course the student will know how to apply methodologies and techniques of parametric design. 2. Implement parametric models (i.e. mathematical models, geometric transformations.3. Algorithms of form finding, form generation). 3. Be fluent in paramedtric language (i.e., grasshopper: Definition of components, relationship and parameters, 4. Design on experimental parametric project on a small scale. Design of experimental parametric project (small scale)
02060841.name: Parametric Design in Digital Architectur

02060842.about:
the course will deal with different methodologies that integrate research, development and design of industrial products in an academic and professional environment. the course will bring together different theories in these processes in the fields of industry and technology design efforts, and will provide live examples from industry projects. a number of guest lecturers will be invited to describe the "test cases" of research, development and design processes, to present possible difficulties in these processes, opportunities and challenges. the students will study the required subjects in the field, and will assimilate the conclusions in the researc h, development and design process of his or her thesis project.final project in the industrial design track.
 learning outcomes: 
 at the end of the course the student will:
 1. learn the subjects required in the theoretical field of research and development methodologies in an industrial product design enviroment.
 2. integrate and use the conclusions of the research, development and design process of the thesis project or its final project in the industrial design track.
 3. demonstrate through a project his.her personal appro
02060842.name: Design Research and Development

02060843.about:
at the end of the course the student will know the disruptive revolutions in industrial design, and will examine the significant role of design in the success of the technological revolutions that will be covered. the course will analyze the major changes broughtabout by the fourth industrial revolution and its impact on a wide range of industrial design areas such as the computing revolution, the handheld pda revolution, the 3d digital object revolution, 3d printing, virtual reality and augmented reality.
 each of the lessons will be devoted to one area from a broad background, will review the field from its birth to the present and will analyze futu re trends. learning outcomes:
 students will be able to:
 1. to analyze and detail the major changes brought about by the fourth industrial revolution.
 2. elaborate on its impact on a wide range of areas in industrial design and ui desin and user interface ux.
 demonstrate it ability by analyzing a product.service that has not been reviewed in the course throught presentation and written work. 
 4. predict future trends in the field surveyed through imaging of future product.service.
02060843.name: Design Now - Issues in Design and Technology at the Turn of the 21 Century

02060846.about:
the course explores key topics from design computation and manufacturing technologies currently disruptingbest practice architectural processes. from within the fourth industrial revolution. students will be exposed to recent research developments and pivotal cases in topics of materiality, fabrication and computation, their multi-disciplinary nature and their influence on both research and pracice.
 at the end of the course, the student will be able to: 1. establishing a comprehensive understanding of disruptive processes from within design research. 2.identification of multi-disciplinary tools and methodologies enabling disruption in architectural pr actice.
02060846.name: Disruptive Technologies in Architecture and Desing

02060847.about:
PRODUCT SERVICE SYSTEMS (PSS) ARE BUSINESS MODELS THAT PROVIDE A COHESIVE MIX OF PRODUCTS AND SERVICES THAT WORK TOGETHER TO FORM ASYNERGISTIC OUTCOME. THEY EMERGE AS INNOVATIVE MODELS OF REDUCING CONSUMPTION AND WASTE AND PROMOTING SOCIAL AND PRO-ENVIRONMENTAL SOLUTIONS. SUCH SYSTEMS ARE AROUND US EVERYWHERE. IN THE COURSE! YOU WILL WORK IN GROUPS TO MAP AN EXISTING PSS AND DEVELOP A VALUE PROPOSITION FOR IMPROVING OR DUPLICATING IT.  
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: BY THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. RECOGNIZE! UNDERSTAND! AND USE BASIC CONCEPTS IN THE FIELD OF PRODUCT SERVICE SYSTEMS (PSS).
 2. USE A RANGE OF ETHNOGRAPHIC TOOLS FOR STUDY ING AND MAPPING EXISTING PSS. 
 3. USE A RANGE OF SERVICE DESIGN TOOLS FOR DEVELOPING! AND COMMUNICATING NEW PSS.
02060847.name: TOPICS IN PRODUCT SERVICE SYSTEM DESIGN

02060911.about:
Formulation of mathematical models in architecture and planning and introduction to optimization techniques:  linear and gravity models, simulation, linear and dynamic programming, network analysis, heuristic models for space allocation.  Emphasis on the use of computer for solving the mathematical models.
 Short exercises and a project in developing mathematical models will be run on the computer.
02060911.name: Computer Aided Design 2

02060913.about: The syllabus will be determined by the guest lecturer, with the approval of the graduate committee, before the beginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060913.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 1

02060914.about: The syllabus will be determined by the guest lecturer, with the approval of the graduate committee, before the beginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060914.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 2

02060915.about: course outline will be determined by the teacher and approved by the committee towards the semester when the course will be offered.
02060915.name: Selected Topics in Architecture 3

02060916.about: course outline will be determined by the teacher and approved by the committee towards the semester when the course will be offered.
02060916.name: Selected Topics in Arcitecture 4

02060917.about:
AN ANALYSIS OF THE BUILT SPACE AND THE DAILY LIFE CONDUCTED IN IT IN THE LIGHT OF SPATIAL THEORIES, A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF FOUNDATIONAL TEXTS IN TWENTIETH-CENTURY THOUGHT BY THINKERS SUCH AS LEFEBVRE AND FOUCAULT, AND CONTEMPORARY CRITICAL ARTICLES, OVERVIEW OF CONCEPTS SUCH AS "HETEROTOPIA" OR "PANOPTICON" IN THE CONTEXT OF THE ARCHITECTURAL DISCIPLINE, AND OF ISSUES DERIVED FROM THEM SUCH AS "THE PRODUCTION OF SPACE".
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE, THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. UNDERSTAND CONCEPTS AND THEORETICAL THINKING CONCERNING THE BUILT AND DESIGNED SPACE, AND DEVELOP A CRITICAL ATTITUDE TOWARDS THEM.
 2. USE T HEORETICAL APPROACHES TO ANALYZE AND DESIGN BUILDINGS THROUGH QUESTIONS AIMED AT THE HIDDEN DIMENTIONS OF LIFE._
 3. DEEPEN THEIR ABILITY TO DEVELOP A THEORETICAL DISCUSSION IN THE FINAL PROJECT OR GRADUATE RESEARCH._
02060917.name: TOPICS IN ARCH: ARCH. AND SPACE THEORIES

02060918.about:
SPATIAL HUMANITIES HAVE EMERGED AS PART OF THE DIGITAL HUMANITIES IN RECENT YEARS. IT IS BASED ON TECHNOLOGICAL DEVELOPMENTS IN THEANALYSIS AND DIGITIZATION OF HISTORICAL ARCHIVES AND BIG DATA! AS WELL AS GEOGRAPHICAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS AND DATA SCIENCE. WE AREAT AN EXCITING POINT IN TIME WHEN DIGITAL TOOLS CAN BE INVENTED AND PERFECTED TO EXPAND THE SCOPE OF HISTORICAL KNOWLEDGE BEYOND "CONVENTIONAL" RESEARCH METHODOLOGIES. IN THIS COURSE! WE WILL EXPLORE WHAT CONSTITUTES BUILT HERITAGE TODAY AND HOW ITS MEANINGS CAN BE DISASSEMBLED AND REASSEMBLED USING THE GROWING DIGITAL KNOWLEDGE BASE. BY APPLYING THEORETICAL AND TECHNOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE TO CRITICAL RESEARCH ON HISTORY AND THE URBAN! LANDSCAPE! OR ARCHITECTURAL SPACE! STUDENTS WILL ACQUIRE THEORETICAL AND RESEARCH KNOWLEDGE! AS WELL AS LEARN TO USE GIS-BASED DIGITAL TOOLS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE 1. COLLECT AND ANALYZE HISTORICAL AND CONTEMPORARY DATA AND PRESENT IT THROUGH DIGITAL AND TRADITIONAL MEANS AND REACH NEW HISTORICAL INSIGHTS THROUGH THEM! AS WELL AS: 2. CONVERT HISTORICAL IMAGERY MAPPING TO DIGITAL MAPPING WITH THE ABILITY TO IDENTIFY UNIQUE PATTERNS BASED ON THE MAPPING 3
02060918.name: DIGITAL HISTORY AND CRITICAL HERITAGE

02060919.about:
G OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. RESEARCH PRECEDENTS OF RESIDENTIAL PROJECTS AND EXTRACT INSIGHTS ON SIGNIFICANT ASPECTS OF RESIDENTIAL DESIGN TOOLS._
 2. ANALYZE A SITE FOR A RESIDENTIAL PROJECT IN AMSTERDAM._
 3. REVIEW ANDDISCUSS ARCHITECTURAL PROJECTS FROM OBSERVATION AND OWN EXPERIENCE._
 4. DEVELOP (INDIVIDUALLY AND IN TEAMS) CONCEPTS FOR RESIDENTIAL PROJECTS._
 5. ENSEMBLE! CURATE! AND PRESENT THE STUDY RESULTS IN A WRITTEN SUMMARY/EXHIBITION.
02060919.name: SELECTED TOPIC IN: THE NETHERLANDS

02060921.about:
PARTICULARLY IN THE GRASSHOPPER ENVIRONMENT! FOR PARAMETRIC DESIGN OF SMART BUILDING SKINS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDETNS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. FAMILIARIZE THEMSELVES WITH THEORETICAL FOUNDATIONS IN CLIMATIC DESIGN OF BUILDING ENVELOPES.
 2. USE KEY PRINCIPLES AND TERMS FOR DESIGNING BUILDING ENVELOPES AND THEIR COMPONENTS._
 3. GAIN TECHNOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE THAT EMPHASIZES THE LATEST ADVANCEMENTS IN ADVANCED TECHNOLOGIES AND MATERIALS! LEADING TO A HIGH LEVEL OF ENVIRONMENTAL OPTIMIZATION AND FOSTERING INNOVATIVE ARCHITECTURAL EXPRESSIONS. 
 4. IMPLEMENT DIGITAL TOOLS FOR PLANNING AND OPTIMIZING ENVELOPE FUNCTIONS DURING THE  DESIGN PROCESS.
02060921.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN SMART SKINS

02060922.about:
exploring the native vegetation of israel, categorized into phytogeographic regions and various taxonomies: trees, shrubs, climbers, and geophytes. studying their botanical, horticultural, ecological, architectural, and agro-technical characteristics. examining their suitability and integration options while creating a mediterranean landscape in urban and rural areas. the learning will take place in the classroom and through field trips. the course is intended for students in landscape architecture and architecture programs. : learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will how to:
 1. recognize the variety of native vegetation that can b e used in planning sustainable gardens and landscapes.
 2. recognize the paradigm of sustainability in planning water-efficient gardens suitable for the mediterranean climate.
 3.integrate native vegetation in urban and rural landscape planning.
 4. acquire toolsfor self-learning of native vegetation and evaluate their integration in the planning of sustainable gardens and ladscapes.
02060922.name: ACQUAINTANCE WITH WILD PLANTS FOR GARDEN

02060923.about:
THE COURSE DEALS WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF RESEARCH METHODS IN THE DIGITAL HUMANITIES FOR THE BENEFIT OF RESEARCH QUESTIONS IN THE HISTORY OF ARCHITECTURE. ACCORDINGLY! THE COURSE DISCUSSES RESEARCH CHALLENGES OF ARCHITECTURAL CREATION PROCESSES THAT OCCUR IN QUANTITY AND THE FORMATION OF SUITABLE RESEARCH TOOLS FROM THE FIELD OF DIGITAL HUMANITIES. THE STUDENTS WILL READ LITERATURE FROM THE FIELDS OF ART HISTORY AND DIGITAL LITERATURE! AND LEARN FROM THEIR DEVELOPMENT OF QUANTITATIVE TOOLS IN THE FIELDS OF LITERATURE AND ART. FOLLOWING! THE STUDENTS WILL DEVELOP THEORETICAL POSITIONS AND PERSONAL METHODOLOGICAL TOOLS FOR EACH STUDENT.
 LEARNING OUTCOM ES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL:
 1. IDENTIFY AND FORMULATE QUANTITATIVE RESEARCH QUESTIONS IN THE HISTORY OF ARCHITECTURE.
 2. GAIN AN INTRODUCTION TO THE LITERATURE IN THE DIGITAL HUMANITIES IN THE FIELDS OF VISUAL ART AND LITERATURE (TEXTUAL ART).
 3. ADAPT RESEARCH TOOLS IN THE DIGITAL HUMANITIES IN THE FIELDS OF ART HISTORY AND LITERATURE TO A RESEARCH QUESTION IN QUANTITATIVE ARCHITECTURAL HISTORY.
 4. CONDUCT A SYNTHESIS OF RESEARCH QUESTIONS AND RESEARCH TOOLS IN FAVOR OF EXPANDING THE DISCIPLINARYBOUNDAR
02060923.name: TOPICS IN HISTORY OF ARCH. AND DIGITAL

02060924.about:
