THE ATOMIC BOMBING OF THE JAPANESE CITIES OF HIROSHIMA AND NAGASAKI IN AUGUST 1945 BY THE US FORCES MARKED THE BEGINNING OF AN UNPRECEDENTED PERIOD IN HUMAN HISTORY. THIS COURSE IS A DESIGN-RESEARCH SEMINAR! WHICH WILL EXAMINE THE VARIOUS CULTURAL RESPONSES TO THE INVENTION AND PROLIFERATION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS AND ENERGY IN THE DECADES FOLLOWING WWII! FOCUSING ON THEIR EFFECTS ON ARCHITECTURAL DISCOURSE! VISUAL CULTURE AND THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT. THUS! THE SEMINAR 6ONE HAND AND NUCLEAR HOPES ON THE OTHER.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
_1. FAMILIAR WITH SIGNIFICANT AND MEANINGFUL EVENTS IN COLD WAR HISTORY.
 2 . FORMULATE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THE INVENTION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF ARCHITECTURE AND CULTURE IN THE 20TH AND 21ST CENTURIES.
 3. CRITICAL ANALYZE ARCHITECTURAL AND ARTISTIC WORKS AND OBJECTS.
 4. FORMULATE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN TECHNOLOGICAL DEVELOPMENTS AND ARCHITECTURAL AND CULTURAL PRODUCTION.
 5. EXPRESS AND REPRESENT HISTORICAL AND ARCHITECTURAL KNOWLEDGE IN VISUAL MEANS AND THROUGH VARIOUS MEDIA.
02060924.name: ARCHITECTURE AND CULTURE IN THE NUCLEAR

02060925.about:
the reform of the architecture program transformed the professional degree to master degree, and in so doing created the opportunity to address the challenge of architectural schools worldwide combining research and practice, that is, producing new knowledge through design in the studio. this conception considers the architectural studio as a research laboratory that respond to contemporary issues in architecture.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the cource he end of the course the students will acquire understading of studio work as research through supervised reading and interviews with expriment in supervised reading of texts and interviews with pa st architects-researchers. they will experiment with project analysis, primarily those conducted in the final project studio, will extract research questions from them, and will acquire tools of analysis, representation and publication of design research.
02060925.name: RESEARCH BY DESIGN IN ARCHITECTURE

02060926.about:
exposition to engineering infrastructures located in the open space (energy, communication, water, drainage, sewage, and transportation). integration of these infrastructures into diverse landscapes along various scales, with emphasis on landscape architecture tools. introduction to infrastructures coordination in public spaces and urban environments. introduction to the green infrastructureparadigm.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course, the students will be able to:
 1. be familiar with the engineering infrastructures located in the open space and in the urban space.
 2. be familiar with the green infrastructure paradigm.
 3. be able to in tegrate infrastructures in the urban and rural landscape planning process.
 4. be able to able to suggest and evaluate green alternatives for infrastructures' location.
02060926.name: INFRANSTRUCTURES IN THE OPEN SPACE

02060927.about:
TO UNDERTAKE A CRITICAL EXAMINATION OF THE URBAN AND HOUSING ENVIRONMENTS THAT HAVE BEEN BUILT AND PLANNED IN ISRAEL DURING THE 2000S. AN ANALYSIS OF BOTH THE MAIN PLANNING PRACTICES WITHIN ISRAEL AND THE RECENT INTERNATIONAL THEORETICAL FRAMEWORKS. THIS INTERDISCIPLINARY STUDY AIMS TO EQUIP STUDENTS WITH TOOLS FOR CONDUCTING CRITICAL AND ETHICAL ANALYSES OF URBAN ENVIRONMENTS. TOPICS: (1) THE PLANNING SYSTEM IN ISRAEL! (2) ANALYSES OF NEWLY DEVELOPED NEIGHBORHOODS! INCLUDING URBAN REGENERATION! AND (3) EXPLORATION OF THEGAP BETWEEN CONTEMPORARY PLANNING PRACTICES IN ISRAEL AND THE FOREFRONT OF THEORETICAL KNOWLEDGE.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. UNDERSTAND THE PLANNING SYSTEM IN ISRAEL AND IDENTIFY KEY STAKEHOLDERS AT THE NATIONAL! DISTRICT! AND LOCAL LEVELS.
 2. FAMILIARIZE WITH CURRENT THEORETICAL STUDIES IN THE FIELD OF URBANISM.
 3. ANALYZE PLANS AND EVALUATE THEM COMPARED TO A SET OF PARAMETERS DERIVED FROM THEORETICAL READINGS.
 4. GAIN INSIGHT INTO THE URBAN REGENERATION PROGRAM IN ISRAEL.
 5. CONDUCT FIELD RESEARCH IN A RECENTLY BUILT AND POPULATED NEIGHBORHOOD.
 6. IDENTIFY VARIOUS COMPONENTS OF URBANISM AND EVALUATE
02060927.name: CONTEMPORARY URBANISM IN ISRAEL

02060928.about:
IN THE HISTORY OF MODERN CITIES! URBAN PROTEST PLAYS A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN GIVING MEANING TO URBAN SPACE! AND ITS DESIGN. SOCIAL MOVEMENTS! LOCAL COMMUNITIES! AND EVEN REVOLUTIONS! TAKE PLACE IN CITIES! INFLUENCING THEIR DEVELOPMENT AND THE LIFE AND MODES OF OPERATION WITHIN THEM. THIS COURSE AIMS TO EXPLORE THE HISTORY OF URBAN PROTEST! AND TO THOROUGHLY ANALYZE THE WAYS ACTS OF PROTEST MATERIALIZE IN URBAN SPACE AND TAKE PART IN THE DESIGN OF PUBLIC SPACE IN THE CITY. THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON THE INQUIRY AND ANALYSIS OFTHE PHYSICAL AND SPATIAL DIMENSIONS OF URBAN PROTESTS! BASED ON INTRODUCTION TO THEORETICAL APPROACHES THAT EXPLORE THEIR POLITICAL!  SOCIAL! AND CULTURAL ASPECTS. LEARNING IN THE COURSE WILL BE BASED ON THE ANALYSIS OF CASE STUDIES OF URBAN PROTESTS IN ISRAEL ANDFROM AROUND THE WORLD.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL:
 1. LEARN DIFFERENT THEORIES THAT HELP TO EXPLORE AND UNDERSTAND URBAN PROTEST. 
 2. COMPARE DIFFERENT CASES AND EVENTS OF URBAN PROTEST. 
 3. EXERCISE A CRITICAL MULTI-DIMENSIONAL ANALYSIS OF CONCRETE CASES OF PROTEST IN URBAN SPACE.
02060928.name: RESISTANCE! ACTIVISM AND URBAN PROTEST

02060929.about:
THIS COURSE TACKLES THE CHALLENGE OF BALANCING HIGH ENVIRONMENTAL PERFORMANCE WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY INCREASING URBAN DENSITY AT THE URBAN BLOCK SCALE. DURING THE PLANNING STAGES! URBAN PLANNERS MUST ADDRESS SEVERAL ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS! WHICH ARE EXCEPTIONALLY CHALLENGING IN THE ISRAELI METROPOLITAN CONTEXT EXPECTED TO DOUBLE IN SIZE BY 2050. DESPITE SCIENTIFIC ADVANCEMENTS AND THE AVAILABILITY OF NEW TOOLS AND METHODS! URBAN BLOCK PLANNING DOES NOT CONSISTENTLY INCORPORATE ENVIRONMENTAL PERFORMANCE CONSIDERATIONS. THIS COURSE IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH A TOOLKIT FOR INTEGRATING CLIMATIC ISSUES INTO DESIGN AND CONDUCTING A COMPREHENSIVE ENVIR ONMENTAL STUDY AT THE URBAN BLOCK SCALE DURING THE EARLIEST PHASES OF PLANNING. THE COURSE EXAMINES THE INTERDEPENDENCE OF CLIMATE!MICROCLIMATE! BUILDING PERFORMANCE! AND BUILDING MORPHOLOGY THROUGH A COMBINATION OF THEORETICAL INSTRUCTION AND PRACTICAL APPLICATION. STUDENTS WILL LEARN SEVERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PERFORMANCE CRITERIA! ANALYSIS METHODS! PARAMETRIC ANALYSIS! AND OPTIMIZATION TECHNIQUES FOR FILTERING PLANNING OPTIONS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. DEVELOP AND REFINE URBAN BL
02060929.name: URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL DESIGN ANALYTICS02

02060931.about: THE COURSE WILL WIDEN AND DEEPEN THE UNDERSTANDING OF PARTICIPANTS IN CONTEMPORARY METHODS IN URBAN DESIGN, FORCES, AND PROCESSES THAT SHAPE URBAN SPACE IN A LOCAL AND GLOBAL CONTEXT.  BY EXPLORING THEORIES, POLICIES AND PRACTICE, WE WILL EXAMEN THE INTERPLAY BETWEEN CURRENT URBAN CHALLENGES, STRATEGIC PLANNING METHODS, (RE)DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF SPATIAL POLICY, AND THE DESIGN OF SYSTEMS, URBAN FABRIC, AND PLACES IN WHICH THE EVERYDAY OF URBAN LIFE TAKES PLACE.
02060931.name: Contemporary Methods in Urban Design

02060933.about:
the course provides an introdution to the urban forest and its planning. major themes include: history, environmental and agrotechnical aspects trees' importance to the urban landscape, planning tools and principles for a proper integration of trees in the publicrealm while making the most of the urban forest ecosystem services.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the coursse the students will:
 * students will familiarize themelves with the concept of an urban forest and its importance to the built environment. * students will learn practical tools for integrating the urban forest in urban design.
02060933.name: THE URBAN FOREST

02060937.about:
the importance of the indoor environment. overview of the metrics utilized to define ieq and methods to identify their correlationsto energy consumption! health and productivity and their contribution to larger sustainable development goals. investigation of newmethods and advanced strategies for ieq improvement! including air quality! lighting! thermal quality! acoustic conditions! and spatial quality. learning outcomes: upon successful completion of the course! students will be able to: 1. apply the metrics used to evaluate air quality! lighting quality! thermal quality! acoustic conditions! and spatial quality to characterize building conditions.
  2 use qualitative and quantitative methods to measure ieq in buildings 3. identify and recommend design solutions that promote healthy! energy-efficient! and productive built environments. 
 4. identify critical questions facing building stakeholders when undergoing a new construction or major renovation project.
02060937.name: INDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY

02060938.about:
this course explores the design of intelligent environments that are aware of - and proactively cater to - the needs of building occupants. the course focuses on the process of developing! simulating! and evaluating human behavior scenarios in responsive buildings to improve people efficiency and experience. classes include lectures! workshops! and project development discussions.
 learning outcomes: upon successful completion of the course! students will be able to:
 1. critically assess opportunities and benefits to designing responsive environments.
 2. define human behavior scenarios in responsive buildings.
 3. use computational methods for modeli ng! simulating! and visualizing human behavior  scenarios in responsive environments.
 4. define desired user experiences and develop design strategies to accommodate them. 
 5. analyze and compare alternative building response strategies to satisfy occupant needs.
02060938.name: INTELLIGENT ENVIRONMENTS

02060939.about:
THE COURSE FOCUSES ON THE BUILDING ENVELOPE AND AIMS TO BRIDGE THE SIGNIFICANT GAP BETWEEN THE COMMON INTUITION IN DESIGNING SHADING IN BUILDINGS AROUND US AND THE UNREALIZED POTENTIAL FOR APPLYING COMPUTERIZED TOOLS THAT ENABLE ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS OF THE ENVELOPE'S PERFORMANCE AT VARIOUS STAGES IN THE PLANNING PROCESS. THE APPROACH TAKEN BY THE COURSE IS RETROSPECTIVE THINKING (REVERSE ENGINEERING) - THAT IS! WE WILL START FROM OBSERVING AND ANALYZING THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT TO FORM PLANNING INSIGHTS AND PROPOSE OPTIMIZATION AND REFINEMENT SUGGESTIONS. THE COURSE INCLUDES A COMBINATION OF THEORETICAL LECTURES! FIELD EXPERIENCE AND OBSERVATION! AND CO MPUTERIZED ANALYSES! WITH THE AIM (A) TO DEVELOP THE ABILITY TO OBSERVE! ANALYZE! AND EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF ENVELOPE DESIGNSTRATEGIES USING ANALYTICAL TOOLS! AND (B) TO USE THE ANALYTICAL MODEL TO EXAMINE VARIOUS ENVELOPE DESIGN STRATEGIES AND SCENARIOS ACCORDING TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS! BUILDING OCCUPANCY PATTERNS AND CLIMATE AND MICROCLIMATE. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. FAMILIARIZE WITH DIFFERENT ENVIRONMENTAL METRICS AND VARIOUS TOOLS TO EFFICIENTLY CALCULATE THEM F
02060939.name: BUILDING ENVELOPES DESIGN IN REVERSE ENG

02060940.about: A basic acquaintance with philosophical trends which have influenced architectural approaches.  (e.g. positivism, phenomenology, structuralism).  Issues in epistemology, ethics and aesthetics will be clarified and discussed in the architectural context.
02060940.name: Philosophical Topics in Architectural Context

02060941.about:
THE AEC SECTOR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR NEARLY 40
 OF THE WORLD'S ANNUAL GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS. BIODESIGN AIMS TO ADDRESS THIS CHALLENGE IN ARCHITECTURE BY INTEGRATING LIVING MATERIALS IN FABRICATION PROCESSES. HARNESSING LIVING ORGANISMS CAN ENHANCE THE ECOLOGICAL FOOTPRINT OF PRODUCTION PROCESSES AND IMPROVE MATERIAL PERFORMANCE WITH PROPERTIES LIKE CARBON DIOXIDE FIXATION! DEGRADABILITY! AND RECYCLABILITY. THE COURSE WILL EXPOSE STUDENTS TO AN INTERDISCIPLINARY APPROACH BETWEEN ARCHITECTURE AND LIVING SYSTEMS. BY UNDERSTANDING AND ACCESSING MATERIAL PROTOCOLS AND FABRICATION PROCESSES! STUDENTS CAN IMPROVE THE MUTUALISM BETWEEN BUILDING MATERIALS AND T HEIR SURROUNDINGS! FOSTERING SUSTAINABLE ENVIRONMENTS. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. LEARN THE FOREFRONT OF RESEARCH AND APPLICATIONS IN BIODESIGN AND BIOFABRICATION GLOBALLY IN THE FIELD OF ARCHITECTURE.
 2. EXPLORE PROTOCOLS OF LIVING MATERIALS IN RELATION TO FABRICATION METHODS IN THE CONTEXT OF ARCHITECTURAL PERFORMANCE. 
 3. ANALYZE SCENARIOS IN THE DESIGN AND FABRICATION OF THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT THAT CAN BE IMPROVED THROUGH PRACTICES FROM THE FIELD OF BIODESIGN.
02060941.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN BIODESIGN

02060942.about:
A CALL TO RETHINK RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOOD IN KIBBUTZIM! CONSIDERING OPTIONS FOR HIGHER-DENSITY CONSTRUCTION! ADDRESSING CURRENT KIBBUTZ PRESENT CONDITIONS! BUT ALSO POPULATION DENSITY IN ISRAEL AND THE COST OF LIVING. PLANNING PROPOSALS WILL BE BASED ON RESEARCHEXAMINING THE KIBBUTZ SPATIAL HISTORY AND THE CONVENTIONAL RURAL SETTLEMENT LIFESTYLE VERSUS ECONOMIC! POLITICAL! AND LAND-RELATED CHALLENGES.
LEARNING OUTCOMES: UPON COMPLETION OF THE COURSE! THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. DEVELOP A CRITICAL APPROACH TOWARDS PLANNING PROCESSES IN THE PAST AND PRESENT.
 2. UTILIZE CONTEMPORARY APPROACHES TO HOUSING DENSITY IN VARIOUS SPATIAL CONTEXTS.
 3. D EVELOP THE ABILITY TO PLAN BASED ON IN-DEPTH RESEARCH AND THEORETICAL DISCOURSE.
02060942.name: HIGH-DENSITY NEIGHBORHOODS IN KIBBUTZIM

02060944.about:
"IN 2012 THE GOVERNMENT OF ISRAEL INITIATED THE PREPARATION OF AN INTEGRATED NATIONAL OUTLINE PLAN, AIMED AT UNIFYING AND SIMPLIFYING THE EXISTING NATIONAL OUTLINE PLANS. THIS DECISION ADDRESSED THE VAST NUMBER OF PLANS, NAVIGATIONAL CHALLENGES AND INTERNAL CONTRADICTIONS. THE ""TAMA ONE"" PLAN WAS APPROVED AND CAME INTO EFFECT IN JANUARY 2020 EFFECTIVELY CANCELLING MOST PREVIOUS NATIONAL OUTLINE PLANS.
 THE PREPARATION OF THE ""NOP 1"" PLAN PROVIDES A VALUABLE OPPORTUNITY TO UNDERSTAND THE NATIONAL PLANNING SYSTEM! THE INTERRELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN PLANS! AND THEIR COMMON RULES. THIS COURSE WILL EXPLORE ONGOING NATIONAL PLANNING ISSUES, CONFLICTS, AND "ODS OF INTEGRATION AND UNIFICATION ULTIMATELY LEADING TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MODERN PLANNING LANGUAGE PREVALENT IN TODAY'S FIELD.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. INTERNALIZE AND APPLY PLANNING TEMPLATES: UNDERSTAND AND UTILIZE THE PLANNING TEMPLATES ACCORDING TO ""TAMA ONE"" WHEN DRAFTING OUTLINE. PLANS AT ALL LEVELS WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON THE NATIONAL LEVEL. 2. CREATE COHERENT STRUCTURES: DEVELOP A CLEAR AND COHERENT STRUCTURE WHEN DRAFTING OUTLINE PLANS.
 3. CRITICAL EXAMINATION OF
02060944.name: NATIONAL OOUTLINE PLAN ONE: LAW, LANGAUA

02060946.about:
THE COURSE WILL DEMONSTRATE THE UNIQUE TIES BETWEEN CULTURE AND SOCIETY, PLACE AND REGION, AND BUILDING MATERIALS AND TECHNOLOGIES.THE INTEGRATION OF ALL THESE WILL BE EXAMINED AS DRIVING FORCES IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF TRADITIONAL BUILDING TYPOLOGIES.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL KNOW:
 1. ABLE TO IDENTIFY BUILDING MATERIALS AND TECHNOLOGIES WHICH ARE CHARACTERISTIC TO TRADITIONAL ARCHITECTURE IN PARTICULAR REGIONS.
 2. ACQUIRE TOOLS FOR THE ANALYSIS OF THE BUILT OBJECT AS A RESULT OF CONTEXTUAL INFLUENCES.
 3. ABLE TO IDENTIFY CONNECTIONS BETWEEN THE PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF AN ARCHITECTURAL OBJECT OR SETTLEMENT AND THE O PPORTUNITIES AND CONSTRAINTS OF ITS IMMEDIATE CONTEX.
02060946.name: Cultue, Materials Technology

02060948.about: the course will serve as a platform for in-depth discussions about the history of conservation from the 18th century onwards, the formulation of the conservation charters and the establishment of conservation organizations. the course will allow a broadening of the discussion about core concepts within contemporary conservation discourse, and their role in shaping current theories and practices relating to the conservation of heritage:ruins, authenticity, originality, monuments, the vernacular, restoration etc.
02060948.name: History and Phylosophy of Conservation

02060949.about:
THE TRANSITION IN THE PAST DECADES TO FINANCIAL CAPITALISM! IN WHICH ECONOMIC SPECULATIONS ARE THE DRIVING FORCE! REDEFINED THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN SOCIETY AND ARCHITECTURE - A DOMINANT CULTURE DEVELOPED AROUND REAL ESTATE! PROFIT AND RETURN - WHERE INVESTORS AND ENTREPRENEURS ARE THE ONES WHO DICTATE THE URBAN AND ARCHITECTURAL SPACES WE LIVE IN. THE COURSE FOCUSES ON SPATIAL PHENOMENON RELATED TO LATE CAPITALISM OF THE 21ST CENTURY! AND ALTERNATIVE POST-CAPITALIST FUTURES THAT MIGHT GENERATE NEW URBAN POSSIBILITIES. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. IDENTIFY CORRELATIONS! PROCESSES AND INFLUENCES BETWEEN ECONOMIC POWERS AND ARCHITECTURE URBANISM.
 2. FRAME CRITICAL RESEARCH QUESTIONS IN VARIOUS TOPIC AT THE INTERSECTION OF ARCHITECTURE/ URBANISM! ECONOMY! AND CONTEMPORARY CULTURE.
 3. DEVELOP PLAUSIBLE ALTERNATIVE SCENARIOS FOR THE CURRENT URBAN ECONOMY.
 4. EXPRESS COMPLEX IDEAS IN VISUAL LANGUAGE WITH ARCHITECTURAL TOOLS.
02060949.name: S.T.: CAPITALIST CITY! REAL ESTATE STATE

02060951.about: the local and international origins characterizing the architecture in israel. the contribution of style, technology, climate, society, landscape and other aspects to the development of local architecture. major buildings and settlements designed by leading architects. the development of building types (i.e., the kibbutz dining halls and co-operative and public housing, synagogues, univercities and museums).
02060951.name: Seminar in the History of Architecture in Israel

02060952.about:
a historical and geographical review of housing as a basic architectural type in the context of needs versus values, home and homeland, citizenship, socio-economic classes, family structure, and housing as real-estate. historical and theoretical aspects in the formation of housing as a central problem in architecture, urban and national planning. housing typologies. the relations between housing typologies and structures and the design and organization of the city and the state.
 learning outcomes:  at the end of the course the student will gain knowledge of various aspects of housing history, their implications and their contexts.
02060952.name: The History of Housing

02060953.about:
"IN 1972! UNESCO ESTABLISHED THE CONVENTION CONCERNING THE PROTECTION OF THE WORLD CULTURAL AND NATURAL HERITAGE. THE CONVENTION INCLUDES WORLD HERITAGE SITES OF OUTSTANDING UNIVERSAL VALUE! ENUMERATED IN THE WORLD HERITAGE LIST. ALONGSIDE SPECIFIC SITES! THE LIST INCLUDES LARGER AREAS THAT INTEGRATE BOTH NATURE AND HUMAN ACTIVITY. THE CONCEPT OF CULTURAL LANDSCAPES ALIGNS WITH LANDSCAPE ENSEMBLES UNDER ISRAEL'S PLANNING AND BUILDING LAW (TAMA 35)! REFLECTING PROFESSOR SHLOMO AHARONSON'S IDEA THAT ALONGSIDE PHYSICAL ELEMENTS! ISRAEL'S LANDSCAPE INCLUDES A HISTORICAL PRESENCE: ""THE STORY OF THE LAND OF ISRAEL."" FURTHEMORE! TAMA 35 PROPOSES HISTORIC! C "URAL AND NATURAL ""LANDSCAPE ENSEMBLES"" THAT WILL FORM A MOSAIC OF DIVERSE OPEN SPACES. DURING THE COURSE! WE WILL EXAMINE LANDSCAPE ENSEMBLES IN TAMA 35 IN LIGHT OF UNESCO'S DESIGNATION! ASSESSING IN WHAT WAYS THEY HAVE CONTRIBUTED TO PRESERVING CULTURAL LANDSCAPES IN ISRAEL AND PROPOSING UPDATES TO THE MAP OF LANDSCAPE ENSEMBLES AND THEIR ACCOMPANYING INSTRUCTIONS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. ANALYZE AND INTERPRET CULTURAL LANDSCAPES ACCORDING TO TYPE (PLANNED LANDSCAPE! VERNAC
02060953.name: LANDSCAPE ENSEMBLES IN NATIONAL OUTLINE

02060954.about:
Survey of the history of the city in the context of ideas of citizenship,political freedom and surplus economy. A brief review of the polis,followed by a focus on the history of the city as an economical and political space,from the 12th century onwards,includingkey periods of development of the industrial city and its consequences, formation of the discipline of city planning in response,and historical survey of theoretical and practical approaches to urban planning until, today: modernism, postmodernism, suburbanization, new urbanism and more. 
Learning outcomes:
 At the end of the cours the student will: 1. Be familiarized with a broad range of iss ues concerning the historical development of the city as a political and economical space . 
2. Understand the implications of historical issues for analysis of case studies in architectural and urban design. 
3. Be able to implement these issues in architecturaland urban design studio courses. 
4.learn to develop and formulate research questions and theoretical frameworks for inquiry.
02060954.name: The History of the City

02060955.about:
THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN ARCHIVAL RESEARCH, ON-SITE DOCUMENTATION, AND THE IDENTIFICATION OF THE VALUES OFHISTORIC SITES AS A BASIS FOR ARCHITECTURAL.LANDSCAPE.URBAN INTERVENTION. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL KNOW:
 ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE AND CAPABILITIES IN ON-SITE DOCUMENTING TECHNIQUES.
 2. BE INTRODUCED TO METHODS OF ARCHIVAL RESEARCH AND TYPES OF ARCHIVES. 
 3. LEARN TO INTEGRATE DTA FROM VARYING SOURCES. 
 4. EXPERIENCE THE PROCESS OF ANLAYSIS AND DRAWING CONCLUSIONS AS PART OF THE ARCHITECT'S ROLE IN HERITAGE SITES.
02060955.name: The Site and the Archive

02060956.about:
THE COURSE AIMS TO EXPOSE THE STUDENTS TO DIFFERENT APPROACHES AND CONCEPTIONS THAT SERVE THE ANALYSIS AND UNDERSTANDING OF SOCIAL AND POLITICAL PROCESSES THAT TAKE PART IN THE PRODUCTION AND DESIGN OF SPACE. THE GOAL OF THE COURSE IS TO OFFER THE STUDENTS THEORETICAL TOOLS WHICH COULD BE USED AS A BASIS FOR CRITICAL ANALYSIS IN THEIR PLANNING AND DESIGN PROCESS IN THE STUDIO, AND ESPECIALLY IN THE FINAL PROJECT. 
 THE COURSE WILL OFFER DIFFERENT APPROACHES AND CONCEPTIONS THAT EXPLORE THE WAYS BY WHICH SPACE, SPECIFICALLY URBAN SPACE, IS CURRENTLY BEING PRODUCED THROUGH SOCIAL AND POLITICAL PROCESSES, AND WILL ANALYSE HOW THESE PROCESSES MATERIALIZE I N THE CONCRETE BUILT ENVIRONMENT AND ARCHITECTURE.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS: 1. THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN DIFFERENT THEORIES AND APPROACHES TO EXPLORE AND UNDERSTAND THE POLITICS OF SPACE. 
 2. THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN DIFFERENT WAYSTO THEORETICALLY
02060956.name: CONCEPTIONS OF POLITICS OF SPACE

02060957.about:
STUDENTS WILL BE INTRODUCED TO TOOLS AND METHODS FOR ROBOTIC FABRICATION IN ARCHITECTURE. THIS COURSE POSITS THAT ROBOTIC RESEARCH WITHIN ARCHITECTURE IS DIRECTED TOWARD DEVELOPING WORKFLOWS AND END-EFFECTORS TO REUSE INDUSTRIAL ROBOTS FOR DESIGN OBJECTIVES. THROUGH CREATIVE DESIGN EXPERIMENTATION, STUDENTS WILL LEARN FUNDAMENTAL TOOLS FOR DEVELOPING PARAMETRIC WORKFLOWS TO FABRICATE ARTIFACTS. 
_LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 * UNDERSTANDING THE FUNDAMENTAL ASPECTS OF ROBOTIC FABRICATION IN ARCHITECTURE. * DEVELOPING A PARAMETRIC WORKFLOW FOR THE ROBOTIC FABRICATION PROCESS. * BASIC OPERATION OF AN INDUSTRIAL ROBOTIC ARM. * EXPERIMENTATION WITH SMALL-SCALE ROBOT IC FABRICATION. * DEVELOPING AND EVALUATING A METHOD FOR ROBOTIC FABRICATION WITHIN
02060957.name: INTRODUCTION TO ARCHITECTURAL ROBOTICS

02060958.about:
THIS COURSE EXAMINES NEW MODES OF INTERACTION BETWEEN BUILDINGS AND PEOPLE LEVERAGING RECENT ADVANCEMENTS IN SENSING, PREDICTION, ACTUATION, AND COMMUNICATION TECHNOLOGIES. STUDENTS FROM TECHNION, CORNELL, AND CORNELL TECH WILL WORK TOGETHER TO DEVELOP PROJECTS IN COLLABORATION WITH INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRY PARTNERS. CLASSES INCLUDE GUEST LECTURES, PAPER PRESENTATIONS, AND PROJECT DEVELOPMENT DISCUSSIONS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 STUDENTS WILL LEARN TO DEVELOP INTERDISCIPLINARY HUMAN-BUILDING INTERACTION PROPOSALS TRANSFORMING BUILDINGS FROM PASSIVE CONTAINERS INTO INTELLIGENT ADAPTIVE SYSTEMS.
02060958.name: TOPICS IN HUMAN-BUILDING INTERACTIONS

02060959.about:
CRITICAL PRESENTATION OF CONSTRUCTION AND COMFORT-PROVIDING TECHNOLOGIES IN ARCHITECTURE FOCUSING ON THEIR PERFORMATIVE AND CULTURAL ASPECTS. SPECIAL ATTENTION IS GIVEN TO PREVALENT LOCAL CONSTRUCTION TECHNOLOGIES. WE WILL ALSO DISCUSS THE CONCEPT OF "PERFORMANCE" IN THE BUILT ENVIRONMENT AND HOW IT HAS INFLUENCED THE ADOPTION OF CERTAIN CONSTRUCTION TECHNOLOGIES. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL LEARN TO APPLY A CRITICAL APPROACH IN DISCUSSING THE CHOICE OF CONSTRUCTION AND COMFORT-PROVIDING TECHNOLOGIES IN VARIOUS ARCHITECTURAL CONTEXTS. THE COURSE WILL ASSIST THE STUDENTS IN REALIZING THAT THE ADOPTION OF CONSTRUCT ION AND COMFORT-PROVIDING TECHNOLOGIES AND THEIR DISTRIBUTION IS INFLUENCED NOT ONLY BY THEIR FUNCTIONAL ROLE BUT ALSO BY CULTURAL,SOCIAL AND IDEOLOGICAL FACTORS THAT GO BEYOND THE NARROW FIELD OF STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING.
02060959.name: TECHNOLOGICAL HISTORY OF ARCHITECTURE

02060961.about:
THIS COURSE WILL FOCUS ON URBAN REGENERATION STRATEGIES AND PUBLIC POLICIES IN ISRAEL AND SELECTED COUNTRIES. THE COURSE WILL EXAMINE THE EFFECTS OF URBAN REGENERATION THROUGH THE PHYSICAL (HOUSING AND PUBLIC SPACE), SOCIAL (RESIDENTS AND COMMUNITY) AND ENVIRONMENTAL ASPECTS. IN THIS WAY, IT WILL ENRICH THE THEORETICAL AND PRACTICAL TOOLBOX._
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BECOME FAMILIAR WITH A VARIETY OF URBAN REGENERATION POLICIES AND STRATEGIES, WHILE DEVELOPING TOOLS FOR CRITICAL THINKING TO EXAMINE THE STRATEGIES INFLUENCES.  THE COURSE CONTAINS THREE LEARNING OUTCOMES: AN INTERNATIONAL CASE STUDY, EMPIRICAL RESEARCH I N ISRAEL AS WELL AS A PERSONAL POLICY PAPER FOR URBAN REGENERATION.
02060961.name: SELECTED TOPICS IN URBAN REGENERATION

02060962.about: THE COURSE INTRODUCES STUDENTS TO THE CONTEMPORARY CRITICAL DISCOURSE IN ARCHITECTURE. THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON BUILDINGS, PROJECTS, AND TEXTS THAT HAVE SHAPED THE DISCOURSE IN THE PAST 30 YEARS. WE WILL EXAMINE THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW FORMS OF ARCHITECTURAL PRACTICE, IN THE CONTEXT OF RAPID URBAN DEVELOPMENT, NEW DIGITAL AND MATERIAL TECHNIQUES, ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATIC CONCERNS, GROWING ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL TENSIONS, AND CHANGES IN THE GLOBAL DIVISION OF LABOR AND RESOURCES. THROUGH A CLOSE READING OF PROJECTS, WE WILL ASK HOW ARCHITECTURAL OBJECTS, MATERIAL CONFIGURATIONS, AND BUILDING SYSTEMS, EXPRESS DISTINCT THEORETICAL POSITIONS. HOW COULD CONTE MPORARY IDEAS BE READ IN THE VERY MATERIAL COMPOSITION OF ARCHITECTURE ITSELF. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BECOME FLUENT IN READING CURRENT ARCHITECTURAL REPRESENTATIONS AND CONFIGURATIONS AGAINST A RANGE OF THEORETICAL POSITIONS. STUDENTS WILL LEARN HOW TO FORMULATE THEIR OWN CRITICAL RESPONSE TO THESE POSITIONS, AND WILL ARTICULATE IT THROUGHOUT THE COURSE BY PRESENTING AND LEADING A DISCUSSION IN CLASS, SUBMITTING A SHORT WRITING ASSIGNMENT AND A FINAL ESSAY.
02060962.name: CONTEMPORARY ARCHITECTURAL THEORYY

02060963.about:
THE COURSE EXAMINES STATUTORY PLANNING AS A TOOL FOR THE POLICY AND REGULATION OF SPACE. THE AIM OF THE COURSE IS TO EXPOSE THE STUDENT TO THE PLANNING AND BUILDING LAW, UNDERSTANDING THE NATIONAL PLANNING SYSTEM, TYPES OF PLANS, PLAN COMPONENTS (BLUEPRINT, REGULATIONS AND APPENDICES), PLANNING AND CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS, FIRE AND ESCAPE SAFETY STANDARDS, USER SAFETY, ACCESSIBILITY AND HEALTH AND IMPLEMENTATION, ON THE CHANGES - THEIR CHARACTERISTICS AND STATUS, DISCUSSION AND APPROVAL PROCESSES, FLEXIBILITY BETWEEN PLANNING AND EXECUTION - FACILITATIONS AND OVERUSE AND DISCRETION. THE COURSE ALSO DEALS WITH REPRESENTING AND INTEGRATING ECONOMIC, SOC IAL, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONSIDERATIONS IN PLANNING PROCESSES, INCLUDING PUBLIC AWARENESS, PUBLIC PARTICIPATION AND TOOLS , AND THE UNIQUENESS OF THE ACTIONS OF A LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT. 
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of thecourse:
 1. Students will be acquainted with and become proficient in the planning and building law and its constant updating process. 2.students will develop preliminary skills in using legal and professional language , and will learn to interpret plans, drawings, guidelines, appendices, and data bases. 3. studen
02060963.name: Legal and Policy Tools in Planning

02060964.about: CONTROL OVER THE IMPLEMENTATION OF PLANNING, LICENSING AND EXECUTION PROCESSES. AT THE PLANNING STAGE - FEASIBILITY STUDY, SURVEYS AND DATA COLLECTION, PROGRAM, INITIAL AND FINAL PLANNING, COORDINATION OF PLANNING, PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION OF A PLAN, TREATMENT WITH PLANNING INSTITUTIONS, COORDINATION OF INFRASTRUCTURE. IN THE LICENSING AND PLANNING STAGES FOR IMPLEMENTATION - INITIAL AND FINAL PLANNING, EDITING AND SUBMITTING AN APPLICATION FOR A PERMIT, KNOWLEDGE OF LICENSING SYSTEMS, COORDINATION OF SYSTEMS AND CONSULTANTS, DESIGN CONTROL AND WORK WITH A CONTROL INSTITUTE, IMPLEMENTATION PLANS, LISTS AND SPECIFICATIONS, KNOWLEDGE OF OFFICIALS IN TH E LICENSING PROCESS, PLANNING CHANGES AND THEIR IMPLICATIONS FOR THE PROCESS. IN THE EXECUTION STAGES - INITIATION OF THE EXECUTIONPROCESS, GUIDANCE OF CONSULTANTS, CONTRACTORS AND PROFESSIONALS, KNOWLEDGE OF THE CONSTRUCTION SITE AND ITS ORGANIZATION, CONSTRUCTION EQUIPMENT AND SAFETY AT WORK, LABORATORY TESTS, TOP AND CLOSE SUPERVISION, PERFORMANCE CONTROL AND WORK WITH CONTROL INSTITUTES,COORDINATION WITH INFRASTRUCTURE AND APPROVING FACTORS, CHANGES DURING EXECUTION, RECOGNITION EXECUTION PROBLEMS, KNOWLEDGE OF FUNCTIONARIES IN T
02060964.name: Planning and Construction Proceses

02060968.about: SPATIAL GEOMETRIES, SPATIAL STRUCTURES AND COMPLEX BUILDING ENVELOPES. LIGHTWEIGHT CONSTRUCTION IN STEEL, ALUMINUM, GLASS, PLASTIC MATERIALS AND LIGHTWEIGHT SHELL ELEMENTS FROM COMPOSITE MATERIALS. MEMBRANE STRUCTURES, AIR-INFLATED STRUCTURES, RETRACTABLE STRUCTURES. CURTAIN WALLS, OPENINGS AND GLAZING. EXECUTION OF A SPATIAL STRUCTURE DESIGN PROJECT IN THE CONSTRUCTION TECHNOLOGIES TAUGHT INTHE COURSE. APPLICATION OF CONSTRUCTION METHODS AND TECHNOLOGIES, USE OF MATERIALS, PLANNING AND DESIGN OF BUILDING DETAILS SUCH AS: COPNNECTIONS, ANCHORS, INSULATION AND SEALING.
02060968.name: Building Technology and Construction Details 3

02060971.about:
he course provides relevant tools for editing final project materials in the faculty courses and producing them for printing. its purpose is to be used as a platform that prepares students for advanced studio courses in the architecture and landscape departments.making the project materials accessible will allow students to market themselves and their work in a better way and to brand the project in which they are involved.
 learning outcomes: at the conclusion of this course! students will be able to:
 1. present their final projects while enriching the terminology they use to describe them..
 2. discuss issues dealing with the application of theorie s of visual perception studied in previous courses._
 3. adopt a pattern of thinking and criticism and ways of expression to describe a single project item as well as entire projects.
 4. familiarize themselves with online platforms for building and presenting portfolios.__
 5! develop strategies for promoting themselves through print and online portfolios. 
 6. produce and criticize researchbrochures for their final projects.
 7. acquire tools to visualize data using various types of mapping methods._
 8. effectively use typ
02060971.name: GRAPHIC DESIGN 2: ADVNCED REPRESENTATION

02060972.about:
this course introduces students to climate change science! including key technical concepts such as the greenhouse effect! carbon cycling! and climate history. it explores socio-ecological impacts and critically evaluates mitigation and adaptation policies. it concludes with students proposing and analyzing approaches to address anthropogenic climate change (e.g.! technological! policy! or planning).
 learning outcomes: at the end of the coursethe studetns will be able to:
 1. demonstrate a solid scientific understanding of anthropogenic climate change! including the mechanisms! empirical evidence! and alternative theories.____
 2. critically analyze p roposed mitigation and adaptation policies! including global agreements and domestic policies.
 3. characterize the drivers of greenhouse gas emissions and evaluate how urban and regional planning can respond to the challenges of climate change. 
 4. propose and critically analyze technological solutions to address anthropogenic climate change._
 5. effectively communicate knowledge and proposed solutions through presentations! posters! and written reports.
 6. apply their professional and academic expertise to the development
02060972.name: CLIMATE CHANGE SCIENCE! POLICY!PLANNING

02060974.about:
the course discusses urban development processes of residential neighborhoods and urban renewal! urban and national infrastructure (ports and airport! energy! railways! traffic management! infrastructure tunnels! technology! innovation)! public building (educational! welfare! and community facilities)! employment spaces (industry! services! commerce! tourism)! open spaces (urban nature! parks! promenades)! and environmental considerations (risk assessment! air quality! soil pollution).
 learning ouctomes: at the conclusion of the course! students will be able to: 1. demonstrate understanding of urban development processes in the fields of municipal and  national infrastructure! urban nature! transportation! and more._
 2. identify key actors in the urban development process! and the tools they utilize. 
 3. critically analyze test cases and urban projects.
 4. develop proposals to improve the built-up public space.
02060974.name: URBAN PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT PROCESSES

02060978.about:
AS PART OF THE COURSE, INTRODUCTORY SUBJECTS FROM THE FIELDS OF MATHEMATICS, COMPUTER SCIENCE AND CODE WRITING WILL BE TAUGHT WHICHFORM THE BASIS FOR CARRYING OUT WORKS AND PROJECTS IN THE FIELD OF PARAMETRIC DESIGN AND DIGITAL FABRICATION. THE COURSE IS ADAPTEDFOR STUDENTS IN DESIGN AND ARCHITECTURE TRACKS. THE CURRICULUM WILL INCLUDE BASIC PROGRAMMING CONCEPTS, SUCH AS VARIABLES AND FUNCTIONS. BASIC CONCEPTS IN DATA STRUCTURES, WHICH WILL HELP STUDENTS ORGANIZE AND MANAGE INFORMATION, SUCH AS LISTS AND ARRAYS. THE STUDENTS WILL BECOME FAMILIAR WITH BASIC CONCEPTS IN GEOMETRY, SUCH AS COORDINATE SYSTEMS AND VARIOUS REPRESENTATIONS OF CURVES, IN ADDI TION TO THE USE OF GEOMETRIC TRANSFORMATIONS. FINALLY, THEY WILL LEARN DIFFERENT METHODS OF DOCUMENTING AND FINDING BUGS IN THEIR CODE.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
02060978.name: INTRO. TO COMPUTER SCIENCE FOR DESIGNERS

02060985.about:
THE COURSE WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING AND 'REALIZING' THE POTENTIALS OF THE BUILT HERITAGE IN RELATION TO ADJACENT  ISSUES SUCH AS: TOURISM IN HERITAGE SITES, THE ECONOMICS OF HERITAGE, RE-USE AND RETROFIT, LEGISLATION AND LEGAL ISSUES, SOCIETY AND COMMUNITY, CULTURAL LANDSCAPES, HISTORIC URBAN LANDSCAPES, WORLD HERITAGE, INTERPRETATION AT HERITAGE SITES, AND ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL KNOW:
 1. DEEPEN HIS.HER GRASP OF THE INTERFACE BETWEEN THE BUILT HERITAGE AND OTHTER CULTURAL AND SPATIAL FIELDS.
 2. BECOME ACQUAINTED WITH CONTEMPORARY APPROACHES TO HERITAGE WITHIN THE BROADER PLANNING AND ARCHI TECTURAL DISCOURSE. 
 3. ANALYZE CENTRAL TEXTS IN CONTEMPORARY LITERATURE AND.OR RECENT SELECED CASE STUDIES. 
 4. AQUIRE TOOLS FORINDENTIFYING THREATS AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE REALIZING THE POTENTIALS OF BUILT HERITAGE.
02060985.name: Conservation and Deelopment in Practice

02060987.about: the syllabus will be determined by the teacher with the approval of the graduate committee before the biginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02060987.name: Special Topics in Conservation 3

02060995.about: INTERNATIONAL WORKSHOP OR STUDY TOUR IN ISRAEL OR ABROAD, IN COLLABORATION WITH AN OVERSEAS ACADEMIC INSTITUTION. THE COURSE WILL RUN AS A CONDENSED WORKSHOP AND INCLUDE SITE VISITS AND LECTURES IN HERITAGE SITES AS A BASIS FOR A DOCUMENTATION AND.OR DESIGN PROJECT TO BE DEVELOPED DURING THE WORKSHOP.
02060995.name: Tour.International Workshop - Heritage Sites

02070001.about: The role of theory in planning process. Planning in modern society in general and Israel in particular. Justifications for planning. Theories of rational planning: comprehensive, incremental, strategic and mixed scanning. Methods for setting planning objectives, development and evaluation of alternative plans and implementation. Other theories of planning in society: advocacy, radical and critical. Students will analyze and evaluate actual planning processes in Israel and abroad.
02070001.name: Planning Theories

02070002.about: The purpose of this course is to acquaint the students with concepts and forms of social planning in Israel. The topics included are: sources of legitimation of planning, ideology and methods of introducing social change in existing social system, planning towardsocial change in the 2000's, social planning in Israel, forms of provision of social services in Israel: housing, education, health, welfare and income maintenance.
02070002.name: Social Planning

02070007.about: studying real estate valuation principles, approaches and critical view on accepted approaches in the academic literature, implementing the principles and appropriate approaches, as well as legislation and court rulings, to estimate the value of different types of properties ,free simple estate as well as partial rights,for different objectives . at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1.propose and examine property value factors in the planning process. 2.understand the criticize real estate assessments according to the buildong and planning law. 3.understand and criticize real estate assessments for different types of properties, for di fferent objectives. 4.coolect comparable transactions, implement the appropriate approch and perform a calculation for the estimated value of properties. 5.understand models, complementary approaches and critique on accpted approaches in the academic literature, in order to analyze issues in real estate valuation in comparable internation view.
02070007.name: Principles in Real Estate Valuation

02070020.about: The objective of the course is to develop skills in the use of advanced technologies in the analysis of spatial data.  The course will concentrate on the GIS (geographical information system) environment.  In the first part, the students will learn a hands on approach to the use of a GIS and in the second part, will learn to apply the technique to a small regional planning exercise.
02070020.name: Introduction to Gis for Planners

02070021.about:
advanced statistical and spatial tools, three dimensional capabilities of the commercial software package arcgis, multicriteria analysis methods for the assessment of ecosystem services and conservation planning and analysis of spatial alternatives for the achievement of environmental objectivespreservation of biodiversity and ecosystem servics, advancedgeographical information system (gis - a basic tool for the presentation and analysis of spatial information) applications. learning outcomes: after having completed the course the student will know how to: 1) present two dimensional raster data in three dimensional form.
 2)  edit vector data ("shape" files) downloaded from on-line gis applications (such as google). 3)  conduct a landscape analysis using gis.
 4)  conduct a multi-criteria analysis using gis.
 5)  incorporate spatial concepts from the field of conservation planning and environmental solutions: connectivity, area-edge ratio, sharon index, resilience.
 6)  understand principles of various zoning applications for spatial conservation prioritization.
02070021.name: Gis for Conservation Planning

02070023.about: the course is intended for students who have taken an introductory course in gis and wish to deepen their knowledge in the field ofspatial analysis. main topics: descriptive statistics - calculations with tables and graphs. spatial statistics - density calculations.  network analysis - optimal path, service areas and geocode.  building metrics-selecting parameters, types of metrics.  trend calculation - explained variable trend line adjustment, forecast. fuzzy logic - site selection. building story maps -using the web asa sharing tool. at the end of the course, the student will be able to: 1. acquisition of theoretical knowledge in the context of exi sting digital research tools and integration of insights from information. 2. practical experience in computerized research tools for quantitative analysis and mapping. 3. impact on knowledge develoment in the context of other courses and independent student research.
02070023.name: Geographic Information Systems 2

02070024.about:
AN INVESTIGATION OF COMPLEX GRAPHIC TECHNIQUES THAT COMBINE TEXT! DRAWING! MAP! PHOTOGRAPHY! AND VIDEO AND THEIR REPRESENTATION THROUGH BOTH ANALOG (MANUAL) AND DIGITAL THINKING AND MEDIA. COURSE EXERCISES WILL EXPLORE AND EXPRESS EXISTING AND DESIGNED PLACES USING CONCEPTS AND TECHNIQUES FROM VARIOUS ART AND DESIGN FIELDS! SUCH AS PUBLIC ART! FASHION! AND SET DESIGN. THE COURSE WILL ALSO APPLY MIDJOURNEY AS A CREATIVE TOOL FOR BRAINSTORMING AND GRAPHIC IDEAS! SIMILAR TO QUICK SKETCHES! WHILE PROCESSING AND ADAPTING THE ACQUIRED IMAGES TO THE EXERCISES.
  LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. PROMOTE CROSS- THINK ING BETWEEN ARCHITECTURE/LANDSCAPE DESIGN AND INTERDISCIPLINARY DESIGN EXPRESSIONS.
 2. ACKNOWLEDGE CHANGING DEFINITIONS OF ARCHITECTURAL PRACTICE IN THE CONTEXT OF A WORLD THAT IS BECOMING DIGITAL AND VIRTUAL.
 3. IDENTIFY THE CHALLENGES FACING ARCHITECTUAL PRACTICE IN THE A.I. ERA. 
4. UNDERSTAND THE USE AND IMPLICATIONS OF THE MIDJOURNEY PLATFORM ON THE DESIGN PROCESS IN THE LADSCAPE ARCHITECURE STUDIO. 5. EXPERIMENT WITH NEW HUMN WORK SKILLS FOR SHARING BETWEEN HUMAN CONTEXT OF A WORLD THAT IS BECOMING DIGITAL AND VIRTUAL. I
02070024.name: LANDSCAPE DESIGN REPRESENTATION

02070041.about: Person and environment.  The ecological basis for regional planning. Integrated methods for land use planning and environmental quality protection.  Data on the natural environment.  The use of computers in data analysis.  Selected approaches to environmental management.
02070041.name: Ecological Principles in City and Regional Planning

02070044.about:
The seminar will critically survey the state-of-the-art  methods of public participation.  The use of the various methods will be evaluated in terms of several dimensions:  the goals, stages of the planning process, the definition of the public, the resources needed, etc.
 Students will apply one or more methods of participation to concrete planning problems.
02070044.name: Public Participation in Planning

02070045.about: Training in research methods, research design, and scientific writing. The format is one of lectures and exercises with emphasis onclass presentations and feedback from the students.
02070045.name: Preparation for the Research Process

02070048.about:
the aim of the course is to expose students to the complexity of integrating environmental considerations in urban and regional planning in israel. course topics: characterization of environmental planning compared to other types of planning, the relationship between environmental planning and population growth, environmental impact assessment, environmental ethics, and principles of sustainable development.
_learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the students will know:
 1.identify 3-4 principal environmental problems in a given city area or community_.
 2. point out a number of possible future scenarios that relate to the issues identified in : 1_.
 3. offer at least one or two (innovative) solutions that could address the issue pointed out in :1 and considering future conditions of :2.
02070048.name: ENVIRONMENTAL PLANNING

02070070.about: Land use allocation in urban and regional planning. Relationship between various urban systems. The connection between land uses and the main role players in the regional and urban dimension: households, firms and institutions. The influence of the populations socio-economic structure and employment base on land uses requirements and location. Means and methods used in urban and regional planning for the allocation of land uses and the choice of preferred location.
02070070.name: Land Use Planning - Principles and Quantification

02070342.about: Description of the spatial structure of neighborhoods, settlements, cities and various types of regions.  Analysis of the major processes that these systems undergo.  Definition of major concepts supported by illustrations from Israel and other countries. List oftopics:  urbanization,  national and regional settlement systems,  metropolitan areas, the urban field and the urban periphery, thespatial structure of cities.  Various definitions of regions, spatial interactions such as migration,  regional development considerations.
02070342.name: Urban and Regional Geography

02070407.about: Definitions of the terms "policy" and "management" in the context of the control of environmental quality and resources.  Analysis of selected cases of policy, planning, and management programs developed for environmental control in Israel and other countries.  Study of government involvement, administrative framework, and legal tools.
02070407.name: Seminar on Environmental Policy and \

02070440.about: theory and practice of planning as a tool for social change. planning with communities (as opposed to planning for communities) as an interface between residents, their surroundings and the political and administrative decision makers. the course includes practical work with social-change organizations in their community planning projects.
02070440.name: Planning with the Community: Concepts, Tools and Strategies for Action

02070450.about: A critical reading of the israeli landscape from a trans-disciplinary perspective that approaches the landscape as a text open to diverse readings and interperation. the course will explore the representation of the israeli landscape in the visual arts, film, arcitecture and literature as a basis for exploring a set of key questions:the relationship between production and representation of the israeli landscape, the effect of social, political and cultural practices on its construction, and the changes that have occurred over time. these questions will be applied to israeli spatial contexts such as the israeli city, kibbutz, heritage sites and sites of  memory, national parks and agricultural landscapes.
02070450.name: Israeli Space: Critical Perspectives

02070456.about:
the course explores the influence of urbanization on nature and the services it provides to city-dwellers.
 winners and losers in the biotic homogenization process, cities - source of invasion, conserving urban biodiversity, dense vs green cities, the value of ecological corridors, benefits of protecting urban nature, urban ecology in israel.
_learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know: 1. understand the implications of the urbanization process on the environment and the natural ecosystem.
 2. assess the ecological value of different planning strategies.
 3. propose solutions for planning and management of cities to enhance biodi versity. 
 4. develop means to enhance the interaction between people and biodiversity and its positive outcomes. 
 5. develop a critical ecological thinking.
02070456.name: Urban Ecology

02070457.about:
themes related to landscape design in israel since the early 20th century, in relation to the local landscape and culture and in the light of international influences. examination of the field according to chronological and thematic axis: from the colonial british mandate era to the contemporary era. among the topics: the search for local, cultural meaning of landscape and landscape architecture, globalisation, the relationship between landscape architecture and related fields. study through examination of case studies, interviews and archival research of historical precedents. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will know: 1. under stand the development of landscape architecture in israel as an outcome of historical, cultural and social processes.
 2. examine critically various projects.
 3. understand the role of landscape architecture in israel in relation to other parallel fields.
 4. establish an independent likited, historical research.
02070457.name: Landscape Architecture in Israel

02070460.about: topics: the study of contemporary theories of landscape architecture from within the discipline and from other fields, to form a basis for critical reading of built works. topics include the picturesque tradition, sustainability and landscape architecture, cultural landscapes, landscape urbanism, language and representation relationships between architecture and landscape architecture, ethicaand aesthetics.
02070460.name: Theories in Contemporary Landscape Architecture

02070462.about: the sylabus will be determined by the teacher with the approval of the programs curriculum committee before the beginning of the semester in which the course is to be given.
02070462.name: Selected Topics in Landscape Architecture 1

02070463.about: the syllabus will be determined by the teacher and will be approved by the program's curriculum committee before the beginning of the semester in which the course is to be given.
02070463.name: Special Topics in Landscape Architecture 2

02070464.about: the syllabus will be determined by the teacher and will be approved by the program corriculum committee before the beginning of thesemester in witch course is to be given. Spring semester 2017.2018:  Urban Ecology
02070464.name: Selected Topics in Landscape Architecture 3

02070465.about: the syllabus will be determined by the teacher and will be approved by the program curriculum committee before the beginning of thesemester in which the course is to be given.
02070465.name: Selected Topics in Landscape Architecture 4

02070467.about: the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate committee, towards the beginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled.
02070467.name: Selec. Topics in Landscape Architecture 6

02070469.about:
the ability to interact with the use of software and technology or respond to changes in the environment is now considered as a basic tool for the contemporary designer. 
course topics: interactive objects, envirommental personal space monitoring, complex responsive environments. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. to develop an interactive design project from concept to execution level. 2. recognize the different characteristics of a dynamic control panel (such as arduino) 3. develop a project through the use of a detailed interaction scenario. 4. translate the interaction scenario to the use of sensors, actuato rs via the use of computer language or programing blocks. 5. develop a prototype and test the integrated technologies and to develop a critical view to the nature of the encounter between the users and the system.
02070469.name: Interaction Design

02070569.about:
cultural landscapes are a common creation of man and nature. representing the development of the human society along time, due to the conditions of the natural environment, and under social, economic and cultural processes. the course examines contemporary tools for categorization, interpretation, planning and management of cultural landscapes in local and global contexts.
 lerning outcomes:
at the end of the course the student will be able to:
 1. identify, classify and document cultural landscapes.
 2. understand the functionality and meaningless of cultural landscapes.
 3. propose design planning and management means for the preservation and sustai nable use of cultural landscapes.
 4. develop critical thinking and representation tools of cultural landscapes
02070569.name: Cultural Landscapes: Theory, Interpretation, Design

02070582.about: the coures will deal with selected topics in landscape architecture
02070582.name: Selec.Topic in Landscape Architecture 12

02070600.about: Transportation system analyses:  includes an overview of the interrelation between activities and transportation systems, land use and transportation.  The transportation planning process, urban transportation problem characteristics.  Modeling flow patterns. Modeling trip generation distribution, mode-split and assignment. Disaggregate travel demand models.  Project evaluation.  Data collection.  Urban transport technologies.
02070600.name: People-Centered Transport Planning

02070700.about: Application of the principal elements of the planning process to land use planning:  setting objectives, the formulation of alternative plans, their evaluation, and application.  Introduction to urban systems and planning institutions: introduction to concepts inland use planning. Preparation of a comprehensive urban plan for a small or medium-size town or city.
02070700.name: Studio 1: Urban Planning

02070701.about:
The studio deals with the neighborhood level of urban planning.  Its aim is to acguaint the student with problems typical of neighborhood planning, the main sub-systems at this level, and the appropriate methods and approaches for planning.
 Students will be asked to do a planning project addressed to creating a neighborhood fit for its residents in terms of public services, residential needs, infrastructure, etc.  Special stress will be placed on the understanding of the relationship between physical form and basic social processes.
02070701.name: Studio 2: Neighborhood Planning

02070804.about: Fundamentals of economics, The economic thinking and its limitations in specific relation to urban and regional planning. The problem of scarcity, the production curve, alternative cost, relative and absolute advantage, consumer theory, producer theory, damand and supply, monopoly, government intervention in the markets, national accounting, the keynesian model and fiscal and monetary policy.Basic quantitative tools for decision-making in planning.
02070804.name: Economic Thinking for Planners

02070806.about: The principles behind planning law in Israel and other countries, the statutory planning system as an aspect of Israeli public administration, institutional structures, local planning bodies and local governments, types of plans, their content and their approval procedure, information and public participation, instruments of implementation: expropriation, compensation, taxation, reparcellation, non-conforming use, building permits, enforcement and its limitations. Analysis of the legislation and select court decisions.
02070806.name: Legal and Administrative Aspects Administrative Aspects

02070807.about: The Arabs in Israel as a developing community.  Background factors and the evolution of physical patterns of settlements, socio-economic and demographic changes in Israel.  Physical change and self-constructed housing, inter-relations with development in Jewish sector, selected planning problems and approaches to the development of the Arab sector.
02070807.name: Planning and Development of Arab Settle.

02070825.about: a conceptual approach to structural design for the collaboration between architects and engineers. structures' classification basedon structural attributes. basic principles and behavior of linear components and systems columns (beams, frames, trusses). planar componets, slab system-types of load transfer construction types. conventional prefabricated concrete structures, stell structures, structural and civil design drawings. load propagation - principal and secondary load transferring systems, soil structure interaction, earthquake consideration in structural design.
02070825.name: Buildings' Stability

02070830.about: topics: the interface between urban design landscape design, ecology and infrastructure, bringing together technical, social and design perspectives. ecological design  principles and techniques on the urban scale as related to: hydrology. biodiversity, microclimates. regenerative technologies (water sensitive design, storm water collection and filtration, stream restoration),treating waste with constructed wastelands, the reuse of brownfield sites, the design of sustainable neigborhoods, new open space types.
02070830.name: Green Infrastructures

02070888.about:
SMART CITIES IS A FIELD THAT HAS CHANGED THE WAYS IN WHICH CITIES ARE MANAGED! AND PLANNED! AND HOW CITIZENS MANAGE THEIR RELATIONSWITH THE MUNICIPAL AUTHORITY AS WELL AS THE RELATIONS BETWEEN THEM. AS A COMMODITY! PRODUCTS FROM THE FIELD OF SMART CITIES DRIVE AN ECONOMY ESTIMATED AT BILLIONS OF DOLLARS AND HAVE RECEIVED A BOOST BOTH IN TIMES OF DEALING WITH THE CORONA EPIDEMIC AND IN TIMES OF WAR. THEREFORE! THE COURSE WILL SIMULTANEOUSLY FOCUS ON TWO AREAS: SMART CITIES AS THEY ARE IN THE WORLD OF PRACTICE AND AS THEY ARE IN THE WORLD OF ACADEMIC RESEARCH.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL : 1. BECOME FAMILIAR WITH BASIC  CONCEPTS IN THE FIELD OF SMART CITIES.
 2. GET TO KNOW AND CLASSIFY THE TOOLBOX OF SMART CITIES IN THE FIELD OF PLANNING AND STRATEG.
 3. EVALUATE AND DISCUSS THE IMPLICATIONS OF ONE FIELD IN SMART CITIES (EG! MONEY) CONCERNING THE RELEVANT TOOLBOX AND THE CONTEXT OF ONE CASE STUDY.
 4. UNDERSTAND THE LIMITATIONS OF THE FIELD MAINLY IN ASPECTS OF ETHICS! SOCIAL SUPERVISION! AND PRIVACY.
02070888.name: PERCEPTIONS! TOOLBOX AND CRITICISM

02070889.about:
THE 'ISRAEL 2020' PLAN REVOLUTIONIZED PLANNING DISCOURSE IN ISRAEL! INTRODUCING A NEW PERSPECTIVE AND VOCABULARY. BY HIGHLIGHTING LAND DEPLETION DUE TO SPRAWL! IT ADVOCATED FOR CONCENTRATED DEVELOPMENT IN URBANIZED SPACES! SPAWNING THE METROPOLITAN CONCEPT. THE COURSE FOCUSES ON THE IMPACT OF PLAN 2020 ON NATIONAL PLANNING AND IS INTENDED FOR BOTH UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE FIELD. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE: 
 1. ABLE TO UNDERSTAND CONCEPTS AND PRINCIPLES - WHAT IS COMPREHENSIVE NATIONAL PLANNING AND HOW DOES IT DIFFER FROM LOCAL-REGIONAL PLANNING.
 2. ABLE TO APPLY PRACTICAL ASPECTS IN NATIONAL-LEV EL PLANNING - CONCENTRATION/DISPERSAL! UNIQUE CHARACTERISTICS! ECOLOGICAL CORRIDOR DELINEATION! AND INCORPORATION INTO DETAILED PLANS AT THE LOCAL LEVEL._
 3. ABLE TO UTILIZE PRACTICAL TOOLS OF DENSITY AND DEVELOPMENT ACCORDING TO THE INSTRUCTIONS AND GUIDELINES OF NATIONAL MASTER PLAN 35.
 4. DEVELOP CRITICAL TOOLS IN LIGHT OF CURRENT GOVERNMENT DECISIONS AND LOCAL AUTHORITIES! WHILE ADHERING TO NATIONAL PLANNING PRINCIPLES.
02070889.name: ISRAEL 2020 - MASTER PLAN FOR ISRAEL

02070900.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate committee, towards the beginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled. Spring semester 2017.2018: Green roofs for Sustainable Cities.
02070900.name: Advanced Issues in Urban and Regional Planning 1

02070901.about: The syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate committee, towards the beginning of the semester in which the course is scheduled.
02070901.name: Advanced Issues in Urban and Regional Planning 2

02070912.about: The syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the Graduate Committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02070912.name: Selected Topics in Urban and Regional Planning 1

02070913.about: The syllabus will be determined by the lecturer, with the approval of the Graduate Committee, before the commencement of the semester in which the course is scheduled to be given.
02070913.name: Selected Topics in Urban and Regional Planning 2

02070915.about: the sylabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate studies committee, at the beginning of the semester in which the course will be given.
02070915.name: Selected Topics in Urban and Regional Planning 3

02070920.about:
foundations of qualitative research methods in planning: presentation of different methodological paradigms (ethnography, grounded theory, case study) and their implementation through practical experience via work with a particular community with the aim of enhancing knowledge and products for the future benefit of the community dilemmas and difficulties that researchers may face while using qualitative methodologies and working intimately with people and communities.
 learning outcomes:
 at the end of the course the student will know how: 1. to apply qualitative research methodologies.
 2. to evaluate planned spaces with qualitative tools.
 3. to appl y research knowledge as a tool for the resolution of planning problems of communities.
02070920.name: Qualitative Research Methods for Planners

02070945.about: the growing envionromental consciousness and the development of the concept of sustainable development. definitions of sustainable development. theoretical and philosophical approaches to sustainable development. planning objectives and measures for achieving sustainability on the urban and community level and practices of community sustainable development in israel.
02070945.name: Planning and Sustainability

02070953.about: coastal and marine policy: physical coastal processes, coastal and marine uses, port development, integrated coastal zone management and marine spatial planning, policy tools for coastal and marine management and planning, laws for coastal and marine management in israel and international frameworks (such as: conventions under the auspicies of the un and the eu).
02070953.name: Coastal and Marine Management

02070955.about: the importance of environmental considerations in urban and regional planning. topics the hydrological cycle-water quality and quantity, human impact on nutrient cycling, waste cycles, air quality, noise, the ecological and environmental role of open space and threats to biodiversity. the physical, chemical and biological principles of todays environmental challenges.
02070955.name: Environmental Science for Planners

02080111.about:
A DESIGN PROJECT THAT MEETS A SELECTED TOPIC . DISCUSSION . IDEA AT THE CONCEPT LEVEL. THE STUDENT WILL DEVELOP A PLANNING POSITIONREGARDING THE RELATIONSHIP THAT IS RELEVANT TO THE PROJECT TOPIC, SUCH AS THE RATIO OF URBAN SCALE TO BUILDING SCALE. PROJECTS WILLFOCUS ON THE SELECTED RESEARCH PATHS. THE PROJECT IS ACCOMPANIED BY A SUPPORTING THEORETICAL COURSE._
 LEARNING OUCTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL ABLE TO: 1. FORMULATE A STRATEGY-TOOL STRATEGY AND MAKE A SPATIAL ARGUMENT BASED ON DISCUSSION OF THE TOPIC . CONTEXT AND ARCHITECTURAL KNOWLEDGE. 
 2. DEVELOP INNOVATIVE AND ORIGINAL TOOLS FOR DISCUSSION, IDENTIFY AND USE RELEVANT  MEANS APPROPRIATE TO INTERVENTION, TAKE A STAND AND APPLY SPTIAL ARGUMENT THROUGHT THE TOOL SELECTED.
02080111.name: Studio Final Project - Section 1

02080112.about:
DETAILED DESIGN ORIENTED ON A TOPIC . DISCUSSION . IDEA, DEVELOPING THE PROJECT FROM THE CONCEPT THAT WAS DEVELOPED IN THE PREVIOUSSEMESTER TO A DETAILED DESIGN. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE APPROPRIATE THESIS AND RESEARCH, PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT, SITE DEFINITION AND ARCHITECTURAL LANGUAGE DEVELOPMENT. FORMULATION OF DESIGN PRINCIPLES FOR VARIOUS PROJECT INTERVENTION AND PROGRAMMATIC SITUATIONS. THE PROJECT IS ACCOMPANIED BY A THESIS SUPPORTING THEORETICAL COURSE. LEARNING OUCTOMES: AT THE END OF THE STUDENT WILL:
 1.COMPILE A DETAILED PROGRAM FOR THE SPATIAL CLAIM DEVELOPED IN THE PREVIOUS STUDIO.
 2. TECTONIC LANGUAGE FOR THE PROJECT.
 3. PREPARE A SET OF PLANS AT 1: 200- (PLANS, SECTIONS, ELEVATIONS), DEVELOP A SPECIFIC SECTION IN THE SCALE1:50.1:100, DEVELOP A UNIQUE DETAIL OF THE PROJCET IN THE SCALE 1:10.1: 5.1:2 AND WRITE A PLANNING DESIGN THESIS.
02080112.name: Studio Final Project - Secion 2

02080171.about:
RESEARCH BY DESIGN PROJECT: DETAILED ARCHITECTURAL DEVELOPMENT FROM A CRITICAL STANDPOINT ON CONTEMPORARY ISSUES. DEVELOPMENT OF A CONSTRUCTION SYSTEM AS A BASIS FOR THE DESIGN OF THE ENTIRE STRUCTURE, AND HIGH LEVEL OF DETAILING, WITH THE KNOWLEDGE, UNDERSTANDING AND APPLICATION OF CLIMATE CONSIDERATIONS, CONTEXT, ENVIRONMENTAL DEVELOPMENT, CONSTRUCTION,LEGISLATION AND STANDARDS.
 LEARNING OUCTOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL BE ABLE TO COMPLETE A COMPREHENSIVE PROCESS OF ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN USING RESEARCH THROUGH THE DESIGN AND USE OF ARCHITECTURAL TOOLS TO CRITICALLY DEVELOP THEMES AND IDEAS. THE STUDIO'S PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE DETAIL ED DEVELOPMENT IN VARIOUS SCALES FROM THE URBAN SCALE TO MATERIALS AND CONSTRUCTION AND THEIR REPRESENTATIION THROUGH ADVANCED TOOLS CUSTOMARY IN CONTEMPORARY ARCHITECTURAL PRACTICE.
02080171.name: Project - Thematic Integrative Studio

02080174.about:
PROJECT INCLUDING RESEARCH BY DESIGN. DEVELOPING A TOPIC . DISCUSSION. IDEA THROUGH ARCHITECTURAL AND URBAN DESIGN TOOLS, USING A RESEARCH METHODOLOGY LEADING TO A CRITICAL PLANNING POSITION ON CONTEMPORARY URBAN DESIGN ISSUES.
 LEARNING OUCTOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENT WILL:
 1. BE ABLE TO ANALYZE AND PROVIDE PLANNING RESPONENTS. 
 2. UNDERSTANDING THE RANGE OF CONSIDERATIONS IN URBAN DEVELOPMENT. 
 3. UNDERSTANDING THE LANGUAGE AND TOOLS OF URBAN DESIGN AND THEIR REPRESENTATION THROUGHT ADVANCED TOOLS CUSTOMARY IN CONTEMPORARY ARCHITECTURAL PRACTICE.
02080174.name: Project- Thematic Urban Design Studio

02080310.about: Design of a product or a system of medium complexity, study and application of industrial design processes. Emphasis on design goals and objectives setting, comprehensive design based on: technical.technological, design, marketing, social, psychological and ecological considerations. Development and analysis of alternative solutions and preparation of a presentation. Method: interdisciplinaryteam. Requirements: complete presentation, including a program, evaluation of alternatives and a well-reasoned solution, ongoing active contact with team member and instrcrors.
02080310.name: Industrial Design Studio 1

02080312.about: A personal project will be undertaken by a student who is interested in working on a project outside the studio  curriculum. The instruction method will be determined by the instructor, and requirements will depend on the subject matter.
02080312.name: Personal Project in Industrial Design 1

02080314.about:
studio 3 is an industrial design studio in the format of a lecture and studio under group and individual guidance. the aim of the course is to outline ways of working, to provide creative methods, to align, and to practice participant presentation and group discussion. the studio launches the final project of industrial design (without thesis) and accompanies the start of the thesis project throughout the semester, to create research volume and sketches and create a clear and coherent concept for further development. the studio accompanies the development and design areas that take place in the process, in connection with the history of design, design and scenario, user-experience and user-interaction, production and digital technologies. the course is conducted in a studio method, where students are obliged to bring a weekly body of work, during short presentations and updates on personal progress.
 learning outcomes: at the course the student will be able to:
 1. submit a full presentation of a design concept.
 2. integrate  design-thinking  project with all aspects.
02080314.name: Studio in Industrial Design 3

02080315.about: studio 4 is an industrial design studio in the format of lecture, group guidance, presentation of participants and group discussion. the studio supports the student's final project in advanced degrees, design projects, writing in a design environment and support the development, design and construction of industrial design project in all personal interests of the students. at the end of the course, the student will be able to: 1.submit a full presentation of a design project including an advanced prototype. 2.include an integrative project in design thinking. 3.formulate the uniqueness of the project for a conference, exhibition ,or journal.
02080315.name: Studio in Industrial Design4

02080320.about: Design of a product or a system of high complexity, application of industrial design processes and methods. Emphasis on design goals and objectives setting, preparation of a design brief, comprehensive design based on: technical.technological, design, marketing, social, psychological and ecological considerations. Development and analysis of alternative solutions and preparation of a presentation. Method: individual work. Reqirements: complete presentation, including a program, evaluation of alternatives and a well-reasoned solution, ongoinc active contact with the instructors.
02080320.name: Industrial Design Studio 2

02080350.about: This course has been planned for industrial designers.  Its purpose is to clarify the structure of industrial materials, their properties and the dependence of the properties on the structure.  The course will emphasize manufacturing technologies and environmental effects of materials.  The industrial materials that will be reviewed include iron, aluminum, copper and precious metals.  In addition properties of polymers and ceramic materials will be studied.  Tours to several industries will be included. Contents: structure of materials and structural defects - metals, polymers, ceramic materials and glass. Mechanical properties - deformation mechanisms , brittal and ductile fracture and fatigue. Manufacturing technologies - metals, polymers and ceramic materials. Environmental effects - corrosion and polymer deterioration. Coatings for protection and decorative finish
02080350.name: Industrial Materials 1

02080353.about: the student will prepare an extended theoretical or research seminar, or a project equivalent to 6 academic pointes. the seminar paper will be submitted after the advisors approval, as partial fulfillment of the requirements for a masters degree in industrial design without a thesis.
02080353.name: Final Project in Industrial Design

02080720.about: Personal supervision of a student on a selected topic in architecture and urban dessign. The topics will be geared towards the areas of interest of the students.
02080720.name: Selected Topics in Architecture and Urban Design

02080750.about: Studies in a range of advanced research methods and approaches and associated topics in architecture, through guided individual work and interactive group discussion.
02080750.name: Selected Aspects of Architectural and Town Planning Research

02080800.about: guiding students in submitting a final project.seminar. topics: problem definition. analysis of relevant literature, collection andanalysis of data, discussion of findings, conclusions and recommendations for further research. the subject of the final paper willbe jointly determined by the student and the teacher. the final paper will be submitted as a professional report.
02080800.name: Project in Architecutre and Town Planning

02090002.about: The purpose of the seminar is to discuss selected topics in the philosphy of science, basic research principles, and different research approaches in the fields of design and planning.  The course is intended for doctoral students who will examine their own approach and methodology in relation to the general principles and approaches surveyed in the course.
02090002.name: Seminar in Research Theories

02090003.about: writing, presenting and discussing academic research in the area of planning. the seminar will focus on leading research studies inthe area of planning  using tools from urban planning research (i.e., economics, sociology, psychology, policy studies and law).
02090003.name: Advanced Ph.D Seminar in Urban and Regional Planning

02090005.about: Goal: to understand processes of urban change, to study programs of urban rehabilitation and revitalization in developed countries,and to evaluate Israeli plans and projects. Subjects: social, economic, architectural and administrative causes of urban change, revitalization programs in Western countries - survey and analysis, methods for selecting target areas for revitalization, programs for revitalization of city centers in Israel, Project Renewal - Israel's program for social and physical rehabilitation of distressed neigborhoods - past, present and future.
02090005.name: Urban Renewal

02090008.about: The purpose of this course is to acquaint the students with concepts and forms of social planning in Israel. The topics included are: sources of legitimation of planning, ideology and methods of introducing social change in existing social system, planning towardsocial change in the 2000's, social planning in Israel, forms of provision of social services in Israel: housing, education, health, welfare and income maintenance.
02090008.name: Social Planning

02090033.about: the syllabus will be outlined by the teacher, subject to the approval of the graduate studies committee, at the beginning of the semester in which the course will be given.
02090033.name: Advanced Topics in Urban and Regional Planning 6

02090037.about:
the cours lays out the outline plan's preparation building blocks and  its products deals with both integrative and detailed outline plans. the cours focusses on the spatial impact of outline plans and its three dimensional as well as social economic and enviromental expressions. it traces the way plan make cities, neighbhoods, streets etc. the cours also expose students to worldwide comparable examples of outline plan
 learning outcomes: at the end of the cours the student will be: 1. familiar with the structure of outline plans and thier components- land uses, building codes etc. 2. acquainted with the ways outline plans generate built forms, urban n etworks, public space and social.economic.cultural.enviromental relationships
 3. able to analyze the various aspects of an outlineplan and its components, their background, their strengths, and weakness. 4. able to use cutting edge knowledge in outline planningaround the world.
02090037.name: The Outline Plan as a Spatial Tool

02090040.about: Mathematical programming and its use for resource allocation, including land use.  Linear programming - duality theorems and shadowprices, and their use in planning. Nonlinear programming - Kuhn-Tucker conditions.  Integer programming, geometric programming.  Dynamic programming and Markov-chains in planning.  Cost-effectiveness analysis.  Graph theory and network analysis and their use in planning.  Simulation processes.
02090040.name: Quantitative Methods in Planning 2

02090050.about: topics: basic axioms of urban economics, economic conception of cities, accessibility and transport economic, explanations of why cities exist, urban spatial structure, dynamics and sprawl, theories of urban growth, urban housing and poverty, urban complexity
02090050.name: Urban Economics

02090100.about: The goal is to acquaint the student with basic concepts of sociology and urban sociology. The major subjects are:  the meaning and purpose of sociology,  culture and society,  values and social norms, stratification and social disparities,  the urban way of life,neighborhood planning - normative aspects and empirical findings.
02090100.name: General and Urban Sociology

02090450.about: each student will carry out a limited-scale study on a topic related to town and regional planning. the study will include: definition of the problem, critical literatue review, collection and analysis of existing data, conclusions and implications for professioal work in urban and regional planning or public policy, and recommendations for future research. results from the study will be submitted in the form of a seminar paper and will be presented to students and faculty.
02090450.name: Advanced Seminar in Urban Planning 2

02090700.about: Concluding studio devoted to comprehensive planning of metropolitan regions. Emphasis is placed on integrated planning of social, economic, physical, natural, and institutional systems in the light of decentralized systems for decision-making and implementation.
02090700.name: Studio 4: Metropolitan Planning

02090970.about: The student will carry out an approved research project under the supervision of one of the members of the faculty.  The topic willrelate to analysis of a central problem in the student's research area.
02090970.name: Individual Research Seminar

02130001.about: THE EXAM ENCOMPASSES THE ISRAELI PHYSICS CURRICULUM AT THE ADVANCED HIGH SCHOOL LEVEL (5 UNITS): MECHANICS, ELECTRICITY AND MAGNETISM, GEOMETRICAL OPTICS, WAVES, RADIATION AND MATTER.
02130001.name: EXAM IN PHYSICS FOR PROSPECTIVE TEACHERS

02130002.about: THE EXAM ENCOMPASSES THE ISRAELI CHEMISTRY CURRICULUM AT THE ADVANCED HIGH SCHOOL LEVEL (5 UNITS): BASIC CONCEPTS, PERIODIC TABLE, STRUCTURE AND BONDING, STOICHIOMETRY, OXIDATION-REDUCTION REACTIONS, ACID-BASE REACTIONS, FOOD CHEMISTRY, CHEMICAL ENERGY.
02130002.name: EXAM IN CHEMIS.FOR PROSPECTIVE TEACHERS

02130003.about: THE EXAM CONTAINS SELECTED CHAPTERS FROM SELECTED CHAPTERS FROM THE MATHEMATICS MATRICULATION EXAM AT THE 5-UNIT LEVEL: ALGEBRA, ANALYTIC GEOMETRY, VECTORS, COMPLEX NUMBERS, GEOMETRY AND TRIGONOMETRY, DIFFERENTIAL AND INTEGRAL CALCULUS.
02130003.name: EXAM IN MATH. FOR PROSPECTIVE TEACHERS

02130004.about: THE EXAM ENCOMPASSES THE ISRAELI BIOLOGY CURRICULUM AT THE ADVANCED HIGH SCHOOL LEVEL (5 UNITS): THE HUMAN BODY, CELL BIOLOGY, ECOLOGY, GENETICS, MICROBIOLOGY, AND COMPARATIVE PHYSIOLOGY.
02130004.name: EXAM IN BIOLOGY FOR PROSPECTIVE TEACHERS

02140011.about: the course includes introduction, discussion and reading of theories from the domain of the philosophy of education, sociology of education, social psychology and teaching and learning
02140011.name: INT. TO EDUCATION IN SCIENCE AND TECH.1

02140012.about: the course provides tools and theoretical foundations for analysis of learning and instruction that builds on understanding of neural mechanisms, foundations of language and cognitive development, and the diagnosis of neuro-typical vs. learning disorders, as wellas familiarity with cognitive and socio-cultural theories of learning, and evidence-based constructivist instruction.
02140012.name: INT. TO EDUCATION IN SCIENCE AND TECH.2

02140091.about: FOR TEACHING STUDENTS WHO STUDY A DUAL TEACHING CERTIFICATE IN A GUIDED CLINICAL PRACTICUM IN SCHOOL: TEACHING, ASSESSMENT, AND CURRICULAR PLANNING IN A SECOND STEM DISCIPLINE, AND CROSS-DISCIPLINARY PRACTICUM SUCH AS CLASS MANAGEMENT, SPECIAL NEEDS STUDENTS, JOINING SCHOOL STAFF MEETINGS, SOCIAL-EMOTIONAL ASPECTS, PARENTS AND COMMUNITY MEETINGS, AND INSTRUCTIONAL REFLECTIVE ANALYSIS.
02140091.name: CLINICAL PRACTICUM IN TEACHING C

02140092.about: a guided clinical practicum of students in school: teaching, assessment, and curricular planning in specific stem disciplines, and cross-disciplinary practicum such as learning and class management, addressing students with special needs, joining the school staff, social-emotional aspects, parents and community meetings, and reflective analysis of teaching and learning.
02140092.name: CLINICAL PRACTICUM IN TEACHING A
