02140093.about: a guided clinical practicum of students in school: teaching, assessment, and curricular planning in specific stem disciplines, and cross-disciplinary practicum such as learning and class management, addressing students with special needs, joining the school staff, social-emotional aspects, parents and community meetings, and reflective analysis of teaching and learning.
02140093.name: CLINICAL PRACTICUM IN TEACHING B

02140103.about: Stemming from the constructivism theory, the course will offer learning and peer teaching experiences followed by reflection, as a source for students to develop their personal conceptions of teaching. Theory of and practice in teaching strategies and skills willfocus on: expository and interactive modes of teaching, in small groups or individualized setting, judicious use of teaching aides,designing and managing of active and meaningful , fostering communication and establishing classroom norms that support learning, motivating students, teaching in heterogeneous classes and dealing with divetsity.
02140103.name: Teaching Skills

02140114.about: Israel education law, values definition, classification and ladders. Dillema and other tools for values education, integrating values in disciplinary curricula, evaluating values. Students will be required to read the literature, surf the web and prepare lesson plans providing for transfer of disciplinary studies to values.
02140114.name: Law and Values in Education

02140116.about: the course is offered to students in the final stages of their undergraduate studies. it aims to expose students to leading research works in technology and science education.
02140116.name: Exposure to Sci-Tech Education Research

02140117.about: The course includes introduction, discussion and reading of theories from the domain of the philosophy of education, sociology of education, and teaching and learning. Practicales will take place in schools and will implement part of the theoretical ideas studiedin the course.
02140117.name: Int. to Education in Science and Tech.1

02140118.about: The course includes introduction, discussion and reading of theories in the domain of educational and developmental psychology (language development, motivation and learning), learning in out-of-classroom settings and online learning. The students will get exposed to various models of teaching, development of learning tasks in conjuction with their implementation in educational. The practice will take place in schools and in out-of-school settings and will implement some of the theoretical ideas studied in the course.
02140118.name: Int. to Education in Science and Tech.2

02140120.about: the aim of the course is to expose undergraduate students to the theoretical and practical basis of learning and teaching. the first part of the course focuses on the cognitive, affective and social aspects of learning, as well as leading learning theories. the second part of the course is dedicated to teaching, during which taxonomies of educational objectives and various teaching and evaluation methods are discussed. each student teaches his.her fellow students a lesson on a subject from the high school science or technology curriculum.
02140120.name: Basics of Learning and Teaching

02140132.about: the course deals with the mathematics curriculum of middle school.  in geometry, the emphasis is on developing deductive reasoning,and in algebra on developing algebraic reasoning. specific attention is given to exploration activities and teaching with technology. the course includes academic articles, teaching model lessons and observations of instruction.
02140132.name: Teaching Methods for Middle School Math

02140133.about: THIS COURSE WILL FOCUS ON SUBJECTS FROM THE FIRST 5-LEVEL QUESTIONNAIRE OF THE MATRICULATION EXAM IN MATHEMATICS (QUESTIONNAIRE 581). IT WILL PROVIDE PEDAGOGICAL-DIDACTICAL TOOLS IN THE FIELDS OF CONSTRUCTING SUBJECT AREAS AS WELL AS IN-DEPTH PRACTICE OF CHALLENGING PROBLEMS ON THE MATRICULATION EXAM LEVEL, WHILE INCORPORATING DIVERSE TEACHING METHODS.
02140133.name: Teaching Methods for Secondary Math a

02140134.about: THIS COURSE WILL FOCUS ON SUBJECTS FROM THE FIRST 5-LEVEL QUESTIONNAIRE OF THE MATRICULATION EXAM IN MATHEMATICS (QUESTIONNAIRE 582). IT WILL PROVIDE PEDAGOGICAL-DIDACTICAL TOOLS IN THE FIELDS OF CONSTRUCTING SUBJECT AREAS AS WELL AS IN-DEPTH PRACTICE OF CHALLENGING PROBLEMS ON THE MATRICULATION EXAM LEVEL, WHILE INCORPORATING DIVERSE TEACHING METHODS.
02140134.name: Teaching Methods for Secondary Math B

02140135.about: AS PART OF THE PRACTICUM IN TEACHING MATHEMATICS, EVERY STUDENT WILL ATTEND CLASSES IN DIFFERENT AGE GROUPS AND LEVELS, AND WILL OBSERVE, LEARN ABOUT AND ACTIVELY EXPERIENCE DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF THE TEACHER WORK. EACH STUDENT WILL BE ENGAGED IN 10 HOURS PER WEEK ON CLASSES OF A MENTOR TEACHER AND WILL TEACH 10 SESSIONS (HALF IN MIDDLE SCHOOL, AND HALF IN HIGH-SCHOOL). IN ADDITION, REFLECTION MEETINGS DURING THE PRACTICUM WILL ENABLE DISCUSSING AND ANALYZING SELECTED EVENTS AND SCENARIOS FROM THE CLASSROOMS TO SUPPORT THE NOVICE TEACHERS. EACH STUDENT WILL BE SUPPORTED AND FOLLOWED-UP BY MENTOR TEACHER. THE FINAL GRADE IS DETERMINED BY THE ON-GOING EVAL UATION OF THE MENTOR TEACHER, SUBMISSIONS DURING THE SEMESTER AND A TEST LESSON.
02140135.name: Practicum in Mathmatics Teaching

02140137.about: methods for teaching topics in the questionnaires at the 5-unit level, through the development of a teaching unit, reflection on active teaching, coping with students' difficulties, and development of problem-solving skills. in particular, emphasis is placed on methods for online teaching and use of diverse assessment tools.
02140137.name: METHODS OF TEACHING SECONDARY SCH. MATH

02140213.about: introduction: what is number theory. the set of integers and its basic properties. divisibility of integers. congruences, their properties and solution. quadrartic residues and legendre symbols. arithmetic functions. special numbers. diophintine equations. binaryquadratic forms. applications of the number theory for encoding an information.
02140213.name: Introduction to Number Theory

02140300.about: As part of the practicum in teaching physics, every student will attend classes in different age groips and levels, and will observe, learn about and actively experince different aspects of the teacher work. in addition, reflection meetings during the practicum will enable discussing and analyzing selected events and scenarios from the classroom to support the novice teachers. Each student will be supported and followed-up by mentor teacher. The final grade is determined by the on-going evaluation of the mentor teacher, submissions during the semester and a test lesson.
02140300.name: School Practicum - Physics

02140301.about: Comprehensive discussion of the instruction of mechanics and waves at the high school level through designing, teaching and discussing exemplary lessons. Presentations skills, leading discussions, students' difficulties, teaching problem solving skills, using experiments and demonstrations, Internet simulations and toys in the instruction of physics, productive homework and assessment.
02140301.name: Methods of Teaching Physics 1

02140302.about: Comprehensive discussions of the instruction of electricity, magnetism, radiation and matter at the high school level through designing, teaching and discussing exemplary lessons. Presentations skills, leading discussions, students' difficulties, teaching problemsolving skills, using experiments and demonstrations, Internet simulations and toys in the instruction of physics, productive homework and assessment.
02140302.name: Methods of Teaching Physics 2

02140400.about: The cognitive, social and affective goals of environmental- education with emphasis on action-competence and action. Its historicaldevelopment and the transition to education-for- sustainability will be discussed, as well as the role and place of environmental-education in the educational system on the sequences of formal-informal and in-school and out-of-school education.
02140400.name: Introduction to Environmental Education

02140401.about: Systematic discussion on high school 3 point level chemistry curriculum, including: basic concepts, ionic substances, atom structure, periodicity and chemical families, chemical bonds and the solid state. Scientific and didactic analysis of concepts and topics inchemistry. Teaching.learning strategies such as demonstrations, laboratory and computer aided experiments, reading and analysis of scientific and popular articles. Assessment according to a final test and project.
02140401.name: Teaching Methods in Chemistry- Environment 1

02140402.about: Systematic discussion on high school 3 point level chemistry curriculum, including: quantitative aspects, oxidation-reduction, acidand base, and food cemistry. Scientific and didactic analysis of concepts and topics in chemistry. Teaching.learning strategies such as demonstration, laboratory and computer aided aexperiments, and molecular modeling. Exposure to 3 point level chemistry matriculation examination. Assessment according to a final test and project.
02140402.name: Teaching Methods in Chemistry- Environment 2

02140410.about: As part of the practicum in teaching Chimestry, every student will attend classes in different age groips and levels, and will observe, learn about and actively experince different aspects of the teacher work. in addition, reflection meetings during the practicumwill enable discussing and analyzing selected events and scenarios from the classroom to support the novice teachers. Each student will be supported and followed-up by mentor teacher. The final grade is determined by the on-going evaluation of the mentor teacher,submissions during the semester and a test lesson.
02140410.name: School Practicum-Chemistry

02140411.about: as part of the practicum in teaching science and technology, every atudent will attend classes in different age groips and levels, and will observe, learn about and actively experince different aspects of the teacher work. in addition, reflection meetings during the practicum will enable discussing and analyzing selected events and scenarios from the classroom to support the novice teachers. each student will be supported and followed-up by mentor teacher. the final grade is determined by the on-going evaluation of the mentor teacher, submissions during the semester and a test lesson.
02140411.name: School Prac.-Teaching Sc.and Technol'

02140444.about: The course focuses on learning and practicing the inquiry approach in chemistry teaching in the laboratory, and on diversified teaching and assessing methodes of inquiry experiments in chemistry. The topics include guided and independent inquiry experiments in chemistry for middle and high school students.
02140444.name: Teaching Inquiry in Chemistry Lab.

02140501.about: The subject matter structure in biology, organization levels and central principles. The biology high school curriculum, teaching approaches -conceptual understanding, exploration and inquiry. Theaching models in biology, analysis of research literature as teaching methodes, values and biological education, teleology, team teaching.
02140501.name: Teaching Methods in Biology 1

02140502.about: The high school biology curriculum (cont.), organizing the Lab - incorporating classroom  and lab-based teaching, doing inquiry laband "bio-field trip", computers and web-based learning, concept maps and student assessment: tests and authentic assessment and developing scoring rubrics.
02140502.name: Teaching Methods in Biology and Environmemt 2

02140510.about: As part of the practicum in teaching biology and environment, every student will attend classes in different age groips and levels,and will observe, learn about and actively experince different aspects of the teacher work. in addition, reflection meetings duringthe practicum will enable discussing and analyzing selected events and scenarios from the classroom to support the novice teachers.Each student will be supported and followed-up by mentor teacher. The final grade is determined by the on-going evaluation of the mentor teacher, submissions during the semester and a test lesson. For undergeaduate students who have accumulated at least 116 credit s points and students from the Mabatim program who studied at least two semesters and completed at least half of the additional disciplinary courses (if required).
02140510.name: School Practicum-Biology and Environment

02140600.about: This course must be taken coupled with one of the method courses. students will experience biology lesson planning and teaching. lessons will be video-recorded in order to enable group discussion and feedback.
02140600.name: Teaching Inquiry Project in Biology

02140607.about: The course discusses the goals of the Science and Technology curriculum for middle school and the integrative approach that characterizes this course. It presents teaching and learning methods for interconnecting science - technology - society, inquiry - based learning, generating questions, peer assessment, etc., while applying advanced educational technologies. The course discusses the topics of matter, energy, force and motion, organisms, technology and environment.
02140607.name: Teaching Sci. Techn. in Jun. High School

02140806.about: design process and design thinking. approaches to engineering design. relationships between design and inquiry, engineering design education methodologies. engineering design as an experiential project-based learning tool. guidance and assessment of outcomes of high-school design projects. practice in executing, documenting, guiding, and evaluating engineering design projects.
02140806.name: Methods of Teaching Engineering Design

02140901.about: The course prepares prospective computer science teachers for teaching the fundamentals of computer science and data structures. Selected topics and their teaching methods are discusses and implemented. Focus is placed on students' perceptions and the implementation of a variety of teaching approaches such as, learning from mistakes and inquiry learning.
02140901.name: Didactics of Computer Science - 3 Point Level

02140902.about: The course focuses on projects based learning ( PBL ): development, implementation, mentoring and assessment, in the context of high school computer science and software engineering curriculum. The contents are the lab units ( web programming, assembler, information systems, computer graphics ) and projects in software engineering specializations ( design and programming systems and cyber).
02140902.name: Didactics of Computer Science - 5 Point Level

02140905.about: As part of the practicum in teaching Computer science, every student will attend classes in different age groips and levels, and will observe, learn about and actively experince different aspects of the teacher work. in addition, reflection meetings during the practicum will enable discussing and analyzing selected events and scenarios from the classroom to support the novice teachers. Each student will be supported and followed-up by mentor teacher. The final grade is determined by the on-going evaluation of the mentor teacher, submissions during the semester and a test lesson.
02140905.name: School Practicum - Computer Science

02140907.about: Computational thinking is accepted today as a relevant thinking skill in all areas, particularly in science. The course develops students' knowledge and skills related to algorithmic and logical computational thinking, using the Scratch environment, which allows building animations and games integrated with media and it is easy to use by dragging blocks.
02140907.name: Microworlds-Learning in Computational Environments

02140908.about: The course deals with the teaching of programming and focuses on gentle introduction to basic concepts and methodologies, on expressive power, and on the potential of computer science in understanding the processes of thinking and learning.
02140908.name: Issues in Cs Teaching 1

02140909.about: Learning and teaching computer science concepts. Presentation: preparing and delivering. Reflection. Teamwork: cooperation, conflicts, communication. Getting and giving feedback. Communication with customers, users, management, marketing. Communication in international environment. Diversity. Change and time management. Ethics, business writing, e-communication. The course is taught in the active learning approach.
02140909.name: Computer Science Problems - Soft Skills

02160003.about: this course is appropriate for advanced ba as well as ma and phd students, due to the increasing numbers of children suffering fromlearning difficulties in the educational system and the need for solutions. therefore, the students will learn the definition of learning and behavioral difficulties and their characterization. the course will include a discuession of the following difficulties: dyslexia, dyscalculia, attention and behavioral deficits and other language and emotional disabilitues. different interventions, appropriate for these difficulties will be discussed as well. learning outcomes: at the end of the course the student will be able to: d efine different learning and behavioral difficulties. understand a diagnostic report. to match an untervention program to the appropriatte difficulty.
02160003.name: Neuroeducation Learning Difficulties

02160004.about: new developments in physics education: genres of inquiry from guided to open inquiry, project based learning, mentorship, developing physical thinking, cultivating students' interest in physics, posturing students autonomy and ownership, exposure to and analysis of research in physics education, discussion of different patterns for integrating authentic inquiry and contemporary physics into the instruction of physics at the upper secondary school level. learning outcomes: at the and of the course the dtudent will know to:formulate authentic research problems in physics that are within the capacity of high school students. advise and mentor high-school  students' research projects analyze inquiry learning processes and essess the products of this learning.
02160004.name: Developments in Physics Education

02160005.about: a discussion of various conceptualizations of key topics in the high school physics from the historical perspective of the scientists who developed these theories, and from the perspective of physics education researchers who studied the development of students' conceptual understanding of these topics and their ability to apply them to problem solving. at the end of the course the student will be able to: 1. understand the complexity, depht and different facets of understanding of the key issues in the high school physics curriculum from disciplinary and educational perspectives. 2. design and critically analyze instructional processes of central topi cs in high school physics that reflect deep understanding of the subject matter as well as the entailed educational research.
02160005.name: Advanced Issues in Teaching Physics

02160007.about:
in this course, the student will focus on a chosen research question in the educational neuroimaging center located in the faculty of education in science and technology and will work closely with one of the educational neuroimaging center lab members. the student will learn how to formulate a research question, how to collect data using eeg, mri or eye tracking devices, how to analyze the collected (or the already collected) datasets and how tosummarize the results in a scientific way. the students will learn the relations between brain structure and function as generated from neuroimaging data and relate it to learning and cognmitive abilities of the  developing brain. additionally, the student will practice the preparation and administration of scientific talk - the student willperesent the prgoress the scientific work during the semester, at the end of the semester, the student will present the full project and results as well as submit a written work describing the research topic methods and results. 
 learning outcomes: at the end ofthe course, the student will be able to:
 1. describe the research teps involved in a neuroscientific study. 
 2. use different nneuroimaging
02160007.name: Lab Project in Neuroscience

02160009.about: understanding the principles of quatitative- empirical research- the researcher's work process, variable types, descripitive statistics including correlations, reliability and factor analysis (structure validity), inferential statistics, hypothesis testing and significance independent samples t-test, basic analysis of variance. the course will be accompanied by critical reading of research articles in the field of science education and practice in spss software to anable data analysis. learning outcomes: at the end of thecourse, the student will be able to: understand quantitative research methods and basic data analysis in academic articales.  adjust  between research questions and selected statistical procedures. process data in the spss software and analyze its output. process data in the spss software and analyze its output.
02160009.name: Quantitative Research Methods in Education

02160011.about: the course deals with the emerging changes in science and technology education in the digital age. the changes are fundamental, affecting both the nature of science and the nature of technology. correspondingly, our understanding of teaching, learning and assessment ptocesses in science and technology education are changing. theoretical issues of science and technology education in the digital age with an emphasis on the practical implications for teachers are in the focus of the course. by the end of the course the students should: be familiar with basic principles and concepts of the nature of science, natureof technology, as well as science and engi neering practices in the digital age. be aware of basic principles, concepts and up-to-date trends of science and technilogy education, both in the theoretical and the practical contexts. be able to reveal interrelations between thearetical discourses and practical implementations of science and technology educational_trends in digital age. be able to assess digital science and technology educational practices
02160011.name: Stem Education in Digital Age

02160012.about: the course covers current and future technilogies that support students with special needs. in recent years many countries has moved to an inclusive model of special needs students. at the same new time technologies that can support this population emerged. this course will cover these technologies and will support creative thinking. learning outcomes: by the end of the course the students should: 1. become familiar with existing technologies that address different disabilities such as autisem, dyslexia, attention deficitdisorders, dysgraphia and dyscalculia. 2. become familiar with technologies that support special needs and inclusion. 3. become fami liar with future directions of technologies that support special needs. 4. be able to define new technologies that can support inclusion of students with special needs.
02160012.name: Technologies for Special Needs Edu.

02160014.about: the course introduces the main theoretical frameworks dealing with learning difficulties in school in general and in stem disciplines in particular. these frameworks include psychological, socio-political, and critical theories. the course will focus on learning disabilities, physical and emotional disabilities. the growing discipline of disability studies will for a basis for discussion issues of inclusion and exclusion in the education system. by the end of the course the students should be able to: 1. describe the maintheories in the field of learning difficulties. 2. connect between theories in the domain of disability studies and school practices  regarding inclusion and exclusion of students with special needs. 3. establish their own teachung philosophies with regard to students with special needs, and justify them based on the theories learned in the course
02160014.name: Learning Difficultiess in Stem Subjects

02160016.about: our brain controls our cognitive abilities, our learning abilities, the functioning of the motor and sensory system, and our ability to understand the internal and external environment. all the above lead the determination of verbal and nonverbal iq. when one of these processes is impaired, then neurological, psychiatric or developmental disorders and diseases occur. this course will focus onbrain activation related to these abilities and their relation to learning at the end of the course the students will: 1. know the neuroanatomy of learning. 2. understand the learnung process in children and adults. 3. understand the brain-behavior connection in t he learning process. 4. understand the effect of the discussed disorders on learning.
02160016.name: Brain, Learning and Intelligence

02160019.about:
the age of children in the education system ranges from 6-18 years. within these years, a dramatic shift from childhood to adolescence and adulthood occurs. this shift is accompanied with neurophysiological, physiological, cognitive, emotional and social changes,directly affect learning and communication skills. this course is an overview of the cognitive, emotional, and social changes along development (in children and adolescence) and the neurobiological markers underlie these changes. We will also discuss the nature-nurture relations and the effect on neurocognitive development. The cognitive changes include langguage cognitive and academic developm ent, whereas the emotional changes include motivatio and risk taking which heavily characterize teenagers. social development and its neural markers will also be discussed. Students will present neuroimaging-based papers aiming to test these abilities. 
Learning Outcomes: 
at the end of the course student will be able to:
1. Understand the cognitive, emotional and social changes from childhood to adolescents. 
 2. Understand the Physiological basis of brain development from childhood to adolescents. 
 3. match the appropriate to
02160019.name: Neuroeucation Child Development

02160020.about:
,     .     ( MEG ,MRI FUNCTIONAL ,EEG ,MRI )  .           ,     ,     MRI - .GNIKCART EYE  :     : 1.      .
 2.            . 
 3.          . 
 4.  IRM - GEE . 
 5.            .
02160020.name: Neuroimaging - Theory and Practice

02160022.about: this course will examine existing learning theories and frameworks for educational thechnologies (e.g. behaviorism, cognitive theories, constructivism) in the context of different edtech companies in israel and the world (e.g. scratch, amplify learning). in particular the course will analyze frameworks for innovation in education and methods for effective development, assessment and implementation of edtech technologies in the classroom and beyond. learning outcomes: by the end of the course students will know the learning theories and models that stand in the foundation of various educational technologies, will know a wide variety of successful edtech  companies as well as companies that did not succeed to break through and the possible reasons for that. will get familiar with theobstacles in bringung new technologies unto the educational system. will know the development, assessment and implementation processes of edtech copmanies, and will develop an idea for a new edtech technology in light of the course content.
02160022.name: Edtech Entrepreneurship

02160026.about: introduction to the diverse facets of the israeli educational system, through a series of visits to schools that serve different sectors and needs, represent various educational perspectives, as well as meetings with different stake holders in the israeli educational system. the course includes a compulsory thre- day field trip. learning outcomes: at the end of the course students will: 1. learn about the diverse aspects of the israeli education system, and understand the complexities, gaps and challenges it faces. 2. be able to explain some of the processes that led to persistent inequalities. 3. write a critical review that examines one of the facets  of the israeli school system to which they were exposed to in the course.
02160026.name: A Journey Into the Israeli Educational System

02160027.about: The couse aims to preparestudents as evaluators of Science and Technology educational projects. Students will become familiar with topics and research focusing on project assessment, develop critical reading skills of assessment literature, question-posing and discussion leading, will be exposed to various affective and subject matter assessment tools, learn methods for initial findings analysis, develop assessment research design skills and perform initial assessment research. The final course project shall be presented as a research poster.
02160027.name: Evaluation Ofeducational Project

02160030.about: the course covers theoretical and applied aspects of learning analytics, including: goals and uses, approaches and common tools (predictive modeling, dashboards, social network analysis) data representayions, ethical dilemmas and adoption. the course project asksstudents to analyze a data set of their choice. open data is available. at the end of the course the student will know: 1. to critically analyze literature in the area of learning analytics 2. to define research question and variables that are suitable for learning analytics and data mining 3. to understand main topics and approaches in the area of learning analytics. 4. to analyze simple data -sets in order to identify learning processes and outcomes. 5. to grasp dilemmas about policy, ethics and adoption of learning analytics. 6. to use learning analytics thechniques and tools to improve learning and instructional design.
02160030.name: Learning Analytics

02160031.about: the course focuse on advanced issues in engineering education at both the high school and higher education levels. the course dealswith cognitive, affective and social aspects in engineering education,e.g., systems thinking, abstract thinking, multimedia, motivation and soft skills. at the end of the course: the student will be familiar with cognitive, affective and social aspects in engineering education. the course content and syllabus might be changed ech semester and should be approved by the undergraduate and graduate faculty committees and be posted in the catalog.
02160031.name: Advanced Issues in Engineering Education

02160033.about:
rinciples of quantitative-empirical research - the research process, types of variables, descriptive statistics, including correlations, reliability and factor analysis (structure validity), inferior statistics: testing hypotheses and significance, t-tests for independent samples, basic variance analysis. emphasis will be placed on the analysis of research in the field of teaching mathematics, science and engineering. a critical review of research articles in the field of science teaching will accompany the course, along with in spss software, which will enable data analysis. 
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course, students will be able to: quan titative research methods and analyze basic dat articles related to science education and make a ch different research questions and statistical proced will also be able to process data in spss software pages.
02160033.name: BASIC QUANTITATIVE RESEARCH METHODS

02160034.about:
the course discusses theoretical and practical aspects related to teaching, learning and assessment in the 21st century with the help of web-based technologies. the course discusses issues related to education in digital environments, such as: synchronous and asynchronous learning, computer simulations, location-based systems, mobile learning, flipped classroom, and open multi-participant online courses (moocs).
 learning outcomes: during the course the students will:
 - become acquainted with methods, tools and concepts in digital teaching and learning.
 - participate in an online forum on 21st century skills.
 - use multimedia tools to illustrate a s cientific concept, process or principle.__
02160034.name: THE WEB AS A LEARNING ENVIRONMENT

02160035.about:
the course aims to establish a conceptual and technological framework, which includes a discussion of the development phases of artificial intelligence, the concepts of narrow and general ai, the idea of autonomous decision-making machines, the concept of artificial moral agent, types of artificial moral agents and more. in addition, the course deals with fundamental topics in the future of ai, and the most significant problems we will be facing while developing future autonomous machines and artificial moral agents. the course discusses the control problem, the ai alignment problem, the attempts to solve these problems and additional security, legal a nd social related problems. learning outcomes:
 upon the successful completion of the course, students will be able to explain and analyse the central concepts related to the fields of machine ethics and the future of ai, the main problems researchers in these fields face and the prominent suggested solutions. additionally, students will be able to formulate an educated position regarding those issues and present their views and ideas using contemporary related views and concepts.
02160035.name: INTRODUCTION TO MACHINE ETHICS

02160037.about:
the course deals with theoretical and practical issues in measuring and evaluating learning. as part of the course! the students will learn about the goals of assessment and will define different types of assessment. the course discusses basic concepts such as fairness! reliability! and validity! that allow for the evaluation to be evaluated and ensure that it achieves its goals. students will practice writing questions and analyzing them in order to evaluate knowledge! understand failures! identify learning processes! and measure transfer. the differences between formative assessment! summative assessment! and research assessment will be discussed. th e course also deals with evaluating learning beyond knowledge! such as motivations! attitudes! and skills. in addition! the students will analyze international tests and alternative assessment approaches. the summative project includes building an assessment battery for a variety of aspects of a single topic: knowledge! transfer! attitudes! motivations and skills. 
 learning outcomes: by the end of the course! the studetns will be able to:
 1.  identify well-defined goals that they wish to evaluate.
 2. know how to designevaluatio
02160037.name: EDUCATIONAL TESTING AND MEASUREMENT

02160038.about:
this course examines design-based research in education as a sociocultural approach that supports collaborative thinking and building of learning environments systematically! while considering needs and desires of diverse learners and diverse communities in society. the course will explore major design research approach(es) through examining the history of design research! defining objects ofdesign in education and human-computer interaction (hci)! using design methods to conduct to think of diverse learners and communities! and examples of participatory research across various settings with youth! teachers! communities. the course will explore the fo llowing aspects: defining design research! objects of design process and outcomes! work with diverse stakeholders and subjects! theinteraction between subjects and artifacts in the design process! values in design process! equity and inequities in the design process! and illustrating of conjecture maps for learning process and its outcomes. 
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the studetns will know:
 1. planning design research project through the lens of various sociocultural theoretical approaches while considering ethic
02160038.name: DESIGN RESEARCH IN EDUCATION

02160110.about:
Analyzing inter-disciplinary aspects of teaching sciences and technology.  Planning of learning sets in scientific or technologicalsubjects,taking into consideration their inter-relationships.
 Implementation of the developed learning unit in school, and carrying out appropriate evaluation aiming at introducing adequate improvements.
02160110.name: Science Teaching in Relation to Tech.

02160112.about: The goal of this course is to help the participants construct a solid theoretical and practical orientation to mathematical teaching. The course introduces innovative teaching practices, including conducting rich discussions and offering opportunities for explorative. Participants will develop lesson plans, analyze videos, teach and receive feedback on their teaching.
02160112.name: Advanced Workshop in High School Mathematics

02160116.about: updated developments in biology education,using argumentation and debate, informal resources, authentic science, students' interests and updated primary literature in biology classroom.
02160116.name: Developments in Biology Education

02160117.about: topics: formulation of message to fit an audience, presentation of science related issues. public knowledge of science and its resources, different models for science communication.
02160117.name: Science Communications

02160125.about: Innovative approaches to assessment in mathematic's education, encompassing a broad scope of mathematical knowledge, relying on various sources and instruments. Several approaches and methods will be analyzed and applied, with reference to the educational theory they reflect and to the mathematics curriculum and teaching goals to which they relate. These approaches include: Diagnostic assessment, performance assessment, assessment of open-end tasks, assessment of tasks designed for a computerized learning environment.
02160125.name: Assessment in Mathematics Education

02160126.about: the workshop will include 4-6 hours per week which the students will spend in science classes and teach several lessons. daily events occurring in school will be discussed and used by the students to perform an action research, which will be presented.
02160126.name: Practicum-Practicing Science Teaching with Action Research

02160128.about: Recent educational reforms advocating the development of higher order thinking skills require implementation of "alternative" assessment. Limitations of "traditional" assessment methods will be analyzed and alternative methods such as: performance assessment, portfolios and concept mapping will be discussed.
02160128.name: Assessment in Science Education

02160131.about: Discussions on issues from contemporary literature on science, technology and environmental education in the outdoors: museums, factories, public institutions, and open areas. Cognitive and affective characteristics of learning in informal settings and their interaction with formal learning. Analysis of curricular characteristics of various environments, suitable teaching methods
02160131.name: Informal Science and Technology Education

02160135.about:
the course deals with innovative approaches to mathematics teaching. these include: choice and design of task, orchestrating productive discussions, attuning instruction to students' needs, learning difficulties and emotional aspects of learning. students will beexposed to different practices in the teaching of mathematics and will discuss their implications, as evidenced by research and practice learning outcomes: upon completion of the course, students will:
 1. understand different practices for teaching mathematics and be able to recognized them from observation of lessons. 2. know to prepare a lesson plan including the practices learnes. 3. be ab le to analyze learning opportunties by different teaching practices based on research literature.
02160135.name: Advanced Topics in Teaching Mathematics

02160136.about: the course focuses on inquiry- learning in science and technology education that includes social aspects as well. changes in conceptions of inquiry- learning will be discussed and different genres of inquiry used in the natural science and other disciplines, suchas experimental, descriptive, corellative, wull be presented. learning outcomes: the students will experience at least two genres of inquiry, and will present research questions, methodology, findings and conclusions for each.
02160136.name: Inquiry Based Science Learning

02160150.about: Personal project in educational research grants Undergraduate and Graduate students the possiblity of conducting a mini-research under the guidane of a faculty member. Students will expand their knowledge in science, Technology, Engineering and mathematics, deepen their understaning of advanced research methods and gain experience in practical and theoretical research. A research report is required for evaluation. Learning Ouctomes: The end of the course the students will know: 1. Plan a research while underlining the useof empirical methods. 2. Perform an up-to-date literature review. 3. Collect data using a variety of tools. 4. Analyze data using va lid methodologies and present different interpretations of the findings. 5. Present the findings in a varid manner and will write aresearch report.
02160150.name: Individual Project in Educational Research

02160155.about:
the course focuses on the integration of artificial intelligence in general and generative ai in particular in all stages of science and engineering education, from school to graduate studies. in particular, core artificial intelligence concepts are discussed, artificial intelligence tools for use in research and education in science and engineering are mapped, and required skills for integrating artificial intelligence in science and engineering education are analyzed, both from the teachers, researchers and learners perspectives. special attention is paid to ethical considerations when integrating generative ai in research and education in general and in the context of science and engineering education in particular.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. explain to different audiences core artificial intelligence concepts. 
 2. map different usages of artificial intelligence tools in science and engineering education.
 3. assess the quality of the products of generative ai tools.
 4. integrate artificial intelligence tools in science and engineering education processes.
 5. plan teaching units in which involve artificial intelligen
02160155.name: AI IN SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING EDUCATION

02160156.about:
the course focuses on mathematical modelling of real-world phenomena within a scientific-engineering context, using mathematical models that are compatible with school mathematics. students are trained in four aspects of instructional modelling competencies: theoretical understanding, familiarity and experience with solving, analyzing and designing modelling tasks, teaching experience (including knowledge of teaching interventions), and thinking as a learner while focusing on expected difficulties and challenges. an emphasis is placed on on inquiry activities using advanced technologies, guided reading of journal papers, and planning and delivering les sons in a simulation lab.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will: 1. gain in-depth knowledge of current literature in mathematical modelling.
 2. gain modelling competencies for solving modelling tasks in a variety of science and engineering contexts. 3. plan a lesson based on mathematical modelling in a scientific-engineering context. 4. gain instructional competencies for effective modelling teaching. 5. assess the quality of teaching mathematical modelling tasks.
02160156.name: EDUCATIONAL MATHEMATICAL MODELING

02160300.about: Teaching advanced key issues in computer science: Programming paradigms and computational models. logic programming, functional programming, automata theory and formal languages. An emphasis on problem solving processes in different programming paradigms and different fields of knowledge in computer science. Development of teaching - learning activities. Learning Outcomes: Upon completion of this course the students will be able to: 1. Formulate the characteristics of programming paradigms. 2. Analyze solutions for given problems based on the characteristics of different programming paradigms. 3. Analyze the complexity of solutions in different program ming paradigms. 4. Analyze problems in computational models based on problem solving heuristics 5. Develop computational models forsolving problems with computational environment (Deterministic finite automaton, pushdown automaton, turing machine). 6. Develop learning activities aimed at developing learner's understanding of computer science principles.
02160300.name: Advanced Topics in Computer Science Teaching

02160320.about: The seminar will address recent developments in teaching chemistry and new technologies, which support the development of curriculain science education, such as technology-enhanced learning environment, modeling, computerized laboratories, analysis of scientifictexts through conceptual modeling. This course will include the analysis of research on Chemical education in Israel and worldwide integrated with development of a mini learning unit and its modeling. Learning Outcomes: At the end of the course, the student will be 1. Familiar with the latest developements in Chemical education. 2. able to model short scientific texts. 3. to read, analyze and critic journal papers that focus on Chemical education research.
02160320.name: Developments in Teaching Chemistry

02180000.about:
Ethics in scientific, engineering, medical and educational research, maintaining ownership and copyrights, misconduct in research, the role of discipline committees, rules and regulations on the implementation of studies in humans and animals in israel, informingthe participants about their rights, technion's regulations on proper conduct in research and the code of conflict of interest.
 Learning Outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be able to implement the follwoing actrivities: identifying situations of ethical conflicts and dilemmas in scientific, engineering, medical and educational research, protecting copyrights  and intellectual property rights, complying with laws and regulations for responsible conduct of research in humans and animals, informing research subjects of their rights, implementing codes of ethical conduct.
02180000.name: Research Ethics

02180003.about: the course will introduce the students to contemporary theoretical framworks for studying emotions, identity and equity in learningand teaching, with focus on stem education. the learning will be based on reading book chapters and journal articles from a wide veriety of international perspectives. in addition, the course will expose the students to a variety of methodolgical tools for examining issues of affect, identity and equity. the students will engage in analysis of real-life cases and will conduct a mini-research pertaining to one of the subjects of the course. learning outcomes: upon completion of this course it is inteded that a student will be able to: 1. describe the main theoretical frameworks that inform the domain of affect, identity and equity in mathematics education. 2. read, understand and analyze critically research papers in this domain. 3. implement the findings presented in the studies discussed to the educational field and the school mathematics classroom. 4. plan and implement a small case -study research that relates to one or more of the main subjects of the course (affect, identity and culture).
02180003.name: Affect, Identity and Equity

02180006.about: the course is intended to give practical and theoretical tools for analyzing discourse in the mathematics and science classroom. students will learn different frameworks for analyzing classroom discourse and will get acquianted with the major theories and studiesof the field. empahsis will be placed on gaining experience with analysis, by transcribing and analyzing audio and video data. at the end of the course the student will be able to: independently analyze an excerpt of classroom discourse according to at least one of the methods learned. the student will understand and be able to use studies that have used other methods of analysis.
02180006.name: Classroom Discourse

02180007.about: understanding the principles of advanced quantitative- empirical research while recognizing advanced statistical procedures- advanced multivariate analyses of variance, repeated measures analysis of variance, regressions. the course will be accompanied by critical reading of research articles in the field of science education, and practice in the spss software to enable advanced data analysis. learning outcomes at the end of the course the student will be able to: understand advanced quantitative research methods and advanced data analysis in academic articles. adjust  between research questions and selected advanced statistical procedures. process dat a in the spss software and analyze its output in advanced level.
02180007.name: Advenced Quantitative Research

02180103.about: Scientific method in educational research.  Formulation of a research problem.  Classification of variables, variance, its sources,measurement and control.  Quantitative and qualitative research design. Internal and external validity, trustworthiness. Sampling and collecting of data.
02180103.name: Foundations of Educational Research

02180120.about: Topics: Learning theroes (i.e., constructivism, constructionism and scociocultural) and their impact on curriculum develoment. Current views of learning, instruction and the curriculum. Historical analysis of the science and technolgy curriculum. Rationale and design principles.
02180120.name: Learning Theories and Curiculum Development

02180122.about: Discussion of theoretical and methodological problems encountered in educational research by means of analysis of research reports.Each student is required to prepare and present a research report for critical discussion by the seminar group. 02180125.about: In this seminar recent studies in mathematics education will be read and examined.Focus will be on papers dealing with students.

Students will develop educational materials based on the latest educational theories and subsequently carry out of large-scale evaluation study. In addition, students will take part in educational studies in the area of mathematics in coordination and supervisionof a faculty member in her.his research field. 
 Learning Outcomes: develop an innovative learning unit, develop an online application and run it among learners, carry out an educational research based on advanced theories, take part in a research project by reviewing relevant literature and.or collecting and analyzing data.

02180145.name: Advanced Seminar in Outdoor Education 1

02180218.about: an introduction to a variety of theoretical framworks that may guide research in the emerging field of science communication, including political communication, risk communication, public engagment, the new media landscape and issues of trust. learning outcomes:by the end of the course a studens will be able to: 1. define science communication and identify the main curret topics studied. 2. point to central studies and prominent researchers in the field of science communication ofeer a critical analysis of research published in a professional journall. 3. develop a resarch proposal based on literature review and grounded in appropriate theoretical fram eworks. 4. ground a research proposal using different theoretical perspectives. 5. compare, contrast and relate theories from the fields of science education and science education and science communication.
02180218.name: The Science of Science Communication

02180319.about:
THE COURSE FOCUSES ON THE PRACTICE OF QUALITATIVE RESEARCH ADDRESSING THE FOLLOWING TOPICS: RESEARCH PROBLEM, TARGET AND QUESTIONS,DATA GATHERING, DATA ANALYSIS, GROUNDED THEORY, RELIABILITY AND VALIDITY, AND ETHICS. THE DISCUSSIONS IN THE COURSE ARE BASED ON ARTICLES THE STUDENTS READ AND THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF QUALITATIVE RESEARCH.
  LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS:
 1. WILL ACQUIRE A COMPRECHENSIVE PERSPECTIVE ON THE PROCESS OF 2. STUDENTS WILL ACQUIRE SKILLS TO CARRY OUT A COMPLETE PROCESS OFQUALITATIVE RESEARCH.
 3. STUDENTS WILL CARRY OUT A QUALITATIVE RESEARCH WORK AT A SCALE APPROPRIATE TO A COURSE FRAMEWORK._
 4. STU DENTS WILL UNDERSTAND THE UNIQUENESS OF QUALITATIVE RESEARCH AND WHAT RESEARCH TOPICS ARE APPROPRIATE TO_ RESEARCH BY QUALITATIVE RESEARCH METHODS. 
5. WILL DISCUSS THEIR CLASMATES RESEARCH WORKS AND DEVELOP A CRITICAL PERSPECTIVE ON THE PRCOESS OF CARRYING OUT AQUALITATIVE RESEARCH WORK.
02180319.name: Qualitative Research: Practical Aspects

02180322.about:
The course focuses on the history and methodological-theoretical aspects of qualitative research. Review of qualitative methods employed in the collection and the analysis of data. Discussions of the applications and philosophical considerations within the context of educational research. Learning Outcomes:  At the end of the course the students:
 1. Will distinguish between the various generes of qualitative research such as ethnography, Grounded theory,, phenomenology, narrative research etc.
 2. Will be able to explaindifferent approaches for confirming trstworthiness. 
 3. Will critically read research papers using qualitative methodologies.
02180322.name: Qualitative Research: Theoretical Aspects

02180324.about: Develop familiarity with high tech e-learning industry, identify e-learning needs of the educational and industrial markets, develop R and D questions relevant to e-learning , such as : methodologies of representation of knowledge, non-linear curricula, testing, collaboration, structure and analysis of educational sites in science and technology.
02180324.name: Practice Vs. Theory E-Learning

02180326.about: Examination of updated literature on science and scientific knowledge. The inclusion of the nature of science issue in currently available curricula. Discussions on attitudes and cognitive characteristics of the nature of science.
02180326.name: Nature of Science in Secondary Schools

02180329.about:
the aim of the course is to improve students' interpersonal, soft skills, such as written and oral communication, providing meaningful feedback following critical reading of abstracts, presentation to a diverse audience, self-esteem, and peer evaluation. the course format is based on research findings of a study on technion students and graduates, which showed that interpersonal skills can developed through active learning and engagements with peers. interpersonal skills were defined by leading engineering and science organizations worldwide as highly essential within the 21st century skills. the course is open to all technion graduate students engaged  in research, enabling them to be exposed to research from a variety of faculties and domains. by the end of the course the studentshould be able to: 1. introduce themselves orally to a diverse audience in a short, elevator pitch.
 2. present their research in writing to a diverse audience, while providing an accessible explanation of the topic and goals of the research.
 3. give and receivefeedback in a positive and constructive way.
 4. evaluate themselves and their peers.
 5. improve the meta-cognitive abilities associated wit
02180329.name: Develop Assess Interpersonal Skills

02340114.about: This course is for Computer Science students. Computer architecture.Algorithmic approach to problem solving. Basic concepts in the C language. Top-down design. Structured programming. Bottom-up design. Debugging. Partial and complete correctness proof of programs. Measures of algorithm efficiency: time and space complexity. Polynomial and exponential complexity. Probabilistic analysis of algorithms. Randomized algorithms. Intractable problems. Stack. Queue. Representations of arithmetic expressions, and implementation of their evaluation by stack. Recursion and its implementation. Branch and Bound Search. Efficient sorting.
02340114.name: Introduction to Computer Science

02340117.about: This course is for electrical engineering students. Computer architecture. Algorithmic approach to problem solving. Basic concepts in the C language. Top-down design. Structured programming. Bottom-up design. Debugging. Partial and complete correctness proof of programs. Measures of algorithm efficiency: time and space complexity. Polynomial and exponential complexity. Probabilistic analysis of algorithms. Randomized algorithms. intractable problems. Stack. Queue. Representations of arithmetic expressions, and implementation of their evaluation by stack. Recursion ans its implementation. Branch and bound search. Efficient sorting.
02340117.name: Introduction to Computer Science H

02340118.about: ADVANCED SYSTEMS PROGRAMMING: FROM ASSEMBLY LEVEL TO AN ADVANCED PROGRAMMING ENVIRONMENT. COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE: HEAP, STACK. INTRODUCTION TO ASSEMBLY. COMPILATION AND BUILDING OF MULTI-FILE PROJECTS. LINKING AND LOADING. ADVANCED MEMORY MANAGEMENT: SMART POINTERS, MEMORY ALLOCATION SYSTEMS. OBJECT LAYOUT IN MEMORY. ALLOCATION AND DEALLOCATION ORDER. RESOURCE MANAGEMENT. SYNCHRONOUS AND ASYNCHRONOUS OPERATIONS. RENDERING A PAGE IN THE BROWSER.
02340118.name: Computer Organization and Programming

02340123.about: The course presents the central issues of modern operating systems, including: processes and threads, scheduling and context switching, cooperation, critical section, semaphores and condition variables, interrupts, memory management, paging, virtual memory, file systems. In the tutorial the students obtain deep knowledge of an advanced operating system.
02340123.name: Operating Systems

02340124.about: ADVANCED C: POINTERS, STRUCTURES, DYNAMIC MEMORY MANAGEMENT, LINKED LISTS, TREES. VERSION MANAGEMENT. COMPILATION, LINKING, AND USING LIBRARIES. BASIC SHELL COMMANDS. PYTHON AS GLUE LANGUAGE FOR SYSTEM PROGRAMMING. DEBUGGING, SOFTWARE TESTING, AUTOMATIC TESTING. INTRODUCTION TO C++: OBJECT-ORIENTED PROGRAMMING,_ABSTRACT DATA_TYPES, TYPES, STATIC AND DYNAMIC POLYMORPHISM.
02340124.name: Introduction to Systems Programming

02340125.about: Liner system of equations: Gauss elimination, LU and Cholesky decomposition, Positive definite matrices, Least squares and pseudo-inverse, Weighted least-squares,Tikhonov's regularisation, Inner-products and normed-vector spaces, Orthogonality, QR and its uses, Eigenvakues and singular values,the SVD decomposition and its uses,Itrative methods for solving linear and least-squares problems, Matrix induced norms, Gershgorin's theorem, the power method, Numerical instability and numerical erros, Toeplitz and Circulant matrices, Convolution, the discrete Fourier transform and the FFT, Iterative solution to 1D non-linear problems: Bisection, Newton-Raphson,  and the Secant algorithms and their convergence.
02340125.name: Numerical Algorithms

02340128.about: computer architecture. hardware and software. data representation. basic concepts in python programming: values, variables, expressions, arrays (one-and multi-dimensional), conditionals, loops, functions, recursion, input.output (textual and graphical). the python development environment: the workspace, program execution, debugging. structured programming, data organization. algorithms: correctness driven development and basic complexity analysis. algorithmic solutions for sorting, searching, problems with integers.
02340128.name: Introduction to Computing with Python

02340129.about: Basic definitions, relations, functions, equivalence relations and order relations, countable sets and cantor's diagonal argument, finite state automata (deterministic and non-deterministic), and non-deterministic), regular expressions, pumping lemma, formal grammars.
02340129.name: Int. to Set Theory and Automata for Cs

02340130.about: this course is intended for technion international programs and will be taught in english. course topics: computer architecture. hardware and software. data representation. basic concepts in python programming: values, variables, expressions, data types, conditionals, loops, functions, recursion, input.output (textual and graphical). the python development environment: the workspace, program execution, debugging. structured programming, data organization. algorithms:  correctness driven development and basic complexity analysis. algorithmic solutions for sorting, searching, problems with integers.
02340130.name: Int. to Computing with Python -Bl

02340141.about: Basic counting principles, Newton's binom, inclusion-exclusion principle, recursion and induction, partitions, directed and undirected graphs, counting trees, euler paths, positional trees and catalan numbers.
02340141.name: Combinatorics for Cs

02340218.about:
Emphasis on abstract data structures, selection and designing data structures for efficient solution of given problems. Various data structures, their properties, implementations and applications: arrays, stacks, queues, dequeues, various types of lists, search trees, heaps and priority queues, hash-tables.
 Other topics:  basic concepts of complexity, garbage collection, memory allocation, internal and external sorting and searching.
02340218.name: Data Structures 1

02340221.about: This course is for industrial engineering and management students. computer architecture. Hardware and software. Data representation. basic concepts in python programming: values, variables, expressions arrays (one- and multi-dimensional), conditionals, loops, functions, recursion, input.output (textual and graphical). The python development environment: the workspace, program execution, debugging structured programming, data organization. Algorithms:  correctness driven development and basic complexity analysis. Algorithmic solutions for sorting, searching, problems with integers.
02340221.name: Introduction to Computer Science N

02340230.about: The purpose is to enable students to study topics not covered by regular courses.  The study is conducted under the supervision of a faculty member.  In order to qualify, a student must have completed at least 80.0 credit points with an average grade of 80 or above.
02340230.name: Reading Course 1

02340231.about: The purpose is to enable students to study topics not covered by regular courses. The study is conducted under the supervision of afaculty member. In order to qualify, a student must have completed at least 80.0 credit points with an average grade of 80 or above.
02340231.name: Reading Course 2

02340247.about: This course deals with  basic methods for the design and analysis of algorithms, including search methods, greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, reductions, augmenting paths, randomized algorithms, and algebraic methods. The course presents efficient algorithmsfor fundamental problems in graph theory and other fields. Among the topics discussed are: breadth first search, depth first search, minimum spanning tree, shortest paths, network flows, cuts, string matching, and geometric and algebraic problems.
02340247.name: Algorithms 1

02340290.about: Intended for students in the last semester of their studies who need 0.5 credit points to complete their studies.  The student willdo a project under the supervision of a faculty member.
02340290.name: Project 1 in Computer Science

02340291.about: Intended for students in the last semester of their studies who need 1.0 credit points to complete their studies.  The student willdo a project under the supervision of a faculty member.
02340291.name: Project 2 in Computer Science

02340292.about: PROPOSITIONAL CALCULUS AND FIRST-ORDER LOGIC: DEFINITIONS, SEMANTICS, PROOF SYSTEMS, SOUNDNESS AND COMPLETENESS THEOREMS, COMPACTNESS THEOREMS AND THEIR USE.
02340292.name: Logic for Cs

02340301.about: In this course,the students develop a complete management information system. Each team of 3-4 students works under the supervisionof an instructor. The process involves requirement analysis, specification development, system design, implementation and testing. Detailed written documentation of each of these phases is required. The implementation will be done with a state-of-the-art application generator. The lectures will provide an introduction to the design of management information systems and to the application generator employed.
02340301.name: Project in Data Processing U

02340302.about: This course will involve the construction of a compiler for a specific programming language. Students will work singly or in small teams under close supervision of an assistant.
02340302.name: Project in Compilation U

02340303.about: A practical research project in a topic related to operating systems, like vrtualization, storage, networking, security, and cloud systems.
02340303.name: Project in Operating Systems U

02340304.about: This  course consists of a large software project in artificial intelligence. Students will work singly or in small teams under close supervision of an assistant.
02340304.name: Project in Artificial Intelligence U

02340311.about: This course is not considered as a project for the purpose of the graduation requirements. This course, together with the course Yearly Project in Software Engineering - Stage B (234312), constitute one unit, which spans over two consecutive semesters, concentrating on planning and carrying out large programming project. The students work in teams under the supervision of a senior faculty member. The course is dedicated to the study of a software development process including the stages requirements analysis, high-level design, detailed design and prototype implementation. Grading is based on interim reports, final reports and the quality of the protot ype which will be implemented at this stage.
02340311.name: Yearly Project in Software Eng.-Stage a

02340312.about: This course counts as a project for the purpose of the graduation requirements. Full implementation of the prototype implemented inthe preliminary course 234311. Grading is based on the overall project quality, which will be implemented at this stage, correctness checks, code quality, and interim reports.
02340312.name: Yearly Project in Software Eng.-Stage B'

02340313.about: Software project worth 3 academic credits, ideally performed by a pair of students (120 hours per student). A variety of project proposals in computer science topics are received from software companies at the beginning of the semester and offered to students. The project is supervised by an industrial supervisor, coordinated by a technion faculty member. The project gives the student experience in "real-world" software development, the use of modern development tools and environments, while fielding typical issues arising  in the development process. The software is to be delivered accompanied by suitable documentation and a summary report.
02340313.name: Industrial Project

02340325.about: Uses of computer graphics and advanced graphics systems. Raster graphics and geometry over the discrete grid. Two and three dimensional transformations. Representation and display of parametric curves and surfaces and three-dimensional objects. Hidden surface removal, shading and shadowing models, texture mapping and color models.
02340325.name: Computer Graphics 1

02340326.about: Students will do projects on the department's graphics hardware. The projects will be done singly or in small groups under supervision of assistants, directed by a senior faculty member.
02340326.name: Project in Computer Graphicsh

02340329.about: an extended project in the fields of image processing and image analysis. the students will work in groups of two, with a close supervision of the teaching assistant and the faculty member.
02340329.name: Project in Image Processing and Analysis

02340493.about: introduction to computer and cyber security. background on the main problems and solutions. basic vulnerabilities, buffer overflow.security in various applications, such as autonomous vehicles, health systems and medical devices, cloud computing. the course willinclude guest lectures for researchers from the academia and industry.
02340493.name: Introduction to Cyber Security

02340901.about: THE CLASS TEACHES PROGRAMMING PRINCIPALS FOR INTERNATIONAL PROGRAMMING COMPETITIONS. IT INCLUDES THEORY AND PRACTICE OF VARIOUS CORE COMPUTER SCIENCE AND MATH TOPICS. STUDENTS WILL GAIN PROBLEM-SOLVING EXPERIENCE, INCLUDING PLANNING DATA STRUCTURES AND ALGORITHMSAND IMPLEMENTING THEM. THE CLASS WILL MOSTLY CONSIST OF REAL-TIME TRAINING IN TEAMS SIMULATING A COMPETITION.
02340901.name: Workshop in Competitive Programming

02360001.about: this course will expose the students to the diverse research topics in the department and current research directions in order to assist in choosing a research topic and an advisor in graduate studies. the course will consist of one weekly lecture that will be given by faculty members in the department and is targeted to starting m.sc. students still without an advisor and undergraduate students with high gpa, at last stages of the degree, who are interested to continue to graduate studies in the department. lecturer approval required prior to registration. learning outcomes: by the end of the course the student: 1) will be acquainted with the various research areas in the department.  2) will possess tools in order to choose a research topic and an advisor for m.sc. studies.
02360001.name: Introduction to Departmental Research in Computer Science

02360002.about:
THIS COURSE IS DESIGNED TO GIVE UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN CS THE REQUISITE SKILLS TO GENERATE AND SCREEN EDEAS FOR THECREATION OF A NEW TECHNOLOGICAL VENTURE AND THEN PREPARE A BUSINESS PLAN FOR AN INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGY OF THEIR OWN DESIGN.
 THESE SKILLS INCLUDE THE ABILITY TO INCORPORATE INTO A FORMAL BUSINESS CASE ALL THE NECESSARY REQUIREMENTS, INCLUDING NEEDS IDENTIFICATION AND VALIDATION, BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL MODELS AND MARKET STRATEIES AND PLANS. STUDENTS WILL BE EXPECTED TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE IN: NEEDS IDENTIFICATION AND VALIDATION, DEVELOPING BSINESS MODELS, DESIGNING MARKETING PLANS AND MARKET ENTRY SSTRATEGIES AND C ONSTRUCTING FINANCIAL MODELS. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. DESIGN AN INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGICAL SYSTEM TO MEET DESIRED NEEDS.
 2. IDENTIFY FORMULATE ANS SOLVE ENGINEERING PROBLEMS. 
 3. FUNCTION ON MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEAMS IN THE CONTEXT OF AN ENGINEERING PROJECT. 
 4. ABILITY TO UNDERSTAND THE IMPACT OF ENGINEERING SOLUTIONS IN A GLOBAL AND SOCIETAL CONTEXT.
02360002.name: TOPICS IN COMPUTER SCIENCE INNOVATION

02360003.about: This course will introduce students to advanced data management algorithms for reliable decision making. The course will teach the students methods for handling different stages of the data-driven decision-making process, including data integration, cleaning and Investigation, to enable drawing sound conclusions from the given data. The course will provide theoretical knowledge and practical experience to draw conclusions from the data. The goal of the course is to learn how to address common data problems that can bias the conclusion, including missing data, dirty or inconsistent data, and the presence of biases. The course requires that the participants have successfully passed the database course. The course consists of weekly lectures and homework. LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:  1. DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN CODE AIMED AT IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF THE DATA.  2. TO K NOW WHICH FACTORS MAY BIAS THE RESULTS OF QUERIES OR APPLICATIONS THAT PROCESS THE DATA.  3. KNOW WHICH SOLU TIONS CAN BE USED TO OVERCOME FACTORS THAT MAY BIAS THE CONCLUSIONS.  4. TO LE ARN ADVANCED PROGRAMMING IN THE PYTHON LANGUAGE.
02360003.name: DATA MANAGEMENT ALGORITHMS FOR DECISION

02360004.about:
SINCE THEIR FIRST APPEARANCE BACK IN 2017 IN THE PAPER "ATTENTION IS ALL YOU NEED" VASWANI ET AL. 2017! TRANSFORMERS BECAME THE STANDARD MODEL FOR ALMOST EVERY TASK IN DEEP LEARNING. THIS COURSE WILL COVER THE COMPONENTS THAT THE TRANSFORMERS IS COMPRISED OF AND THE PART EACH ONE PLAYS IN THE COMPLETE FUNCTION OF THE MODEL AS WELL AS ADVANCED/SOTA TRANSFORMER-BASED METHODS FOR VARIOUS TASKS. TOPICS SUCH AS REINFORCEMENT LEARNING! MULTI-MODALITY! VISION! IN-CONTEXT LEARNING (ICL) WILL BE COVERED FROM THE VIEWPOINT OF TRANSFORMERS AS WELL AS ARCHITECTURE-SPECIFIC TOPICS SUCH AS SPARSITY AND SCALABILITY! ARCHITECTURE OPTIMIZATION! AS WELL AS ENCODER-D ECODER VS. ENCODER-ONLY VS. DECODER-ONLY.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDETNS WILL BE ABLE TO/KNOW:
 1. REVIEW THE FUNDAMENTALS OF DEEP LEARNING AND EXPLAIN THE DIFFERENT PROS AND CONS OF DIFFERENT MODELS IN THE CONTEXT OF THE TRANSFORMER AND ATTENTION IN GENERAL.
 2. TRAIN VARIOUS DEEP NEURAL NETWORKS AND ANALYZE THE VARIOUS CHALLENGES THAT ARISE WHEN USING THEM.
 3. CONSTRUCT/MODIFY TRANSFORMER-BASED NETWORKS AND APPLY THEM ON DIFFERENT DOMAINS._
 4. EXPLAIN THE REASONS FOR SUCCESS/FAILURE IN A NETWORK FROM A
02360004.name: TOPICS IN TRANSFORMERS AND ATTENTION

02360005.about:
SEARCH.
 3. CAPABLE OF CRITICALLY ASSESSING STUDIES FOCUSED ON RESOURCE ALLOCATION AND OPTIMIZATION.
 4. DISTILLING AND EFFECTIVELYPRESENTING KEY FINDINGS FROM CONTEMPORARY RESEARCH ARTICLES.
02360005.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN OPERATING SYSTEMS

02360006.about:
ACT USING DIFFERENT ALGORITHMS.
 2. USE A VARIETY OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE APPROACHES TO MODEL SINGLE-AGENT SETTINGS.
 3. USE A FRAMEWORK OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE APPROACHES TO MODEL MULTIPLE AGENT SETTINGS. 
 4. PRACTICALLY IMPLEMENT AI TOOLS IN ROBOTIC APPLICATIONS.
02360006.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN AI AND ROBOTICS

02360007.about:
INCLUDING CRITICAL ANALYSIS AND RE-IMPLEMENTATION OF KEY ALGORITHMS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. GAIN UNDERSTANDING OF THE CHALLENGES AND SOLUTIONS IN 3D COMPUTER VISION RESEARCH. 
 2. GAIN FAMILIARITY WITH IMPLEMENTATIONS OF LEARNING-BASED APPROACHES FOR 3D REPRESENTATIONS! INCLUDING TECHNIQUES AND ALGORITHMS USED IN THE FIELD. 
 3) CAPABLEOF CRITICALLY ASSESSING STUDIES FOCUSED ON SEMANTIC UNDERSTANDING OF 3D OBJECTS AND SCENES! 3D RECONSTRUCTION! AND GENERATIVE MODELS._
 4. ADEPT AT DISTILLING AND EFFECTIVELY PRESENTING KEY FINDINGS FROM CONTEMPORARY RESEARCH ARTICLES IN 3D COMPUTER VISION! USING BOTH WRITTEN AND ORAL COMMUNICATION SKILLS.__
02360007.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN COMPUTER VISION

02360008.about:
THE COURSE AIMS TO ALLOW STUDENTS TO DEVELOP HARDWARE/SOFTWARE CO-DESIGN SYSTEMS TO SUPPORT ADVANCED ALGORITHMS IN MACHINE LEARNING! ML FOR HARDWARE SECURITY! AND RISC-V BASED SYSTEMS. THE COURSE FOCUSES ON ITS MULTIDISCIPLINARY ASPECTS! IT COMBINES A FEW FRONTALLECTURES WITH HANDS-ON DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES. AT THE END OF THE CLASS! EACH STUDENT (OR COUPLE OF STUDENTS) WILL DEVELOP AN INDIVIDUAL PROJECT AND WRITE A PROJECT COURSE. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OFTHE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL  ABLE TO:
 1. DEEP UNDERSTANDING OF RISCV'S STRUCTURE.
 2. KNOWLEDGE OF ACCELERATOR DEVELOPMENT.
 3. USE OF ADVANCED ALGORITHMS IN MACHINE LEARNING FOR THE PURPO SE OF SOLVING ENGINEERING PROBLEMS SUCH AS HARDWARE SECURITY.
02360008.name: TOPICS IN AL FOR HARDWARE SECURITY

02360009.about:
THIS COURSE WILL INTRODUCE STUDENTS TO ADVANCED LINUX KERNEL DEVELOPMENT! USING INTERNAL KERNEL APIS AND DATA STRUCTURES. THE COURSE WILL TEACH STUDENTS ABOUT THE KERNEL S MAIN COMPONENTS! AND IT WILL ALLOW THEM TO MAKE NONTRIVIAL CHANGES! PRIMARILY FOCUSING ON DEVICE DRIVERS. THE COURSE WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON! PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE IN CURRENT OPEN SOURCE CODE DEVELOPMENT USING SOFTWARE ENGINEERING TOOLS AND PRINCIPLES! INCLUDING KERNEL DEBUGGING! WORKING WITH GIT! STRUCTURING A SUGGESTED SOFTWARE CHANGE AS A LOGICAL SEQUENCE OF PATCHES THAT COMPRISE A PATCHSET! CONDUCTING CODE REVIEWS!AND PRESENTING A SUGGESTED PROJECT TO MULTIPLE INTERESTED PARTIES. TH E COURSE REQUIRES THAT PARTICIPANTS HAVE SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED THE BASIC OPERATING SYSTEMS COURSE. THE COURSE CONSISTS OF WEEKLY LECTURES AND TUTORIALS. THE OVERALL GRADE IS BASED ON A NUMBER OF PRACTICAL ASSIGNMENTS AND A PROJECT! WHICH WILL BE PRESENTED AT THEEND OF THE SEMESTER TO THE COURSE STAFF. THE LECTURES AND TUTORIALS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN ENGLISH. THE COURSE FULFILLS ONE PROJECT REQUIREMENT FOR UNDERGRADUATES.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. DEVELOP AND MAINTAIN NONTRIVIAL L
02360009.name: TOPICS IN LINUX KERNEL DEVELOPMENT

02360010.about:
THIS COURSE WILL INTRODUCE STUDENTS TO ADVANCED DATA MANAGEMENT ALGORITHMS FOR RESPONSIBLE DATA MANAGEMENT. THE COURSE WILL TEACH STUDENTS TECHNIQUES TO HANDLE DIFFERENT PROBLEMS CONCERNING RESPONSIBLE DATA MANAGEMENT! INCLUDING BIAS REMOVAL! FAIRNESS AND PRIVACY. DURING THE CURSE! THE STUDENTS WILL GET TO KNOW THE MOST RECENT PUBLISHED PAPERS IN THE FILED OF RESPONSIBLE DATA MANAGEMENT. THE OVERREACHING GOAL IS TO LEARN HOW TO HANDLE COMMON DATA ISSUES THAT MAY OBSCURE THE CONCLUSION! OR LEAD TO UNFAIR RESULT. THE COURSEREQUIRES THAT PARTICIPANTS HAVE SUCCESSFULLY COMPLETED THE BASIC DATABASES COURSE. THE COURSE CONSISTS OF WEEKLY LECTURES GIVEN BY S TUDENTS. THE FINAL GRADE IS DETERMINED BY ATTENDANCE! ACTIVE PARTICIPATION IN CLASS DISCUSSIONS AND PERFORMANCE IN ASSIGNED LECTURE. 
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. READ AND PRESNT AN ACADEMIC PAPER IS A CLEAR AND CONCISE MANER.
 2. TO KNOW WHICH FACTORS MY BIAS THE RESULTS OR EXPOSE PRIVATE DATA. 
 3. KNOW WHICH SOLUTIONS CAN BE USED TO OVERCOME FACTORS THAT BIAS THE CONCLUSIONS AND ENSURE THAT PRIVACY IS PRESERVED.
02360010.name: TOPICS IN SEMINAR ON RESPONSIBLE DATA

02360011.about:
THIS COURSE WILL INTRODUCE STUDENTS TO ADVANCED ALGORITHMS FOR DYNAMIC GRAPHS. THIS ACTIVE RESEARCH AREA FOCUSES ON QUESTIONS OF THE FOLLOWING FLAVOR: HOW QUICKLY CAN WE SOLVE ALGORITHMIC PROBLEMS ON GRAPHS THAT CHANGE SLOWLY OVER TIME. IN PARTICULAR! HOW MUCH FASTER THAN RECOMPUTING FROM SCRATCH AFTER EVERY CHANGE IN THE GRAPH. THIS QUESTION IS CENTRAL TO PROBLEMS WITH INPUT THAT CHANGES OVER TIME (FOR EXAMPLE! IN GPS APPLICATIONS! CLOSURE AND OPENING OF ROADS CHANGES THE ROAD NETWORK)! BUT IS ALSO KEY TO SPEEDING UP ALGORITHMS WITH STATIC INPUTS (IN MUCH THE SAME WAY THAT BASIC DATA STRUCTURES CAN BE USED TO SPEED UP OTHER CLASSIC ALGORITHMS). THE COURSE S OBJECTIVE IS TO EXPOSE STUDENTS TO TECHNIQUES AND RESULTS FOR BASIC PROBLEMS IN THE FIELD (SUCH AS MATCHING! SHORTEST PATHS! MINIMUM SPANNING TREES! ETC). AS PART OF THE COURSE! THE STUDENTS WILL ALSO BE EXPOSES TO CENTRAL TOOLS IN ALGORITHM DESIGN AND THEORY OF COMPUTER SCIENCE MORE BROADLY THAT ARE RELEVANT TO THE COURSE TOPIC! INCLUDING LINEAR PROGRAMMING AND DUALITY! RANDOMIZED ALGORITHMS AND THE MULTIPLICATIVE WEIGHT UPDATE METHOD. THE COURSE EVALUATION WILL BE BASED ON HOMEWORK AND A FINAL PROJECT.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES:
02360011.name: TOPICS IN DYNAMIC GRAPH ALGORITHMS

02360012.about:
DISTRIBUTED SYSTEMS SOLVE TASKS THAT INVOLVE SEVERAL PROCESSING UNITS OR SERVERS.
