 3. understand the principles of planning metabolomics experiments using diverse- analytical instrumentatio n.
 4. gain hands on experience in seahorse assays data analysis.
 5. gain hands-on experience in mass spectrometry metabolomics data analysis.
02780958.name: INTRODUCTION TO METABOLOMICS

02780959.about:
THIS COURSE WILL CONVEY AND EXPLAIN ADVANCED PRINCIPLES IN COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY. FIRST! ADVANCED BIOSTATISTICAL CONCEPTS WILL BE TAUGHT! INCLUDING RANDOM VARIABLES! HYPOTHESIS TESTING! PRIORS! BAYESIAN FRAMEWORK! ETC. WE WILL THEN MOVE TO ANALYZING HIGH-DIMENSIONAL BIG DATA METHODS. NEXT! WE WILL DISCUSS BIOLOGICAL NETWORKS! AND THEN MOVE TO LEARNING: SUPERVISED! INCLUDING CLASSIFICATION ALGORITHMS! AND UNSUPERVISED! STARTING WITH SHALLOW! SUCH AS CLUSTERING! AND FINISHING WITH DEEP LEARNING! AND THE THE PRINCIPLES UNDERLYING SOME OF THE COMMON ALGORITHMS USED AND THEIR APPLICATION TO BIOLOGICALLY-DRIVEN QUESTIONS.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF TH E COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1.  UNDERSTAND THE PRINCIPLES UNDERLYING ALGORITHMS AND DATA ANALYSIS METHODOLOGIES THAT ARE COMMONLY USED IN COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY.
 2. UNDERSTAND WHEN AND HOW TO USE THE DIFFERENT METHODS IN ORDER TO SOLVE DIFFERENT PROBLEMS IN COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY.
 3. APPLY THE METHODS LEARNED TO MULTI-DIMENSIONAL BIOLOGICAL DATA OF DIFFERENT TYPES.
02780959.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN COMPUTATIONAL BIOLOGY

02780960.about:
proper use of artificial intelligence tools from an ethical and academic perspective! artificial intelligence literacy! defining the research question through templates and with the assistance of artificial intelligence tools! literature review in the age of artificial intelligence! effective prompt writing! using artificial intelligence tools for reading! understanding! summarizing and editing information! using citation management software in conjunction with artificial intelligence tools! artificial intelligence tools for analyzing research results and promoting its dissemination.
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will:
 1. u nderstand the importance and ways to use artificial intelligence tools responsibly and ethically._
 2. accurately define the research question using templates and with the assistance of artificial intelligence tools.
 3. conduct an efficient and comprehensive literature review by integrating databases and artificial intelligence tools.
 4. formulate prompts precisely and effectively to obtainoptimal results from artificial intelligence tools.
 5. use artificial intelligence tools for reading! understanding! editing and analyzin
02780960.name: UTILIZING ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

02780962.about:
IN THIS COURSE SELECTED LECTURES WILL BE GIVEN BY LEADING SCIENTISTS IN THE FIELD OF DEVELOPMENTAL BIOLOGY FROM OUR FACULTY, OTHER FACULTIES FROM ISRAEL AND FROM ABROAD.IN ADDITION, EACH STUDENT WILL BE REQUIRED TO PRESENT THEIR RESEARCH PROJECT IN THE FORMAT OF 30 MINUTES LECTURE.
 LEARNING OUTCOMES: AT THE END OF THE COURSE THE STUDENTS WILL BE ABLE TO:
 1. EXPERIENCING WITH SELECTED TOPICSIN CUTTING EDGE RESEARCH IN DEVELOPMENTAL BIOLOGY.
 2. KNOW DIFFERENT MODELS OF ORGANISMS THAT SERVE FOR RESEARCH IN DEVELOPMENTAL BIOLOGY, THE ADVANTAGES AND DISADVANTAGES.
 3. KNOW INNOVATIVE RESEARCH TECHNOLOGIES THAT ARE USED IN DEVELOPMENTAL BIOLOGY RESEARCH:  LABELLING AND TRACKING CELLS IN LIVING ORGANISM DURING DEVELOPMENT, FUNCTIONAL SCREENING TO IDENTIFY GENES INVOLVED IN EMBRYOGENESIS ETC.
02780962.name: TOPICS IN DEVELOPMENTAL BIOLOGY 2

03140003.about: Average stress and strain. Ductile and brittle materials. Failure of materials. Stress and strain at a point. Stress and strain transformations. State of stress in 3-D. Generalized Hooke's Law. True stress and strain. Yield criteria - Von Mises. Tresca. Beam theory. Torsion. Boundary value problem.
03140003.name: Introduction to Solid Mechanics

03140006.about: Correlation between microstructure and properties of materials. Analysis of crystallographic structure: real space and reciprocal space, X-ray diffraction, electron diffraction. Optical microscopy: images formation, resolution and contrast, phase contrast. Electron microscopy: image formation, resolution and contrast in TEM and SEM. Chemical analysis: energy and wavelength dispersive spectroscopy, electron energy loss spectroscopy, Auger, XPS.
03140006.name: Microstructural Characterization of Mate

03140009.about: Structure and properties  of materials: crystallography, defects, testing of mechanical properties, optical metallography, fracture, creep, fatigue, environmental stability. Engineering materials and processes: phase diagrams, solidification and growth, ceramics,polymers, composites, thermal processing, aging.
03140009.name: Materials Laboratory

03140011.about: Interatomic bonding, structure of crystalline solids, defects in crystal structure. Diffusion. Mechanical properties: elastic deformation, plastic deformation, mechanical failure. Phase diagrams, phase transformations, thermal processing. Engineering materials: metal alloys, ceramics, polymers, composites. Environmental stability of materials. Thermal properties. Electrical properties: conduction, semiconductors, insulators.  Optical properties.
03140011.name: Fundamentals of Materials Science and Engineering

03140014.about: Metallic biomedical materials. Ceramic, glass - ceramic biomedical materials. Biostable and biodegradable polymeric biomedical materials. The host body response and biocompatibility. Surface properties and their impact on the interaction with the biological environment. Extra - cellular matrix. Immunology and immune reactions to biomedical materials. Infections related to biomedical materials. Mucoadhesive systems. Tissue engineering. Cellular therapy and immunoisolation.
03140014.name: Biomedical Materials

03140016.about: introduction to solidworks fundamentals. two-dimensional (2d) modeling. restrictions and geometric relations. three-dimensional (3d) modeling. creating assemblies. creating detail drawings and part assembly drawings in materials engineering applications.
03140016.name: COMPUTER-AIDED MATERIAL ENG. GRAPHIC

03140100.name: Principles and Learning Methods of Ma.En

03140124.about: selected advanced topics in materials engineering and processes, presented by a guest lecturer. the syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordance with the field of speciality of the lecturer.
03140124.name: Advanced Topics in Mater. Engineering 1

03140126.about: selected advanced topics in materials engineering and processes, presented by a guest lecturer. the syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordance with the field of speciality of the lecturer.
03140126.name: Advanced Topics in Mater. Engineering 2

03140150.about: PERIODIC CRYSTALS, RECIPROCAL LATTICE AND DIFFRACTION, BRILLOUIN ZONE, BLOCH THEOREM, FREE AND BOUND ELECTRON IN A SOLID, EFFECTIVEMASS, ENERGY BANDS, FERMI LEVEL AND SURFACE, ELECTRONIC CONDUCTION, DRUDE MODEL, SOMMERFELD MODEL, PHONONS, THERMAL PROPERTIES, SPECIFIC HEAT, DEBYE MODEL, NEARLY FREE ELECTRON APPROXIMATION, MAGNETISM.
03140150.name: SOLID STATE PHYSICS

03140309.about: Introduction: casting techniques, rapid solidification, cooling rate-microstructure relationships, Welding and Brazing techniques, Microstructure of the heat affectedzone (HAZ), zone refining, and crystal growth, powdwe metallurgy, sintering theory, liquid phase sintering, advanced powder technology, Sol-gel process, surface treatments, CVD and PVD, ion implantation, litography, metallization, doping of semiconductors, machining, plastic forming, glass products.
03140309.name: Materials Processing

03140311.about: Crystal structure of oxides, silicates, clays and other minerals, physico-chemical properties and composition of melts and glasses,melting and equilibrium in ceramic systems, solid state reactions, methods of preparation, production under pressure, hydro-plasticshaping, casting and cementation, shaping of glass, various shaping processes, mechanical and thermal properties and behavior at high temperatures.
03140311.name: Ceramics & Refractories

03140312.about: Definitions, polymerization mechanisms and processes, molecular weight, amorphous and semi-crystalline polymers. Thermal characteristics, viscoelasticity, mechanical properties, rheology, processing, selection of polymeric materials.
03140312.name: Introduction to Polymeric Materials

03140316.about: The structure of surfaces and surface finish, chemistry, physics and thermodynamics of solid surfaces. The testing of joints and their mechanical strength. Mechanical joining: seals, bolts and rivets. Principles of welding, ferrous and non-ferrous welding. Soldering and brazing processes. Diffusion bonding and ceramic-metal joints. Polymeric adhesives and glued joints. Selection of adhesives for metallic and non-metallic systems. Joints in high vacuum systems. Joints in microelectronic devices.
03140316.name: Joining Processes

03140532.about: Electrochemical and thermodynamic principles of corrosion processing: electrode potential, exchange current density, polarization, mixed-potential theory, corrosion cells, passivity.  Factors affecting corrosion rate.  Corrosion rate measurements, corrosion resistance of metals and alloys. Forms of corrosions: pitting corrosion, intergranular corrosion. Corrosion prevention:  Cathodic and Anodic protection. Surface treatments:  passivation and coatings.  Alteration of corrosion environment:  inhibitors, oxygen removal.  Materials selection and engineering design from corrosion point of view.
03140532.name: Electroch., Corrosion and Protection

03140535.about: Introduction, crystal structures and defects. Mechanical properties: stress-strain curves, elastic and plastic properties, ductile and brittle fracture, fracture toughness, fatigue, creep, phase diagrams, ferrous and non-ferrous alloys, heat treatments, ceramics,polymers composites, corrosion. Physical properties: thermal, electrical and optical properties.
03140535.name: Introduction to Materials Engineering

03140536.about: INTRODUCTION! CRYSTAL STRUCTURES AND DEFECTS. MECHANICAL PROPERTIES: STRESS-STRAIN CURVES! ELASTIC AND PLASTIC PROPERTIES! DUCTILE AND BRITTLE FRACTURE! FRACTURE TOUGHNESS! FATIGUE! CREEP! PHASE DIAGRAMS! FERROUS AND NON-FERROUS ALLOYS! HEAT TREATMENTS (TTT)! AGING! CERAMICS AND POLYMERS.
03140536.name: GNIREENIGNE SLAIRETAM OT NOITCUDORTNI

03150001.about: Characterization techniques: optical microscopy, transmission and scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction. Physical metallurgy: precipitation hardening and Phase diagrams. Mechanical behavior: powder metallurgy, effects of strain rate and  temperature, surface effects.
03150001.name: Advanced Materials Laboratory 1

03150002.about: Metallurgical processes: carburization of steels. Electronic materials: characteerization of silicon crystals, silicides in thin film. Ceramics: thermal shock resistance, fracture toughness by indentation technique. Composite: mechanical behaviour of composites. Polymers: crystallization from the melt.
03150002.name: Advanced Materials Laboratory 2

03150003.about: System classification, first law, second law, entropy, enthalpy, Helmholz and Gibbs free energies, thermodynamic potentials, ideal and non-ideal gases, solutions, Gibbs-Duham relations, activity, binary and ternary phase diagrams.
03150003.name: Thermodynamics of Materials

03150008.about: Relations between stress and strain. Fundamentals of plasticity. Defects in crystals. Interaction between dislocations. Interactionbetween dislocations and other defects. Yield stress. Work-hardening- ductile and brittle fracture. Fracture toughness. Mechanical behavior of polymers and ceramics. Fatigue and residual stresses, creep. Stress-relaxation.
03150008.name: Mechanical Behavior of Materials

03150012.about: Review and classification of materials, review of materials processing methods, solving materials selection problems applying Ashby's approach, application of Edupack software for materials selection, economic and environmental aspects, standards and regulations,studies.
03150012.name: Materials Selection

03150014.about: Specific subjects on properties of materials and processes will be suggested by faculty members in various fields: metals, ceramics, electronic materials, polymers, materials in energy conversion, etc.
03150014.name: Advanced Project in Materials Engineering

03150016.about: Fundamentals of semiconductors (rev.) free carriers, energy levels, mobility, conductivity, lifetime. Continuity and flow equationsfor carriers. Metal-semiconductor contact, rectifying and ohmic contact. P-n junction, diodes. Bipolar transistor. MOS transistor. Principles of integrated circuits.
03150016.name: Semiconductor Devices for Materials Eng.

03150017.about: Electrochemical and thermodynamical fundamentals of coating processes. Polarization and kinetics of electrode processes. Anode and cathode reactions. Conversion coating processes, galvanization. Electrodeposition. Chemical coating. Anodization. Measurements of properties of coatings.
03150017.name: Finishing Processes & Electrolytic Coat

03150018.about: Classification of materials: metallic, ceramic and plastic. Biomaterials. Defensive processes of the body, tissues' response to implants, biocompatibility. The use of implants to replace soft and hard tissues. Biodegradability, adhesives and medical cements. Recent developments: shape memory, localized applications.
03150018.name: Biomaterials

03150025.about: The student will continue his research from the course "Advanced Materials Engineering Project" (1), together with deeper insight into the research, and will report on his work and findings by written report and seminar.
03150025.name: Advanced Materials Engineering Project 2

03150027.about: Reliability theory: quantification of reliability, graphical modeling. Failure mechanism in VLSI devices: ESD, electromigration, hot electrons, radiation effects. Reliability statistics and accelerated testing, acceleration models. Building reliability into the device, reliability element in the design phases, production and assembly, screening and comparison of field data with laboratory experimentation.
03150027.name: Reliability of Microelectronic Device

03150030.about: Electrical conductivity in metals and semiconductors: band structure, equilibrium carrier concentration, generation - recombination, defects and their effect on electrical properties. Junctions: metal semiconductor, p-n, hetrojunction. Photovoltaic effect, photo-conductivity, solar cells. Dielectric materials: polarizability, capacitance, dielectric constant, dielectric strength.  Optical properties: absorption, luminiscence and lasers in semiconductors, absorption, transmission, reflection in thin films.
03150030.name: Properties of Electronic Materials

03150031.about: Crystalline symmetry and physical properties. Ferroelectetc properties, dielectric materials, piesoelectric and electro-optic materials, ionic conductivity in oxides, insulators. Semi-conductors. magnetic ceramics and ferrites, ceramic transducers and detectors, materials for solid-state lasers, multi-layer capacitors.
03150031.name: Electronic Ceramics

03150034.about: Advanced ceramics, classification, powder preparation and characterization, mixing, dry and semi-dry pressing, cold pressing, CIP and HIP, plastic forming, tape casting, green machining, sintering, densification, pressure sintering, reaction sintering, abrasive and chemical processing, quality control.
03150034.name: Processing of Advanced Ceramics

03150035.about: Independent research under supervision of the Technion faculty member in a specific subject (metals, ceramics, polymers, bio-materials, composites, etc.).
03150035.name: Materials Engineering Project-Optional

03150039.about: introduction: momentum transfer-fluids, fluid statics, fluids in motion: Lagrangian Eulerian, streamlines. Control volume approach.Laminar flow, poiseulle flow, differential approach: Navier Stokes. Bernouli. Dimensional analysis. Viscous flow: Reynolds number, Drag, boundary layer. Heat transfer - conduction, convection, radiation. Differential approach. Steady and unsteady state. Prandtl number, boundary layer. Mass transfer - diffusion. Differential approach. Steady and unsteady state. Convective Mass transfer. Schmidt number.
03150039.name: Momentum, Heat and Mass Transport for Materials Engineering

03150041.about: Optical absorption in solids. Excitons. Luminescence in solids. Absorption and emission in low dimensional solids. Absorption and emission in molecular materials. Optical processes in conjugated polymers. Color centers. Ions as emitting centers in solids.
03150041.name: Optical Phenomena in Materials

03150042.about: Introduction, classification of nanomaterials, cohesion, surface energy, fabrication of nanomaterials, lithography and nanolithography, characterisation of nano materials-spm and electron microscopy, properties of nanomaterials (band structure, electronic and optical ptoperties, mechanical properties), carbon nanotubes, semiconducting nanowires, applications of nanomaterials.
03150042.name: Introduction to Nanoscience and Nanotechnology

03150044.about: Optical properties of materials, and their structural origins, optical losses, refractive index and dispersion, thermo-and electro-optical coefficient, light transmission in crystals. Commonly used materials and fabrication processes. Characterization of optical properties. Applications: bulk materials for the visible and infra-red, optical coatings and filters, optical fibers, integrated optics.
03150044.name: Optical Materials

03150045.about: Crystal growth, epitaxial growth, thin films depositions of semiconductors. Diffusion and ion implantation, oxidation, dry etching,processes, efficiency and reliability of fabrication of processes.
03150045.name: Processes in Microelectronics Fabrication

03150046.about: This course introduces basic physics, materials, technology and modeling used in modern microelectronic packaging and assembly technology. The course covers the well established wire bond and flip-chip package technologies, materials and flows, as well as future trends and state of the art chip-scale packages and hybrid packages.
03150046.name: Intro. to Modern Vlsi Device Packaging

03150048.about: Introduction to biomineralization, basic definitions and mechanisms, nucleation and growth of biogenic crystals, short and long-range order, mechanical, magnetic and optical properties of biological materials, wetting of surfaces nature, self cleaning properties of plant leaves, current topics in the field.
03150048.name: Biomineralization and Biological Materials

03150049.about: Introduction to biomineralization, basic definitions and mechanisms, nucleation and growth of biogenic crystals, short and long-range order, mechanical, magnetic and optical properties of biological materials, wetting of surfaces in nature, self cleaning properties of plant leaves, current topics in the field.
03150049.name: Biomineralization and Bio. Materials

03150051.about: Fick's law. Diffusion coefficients. Diffusion equations. Experimental techniques. Atomic theory of diffusion. Random walk. Diffusion by vacancies and interstitials. Kirkendall effect, thermodynamic theory of diffusion. Darken analysis. Short circuit diffusion, etc.
03150051.name: Diffusion in Solids

03150052.about: Driving force for solid-state transformations, compositional changes, morphological changes. Homogeneous and heterogeneous nucleation, nucleation in the stress field. Massive transformations. Diffusional transitions. Precipitation. Coarsening, G.P. zones and metastable phases. Spinodal decomposition, etc.
03150052.name: Transformation Kinetics in Materials

03150053.about: Biomedical materials (biomaterials)-general introduction, biocompatibility, classification of biomaterials, biostable biomaterials,natural biodegradable biomaterials, synthetic biodegradable biomaterials, new technologies for synthesis and processing of biomaterials, injectable biomaterials without structural continuity, injectable biomaterials with structural continuity, drug delivery systems, self-assembly polymeric nanocarriers, mucoadhesive drug delivery systems, polymeric systems for the treatment of skin wounds.
03150053.name: Engineering of Polymeric Biomaterials

03150057.about: Introduction to computational methods for materials, accuracy and speed, practical limitations, size and boundary conditions, methods of calculating the first principles, the principle of variation, Hartree-Fook, configuration interaction, density functional theory, electronic density, Hohenberg-Kohn, approximations, molecular dynamics, empirical potentials, equations of motion, time step andmean accumulation, Monte-Carlo, thermal averaging, selection and use of materials engineering with these methods.
03150057.name: Introduction to Computational Mat. Sci.

03150058.about: Numerical vs. physical parameters in modeling materials, interpolation material potentials, root finding for dispersion relation ofmaterials, integration and differentiation for calculating flux in materials, solving ordinary differential equations, predictor - corrector algorithm. Molecular dynamics of materials and application for mechanical defects formation, application to thermodynamic laws and kinetics of diffusion in materials.
03150058.name: Computer Analysis Methods for Materials

03150059.about: how do materials become devices- this course discusses the basic functionality of materials: dielectric, magnetic and optical properties as well as how these properties originate from the material structure. finally, we will study the principles of various devices and technologies that are based on these properties (e.g. memory devices, mri and detectors- optical, magnetic, biological).
03150059.name: From Functional Materials to Devices

03150060.about: epitaxy and its importance in science and industry. epitaxial growth methods from the liquid, solid and vapor phases. the surface of solids in equilibrium in homo- and hetro-epitaxial layers, including shapes of crystals and surfaces, growth modes and misfit strain relaxation. step flow versus island growth. dynamics of the development of surface morphology at various growth regimes. growth instabilities. the effect of impurities and surfactants.
03150060.name: Epitaxy Fundementals: Surface Morphology

03150061.about: theoretical background on nanoscale and quantum electronics, charge transport in ballistic and diffusive systems. emphasis on 2-dimenstional (2d) electronics including conventional and  real  2d systems i.e. graphene, mos2, h-bn etc. van der waals heterostructures based on 2d materials.
03150061.name: 2D Materials Based Nanoelectrinics

03150062.about: mechanics of soft materials, polymers, and gels. large deformations, deformation gradient. volumetric deformation. relations between reference and deformed configurations. first piola-kirchhoff and true stress tensors. deviatoric and hydrostatic stress components.  stress under tension, shear, and hydrostatic pressure. objectivity. hyperelasticity and constitutive relations. solutions to representative problems with hyperelastic models.
03150062.name: Intro. to Mechanics of Soft Materials

03150200.about: CLASSIFYING POLYMERIC STRUCTURES SUCH AS BRUSH, STAR-SHAPE, COMB, WITH A PARTICULAR FOCUS ON CROSS-LINKED NETWORKS, NORTON-HOFF, MAXWELL AND KELVIN ELEMENTS, BURGERS MODEL, MOLECULAR MECHANISMS OF CREEP AND YOUNG S MODULUS IN POLYMER NETWORKS, FLORY-HUGGINS THEORY, CHARACTERIZATION OF NETWORK ARCHITECTURE BY NANOINDENTATION, RHEOLOGY, AND TEM USING FLORY AND STOCKMAYER AND DENG-ISAEV MODELS
03150200.name: MECH.OF POLIMER NETWORKS IN BIOLOG.MATER

03150202.about: COLLOIDAL SYNTHESIS OF NANOCRYSTALS! NUCLEATION! AND GROWTH! LA-MER MODEL. KINETIC AND THERMODYNAMIC CONTROL OVER SHAPE AND SIZE OFNCS. STERIC AND ELECTROSTATIC STABILIZATION OF COLLOIDAL SUSPENSIONS. OPTICAL AND ELECTRONIC PROPERTIES OF QUANTUM DOTS. QUANTUM CONFINEMENT AND SPECTROSCOPIC PROPERTIES! METALLIC NANOPARTICLES AND PLASMONS! SELF-ASSEMBLY OF QUANTUM DOTS.
03150202.name: COLLOIDAL QUANTUM DOTS

03150721.about: Chain configuration and conformation, solution thermodynamics and phase separation. Rubber elasticity and networks. Viscoelasticityand time-temperature superposition. Yield, failure and fracture. Anisotropy and liquid crystalline polymers.Chain growth copolymerization . Green: biopolymers, degradability, sustainability, structural hierarchy in polymeric systems.
03150721.name: Structure and Behavior of Polymers

03160000.about:
chain configuration and conformation. solution thermodynamics and phase separation. rubber elasticity and networks. viscoelasticityand time-temperature superposition. yield, failure, and fracture. anisotropy and liquid crystalline polymers. chain growth copolymerization. "green": biopolymers, degradability, sustainability. structural hierarchy in polymeric systems. learning outcoes: at the end of the course the students will know how to:
 1. find the appropriate solvents and dissolution conditions for a given polymer based on its macromolecular structure._
 2. develop models for the mechanical behavior of rubbers based on thermodynamic assumptions . 3. predict the mechanical behavior of polymers at various times based on their behavior at various temperatures._
 4. predict themechanical behavior of liquid crystalline polymers based on their anisotropy. 
 5. prevent polymer failure by identifying the yield-failure conditions 6. predict copolymer compositions based upon feed composition and reactivity ratios.__
 7. apply  green  concepts to reduce the impact of polymers on the environment. 
 8. apply structural hierarchy concepts to design advanced polymeric systems.
03160000.name: STRUCTURE AND BEHAVIOR OF POLYMERS

03160001.about:
mechanics of soft materials, polymers, and gels. large deformations, deformation gradient. volumetric deformation. relations between reference and deformed configurations. first piola-kirchhoff and true stress tensors. deviatoric and hydrostatic stress components.  stress under tension, shear, and hydrostatic pressure. objectivity. hyperelasticity and constitutive relations. solutions to representative problems with hyperelastic models._
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will know:
 1. analysis of problems related to non-linear mechanics.
 2. phrase the conditions required to achieve equilibrium in soft materials under different  loading states.__
 3. perform analyses of complex problems related to elastomers and soft tissues._
03160001.name: INFO. TO MECHANICS OF SOFT MATERIALS

03160240.about: CRYSTAL SYMMETRY IN REAL AND RECIPROCAL SPACES. STEREOGRAPHIC PROJECTION AND CRYSTALLOGRAPHIC CALCULATIONS. LOCAL SYMMETRY ELEMENTSAND POINT GROUPS. TRANSLATIONAL SYMMETRY AND BRAVAIS LATTICES. ATOMIC PACKING AND COORDINATION NUMBERS. COMBINATION OF LOCAL SYMMETRY ELEMENTS WITH TRANSLATIONS: SCREW AXES AND GLIDE PLANES. SPACE GROUPS. SYMMETRY AND PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF CRYSTALS.
03160240.name: Elements of Crystallography

03160241.about: main theory of symmetry, major crystal structures, the real structure of crystals, the geometry of the lattice and the reciprocal lattice, ctystal structure analysis. learning outcomes: the student should be able to work mathematically with crystal lattice in direct and recipocal space, be able to calculate directionce. lattice planes, orientations, angles and other geometrical relationship, to be familiar with all bravais lattice types, point groups, symmetry operators and selected space groups, be able to perforf tensortransformations and calculations of physical properties and symmetries.
03160241.name: Fundamentals of Crystallography

03160243.about: basicscattering processes for x-rays and neutrons, neutron sources, synchrotron sources, neutron diffractometers, applications of netron diffraction, synchrotron diffractometers, applications using synchrotron diffraction ,texture measurements, in-situ methods, time resolved methods, single crystal diffraction, micro-laue diffraction, large-scale structures, inelastic scattering of neutrons and x-ray, coherent beam x-ray methods, phonon dispersion measurements, diffusion in solids, tunneling states, amorphous structures, polarization analysis, magnetism, thin films.
03160243.name: Neutron and Synchrotron Instrumentation

03160244.about: magnetic structures and materials, magnetic interactions in nanolayered structures, thin film magnetism and domains, nanoscale magnetism and interface coupling, exchange bias materials, supermagnetism in nanostructured materials, scattering theory and born approximation, x-ray reflectivity, grazing incidence small angle scattering, neutron scattering and polarized neutron reflectivity (pnr), interface scattering theory, neutron reflectometers, modes of pnr in research.
03160244.name: Magnetic Properties of Thin Films

03180020.about:
introduction to molecular electronics, advanced methods to fabricate molecular junctions: single layer molecular junction, transport mechanisms in nanoscale: tunneling vs hopping, basic principle of molecular conduction, analytical model for molecular junctions, quantifying molecular structure-tunneling conductance relationships, conductance switching in molecular junctions through conformational changes, molecular switcher, molecular rectifier, molecular transistors, challenge and current focus in molecular electronics.learning outcomes: 
 1) understanding the experimental methods, theoretical basis, device fabrication, basic working mechanism of de vices of molecular electronics.
 2) exposure to the cutting-edge research progress and updated knowledge about this area.
 3) understanding the importance of the research of nanoelectronics and its basic research methods.
03180020.name: EXPERIMENTAL MOLECULAR ELECTRONICS

03180021.about:
introduction to extreme conditions.
 experimental techniques to probe materials under extreme conditions.
 structure and physical properties under pressure.
 phase diagrams and thermodynamics under extreme conditions.
 mechanical properties and equation of state of materials under extreme conditions.
 melting of materials under extreme conditions.
 high-pressure chemistry and materials science.
 synthesis of materials under extreme conditions.
 response of materials under shock conditions.
 energetic materials and detonation.
 the importance of stress/strain in technology.
 effect of extreme conditions on geoscience related materials.
 learning outcome s:
 he aim of this course will be twofold: a) introduce to students how material properties are affected by extreme thermodynamic conditions, ranging from high axial strain, due to substrate mismatch, to shock/detonation events that induce extreme pressure and temperature conditions and b) how we can use extreme conditions to synthesize novel materials with outstanding physicochemical properties.
03180021.name: MATERIALS UNDER EXTREME CONDITIONS

03180101.about: pore generation - conceptual approaches: macromolecular design, self assembly, solution-separation, solid assembly and templating, liquid assembly and templating. porosity - investigative approaches: intrusive, non-intrusive, imaging. porosity - impact on polymers: mechanical behavior, applications. learning outcomes: 1. identify the size scales and the structural features of polymer systems.2. appreciate the advantages of polymers as porous materials. 3. understand the different synthetic strategies. 4. apply the appropriate characterization techniques and interpret the results. 5. predict the effects of polymers porosity upon the mechanical behavior . 6. describe the utilization polymers in a variety of applications.
03180101.name: Porous Polymers

03180119.about: The student will prepare an extended term paper, under the supervision of a faculty member. The term paper will be submitted, afteradvisor's approval, as partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Engineering in Materials Engineering.
03180119.name: Advanced Seminar in Materials Engineering

03180124.about:
Selected advanced topics in Materials Engineering and Processes, presented  by a guest lecturer.
 The syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordonce with the field of speciality of the lecturer.
03180124.name: Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering

03180126.about: Selected advanced topics in materials engineering and processes, presented by a guest lecturer. The syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordance with the field of speciality of the lecturer.
03180126.name: Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering 2

03180127.about: Selected advanced topics in materials engineering and processes, presented by a guest lecturer. The syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordance with the field of speciality of the lecturer. Spring Semester 2017: Microelctronic Materials and Processes for Memory Applications.
03180127.name: Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering 3

03180128.about: selected advanced topics in materials engineering and processes, presented by a guest lecturer. the syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordonce with the field of speciality of the lecturer
03180128.name: Advanced Topics in Materials Engineering

03180129.about: selected advanced topics in materials engineering and processes, presented by a guest lecturer. the syllabus will be determined before the semester in which the course will be given and in accordonce with the field of speciality of the lecturer.
03180129.name: Advanced Topics in Matrials Eng.1

03180130.about:
INTRODUCTION TO COMPUTATIONAL MATERIALS SCIENCE, EXAMPLES OF DENSITY FUNCTIONAL THEORY USAGE IN MATERIALS SCIENCE, FUNCTIONALS AND ELECTRON INTERACTIONS IN QUANTUM MECHANICS, DENSITY FUNCTIONAL THEORY CALCULATIONS FOR SIMPLE SOLIDS AND SURFACES, EQUILIBRIUM STRUCTURES AND VIBRATIONS OF MATERIALS, ELASTIC PROPERTIES, BAND STRUCTURES AND PHOTOELECTRON SPECTROSCOPY, DIELECTRIC FUNCTION AND OPTICAL SPECTRA, DENSITY FUNCTIONAL THEORY FOR MAGNETIC MATERIALS. LEARNING OUTCOMES:
 THE COURSE WILL GIVE TOOLS TO CRITICALLY INTERPRETRESULTS FROM DENSITY FUNCTIONAL THEORY THAT ARE REPORTED IN THE LITERATURE. MOREOVER, THE COURSE WILL PROVIDE ABILITY TO PERFORM DEN SITY FUNCTIONAL THEORY CALCULATIONS THROUGH HANDS-ON EXERCISES.
03180130.name: QUANTUM MODELING OF MATERIALS

03180131.about: RESEARCH TOPICS IN ADVANCED ENGINEERING SCIENCE AS DETERMINED BY THE LECTURER. DETAILED BY SYLLABUS AND LEARNING OUTCOMES WILL BE PUBLISHED BEFORE THE BEGINNING OF EACH SEMESTER IN WHICH THE COURSE WILL BE GIVEN.
03180131.name: ADVANCED TOPICS IN MATERIALS ENG. 5

03180221.about: Introduction. Surface analysis by means of electron beams: Electron diffraction (LEED, RHEED), Auger electron spectroscopy, electron ion beams: Ion scattering, Rutherford back scattering (RBS), channeling, sputtering, SIMS (Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry). Surface analysis by means of photons: X-Ray photoemission Spectroscopy (XPS), Ultra-Violet Photoemission Spectroscopy (UPS). Atomic resolution surface microscopy: Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM), Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM).
03180221.name: Structure and Composition of Solid Surfaces

03180222.about: ion beam analysis(iba) introduction, rutherford backscattering spectroscopy (rbs), channelling, nuclear reaction analysis, narrow resonance depth profiling, ion induced x-rays and low energy iba , iba damage, iba data analysis software, iba microscopy, iba aplications, ion beams for surface modification. learning outcomes: understanding of the use of ion beams produced by accalerators for near surface region analysis and modifications - knowledge of the physics, the tools, and how to use them for various applications.
03180222.name: Ion Assisted Surface Analysis

03180319.about: Static microstructure: interface energy and stresses. Equilibrium shape of interfaces, Wulff and  plots. Facetting and roughening phase transitions. Movement of interfaces. Grain boundary migration in solid solutions. Solute drag theory. Grain boundary migration in two-phase alloys. Zener drag theory. Role of anisotropy in Zener drag. migration of triple junctions. Recrystallization. Normal vs. abnormal grain growth. Hillert theory. Overview of computer simulations. Grain growth in multicomponent solids. Diffusion inducedmicrostructure evolution. Discontinuous solid state reactions. Evolution of microstructure in thin films and multilayers.
03180319.name: Physical Fundamentals of Microstructure Evolution

03180320.about: Gibbsian approach to interface thermodynamics. Interface excesses. Thermodynamic models of interfaces. Chemical potential and activity of components in interface layers. Composition of interface layers. Segregation isotherms. Grain boundary diffusion. Fisher model: basic equations. Evaluation of the grain boundary diffusivity from experimental data. The effect of segregation on grain boundarydiffusion. Diffusion along interphase boundaries. Thin film diffusion. Reactive diffusion in interfaces. Surface diffusion. Mullinsequation. Interface instability.
03180320.name: Thermodynamics and Kinetics of Interfaces

03180321.about: Entropy and its components.  The statistical meaning of thermodynamic potential.  Equilibrium and stability. Lyapunov's criterion. Le Chatelier's principle. Thermodynamics of solutions and alloys.  Order-disorder reactions. The Landau theory of ordering. Thermodynamics of irreversible processes.  The Onsager relations. Entropy production.  The role of large fluctuations, relaxation and diffusion. criteria.
03180321.name: Advanced Topics in Thermodynamics

03180336.about: TPC diagrams.  The stability of structure and the driving forces for phase transitions - temperature, pressure, electric and magnetic fields.  Classification of phase transformations.  Recrystallization. Polymorphic changes and massive transformations.  Martensitic transformations.  Order-disorder reactions and Landau's theory. Precipitation from solid solution. Eutectoid transformations. spinodal decomposition.  Phase growth in diffusion couples and the Stefan problem. Glass-metal transitions.
03180336.name: Phase Transformations in Metals and Alloys

03180337.about: Fick's laws. The mathematics of diffusion.   Atomic mechanisms  of diffusion. Random walk and correlation effects. Experimental methods.  Self-diffusion. Solute diffusion. Thermodynamics of diffusion. Chemical diffusion in alloys and the Kirkendall effect. Diffusion and epitxoial stresses. Electro-and thermo-migration. Grain-boundary diffusion. Surface diffusion. Diffusion in amorphous alloys.
03180337.name: Diffusion and Mass Transfer in Solids

03180525.about: Introduction, Structure of Transmission Electron Microscope. Specimen preparation techniques.  Image formation, diffraction patterns, crystallographic basis. Kinematic theory of electron diffraction. Identification and characterization of phases by electron diffraction pattern. Kinematic theory of image contrast. Dinamic theory of image contrast. Identification and characterization of structural defects. Theory of phase contrast. Lattice image. Combination of other analytical techniques with TEM.
03180525.name: Transmission Electron Microscopy

03180526.about: X-ray sources, photon scattering from electrons, coherency, fluotescence, absorption, filtration. Emission spectra, principles of x-ray spectroscopy.  Scattering from atoms, dispersion correction and inelastic scattering. Scattering from clusters of atoms, structure factors. Diffraction from crystals, kinematic and dynamic theories. Ewald construction, Laue equation and Bragg's law. Width andintensity of diffraction lines from small crystals. Single crystal methods.   Powder diffactometry. Line-broadening. Structure determination and refinement. Qualitative and quantitative phase analysis. Texture,  thin films and residual stresses.
03180526.name: X-Ray Diffraction

03180529.about: Electron-matter interaction, secondary electrons, backscattered electrons, electron scattering mechanisms, photon emission. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM): electron sources, principle of image formation, electrooptic of scanning beam, signal to noise ratio, contrast and resolution, signal processing, materials surface analysis. X-ray spectroscopy, wavelength dispersive spectroscopy, energy dispersive spectroscopy. Materials composition analysis. The course includes a laboratory.
03180529.name: Analytical Scanning Electron Microscopy

03180530.about: mechanics of polymers and gels, micro-structure of polymers. the concept of entropy, free energy, reversible processes configurations of polymer chains:  freely-jointed chains model, freely-rotating chains model, worm-like chains model .microscopically motivated model for a polymer network with gaussian chains. the lock-up stretch phenomenon and finite chain extensibility.  analysis of the large deformation respnose of a polymer chain according to the freely-jointed chain model. integration from the chain to the network level: 3-chain model, 8-chain model. behavior of polymers under uniaxial and bi-axial extension, pure shear. sources of error in the a bove models. gels - entropy and enthalpy of mixing, chemical potential, the swelling process. learning outcomes: the course will familiarize the students with the different mechanisms that enable deformations in polymers and emphasize the relation between the microstructural arrangement of polymer networks and their macroscopic response. the students will learn the basic models that describe the response of polymers under different loading conditions and understand the influence of key micro-structural parameters on the macroscopic r
03180530.name: Thermodynamics and Mechanics of Polymers

03180532.about:
introduction: the thermoelectric (te) effect and its physical foundations and applications. thermodynamics of te energy conversion and devices. the kelvin relations. electron and thermal transport phenomena: microscopic and macroscopic approaches. the near-equilibrium approximation. the boltzmann transport theory. development of electron and thermal transpot coefficients. the seebeck and peltier coefficients. the lorenz number. the landauer formalism for representaion of transport phenomena. lattice thermal conductivity. the callaway model for lattice thermal conductivity and phonon scattering mechanisms in solids. the role of lattice defects and low-d imensionality structures. metrology of electron and thermal transport. classification of te materials and characteristics: chalcogenides, oxides, and materials having complex crystal structures.
 learning outcomes at the end of the course the stuents wiked to be 1. familiar with thermoelectric (te) phenomena and how to will know: for energy conversion.  2. be familiar with the microscopic andmacroscopic mechanisms responsible for charge and heat transport in crystalline materials. 3. know how to utilize different approaches represen
03180532.name: Charge and Heat Transport in Materials

03180541.about: Electron theory of solid surfaces. Quantum mechanics of the tunneling effect. Scanning tunneling microscopy (STM): principles of operation. tunneling spectroscopy. Scanning force microscopy (STM). Contact and non-contact operation modes. Electrostatic and magnetic force microscopies. Scanning near field optical microscopy (SNOM).principles of dedicated depth-sensing nanoindentation. contact of two elastic solids (hertz problem). Oliver-pharr method. Nanolithography. measurement of the mechanical properties of thin films. Nanotribology.
03180541.name: Scanning Probe Microscopy Fundemental Characterization, Nanofabrication

03180600.about: Polarization mechanisms, theories relating the molecular quantities to the macroscopic ones, complex permitivity, relaxations, resonance, dielectric strength, linear and non-linear dielectric materials (high K and low K films). The influence of microstructure andcomposition on dielectric properties. Optical properties of dielectrics, piezoelectric materials, relaxors, 2D ferroelectrics, superlattices, characteriaztion methods for dielectrics applications such as capacitors, switches, detectors, memories and more.
03180600.name: Dielectric Materials: Structure, Properties and Applications.

03180722.about: Growth of single crystals.  Dislocations in crystal growth.  Mass crystallisation.  Kinetics and thermodynamics of crystallization.Methods of classifying polymer structure:  X-ray diffraction, light-scattering, optical and electron microscopy, thermal analysis. Crystallization under high pressure.  Deformation and preferred orientation. Microstructure. Amorphous materials. Annealing. Mechanical properties of crystalline polymers.
03180722.name: Properties of Crystalline Polymers

03180724.about: Thermodynamics, morphology, rheology, thermal transitions, mechanical behavior, reactive blending, interfaces, toughening, core-shell modifiers, transport phenomena, liquid crystalline polymers, fillers, nanoscale blends.
03180724.name: Polymer Blends: Structure and Properties

03180819.about: Microbial corrosion: general processes, polymers, wood, cement. chemical treatments inhibiting wood corrosion. Underground corrosion processess. Corrosion: ceramic compounds, copper, copper alloys, magnesium, MG alloys, electronic materials and devices.
03180819.name: Corrosion Processes in Selected Materials

03180820.about: Types of cells and batteries. Energy density: theoretical calculations. Thermodynamics of batteries. Kinetic and thermodynamic characteristics of anode, cathode, electrolyte and separator. Kinetics of reactions: primary and secondary batteries. Cells: electrochemical potential, reaction and design. Chemistry of batteries and fuel cells. Theoretical calculations and practical considerations: charge, discharge, self discharge, cycle life, cell capacity. Applications.
03180820.name: High Energy Denisty Electrochemical Systems

03200096.about: Dynamical models in physics, biology, chemistry and other: 2D+1 Ising model, daisyworld, turing RD model, BML traffic model, ZRP model, L-systems, and the Dyson model for the origin of life, phase diagrams and transitions, the role of numerical simulations, convergence.
03200096.name: Physical Modeling and Law 2

03200098.about: Physical, chemical, engineering, mathematical and biological aspects of: non-linear dynamics in space and time, pattern formation and symmetry-breaking dynamics, networks, synchronization, motion, symmetry and conservation laws, patterning and packing. The conceps will be discussed in the context of heterogeneous compartments. Tools for statistical analysis of spatiotemportal patterns, characterization of spatiotemporal correlations and modes, model construction and model analysis.
03200098.name: Integrative Science-Space and Symmetry

03240053.about:
The aims are:  broadening of vocabulary, improving written expression, writing of summaries, reports, correspondence, and introduction to history of the Hebrew language.  Emphasis is on comprehension of scientific and technical articles.
 Note: This is a compulsory course exclusively for students who were not tested by the psychometric test in Hebrew and were directed to this course on the basis of a placement exam. Students who complete this course proceed to 324054 and 324055, both compulsory courses to be taken in any order the student chooses.
03240053.name: Hebrew 4

03240063.about: This is the continuation course from Hebrew for Medicine 2. Course program: broadening of general Hebrew vocabulary, acquisition ofinitial medical vocabulary and ability to read basic articles and understand a lecture in science and medicine. Plus developing verbal communication skills, especially in the field of medicine.
03240063.name: Hebrew for Medicine-Intermediate Level 3

03240064.about: This is the continuation course from Hebrew for Medicine 3. Course program: enriching the medical dictionary, developing the capability of understanding medical documentation, deciphering and amalgamating of medical documents, such as medical record, admittance to hospital, discharge letters, referral to specialist doctors etc.
03240064.name: Hebrew for Medicine - Advances Level 4

03240065.about: This course is preceded by the Ulpan Summer Course and is intended for students of the International School only. The course will consist of basic Hebrew language study.
03240065.name: Hebrew 1

03240069.about: This course is preceded by the course Hebrew for the International School 2 (324065) and is intended for students of the International School only. Study program: expansion of vocabulary (nouns, prepositions, logical connectors and verbs), and basic language configurations.
03240069.name: Hebrew 2

03240070.about: This course is preceded by the course Hebrew for the International School 33(324069) and is intended for students of the International School only. Study program: reading and understanding of scientific articles and the teaching of the fundamentals of writing in Hebrew.
03240070.name: Hebrew 3

03240227.about: The purpose of the course is to teach the theoretical and practical elements of jazz improvisation, develop improvisational abilityon standards from the jazz repertoire, and to learn the instrumental roles within the jazz combo through guided listening to recordings of distinguished jazz artists.
03240227.name: Jazz Improvisation for Beginners

03240228.about: The purpose of the course is to build a working jazz combo while deepening the theoretical and practical knowledge of jazz improvisation, developing sensitivity to rhythm and time feel, as well as musical interaction between the players, as exemplified in the transcription and analysis of relevant jazz combos recordings.
03240228.name: Inprovisation in a Jazz Combo

03240235.about: The course combines the study of works by artistic communication theoreticians with exercises and sketches aimed at development of social awareness and self-consciouness. Dramatic inpersonation enriches the students' interpersonal communication skills and helps them develop and improve strategies of teamwork, and leadership.
03240235.name: Communication by Theatrical Means

03240236.about: the wind orchestra is a performing ensemble consisting of members of the woodwind, brass and percussion instrument s families. the repertoire of wind orchestra includes original wind  compositions, transcriptions.arrangements of orchestral compositions, marches, light  music, movies and popular tunes. the orchestra has a weekly rehearsal. the orchestra members should come well prepared for the rehearsals. every semester ends with a concert and the orchestra perform in various events  the dates are given at the beginning of-the semester.
03240236.name: Wind Orchestra

03240245.about: the technion campus is an open museum for israeli architecture. the purpose of the ciurse is letting the students know the campus better, understand its uniqueness and learn about the processes, the planners and the different architectural styles in the campus.
03240245.name: The Architectural Heritage of the Campus

03240247.about: the course focuses on one of the "hottest" topics in technology and innovation: entrepreneurship and design. design thinking is a methodology for product development that place the users front and center. the proposed course will expose students to the theoretical bases of design thinking and entrepreneurship and will gain hands-on experience through working on projects in multidisciplinary teams.
03240247.name: Entrpreneurship and Design

03240250.about: this course is about the world of design, creativity and visual communication, including the design process and how to apply it. the course also works on understanding the composition of a graphic piece and recognizing design in its various supports and formats, and how to use it to communicate.
03240250.name: GRAPHIC DESIGN AND VISUAL COMMUNICATION

03240251.about: in this course, students will learn the hebrew alphabet, vocabulary, self-introduction, nouns, prepositions, and the basics of the hebrew verbal system. in addition, they will acquire tools for reading, writing, and conversing in hebrew.
03240251.name: BEGINNERS HEBREW

03240252.about: hebrew for beginners 2 is a course following hebrew for beginners. the course will deepen the basics of reading, writing and speaking skills. the students will expand their vocabulary and language grammar patterns which enable them to have a broader communication abilities in the hebrew speaking environment.
03240252.name: BEGINNERS HEBREW 2

03240257.about: the purpose of the course is to deeply understand the climate crisis. during the course we will explore themes including: the scientific community claims and suggestions on how to prevent climate change, the carbon budget, understanding paris climate agreement. to explore these issues, we will become familiar with recent scientific reports and view videos in which scientists and activists explain core issues in their own voices.
03240257.name: Climate Crisis:Root Causes,Impli.Soluti.

03240258.about: the course is intended for music lovers interested in acquiring tools for developing listening abilities and knowledge in orchestral masterpieces in western culture. moreover, the course will focus on becoming familiar with diverse orchestral styles by listening and watching excerpts, alongside live music. no prior musical knowledge is required.
03240258.name: INT. TO ORCHESTRAL MUSIC

03240260.about: the christian sacred history-with the incarnation, crucifixion and resurrection of christ at its core-constitutes a central foundation of western culture, and of western art. countless artworks were dedicated to the portrayal of the life of christ, as well as to the life of the madonna and the different saints.
03240260.name: Christian Narrative in the Visual Arts

03240261.about: what is professional liability, does the answer differ between engineering or public positions or military ones, taking into consideration of the cyber age, the global world, competition on money and control, we will understand legal models (as negligence, agreements, privacy) ethics and ideology. according to the models, we will solve dilemmas.
03240261.name: Professional Liability Dilemmas

03240262.about: this course aims to study the rise of modern science and philosophy at the 17th century by reading of the most influential texts and thinkers of the period. this will help us understand the main features of contemporary science and philosophy, as exemplified by the problematic relations between mind and body.
03240262.name: History of Modern Science and Philosophy

03240263.about: this course is an examination of the earth over 4.6 billion years of development. it provides a brief idea of the earth interior, origin of earthquakes, plate tectonics paradigm, earth materials classification, volcanoes, faults and folds. we will also learn about prominent landforms and the processes that shape the earth surface.
03240263.name: Earth: the Biography

03240265.about: the aim of the course is to provide the computer tools to discuss the pressing questions regarding the environmental crisis and toofamiliarize themselves with the various positions on them. this is done by becoming familiar with the key concepts, ideas and arguments that have emerged in environmental thought, such as "free resources of nature","ecological footprint",the i equal pat formula,"the tragedy of the public domain".
03240265.name: Eco-Philosophy:Environmental Thought

03240266.about: we will discuss the unique features of science, its strength and its weaknesses. we will explore questions like: what distinguishesscience from alternative theories,  what makes an explanation scientific, can a theory be proved wrong, can it be proved right, if not, is science merely a conjecture like any other.
03240266.name: Science and Its Critics

03240267.about: the course examines the philosophical question of mind-body relations. it presents the central positions from plato to the present day. we discuss how the gap between mind and body has come about in the early modern period and examine scientific, philosophical, as well as practical approaches to it.
03240267.name: Mind to Body:from Plato to Brain Science

03240269.about: global economic growth also has a negative side: decimation of forests, mass destruction of land and aquatic habitats, decreased biodiversity and massive greenhouse gas emissions that undermine global climate stability. humanity is facing new ecological problems,and new infectious diseases such as the covid-19 virus that are threatening the world.
03240269.name: Ethics in Action

03240270.about: the course consists of 13 content units dealing with the major dilemmas that characterize israeli society. the course does not seekto decide these questions, but it does seek to stimulate discussion, presenting the different positions on each of the issues. for example, the social contract and recruitment of yeshiva students, partnership with a national minority, freedom of expression and the boundaries of discourse.
03240270.name: Israeli Identity-Divided We Stand

03240271.about: what are emotions, how do they influence our behavior, and how ought they influence it, are they animalistic impulses that must be restrained, or rather a compass that should guide us in leading a good life, these questions will be examined by scrutinizing the answers of some prominent theoreticians.
03240271.name: Morality, Emotions-How They Are Related

03240272.about: the race to build quantum computers, leading approaches to hardware realization, quantum supremacy, potential applications of quantum computers, qubits, superposition, the no-cloning theorem, quantum cryptography, quantum gates, entanglement, teleportation, quantum circuits, programming a real quantum computer, deutsch s algorithm, grover s algorithm.
03240272.name: Quantum Computing:Theory and Practice

03240273.about: we are becoming increasingly dependent on technology. professional decisions made by computer scientists and engineers in artificial intelligence, big data or networks create far-reaching and unpredictable ethical, moral and social implications. sharpening the ethical and moral stakes is required, so we may come up with bold and creative solutions.
03240273.name: Technology and Society:Ethical Challenge

03240274.about: what is the secret of the piano, the magnificent musical instrument, which won the highest number of masterpieces, this course is for music lovers   who are eager to expand their understanding of classical music and its styles through impressive piano literature,from the baroque, through romanticism, impressionism, modernism, and jazz.
03240274.name: INT. TO PIANO LITERATURE

03240279.about: the course is devoted to the views of some of the greatest greek philosophers, including socrates, plato aristotle, and others, regarding the deep connections between knowledge and happiness. our aim will be to understand what they thought real knowledge is, whatis goodness, and  what is happiness, and how they are related to and dependent upon one another, according to these thinkers.
03240279.name: Socrates and His Followers

03240282.about: the complexity of the israeli society has different manifestations. demographics and cultural processes are reshaping it. these changes raise complex issues such as: what is an israeli culture and whether there is room for a dominant israeli culture. the course will dealel with three main topics: media and politics, family and education and popular culture.
03240282.name: A New Israel Order:a Multicultural Perspective on Israeli Society

03240283.about: this course explores the relationship between economic processes and culture and social change. we will discuss the commonly used terms economy  and  social change  from an anthropological perspective, through the exploration of their cultural and social dimensions. students will be engaged in discussions about people s economic lives, issues concerning poverty, development, work, and migration.
03240283.name: Economy and Social Change:Cross-Cultural Perspective

03240284.about: the past three decades in china have seen the emergence of a new dominant discourse, which highlights children s individualism and personal freedom. however, china's education system is still perceived lacking creativity and innovation. what are the main reasons for this,in the course we will discuss the child's place in contemporary chinese society through a comparison to the israeli society. this observation is interesting because both israeli society and chinese society, despite the great differences between them, bothsocieties view education as an essential tool for shaping the future.
03240284.name: Comparison of Education in China-Israel

03240285.about: in recent years migration has become an important phenomenon with major global impact. internal migration in the china is one of theons largest in the world. the course will address social, economic,icies, political aspects of migration in china, with an emphasison the relationship between state policies and aspirations of the individual.
03240285.name: Migration, Urbanization and Social Change in China

03240286.about: we will learn basic concepts in semantics: lexeme, collocation, proverb and idiom. learn to distinguish between different types of linguistic expressions. the way a new idiom is created can teach us about the ways the language lexicon is expanded. language is dynamic, it developments are expressed in new creations of language.
03240286.name: Man and nature in Western philosophy

03240288.about: the course examines the reciprocal relationship between technology and music, and the musical role of scientists and engineers: technological basis of instruments. instrument invention- electric guitar as a case study. digital instruments, effects and synthesis. xenharmonic music. storage mediums, from vinyl to streaming. music in virtual reality. music for makers.
03240288.name: MUSIC TECHNOLOGY

03240292.about: introduction, historical background, law and justice, distribution of social and economic resources among residents, african-americans' fight for equality, evolution of equality in israeli law, affirmative action, equality for minorities in israel, feminist legaltheory, equality and justice in private law, workplace equality, ageism, equality of opportunity for people with disabilities.
03240292.name: Law, Equality and Social Justice

03240293.about: Exposure to the world of Maimonides, experiencing the tension and integration between life of contemplation and of action by gaining acquaintance with two najor works: the mishne torah and the guide of the perplexed. emphasizing, on methodology of how to probe their secrets, the concepts of the private individual versus the leader, the problem of good and evil, and the maimonidean controversy.
03240293.name: Principal Insights,Maimonids' Philosophy

03240294.about: The course deals with fundamrntal issues in Jewish thought. The topics discussed: the people of Israel and its mission, anti-Semitisim, way of looking  at the long-term historical processes. Sinai, Halacha and customs. Relations in Israeli society. The meaning ofZionism and the Holocaust, social justice in Judaism.
03240294.name: Foundations of Modern Jewish Dtudies

03240295.about: In this course we will learn selected topics from jewish philosophy in the middle ages. Learn selections of Rabbi Yehuda Halevi, Maimonides, Nahmanides and others. We will discuss the cultural background and implications of the ideas to judaism today. Learning will be by reading some significant books and songs. We will discuss recent studies on those texts. Learning outcomes: 1. Exploring medieval thinkers. 2. Exploring the cultural challenges during this period. 3. Dealing with the ability to read and study texts from this period. 4. Understanding the relevance today.
03240295.name: Jewish Philosophy in the Middle Ages

03240297.about: During the course we will meet a variety of personalities from the bible. Looking at the background of their activities, their behavior and their effect on history. Zionism and the return of the people of Israel to their country, again nearing us to reality of the plan and the understanding of their world. The course will look in depth by using various texts that were written about the personalities over a period of thousands of years.
03240297.name: Personage in Bible in Light of Our Times

03240298.about: The course will deal with the mythological stories from the Bible. Their unique narrative qualities and structure which can also beconnected to modern Israeli law. Examples of the pursuit of Bible narratives in today's culture and the structuring that takes place in society and Israeli law.
03240298.name: From the Bible to the New Israeli Law

03240299.about: historical review of terrorism from the french.soviet revolutions thru modern ethno-nationalist and extremist left.right.religious movements. we investigate the ideological.theological.political aspects of the jihadi terror including hybrid organizations-hamas.hezbollah enjoying political support from iran. al-qaeda.isis are examined through their theological perspectives and actions. are governments effectively confronting terrorism, jihad.
03240299.name: Terrorism, Jihad and State Response

03240305.about: this course aims at introducing basic concepts in the history of science from antiquity to the 19th century. the course will discuss how scientific knowledge develops, transforms, and changes and examines how science is defined across history and how major scientific revolutions come about.
03240305.name: History of Science

03240306.about: the ethical, legal, and social implications (elsi) of the human genomic project since its inception, including controversies and dilemmas, such as gene patentability, genetic non-discrimination protection and legislation, precision medicine, resource allocation and justice, fertility issues,  designer babies  and genome editing, slippery slope and regulatory measures.
03240306.name: HUMAN GENOME! ETHICS, LAW AND SOCIETY

03240307.about: the course introduces the midrashic literature of the jewish sages, of its central compositions and common genres, by focusing on selected texts, examines the development of the midrashic style from classic midrashim of the first centuries ac to late midrashim, and discusses their historic and cultural context.
03240307.name: THE MIDRASHIC LITERATURE

03240314.about: this course aims at examining major events and theories in the history of science in the 20th century and beyond. the course will discuss how science impacts the modern world, the ethical challenges it induces, and how science alters philosophy, culture, and everyday life.
03240314.name: HISTORY OF SCIENCE:20TH CEN. AND BEYOND

03240315.about: technological developments in microbiology have changed our understanding of the microbial role on earth. microbiology studies in biomedicine raise issues concerning the organism (individual), its relationship with the environment, and the immune system function. this course will focus on the historical, conceptual, and technological aspects of these recent developments examining contemporary researches in microbiology, medicine, and ecology.
03240315.name: THE MICROBES AND US:MEDICINE!AGRICU.,ECO

03240385.about: This undergraduate post-technical english course will enable students to develop speaking and writing skills by exposing them to the practical tasks and skills necessary for functioning in professional settings. Activity-oriented guidance and instruction will be provided. A significant amount of class time will be devoted to speaking and writing.
03240385.name: Communicating in English

03240397.about: The course will focus on the principle question - the characterization of biological organization as a physico- chemical phenomenon, which is nevertheless, uniquely biological. The problem of the reduction of biology to chemistry, the status of teleological explanations and the philosophical aspects of the origin of life, and evolutionary processes will be discussed.
03240397.name: The Philosophy of the Life Sciences

03240424.about: The Mishna, Tosefta, Halakhic and Homiletical Midrashim, as well as the two Talmudim - Yerushalmi and Bavli constitute the classical canon of the Jewish people. These were composed over the first half millennia of the Common Era, in the land of Israel and Babylon. This corpii will be surveyed and their various methods and genres will be studied. No ptior knowledge if required for this course.
03240424.name: The Jewish Literature of Late Antiquity

03240426.about: Destruction of the temple was a fatal blow to judaism in Israel and the diaspora. Sages dealt with this disaster in different ways,with awareness of the immensity of the responsibility to restore and maintain the tradition, while renewing and adapting to the newreality. The course studies this process.
03240426.name: From Destruction to Creativity

03240427.about: Introduction: oral Torah and the world of Halacha. False messianism, orthodoxy and the resistance in Europe at the beginning of thenew era. Overview of atheism and secularization, in Europe. Case study and the roots of the education. The thirty year war of the development of the secular Europe. World reaction to the formation of traditional and modern orthodox.
03240427.name: Fragmentation of Unity

03240428.about: The course will expand on areas of society referring to identity and globalization among excelling students in their studies and intheir contribution to society. Each week we will meet with lecturers of different areas of interest. Ee will question the roots of our existence as a society, as people and as a Jewish nation within the global village.
03240428.name: Leadership and Identity

03240432.about: The course presents the different areas related to the various influences of music on human behavior. These include psycho- accoustic foundations, the manner in which we respond to music, the development of musical ability, extraordinary musical ability, cognitive and motoric elements in music performance, and the use of music for commercial and health purposes.
03240432.name: Psychology of Music

03240433.about: The purpose of the course is to present the holocaust as reflected in the cinema from the 1950's until today, as part of an ongoingdialogue with the past. Propaganda films produced in nazi germany, along side films that reflect aspects of life in the shadow of the holocaust, nazi childhood and youth, the use of humor as a strategy of defense and survival. research questions arise in the young german generation who are confronting the past.
03240433.name: The Holocaust as Reflected in the Cinema

03240436.about: A panoramic view of different musical cultures: the indians in North america, Cuba, Brazil, Bolivia, Ireland, Spain, Greece, African music.
03240436.name: World of Music

03240439.about: Foundations of Japanese art and civilization:  a review of Japanese sculpture, painting and architecture in relation to history andsociety:  emphasis of aesthetical, social and religious elements.
03240439.name: Foundations in Japanese Art

03240441.about: The study of the visual language of the Renaissance, concentrating on painting, sculpture and architecture, focusing on leading artcenters and major characteristics of representation. Examining the artistic characteristics and contents of the Italian Renaissanceart and the leading patrons in the aristocracy and the church. Observing the different painting and sculpture techniques prevalent among the leading artists, and examining the implications of scientific achievements on art, such as the development of perspective and naturalism in painting.
03240441.name: Selecterd Chapters in the History of Art

03240442.about: Engineers, managers and hi-tech entrepreneurs need legal information on two issues: patents and labor law. The course deals with the theory, principles and legal practice on these issus while integrating ethical, social and historical espects.
03240442.name: Israeli Labor Law

03240443.about: The course follows the development of Islam from the middle Age until Modern History. The students will study major topics in the history of the Middle East, wich refer to Islam, such as the life of the Prophet Muhammad, dynasties and Empires, modern politics, the influence of foreign powers and Islamic movements. The course also includes a general introduction of Muslim religion.
03240443.name: The History of Islam

03240444.about: Psychological warfare is a major element in miltary conflicts. The course will expose the components of the field over years and will focus on the wars of the 20th century. Propaganda products will be analyzed such as leaflets, posters, movies, cartoons and more.
03240444.name: Psychological Warfare

03240445.about: The course will examine different aspects of dealing with stress. We will learn to distinguish physiological, psychological and social patterns of dealing with stress and to locate and understand the stressors in their life, to examine the ways and patterns they cope with stress, acquire tools and develop effective skills of dealing with stress.
03240445.name: Adjustment to Stressful Situations

03240446.about: The course outlines the development of jazz music and its different styles in relationship to the cultural, social and musical influences that contributed to its development. Important jazz musicians and their unique styles will be discussed. The course includes guided listening to recordings that present the different styles and musicians.
03240446.name: Introduction to the History of Jazz

03240453.about: In light of recent legal dilemmas that raise legal, moral and philiosophical questions, the course will focus on the world of ultramodern reproduction, including reproduction of the dead, surrogacy, trading of reproductive cells, choices made and genetics. Involving love, hope, power struggles, interests, political and finanacial gains. We will learn about israeli law in these contexts as well as cultural, social and international influences.
03240453.name: Love and Law in the Age of Tech.

03240454.about: What is science and how is it distinguished from other practices such as religion. Does science aim at the truth, or, maybe, at developing tools for controlling nature. what brings about scientific revolution, what are the relations between the human sciences andthe physical sciences. The course introduces the students to questions in the foundations of science from theoretical and historical perspectives.
03240454.name: Int. to the Philosophy of Science

03240456.about: The course introduces thought informal logic and creativity. Studying the concept and methodology of thought will reveal common processes, hindrances and fallacies as well as ways for better analysis, decision taking and self-expression. Class discussions of excerpts from literature and philosophy will allow lively study and practice.
03240456.name: Thought: Criticism and Creativity

03240457.about: The course introduces museology, emphasising connections between various technologies and spaces.exhibitions.visitors. Museums are employed here as a microcosm of relationships between components of content, architecture and technology in their context. The course presents museums worldwide, including visits to local ones and a theoretical exercise in intervention within the museum.
03240457.name: Museology and Technology

03240460.about: The student will be exposed to the concepts of the two perfections in medieval thought: the individual and the collective, and to the tension between them. He will gain acquaintanceship with the language and sources, including maimonides and his contemporaries with translation from the " religious " language to the " political " language.
03240460.name: Jewish Political Thought Up Modern Age

03240461.about: The term "modernism" unites a variety of artistic movements, developed throughout the second half of the 19th century to the late 20th century, and constitute the ideological and aesthetic foundation for theater today. The course reviews key trends in theater andthe live performance through works and writings of major practitioners, playwrights and thinkers.
03240461.name: Modernism in Theatre

03240462.about: the course will present the way the nazi films served as a means of shaping public opinion, which was done through movies that glorified the fuhrer and established the superiority of the aryan race and.or served as virulent anti - semitic propaganda. it will alsopresent germany's contemporary dialogue with those films.
03240462.name: Filming Berlin: from 1930'S Till Today

03240463.about: Survey the powerof religion and secular nationalism in the middle east, their development and clash within different national entities and across state boundaries. in particular secular arab nationalism and islamic fundamentalism are locked in combat and jewish nationalism (zionism) remains in a conflictual relationship with much of arab.islamic society.
03240463.name: History of the Middle-East

03240473.about: any knowledge gained during a scientific innovation first challenged the scientific community and later changed the way people see the world. learning the structure of scientific revolutions and past paradigms helps us to understand that breakthrough moments and scientific development are the result of disruptive thinking and change of existing paradigms.
03240473.name: Structure of Scientific Innovation

03240474.about: this course will introduce you to the field of ethics on three key levels: fundamental questions of ethics (meta-ethics), normativeethics and applied ethics. we will survey the most significant ethical theories, and will debate key issues in topics like animal rights, privacy, euthanasia, abortion and death penalty. at the end of the course, the student will have a better understanding, and ability to confront and think critically about difficult moral questions that we all often encounter in life.
03240474.name: Ethics: Fundament, Norm and Application

03240475.about: this course is an introduction to the field of political science through a survey of the major issues, questions, and ideas of politics from a comparative and international perspective. questions as fundamental as why people behave as they do in the political process are examined. the course also compares different forms of government, and the role of the individual and the state. a comparison of different governing institutions and processes between various countries will be made. there will also be conversations about international politics.
03240475.name: Political Science: a Survey
