03240478.about: this course introduces students to design thinking method and its application in career planning and development. students will learn to explore and design their career and life after studying in the technion using a design thinking approach. they will also assess their career competencies and develop an action plan to get ready and launch their desired career. through the course, students will understand the career designing process, the connection between career competencies and different career paths, develop techniques for conducting successful job searches.graduate school applications, and identify strategies necessary for ongoing career developme nt in today s workplace. this experiential class will be delivered weekly with the use of lectures, seminar-style discussions, reflection journals, guest speakers, and individual mentoring.coaching.
03240478.name: Designing Your Career

03240481.about: the aim: to develop the basic ability of practical freehand drawing - a basic technique for all kinds of arts. basic theoretical and practical lessons in drawing.sketching different objects: basic forms, still life, complex composition. applications to the field of technology. the course will provide the basis for advanced art studies.
03240481.name: Freehand Drawing for Beginners

03240482.about: Object of course: advanced development of practical ability in freehand drawing. Advanced theoretical study of the set of principles of freehand drawing, development of ability for drawing complex objects, exposition of light and shade, combination of linear and air perspective, familiarization with different drawing techniques, including monochrome aquarelle, etc.
03240482.name: Freehand Drawing Advanced Level

03240483.about: object of course: development of primary painting ability, theoretical study of the set of concepts and principles of painting, development of basic ability for painting different objects: basic forms, still life, complex objects (landscape): exposition of light and shade, air perspective, composition, etc. study of aquarelle (water color) technique.
03240483.name: Painting for Beginners

03240485.about: the course examines roles and responsibilities of management, skills and attributes needed to be an effective manager. focuses on how management help an organization achieve its overall goals, addresses a variety of organizations and management positions, including history of management, decision making, marketing, teams and motivation, leadership and strategy. lecturers will be complimented by class discussions, assignments, team presentations and guest lecturer(s).
03240485.name: BUSINESS MANAGEMENT

03240490.about: the course aim is to provide and develop academic writing tools for students who wish to submit a research paper during their undergraduate education. we will focus on the structure of an academic text based on scientific sources, and we will learn how to write it in a coherent way.
03240490.name: ACADEMIC WRITING FOR UNDERGRADUATE ST.

03240495.about: The course will provide the techniques of drawing, as well as skills for the performance of figurative representations of objects and landscapes in color.
03240495.name: Drawing and Painting in Color

03240513.about: THE COURSE IS INTENDED FOR STUDENTS WHO WISH TO TAKE PART IN A THEATRICAL PERFORMANCE. THE PURPOSE IS TO ENABLE PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE IN WORK PROCESSES. THE CREATIVE WORK WILL BE BASED ON ELEMENTS OF STAGE WORK AND INTERACTION BETWEEN ACTOR, DIRECTOR, TEXT, SPACE AND AUDIENCE. WE WILL STUDY A VARIETY OF PERFORMANCE TECHNIQUES AND WORK ON LITERARY PASSAGES FROM PLAYS OF BOOKS AND FILMS. INCORPORATING MATERIALS FROM THE EMOTIONAL.PERSONAL AND CULTURAL WORLD OF THE STUDENTS, TO CREATE A UNIQUE THEATRICAL PERFORMANCE.
03240513.name: A Play-a Show-a Performance

03240518.about: the course will address the importance of change and innovation processes, and the characteristics of creativity. the course will expose the students to the field of positive psychology and the factors affecting personal happiness. the impact of these issues on performance and success will be addressed as well.
03240518.name: Innovation, Creativity and Happiness

03240520.about: the course introduces the concept of launching a new business venture, as of its inception and onward. along the semester, studentswill acquire both the theoretical knowledge and the practical skills necessary for building a business plan for a new venture. during the course, several entrepreneurship projects will be presented - alongside their business plans - and analyzed jointly by the lecturer and students.
03240520.name: Business Entrepreneurship

03240521.about: the course deals with different types of organizations, the relationship between organization and environment in general, and the israeli case in particular. the course will discuss a variety of topics related to descriptive issues in organizational research, organizational processes and changes, organizational culture, organizational decision making, globalization and post-fordism, the organization and the individual, work and meaning and post bureaucracy and social responsibility.
03240521.name: Entrepreneurship in Organizations

03240524.about: THE THEATER, AS WE KNOW IT TODAY, TOOK SHAPE ABOUT 2,500 YEARS AGO, AND SINCE THEN HAS NOT CEASED TO CHANGE AND DEVELOP, BUT A NUMBER OF BASIC PRINCIPLES HAVE BEEN PRESERVED OVER THE YEARS. WHAT IS DRAMA, WHY IS NOT EVERY DISASTER A "TRAGEDY", WHAT IS THE ROLE OFTHE PLAYER, THE PLAYWRIGHT, THE AUDIENCE, THE STAGE, WHAT HAPPENED TO THE THEATER, THE ART OF THOUSANDS OF YEARS, IN A MEETING WITHLATER MEDIA (CINEMA, TELEVISION AND EVEN THE INTERNET), ALL THESE WILL BE REVIEWED AND EXAMINED IN THE LIGHT OF PLAYS FROM ANCIENT GREECE TO THE 19TH CENTURY, ALONGSIDE CONTEMPORARY OBSERVATION OF CLASSIC PRINCIPLES AND PLAYS.
03240524.name: Classical Theatre: the Myth Gets Body

03240527.about: in this innovation masterclass, you will learn how to become an entrepreneur and gain the management skills needed to make your venture successful. the course provides a basic introduction to the principles of entrepreneurial thinking that are essential to achieve excellence. the purpose of the course is not limited to training business entrepreneurs. although the course is structured around the establishment of a business venture, its goal is to provide entrepreneurial thinking tools that are essential to excellence of technion graduates in industry, management and academia, and in initiating and participating in both commercial and non-commercial ven tures.
03240527.name: Innovation Masterclass

03240528.about: the aim of the course is to enhance the entrepreneurial leadership skills of the students. entrepreneurial leadership reflected in the establishment of technological and scientific startups in all areas of knowledge and application. reflecting the ability to initiate and lead innovative projects within an organization or technology company.
03240528.name: Entrepreneurial Leadership

03240536.about: the course reviews the israeli hi-tech sector: its structure, internal dynamics, strengths and weaknesses, and the macroeconomic forces that shape it. next, the government policies and the measures it may take to preserve the sector's leading global position are presented. lastly, the course discusses the sector's current and future challenges.
03240536.name: Israeli Hi-Tech: How to Lead Globally

03240539.about: the course is broadly structured to follow the steps in the marketing research process. the topics include problem definition, research design data collection methods, questionnaire design, sampling methods, and data analysis.
03240539.name: Marketing Research

03240540.about: the field of "commercial law" is one of the most comprehensive areas of law, which incorporates in it a wide range of laws that have as of major impact on the daily lives of all of us. this course will focuse on the central issues of business law and business entrepreneurship in israel, and in doing so, we will be familiar with the basic focus principles of the laws of contract, property, corporation, tendering and antitrust, in addition to recognizing the commercial civil system of the state of israel.
03240540.name: Legal Aspects of Busine.Entrepreneurship

03240541.about: the course will describe the processes methodologies and tools of the business development manager in the organization. it will cover how to use these tools in order to harness the ecosystem in order to achieve the strategic and business goals of the organization.
03240541.name: Bd-Harnessing the Eco System

03240567.about: This workshop will focus on the development of the capacity of observation and its application to photography: the language and techniques in photography such as light, point of view, framing, timing, composition, together with correction and manipulation of the image. The workshop wil combine directed exercises in class and outdoors and will introduce a variety of subjects including portrait, self-portrait, still life, images from nature and from the urban environment.
03240567.name: Workshop in Photography

03240580.about: The course includes intensive acquisition of Japanese grammar, the study of an additional phonetic writing system (Hiragana), learning of additional 100 Kanji, and maintenance of basic conversation skills.
03240580.name: Japanese 2

03240600.about: Acquisition of basic spoken German, reading and writing.
03240600.name: German 1

03240602.about: The course includes an introduction to the history and characteristics of the Japanese language, study of the two phonetic writing systems, study of 50-100 Chinese characters (kanji), study of the structure of the Japanese sentence, practice of conversation regarding basic daily life situations, and reading of short dialogues.
03240602.name: Japanese for Beginners

03240603.about:
Continuation of "German for Beginners 1".
 Acquisition of basic knowledge of the language.
03240603.name: German 2

03240605.about: Acquisition of the language at intermediate level.
03240605.name: German 4

03240609.about: This course is intended for beginners only.  The course gives a basic knowledge of the spoken language.
03240609.name: French 11

03240611.about: Grading on basis of semestral folow-up mid- semestral examination and final examination. This course is intended for students who completed French 11.
03240611.name: French 22

03240625.about: Acquisition of the Russian language at a higher level.
03240625.name: Russian (Advanced) 1

03240626.about: The course is intended to enable students to communicate in the colloquial dialect (urban Jerusalem dialect) used in the country atan elementary level.
03240626.name: Arabic (Beginners)

03240627.about: The course is intended to enable students to communicate in the colloquial dialect (urban Jerusalem dialect) used in the country atan intermediate level.  Marks are determined by noting progress during the term and a final examination.
03240627.name: Arabic (Beginners) 2

03240628.about: THIS COURSE IS INTENDED AS AN INTRODUCTION TO COLLOQUIAL ARABIC LANGUAGE IN THE PALESTINIAN DIALECT. THE STUDENTS USE HEBREW TRANSLITERATION AND THE COURSE INCLUDES BASIC TRAINING IN READING OF ARABIC LETTERS. AMONG THE TOPICS OF STUDY: BLESSING, COURTESY AND CUSTOMS, CONVERSATION IN THE MARKET, ACQUAINTANCE, ORIENTATION, FAMILY AND WORK.
03240628.name: Colloquial Arabic

03240630.about: Acquisition of the basic Italian language.
03240630.name: Italian for Beginners 1

03240631.about: Acquisition of the language at a level higher than beginners.
03240631.name: Advanced Italian

03240679.about: Spanish language at a higher level than beginners.
03240679.name: Intermediate Spanish

03240692.about: The purpose of this course, designed gor beginners, is to enable the student to communicate in chinese for everyday purposes. As well as emphasis on oral communication, it offers the student the basic elements required for further advanced study of the language.
03240692.name: Chinese for Beginners

03240694.about: The course will begin with a short rehearsal of what was learned in the former chinese for beginners. We will proceed with an outline of the grammar of the language. Our studies will then focus on increasing the amount of words and exercise their usage in familiar and new grammatical constructs. The emphasis will continue to be on a dialogical speaking of the language, but basic reading and writing will be exercised too.
03240694.name: Advanced Chinese

03240697.about: THE COURSE DEALS WITH THE PRINCIPLES OF PHOTO PROCESSING AND REPAIR, USING IMAGE PROCESSING SOFTWARE. THE STUDENTS WILL STUDY A VARIETY OF SUBJECTS IN THE FIELD OF IMAGE PROCESSING, WITH EMPHASIS ON CORRECT APPROACHES TO IMPROVING PHOTOGRAPHS AND PRESENTING THE TOOLS NEEDED BY A PHOTOGRAPHER IN HIS WORK, AS WELL AS IMAGE PROCESSING TOOLS IN THE FIELD OF PREPARING PHOTOGRAPHS FOR ACADEMIC ARTICLES AND POSTERS.
03240697.name: Practical Principles for Image Processing

03240702.about: the "introduction to social thinking" course is a basic course, designed to help students understand basic concepts of social thinking. the course will focus on the changes taking place in the society around us. we live in a time where changes are taking place inmany areas of life that affect us as individuals and as a society. the course itself will reveal major trends of social change in the world in general and in israel in particular. its main purpose is to encourage you, the students, to develop awareness and raise questions in the social disciplines. the study is based on the five volumes of the book introduction to social thinking. each of the volumes deals with one major theme, such as: identity, family, labor market, globalization, social order, science -what is, and thelike. in dealing with these topics, students will gain an initial introduction to the perspectives of the various disciplines in the social sciences: sociology, political science, economics and psychology.
03240702.name: Introduction to Social Science: Understending Social Changes

03240710.about: THE COURSE ALLOWS STUDENTS A BASIC EXPERIENCE WITH THE WORLD OF MAKING MOVIES USING THE CELL PHONE. STUDENTS LEARN TOOLS FOR MAKINGFILMS, FROM WRITING THE SCRIPT, PREPARING FOR FILMING, FILMING AND EDITING. STUDENTS WILL UNDERSTAND THE LANGUAGE OF CINEMA AND WILL BE ABLE TO ~READ~ AND ~WRITE~ THROUGH IT.
03240710.name: CREATE A MICROFILM: MY FAMILY AND ME

03240711.about: HE COURSE WILL REVIEW THE HISTORY OF EUROPEAN AND AMERICAN CINEMA. STUDENTS LEARN A BASIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE MAJOR PROCESSES THATINFLUENCED THIS ART, TO CLARIFY THE HISTORICAL CONTEXT OF THESE PROCESSES AND TO BECOME FAMILIAR WITH KEY CURRENTS, IMPORTANT CREATORS AND THEORETICAL APPROACHES TO UNDERSTANDING THE FIELD.
03240711.name: HISTORY OF CINEMA-EUROPEAN AND AMERICAN

03240879.about: This course seeks to unravel the complexity of the Israeli political, social and cultural aspects and provide tools for understanding the uniqueness of Israeli society and peoples. Issues for discussion: gender, media and popular culture. The course introduces Israel's contemporary society through a holistic approach - lectures, movies, discussions and guest lecturers.
03240879.name: Issues in Contemporary Israeli Society

03240881.about: This course is taught in English. A survey of the history of the Jewish people with an emphasis on the modern period and the development of the state of Israel. There is one field study to the Diaspora Museum during the course. Example of areas of study: first temple period, second temple period, Jewish existence in the Byzantine and Islamic worlds, Russian Jewry, Antisemitism.
03240881.name: Topics in History of the Jewish People

03240908.about: The invention of photography in the mid-19th century brought to the world a new medium. Immediately after its invention people tookthe camera and began documenting their surroundings and had to deal with brand new technical and esthetic dilemmas. Photography became a major medium of the modern experience which has enormous influence on our imagery. In our meetings we will follow the development pf photography as art and examine its interrelationship with other media.
03240908.name: History of Photography: from the Camera Obscura to the Smartphone

03240917.about: The course focuses on one of the most fascinating periods in the history of christianity in the holy land. Through the analysis of the different types of images, we will explore the importance of material culture for understanding political, historical and religious issues. Special attention will be given to the changing status of Jerusalem, jewish christian relations, and fate of the christian community with the rise of islam.
03240917.name: The Holy Land as Mirrored in Art

03240929.about: This course focuses on photographs created in the holy land furing the 19th and early 20th century by photographers travelling froneurope and usa. It explores their aim to strengthen religious, political, ideological and cultural ideas that supposedly reflect the reality truthfully, but in fact were subjective and even fables.
03240929.name: Photographic Pilgrimage of the Holy Land

03240940.about: The course examines the affinity existing between fairy-tales and dreams. We examine the possibility of making use of materials resulting from research on folklore to interpret dreams. We will examine the genre of tale, the chatacteristics of fantasy, primary anduniversal, and examine the dialogue with different types of dreams. Learning outcomes: the students will be able to identify the features that dreams and fairy-tales share in common. The students will be able to apply methods and interpretation taken from the field of dream's study, when relating to fairy-tales, and vice versa.
03240940.name: Dreams: Folklore and Psychoanalysis

03240943.about: The course will discuss ways of formation of the various systems of the land border from the bible to the end of the first millennium, and their place in the consciousness of the different groups. We will also examine the sacred places and spaces for jews, christians and muslims in the land of Israel. Learning outcomes: on completion of this course, the learner will be able to recognize the various border systems of the land of israel in ancient times, as reflected in contemporary sources and will be able to classify them. he will also be able to analyze the components of the various mental maps and be able to compare between them and other boundary sy stems. Alongside with perception of space and collective maps, the student will specialize in various methods in the study of comparative religion, in relation to holy places and the implementation of theories in analyzing the status of the holy sites of judaism,christianity and islam in Israel.
03240943.name: Space, Boundaries and Holiness

03240944.about: The course will examine the transformations in the communication field with emphasis on the digital sphere. Social media will play a key role on various fields. Learning outcomes: the students will be able to analyze and understand communication events mostly around digital media.
03240944.name: Communication in the Age of Information

03240945.about: The course follows the main split in the muslim world between the sunni majority and the shi'i minority and major theological differences. The course follows the roots of the conflict in the first centuries of islam (7th to 12th centuries), analyzing its implications on modern middle east. Learning outcomes: a thorough understanding of the reasons for the split in islam and its results in modern history.
03240945.name: The Sunni Shi'I Conflict in the Islam

03240946.about: during the renaissance, man's identity and beliefs changed dramatically, as well as his material surroundings. the course regards the "court" as the cradle of renaissance culture, and analyses art, architecture, and designed landscape developing at the courts of urbino, ferrara, mantua, florence, milano and roma (15th-17th centuries). learning outcomes: student will acquire basic concepts on the italian renaissance, through the analysis of representative case-studies. the course will provide the necessary tools enabling the recognition of major works of art, architecture and designed landscape of that period. further, an understanding of the historic, philosophical, social and scientific background charateristic of the renaissance, as part of the history of culture, will be gained.
03240946.name: The Renaissance in Italy: An Artistic and Cultural Journey

03240948.about: The cinema that started in the 20th century documented the great wars that shaped our world and turned the western world into what we know today. The course deals with descripions of the war that were commemorated in documentaries, mystery, romances, espionag ect. We can identify films with a political message or propaganda etc.
03240948.name: War and Film

03240949.about: 20th century europe faced ideological, social, cultural, political and economic changes. It was the cinema that managed to bring tothe masses, the intellectual criticism and remorse over european colonialism, fascism, and militarism. We will view the major issues of the 20th century through the cinematic prism: age of ideologies, great wars, and the holocaust.
03240949.name: European Cinema-Issues of the 20Th Cent.

03240962.about: the purpose of this course is to acquaint students with modern psychology, and the variety of issues dealt with by the field. we shall address the scientific stance of psychology, and areas that are at the heart of recent psychological concern, such as development, learning, memory, personality, psychopathology and psychotherapy.
03240962.name: INT. TO PSYCHOLOGY

03240966.about: We will talk about the musical experience, what should the listener do.think.feel when listening to music. Possible answers will arise through the contrast of experiences in music and other arts: literature, film, poetry and dance for example. Finding the uniqueness in music that is not ready to be made into a soundtrack or be background music, as well as looking at the aesthetics of the musical experience.
03240966.name: Observing the Musical Experience

03240973.about: This course shall explore the available possibilities of musical syntax, with all their variations and meanings. The course shall analyze and clarify the syntax structures of the musical sound: duration, pitch, timbre and volume, as well as the relationships between them, through musical masterpieces of various periods and genres.
03240973.name: The Language of Music-Syntax of Tones

03240975.about: This course will discuss Israel's foreign policy as it has developed from the establishment of the state to the present day. The issues we will include the nature of diplomacy and the affinity between foreign policy and security, the history, structure, and objectives of the israeli foreign service, perceptions, principles, and basic assumptions in Israel's foreign policy, and the past and presents relationship between Israel and selected countries around the world.
03240975.name: Israel'S Foreign Policy

03240979.about: the birth of empirical science and its current role are embedded in a complex set of values. noticing these complexities, we will ask about the practical meaning of scientific objectivity, the researcher's responsibility, the values that may constitute scientificpractice, and critically-reflect upon values in our studies and.or lab work.
03240979.name: Science and Values

03240983.about: aspects of communism: a utopian ideal, an ideology, a political movement, and real historical practices of the 20-th century. attempts to construct communist polities in russia ("war communism", stalinism, "advanced socialism"), eastern europe, and asia. anti - communism. collapse of communism: causes and consequences. influences of the communist ideas and practices on the modern culture.
03240983.name: Communism:An Ideology and Practices

03240984.about: the course makes an introduction to contemporary korea and to the changes it has been going through since its establishment. we will explore issues such as popular culture, state of democracy and religion, changes in family structure and women's status, and korea's relations with japan and north korea.
03240984.name: Contemporary Korea

03240987.about: physics, early 20th century - new paradigms: atomin preception, relativity, quantum physics - the founding fathers: boltzmann, einstein, planck and bohr - the quantum world and the new reality - applications and new developments: nuclear energy and particles.
03240987.name: A Brief History of Modern Physics

03240992.about: the course deals with philosophical issues related to ethical and professional ethics. among the topics to be discussed: trade and freedom of information, information security, purpose biased information processing, ethical implications of artificial intelligence, the moral implications of technological breakthroughs and implications of data usage on individual rights.
03240992.name: Ethical Issues in the Personal and Public Space

03240997.about: the greeks enjoy a special place in the construction of western identity: poetry, tragedy and comedy, historiography, philosophy, architecture, political theory, and many more. in this class, we will cover the period from the late bronze age down to the death of alexander the great in 323 bce.
03240997.name: Classical Greece and Western Civilizatio

03250001.about: THE  ARTIST IN RESIDENCE STUDIO  IS AN ART OR MUSIC COURSE WHICH CHANGES ON A SEMESTER BASIS. THE COURSE OFFERS EXPOSURE TO BOTH THE THEORETICAL BACKGROUND AND PRACTICAL EXPERIENCE IN THE VISITING ARTIST S PROFESSIONAL SPECIALTY. THIS MAY INCLUDE FIELDS OF MUSIC,SCULPTURE, DRAWING AND/OR ANY OTHER FORM OF ART.
03250001.name: ARTIST IN RESIDENCE STUDIO 1

THIS MAY INCLUDE FIELDS OF MUSIC,SCULPTURE, DRAWING AND/OR ANY OTHER FORM OF ART.

03250005.about: THE COURSE CONSISTS OF WEEKLY LECTURES GIVEN BY EXPERIENCED AND SUCCESSFUL ENTREPRENEURS. THEY SHARE THEIR EXPERIENCE WITH THE STUDENTS, WITH EMPHASIS ON  LESSONS LEARNED  FOR THE NOVICE ENTREPRENEUR. AMONG THE SUBJECTS, INNOVATION AT THE TECHNION, THE ENTREPRENEURIAL ECOSYSTEM, MARKETING, WRITING A BUSINESS PLAN, FUNDRAISING AND MORE.
03250005.name: ENTREPRENEURSHIP BY ENTREPRENEURS

03250006.about: THIS COURSE OFFERS A COMPREHENSIVE INTRODUCTION TO ARCHAEOLOGY AND THE CURRENT STATE OF THE FIELD. THROUGH LECTURES AND HOME ASSIGNMENTS STUDENTS WILL LEARN HOW ARCHAEOLOGISTS STUDY THE PAST, AS WELL AS ABOUT MAIN EVENTS IN HUMANKIND HISTORY, AND GAIN TOOLS FOR CRITICAL UNDERSTANDING OF THE PAST IN MODERN HUMAN LIFE.
03250006.name: INTRO.TO ARCHAEOLOGY IN THE 21 CENTURY

03250007.about: THE COURSE REVIEWS MORAL DILEMMAS OF THE INTELLIGENCE SERVICES! FOCUSING ON THE ISRAELI EXPERIENCE. WE LAY THE THEORETICAL FOUNDATION FOR A SCIENTIFIC EXAMINATION OF SUCH DILEMMAS! AND THEN FOCUS ON PROMINENT DILEMMAS RELATED TO INTELLIGENCE GATHERING/OPERATIONS.AS A CASE STUDY! WE REVIEW THE PROCESS THAT THE ISRAEL SECURITY SERVICE UNDERWENT.
03250007.name: STRATEGIC INTELLIGENCE AND ETHICS

03250008.about: CREATING NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND COMMERCIALIZING THEM IS A KEY COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE OF ISRAEL. THIS COURSE WILL EXPLORE THE CHALLENGES FACING ENTREPRENEURS AND WILL FOCUS  ON THE KEY ISSUES AND BASIC QUESTIONS TO BE ADDRESSED IN THE FORMAL VENTURE PROCESS: CREATION! EVALUATION! DEVELOPMENT! LAUNCH! AND FUNDING OF A NEW VENTURE.
03250008.name: NEW VENTURE CREATION AND VENTURE CAPITAL

03250009.about: PROFESSIONAL STAGE PERFORMERS AND MUSICIANS ARE CONSTANTLY COPING WITH VARIOUS DILEMMAS AND LEADING TASKS. THESE GIVE VALUABLE INSIGHTS TO OTHER DISCIPLINES TO DEMONSTRATE LEADERSHIP AND DISTINCTIVE PRESENTATION. THIS COURSE IS GOVERNED BY THREE CORE PRINCIPLES: EXPERIENCE! RESEARCH AND IMPLEMENTATION TO SEARCH THE ELEMENTS OF THOSE WHO LEAVE A MARK.
03250009.name: LEAVING YOUR MARK IN SCIENCE AND ART

03250010.about: THE DIALOGUE BETWEEN JUDAISM AND THE SCIENTIFIC WORLD HAS CONTINUED FOR MANY YEARS. THIS COURSE COVERS MANY TOPICS THROUGHOUT HISTORY: FROM THE MIDDLE AGES! THROUGH THE RENAISSANCE! ENLIGHTENMENT! AND THE TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY. THE COURSE PRESENTS SUCH ISSUES THROUGH WRITINGS OF THE MAIN JEWISH THINKERS AND CONTEMPORARY RESEARCHERS DURING THESE PERIODS.
03250010.name: SCIENCE! RELIGION AND PHILOSOPHY

AND POLITICS. THE COURSE TOPICS WILL DRAW FROM A VARIETY OF PHILOSOPHICAL TRADITIONS AND DISCIPLINES! INCLUDING ANALYTICAL PHILOSOPHY! CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY! PHILOSOPHY OF SCIENCE! AND NON-WESTERN PHILOSOPHICAL TRADITIONS.

AND POLITICS. THE COURSE TOPICS WILL DRAW FROM A VARIETY OF PHILOSOPHICAL TRADITIONS AND DISCIPLINES! INCLUDING ANALYTICAL PHILOSOPHY! CONTINENTAL PHILOSOPHY! PHILOSOPHY OF SCIENCE! AND NON-WESTERN PHILOSOPHICAL TRADITIONS.

03250021.about: Artificial Intelligence (AI) has become a common term, capitalized by numerous organizations and companies. Related concepts, such as machine learning and neural networks, are also becoming widespread. AI algorithms stand at the heart of far reaching technological breakthroughs and hold great promises, but at the same time raise concerns about the possible rise of a destructive force driven by superintelligence. But what does artificial intelligence mean? What are the sources of the idea that one could artificially produce or create an intelligence? And what are the implications of this idea on human society? The course will run in the historical axis from Turings test for machine thinking articulated in the 50s to recent debates. We will converse with chatbots ourselves, analyze anthropomorphism and empathy towards robots, relate the primordial desire to overcome nature to current debates on granting human rights to digital entities, ask about the economic and cultural implications of automation, and of the different ways biases migrate from the human to the digital realm. And most importantly we will ask - in what way does this change the way we conceive humanity.
03250021.name: SELECTED ROPICS IN HUMANITIES 1

03250022.about:
From Here to There": Exploring the Precursors of Modern Mechanics through Texts on the Medieval Concept of Motion. 

Modern science is credited with having developed a 'new science of motion' (Galileo). In our seminar, we will both challenge and support this conviction by analyzing translated original medieval texts about motion. We will begin by focusing on the concept of motion (Sessions 1-2). Session 3 will explore the medieval treatment of motion in terms of space and time, which we will connect in the following session (Session 4) to the geometrical representation of qualities and motions (the 'doctrine of configurations'). In Sessions 5 to 10, we will focus on various problems in Aristotelian dynamics, analyzing causality, the role of the medium, and resistance. This will include discussions of the impetus theory as applied to projectile motion, the acceleration of falling bodies, and the possibility of motion in an empty space. During the final two sessions, we will examine special cases that are both fascinating and characteristic of the late Middle Ages: the debates on the Earth's rotation (Session 11), and a unique chapter on angelology (Session 12). Here, we will explor
03250022.name: Selected Topics in Humanities 2

03250024.about: BIOETHICS IS DEDICATED TO THE PHILOSOPHICAL-ETHICAL STUDY OF ISSUES WITHIN MEDICAL! NURSING AND PARAMEDICAL CARE! RESEARCH ON BIOLOGICAL MATERIALS AND THEIR IMPACT ON ORGANISMS! AND DESIGN OF HEALTH POLICY. THE COURSE FOCUSES ON BIOETHICAL ISSUES RELATING TO HUMAN CARE FROM FERTILIZATION TO END-OF-LIFE! AND PHILOSOPHICAL TEXTS AND CASE LAW IN ISRAEL.
03250024.name: SCIHTEOIB ILEARSI DNA SCIHTE LACIDEM

03260000.about:
during the course we will discuss the following questions: what is a computer, really, what is the internet, how far back in history can we find the antecedents of the technologies we take for granted today, what are the philosophical commitments that led to the development of these technologies, and what can we learn from the long history and history and philosophy of computing about the ethical and political challenges our new technological reality presents us with toda, in this course, we will study both key historicaltexts (from leibniz, pascal, babbage, lovelace, turing and others), as well as contemporary scholarly literature on the philosophy o f artificial intelligence, aiethics and related topics. 
 learning ouctomes:
 at the end of the coure the students:
 1. will learn about the history of computing and information theory, including biologoical and technological antecedents of the internet. 2. will become familiar with texts of foundational figures in it, such as leibniz, pascal, babbage, lovelace and turing. 
 3. we learn on the impact the history of the internet has on its current concerns and dilemmas.
03260000.name: Chpaters in Hitory and Philosophy: from the Early Days of Calcu. to the Internet

03260001.about:
sciences and engineering refer to mechanisms all the time. we talk about synaptic transmission mechanisms, or photoluminescence mechanisms in quantum dots, or docking mechanisms on spacecraft, etc. but what is a mechanism. why are they so useful in explanations. what is the historical background for talking in these terms. learning ouctomes: at the end of the course the student will know:
 1.a more precise understanding of what mechanisms are, in general (the 'ontology' of mechanisms).
 2. an understanding of what makes mechanisms explanatory. 3. broad knowledge of the history of appeal to mechanisms, from the ancient world to today. 4. some understan ding of the limitations of appeal to mechanisms. 5. some knowledge of non-mechanistic approaches to stem.
03260001.name: Sel. Iss. in History and Philosophy of Science on Mechanisms and Their Use

03260002.about:
emerging technologies like ai, the internet of things, and blockchain technology, have an increasingly transformative impact on people and society. in this course, students will be introduced to the different ways to theorize technology, reflect on its ethical impacts, and use practical tools to integrate ethical reflection in day-to-day projects. 
 learning outcomes:
 the students will gain:broader knowledge about the major approaches in normative ethics and philosophy of technology.
 a more precise understanding of contemporary themes in ethics of technology, with a focus on ai ethics and ai principles (e.g., privacy, fairness, explainability) - an understanding of how ethical impacts of emerging technologies play out in practice (e.g., bias in ai systems, conformism in social credit systems) - broad knowledge of approaches in technology ethics to translate- reflection into action, including value sensitivedesign and ethical impact assessment.
 - some ability to apply practical tools in applied ethics (e.g., the ethics canvas) in innovation projects to reflect on and mitigate ethical issues.
03260002.name: ETHICS OF EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES

03260003.about:
the course will survey major conceptions of pain as an example of mind-body conceptualizations from ancient greece to our day. we will present central mind-body conceptions of influential philosophers and physicians from antiquity to our day and will pay particular attention to the way pain is understood within these frameworks.
 learning outcomes:
 students will become familiar with the major conceptions of pain against the context of mind-body relations. 
 - students will become familiar with the historical development of this question as it was conceived by philosophers and physicians. 
 - through the historical survey, stuents will gain a quick int roduction to philosophy and its history. 
 - students will become familiar with contemporary approaches to mind- body relations andthe role pain has within them. 
 - students will gain insight into the complicated relations between medicine and philosophy.
03260003.name: HISTORY OF PAIN BY PHILOSOPHERS

03260004.about:
the course will investigate philosophical questions about the nature of time and space in the light of modern physical theories, from the newton-leibniz debate to the second law of thermodynamics, to special and general relativity.
 learning ouctomes: 
 1. understanding philosophical questions and concepts related to the metaphysics of time and space._
 2. understanding how different physicaltheories have shaped our conceptions of space and time.__
 3. acquiring/improving knowledge about basic concepts in euclidean an non-euclidean geometry, newtonian mechanics, statistical mechanics, and einsteinian relativity._
 4. deeper understanding of the relati oship between experienced reality and the scientific description of reality. 
 5. basic understanding of the mind-body problem, theproblem of free will, and the problem of personal identity.
03260004.name: PHILOSOPHY OF TIME AND SPACE

03260005.about:
the course will explore the history of mathematics and its connection to philosophy through a series of landmark results, from the discovery of incommensurability by the pythagoreans to godel's incompleteness theorem. a recurring theme is how the concept of infinity has challenged the limits of human understanding. 
 learning outcomes:
 1. basic knowledge about the history of mathematics.
 2.basic knowledge about the philosophy of mathematics.
 3. understanding landmark results from the history of mathematic.
 4. understanding how this history has shaped modern mathematics.
 5. a deeper appreciation for mathematics and its role in science, technology,  and philosophy.
 6. reflecting on the nature of truth and knowledge.
03260005.name: MATHEMATICAL THINKING

03260006.about:
despite the extraordinary success of quantum mechanics, debates about the interpretation of the formalism and its various  paradoxes persist to this day. the course will provide a state-of-art introduction to the foundations of quantum mechanics, addressing, in particular, the question, what quantum theories are actually telling us about the world.
 learning ouctcomes:
 1 understanding the fundamental concepts and innovations of quantum mechanics. 
 2. understanding the foundational problems of quantum mechanics, especially the measurement problem and its possible solutions. 
 3. acquiring basic knowlege of main contemporary formulations (interpretaton s) of qm, such as bohmian mechanics, objective collapse theories, and the many-worlds theories that are not part of a standard physics curriculum. 
 4. understanding the physical and philosophical debates about the ontology of quantum mechanics, the meaning of the wave function, and the status of probabilities, thereby developing thee ability to weigh different positions and develop precise arguments. 
 5. understanding key experimental (double-slit, stern-gerlach, eprb) and theoretical (einstein-podolsky-rosen paradox, bell's
03260006.name: QUANTUM THEORY: PHILOSOPHICAL PERSPECTIV

03260008.about:
the course presents a wide variety of classical texts constituting the western tradition of learning, beginning with classical antiquity and progressing through the renaissance. these texts are drawn from various fields and genres, including history, philosophy, autobiography, and epistolary non-fiction. the course will emphasize close reading, critical analysis, and understanding of each text's historical background. the course will deepen our understanding of the main lines of thought that have shaped the western tradition and consider them in relation to changing social, economic, and political circumstances and institutions. the course considers ho w these works have influenced and shaped our present, while it also emphasizes the importance of situating them in their historicalcontext._
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. develop the skills of careful reading of classic texts: to become familiar with classic texts in history, philosophy, and autobiography that shaped the western tradition.
 2.appreciate classical texts and learn to analyze them critically in the future -  to cultivate an appreciation of the body of literature that i
03260008.name: TEXTS IN WESTERN CULTURE: NON-FICTION

03260009.about:
through the comparative study of different cultures, anthropology explores fundamental questions about what it means to be human. the course introduces core anthropological concepts and presents the discipline s distinctive perspective on society and culture. this perspective will be illustrated by examining several important contemporary social and technological issues. the course will include four major topics: 1) fundamental anthropological questions, 2) the definition of culture and cultural theories, 3) canonical topics in anthropological research 4) ethnography, field work and representation. 
 learning outcomes: at the end of the course the stud ents will be able to:
 1. develop analytical, communicative, and critical thinking skill using anthropological knowledge._
 2. be able to ask important anthropological questions.
 3. understand anthropology as a discipline, as well as with its methodologies.
 4. understand how humans construct their worlds.
 5) think critically about social issues and articulate diverse perspectives.
 6) apply anthropological thinking to understand problems (social and technological).
03260009.name: ANTHROPOLOGICAL THEORIES

03280013.about:
the course aims to develop advanced receptive skills essential for reading english academic texts. reading and analyzing academic texts, enriching vocabulary and practicing grammatical structures are stressed. in addition, listening comprehension and english productive skills are enhanced.
learning outcomes: by the end of the course, the students will have attained english proficiency corresponding to the b2 level of the common european framework of reference for languages. they will be able to:
 1. read english academic texts of different genres in various scientific fields and extract main ideas and details across different comprehension levels - bot h explicit and implicit.
 2. understand spoken english in various scientific fields, extract and summarize the main ideas and supporting details across different comprehension levels - both explicit and implicit.
03280013.name: ADVANCED ENGLISH FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS

the course aims to develop advanced receptive and productive skills essential for english academic communication. reading and analyzing academic texts, enriching vocabulary and practicing grammatical structures is complemented by watching and discussing videos. following the learning phase of each of 6 course modules, the students will express their opinion, develop and compare arguments, making use of the acquired skills.
learning outcomes: by the end of the course, the students will have attained english proficiency corresponding to the b2 level of the common european framework of reference for languages. they will be able to:

 2. understand spoken english in various scientific fields, extract and summarize the main ideas and supporting details across different comprehehnsion levels - both explicit and implicit. 
 3. integrate the different information sources into their own presentation, employing their critical thinking. 
 4. express themselves spontaneously, fluently and coherently on scien
03280014.name: ENGLISH ENRICHMENT

the communication course for graduate students aims to improve oral academic and professional communication skills! as required in presentations! meeting management! and intercultural communication. most importantly! the course provides an opportunity for practical exercises! performed individually! in pairs and in teams. moreover! time is allotted for peer and instructor feedback._
 learningoutcomes: at the end of the course the students will be able to:
 1. to produce and present an oral academic presentation with a professional style and academic structure._

 6. to apply! using proper academic style! for graduate studies! internships! and jobs as well as collaborate with otherlabs and universities._
 7. to conduct regular professional communication in a polite and acceptable manner._
 8. to produce texts and s

03280049.about: the structure of an academic article in different research areas. emphasis is put on grammar and typical syntatic issues. the cource includes a weekly two hour general lesson and personal meetings with each student.

03280050.about: An analysis and discussion of the structure of the academic article in various disciplines.  Emphasis is placed on problems in grammar, syntax and cohesion. The course comprises one weekly two-hour meeting and individual tutorials for discussing and analyzing each student's writing.

 2. understand spoken english in various scientific fields, extract and summarize the main ideas and supporting details across different comprehension levels - both explicit and implicit. 3. integrate the different information sources into their own presentations, employing their critical thinking_.
 4. express themselves spontaneously, fluently and coherently on scientifictopics u
